description: Like Oliver Twist, the dance public wants some more. That, at least, appears to be the conclusion drawn by dance companies that will extend their seasons. Some will even repeat the same program nightly for two weeks in a row.

title: Middle East Pact...
description: A halfyear after his failure last March, Secretary of State Kissinger has succeeded in negotiating an IsraeliEgyptianAmerican package aimed at reducing tensions in the Middle East. If the complex of agreements involved is approved and carried out in good faith by all parties, it could be a historic step toward lasting peace in this strategic and volatile region.

title: Estimate of Shortages
description: Following are the estimates by the Municipal Assistance Corporation of the city's cash shortages, month by month, for the rest of the fiscal year. The amounts, in millions of dollars, could change if revenues or expenses are cut from current projectons:

title: People in Sports
description: When Mike Marshall left the mound after warming up for some relief work last Sunday it was for the remainder of the season. The Los Angeles Dodgers' Cy Young Award winner was examined yesterday by the team physician, who found that Marshall had reinjured the rib cartilage in his right side. He had suffered the original injury on April 19.

title: Congress to Debate Oil and the Mideast Upon Return Today
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2Congress will reconvene tomorrow after a monthlong recess and plans to begin deliberations at once on two pressing issues: the Middle East agreement negotiated by the Ford Administration and the price of oil.

title: The American Record
description: Almost everybody seems to have a complaint about American foreign policy these daysoften with good reasonbut the critics have a problem. For no nation in the world, despite Vietnam, has been more generous or imaginative in trying to deal with the intractable problems of the world than the United States, and the Administration's critics have so far put up no better alternative.

title: Notes on People
description: Joseph Woodrow Hatchett was sworn in yesterday as the first black State Supreme Court Justice in the postReconstruction South. Gov. Reubin Askew, who appointed him to the Florida court, was present at the ceremony in Tallahassee. Judge Hatchett, age 42 is a deputy United States Attorney and Federal magistrate. His father was a fruitpicker. His mother, Lula Hatchett, a former domestic worker, said at her son's investiture, I'm so happy that I feel like screaming and crying.

title: $750,000 Theft Here
description: Jade and other objects valued at $750,000 were reported stolen from the East Side home of Paul E. Manheim, an investment banker. Page 40.

title: 5 Schools Struck
description: Lay teachers in five Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens, enrolling 8,000 pupils, voted to go on strike today. Page 34.

title: M.A.C. BOND PRICES TAKE SHARP DROP
Chorus and Ballet Union Strikes at the Met Opera
description: The American Guild of Musical Artists, which represents the Metropolitan Opera's chorus, ballet and solo singers below star rank, struck the opera campany late yesterday. The chorus and ballet were to have reported earlier in the day for first rehearsals.

title: PERU MILITARY PUTS CIVILIAN IN CABINET
description: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 2 (UPI) Peru's military rulers have given a civilian a voice in the Government for the first time in nearly seven years.

title: Article 3  No Title
Monetary Score Card
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2Although this 30th annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank will go on for the rest of the week, for all practical purposes Its work is over. Quite a few finance ministers and central bankers are already packing their bags, and some are heading for airports.

title: Many Jersey Schools Are Facing Strikes
description: Public schools in most sub urbs in the New York metropolitan area are scheduled to reopen today, but in New Jersey the beginning of the academic year is being marred by what state officials say is a prospect of an unusually high number of strikes.

title: Settlements of Most Major Land Areas Around Pacific Put at 30,000 Years Old
description: All major land areas surrounding the Pacific, apart from South America and Antarctica, were settled by man as early as 30,000 years agofar earlier than many archaeologists had supposed  according to reports to the Pacific. Science Congress in Vancouver, British Columbia, last week.

title: Iran Replies Skeptically To U.S. Economic Offers
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 2Iran, stung by United States criticisms of the oilproducing countries, gave a skeptical response in the General Assembly today to Secretary of State Kissinger's new proposals for bridging the economic gap between rich and poor countries.

title: For Crepes, Tout de Suite
description: There's always something new for the kitchen that has everything.

title: Teachers Vote to Strike 5 Catholic Schools Today
description: Lay teachers voted last night to strike today at five Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens. About 8,000 pupils attend the schools operated by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn. Brother Medard Shea, assistant superintendent for teacher personnel of the Brooklyn diocese, said he expected that SO nuns and priests would continue to teach at the schools, which are scheduled to open for the school year today.

title: Illinois Cites 17 New Cases Of St. Louis Encephalitis
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (UPI)The Illinois Department of Public Health reported 17 new cases of St. Louis encephalitis today and said that there were five areas in the stale where the mosquitocarried disease seemed to he centered, but that the major outbreak was in Cook County.

title: BANKS AMENABLE TO M.A.C.'S PLAN; MAYOR RESISTANT
description: The city's major banks committed themselves late yesterday to a $500million part of the Municipal Assistance Corporation's financial plan designed to forestall what could be the city's imminent default.

title: DR. WILLIAM ROGERS, HEART RESEARCHER
description: Dr. William M. Rogers, a heart researcher and professor emeritus of anatomy of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, where he taught for 41 years until his retirement in 1969, died Tuesday at his home in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He was 74 years old.

title: Woodall Is Out for Season
description: The Jets decided yesterday they could not afford the luxury of carrying an injured Al Woodall on their varsity squad for at least a month while the patient understudy to Joe Namath healed an injured knee. So the team placed Woodall on its injured reserve list, an action that immediately put Woodall out of action for the entire season.

title: North Sea Story on Oil Platform : Little Work and Little Production
description: ABOARD TRANSWORLD 58, NORTH SEA, Sept. 2The 56 oilmen working here, aboard a mass of pipes and machinery held above the sea on metal supports are enjoying the luxury of doing nothing.

title: Simon Says U.S. Weighs Action if the City Defaults
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 William E. Simon, Secretary of the Treasury, said today that although officials of the Ford Administration strongly believed in nonintervention in New York City's fiscal crisis, they were studying possible Federal action in the event of a default.

title: Ore Bonanza for an Australian
description: PERTH, Australia, Sept. 1 (AP)I think my enemies wish I would just shut up, take my money and go live in Switzerland or somewhere, chuckles Lang Hancock.

title: Underneath That Sneaker Canvas, a Poetic Soul
description: In French it's called le sneakaire, Karen Leon recited.  In Russian it's sneakotsch. In Japanese it's snikorru. I'm not sure how it's in Dutch?

title: SOVIET OFFERS U.S. RIGHTS CHALLENGE
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 3A prominent Soviet authority on American affairs challenged the United States today to resolve its own social problems rather than to try to put pressure on the Soviet Union on human rights.

title: CHILE GIVES HAVEN TO ECUADOR REBEL
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Sept. 3 (UPI) The foreign ministry said today that the leader of an abortive but bloody military revolt, against the Government of President Guillermo Rodriguez Lara had asked for political asylum in the Chilean Embassy.

title: Amex Prices off
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell slightly in moder ately light trading yesterday In the overthecounter market prices were mixed.

title: House Panel Hears Explanation Of How Tax Shelters Help Rich
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The House Ways and Means Committee heard explanations today of how it is legally possible for a doctor with an income of $105,000 to pay no Federal income tax, for a stockbroker with an income of $181,000 to pay a tax of only $1,000, and for a business executive with $448,000 to pay $1,200.

title: 24,000 Chicago Teachers Strike, Closing 666 Schools
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 3Chicago's public school teachers went on strike today, effectively closing all 666 of the city's elementary and high schools on the day they were to have opened for the new school year. It was the city's fourth teacher walkout in the last six rears.

title: Freshets Are Running
description: WASHINGTONThe political freshets have begun to run: soon, streams of press releases will be coming from various camps and factions, each purporting to represent the mainstream, culminatingnine months from nowin two mighty rivers of conventionneers, flowing vexatiously to the sea.

title: Brokers Fear Default May Start U.S. Ripple
description: Default by New York City on its notes or bonds would probably cost investors across the United States millions of dollars regardless of whether they held securities issued by the city, brokerage officials said yesterday.

title: Laird Says It's Worth the Risk
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3Former Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that stationing American civilians between the Egyptians and Israelis to help keep the peace in the Sinai Desert was worth the risks.

title: CITY ROSTER IS DOWN 19,998 SINCE JAN. 1
description: In the first seven months of this year, the number of fulltime employes on the city payroll decreased by 19,998, Budget Director Melvin N. Lechner said yesterday.

title: PRISONERS REFUSE FOOD AT NEW JAIL
description: About 25 prisoners refused to eat lunch yesterday on the second day of a protest over food at the new Federal jail off Foley Square.

title: BILL WOULD AVOID CONSTRUCTION LAGS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) Labor Secretary John T. Dunlop proposed today legislation to revise collective bargaining in the construction industry by establishing a national labormanagement committee that could impose a cooling off period of up to 30 days in any strike.

title: Albany Bank Bandit Holds 10 Hostages Near Capitol
description: ALBANY, Thursday, Sept. 4 A lone gunman who held up a downtown bank here yesterday, then shot and wounded an Albany policeman in a getaway attempt, continued to hold as many as 10 hostages early today in a sandwich shop less than a block from the holdup scene.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Green Tops Field Today In Georgia
description: COLOMBUS, Ga., Sept. 3 (AP)Golf's superstars have spurned this year's Southern open golf tournament, which opens tomorrow, leaving the chase wide open, although the touring pro, Mac MacLendon, disagrees.

title: Article 1  No Title
Only Lifeline
description: When the waters are rising inexorably inside a foundering ship, captain and crew are in no position to argue about whether they will use the only lifeboat. Confronted with precisely such an emergency, the principals in the desperate lastminute efforts to save the city from default simply cannot afford to reject the latest, and almost certainly the last, Municipal Assistance Corporation rescue package on the grounds that it lacks perfection.

title: Wheat Farmers May Get Direct Access to Market
description: HUTCHINSON, Kan., Sept. 3 (AP)The nation's largest regional grain cooperative announced today a program it said would give wheat farmers direct access to foreign and domestic markets.

title: Senate in Texas Recesses Trial Of Judge Accused of Corruption
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 3  The State Senate voted unanimously today to begin the impeachment trial of Judge O. Carrillo Jr. of the Texas District Court, established a set of guidelines For the trial, and then recessed to allow the Federal Government to try him first on taxevasion charges.

title: In Paris, a Beloved Bistro Closes
description: PARIS, Sept. 3Chez Louis, perhaps this city's coziest late night caferestaurant, was to reopen last night after the annual summer vacation closure. But it didn't. A sign on the door said, Closed because of illness.

title: Party Moderates Bid Ford Soften Conservative Tone
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Moderate Republican members of the Senate told President Ford today that the conservative tone of his candidacy for a full term in the White House could cost him the electoral votes of crucial industrial states next year.

title: WATER SHORTAGE WORSE IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON, Sept. 3Increasing sections of this capital city and parts of nearby Ewing Township began running out of water late tonight after a tight industrial and governmental shutdown and voluntary conservation measures had kept water running, although sometimes at a trickle, all day.

title: House Panel Hears Explanation Of How Tax Shelters Help Rich
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The House Ways and Means Committee heard explanations today of how it is legally possible for a doctor with an income of $105,000 to pay no Federal income tax, for a stockbroker with an income of $181,000 to pay a tax of only $1,000, and for a business executive with $448,000 to pay $1,200.

title: Suffolk D.A. Accused of Sexual Abuse; Calls Charge by Police Head Political
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I. (Sept. 3)Henry F. O'Brien, the Suffolk District Attorney, was charged here today with sexual abuse and misconduct involving a 21yearold unemployed handyman, in papers filed by the County:s Police Commissioner, Eugene R. Kelley.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Retail Sales Gain

title: $12.6Million Settlement Proposed in Pennsy Suits
description: A $12.6million proposed settlement to end litigation against former directors and officers of the Penn Central Company, their investment bankers and accountants and two real estate subsidiaries has been agreed to by lawyers for the plaintiffsthe bankrupt railroad's trustees, debenture holders and shareholders.

title: Books of The Times
description: It was a slow afternoon in the literary detection business. The phone was deader than a call girl's kiss. I'd just finished a small symboltracking job on Ezra Pound's Pisan Cantos for a little jerkwater college upstate, but my appointment calendar looked blanker than an honest politician's bank statement. Nowadays it's all done by computers in the literary detection game anyhow. Not like the nineteenfifties when the New Criticism was riding high and you could pull down big foundation dough for a skiptrace of the whiteness of the whale in MobyDick or running down Eliot's footnotes to The Waste Land.

title: NEW ENGINE TYPE FOR AUTOS URGED
description: Adoption of a billiondollar program to massproduce by 1983 a fuelsaving, pollutionfree replacement for the standard internal combustion auto engine was urged yesterday by a team from a top research center.

title: NEW BEAME CUTS GRIEVE OFFICIALS
description: City Administrators reacted yesterday with dismay, tinged with the kind of fatalistic acceptance that is born of political caution, to Mayor Beame's decision to dismantle all nine of the city's superagencies.

title: Kleppe Reported Ford Choice at Interior
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 President Ford intends to nominate former Representative Thomas S. Kleppe, now head of the Small Business Administration, to be Secretary of the Interior, sources on Capitol Hill and at the Interior Department said today.

title: Via Route 1, or Foreign Policy Rd., to Defense Budget Ave.
description: WASHINGTONThis seems to be a bad year for an assault on the defense budget. Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger has submitted a budget of $105 billion for fiscal year 1976, almost 18 per cent above last year's amount. Before the end of this decade, in the Pentagon's own figures, the defense budget will be $148 billion; by 1085, it will top $200 billion. Even in inflated dollars, we had better take these projections seriously.

title: ISRAELI DEPUTIES BACK SINAI ACCORD
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 3Parliament approved the interim agreement with Egypt tonight by 70 votes to 43, setting the stage for the signing tomorrow in Geneva.

title: Columbia Eleven Heads for Home
description: LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 3  The Columbia football team concluded a weeklong stay at its Camp Columbia training base today with a 90minute intrasquad scrimmage.

title: Gold Price Makes A Slight Advance; Dollar's Value Dips
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 3 (UPI)Gold staged a minor rally today, partially offsetting the $10anounce loss it suffered at the beginning of the week.

title: Screen: A Frothy 'Wilby Conspiracy':Apartheid Is Backdrop for Chase Melodrama
description: "The Wilby Conspiracy" is a sort of light hearted "Defiant Ones," played for a good many laughs as well as for suspense and of course social content in the Union of South Africa. It's about a black political activist (Sidney Poitier) and an apolitical white English businessman (Michael Caine) who become locked together by their need to escape from the Cape Town police.The film, which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, was directed by Ralph Nelson ("Lilies of the Field") and written by Rod Amateau and Harold Nebenzal. For a whileat the beginning when the film is establishing the reasons for the flight and pursuit that make up most of the filmit seems as if "The Wilby Conspiracy" is going to take itself seriously and solemnly as one of the first major American movies to come out firmly against apartheid.It does take itself as seriously as the plot demands but never too solemnly, since 'The Wilby Conspiracy" is, at heart, a good old chase melodrama, decked out in modern dress and in liberated racial attitudes. The best thing about the movie, flimed mostly in Kenya, is its performances, funny and hip and self-assured in the manner of television personalities working in front of loving audiences.Mr. Caine and Mr. Poitier are never unaware that their material may not be the greatest, but that doesn't spoil their good spirits, and when a good line comes along they get maximum results without stomping on it or us.Giving them excellent support, acting, in effect, as straightmen to the two leading comics, are Nicol Williamson, who is brilliantly wicked as the Cape Town security officer dedicated to the capture of the fugitives, and Saeed Jaffrey, who plays what is described as "a deeply committed Indian dentist," who attempts to assist the fugitives in Johannesburg. Mr. Jaffrey is gently, soberly funny, and it's no reflection on him when Mr. Caine says with some skepticism: "A deeply committed Indian dentist? That sounds like all the people I hate at cocktail parties.""The Wilby Conspiracy" has a lot more plot than need be gone into here, some of it involving jet fighters, helicopters and Prunella Gee, as a pretty, liberated white South African lawyer, and Persis Khambatta, as a beautiful, perfidious Indian dental assistant, who, according to this film, should never be trusted with anything more lethal than a cotton swab.

title: DRILLING CUES FOR OIL AND GAS
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 3 (AP)Domestic oil and gas drilling operations have reached their highest level in 12 years as crude oil purchasers awaited the outcome of the Washington debate over price controls.

title: BANKS AMENABLE TO M.A.C.'S PLAN; MAYOR RESISTANT
description: The city's major banks committed themselves late yesterday to a $500million part of the Municipal Assistance Corporation's financial plan designed to forestall what could be the city's imminent default.

title: Illiteracy Among World's Women Rising Steadily
description: PERSEPOLIS, Iran, Sept. 3The number of women who cannot read and write has been growing steadily in recent years and now constitutes almost twothirds of the world's 800 million illiterate adults, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization reported here today.

title: BUTZ OFFERS BILL ON GRAIN CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 3 (UPI) Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz today sent Congress a bill intended to restore integrity to the nation's grain inspection system through tighter Federal controls.

title: DEMOCRATS DELAY OIL PRICE ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 Democratic leaders in the House and Senate have decided to put off further action on oil prices until after the Senate votes next week on whether to override President Ford's expected veto of legislation that would extend price controls on most domestic oil for six months.

title: Advertising
description: The J. Falter Thompson Company is preparing a fourpart television series on the contributions of blacks to American history. It will he pegged to the Bicentennial.

title: COAL STRIKE LEADS TO GRIEVANCE UNIT
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va. Sept 3 (AP)The United Mine Workers of America and the coal industry agreed today to set up a commission to investigate grievance problems that contributed to a threeweekold wildcat walkout by coal miners, according to Arnold Miller, the union president.

title: Having and Having Not
description: FAIR LAWN, N. J.The basic intent of the Great Society programs of the 1960's was to reduce inequality in America. The educator Christopher Jencks in his book Inequality points out this has not been accomplished.

title: Sutton Place Congregation Dedicates New Synagogue
description: Summoned by the cry of a shofar, or ram's horn, members of the Sutton Place Congregation followed a procession of their officers and directors into the new synagogue at 225 East 51st Street yesterday for a service marking the opening of the new facility.

title: BRITISH PAY CURB WINS CRUCIAL TEST
description: LONDON, Sept. 3The Labor Government and its allies in the union movement won a major victory today when the Trades Union Congress voted by a margin of 2 to 1 to approve sharp restrictions on new wage increases.

title: Contract Award
description: Orders worth about $22million for telecommunications equipment and services, designed to upgrade the telephone network in Iran, have been received by the L. M. Ericsson Telephone Company in Stockholm.

title: 'Macon County' and 'McCullochs,' a Double Feature
description: Bonnie and Clyde did not die in vain. Go to a movie set in the thirties or forties or fifties. Let it begin with two or three funny, rebellious and attractive youngsters climbing into a car to conquer the world. It is going to end with the world squatting on them.One of the troubles with "Return to Macon County"besides a mindless plot and its gross imitation of the atmospherics of "American Graffiti"is that no sooner do its young protagonists begin to charm than the viewer begins to wait unhappily to see where the bullet holes will appear.As it turns out the bulletsfired by the customary hate-choked rural policemansmash the car but not the heroes. This spares us the final grisly convention of doomed-youth pictures. It doesn't spare us from sitting through most of the picture waiting for it."Return to Macon County," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, is about two country boys who set out for California with their lovingly supercharged stock-car, determined to become champion racers. They pick up a hash-house waitress, an endearing pumpkin-faced girl played by Robin Mattson, who wants to get to California to be a movie star.Besides being endearing, she is somewhere between fey and mad, and as dangerous as booby-trapped peanut butter. The two young racers think they're reasonably toughthey drag-race for money and sass police carsbut the waitress has the disconcerting habit of pulling out a revolver in moments of stress. "My Daddy gave it to me," she explains to her startled companions. "He says you meet some funny people."The three tangle with some mean-spirited rival dragracers, who improbably get on their trail with shotguns. They also cross a maniac policeman who, even more improbably, takes it upon himself to kill them. In fact he shoots their car full of holes, but it is the shotgun-wielding rivals who are in it at the time.It is a pity about the car. It was boxy, cheerful and vivid yellow and it functioned serviceably, if unoriginally, as a symbol of youth and hopefulness. It is one of the curious things about movies, in fact, that the yellowness of the car should serve to shore up this picture's frail virtues. A color itself can have an emotional value; as it does when the waitress tries on an old hat, and its yellow arouses the same brash hopefulness already flaunted in the canary car.Both the young men, played by Nick Nolte and Don Johnson, are very good. Mr. Nolte, in particular, conveys exuberance, a reasonable but not excessive violence, and vulnerability.Robin Mattson is the picture's strongest asset, however. Her half-innocent explosiveness is skilfully conveyed: at first it captivates her partners, and finally it is too much for them. She has some wonderful moments: one of the best, when in the middle of fantasizing about the future with Mr. Nolte she looks at him, takes in his boyish good looks, says matter-of-factly: "You're going to lose," and resumes the fantasy.On the same double bill is a terrible picture called "The Wild McCullochs." A mawkish revival of nineteen-fifties melodrama, it tells about a rich father, a two-fisted, self-made man, who gives his children lots of nice clothes and opportunities but doesn't understand them. There is a great deal of weeping, a long, boring and lovable fistfight, and a family priest who wears a red wig and the kind of quaintness that was prohibited by Vatican Council II.

title: Penn Fruit Bankruptcy Step Is Taken Under Chapter XI
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (UPI)  The Penn Fruit Company, the large supermarket operator, filed a petition today to reorganize under chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Space Agency Asks Proposals For Tests on Flight to Uranus
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 3 (UPI)The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has invited scientists from around the world to propose experiments for a possible 1979 space mission to Uranus, the mysterious seventh planet out from the Sun.

title: 2 MEN WOUNDED IN SHOOTOUT HERE
description: A gun battle between two policemen and two suspects sent motorists and pedestrians rushing for shelter ?? at the intersection of Atlantic and Franklin Avenues in ?? heart of the BedfordStuyvesant district of Brooklyn.

title: Feeding Children
description: The conference report on the Child Nutrition Bill of 1975 has not yet been approved by Congress, but the Office of Management and Budget has already indicated that a veto is likely because the Administration considers the bill too expensive. A confrontation between White House and Congress on this issue would be unfortunate in the light of the significant improvement the bill would effect in Federal food programs for the children of the poor, nearpoor and working poor. With a little Congressional foresight, such a showdown can probably be avoided.

title: 11 MORE FOOD PLACES CITED AS VIOLATORS
description: The Health Department has cited 11 more food businesses for failing their second Health Code inspection and has warned that they face closing orders if the violations persist upon a third and final inspec tion.

title: Coleman Links White Flight To Ordered Desegregation
description: BOSTON, Sept. 3 (AP) James S. Coleman, the sociologist, says white flight from cities where courts have ordered school desegregation is 14 per cent greater than normal.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Publisher Completes Bid To Buy Washington Star
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The financially troubled Washington Star won a new lease on life today when its publisher, Joe L. Allbritton, completed an agreement to buy full control of the newspaper's parent company for $28.5million.

title: Woman Arraigned In Nutley on Charge Of Killing Daughter
description: NUTLEY, Sept. 3At an arraignment before a local magistrate, Marie Horst was ordered held without bail for the grand jury today on a charge of murdering her 4yearold daughter in their apartment last week.

title: SOME IN CONGRESS FEAR SINAI ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 Some leading members of Congress of both parties today expressed reservations about the EgyptianIsraeli peace accord with a few stating that the deployment of Americans in Sinai would be reminiscent of the early involvement of the United States in Vietnam.

title: Avatar, 35, Wins Sprint At Belmont
description: Avatar, the winner of the Belmont Stakes, making his first start since running out of the money in the Swaps Stakes at Hollywood Park June 29, took the $20,000 Jamestown Purse yesterday at Belmont Park and shared the spotlight with Picture Tube, who came through on the rail to capture the $38.900 Astarita Stakes for 2yearold fillies.

title: Judgment at Petaluma
description: Has a community the right to set limits on its own growth? A Federal Appeals court in California has ruled that the city of Petaluma has that right, overturning the decision of a lower court that had just as emphatically ruled to the contrary. The difference between the two opinions points up a controversy that has now divided courts from one end of the country to the otherand major segments of the population as well.

title: American General Insurance Is Given Divestiture Order
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) A Federal Trade Commission judge ruled today that the 1969 merger of two insurance companies in the fidelity and surety bond markets might substantially lessen competition.

title: Amex Continues Expansion Of its U.S. OddLot Trading
description: The American Stock Exchange, in a major expansion of oddlot trading in Government securities, said yesterday tha tit would add 14 issues on Sept. 5 and 16 more on Sept. 12 for a total of 71 issues. It added 14 on Aug. 29.

title: Membership in Klan Barred to Employes Of Prisons in State
description: ALBANY, Sept. 3 (AP)The State Correctional Services Commissioner today issued what he called a landmark directive, prohibiting employes of the prison system from belonging to the Ku Klux Klan.

title: WATER SHORTAGE WORSE IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON, Sept. 3Increasing sections of this capital city and parts of nearby Ewing Township began running out of water late tonight after a tight industrial and governmental shutdown and voluntary conservation measures had kept water running, although sometimes at a trickle, all day.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1975

title: People in Sports
description: The Baltimore Hustlers, formerly, the bankrupt Memphis Sounds, of the American Basketball Association have retained their old coach, Joe Mullaney, but their new name has to go.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In Tuesday's New York Times it was incorrectly reported that a New Jersey state grand jury had subpoenaed the records of the Elizabeth Nursing Home in Elizabeth. N. J. The grand jury subpoenaed the records of Elizabeth N. H., Inc., which operated the Wedgewood Nursing Home in Elizabeth.

title: ExJudge J. Howard Rossbach Of Criminal Court Dies at 61
description: Former Criminal Court Judge J. Howard Rossbach, a longtime advocate of court reform and improvement in court procedures, died of cancer last evening at General Hospital, Saranac Lake, N.Y. He was 61 years old and lived at 5040 Arlington Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx and at Lake Kiwassa, near Saranac Lake Village.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The National Football League commissioner, Pete Rozelle, presented a $10,000 check on behalf of the N.F.L. to the United Way of America charity yesterday to start the fall fundraising drive. The presentation was made as the charity previewed a series of publicservice broadcasting spots done by N.F.L. players supporting the United Way campaign.

title: Frustrated Teachers Fearful of Strike
description: The deep blue September sky and crisp autumn air yesterday were sharp reminders that school days were not far off. But the grim question that faced thousands of teachers who reported for their first day of work was just how far off those school days might actually be.

title: Aeroflot Crewman Is Fatally Wounded On Flight to Britain
description: LONDON, Sept. 3A soviet jet liner from New York landed at Heathrow Airport this morning with the body of a man, shot through the head, slumped in a seat in the firstclass cornpartment.

title: Gilliam, ExViking, ExWind, Seeks a Return to N.F.L.
description: John Gilliam, Fran Tarkenton's onetime favorite receiver with the Minnesota Vikings, has found himself without a team in the World Football League and wants to jump back to the National League. The Chicago Winds, Gilliam's W.F.L. club folded on Tuesday and Gilliam, leading the league with 20 pass receptions, was assigned to the Philadelphia Bell.

title: U.S. judge Enjoins California From Enforcing Rule Giving Union Aides Access to Farms
description: FRESNO, Calif., Sept. 3Federal District Judge M. D. Crocker issued today a temporary restraining order here enjoining the state's Agricultural Labor Relations Board from enforcing a controversial ruleenacted last weekthat allows union organizers access to growers' land to talk to workers about representation elections.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Connecticut's Commission on Hospitals and Health care has approved budget increases averaging 9.6 per cent and totaling $686.7million for the state's 35 general hospitals. This was $8.8million less than the hospitals had proposed. The commission has also approved $18.6million in capital projects or $6.6million less than the hospitals had requested.

title: African Militant Sees War as Rhodesia Solution
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 3The Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole, the exiled Rhodesian African nationalist, said in a radio broadcast here today that the 10 year Rhodesian constitutional crisis could he resolved only through fullscale guerrilla war.

title: U.S. Wary of Refugees on Guam Who Seek Repatriation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The Ford Administration has become increasingly concerned about 1,802 South Vietnamese seeking to return to their homeland from temporary quarters on Guam.

title: $8.5Million Sought From Army in 1953 Drug Death
description: A New York woman announced yesterday that she had Filed a claim against the Army for $8.5million for the wrongful death of her father, Harold Blauer, in an experiment with a hallucinogenic drug 22 years ago.

title: Personal Finance: Women's Policies
description: For several decades, many insurers have sold whole life or term insurance policies to women at annual rates that were less than the amount charged to men of the same age for a policy of equal face value.

title: Opening Day Eases Impact of Catholic Schools Strike
description: Lay unionized teachers went on strike yesterday at five Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens but because yesterday was the first day of school, traditionally a time for orientation and course registration, the strike's impact was limited.

title: Rizzo Backed by Arch Foe In Philadelphia Mayor's Race
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (AP) The city Democratic Committee's chairman, Pat Camiel, whose threeyear feud with Mayor Frank Rizzo threatened to shatter the party, announced today that he would support Mr. Rizzo's reelection bid in November.

title: Retailers' August Gain Was'75's Best
description: Retail sales in New York City made their best gains of 1975 in August, showing the largest monthly improvement over the previous year since September, 1974. However, the increases did not equal the inflation rate.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: West Germans Triumph VIENNA. Sept. 3 (UPI)West Germany, the world cup soccer champion, defeated Austria, 20, in an exhibition match today.

title: Brokers Fear Default May Start U.S. Ripple
description: Default by New York City on its notes or bonds would probably cost investors across the United States millions of dollars regardless of whether they held securities issued by the city, brokerage officials said yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, Sept. 3 (Reuters)The Ford Motor Company wrote dealers last week that they could presell 1976 model trucks at price increases ranging from 6 to 9 per cent above corresponding 1975 models. A 6 per cent increase was listed for conventional light trucks and Bronco utility vehicles, and a 9 per cent increase for Econoline vans and club wagons. Medium, heavy and extraheavyduty truck prices are being raised 7 per cent, Ford said.

title: F.B.I. Joins Police Hunt In $750.000 Art Theft
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation joined the city police yesterday in a hunt for the thieves who stole more than $750,000 worth of art objects over the Labor Day weekend from the East Side apartment of Paul E. Manheim, an investment banker.

title: SOVIET SAYS IT LED IN DEFEATING JAPAN
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3The Soviet Union, which lavished praise upon itself last spring on the 30th anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany, is now taking credit as well for the defeat of imperial Japan.

title: HOFFA CASE FIGURE REPORTED SILENT
description: DETROIT, Sept. 3Charles L. J. O'Brien, the foster son of James R. Hoffa, refused to answer questions in a sevenminute appearance today before the grand jury investigating the disappearance of Mr. Hoffa, according to Mr. O'Brien's lawyer.

title: Guerrillas in Argentina Kill Police Officer and Soldier
description: LA PLATA, Argentina, Sept. 3 (Reuters)Leftwing urban guerrillas today shot and killed a provincial police officer and an army sergeant in separate incidents in this provincial capital.

title: Stabilized Construction
description: The construction industry collective bargaining bill proposed yesterday by Secretary of Labor Danlop, with strong labormanagement backing, represents a sophisticated substitute for antiinflation controls, a nono in the Ford Administration.

title: REUNION WITH NORTH STRESSED IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 3 (Agence FrancePresse) South Vietnam kept the emphasis on unification with the North as it wound up celebrations of National Day with a banquet here last night.

title: ARMY IN PORTUGAL INSISTS PRESIDENT RULE OUT PRORED
description: LISBON, Sept. 3The general assembly of Portugal's army demanded today that the President cancel his appointment of Gen. Vasco Gonalves, the Communistbacked former Premier, as chief of staff of the armed forces.

title: Suffolk D.A., Cited, Calls Sex Case Charge Political
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 3 Henry F. O'Brien, the Suffolk District Attorney, was charged here today with sexual abuse and misconduct involving a 21yearold unemployed handyman, in papers filed by the County's Police Commissioner, Eugene R. Kelley.

title: Notes on People
description: The Senate was up to its full complement of 100 but Senator Norris Cotton was down to zero seniority as the 75yearold veteran of 20 earlier years was sworn in by Vice President Rockefeller yesterday for a probable twoweek term. The New Hampshire Republican, who retired in January, was appointed by Gov. Meidrim Thomson after the 99member Senate was unable to decide whether the November election to succeed Senator Cotton was won by John A. Durkin, the Democratic candidate, or Louis C. Wyman, the Republican. A new election will be held Sept. 16.

title: School Openings Marred By Walkouts in 3 States
description: An estimated total of 40,000 students throughout New York State attended the first day of the school year yesterday in classes held by substitute teachers, supervisors and parents as union teachers went on strike in contract disputes.

title: Remember the House That Blandings Built? There's an Epilogue
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn.With the farmhouse and the tree, Eric Hodgins began his wry, amusing novel, Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House, published in 1946. In it, he described the hilarious tribulations of a pair of citybred innocents building their first country house.

title: OFFERING OF STOCK AGAIN SET BY A.T.&T
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday its previously announced public offering of 12 million common shares to be marketed about Oct. 1.

title: Bell Offers to Trade Rise In Rates for a Wage Curb
description: NEWARK, Sept. 3 (AP)New Jersey Bell offered today to forgo an automatic rate increase next January and guaranteed not to lay off any operators if the state Board of Public Utility Commissioners dropped a demand for a 4 per cent productivity increase.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: Hunting in a state other than one's own has gradually become a rather expensive proposition.

title: Janet Bogardus, Librarian With Federal Reserve Here
description: Janet Bogardus, chief librarian of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York from 1954 until her retirement in 1969, died yesterday, apparently of emphysema, at a hospital in Austin, Tex., where she lived. She was 71 years old.

title: Study Is Scheduled On North Sea Costs
description: LONDON, Sept. 3.(Reuters) Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. said today that; in association with the W. S. Atkins Groupiit was awarded a contract by the Department of Energy to undertake a study of the escalation in costs of exploitation, of oil and gas from the North Sea.

title: At Trenton, Boil Before Drinking
description: TRENTON, Sept. 13Public and parochial schools were closed. So were laundromats and car washes, along with other businesses that need a lot of water. The state government was running with skeleton staffs. Do Not Drink This Water signs were at drinking fountains in one hospital.

title: Court Curbs N. C. A. A. on Football Cut
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Sept. 3 (UPI)A Federal judge ruled tonight that the National Collegiate Athletic Association does not have the right to restrict the size of football squads traveling to games away from their school.

title: KISSINGER MISSION TO MIDEAST ENDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Secretary of State Kissinger wound up his successful Middle East mediation mission and returned home tonight after assuring Jordan and Syria that the United States would seek further ArabIsraeli accords beyond the Sinai agreement between Egypt and Israel.

title: RECORDS ON HISS RELEASED BY F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation's records of its Alger Hiss investigation show its agents often were at a disadvantage in gathering evidence because a Congressional committee got it first.

title: Packard  San, the Persistent Collector
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3To his admirers, Harry Packard, who sold his extensive collection of Japanese art to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York for $5.1million last week, is an intense, dedicated and discriminating collector.

title: Bridge
description: Silent bidding may eventually be the rule in New York tournaments. The Swedish bidding boxes, used in two regional knockout team championships here during the summer, proved popular with almost all the comnetitors.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Retail Sales Gain

title: BEAM TO SELL SNORTTERM BILLS
description: The Treasury Department yesterday announced that it would auction today up to $1.5billion of shortterm bills to help meet its financing requirements during the early part of this month. The offering, similar to one made last month, will consist of 13day bills totaling $800million and 20day bills totaling $700million. The bills, which the Treasury described as cash management instruments, will be auctioned only through the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for payment on Friday.

title: Informs Congress It Will Open Hearings Oct. 1 on Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that current rules prohibiting securities sales outside the major stock exchanges were an impediment to free competition.

title: Needham Says Rule Is Cornerstone of Auction Market
description: James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, in a strong defense of its present method of operations, declared here yesterday that the Big Board's controversial Rule 394  now the subject of Government scrutiny was the acknowledged cornerstone of the exchange auctionmarket system.

title: Marshall Kay of Columbia Dies; Proponent of LandDrift Theory
description: Dr. Marshall Kay, Newberry Professor Emeritus of Geology at Columbia University and one of the country's most influential geologists, died yesterday in Englewood Hospital, Englewood, N. J. He, was 70 years old and lived at 175 Glenwood Avenue, Leonia, N. J.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Four galleries prominent in the contemporary art scene were damaged by flooding Monday night in Jamaica House, at 29 West 57th Street, in the heart of the 57th Street gallery district. Art works stored in the Arras Gallery and the Fischbach Gallery were damaged, and together with the Rosa Esman and Zabriskie galleries, they all suffered office damage.

title: Dancers, New Troupe, Richly Talented
description: There were plenty of wellwishers on hand for the local debut Tuesday night at the City Center Downstairs of Dennis Wayne's new company, Dancers.

title: BENTSEN ATTACKS FORD ON ECONOMICS
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, charged yesterday that under President Ford this country's response to international economic problems was confused, ambiguous and lacking in the strength and coherence that befit a world power.

title: Files of 2 Virginia Banks Called For in Nursing Inquiry
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Sept 3 (AP)  Records of transactions of two banks here have been subpoenaed in a grand jury investigation of pratices of New York City nursing homes

title: Mathews Says H.E.W. Plans to Ignore Rule on Cutting State Medicaid Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3F. David Mathews, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, has told Congress that, for the time being, he is refusing to enforce a law requiring him to reduce Federal Medicaid assistance to sates that do not adequately control their nursing homes and other medical care.

title: DEAL IS OPPOSED BY COPPERWELD
description: The board of directors of the Copperweld Corporation said yesterday that the $111million offer of Sociad lmetal of Paris to purchase ail of Copperweld's common shares at $42.50 a share and more than $4million in 5 per cent debentures was clearly inadequate and the company would strongly recommend that its shareholders reject the offer.

title: TEACHERS' TALKS NEAR A DEADLOCK
description: Teacher contract talks were at a near deadlock as the city's layoffdepleted teaching staff returned to school yesterday to prepare for the scheduled start of the fall term on Monday and, possibly, a teachers' strike, on Tuesday.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Waters From Hurricane Receding in Texas Town
description: RAYMONDVILLE, Tex., Sept. 3 (UPI)  Floodwaters from a hurricane that inundated most of the city receded six inches today, but officials feared that new rains from the Rio Grande Valley would affect displaced home and business owners.

title: The Grass Is Always Greener
description: In tennis the word pushers is uttered with the same despicable tone that narcotics agents use. with

title: Celanese Price Increase On Chemicals Set for Oct. 1
description: The Celanese Chemical Company announced yesterday a price increase ranging from one cent to two cents a pound on several of its organic chemicals, effective Oct. 1. Vinyl acetate has been increased 2 cents a pound, acetic acid 1 cent, actic anhydride 1 cent, acetaldehyde 1 cent and butyl acetate 1 cent. Celanese also raised the price of propyl acetate and propanol by 2 cents a pound and diacetone alcohol by 2.5 cents a pound.

title: POOR LANDS HEAR ASSURANCE IN U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 3Britain. Sweden and Canada sought to assure the developing countries today that their demands for more equitable sharing of the world's resources were evoking concrete responses from the richer countries.

title: New Peru Leadership to Allow Deported Politicians to Return
description: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 3 (AP)Political exiles may return to Peru and news organizations closed by the former government have received permission to reopen under a decree issued by the new military rulers.

title: Center in RCA Building to Draw On Sun for Heating and Cooling
description: Construction will begin this month on a $6million con??erance center atop a 12thfloor setback on the 70story RCA Building in Rockefeller Center that will afford the first pracrical application in the city of solar energy for heating and cooling.

title: 12 Fail to Comply in Inquiry On Weapons in Courtroom
description: Twelve spectators ordered to comply with a subpoena to testify before a grand jury investigating the smuggling of weapons and explosives into a courthouse where three members of the Black Liberation Army were sentenced for murder failed to appear yesterday.

title: Sirhan Brother Arrested
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 (AP) The elder brother of Sirhan B. Sirhan, the convicted slayer of Robert P. Kennedy, has been hooked for investigation of drunken driving, a police spokesman reported today. The police said that the elder Sirhan, wh osnelled his first name alternately as Sherref and Sharif, was driving a car that collided with a parked Vehicle, causing about $600 damage.

title: 2 Killed as Guerrillas Attack A Police Unit in Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Thursday, Sept. 4 (Reuters)Communist guerrillas throw four hand grenades into the headquarters of a paramilitary police unit here yesterday, killing two policemen and wounding 52, several of them seriously.

title: SOVIET DEFENSIVE ON CRISIS IN LISBON
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3With the recent erosion of Communist strength in Portugal, the Soviet press has turned decidedly defensive and pessimistic on the subject, in what some Western diplomats see as a possible attempt to prepare the Soviet peonle for a setback there.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Wednesday.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: $12.6Million Settlement Proposed in Pennsy Suits
description: A $12.6million proposeal settlement to end litigation, against former directors and officers of the Penn Central Company, their investment bankers and accountants and two real estate subsidiaries has been agreed to by lawyers for the plaintiffsthe bankrupt railroad's trustees, debenture holders and shareholders.

title: Advice Now in Trenton Is Boil Before Drinking
description: TRENTON, Sept. 3Public and parochial schools were closed. So were Laundromats and car washes, along with other businesses that need a lot of water. The state government was running with skeleton staffs. Do Not Drink This Water signs were at drinking fountains in one hospital.

title: The Weather Here Last Month
U.S. LEASING TALKS WITH PITNEY BOWES
description: Pitney Bowes announced yesterday that it was holding preliminary discussions with United States Leasing International regarding the possibility of Pitney Bowes developing its own equipmentleasing capability.

title: Downstate Seeks a Share of Bond Funds
description: CHERRY HILL, Sept. 3A group of southern New Jersey legislators, representing both parties and hoping to swell their ranks to ninecounty representation, said today that they planned to tell Governor Byrne tomorrow that they would oppose his proposed bond issue unless their areas received a muchlarger share of the money from the bonds.

title: TWO U.S. CONCERNS ADDED TO ARAB LIST
description: CAIRO, Sept. 3 (Reuters) The Arab League's boycott committee added 14 companies to its blacklist today, including Rockwell and General Telephone and Electronics of the United States but lifted its ban on 19 other companies.

title: KISSINGER MISSION TO MIDEAST ENDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Secretary of State Kissinger wound up his successful Middle East mediation mission and returned home tonight after assuring Jordan and Syria that the United States would seek further ArabIsraeli accords beyond the Sinai agreement between Egypt and Israel.

title: Networks Shift Schedules in Battle for Audiences
description: When CBSTV scheduled a twohour preview of Beacon Hill on Aug. 25, hoping to capitalize on the lean competition of summer reruns, ABCTV responded by pitting against it a repeat showing of The Legend of Lizzie Borden, a movie made for television exploiting the ax murder case that took place in Fall River, Mass., around the turn of the century.

title: 2.5% Drop in Traffic on Bridges Is Attributed to New Tolls Here
description: The new toll increases at seven bridges and two tunnels here caused only a 2.5 per cent drop in motor traffic compared with last year's first day after Labor Day, the Trihorough Bridge and Tunnel Authority reported yesterday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two hundred Atlantic County welfare Workers went on strike yesterday in a contract dispute. Local 2302 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes said the employes had been without a contract since last July.

title: Big city Problems In Big Sky Country
description: BILLINGS, Mont.His city was on the brink of a teachers' strike. An apparent shortfall in the budget led the city fathers to believe they might have to lay off more than 12 per cent of the municipal employes. A crisis over funding threatened to shut the public library.

title: Party Moderates Bid Ford Soften Conservative Tone
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Moderate Republican members of the Senate told President Ford today that the conservative tone of his candidacy for a full term in the White House could cost him the electoral votes of crucial industrial states next year.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SWINGTIME All of the sounds on Morningside Heights these days are not from enthusiastic frosh registering on the Barnard and Columbia campuses. Some sounds come every night from the West End, a longtime campus foodanddrink haunt that has for some time now installed a variety of groups playing contemporary American music.

title: MOOREMACK PLANS VOTE ON STOCK SPLIT
description: Moore McCormack Resources, Inc., announced yesterday that it will hold a special meeting in early November to enable shareholders to approve a 2for1 stock split that the board has authorized. The Mooremack board also authorized a dual stock certificate system and related provisions designed to in. sure compliance with citizenship requirements of United States maritime law, and an agreement to terminate the company's obligation under its share unit plan, which provides for incentive compensation to key executives.

title: Nastase Is Fined $8,000 for Outburst
description: The Joint Professional Tennis Council fined Ilie Nastase $8,000 yesterday for conduct detrimental to the game during the recent Canadian open championships.

title: U.N. Debate: Groping for New Relationships
description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., Sept. 3The United Nations seems destined to become the principal arena where the United States and the other industrial powers grope for a new relationship with the countries that describe themselves as nonaligned. Most of these countries are poor, some desperately so, and a few are newly rich through the windfall of enormous earnings from oil. But their mood is similara deepseated feeling of grave injustice that 70 per cent of mankind has to get along on 30 per cent of the world's income.

title: Fire at Blacks' Rosedale Home Is Termed Definitely Arson
description: The city Fire Marshal's office said yesterday that an arsonist set fire last Saturday to a house containing the furniture and effects of a black family moving into the Rosedale section of Oueens.

title: Kleppe Reported Ford Choice at Interior
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 President Ford intends to nominate former Representative Thomas S. Kleppe, now head of the Small Business Administration, to be Secretary of the Interior, sources on Capitol Hill and at the Interior Department said today.

title: Market Place
description: Ricardo Cortez, a senior market analyst at Merrill Lynch, has just studied the stock market's momentum of the last 103 years and has reached some optimistic conclusions.

title: Dentist Commutes To Show His Dogs
description: I'm a commuter, said Dr. Jerry Roseff. I commute between my home in Lakewood [N.J.] to Canada in order to show my Cavalier King Charles spaniels.

title: Heinz Earnings Up As Sales Increase
Article 6  No Title
Red Sox, on Homer, Beat Orioles in 10th
description: Cecil Cooper led off the 10th inning with a home run off Baltimore's pitching ace, Jim Palmer, to give the Boston Red Sox a 32 victory over the Orioles last night in Baltimore. The triumph increased Boston's lead in the American League's East Division to seven games over the second= place Orioles.

title: Grim Traded To Bears
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y. Sept. 3  The New York Giants sent Bob Grim, a wide receiver, and an undisclosed draft choice to the Chicago Bears today in exchange for a secondyear defensive lineman, Dave Gallagher.

title: Legislative Leaders Meet Carey on City Fiscal Plan
description: ALBANY, Sept. 3  Governor Carey went into private meetings with the Democratic aild Republican legislative leaders tonight, indicating that the initial proposal for the fiscal restructuring of New York was oven to negotiation.

title: SYRIA DENOUNCES ACCORD ON SINA
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 3 (UPI)Syria, Egypt's main ally in the 1973 Middle East war against Israel, denounced the EgyptianIsraeli interim agreement in Sinai today as a setback to the march of Arab struggle.

title: ARMY IN PORTUGAL INSISTS PRESIDENT RULE OUT PRORED
description: LISBON, Sept. 3The general assembly of Portugal's army demanded today that the President cancel his appointment of Gen. Vasco Goncalves, the Communistbacked former Premier, as chief of staff of the armed forces.

title: Dance: Treasures of 40's
description: Halfway through its short run the New York Dance Festival has already restored three treasures from the modern  dance repertory, which stands as a record for responsibility. On Tuesday evening Sophie Maslow's rollicking Folksay received its lust local performance in years and May O'Donnell's serene Suspension was shown to the capacity audience at the Delacorte Theater. Previously, Lester Norton's sinister Salom had been presented.

title: Many Ages of Literature In Children's Display Here
description: Some tots have a devouring passion for literature, and others are content merely to rio or chew.

title: Malaysian Land Plan Thriving, but Snags Arise
description: SUNGEI DUSUN, Malaysia Hadji Hasmuni bin Johari owns 10 acres of land with a fiveroom wooden house. He supports a wife and eight children and has just returned from a pilgrimage to Mecca. Last year he earned more than $700 a month, 10 times what he was earning seven years ago.

title: Energy Agency Seeks to Expand '74'75 Price Audits
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 Even though oil price controls have expired and revival by Congress is in doubt, the Federal Energy Administration wants to increase the number of people checking for pricing violations that may have occurred in 197475.

title: Review of Bail Process in Crimes Of Violence Is Asked by Hughes
description: CHERRY HILL, Sept. 3 (AP)  Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes called today for a careful look at bail procedures in cases of violent crime.

title: PLIGHT LAMENTED BY POOR NATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3As such poor nations Bangladesh, Egypt and Zaire lamented today, though not in strident terms, their worsened plight in the current state of the world's economy.

title: Mrs. Ford Flies Here For an Award Dinner
description: Betty Ford came to New York City yesterday for what she described as a very emotional evening to present a humanitarian award to a very old, dear friend, Milton H. Hoffman.

title: CHICAGO ENSEMBLE PLAYS VARIED MUSIC
description: The name of the Art Ensemble of Chicago may not suggest that it is a jazz group, and quite a bit of its performance at the Five Spot, Third Avenue at St. Marks Place, does not conform with what one might normally expect of a jazz group.

title: Slayers Win Parole Right
description: BOSTON, Sept. 3 (AP)Two convicted murderers whose lives were spared in 1957 on the ground that they would never be released won the right to parole from the Executive Council today. Arthur L. Devlin and Russell LeBlanc could be paroled in a year. They were convicted and sentenced to die for the murder of Merrill Lovingr, a young attorney in 1955.

title: SIR JOHN NEALE, 84, HISTORIAN, IS DEAD
description: LONDON, Sept. 3Sir John Neale, the distinguished historian whose specialty was the age of Queen Elizabeth I, died last evening. He was 84 years old.

title: The Proceedings in the U.N. Today
U.S. Again Seeks To Sell Jordanians Missile Batteries
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The Administration resubmitted to Congress today a notice of its intention to sell Jordan 14 batteries of Hawk groundtoair missiles.

title: Prices of Stocks Advance After Late Buying Surge
description: A surge of buying swept into the stock market late yesterday, pushing share prices higher on rising volume amid mounting speculation that the summer decline had ended prior to the Labor Day weekend.

title: Books of The Times
description: It was a slow afternoon in the literary detection business. The phone was deader than a call girl's kiss. I'd just finished a small symboltracking job on Ezra Pound's Pisan Cantos for a little jerkwater college upstate, but my appointment calendar looked blanker than an honest politician's bank statement. Nowadays it's all done by computers in the literary detection game anyhow. Not like the nineteenfifties when the New Criticism was riding high and you could pull down big foundation dough for a skiptrace of the whiteness of the whale in MobyDick or running down Eliot's footnotes to The Waste Land.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1975

title: DEMOCRATS DELAY OIL PRICE ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 Democratic leaders in the House and Senate have decided to put off further action on oil prices until after the Senate votes next week on whether to override President Ford's expected veto of legislation that would extend price controll on most domestic oil tog six months.

title: Portuguese Timor's War: Untreated Wounded, P.O.W. Beatings
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 3  It was 7 A.M. on Aug. 29 when our 100foot trawler nosed up cautiously to the reef marking the entrance to the harbor of Dili, the capital of Portuguese Timor.

title: ANTIBUSING RIDER KILLED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) The Senate voted today to kill an antibusing amendment that would have prohibited the Justice Department from asking for busing, school closings or involuntary student transfers as desegregation tools.

title: One Dead and Two Missing In Crash of Air Force B52
description: AIKEN, S. C. Thursday Sept. 4 (UPI)An Air Force B52 exploded in flight and crashed about 20 miles from the Savannah River Atomic Plant yesterday. One crewman was killed, two others were missing and four were injured in the crash.

title: AntiLeft in Portugal
description: With the commanders of Portugal's Army and Air Force in open revolt against the appointment of proCommunist Gen. Vasco Gonalves as chief of staff of the armed forces, it is obvious that a showdown in Lisbon cannot be long postponed. President Costa Gomes must realize by now that his attempt to sidestep an agonizing decision by shifting General Gonalves from the premiership to the top military post is totally unacceptable to the vast majority of Portuguese in and out of uniform.

title: Many Ages of Literature In Children's Display Here
description: Some tots have a devouring passion for literature, and others are content merely to rip or chew.

title: Pirates Triumph, 3 to 1; Mets Trail by 6 Games
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates won the deciding game of their critical series with the Mets last night, 31, when Jerry Reuss bested Jon Matlack and the Mets Cropped six games out of first place in the National League East with 24 to go.

title: Chess
description: If you are on the receiving end of your opponent's unpleasant tactical surprise; what do you do? A long moment of startled anger is surely forgivable. Besides, most competitive temperaments find it impossible to avoid. But what comes after that?

title: City Needs $100 Million For Tomorrow's Debts
description: Unless the city raises $100million by tomorrow, Controller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday, a $7.1million payroll for sanitationmen will not be met and $4.5million in welfare checks that will be mailed today to recipients in 35,884 cases will be in jeopardy.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: School Buses Crash,14 Hurt

title: Futures in Gold Rise by $1 an Ounce
description: Goldfutures prices maven up Si or so an ounce yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here, following a sharp decline of $10 on Tuesday. Sliver prices also rose.

title: Legion Post Destroyed By Fire in Park Slope
description: A twostory building in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn housing the Michael A. Lawley American Legion Post was destroyed last evening by a fire caused by an explosion of undetermined nature, according to the police.

title: VIOLENT EPISODES PLAGUE LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 3Outbreaks of violence around the country and a vicious running feud in a resort town east of here have once again raised tensions throughout Lebanon.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In Tuesday's New York Times it was incorrectly reported that a New Jersey state grand jury had subpoenaed the records of the Elizabeth Nursing Home in Elizabeth, N. J. The grand jury subpoenaed the records of Elizabeth N. H., Inc., which operated the Wedgewood Nursing Home in Elizabeth.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit Attacks Lulus for 163 Legislators
description: A citizens' group filed suit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday to require that 163 legislators who had voted themselves $875,800 in luluspayments in lieu of expensesreturn the money to the state.

description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900: WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNIIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691803; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Fighting in Ethiopia Reported on Rise; Toll Putin Hundreds
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 3 (UPI)African diplomats said today that renewed fighting in northern Ethiopia between Government troops and separatists had taken hundreds of lives and generated fears of fullscale warfare.

title: People and Business
description: Brinco, Ltd., the big Canadian mining and energy resources company said yesterday it had successfully ended its search for a new chief executive. He is Donald Robins DeLaporte, 53, a native of Toronto who has born vice president of the Western Minerals division of Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd., and president of several associated companies, including Giant Yellowknife Mines, Ltd., United Keno Hill Mines, Ltd., and Wesfrob Mines, Ltd.

title: Gimmick Financing Raises City's Pension Outlay 35%
description: New York City must contribute $897million of its city tax collections to its pension systems in the current budget, an increase of $232million or 35 per cent, largely as a result of gimmick financing in last year's budget.

title: Misses Evert and Wade in Semifinals With Mrs. Cawley, Miss Navratilova
description: The women had their day at the United States Open tennis championships yesterday, but it was no different from what the experts had predicted all along.

title: Tomahawks Begin Playoff by Winning
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 3 The only firstplace major league club in the metropolis tan area, the Long Island Tomahawks, opened defense of their National Lacrosse League championship tonight with a 1913 trouncing of the Quebec Caribou.

title: Matawan School Strike Is Settled Within 2 Hours
description: MATAWAN, Sept. 3  Approximately 400 teachers manned picket lines for nearly two hours outside the eight schools in the Matawan regional school system today before entering their classrooms at 10 A.M. with a new twoyear contract.

title: TV: New on NBC, 2 Comedies and Medical Story
description: CBSTV has given the primetime weekly series Beacon Hill, which, if nothing else, has set both WASPs and IrishAmericans to sniffing that the Irish could never have lived in that section of Boston, and has a good number of Irish wailing about the loose moral standards of the fictional Lassiter family. The series may still fall flat on its pretensions, but at least it has the viewers stirring.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Legislators Reluctantly Go to Albany For Special Session on Fiscal Crisis
description: ALBANY, Sept. 4Assemblyman William B. Hoyt of Buffalo and a friend, Assemblyman Rolland E. Kidder of Jamestown, both Democrats, were not on hand today for the opening of the extraordinary session of the State Legislature. They were on a canoe trip on a river in Canada 200 miles north of Lake Superior.

title: The Forgotten Civilities
description: If you watch the news on television these days, you can hardly avoid the feeling that the United States is a nation of selfish factions, lobbies and squabbling tribes that have lost their concern for the national interest and even abandoned the tradition of public civility. It is not quite that way, but that is often how it looks.

title: 2 Killed in Denver Shootout
description: DENVER Sept. 4 (AP)Two men were killed and a detective was wounded last night in a shootout that devloped as 14 officers attempted to apprehend a suspect, the police said. The suspect, Delford Joseph Derrera, 38 years old, was shot dead after he allegedly jumped from a pickup truck and opened fire at the officers with a sawedoff shotgun, the police said. The other man in the truck, Theodore A. Trusty. 39, of Denver, was also killed by gunfire.

title: BEANE BACKS CAREY PLAN FOR CITY FISCAL REVISION; SPECIAL SESSION IS OPENED
description: ALBANY, Sept. 4  Governor Carey's emergency plan for the fiscal restructuring of New York City and its rescue from the immediate threat of default received public support from Mayor Beame today, but some initial criticism from the Legislature's Republican leadership.

title: BIG LONDON PAPER IS CUTTING STAFF
description: LONDON, Sept. 4The Daily Telegraph, one of Britain's most successful newspapers, has announced plans to reduce its production staff in what it called a move necessary to its survival.

title: Trot Tracks Setting Up Pensions
description: Stablehands at Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways came up with a big winner yesterday when the two harness tracks disclosed plans to establish a backstretch pension fund.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Believe this or not, just as you wish. I found it hard to believe while it was happening and have only my notes taken on the inside of a matchbook to prove it, but one night last week at La Cabana, a very good bistro at 146 East 57th Street, we began our dinners to the piped, and rather badly fuzzed, accompaniment of Strauss waltzes, shifted to a Mozart symphony, swung into Khachaturian's Sabre Dance, drifted for a while on the current of the Barcarolle from The Tales of Hoffmann. made a quick cut into the middle of a late Beethoven symphony, wandered into the Moonlight Sonata, broke into a brisk trot with Mozart's Turkish March, and wound up with Bach's Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiringfull choralebefore settling down for the rest of the evening with, of course, Edith Piaf.

title: Egypt Calls in U.N. For Total Pullout By Israeli Forces
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 4  Egypt said in the United Nations today that she was determined to achieve a just peace based on the withdrawal of Israeli forces from all territory occupied since 1967.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1975

title: TV: Guns of Autumn Draws a Bead on Hunting
description: Commenting on The Guns of Autumn, Bill Leonard, CBS News senior vice president, said, this is purely and simply a broadcast about hunting ... It is not for the fainthearted, but neither is hunting. Iry Drasnin, the writer, producer and director, noted: Millions of people regard hunting as recreation ... Yet most people don't realize what is really taking place, or why, or even what the rules are. We've tried to find out.

title: A New Panama Canal Treaty Is Now Supported by Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. George S. Brown, and the Department of Defense are committed to the conclusion of a new Panama Canal treaty and fully support the Administration's negotiating efforts in that direction, the State Department said today.

title: McLendon, Schroeder in Lead on 65's
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 4 (AP)  Mad McLendon and John Schroeder each carded a fiveunderpar 65 today and shared a onestroke lead after the opening round of the $100,000 Southern open golf tournament.

title: HOLLOMAN CRITIC RESIGNS ABRUPTLY
description: A key member of the board of directors of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation who has been critical of the corporation's alleged failure to take decisive action to meet the fiscal crisis has resigned abruptly.

title: School Talks Mediator
description: When negotiators for the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers confront each other across a table in a Plaza Hotel suite these days, the talk is full of pressure, the signals are subtle and the words are sometimes angry and often ambiguous. But there is a man in the middle, trying to work things out to everybody'sor, more properly, nobody's satisfaction.

title: Vilas: Poetry on the Courts
description: The soulful green eyes of Guillermo Vilas were bloodshot after the match, and as he walked toward the clubhouse he literally stumbled into the groups of young female admirers.

title: TV Access Time: Mainly Quiz Shows
description: Quiz shows will again dominate the 7:30 to 8 P.M. period the primetime access slot on the three networkowned stations, WABCTV, WCBSTV and WNBCTV in the season getting under way next week.

title: TathamLaird Names Top Operating Officer
description: Jerry Birn, who has been managing partner here of TathamLaird & Kudner of Chicago and New York, has been promoted to chief operating officer of the entire agency (32d among American shops). There's no change in the chief executive's job. That still belongs to Charles R. Standen, who operates mostly in Chicago and its adjoining golf courses.

title: Sadecki of Braves Traded to Royals
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 4 (AP)The Atlanta Braves traded Ray Sadecki, a lefthanded pitcher, to the Kansas City Royals today for Norm Angelini and Al Autry, two minor league pitchers.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday.

title: SenateVotes a Redlining Curb Ordering Loan Data From Banks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4The Senate, in an effort to curb the socalled practice of redlining or denying loans in certain urban areas, approved today a bill requiring banks and savings and loan associations to disclose the pattern of where they makeand do not makehome mortgage and home improvement loans.

title: Some Druggists Leave State Medicaid Program
description: TRENTON, Sept. 4Some of the 1,400 pharmacists in the state have begun to withdraw from the Medicaid program following a New Jersey Supreme Court ruling yesterday that restored the state's right to reduce Medicaid payments for prescription drugs. The withdrawals were announced by Alvin Geser, executive director of the New Jersey Pharmaceutical Association.

title: Market Place
description: Coal and steel are the real bone and muscle of the economy, and the stocks of the companies in these basic industries have performed well this week. Steel stocks were especially strong yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, and their gains seemed to confirm the strength in Pittston Company common that developed Wednesday.

title: Ford to Speak at Dinner For State Republicans
description: NEWARK, Sept. 4 (AP)President Ford will attend New Jersey Republican fundraising event here on Oct. 4, state party officials have announced.

title: Bridge:
description: A basic principle of defensive bidding is that the first suit bid by any player shows at least five cards unless his partner has indicated a desire to hear something.

title: Louisville, Suburbs Integrate Schools
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 4Louisville and surrounding Jefferson County became today the first major metropolitan area in the country to carry out the courtordered crossdistrict busing of children between the central city and the suburbs to achieve racial balance in the public schools.

title: SADAT SAYS SOVIET IS TRYING TO SPLIT ARABS OVER SINAI
description: CAIRO, Sept. 4President Anwar elSadat accused the Soviet Union today of seeking to divide the Arab countries by staying away from the signing of the EgyptianIsraeli disengagement agreement at Geneva.

title: MOVE TO CURB E.P.A. ON PESTICIDES LOSES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) The House Agriculture Committee defeated today a farmbacked plan that would have allowed the Secretary of Agriculture to veto pesticide ban actions by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Three Canadians Pacing Junior Jumping on L.I.
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 4The first day of the annual junior international jumper competition evolved into an event with no competition at all today at the North Shore Horse Show.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Synergy in Greenwich Village is exactly what it appears to be, an outlet for handcrafts such as pottery, quilts, needlework and jewelry. But there is a difference. The shop at 126 Seventh Avenue South is sponsored by the Educational Alliance and supplied in part by three of that social service agency's selfhelp programs.

title: Oil Producers Silent On Prices at I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4One of the key issue confronting the world economy a possible future increase in oil priceswas not addressed here this week by the oilproducing countries at the annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

title: 3M Will Say it It Made Political Gilts Abroad
