description: John M. Williams Jr., a lawyer, died Wednesday at Bergen Pines. Hospital in Paramus, N.J., after a long illness. He was 58 years old and lived at 336 Westview Avenue, Leonia, N.J., where he had a private practice:

title: DRUG IS IDENTIFIED IN V.A. PATIENT CASE
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.. Sept. 5 (UPI)Veterans Administration hospital officials confirmed today that the drug Pavulon, related to the paralyzing poison curare. was found to have been given to two patients who suffered breathing failures last month.

title: Sag Harbor Teachers Vote To End Strike
description: SAG HARBOR, L. I., Sept. 5 (UPI)Teachers in the Union Free School District here voted early this morning to end a twoday strike and return to their classrooms in the district's two schools, officials said.

description: Leif Ericson would have felt at home watching 90 young Scandinavian sailors gaze at the New York skyline yesterday.

description: More than half a dozen advertisers withdrew their commercials from last night's CBS telecast of a news documentary on hunting after receiving calls from the National Rifle Association and a variety of gun and hunting groups around the country, according to CBS.

title: Pilot's Ashes Recovered From Stolen Car's Trunk
description: A bronze urn containing the ashes of a Navy Reserve pilot that was in the trunk of a car stolen three days ago in Queens was recovered yesterday when the car was found abandoned about half a mile from where it had been stolen in Bayside.

title: House Panel Backs Amnesty for Those Who Opposed War
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) A House subcommittee gave approval today to a bill that would extend amnesty to draft resisters and soldiers who dePied orders or deserted because of their opposition to the war in Indochina.

description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 5Federa( prosecutors here served subpoenas today on eight state agencies demanding records by Sept. 11 on contracts with any one of 100 businesses believed linked to Gov. Marvin Mandel's closest associates.

description: The Long Island Rail Road police have been puzzling for a week over a rare casewho stole two cars of an idle commuter train from the Jamaica station last Saturday morning at 5 o'clock and went on a 12mile joyride?

title: Bomb Blasts Lobby At London Hilton; 2 Dead and 63 Hurt
description: LONDON, Sept. 5A bomb exploded in the crowded lobby of the London Hilton Hotel in Park Lane today, killing two persons and wounding 63, seven of them seriously.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5The Ford Administration has drafted and sent to Congress the resolution sanctioning the stationing of Americans in Sinai, Capitol Hill sources said today.

title: U.S. Loses in Volleyball
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 5 (UPI) The Soviet national volleyball team easily defeated the United States team at the Sports Arena last night in straight games, 158, 157, 154, in the third of an eightstop United States tour.

title: COAL UNION AIDES OPPOSE STRIKERS
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 5 (AP)Local United Mine Workers union officials today pledged a backtowork movement in the coalfields and urged the union to act against those who have continued the 26day unauthorized strike.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Stand Is Scheduled for OPEC Meeting
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 5Saudi Arabia intends to hold the line against a stiff oil price rise when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meets in Vienna Sept. 24, according to Saudi statements and industry sources.

title: Postal Rate Rises Won't Be Imposed Before Christmas
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5The United States Postal Service has decided not to increase postage rates for letters to 13 cents from 10 cents until after Christmas, the agency reported today.

title: Alfredo Salmaggi Dead at 89; Staged BargainPrice Operas
description: Alfredo Salmaggi, the operatic impresario who produced bargainprice opera and crowded his houses in this city for many years, died yesterday in a nursing home in Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 89 years old and formerly lived at 1 Quentin Road in Brooklyn.

title: Stage: TragedyQueen
description: Arthur Williams dedicates his new play, The Tragedy Queen (at Theater for the New City), to Charlotte Cushman, a mid19th century American actress known for playing male as well as female roles. She played Hamlet and also Romeoto her sister's Juliet. The subject of Mr. William's backstage escapade, as one character describes it, is crossdressing: sexual mistaken indentity is the key to the intricate plot.

title: European Socialists Promise Support to Lisbon Party
description: LONDON, Sept. 5Socialist Pleaders from five European democracies met here today and, in tones of both frustration and hope, pledged financial and moral support to the cause of democracy and Socialism in Portugal.

title: WOMAN NOT LISTED AS SECURITY PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5A White House spokesman said today that Lynette Alice Fromme, who was charged today with attempted assassination of President Ford, was not on the Secret Service list of persons representing a potential threat to the security of the President.

title: People in Sports
description: Dave Schultz, the hardhitting forward for the Philadelphia Flyers who set National Hockey League records for penalties while the Flyers were winning the Stanley Cup the last two seasons, says he has signed a contract that will run through the 1950 season.

title: LEROY HUTSON SINGS AGAINST MUSICIANS
description: Leroy Hutson is a singer now going solo who was formerly a member of the soul quartet called the Impressions. But Mr. Hutson's solitary flight does not exactly mean that he is alone; he managed to squeeze 13 assorted musicians onto the small stage at the Other End on Thursday.

title: Soviet Baptists Try a Dash Into U.S. Embassy for Visas
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 5 (Reuters) A Russian Baptist, his wife and five children tried to rush past Soviet policemen into the American Embassy here today to apply for visas to go to the United States.

title: Girl 7. Freed for Ransom
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 (AP) A sevenyearold girl on her way to school today was kidnapped and later released when a $1,600 ransom was paid, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said. A spokesman said that Angela Brown, daughter of William and Edna Brown of North Philadelphia, was released unharmed in Fairmount Park several hours after the ransom was paid. He said there were no suspects.

title: Japan Will Announce Economic Measures Soon
description: TOKYO, Sept. 5 (Reuters)Minister of International Trade and Industry Toshio Komoto told a news conference the Government will announce around Sept. 17 or 18 a new package of measures to stimulate the economy.

title: CORRECTION
Violence in Louisville
Violence Breaks Out in Louisville After 2d Peaceful Day of CrossDistrict Busing
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Saturday, Sept. 6Serious violence erupted just outside Louisville last night after the second day of courtordered busing of black and white students between the city and suburban Jefferson County.

title: Mrs. Ford: Something You Live With
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI) It's something you just have to live with, Betty Ford said today after learning of the assassination attempt on the President in Sacramento, Calif.

title: Studies Are Started On Copperweld Trades
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission were reported yesterday to have begun routine investigations of insider trading in stock of the Copperweld Corporation. The Big Board confirmed that the inquiry had begun but the S.E.C., by custom, refused to comment.

title: Puerto Rico Blast Kills Four
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 5 (UPI)An explosion attributed by the police to a natural gas leak ripped through a coffee shop in suburban Bayamon today, killing four persons and injuring seven. two of them critically.

title: CONSUMER DEBT CLIMBED FOR JULY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI) A vigorous stimulus from auto and personal loans raised new consumer debt by $1.02billion in July for the biggest monthly gain in 11 months, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Susan W. Dryfoos Is Married To Douglas H. Mazonowicz
description: Susan Warms Dryfoos, daughter of Marian S. Heiskell and the late Orvil E. Dryfoos, was married last evening to Douglas Howcroft Mazonowicz, director of the Gallery of Prehistoric Paintings in New York. Justice of the Peace William J. Murphy performed the ceremony in Darien, Conn., at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Andrew Heiskell, chairman of the board of Time Inc.

title: Jersey Couple Found Safe After Florida Sea Mishap
description: MIAMI, Sept. 5, (UPI)A vacationing New Jersey couple. missing since their 22foot open skiff left Grand Bahama Island for Fort Lauderdale on Wednesday were found apparently unharmed today, clinging to the overturned craft.

title: FRENCH PROGRAM GIVEN APPLAUSE
description: PARIS, Sept. 5 (Reuters)France's $6billion economic recovery program was applauded by her leading European partners today, but drew a mixed reaction at home because of doubts about her ability to check unemployment.

title: Maple Leaf Entry Wins In jumping
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 5Maple Leaf Farms' Rogue River could do no better than a fourthplace finish in the final class, the Stake, but still coasted to the junior jumper championship today at the North Shore Horse Show.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD IS REACHED AT MET
description: The Metropolitan Opera and the American Guild of Musical Artists, which struck the company Tuesday, announced agreement on a tentative contract yesterday.

title: MONETARY BODIES FACING DECISIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 The heads of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund listed today a long agenda of detailed decisions to be made in the months ahead, mainly by their boards of directors, to carry out agreements in principle reached here this week at the annual meetings of the Bank and Fund.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Guns and Leaders
description: After a decade in which three public menJohn F. Kennedy, Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy were gunned down in open view and less than four years after a bullet maimed Gov. George C. Wallace for life, the news that a young woman came close to murdering President Ford looms as almost too awful for intelligible comment. The impulse is to despair for the country or to frame condemnations or to draw conclusions that are too large to withstand rational scrutiny.

title: Inmates at Walkill Getting Conjugal Visiting Rights
description: The State Crime Control Board today approved an experimental conjugal visiting program for the Wallkill Correctional Facility near Newburgh, N.Y.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled 2 to 1 that an advertising concern could not be penalized for inadvertently leaving out the mileage reading on a used car that was for sale. The court overturned a $200 fine against Joseph Friedman Associates for failure to include the odometer reading in a newspaper ad for a used vehicle owned by Kay American Jeep. It said that under consumer fraud regulations adopted in 1973, advertising agencies could not be held liable for any oversight.

title: No Title
description: H. Page Cross, an architect, (died Aug. 28 at the Lenox Hill Hospital, following heart surgery. He was 65 years old ands lived at 157 East 75th Street, where he also had an office.

title: Agenda for Monday
description: Although deference to the Jewish New Year put off until Monday a vote on the emergency legislation to save New York City from imminent default, all indications are that the lifesaving package will be approved by both houses of the Legislature after the weekend recess. Few among those whose affirmation is needed will vote entirely without reservations; but the truth has apparently penetrated that there is no rational alternative to the rescue course charted by the Municipal Assistance Corporation and now backed by both Governor Carey and Mayor Beame.

title: Pro Transactions
UNIONISTS APPEAL FOR AID TO CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5Leaders of public employe unions, warning that New York City's fiscal crisis could become a national catastrophe, called today for Federal Government action to guarantee the bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

description: The American Civil Liberties Union said Thursday it had filed suit to require the Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Administration to cut off funding to police departments that discriminate against blacks or women.

title: Court Orders an Inventory Of Indian Museum Objects
description: An interim agreement requiring an immediate inventory of all objects in the Museum of the American IndianHeye Foundation has been filed in State Supreme Court by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: Bolivia Sets $640Million For Petrochemical Complex
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 5 (Reuters)Bolivia will invest $640million in building a petrochemical complex under its new commitment with the Andean Common Market, Bolivia's Minister of Power and Hydrocarbons Guillermo Jimenez Gallo said today.

title: Youth Held as Extorter
description: FRANKLIN, Sept. 5 (AP)The police in this Sussex County community arrested a 19yearold youth last night on a charge of extorting $10,000 from a local bank by threatening to blow it up. The suspect is Keith Conklin of Franklin.

title: Pirates Victors, 52, After a 43 Setback
description: Willie Stargell hit his 21st home run of the season in the fourth inning and Richie Heiner slapped a 2run single in the seventh to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 52 victory and a split of their twilightnight doubleheader id Montreal last night. The Expos won the first game, 43, in 10 innings.

description: By Reuters

title: Control Board's Role On Event of Default
description: Under the proposed fiscalcrisis legislation, it would be up to the Emergency Financial Control Board to determine how money should be spent in the first, critical days after any default by the city.

title: 4 Women Get Roles In Mother Seton Rites
description: ROME, Sept. 5 (Reuters)Four women will take part in the ceremony Sept. 14 when Pope Paul VI will proclaim Elizabeth Ann Seton the first American saint of the Roman Catholic Church, it was announced today.

title: Gogolak Dropped By Giants
description: The Giants yesterday dropped Pete Gogolak, their fieldgoal kicker for the last nine seasons, thereby closing another chapter in the annals of pro football. Gogolak, 33 years old, has said he would retire if cut by the Giants. He lost his job to George Hunt and to the new National Football League economy squad limit of 43 players, rather than 47.

title: Antiques: Autographs
description: John Hancock's sweeping style when he put quill to paper to sign his name is known to virtually everyone. And Thomas Jefferson's spare, smallish signature is renowned. But how did Button Gwinnett pen hisand who was he?

title: Kissinger Hopes to Sway Soviet on Pact
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 5Secretary of State Kissinger said during a visit hero today that he believed he would be able to dispel Soviet objections to the latest EgyptianIsraeli disengagement accords.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ART ALFRESCO There are more artists in New York than galleries willing to show their work, so a lot of art is hung on fences. One of those fences is in front of the Museum of Bronx History, at 3266 Bainbridge Avenue, between Van Cortlandt Avenue and 208th Street. The museum's fall exhibits are on view three consecutive weekends this month, starting today.

title: Library of Congress Gets Archives of Modern Music
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) The Library of Congress has been given the archives of Modern Music, a journal that for more than 20 years championed the cause of new music, the library said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Gen. Vasco Gongalves, forced out as Premier of Portugal a week ago because of his proCommunist leanings, was stripped of all authority yesterday. Facing the open defiance of the army and the air force as well as the opposition of the major political parties, General Gongalves on his own gave up his appointment as Chief of Staff of the armed forces. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: FIREMEN ANGERED BY TERMS OF PACT
description: Widespread rankandfile dissatisfaction among city firemen was voiced yesterday over a proposed settlement of the longstanding dispute on productivity between the Beame administration and the Uniformed Firefighters Association.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Says Discipline Now Is Fact of Life in India
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 5 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said here today that she did not want India's state of emergency to remain in force for very long but stressed that discipline had to become a permanent feature of Indian life.

title: Concetta Scaravaglione Is Dead; PrizeWinning Sculptor Was 75
description: Concetta Scaravaglione, sculptor and painter, died Thursday evening of cancer in Calvary Hospital, the Bronx. She was 75 years old and lived at 441 West 21st Street.

title: Greenspan Asserts Energy Loan Plan Could Have Potential for Corruption
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, has warned that Vice President Rockefeller's plan to create a $100billion energy loan corporation creates a large potential for real or perceived corrupt practices.

title: PRICE IS CALLED KEY IN DRILLING FOR OIL
description: ITHACA, Sept. 5 (AP)The price of oil may be the keys factor in how much of the petroleum under the continental shelf on the Atlantic seaboard is brought to market.

title: BLACKS COMPLAIN OF FEDERAL BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5One of the principal Government agencies charged with enforcing laws against employment discrimination has been accused of discrimination against its own minority workers.

title: Robert B. Hobbs, Headed First National of Maryland
description: Robert B. Hobbs, who retired in 1968 as board chairman of the First National Bank of Maryland in Baltimore, died Monday at the age of 72.

title: How State Board Would Run City Finances
description: ALBANY, Sept. 5The state financial emergency bill unveiled by Governor Carey today is a complex document, 25,000 words long that would transfer the financial affairs of New York City and the fiscal powers of its elected officials to the state until the city was once again operating with a balanced expense budget.

title: Job Total in August Rose; Wholesale Prices Up 0.8%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5The nation's job picture continued to improve somewhat in August, chiefly for experienced workers, but inflationary pressures worsened during the month. The good news about jobs and the bad news about prices were both made public today in the regular monthly statistical reports of the Labor Department.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: C.A.B. Denied Right to File
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (UPI)A Federal judge ruled today that the Civil Aeronautics Board had no right to examine all records of United Airlines in an investigation of political contributions made to the reelection campaign of former President Richard M. Nixon. United States District Court Judge Richard W. McClaren said in dismissing the C.A.B. suit that it did not have the right to see all documents of the carriers it regulates.

title: Dayan Captures a New Strongholdthe Lecture Hall
description: He is a familiar figurethe black eyepatch making him instantly recognizable  as well as a controversial personality and a distinctive speaker.

title: COURT APPROVES REVISED APCO BID
description: An order permitting the Northwest Energy Company to proceed with a revised cash tender offer of $25 a share for common stock of the APCO Oil Corporation was issued by the United States District Court for the District of Delaware, yesterday in Wilmington, it was announced by John G. McMillian, chairman and chief executive of Northwest Energy.

title: Fluor Corporation Cites Advance in Its Earnings
description: The Fluor Corporation, a leading factor in the engineer ing and construction of oil chemical and power plants, reported yesterday a 41.1 per cent gain in revenues in the quarter to July 31, its third fiscal quarter, and the booking of $4.6million of new orders durinz the period.

title: Fire in City College Building
description: A suspicious onealarm fire damaged a temporary classroom building at City College's Finley Student Center near 137th Street and Convent Avenue early yesterday. The investigation was ordered when it was found that one of the building's doors had been tampered with. No one was injured.

title: Syrians Denounce Egypt's Agreement With Israel on Sinai
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 5 (AP)Syria today termed the new IsraeliEgyptian agreement strange and shameful and announced Its third military maneuvers in less than a week.

title: PRICES ON AMEX AND OTC DECLINE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market dropped yesterday in decreased trading.

title: BUYING IS ACTIVE IN SUGAR TRADING
description: Buying dominated sugar trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, with prices moving up the limit of one cent a pound in some contracts. Apparently many buyers thought prices, which had drifted down in recent weeks from the 20 cents to the 15centapound range, were at bargain levels.

title: Querube Arias Is Bride Of Carlos Brillembourg
description: Querube Arias, daughter of Dr. Roberto E. Arias, the former Panamanian diplomat, was married here yesterday afternoon to Carlos Fernando Brillembourg, a Venezuelan architect. The Rev. Kenneth Jadoff performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: EDNA POTTS REED
description: Edna Potts Reed, former president of the Appeal Printing Company, a law publishing house here that was founded by her father, died Aug. 29 in Buffalo. She was 92 years old.

title: Cooking Schools in the City: It's a MouthWatering Array
description: The American Cooking Tutor, Pamela it. Prince, Apt. 2C, 220 East 54th Street, 7510976.

title: MOSCOW DISPLAYS A DISLIKE OF PACT
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 5 While maintaining a conspicuous official silence on the conclusion of a new disengagement agreement between Egypt and Israel, the Soviet Union has made clear its unhappiness over the course of events in the Middle East.

title: Electronic Device Designed to Curb Pain
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 An electronic pain suppressor is being offered for the relief of arthritis. The small, batteryoperated, portable instrument has two electrodes to be anplied to the skin. According to a patent granted this week, pain suppression is effective for from one to eight hours. Of two models now available, the larger is about the size of two packs of cigarettes.

title: Strauss Says G.O.P. Funding Of President's Trips Is Mega
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5,Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic National chairman, asserted today that the RepubliIcan party was risking another national political scandal in its heavy spending on President Ford's political travels.

title: NO DUMPING FOUND OF FOREIGN AUTOS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI) Foreign auto makers have not (dumped their products on the United States market but have provided moderating price influences on American manufacturers, the Council on Wage and Price Stability said today.

title: Text of Carey's Message on City's Plight
description: ALBANY, Sept. 5Following is the text of the message sent by Governor Carey today to the special session of the Legislature:

title: 4 Women Will Have Role In Mother Seton Ceremony
description: ROME, Sept. 5 (Reuters)Four women will take part in the ceremony Sept. 14 when Pope Paul VI will proclaim Elizabeth Ann Seton the first American saint of the Roman Catholic Church, it was announced today.

title: Suzanne Groome Bride of T. S. Stier
description: Suzanne Starkey Groome, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Groome of Syosset, L. I., and Sarasota, Fla., was married last evening to Timothy Stephen Stier, son of Mrs. Albert Henry Stier of Columbia and Charleston, S. C., and the late Mr. Stier. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Malcom Bertram in the Community Church of Syosset, which is affiliated with the United Church of Christ.

title: Why One Filling Station Sells Gas for 54.9 Cents
description: EATONTOWN, Sept. 5It's a buyers' market out there basically, said Robert T. Hayes, operator of the Eatontown Circle Exxon filling station yesterday.

title: Art: The Pleasures Found in Drawings
description: The pleasures afforded by the art of drawing are inexhaustible. In certain drawings, it is the freshness of the artist's initial impulse that holds all attention. In others, it is the patient, painstaking orchestration of myriad tiny touches into a complex, unitary image that counts for everything. Some drawings are executed with an emotional detachment so complete that they seem to be acts of pure cerebration, whereas others are the sheerest effusions of spontaneous feeling. And then there are the drawings in which an artist seems almost to live a secret life, confiding to the intimacy of pencil and paper the kind of naked emotion he would hesitate to disclose to the more public medium of brush and canvas.

title: Diocese Cites School Enrollment Drop
description: The ability of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn to pay higher school bills, one of the issues involved in the curirent strike at five Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens, has been crippled in recent years by population shifts and changes in repigious climate, a diocesan official said yesterday.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 3 million common shares of Pacific Power & Light Company, at $18.625 per share, was completed yesterday by underwriters headed by Kidder, Peabody & Co.

title: Braniff Vows Fare Cuts
description: DALLAS, Sept. 5 (UPI) Braniff International, Inc., said today that it would reduce fares immediately from present levels if it succeeded in getting authourity to fly nonstop between Chicago and Montreal and Kansas City, Mo., and Montreal.

title: Market Place
description: For more than a year, commodity prices he given investors very goo?? clues about the direction of the stock market. When commodity prices began to decline, stock prices began to advance, and when commodity prices began to advance, stock prices began declining.

title: Open Interest
Business Briefs
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco announced yesterday that it would establish a pilot project enabling depositors in three California savings and loan associations to make deposits and withdrawals through retail merchandise outlets.

title: Precautions for Rockefeller
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 5Security precautions for Vice President Rockefeller were considerably tightened here today after he received word of the assassination attempt on Mr. Ford.

title: Pistol Was a .45 SemiAutomatic
description: The handgun that Federal authorities said Lynette Alice Fromme pointed at President Ford yesterday was a Colt .45caliber semiautomatic pistol, according to United States Attorney Dwayne Keyes in Sacramento. Calif.

title: City Ills Depress Stocks; Dow Off by 2.34 to 835,97
description: The stock market, increasingly concerned with the financial tribulations of New York City, declined yesterday in continued sluggish trading.

title: Low Point for Soviet in Mideast
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 5With President Anwar elSadati openly inviting an American role in Egypt and attacking the Russians for splitting the Arab ranks, the Soviet Union's position In the Middle East appears to have fallen to a new low point.

title: TV: Family Holvak Aspires to Simple Decency
description: Take two parts goodness from The Waltons, one part cuteness from Little House on the Prairie, shake cautiously, and the product should come fairly close to The Family Holvak, which has its debut on NBC tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. The commodity being pushed heavily is traditional virtue, which is distinctly attractive when the competition consists of CBS's Cher, with or without exposed navel, and ABC's $6Million Man and his computerized violence: Unfortunately, the basic Family Holvak vehicle gets off to a weak start.

title: H. PAGE CROSS DEAD; ARCHITECT WAS 85
description: H. PAGE CROSS DEAD; ARCHITECT WAS 85

title: Large Mortgage Concern Fined In a Suit on Filing False Papers
description: NEWARK, Sept. 5The Jersey Mortgage Company, consid ered the largest lender of its kind in the state, agreed today to pay the United States $250,000 in damages and a $50,000 fine in settlement of a Federal suit charging it with submitting false documents in support of applications for Federal mortgage insurance.

title: Senate Rejects Lunch Bill As Over Budget Guideline
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5The Senate. in a display of fiscal restraint toward a politically popular social program, rejected today a $2.8billion school lunch bill because it exceeded the budget guidelines set by Congress. By a vote of 76 to 0, the Senate sent the measure back to a SenateHouse conference to be trimmed.

title: Books of The Times
description: They are all coming out of obscurityfaster and faster, it seemsthese American architects of the late 19th and early 20th centuries whom historians had long overlooked in favor of modernism's giants, Wright, Le Corbusier and Mies. We have had recent biographies of Daniel Burnham, Albert Kahn and Raymond Hood, among others, and now Robert A.M. Stern has added to the list his superb study of George Howe, the Philadelphia architect who died in 1955.

title: FIREMEN ANGERED BY TERMS OF PACT
description: Widespread rankandfile dissatisfaction among city firemen was voiced yesterday over a proposed settlement of the longstanding dispute on productivity between the Beame administration and the Uniformed Firefighters Association.

description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 5 (Reuters)  Forces of the leftwing Timorese Liberation Front seeking independence for Portuguese Timor were reported today to be fanning out from the capital, Dili, and threatening to cut off troops of a rival organization.

description: St. Louis at New York (2:15 P.M.)Forsch (139) vs. Koosman (1112).

description: LISBON, Sept. 5The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has cut ofi all financial support to its Portuguese subsidiaries because it feels it can no longer provide effective management support here.

description: LUHMUEHLEN, West Germany, Sept. 5 (AP)Karl Schultz of West Germany won the dressage competition today and Britain, led by Lucinda PriorPalmer and Princess Anne, took the lead in team competition at the European equestrian championships.

description: Daniel Flynn, a former State Assemblyman, was killed Monday evening in a car collision on the Garden State Parkway in Clifton, N.J. Mr. Flynn was 68 years old and had homes at 5 Peter Cooper Road and in Spring Lake, N.J.

title: 19 Die in Thailand Mishap
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 5 (Reuters)  Nineteen people were killed and about 20 injured when a truck loaded with logs plowed into a crowd at an open air movie, about 80 miles northwest of here, police officials said today.

title: FILM VIEW
description: How many Americans are going to end up as a shark's breakfast, turn into Satan robots, be dynamited by a Western policeman, gunned down by a Southern policeman, or have a Russian policeman topple from a skyscraper onto their heads? Or suffer any of the other inconveniences that make up Hollywood's notion of the human condition, judging from the film product it has been extruding these past couple of months?

title: Penn State Tops Temple, 2625
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6Penn State, the undisputed leader of Eastern college football the last four seasons, narrowly avoided a major upset in the season opener tonight, beating Temple. 2625, before 57,112 fans at Franklin Field.

title: For Younger Readers: Six Suspense Stories
description: Adult suspense fiction often depends upon the unpredictability of human behavior and relationships for its impact. Suspense stories written for children, on the other hand, more often derive their effects through resonance: drawing upon a stock of familiarand frightening imagesthe author may vary or embellish plot details, but the power of the story ultimately rests on the young reader's familiarity with standard categories of virtue and villainy.

title: Country Music
description: Bobby Joe Gilbert, Hedorville's Bane to Virgins, is the kinky hero of Country Music, C. W. Smith's novel about the sexual scrambling and scratching of high schoolers and posthigh schoolers in West Texas during the early sixties. Bobby Joe has a talent for bedding down girlfriends, drinking beer and playing pinball. In the first chapter we see him warding off the sexual advances of his friend Lonnie's mother, lunching on five beers and sixteen games of pinball, and grappling with his high school teacher, who accuses B.J. of being a Hun, a Snopes, a Nazi.

title: SAIGON HAS EXHIBIT OF U.S. WAR CRIMES'

description: LISBON, Sept. 6They have come here from all over the world to see a revolution in action, and I think they are satisfied, said Joo Vicente, leader of what is known as the International Youth Camp.

title: Epilogue
description: Three aged, former Chinese Nationalist military officers decided last week to return from Hong Kong to China, where they had been prisoners for twentyfive years. They were released by Peking last April, so that, before they died, they might join their families in Taiwan and live under the regime for which they had fought and been imprisoned. They waited in Hong Kong for Taiwan to admit them. The invitation never came and now they have said they would go back to China since they were all old and ill and not accustomed to life in Hong Kong. They are part of a group of ten former prisoners who have been waiting for a welcome from the Taiwan Government. One of the officers committed suicide; in a note, he said that he had lost hope of getting to Taiwan. Two others have left for the United States. Four remain in Hong Kong, waiting.

title: G. T. Boggs Weds Miss von Thelen
description: The marriage of Emilie Louise von Thelen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander von Thelen of Charlottesville, Va., to George Trenholm Boggs took place yesterday afternoon in Ivy, Va. The bridegroom is the son of Edwin Palmer Boggs of Charleston, S.C.. and Mrs. William Marvel of Greenville, Del.

title: The Worst Teacher
description: Sometimes experience can be the worst teacher. People and nations become so obsessed with certain events that they vow never to let them happen againthus freezing themselves into a future response that may be totally inappropriate to changed circumstances. Thus, the World War II lesson that any aggression anywhere should be instantly met with force led American leaders into the Vietnam quagmire, where the lesson had no real application.

title: Book Ends
description: Mayagez. Although the average book takes from six to nine months from completed MS. to bound books in the stores, hardcover publishers can, like their paperback brethren, do an instant book if they are of a mind to. Witness the celerity with which W. W. Norton disgorged The Four Days of Mayagez. which was officially published Sept. S. Of course the actual capture and release of the container ship Mayagez off Cambodia took place back in May, so Norton's account was not right on the heels of the headlines. Nevertheless, once Norton's Mayagez book got underway, the project went from completed MS. to bound copies in only three days.

title: Court in Seoul Jails 4 Clerics on Charge Of Misusing Funds
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 6Four prominent Christian activists received jail sentences of six to 10 months today after being found guilty of having misused missionary funds to help support the families of imprisoned opponents of the Government.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The albatross that hangs around every Soviet ballet choreographer's neck is sovremennostthe Russian word for contemporaneity. No writing about ballet in the Soviet Union is free of this term. The political requirement of Soviet ballet calls, on paper at least, for all new dance works to embody this quality and to reflect contemporary life.

title: Shore Area Units To Extend Season
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH  Although the Labor Day weekend marks the end of summer for most Jersey shore communities, the 200member Greater Point Pleasant Area Chamber of Commerce, whose activities encompass this town, Bay Head and Point Pleasant Borough, will play host to Seafood Festival Days next weekend. The program is part of the chamber's strategy to extend the summer season here and promote ninemonth tourism.

title: H.E.W. WON'T RENEW DETROIT CLINIC FUND
description: DETROIT, Sept. 6 (UPI)The Federal Government has refused to renew a $1million grant for a Detroit clinic that was established after the 1967 riots to provide health care for 193,000 inner city residents.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: The first major event of the current opera season takes place tonight at the City Opera a new production (new to New York, at least) of Donizetti's The Daughter of the Regiment starring America's favorite prima donna, Beverly Sills. With the kind of timing that has become quite frequent in the record N'orld, a new recording featuring the soprano of the moment is tied in with the occasionnot Donizetti's Daughter, but a very close relation, Rossini's The Barber of Seville, taped this past summer by Angel Records. Sills heads the cast as Rosina, with Nicolai Gedda (Almaviva), Sherrill Milnes (Figaro), Renato Capecchi (Bartolo), Ruggero Raimondi (Basilio), Fedora Barbieri (Berta) and James Levine conducting the London Symphonyan impressive lineup

title: BRIDGE
description: The extent to which an expert partnership is aided by a detailed bidding understanding developed over many years is highly arguable. There is no question that detailed, tested agreements improve effectiveness, but is the advantage 1 per cent, or 10 per cent?

description: CLEVELANDIn the annals of crime in the suites, the American Ship Building Company and its chairman, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, hold several dubious distinctions.

title: Patna Floods Recede; Death Toll at Least 17
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 6 (Reuters)Devastating floods have receded from Patna, the capital of Bihar state in northeast India, leaving 17 people dead and damage estimated at more than $500million.

title: Business Courses Planned at Post
description: GREENVALE  Programs and workshops on smallbusiness opportunities will be available this fall at the Small Business Institute of C. W. Post Center here.

title: Good Enough to be Free?
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Since history is much more a story of servitude than of freedom, the liberties that Americans enjoy can never be regarded as wholly secure. Despite our wealth, power and proud traditions, we are not immune to the appeal of a political demagogue or the risk of a military takeover implicit in having a large military establishment.

title: FRANCIS P. SARUBBI
description: Francis Paul Sarubbi, a chemical engineer for the Consolidated Edison Company for 25 years, died of cancer Friday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in River Edge. N. J.

title: Article 4  No Title
The Business Of Moving Hits a Slump
description: The people who move are having a rough time of it these daysand they're not sure whether to worry most about the economics or the sociology of it all.

title: Design
description: This man with a leaf in his head is Stanley Kunitz, a poet who is also a gardener. One October, before leaving his summer home in Provincetown, Mass., Kunitz wrote The Mulch. The poem articulates a central tenet of his vision of life, a belief that man is not separate from the whole marvelous show of creation, that he too is a part of the natural world.

title: John Boynton Marries Ellen Forsberg
description: Ellen Marian Forsberg, assistant superintendent of the foreign reinsurance department of the Continental Insurance Companies, was married yesterday to John Sanford Boynton of Bedford, N.Y., an assistant treasurer in the real estate department of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Kennedy Leads in California, With Brown Second in Poll
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who insists he does not want the Democratic party's Presidential nomination, remains the top choice of party members in California, the California Poll reported yesterday.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly. one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good. three as excellent and four as superb.

title: A BODY IDENTIFIED IN LONDON BOMBING
description: LONDON, Sept. 6The police named one of the two persons killed in yesterday's bombing of the London Hilton Hotel and said an American was among those seriously injured.

title: Todd, Sandman Increase Power
description: TRENTON Webster B. Todd, the Republican state chairman, and a group of Republican conservatives loosely allied with former Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. have extended their control of the party to include its Finance Committee.

title: Poodle Gets Top Award In Jersey
description: NORTH BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 6Ch. Bel Tor Blissful, a black standard poodle, owned by Mary Peacock of Chester Springs, Pa., and Pamela Hall of Mahopac, N.Y., was judged best in show over 1,881 canine competitors tonight at the Somerset Hills Kennel Club's 41st allbreed show in North Branch Park.

title: Miss Navratilova Asks U.S. Asylum
description: Martina Navratilova, the 18yearold tennis star from Czechoslovakia, asked for political asylum in the United States last night, the State Department announced.

title: Maura E. Jones Is Bride Here
description: Maura Ellen Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brendan Jones of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Michael C. Seger, manager of financial analysis and reporting for a textbook division of McGrawHill, Inc.

title: Bay State Revenue Listed
description: BOSTON, Sept. 6 (AP)Locally collected taxes represented 54.75 per cent of the $4.7billion in taxes raised in Massachusetts in the fiscal year that ended June 30. The state Tax Department reported this week that local real estate taxes brought in $2.12billion, 45.1 per cent of the total.

title: Look Quick! That's a Pileated Woodpecker!
description: Birdwatching is booming. According to an official at the National Wildlife Federation in Washington, the number of birdwatchers in this country has increased by about 100fold.

title: Yankees. Beaten in 13th by 76
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 6In a game that had more chapters than War and Peace and more dramatic reversals than King Lear, the Baltimore Orioles scratched out a 13inning 76 victory over the Yankees tonight at Memorial Stadium.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: The glory of classical Athens is a commonplace of the traditional approach to Greek History. The intellectual and artistic products of Athens were, admittedly, dazzling. But ...did his wife Xanthippe ever hear Socrates's dialogues on beauty and truth? How many women could read the histories of Herodotus and Thucydides? What did women do instead? Sarah Pomeroy, who thus indicates her book's area of inquiry, is a professor of the classics at Hunter College. She has consulted archeological data, documents, historical writing and, of course, the literature of the high civilization of Greece and Rome with minute attention; her bibliography runs to nine closelyspaced pages. Her book is splendidly free of anachronistic speculation about what women must have felt, speculation projected back from our age onto a blank page of the past.

title: Conference Slated On Care of Hares
description: NEW BRUNSWICKAdvice on caring for hares will be dispensed at the third Rabbit Disease and Management Conference, which will be held at Rutgers University on Sept. 20. Commercial rabbit producers, representatives of the drug industry and other experts will speak during the program, which will take place in Blake Hall at Cook College.

title: Headliners
description: Philadelphia's Board of Education has succeeded, at least temporarily, in preventing Susan Vorcheimer from becoming the first female student to attend the city's prestigious Central High School. Miss Vorcheimer was to have begun the school term at Central High, after she won a law suit earlier this year that produced a court order for her enrollment. But a Federal Court stayed the order, pending an appeal by the Board. Miss Vorcheimer's application for admission has evoked considerable protest from Central's allmale alumni. Nonetheless, she is determined to attend what is generally regarded as the city's best high school: her parents have said that if they lose the appeal, they will take the case to the U.S. Supreme Court.

title: Best Seller List
description: Based on reports from more than 250 bookstores in ?? communities throughout the United States. Weeks are not necessarily consecutive.

title: THOMAS E. COLETTI
description: Thomas E. Coletti, the former owner and operator of the Park Hill Florist shop in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn, died of a heart ailment Friday at Faxton Hospital in Utica, N. Y. He was 62 years old and lived for the last three years in Utica.

title: Manila Seeks Negotiations With Rebels in Sulu Area
description: MANILA, Sept. 6 (AP)  The Philippine Government said today that it had ordered a halt in military operations against Moslem rebels in the south to permit a highlevel intermediary to negotiate the surrender of other insurgent leaders.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: CREEKS STIRRED BY TORTURE TRIAL
description: ATHENS, Sept. 5Alexander Lavranos is one of 32 Greek military policemen accused of torturing political prisoners during the former dictatorship. At his trial last week Mr. Lavanos's father took the stand and declared:

title: Bicentennial Guide Offered to Teachers
description: WAYNEProf. Ken Job of William Paterson College has developed a complete Bicentennial guide for elementary and junior high school teachers. The 28page publication outlines a structure from which teachers can develop daily lesson plans if they desire to place Bicentennial activities into an academic framework.

title: Spain Fines Critical Priest
description: MALAGA, Spain. Sept 6 (AP) A Roman Catholic priest was fined $9,000 by the civil gov?? today for having publicly criticized legal measures to combat terrorism. The governor's office said that the criticism by the Rev. Andres Alfambra Torcello was aimed at disrupting the peace in Spain.

title: U.S. Says Its Mail Service To Saigon Is Halted. Again
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) Mail service to South Vietnam has been suspended again because that country refuses to accept dispatches from the United States, the Postal Service says.

title: Merrill Lynch was bearish
description: Golden banners of People's Capitalism, unfurled by G. Keith Funston, once waved above the New York Stock Exchange, and there was a time when Merrill Lynch was bearish on America. Now the standards of People's Capitalism, tattered by the blasts of market declines and the recession, have been struck, but Merrill Lynch is assertedly bullishat least for the long term.

title: Bridal for Dorothy A. Jannarone
description: Dorothy Ann Jannarone, daughter of Brig. Gen. John Robert Jannarone, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Jannarone of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to David Woods Kemper, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Madison Kemper Jr., of Kansas City, Mo., at West Point, N.Y.

title: Inspiration From India
description: Someone once said that there is no politics in fashion, and it's apparently true. The latest application of the maxim is fashions from India which, despite political unrest in that country, are being imported and worn in this country by almost every age group.

title: Strike Challenging Reform Leadership of U.M.W.
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 6 The wildcat strike of coal miners that has nearly paralyzed this Appalachian state's most important industry for four weeks has also raised serious challenge to the new leadership of the United Mine Workers union, which so far has failed in repeated attempts to end the walkout.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1975

title: Ford Widens Lead in a Republican Preference Foll
description: President Ford has widened his lead over former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California and other possible rivals for the 1976 Republican Presidential nomination, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Thrilling threats of dysentery and decapitation
description: Travelers do not read travel books. Tourists do, and there is nothing we tourists like better than a little gore served up with our exotica. We are as interested in the traveler as the place he travels to. There is an endless thrill in the threats of dysentery and decapitation that mark our hero's route, a thrill best exercised from an armchair.

title: Chris: Never Thought I'd Win
description: This has to be the year's biggest upset, a champion of underdogs said gleefully yesterday after Evonne Goolagong beat Chris Evert in the opening set of their United States Open tennis final yesterday.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox:
description: New Homes For the Jets

title: A New Season With Something For Everyone
description: A new dance season that begins with the private abstractions of Erick Hawkins at Carnegie Hall next week and ends with the pulsing mixedmedia celebrations of Aiwin Nikolais must be said to be unusually eclectic. Indeed, it will offer something for everyonefrom moderndance devotees to stargazers to those who are more interested in what the stars are dancing.

title: Teaching Hospital Planned In Queens
description: Peninsula Hospital Center intends to submit a plan for absorbing the South Shore Division of Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center in Far Rockaway, Queens, as part of a $50million expansion program aimed at raising Peninsula to teaching hospital status.

title: Outdoor Events Today
description: Christian Radich: Visitors welrome aboard threemasled Norwegian windjammer front 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Public also invited to visit the Coast Guard Cutter Eagle, squarerigged training shin, 1 to 4 P.M. Both ships are berthed at South Street Seaport, East River, foot of Fulton Street.

title: Namath Returning to Action Tonight
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6A body of men with an average age almost as high as the Senate's  the Redskins will help the young New York York Jets continue their learning process tomorrow night.

title: WILLIAM A. SMALL
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 6 (UPI)William A. Small, former editor and publisher of The Tucson Daily Citizen, died last night at Scripps Memorial Hospital at the age of 81.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: No matter what the merits of the case, the refusal of tenure to a black woman timpanist at the San Francisco Symphony has left a bad taste in the mouth. Elayne Jones, you will recall, was brought into the orchestra by Seiji Ozawa in May, 1974, as part of his effort to rebuild the orchestra in line with standards that he, as the new music director, thought should prevail. But Miss Jones, a former New York freelancer and regular timpanist for Leopold Stokowski's American Symphony Orchestra, ran right into a political buzzsaw: the current union contract gives the San Francisco orchestra's rankandfile almost total power over renewal of a player's contract, and Ozawa found that very hard to take. He thought he was boss.

title: Sue Mills Is Wed To Albert Oehrle
description: Sue Dailey Mills, daughter of Mrs. M. Beard Casey of Louisville, Ky., and Col. G. H. Dailey, U.S.A., retired, of Marbella, Spain, was married yesterday afternoon to Albert C. Oehrle, a partner in the Norristown, Pa., law firm of Wilson. Oehrle & Drayer.

title: Endpaper
description: It used to be fashionable to bury time capsules. For events such as the 1939 World's Fair in Flushing Meadows, some newspapers and books of the day, some phonograph records and photographs of politicians would be sealed hermetically in a buried cylinder timed to open in a few hundred years. The expectation was always that our descendants would have enough information to know where the capsule was buried, but not enough information for its contents to be redundant. It was also assumed that everyone would understand forever, with no special explanations, the Italian invasion of Abyssinia, the battle of the Marco Polo bridge, the W.P.A. and Presidential cigarette holders.

title: Fine Arts Appeal to Children
description: DEAL PARKDavid Betesh was learning how to put hair and a beard on his sculpture of a man's head. Sharon Eliscu was rehearsing a tap dance for the final Talent Night. And Michael Epstein was being taught that there was a lot more to drama than acting.

title: Rosh haShanah Hailed as a Time for Spiritual and Cultural Uplift
description: Rosh haShanah was described yesterday in sermons as a holiday that called for an intensified effort by Americans to improve the economic, spiritual and cultural life of the nation.

title: Big A Is Becoming Big Top for a Week
description: The redandwhitestriped big top went up on Wednesday. The 50 carnival rides were positioned Thursday. And Friday the oval familiar to thousands of fans of sleek equine sprinters was hidden. The metamorphosis of the Aqueduct Racetrack into the Aquadream Fair was coanplete, just in time for thousands of wideeyed youngsters to pour through the gate.

title: CONGRESS TO GET BID TO AID GREECE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Ford Administration is ready to ask Congress to resume grant military aid to Greece. The move is part of an attempt to ?? the Congressional ban on aid to Turkey, according to Administration officials.

title: Sewer Plan Starts In Parts of Queens
description: A $400,000 sewer program has begun in Queens, Robert A. Low, Environmental Protection Administrator, and Charles Samowitz, Water Resources Commissioner, have announced.

title: Israelis Say U.S. Ends Ban on Sales of Arms
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 6 (AP) The United States has ended its ban on longterm arms sales to Israel imposed after the failure of United States efforts to negotiate a Sinai agreement last March, Israeli Government sources reported today.

title: Newark Gains in Fight on Tuberculosis
description: NEWARKStatistics gathered by the Federal Center of Disease Control in Atlanta disclose that Newark has made significant progress in its fight against tuberculosis.

title: Miss Mann Leads by 3 At Dallas
description: DALLAS, Sept. 6 (UPI)Carol Mann battled hard pin placements and the heat but scored a twounder par 70 today and took a threestroke lead through the second round of the $43,000 Dallas women's open golf tournament.

title: Miss Siltberg Marries
description: Miss Siltberg Marries

title: Barbara Lee Siltberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Arnold Siltberg of Middle Village. Queens, was married yesterday morning at Grace Lutheran Church in Forest Hills, Queens, to Christopher Wildner Wentz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore H. Wentz of Villanova. Pa. The Rev. E. Phillip Sebastian performed the ceremony. The bride is a graphic designer with Boller & Seligman, a commercial an studio here. Her husband is a sailmaker with Hilda Sails in City Island, the Bronx.
Dale B. Conron Bride of Richard Ahearn
description: Dale Beldon Conron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Belden Conron of New Canaan and Washington, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Richard John Ahearn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Ahearn of New Canaan and Westerly, R.I.

title: U.S. Catholic Group, Girl Scouts Agree On National Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) The United States Catholic Conference and the Girl Scouts have reached agreement on a plan to cooperate on the national level, spokesmen for the organizations said this week.

title: Rent Curbs Stir Westchester
description: The adoption of rent stabilization in 10 Westchester County communities last year has produced bitter disputes between homeowners and tenants and has thrown municipal budget planning into a state of confusion.

title: TV VIEW
Today's Folk MusicIt Goes To Your Feet
description: Simply getting into the Philadelphia Folk Festival last month was difficult. Early in the spring, more than three months before the event took place and before any of the performers had been announced, seventyfive per cent of the threeday tickets had been sold. Two months before the festival opened, the allotted 60acre camping area, which holds almost 6,000 patrons along with more than 1,500 volunteer workers, was spoken for.

title: Letters: Suffolk's Solons
description: To the Editor.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction

title: Iran, Glorifying Her Past, Will Rebuild 7 Columns of Xerxe
description: PERSEPOLIS, Iran, Sept. 6The Government of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi which has been trying to highlight Iran's monarchic traditions, has decided to rebuild seven huge columns from the great reception hall here of Emperor Xerxes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Other Places Are Already Being Affected
description: If New York City finds its tin cup empty and has to default on any part of its multibilliondollar debt, the scope and intensity of the resulting dislocations would probably far exceed the cumulative damage to the national economy of all the defaults suffered over the years by more than 6,000 other cities.

title: Athlete Weds Kathleen Auer
description: Kathleen Auer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Auer Jr. of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to John William James, a professional tennis player and son of Mr. and Mrs. William I James of Adelaide, Australia.

title: Choosing the Right Clear Wood Finish
description: When trying to choose a Clear finish for woodregardless of whether it is for use on wood floors, furniture, cabinets or trimmany people have trouble deciding what material to use because they are confused about the differences between the four most widely sold categories of clear wood finishes: shellac, varnish, lacquer and penetrating sealer.

title: Political Adventures
description: WASHINGTONThere are more security devices in this city than in any other capital in the world outside of Moscow, but far less security than in the days when Harry Truman used to leave the White House for his morning walks in the public streets of Washington.

title: Big Earthquake in Turkey Leaves at Least 1,000 Dead
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sunday, Sept. 7  A strong earthquake killed at least 1,000 persons yesterday in eastern Turkey. the governor of Diyarbakir Province reported.

title: 166 Housing Units at Westhampton Air Base Sold to Developer
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH One hundred and sixtysix surplus Air Force apartments, vacant for five years as the result of controversy over the availability of lowcost housing in the area, have been sold to a rolorado developer who plans to renovate the abandoned units and sell them to anyone who can come up with the downpayment.

title: TV VIEW
description: It was the sort of week that began with Jerry Lewis, middled with Eve! Knievel, and ended with Bert Parks: a telethon on behalf of muscular dystrophy, a portrait of a brainscrambled motorcyclist, and the 55th annual Miss America beauty pageant. To be sure, there were also documentaries on hunting and land use. In other words, it was an exemplary week. As the nation stumbled out of the summer doldrums and into the new TV season, all its cultural obsessions were in working orderguns, property, disease, death and sex.

title: Edward Francis John Weds Lauren Freeny
description: Lauren Lucille Freeny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence C. Freeny of Stamford, Conn., formerly of Towson, Md., was married yesterday to Edward Francis John, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. John of Towson.

title: J. M. Alexander, Susan Douthit Set June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Claude Douthit Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Watch Hill, R. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Helen Douthit, to James MacLeod Alexander, son of Donald C. Alexander, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and Mrs. Alexander of Washington and Cincinnati.

title: Bengals Top Lions With Field Goals
description: PONTIAC,. Mich., Sept. 6 (AP)Cincinnati got three field goals from Dave Green and standout performances from Ken Anderson, the quarterback, and Boobie Clarke, the fullback, as the Bengals took a 2214 National Football League exhibition victory from the Detroit Lions today.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONTo bankers and traders engaged in the myriad of daily transactions in international business, the most important aspect of last week's annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund was the question of currencyexchange rates.

title: THE JAILER AS SEEN BY HIS EXPRISONER
description: Last June 9, while residing in Uganda, the 61yearold British author and lecturer Denis Cecil Hills was sentenced to death by firing squad for his uncomplimentary remarks, in an unpublished manuscript, about Ugandan President Idi Amin. Hills's fate preoccupied Britain; friends recalled his brilliant if iconoclastic record at Oxford, his World War II service in the Middle East and Italy, his lecturing and travels in Turkey and Uganda"an enigmatic figure, a New York Times correspondent wrote. a man who could serve as a character in a novel by John Le Carre or Graham Greene. Finally, Amin released his British prisoner after the personal intercession of the British Foreign secretary.

title: HAWAII AGREEMENT AVERTS DOCK STRIKE
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 6The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union reached agreement with the stevedoring industry yesterday, ending the threat of Hawaii's second dock strike in three years.

title: ESCAPING THE DOMINO TRAP
description: In a famous speech in January, 1950, Secretary of State Dean Acheson discussed the American comailment in Asia in light of the triumph of the Chinese Communists only a few months earlier. The purpose of the speech, as he saw it, was to explain where the United States stood in Asia after the final retreat from the Chinese mainland of Chiang Kaishek's forces.

title: Swedish American Liner Sold to Cruise Operators
description: The Three Crowns, the stack markings of Swedish American Line passenger ships, are about to disappear from the local maritime scene.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Some 40 years and 50 novels later, Rex Stout is still turning them out. The doughty octogenarian has just come out with A FAMILY AFFAIR (Viking, $3.95), with the usual cast: Nero Wolfe, and Archie, and Saul, and Fred, and Orrie, and Inspector Cramer (still chewing but never smoking his cigars). Yes, it is indeed a family affair, in that a client is murdered in Wolfe's own house, which of course means that Wolfe has to solve the case. In my own house, sleeping in my own bed....

title: Mutual Funds Tackle Commodities
description: The mutual fund model has been pulled out and dusted off again, and in the wake of gold bullion funds, municipal bond funds and money market funds comes the latest wrinkle  computermanaged commodities futures funds.

title: Grain Loaded in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 6 (AP)  A survey of three grain elevators on the Houston ship channel shows longshoremen in this area have loaded about 8.7 million bushels of Russianbound grain since an attempted boycott Aug. 9.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market last week showed little reaction to a number of favorable economic reports.

title: Poll To Guide Lavallette On Acquiring Subdivision
description: LAVALLETTE  The Borough Council here, in a move designed to write the final scene of a sevenyearlong drama about a small community's efforts to join this seashore town, has began an unusual mail referendum.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: It was in June, 1962, that a State Supreme Court jury in Manhattan awarded $3.5million in libel damages to John Henry Faulk after the humorist had told how he was blacklisted in the radioTV industry because of a pamphlet that linked him to a Communist conspiracy. The damages were cut to $550,000 on appeal.

title: Drunkenness Among Youths Cited in Australian Survey
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 6 (Reuters)  More than 9 per cent of Australian children between the ages of 12 and 17 say that they get very drunk more than once a month and 2 per cent say that they regularly become unconscious from drinking, according to a Government report released here this week.

title: EPISCOPAL WOMEN REHEARSE RITES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 Four Episcopal women deacons who expect to be elevated to their church's priesthood here tomorrow went through an elaborate rehearsal of ordination, rites early today, then left together on a daylong retreat.

title: Rampant Vandalism Plagues Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY  Vandalism is a major problem in this city. It is affecting eclucation, recreation, business, transportation, city services is and worship. It has resulted in injuries to residents and it has caused an untold amount of property damage and theft.

title: 7 Senate Democrats Hopeful of Accord on Oil Price Curbs After Meeting Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)Seven Democratic Senators met with President Ford today and voiced guarded optimism that a, compromise could be worked out on domestic oil price controls.

title: Constance Biddle Barnes Married
description: Constance Biddle Barnes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Hampton Barnes Jr. of Edgemont, Pa., and Boca Grande, Fla., was married yesterday to Peter Richard Wingate Pemberton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis W. W. Pemberton of Cambridge. England.

title: Dredging to Start At Port Raritan
description: TRENTON  Ceremonies tomorrow will mark the beginning of dredging operations on the Raritan River at Port Raritan, the nation's newest designated generalcargo shipping facility. Port Raritan, which is in Edison, is the site of the old Raritan Arsenal.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Originals. Except for occasional sports like the works of Xaviera Hollander, in the past only books that had first made a reputation in hard covers would make the massmarket paperback list. But look! This week's list includes two original paperback novels by authors unknown to hardcover buyers. Spotters of trends are surmising that this is a sign of things to come  that paperback readers are learning to hunt out new writers on their own, and when they find one to their liking, they spread the word among their fellows.

title: Britain's SoaktheRich Tax
description: LONDONMichael Caine, the British movie star, announced last month that if the Labor Government went through with its latest tax plan, he would flee to California.

title: VIETNAMESE HELD ON DANISH ISLAND
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 6A remote island in a fjord that cuts through the northern part of Denmark's Jutland Peninsula is inhabited these days by 197 South Vietnamese, most of them between the ages of 11 and 16.

title: This Week in Sports
description: With just three weeks remaining in their schedule and no pennant hopes, the New York Yankees play six night games in Shea Stadium this week. They face the Detroit Tigers tomorrow and Tuesday, the Milwaukee Brewers Wednesday and Thursday, and the Cleveland Indians Friday and Saturday. Game time is 8 o'clock nightly.

title: Nancy Connolly Is Wed
description: Nancy Hotchkiss Miller Cormolly and David West Bentley, both of New York, were married here yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Norman Stanton. The bride, daughter of Mrs. H. Stanley Goodwin of West Haven. Conn., and the late Atwood Hale Miller, is an executive assistant at Time magazine. Her husband, son of Mrs. John Latta of Danville, Vt., and Cherokee Village, Ark., and the late Perce J. Bentley, is Eastern sales manager of Media Decisions magazine. The couple both have been married previously and divorced.

title: Mary Sinclair, Dr. Rothenberg Plan Nuptials
description: The engagement of Mary Sinclair to Dr. Jon Anderson Rothenberg has been announced by Lord and Lady Pentland of Riverdale, the Bronx, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Edward Rothenberg of Pittsburgh and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Browns Are Foes in Seattle Contest
description: SEATTLE, Sept 6A football game between the New York Giants and Cleveland Browns, a pairing once guaranteed to stir the interest of fans everywhere, will take place here tomorrow afternoon thousands of miles from the two home pockets of interest the teams still command.

title: GoItAlone Policy On Transit Urged
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne wants the state to adopt a goitalone policy for numerous key transportation projects that otherwise might be delayed for years if dependent solely on Federal approval and financing.

title: The Nation
description: For the first time in the United States a large metropolitan area, Louisville, has bused students between city and suburban schools under a courtordered desegregation plan.

title: Women Coal Miners Called Bad Omen by an Executive
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 6 (UPI)  Kentucky's Human Rights Commission has been told that coal companies were afraid to hire women as underground miners because other employes considered them a bad omen.

title: Sandra D. Lawrance Married To Richard Crawford Webel
description: Sandra Dix Lawrance and Richard Crawford Webel, graduates of the University of Pennsylvania and candidates there for master's degrees in landscape architecture and regional planning, were married in Southport, Conn., yesterday afternoon.

title: Archivist Is Digging Into the Past
description: While many Americans are preparing for the Bicentennial celebration in a literary way by reading history books, William Asadorian is digging into the nation's past in a very literal mannerwith a pick and shovel

title: Nevada Underground Blast
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 6 (UPI)  A relatively small 20kiloton nuclear device was detonated underground at the nuclear test site in the desert 90 miles northwest of here today

title: C.C.N.Y. WILL WEIGH MEDIACENTER PLAN
description: A panel of City College academicians has drawn up plans for a media center, including a publishing house and a research unit, for a selected group of students.

title: The Region
description: Schools are opening in the region with pedagogic issues temporarily overshadowed by pragmatic ones: many school districts have insufficient funds to keep up with rising costs. The alternatives are onerouseither to cut back personnel or Into contracts (and thus invite union retaliation) or to curtail activities that if not essential, are the desiderata of a broad educational program.

title: Welfare Protest Symbolizes a Financial Squeeze
description: GOSHEN. N.Y.Except for the earthcolored cubism of the new Orange County Government Center on Main Street, Goshen appears to be the quintessential expression of what this area was like a century ago. Good fat cattle and thoroughbred horses graze on hills that are within a few miles of the county seat, the antebellum architecture remains intact and in use. The place generally exudes the genteel serenity one might expect from the land where Hambletonian trotting was born.

title: The Attorney General as scholar, not enforcer
description: After President Ford let it be known that Edward Hirsch Levi, president of the University of Chicago, was his choice as Attorney General, Senators James Eastland and Roman Hruska made some unhappy noises. Hadn't Levi belonged to the leftwing National Lawyers Guild in his youth? Hadn't he once been involved in (and testified before Senator Eastland about) the bugging of jury deliberations in connection with a Ford Foundation research project back in the nineteenfifties? Wasn't he a protg of that woollyheaded liberal, Robert Maynard Hutchins? Or; to put it another way, why hadn't the Senators been consulted in advance? I was asked, recalls Levi, if I would go to see Eastland and Hruska. My first reaction was that I wouldn't. Then I said I would if it was made clear that it was at the direction of the President.... I didn't really think the president of the University of Chicago should go around looking for a job.

title: Attention Is on the Cumbersome Economic Committee
description: The promises and proposals that Secretary of State Kissinger made to the United Nations General Assembly last week contained suggestions for significant changes In the world body. Mr. Kissinger's ideas reflected American recognition of the developing nations' demands for more power and the United Nations' need for more efficient ways to help their development.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: A proposed piece of legislation has become the starting point for possible expansion of schooling downward to begin the process at twoor threeyearolds, and there is increasing controversy over the educational and social impact of such a development.

title: A Play About HUAC Stirs Hollywood
description: Los ANGELES The most remarkable theatrical went in Los Angeles this year is a new production of Eric Bentley's play Are You Now Or Have You Ever Been, taken directly from transcripts of the Hollywood hearings conducted by the House UnAmerican Activities Committee between 1947 and 1956. Performed in a 183seat, 50yearold theater in a seedy section of Hollywood, Are You Now Or Have You Ever Been has been playing to packed houses for over six months. Bentley's play was first produced at Yale, and then at the Riverside Church in New York, but the Los Angeles presentation is the first to have caught fire. Partly, this success is due to some fine acting and good direction and script editing by William Devane. What makes the Los Angeles production a special event, however, is that here the audiences include movie personalities who were either directly or peripherally involved in the HUAC hearings. Members of the Hollywood Ten  the group of writers and directors who went to jail for refusing to testify before the committee have seen the play and been free with their comments afterwards. (Later this month the play may also rattle a few skeletons on Capitol Hill. Are You Now is set to open a fiveweekrun at Ford's Theatre in Washington on Sept. 19, with most of the members from the Los Angeles company; at the same time the play will continue running in Los Angeles with a replacement cast.)

title: Suffolk Housing Aide Quits Amid Furor
description: EAST HAMPTONThe director of the Suffolk Community Development Corporation, a nonprofit agency involved in building housing for low and moderateincome families, has resigned amid reports that he made privileged information available to a wouldbe developer of an East Hampton project for the elderly.

title: Ozaki Leads Tapan Golf
description: INZAIMACHI, Japan, Sept. 6 (AP)  Jumbo Ozaki of Japan, carded a 10underpar 62 today that lifted him from eighth place to a twostroke lead after the third round of the $100,000 Suntory open golf tournament. Ozaki swept past three Australians, including Stewart Ginn, with a 54hole total of 200, 16 under par. Ozaki bettered the course record of 64, set by Brian Jones of Australia in the opening round Thursday. Yoshiteaka Yamamoto of Japan posted a sevenunderpar 65 to rank second at 202.

title: Food News
description: WARRENIt's not every day that a milk drinker can check out the cows in the back barn while making a purchase in the store up front. But that's the way it is at Wagner Dairy Farm's spanking new store in this Somerset County community.

title: DEMOCRATS VOTE ON SLATE TUESDAY
description: Democratic voters will go to the polls Tuesday to select party nominees for a City Council seat in Brooklyn and Civil Court judgeships in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens in what is expected to be the dullest primary election here in recent years.

title: George Eliot
description: After almost a 100 years, we are beginning to understand what a stunning feat it was for Mary Ann Evans to turn into George Eliot. The cumulative struggles that led to this transformation were withheld from us by those who worshiped her during her lifetime. Soon after her death in 1880, her new husband John Cross, 20 years her junior, began putting together her Life. He went through her journals (the ones she hadn't destroyed at the death of her companion George Henry Lewes) and he carefully edited out the parts that failed to coincide with the woman he knew. They must have been many. He met her when she was 50, famous, and had achieved her hardwon personal harmony. He asked friends for her letters. Some refused. Edith Simcox, a friend and admirer of Eliot's, whom he was afraid to ask, did not offer hers, and so far these letters have not been found. John Chapman offered Cross his letters, but was refused. And so Cross's idealized pasteup woman was offered to the world in 1885.

title: COMPOSERS SERIES OPENS AT MODERN
description: Since the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art is one of the handsomest outdoor areas in Manhattan, it is marvelous to have it opened as a public park on weekend evenings.

title: PUBLIC EMPLOYES DRIVE FOR UNITY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Somehow, public workers are considered to be different from the rest of the work force in our economy, W. Howard McClennan, president of the Public Employes Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, observed recently.

title: Riding InterestRate Roller Coaster
description: Little more than a year ago, investors were lining up around the block to buy Treasury notes and bills at record high yields. Stock prices were sinking, and the outlook for equity investments was discouraging.

title: Encounter: In Its Final Days, a Hotel Can Be Less Than Grand
description: ANOTHER crowd was checking out of the Bahama Princess Hotel on Grand Bahama as our charter group checked in. We watched a bellboy carry two pieces of outgoing luggage along the third floor outdoor corridor of the same cabanatype outbuilding in which our rooms were located and place them on the lip of the top step leading down to the next landing. Then he toed them, not too hard, and they came jouncing and somersaulting down the flight of steps. This amused the bellboy. Soon after, other luggage followed in similar descent. Disconcerting.

title: The World

So far President Hafez alAssad has held off his anticipated attack on the Sinai deal, apparently hoping that it will serve as a precedent for a similar agreement in the north.
