description: Outbreaks of mosquitoborne encephalitis in 13 states, reaching epidemic proportions in at least two, have led Federal health officials to forecast that this will be the worst year in the last decade for the potentially fatal, viruscaused disease.

title: Make Your Schools Work
description: Two historic trends are running strong in this society. One is the continuing expansion (even in these hard times) of the human service sectors of the society, the world of institutions supposed to help people. The other is the movement on the part of the consumers of these services to make them more responsive. Often what prompts the consumers to organize in the first place is what I call pathological professionalism: too many of our institutions work to insulate the professionals from the public rather than to provide decent services.

description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 6 (AP) Carlton Fisk slammed a threerun homer and Rick Burleson hit a tworun clout in a sevenrun second inning, powering the Boston Red Sox to a 206 rout of the Milwaukee Brewers today.

Follow it to Waukegan Road and make a right. The bakery and resale shop are one and a half blocks on the left. Traveling time from Chicago is about 50 minutes.

title: Critic's Notebook: Form Follows Fantasy on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES  Southern California, long spurned as landscape of freeways and hamburger stands, is getting more and more serious looks these days from architects and planners. These looks are coming not because California has managed to break out of its freeway syndrome, but because it hasn't. This is a land of makebelieve architecture, and it works. It is all very silly; it has none of the heavy, moralistic overtones of orthodox modern architecture, but it clearly fulfills certain human needs a lot better than the Bauhaus did.

title: Food
description: Lemon is the vanilla of Greek cooking. We have certain Greek friends who would sooner do without salt than the juice of a freshly squeezed lemon. This fondness for the sour citrus is nowhere more apparent in the Greek kitchen than in those celebrated dishes that bear the name avgolemuno. Avgolemono (the name derives from avog, meaning egg, plus lemon) comes in the form of soups and sauces, and one of the best uses to which it can be put is as a sauce for stuffed cabbage. A recipe for the cabbage and sauce is given here, accompanied by recipes for an assortment of complementary dishes and a menu.

A gun was pointed at the President at close range as he walked through a friendly crowd; the agent saw the weapon and disarmed the woman aiming it.

title: Dana Dowd Married to Mark Williams

title: Mrs. Backer Has Child

description: THE Tanzanian guide was leading a trekking party along the massive run of the extinct volcanic crater to the glacier line. At an elevation of nearly 20,000 feet, Mount Kilimanjaro sapped the energy of the climbers at every step. All of them were neophytes, yet each was fully aware that this was one of the highest points in the world that could be reached without special equipment and expertise.

description: It appears that former President Richard Nixon has nothing to hide, after all. His noticeable reluctance to tell his story to Congress and the courts may have struck the suspicious as evasiveness, but we know now that it was nothing of the sort. He has come forward willingly and forthrightly to testify before David Frost over a national television network. You can't ask for more openness than that.

Peter and Paul Roman Catholic Church in Norwich, Corm. The pastor, the Rev. J. Clifford Curtin, and the Rev. title: MIDEAST OUTPUT OF OIL DOWN 14%
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 6 (AP)Middle Eastern oil production in the first half of 1975 dropped 14 per cent from last year's level, reflecting softening demand in the West, the Middle East Economic Survey said today

description: NEWARK, Sept. 6 (UPI) Several hundred supporters of former boxer Rubin (Hurricane) garter, led by the heavyweight coxing champion, Muhammad Ali, rallied in front of City Hall today in a show of support for he onetime middleweight contender in his battle against a triplemurder conviction.

During the last few years, many noted pianistsCecil Taylor, Keith Jarrett, McCoy Tyner, Chick Corea and Paul Bleyhave recorded solo albums, and, along with other leading jazz pianists, they have also begun to devote entire concert programs to solo piano work.

description: LANDING  On a recent rainy Sunday, a day when most people were catching up on their sleep or immersed in television or the newspapers, about 25 mushroom people were out combing the woods of a Morris County reservation for rare species of fungi.

description: CAIROA gamble on the future was the way President Anwar elSadat on national television described the new EgyptianIsraeli agreement signed in Geneva last week.

title: Not so much red as olivegreen, or perhaps avocado green
description: In this bookwritten in his retirement years, Herbert Matthews once alludes to himself as old, and several times as a newsman and not historian or social scientist. He needs no allowances on either score. This essay in understanding reflects the activist idealism of enthusiastic youth, not the crankiness of an aging exUtopian. And, like some of his colleagues who wrote on Vietnam, Matthews puts academic writers in the shade in this most informative and broadly understanding study of Castro's Cuba yet to appear.

title: The Gun Thugs

They mounted a rough and effective campaign which drove all but one advertiser off a CBS documentary on hunting.

title: Bogota: Nothing Much Happens, but the People Like
description: BOGOTA  This Bergen County community shares its name with the capital city of Colombia, but that is where any similarity to the South American metropolis ends. For one thing, the local Bogota is pronounced with the accent on the second Avliable, not the last; also na one is sure where the town's name came from, although most residents are convinced that it is derived from that of the first Dutch family to have settled here.

title: Two Die in Boston Fire
description: BOSTON, Sept. 6 (AP)Two persons were killed in a fire in a fourstory apartment building in the city's North End shortly before dawn today. A man and his son were injured. Officials at Massachusetts General Hospital said Josephine Donnarumma, 47 years old, was dead on arrival. The other victim was not identified.

title: Law May Cut Building Costs
description: A new state law is expected to lower substantially the insurance costs of subcontractors, who say that it may also reduce overall construction costs in the city by about 1 per cent.

title: Barnegat Beacon Opened Weekends

An article in this section of The New York Times last Sunday reported that the lighthouse would not be opened in the foreseeable future.

title: Notes: The Colorful Chemistry of Fall
description: THE complex foliage phenomenon called autumn color is in its very early stages at this time of year, but some people in upstate New York and New England are already trying to predict how brilliantly hued the leaves will be and just when the season will reach its peak. However, if there is one certain thing about the behavior of such chemicals as carotin and xanthophyll (the pigments that turn leaves yellow) and anthocyanin (which makes them red), it is that this behavior is as unpredictable as the weather. The wise countryman knows that as soon as he makes fall foliage forecasts, Mother Nature will step in and turn the situation around. It is the brilliant reds and scarlets that, combined with the yellow tints, make foliage of outstanding beauty, and it is the reds and scarlets that depend most on the right weather conditions. Some trees will turn yellow regardless of the weather, but the trees producing red leaves will only assume vivid colors when warm sunny days prevail, followed by cool nights with temperatures below 45 degrees. That is why the colors are more pronounced in some years than in others.

title: Planners Change Greenpoint Zoning
description: The City Planning Commission approved last week a zoning change to accommodate mixed residential and industrial land uses in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

title: Humor of Artists On Display Here
description: Humor is the bill of fare at the Queens Museum and it will arouse as much sadness, anger and scorn in visitors as it will laughter. This show is evidence that humor and art is a complex phenomenon, dealing not only with standard sight gags and visual oneliners but also with revealing depictions of cynicism, irony, satire and cruelty.

title: A House on the Rocks
description: RYE, N. Y.Until Richard Headley came along, no one wanted to build on the steep, narrow lot on a rocky prominence on Lavender Lane, off Midland Avenue here.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A: BABY SPIDERS (Aug. 10)  F. N., Pearl River, N. Y., wondered how to get rid of baby spiders in her home. Mrs. Jack DeLange,  a Westchester County reader, writes, Very easily. We used an aerosol spray for household insects containing pyrethrum. We sprayed it in corners and around wall boards in rooms where spiders were seen. It worked and our cat scouted out any stray spiders.

title: Still Stagflation
description: The latest reports on unemployment and inflation confirm that the first is coming down too slowly and the second is going up too fast. More effective teamwork between the White House and Congress is essential on both fronts.

title: Heights Players to Offer Reruns
description: The Heights Players, which owes its founding as an independent theater company to a minister's abhorrence of the expletive damn and is Brooklyn's oldest theater troupe, is celebrating its 20th anniversary with a season of revivals of its most popular productions.

title: Philadelphia: A Journey to the Shrines of Independence
description: WE The People of the United States (or at least a goodly portion thereof), in order to form a more perfect understanding of our historical heritage, will journey this year and next to Philadelphia and, more particularly, a square mile of hallowed soil that contains numerous shrines to our Colonial struggle for independence and our birth as a new nation.

title: Parking Fee Rise Urged
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (AP) City Controller William Klenk has urged that parking meter rates be increased from 10 cents an hour to 40 cents to increase city revenues. Mr. Klenk also asked the city to install 6,000 more parking meters and to buy 66 new police tow trucks so the city can seize autos belonging to motorists who do not pay their parking fines.

title: Wheat Exports: The Protein Factor
description: Whether President Ford lifts the ban on grain sales to the Soviet Union or longshoremen work ships carrying wheat to the Communist lands, Americans will have no problem this year in satisfying their craving for junk foods, cookies, crackers and pastries.

title: Flammable Carpet Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) The Consumer Product Safety Commission has accepted a consent order prohibiting Richmond Carpet Mills, Inc., of Chattanooga from selling floor coverings that failed to meet Federal flammability standards. Under the terms of the consent order, Richmond Carpet agreed to recall all noncomplying carpeting from distributors and retailers.

Young of Washington and Chilmark, Mass., was married in West Tisbury, Mass., yesterday to Dennis Craig Guittarr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy G. Guittarr of Gloucester, Mass. The Rev. John Golding performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.

title: Two stories simply for reading
description: A story, as defined in Websters, refers to a series of connected events, that is written or told with the intention of entertaining or informing. That doesn't sound so bad, and perhaps it's time for the public to stop apologizing for its enjoyment in reading simply stories, those which make no claim to hold answers to eternal questions, but are nonetheless engrossing enough to keep one curious and attentive, eager to discover what's going to happen next.

C., were married yesterday in Litchfield. An Anglican ceremony was performed in St. Peter's Church by the Rev. William Sachs of Richmond and the Rev. Thomas Pemberton, vicar of St. Peter's Church.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Philadelphia to visit the shrines of Independence, the best place to get oriented is downtown (Penn Center) in the glassy rotunda building (16th Street and Kennedy Boulevard) of the Convention and Visitors Bureau. Bus tours (e.g., Gray Line, $6.75, two 90minute trips daily) are a good introduction to the Independence Hall area, but a followup on foot is a must, since Philadelphia with its impeccably even grid of streets, an ingratiating blend of the old and the new, is made for walking. Sixhourlong selfguided walking tours fan out from the National Park's new Visitors Center (Third and Chestnut Streets), and tickets (a donation of 50 cents) for a tour by candlelight (ends Sept. 27) can be obtained at the Bourse Building, 21 South Filth Street. A 28minute orientation film on the Revolution directed by John Huston will premiere at the Visitors Center on Oct. 4. A tollfree hospitality number (8002281776) has been set up for information on lodgings and special events during the Bicentennial.

title: Gotbaum Union Asks Ouster Of Benin as Health Chief

title: Futurity Victory To Vasquez
description: Soy Numero Uno, which even a beginning student of Spanish knows means I Am Number One, demonstrated yesterday in the 86th running of the rich Futurity at Belmont Park that he was just thatand with something to spare.

title: Shuttle Diplomacy: The Talks That Led to Accord in Mideast
description: These photographs of the recent negotiations in the Middle East were released yesterday in Washington. An interim pact was signed by governments Israel and Egypt last Thursday in Geneva, following 12 days of talks mediated by Secretary of State Kissinger. Israel agreed to give up the Gidi and Mitla passes in Sinai, as well as the Abu Rudeis oilfield on the Gulf of Suez: Egypt promised to renounce the use of force for three years and to grant Israel merchantshipping rights to the Suez Canal.

title: Growing up in Brooklyn and Texas
description: The Young Man Who Wrote Soap Operas is a modest, straightforward portrait of the artist gone aslant. Brooding, sensitive Dan Bergson, with an I.Q. so astronomical it cannot be uttered aloud, is one of a long line of tense overachievers at the Hebrew Academy of Surfside in the suburbs of Brooklyn. Aware that the Hebrew Academy has set him apart from the real world, he transfers to the public high school at Oceanbeach, where he is confronted with a dizzying imbroglio of obligations, rituals and sexual rites.

title: Parents, Fearing City Teacher Strike, Look to Private Schools
description: The city's private and parochial schools, whose new terms are now beginning, have been flooded with inquiries about student openings from parents worried about a strike in the public school system, and with applications from public school teachers who lost their jobs in the city's financial cutbacks.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: In spite of the fact that many otherwise knowledgeable photographers insist that developing one's own color slide film is too difficult for the average amateur (and really not worth the trouble anyway), there are a number of good reasons why many serious amateurs are finding it worthwhile to process their own color slide films at home.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) The Forest Service has announced it is distributing $88million to 39 states and Puerto Rico as their share of the $360million earnings from Federal timber sales during the fiscal year 1975.

title: Art Show Revival Set in Perth Amboy
description: PERTH AMBOY  The Perth Amboy Cultural Art Commission is planning to revive the city's Boardwalk Art Show, which was suspected a umber of years ago.

title: The Davis Cup Detente
description: On that historic occasion in domestic diplomacy when Tony Trabert was introduced as the new captain of the United States Davis Cup team, Jimmy Connors's guardian devil, Bill Riordan, assessed the appointment with literary flair. It is, Riordan announced, an American tragedy. Only a true patriot would understand. Riordan meant that Trabert had no chance of recruiting the world's best tennis player, who had previously snubbed the United States team on Riordan's counsel. Trabert ostensibly had offended Jimmy Connors, or at least Riordan, early this year with words obviously distorted by truth. But when the United States team opens its 1976 quest for the Davis Cup against. Venezuela next month in Tucson, Ariz., the world's best tennis player will he competing in singles, perhaps in doubles, and hopefully in a gentlemanly manner. It just goes to prove that a guardian devil can put his pitchfork in his mouth.

title: Kathryn Phillips Bride Of Philip Zimmermann
description: Kathryn Noel Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Laurimore Phillips Jr. of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Philip Becker Zimmermann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Walter Zimmerman of Washington.

title: The Fight for Control of a Leading Newspaper
description: LISBONWhat is supposed to be Portugal's leading and most prestigious newspaper had to be defended against an angry mob Thursday night. The venerable Diario de Noticias, now in its 111th year of publication, pulled down its iron shutters and called on troops and armored cars to protect it from several thousand citizens who shouted things like Noticias belongs to the people, not to Moscow and No to the lackeys of Cunhal, Cunhal being Alvaro Cunhal, Secretary General of the Communist party.

title: Tomatoes Fresh From the Vine for Puree Pleasure
description: Guido Foglia, professor of health and physical education at Queens College, and his wife, Dinah, director of the Office of Space Administration at Queens, devote their energies to Fox Hollow Farm in Dix Hills on weekends and during the summer.

title: LETTERS
description: Social Security

title: Architects Named Curators of Park
description: Joseph and Mary Merz are awardwinning Brooklyn architects whose philosophy is to incur as little as possible on the natural environment, and this is the concept that they intend to follow in their new role as curators of Prospect Park.

title: City Council Units Plan 2 Hearings This Week
description: City Council committees will hold the following publie hearings this week:

title: So What Do You Do at Midnight? You See a Trashy Movie
description: There is nothing to do. That is how the distributors and marketing men explain the popularity of lowbudget movies that play to predominantly young audiences exclusively at midnight.

title: Richard AvedonAn Artist Despite His Success?
description: June is one of the most beautiful women I've ever photographed  maybe, in part, because she's not a professional beauty. She makes me feel I'm just learning to photograph women.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: As readers of these pages already know. passions ran high a week or so ago when the membership of Actors Equity, doing fierce battle over a new Off Off Broadway contract proposed by its own counsel, voted down its right to carfare to and from the theater, regular pay for its performances, a closed shop, and a permanent stake in any tryout venture that went on to eventual commercial success. Actors, born broke, are perfectly willing to stay that way. My own favorite observation on the whole unlikely, yet somehow exhilarating, business is one picked up by Variety. An onlooker who'd been around a long time murmured, once the shouting had died down and the issue settled, Actors always panic when their insecurity is threatened.

title: Secrecy Marked Particle's Discovery
description: So determined were physicits to keep secret their historic discovery of a new kind of atomic particle last fall that one of them, to put a colleague off the track, bet him $10 that it did not exist.

title: ART VIEW
description: It is always a shock to be reminded that art is, after all, a spiritual enterprise. Our culture has developed in a way that makes it so much easier to think about art in terms of techniques or economics, as a game of personality cults and epochal breakthroughs, that its spiritual attributes tend to be, if not Wholly denied, then discreetly consigned to the ineffable. Public discourse is more comfortable with the material aspects of art. Its spiritual life is a subject for which we seem to lack even the rudiments of a persuasive vocabulary.

title: Boston Prepares for More Busing
description: BOSTON, Sept. 6With plans for 1,600 policemen on the streets, a markedly heavier Federal presence, and fear and resentment in its neighborhoods, this city is bracing for a sec, ond, greatly expanded year of courtordered busing for school desegregation.

title: How could someone who looks like a puffball pitcher become the highestpaid player in baseball history?
description: Joe DiMaggio, still grumbling about the dressingroom facilities, slapped a single to center. Mickey Mantle, all those businessmen's lunches showing round his middle, popped a fly to left, which Sandy Amoros lost in the sun and Willie Mays caught after a lumbering run. When Tommy Henrich singled, Pee Wee Reese grabbed him by the belt to keep him from getting to second.

title: Letters
description: Repeat performance

title: Almost Unlimited Freedom
description: Soviet Governments have traditionally attached great importance to scientific progress, both as a source of international prestige and a means of generating innovation in military techniques and civilian production. Though the results have not been uniformly good, the Russians are, with justification, proud of their scientific and technical achievements.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: AT this point every yearthe days immediately following Labor Daythe business world figuratively turns a new leaf in its calendar, tries to assess prospects and generally finds reasons for optimism. It's the time when Detroit traditionally introduces its newcar models on a wave of confidence, when the steel industry and various other factories prepare to push production into higher gear after their summer doldrums and when the retail field begins to anticipate its peak sales season.

title: IDLED FUEL TRUCKS SEIZED BY LEBANON
description: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, Sept. 6 (Reuters)The Lebanese Government today commandeered oiltanker trucks throughout the country after their owners stopped operating them because they were being fired on during; the factional violence here.

title: McCarter Theater Expanding Season
description: PRINCETONThe McCarter Theater Company is expanding its season this year to produce six plays, instead of five. In keeping with the Bicentennial spirit, all six plays were written by Americans.

title: Money
description: John Kenneth Galbraith has had, on balance, a salutary effect on political arid economic discussion in the United States. He has, in particular, challenged, with wit and grace, some of the most cherished myths of his fellow liberals as well as of those to his left and right. His wit and grace have, predictably, provided an excuse for his detractors to dismiss him as superficial. In truth, however, he has admirably demonstrated that respect for the English language provides everything necessary to demystify economics and render its complexities intelligible. With justification, Galbraith

title: CHINA DENOUNCES LITERARY CLASSIC
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 6China has opened an ideological campaign to combat the influence of a popular 14th century historical novel about peasant heroes that has often been quoted by Chairman Mao Tsetung.

title: Roebling's Bridge Sketches Found
description: Thousands or Washington Augustus Roebling's original engineering sketches for the design and construction of the Brooklyn Bridge are lying in neglect and obscurity in a cityowned Brooklyn carpenter shop at 352 Kent Avenue, under the Williamsburg Bridge.

title: Parkway Looking To Cyclists' Tolls
description: WOODBRIDGE  Although the Garden State Parkway fought, and lost, a long rearguard action to keep motorcycles off its 172mile length, it is unlikely that the New Jersey Highway Authority, which operates the toll road, will spurn the additional revenues that the twowheel vehicles will generate.

title: Tom Richard Strumolo Weds Ann Havemeyer
description: Ann Havemeyer, who graduated magna cum laude from Yale University this year, was married yesterday afternoon to Tom Richard Strumolo, Yale, class of '74.

title: Canada Trims Her List of ForeignAid Recipients
description: OTTAWA, Sept, 6Canada has revised her $900million foreign aid program, the fourth largest in the nonCommunist world, to concentrate on assistance to the poorest nations, especially those that show an effective disposition to help themselves.

title: Bronx Suspect Held
description: A 20yearold youth was arrested yesterday and charged with murdering and robbing three elderly women in the last few months in the Fordham section of the Bronx. The strangulation murders had produced fear among the elderly there and many phoned to thank the police for the arrest. Page 21.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A violent earthquake killed at least 1,000 people yesterday in eastern Turkey, the governor of Diyarbakir Province said. Local officials said the number of deaths might be much higher when rescue teams reached remote mountain villages. Rescue workers reported that the quake, which occurred at noon, toppled buildings and touched off fires along the Anatolian Fault. Further shocks continued past midnight. [Page 1, Columns 67.]

title: Major League TeamAgainstTeam Records
description: Includes games of Sept. 5

title: Seat on Council and Judgeships Open in City
description: Contests for five Democratic nominations for Civil Court and the Democratic nomination for a City Council seat highlight Tuesday's primary election in Brooklyn and Queensone of the most Peaceful in many years.

title: ABRAHAM JAGLOM
description: Abraham Jaglom, a financier, died Friday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived at 146 Central Park West.

title: Reaper
description: Whatever else they might suggest, street gangs Connote evil to the socially innocent. Never mind the realities of ghetto life, which spawned them in the first place, the sight of 50 toughs rolling purposefully down a city street in their painted jackets inspires not only terror in the public mind but morbid curiosity as well. So here is evil with great fascinationand natural material for the media. As a result, a gaudy mythology has sprung up about street gangs, dulling our fascination to the point where my own reaction to a book teasingly titled Reaper: The Inside Story of a Gang Leader is to pass it up as more of the same. I would have been making a mistake.

title: Bergman's Celebration of Sexual Love
description: STOCKHOLM Shakespeare's Twelfth Night is a play about love and sex in their endless varieties, but it can never before have been so wholehearted and enthusiastic a celebration of sexual love as it is in Ingmar Bergman's current stage production, which opened here at the Royal Dramatic Theater in March, visited the Theater of the Nations in Warsaw in June and reopened here a few weeks ago.

title: Karen Wilson Is Bride Of William P. Hommel
description: Karen Anne Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Wilson of Huntington Bay, L. I., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday noon to William Powers Hommel, son of Mrs. Richard Glavan of Kirkland, Ohio. The ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington was performed by the Rev. John McGeever.

title: Handicapped Get Chance to Enjoy Camping
description: SHELTER ISLANDThe two weeks are like a twoyear vacation for me.

title: Outdoor Events Today
description: Christian Radich: Visitors welcome aboard threemasted Norwegian, windjammer from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Public also invited to visit the Coast.Guard Cutter Eagle, squarerigged training shin, 1 to 4 P.M. Both ships are berthed at South Street Seaport. East River, foot of Fulton Street.

title: Sluggish Rivers
description: When Congress created the National Wild and Scenic Rivers Systems in 1968, it intended that all or portions of many rivers would gradually come under Federal protection. The original law covered eight rivers and listed 27 others to be studied for possible inclusion the first decade. Subsequent legislation added twenty rivers in Alaska and 29 more in the other states.

title: Paisley Leading Harness Drivers
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 6 (AP)Walter Paisley, a 34vealold harness racing driver in the Chicago rea, has taken the lead in the orth American dash  winning standings, according to the United States Trotting Association.

title: Letters to The Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jumping Event Won By Swedish Rider
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 6  Eva Casparsson of Sweden, riding a borrowed horse, scored three clean rounds and won the second class on faster time in the junior international jumping competition today.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained front the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Icelandic: Price War's Warmhearted Survivor
description: LUXEMBOURG  John Cranston, a history professor at Rust College in Holly Springs, Miss., recently called his travel agency in Memphis with a single question: Is Icelandic still cheaper? The answer was yes, and he, along with more than 100,000 other budgetconscious Americans and Europeans, flew the airline across the Atlantic this summer.

title: INEQUITIES CITED IN NOFAULT LAW
description: ALBANYA motorist injured in an accident may not sue a negligent driver unless his injury is serious, but no such limitation exists for a motorist injured in an accident with a motorcyclist.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: I am not one for silver linings or Panglossian optimism; I deal too much in the darker sides of people and cities. I am as aware as anyone that the world, or a good part of it, is teetering on the brink. It may even seem odd at such a time to suggest: that a few things are going right. One small thing that is going very right, very quietly, and that will have noticeable longterm effects, is the consciousness that cities have developed about themselves. This selfdiscovery, brought about by calamitous renewal and the recognition of something called the environment, is barely 10 years old. It has been largely unheralded urban revolution. But it is now generally acknowledged that an active awareness of a city's character, amenity and style, of its cultural and architectural tradition, of its ambience and quality of life, are as essential as the tax base to its prosperity and health.

title: Miles Davis Leaves Them Limp, Waiting For More at Park
description: Miles Davis's ability to leave his listeners languid was given pointed display at the Schaefer Festival in Central Park on Friday evening. His eightpiece group, which opened the program, perfomed for an hour. Mr. Davis was present for the first 50 minutes. He left during a solo by his bassist, who left during a solo by a conga player, who left during a solo by a second conga player.

title: Ohio Fire Kills 3 Children
description: DELHI, Ohio, Sept. 6 (AP)Three children were killed early today in a house fire in this Cincinnati suburb, fire officials said. The victims were. Tina Licht, 8 years old; Renee Licht, 5, and Nickie Licht, 2, the authorities said.

title: Five Teams From Massapequa Make Hit on Netherlands Trip
description: Taking five youth teams to the Netherlands to play soccer and winning three of the five divisions is the achievement of a suburban town on Long Island, a town that started a youth soccer program with 3 teams in 1971 and now has grown to 104 teams.

title: 2,619 in Westchester Show
description: The blueribbon event of the Eastern outdoor season takes place today at Lyndhurst, on Route 9 in Tarrytown, N.Y. It is the 58th edition of the Westchester Kennel Club and it has drawn 2,619 dogs.

title: Luhrs, Retired Boat Builder, Designs With an Easel Now
description: Henry Luhrs spent 40 years building boats for the Jersey shore waters. Now after 12 years in retirement, he's creating boats againthis time on canvas. Energetically, the 70yearold Luhrs heads for his studio in the basement of his spacious Colts Neck, N. J., ranch house. Before bounding down the stairs, he pauses to peek in the sunny, plant filled porch. This is where I should be working, but my wife won't move the plants, he says, shrugging.

title: Susette Chu Is Bride of Winford Caldwell Naylor Jr.
description: In the Versailles Room of the St. RegisSheraton here last evening, Susette Hsinhua Chu, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kuangche Chu of the Bronx, was married to Winford Caldwell Naylor Jr.

title: Previous Industry Links Noted Among U.S. Regulatory Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) More than 100 of the Government officials who decide what drugs can be sold and what chemicals can be put in food in this country once worked for drug or chemical companies.

title: Study in Contrasts: G.O.P. and Democratic Platforms
description: TRENTONAfter weeks of delay, the new platforms of the state's Democratic and Republican parties finally have been approved. As could be expected, each party devotes major sections to bitter denunciations of the other's policies and leaders.

title: A Handsome Gift
description: As of now, it's none of my official business. I've relinquished my stamp pad, my paper clips and my hotline to Parnassus. Five years is long enough to play the part of Captain Kangaroo.

title: Nancy J. Brunelle Wed To Roderick Baird 3d
description: Nancy Jean Brunelle, an art teacher at the Blessed Sacrament School in New Rochelle, N. Y., and Roderick Anthony Baird 3d, an advertising sales representative with House & Garden magazine, were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Daniel St. Laurent at All Saints Roman Catholic Church in Ogunquit, Me.

title: Mrs. Monsees Has Child
Grain Loaded in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 6 (AP) A survey of three grain elevators on the Houston ship channel shows longshoremen in this area have loaded about 8.7 million bushels of Russianbound grain since an attempted boycott Aug. 9.

title: Saturday Classes Set by St. Peter's
description: JERSEY CITYMen and women wishing to attend college, but unable to devote full time to studies, will be able to earn credit at St. Peter's College by attending class on Saturdays.

title: FARM UNION VOTE DIVIDED ON COAST
description: DELANO, Calif., Sept. 6The United Farm Workers union won two elections and the rival International Brotherhood of Teamsters won one today in the first secret ballot representation voting held under California's new farm labor law, the first of its kind in the nation.

title: GUARD CABLED OUT IN LOUISVILLE RIOT
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 6Kentucky National Guardsmen were called to Louisville early today after a night of rioting, violence and vandalism associated with the start of school busing of black and white students between the city and its suburbs.

title: Imperiled Animals Subject of Seminar
description: LINCROFTThe Monmouth County Park System will present a seminar on endangered animals on Sept. 17. It will be held at the Thompson Park Visitor Center at 8 P.M. and will be conducted by Andrew Coeyman, the park system's naturalist.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy Jackson Wed to Robert Burton
description: Wendy Barbara Jackson, daughter of Ernest F. Jackson of New York and Mrs. Hollister B. Cox of Watertown, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Howard Burton, son of Col. Marcellus W. Burton, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Burton of San Jose, Calif.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: After months of highlevel discussions the U.S. Mint has decided to go into the wholesale coin business. The threepiece, 40 per cent silver, uncirculated Bicentennial coin set, which is priced at $9 when purchased in customary collector's quantities, is now available at $7 per set when purchased in bulk lots of 50 sets or more. This new sales policy went into effect last Monday, Sept. 1. It applies only to the uncirculated setssometimes called Mint setscontaining the 40 per cent silver quarter, half dollar and dollar with the special Bicentennial reverse designs (a colonial drummer boy on the Washington quarter, Independence Hall on the Kennedy half dollar and a liberty bell and moon design on the Eisenhower dollar.) It does not apply to the much handsomer and more popular Bicentennial threecoin, 40 per cent silver proof sets, priced at $12. The proof sets have been selling at a rate of better than 2 to 1 over the uncirculated sets.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to watch polo, you have a variety of sites to choose from. You can get some facts to help you decide from the United States Polo Association, 1301 West 22d Street, Oak Brook, Ill. 60521 (tel: 3126541631). Miss Ruthe Larson, its assistant secretary, has a lot of information to pass on, from the addresses of clubs (139 clubs in the United States and Canada, and one in Manila, are affiliated to the association) to the titles of books about the sport. Game times vary from club to club, but generally, in the Northeast, games are at 3 P.M. on Sundays. The admission charge, if any, differs, too. Some clubs charge $2 a car, regardless of the number of passengers. The season usually runs from June until the middle of October. Two competition finals are coming up at the Fairfield County Hunt Club in Westport, Conn., this month. They are the Governor's Cup next Sunday and the New England Championship (Forbes Cup) on the Sunday after that. Both finals are scheduled for 3 P.M., with admission of $2 a person. The Fairfield County Hunt Club (2032278445) has regular Sunday games and also plays Saturdays at the Yale University field in New Haven. It is one of four teams in the Northeast that are considered major by regular spectators. The other three are the Meadow Brook Club, which plays at Bethpage, L.I.; the Myopia Hunt Club, South Hamilton, Mass., and Skaneateles Polo Club, Skaneateles, N.Y.

title: ChukkerWatching On Northeast Turf
description: THE names come booming over the public address system: Holly Ward! Harlow Carpenter! Andy Deeds! Vincent Sardi! Ed Tishman!

title: Parley on Courts Due Sept. 26
description: NEWARK  What many members of both the bench and the bar consider a longoverdue dialogue on their respective roles in the administration of justice will take place in Princeton on Sept. 26.

title: Miss Evert Takes Open Crown; Connors, Orantes Reach Final
description: Chris Evert won her ?? United States Open singles championship on her fifth attempt yesterday, defeating Evonne Goolagong of Australia. 57. 64, 62.

title: Miss Quinn Is Wed To B.H. LaMotte Jr.
description: The marriage of Henrietta Quinn to Byron Hilliard LaMotte Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. LaMotte of Easton, Md., took place in Cornwall, Pa., yesterday afternoon. Canon Heber W. Becker performed the Episcopal ceremony at Rolling Meadows, home of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Sydney Quinn Jr., parents of the bride.

title: STAMPS
description: Papua New Guinea, an area with a rich and varied philatelic history, is issuing this Wednesday a pair of commemoratives to celebrate its becoming on Sept. 16 the world's newest independent nation.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WHOLESALE PRICES in August were up 0.8 per cent, seasonally adjusted.... Unemployment at 8.4 per cent of the work force was unchanged from July. The country's 1,000 largest manufacturers have reduced capital appropriations in the second quarter by $9.42billion, or 17.7 per cent from the revised figure of $11.48billion in the first quarter, the Conference Board reported. . . . F. W. Dodge said the value of construction contracts in July, totaling $.04billion, was down 1 per cent from July, 1974. Nonbuilding construction contract value rose 23 per cent. . . . Orders for durable goods rose $1.72billion in July to $41.45billion, the Commerce Department said. Manufacturers reduced inventories $950million to $147.11billion.

title: School of Arts Expands Courses
description: Th Cedarhurst School of the Arts, a newly reorganized nonprofit education institution originally founded for piano students, will begin its first session tomorrow with expanded courses.

title: Best Sellers
description: Mass Market Paperbacks

title: What's Doing in ANNAPOLIS
description: ATHENS OF AMERICAAnnapolis, the capital of Maryland, is a compact city that is over 300 years old and yet is as modern as the hundreds of sleek sailboats and cabin cruisers bobbing in the harbor. Called the Athens of America in Colonial times, this city with its narrow brick and cobblestone streets and its dozens of 18thcentury buildings is a treasure trove of early Americana. Furthermore, everything a visitor would want to see can be reached on foot  the entire downtown area (one square mile) has been designated a National Historic Landmark by the United States Department of the Interior. Annapolis, originally settled by a group of Puritan families from Virginia in 1649, was the first peacetime capital of the United States (November, 1783, through midAugust, 1784) and is the home of the United States Naval Academy.

title: Kathryn Ritchell Of TimeLife Wed
description: Kathryn Ann Ritchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Ritchell of WinstonSalem, N.C., and Henry Joseph Sommerkamp 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Sommerkamp of Sea Island, Ga., were married yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church here by the Rev. Andrew Mullins, assisted by the Rev. Richard Martin.

title: The World
description: The Sinai agreement signed last week by Egypt and Israel, although far from a full peace treaty, contains provisions that make resumption of hostilities difficult, so much so that some of Egypt's Arab allies have charged the agreement betrays the Arab cause.

title: One Dead, 48 Hurt in Crash
description: PRINCETON, W. Va., Sept. 6 (UPI)A bus carrying North Carolina Baptist delegates overturned in a muddy construction area on the West, Virginia Turnpike today. One;man died and 48 others were injured. The victim, Frank Kelly of Selma, N. C., left the wreckage, then collapsed, a hospital spokesman said, indicating a possible heart attack. The delegates were returning home from the Ohio Baptist Convention in Cleveland.

title: The fight for $60,000 a half minute
description: A Sunday evening in midMay at the CenturyPlaza Hotel in Los Angeles. Two floors below the modern, opulent lobby, in the massive Los Angeles Room, 2,000 people mill about, taking champagne from flowing fountains, munching coquilles St. Jacques, meats, cheeses, salads and thick, rich desserts served out of a hundred chafing dishes by more than 50 waiters from a huge, Xshaped table under a massive chandelier. Enormous dusters of pink and white flowers suspended from the ceiling, under which mill starlets in skimpy gowns, welltailored men with hair styles as impeccable as their suits. There is the occasional deeply tanned face of a Starthose whose clothes seem to fit without effort, and whose smiles never waver. Hard by these glittering people is another group; their jackets are doubleknit, their shoes inevitably bright white, their stares illdisguised. These are the affiliates the people from the more than 200 local stations from Alexandria, Minn., to Midland, Tex., who are here to witness the most public rite of an American television networkthe unveiling of the fall schedule.

title: Negotiators Nearing Agreement to Avert Strike by Teachers
description: Board of Education and union negotiators were working out a compromise last night that could avert a teachers' strike theatened for Tuesday. the day after the fall term begins for the city's 1.1 million pupils.

title: Watson Leads by 3 With 69
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 6Tom Watson, the 26yearold British Open champion with the Huck Finn image, shot a 69 today to lead the first round of the 36hole, fourman World Series of Golf.

title: Franklin Post Office Open
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (AP) After a 200year hiatus, ,the post office at Benjamin Franklin's house has been reopened. Ceremonies were held Wednesday to dedicate a new post office substation at 316 Market Street, the site 200 years ago of Franklin's home. Franklin, the first Postmaster General of the United States, ran a post office from his house in 1775.

title: Richly deserved
description: New York's financial trouble has apparently left most Americans rather pleased. Many seem downright delighted, and salesmen trying to find buyers for Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds report a positive emotional hostility, suggesting a desire to see the place plowed with salt like conquered Carthage.

title: FEAR OF RADICALS IS DERIDED BY BOLL
description: SCHNEIDHAUSEN, West GermanyHeinrich Bll, the West German writer who won the Nobel Prize in 1972, objects to being called the conscience of the nation. He has just pricked it with the publication of a hook on what has been called a witchhunt for radicals in West German schools, courts and official agencies.

title: Sextuplets Born, But All Die
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 6 (UPI)  A 25yearold woman gave birth to sextuplets last night, but none of the babies survived, hospital officials said. A spokesman at Bess Kaiser Hospital said three of the babies, all boys, died soon after birth. The others, two girls and a boy, died today. The mother is Mildred Hynes of nearby Aloha.

title: Football and the Root of Evil
description: Bear Bryant, the professor of spinning and weaving at Alabama whose football teams can whip almost any other team almost anywhere except in a bowl, has scored another signal victory, this time in court. A Federal judge in Tuscaloosa, which is the heart of bear country, has ruled that when Bryant takes his students on field trips to Jackson. Miss., or Nashville. Tenn., he of need not limit the party to 48 biochemistry majors, approximately tour and onethird teams, but may have 60 in uniform (five and a half teams), same as Mississippi State and Vanderbilt, the hosts.

title: Beane and Fiscal Crisis: A Mayor Loses Stature
description: New York's new Mayor stood bareheaded on the steps of City Hall on Jan. 31, 1974, unmindful of a steady drizzle, and in a voice made soft with emotion said, This is the proudest day of my life.

title: GUN INQUIRY FINDS NO PLOT EVIDENCE IN THREAT TO FORD
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 6The Government has turned up no evidence thus far of a conspiracy to assassinate President Ford, Dwayne Keyes, United States attorney, said today.

title: Johanna Meier: From Rodeo to Opera
description: GLEN ROCK  The path twists up a steep, green hill to the house. The front porch is wreathed in vines and almost hidden from the street below.

title: Yonkers College Student Is Named Miss America
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 6 (AP) Miss New York, Tawny Elaine Godin, an 18yearold pianist from Yonkers whose family roots in America date back three centuries, was crowned Miss America 1976 here tonight.

title: Gamble for Peace...
description: Israel and Egypt, acting through Geneva representatives seated at separate tables, have now signed the new Interim peace agreement concluded with the help of Secretary of State Kissinger's shuttle diplomacy. Mr. Kissinger, back in Washington, has joined with President Ford in an energetic effort to get Congressional approval of the United States participation that is so essential a feature of this new agreement.

title: Suzanne Farrell Bride of Barry O'Brien
description: Suzanne Barton Farrell of Sarasota, Fla., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Martin Farrell of Ridgewood, N. J., and Quonochontaug, R. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Barry Brennan O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Dennison O'Brien of Longboat Key in Sarasota, formerly of Yonkers.

title: Mexican Politicians Try to Pick Presidential Sweepstakes Winner
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 6One month before President Luis Echeverria Alvarez chooses his successor, thousands of Mexican politicians and bureaucrats are nervously trying to guess who the next president will be so as to express their loyalty to him and thus secure jobs in the coming administration.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports
description: TodayTaconic Auto Sport's Club autocross at Grand Union Distribution Center, 333 North Bedford Road, Mount Kisco, N. Y. Registration: 9:30 A.M., first car off 10:30. Cars must be muffled; seat belts required. To verify because of questionable weather, phone: (914) 7377770 or 7624225.

title: Rutgers Unit Aids Minority Businesses
description: NEWARK  There would appear to he little in common between an Elizabeth attorney and a Lakewood barber, or a Camden land developer and a Newark cigarette distributor, but all have their financial roots in a Federally licensed investment company run by the Rutgers Graduate School of Business Administration.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Tanzania with the intention of climbing Kilimanjaro, you will find there is no limit to the size of a trekking party, but each group must have a guide and, strictly for the guide's use, a porter. You may hire as many porters for your own use as you wish; each man will haul up to 33 pounds of food, clothing and other gear.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Plant new evergreens; transplant mature overcrowded specimens. . . . Select one or two geraniums, begonias, petunias to pot for indoor plants; pot and keep outside for a week or two; cut back and bring indoors. . . . Move all summering house plants indoors. . . . Plant peonies. . . . Order hardy bulbs.

title: 8 Are Attendants Of Judith B. Self At Her Nuptials
description: Judith Bellinger Self and Charles Malcolm Murphy Jr. were married yesterday afternoon in the Federated Church in Edgartown, Mass., by the Rev. Brian E. Roberge.

title: Horse Firms Are Increasing in Hunterdon
description: PITTSTOWNAn Eastern base for American Saddlebred horses, usually sired in Kentucky or California, has been established. here in Hunterdon County, where horse farms are rapidly replacing nonprofitable dairy farms.

title: Alice Evans, Who Found Cause Of Undulant Fever in Man, Dies
description: Dr. Alice C. Evans, a pioneer bacteriologist who helped identify raw milk as a common source of undulant fever in man, died Friday of a stroke. She was 94 years old and lived in Goodwin House, a nursing home in Alexandria, Va.

title: A Small Chapter of Amnesty International, Begun in a Moscow Apartment, Survives Its First Anxious Year
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 6A year ago a small chapter of Amnesty International was founded in a Moscow apartment, and perhaps the most significan characteristic of the group is that it still exists.

title: Sara Lee: A Pilgrimage to the Fountainhead of Cheesecake
description: THE gleaming antisepticlooking plant did not fit my mental image of Sara Lee Kitchens. The Victorian gingerbread building next door was more my idea of the font of famous cheesecakes, but the sign outside indicated that it was a nursing home. So much for sentimental preconceptions.

title: Social Announcements
description: Births

title: BRONX YOUTH HEW IN THREE SLAYINGS
description: A 20yearold youth was arrested yesterday and charged with murdering and robbing three elderly women in the last few months in their apartments in the Fordham section of the Bronx.

title: Life on Top Floor in an Indian Flash Flood
description: PATNA, India, Aug. 30Monsoon floods are a seasonal hazard throughout much of Asia, destroying crops and intensifying the plight of millions of malnourished people. Floods drown hundreds, perpetuate endemic diseases and cause tremendous economic losses. For many, Asians floods are just another hardship in the struggle through life. For one American visitor a monsoon flood of the Ganges was a strange and frightening experience.

title: The Stage: In Edinburgh
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 5How do you handle theater at an international festival? Should it be classics or should it be creative? Old plays staged with the special glamour of a festive occasion, or new plays, with all the risks attendant on such ventures, that might by happy chance give the festival a sudden measure of immortality?

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: Our crawl space has an air conditioning duct running through it and there is constantly water dripping from this. There is adequate ventilation of this crawl space, but of course no sun. How can we prevent musty odor and mildew growth?Mrs. P. S., Princeton, N. J.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Rising interest rates and the unsettled nature of the mortgage market have led the Government National Mortgage Association to postpone indefinitely its attempt to revolve its funding under the Emergency Home Purchase Act of 1974.

title: Billboards Decline as Rents Rise
description: Everyone's winning the battle of the billboardsor so say government and industry officials.

title: Fiscal Crisis at a Glance
description: Because its budget is out of balance, and because incoming revenues flow erratically, the city must borrow hundreds of millions of dollars each month to meet expenses, including shortterm borrowing obligations that come due. But banks and other investors have refused, since early this year, to buy the city's notes and bonds.

title: Susan Huggins Becomes Bride
description: Susan Huggins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Ellsworth Huggins of Naples, Fla., formerly of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to John Philip Kipp Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kipp of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: Unlike New York, Chicago Frowns on Borrowing
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 6Comparing the finances of New York City with those of Chicago is a bit like comparing a cashshy diner with a credit card who is munching a filet mignon to a fellow at a counter who has just anted up the cash for a blueplate special.

title: Yacht Racing Results
description: AT BELLE HAVEN CLUB

title: Paperbacks
description: THE BEST, by Peter Passell and Leonard Ross. (Pocket, $1.75.) An economist and a law professor extol their favorites among matters ranging from Arline food to zoos: there's always much information behind their panache.

title: Growing Pains Are Afflicting Open at Forest Hills
description: Last Thursday, while hundreds of fans futilely sought tickets for the United States Open tennis championships, a security guard was ??ashing his pockets with $10 bills at the gates of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Nancy Nevius Bride in Maine
description: Nancy Lowrie Nevius, daughter of Garrett Winder Nevius of Farmington, Conn., and the late Lowrie Flagg Nevius, was married at noon yesterday in Northeast Harbor, Me., to Todd McClive Bacon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Bacon of Flint, Mich.

title: Pigeons Bred for Racing Skill
description: SAYREVILLELatitude 402540.0, longitude 762723.7 is not the bearing of a ship at sea. It is, rather, the home address of the 50 pigeons owned by William Crane, a member of the Middlesex RacingPigeon Club.

title: WCBSTV CANCELS SHOW ON SCHOOLS
description: A halfhour Board of Education television program that was scheduled to be shown on WCBSTV yesterday afternoon was canceled by the station's policymakers after they concluded that it was a puff job for the Board of Education, a spokesman for the station said yesterday.

title: Satellite Tennis Circuit: They Love You but Don't Understand You
description: It's not that I'm complaining. Tennis is a fair game. The fairest of them all, the deadly equalizer.

title: Jennie Ross Downer Is the Bride Of Dr. Howard Austin 3d on L.I.
description: The nonsectarian chapel at Point O'Woods, L.I., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Jennie Rosy Downer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Halsey S. Downer of Old Westbury, L.I., and Point O'Woods, to Dr. Howard A. Austin, 3d, son of Mrs. Austin Jr. of New York and Point O'Woods and the late Mr. Austin.

title: Apples
description: This is one of those years when apples have outdone themselves. Orchards are loaded with fruit. Backyard trees in the suburbs are so heavy with fat red apples that their limbs have to be propped up. Out in the hills the old snags of trees that persist near forgotten farmhouses now long vanished are littering the ground with windfalls that fatten woodchucks and sweeten the diet of furtive deer.

title: Nassau Sets Up Bureau to Speed Processing of Major Crime Cases in Courts
description: MINEOLAIn an effort to increase the speed of processing major crimes and to restrict plea bargaining in these cases, the Nassau County District Attorney's Office has established a Major Offense Bureau.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, Sept. 7, 1975

title: False Poets and Real Poets
description: The depression depresses poetry, like everything else. Publishers say they can't afford verse, but at the same time they put outunforgivably the pathetic and illiterate efforts of religious amateurs, which they hope to sell to equally pathetic and illiterate readers. The editors at Doubleday know that this is not poetry:

title: End of P.S.A.L. Indoor Track Ends an Educational Experience
description: The elimination of the Public Schools Athletic League indoor track and field program, part of the league's overall budget cut from the Board of Education, is perhaps the most devastating blow ever to hit the city's sports system.

title: Scientists Say Age of Aquarius Is Childhood
description: Despite, or perhaps because of, the rational and technological nature of American society, there has been an extraordinary growth in the popularity of astrology. Millions of Americans, with varying degrees of commitment and seriousness, are devotees or believers. As a result, group of prominent scientists has just issued a statement deploring the trend and insisting that there is no rational basis for astrology.

title: The Democrats Will Pick A Candidate, Eventually
description: WASHINGTONWhat shape is the Democratic party in for 1976? Perhaps the better question is, does the Democratic party have any shape at all this fall as a big flock of littleknown candidates gets ready to migrate through the primaries next spring.

title: The Nation
description: LOS ANGELESGovernment officials expect that sometime next week the 100,000th Vietnamese will leave a refugee camp and enter American society.

title: Yunich Is Accused Of Hiding Surplus For Transit Agency
description: The Institute for Public Transportation, a privately financed organization, contended yesterday that David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, had hidden a $34.8million surplus expected this year.

title: Legal Help for the Police
description: MINEOLAA legal bureau to advise members of the Nassau County Police Department in legal and quasilegal matters that pertain to and affect law enforcement has been established through a Federal grant.

title: Marcos Outlines Campaign for More Control Over U. S. Bases
description: MANILA, Sept 6 The United States and the Philippines have begun informal talks designed to give the Philippines more control over the important American air and navy bases here, President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today.

title: Russians Climb Mt. Rainier
description: PARADISE LODGE, Ore., Sept. 7 (UPI)Russian mountaineers have scaled 14,400foot Mount Rainier, national park rangers said today. The climb was completed Friday and is the second phase of an exchange between Soviet and American climbers. American mountaineers climbed in the Pamir range last year as guests of the Russians.

title: Defeat by Browns First in Preseason
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 7After four straight victories, the New York Giants lost an exhibition game today, 2420, to the Cleveland Browns, in the unlikely setting of the University of Washington's Husky Stadium, which was only about onethird filled, fewer than 20,000 spectators. It made Cleveland's exhibition wonlost record 23

title: Green's 264 Wins Golf by 3
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 7 (AP)Hubert. Green surged to a sixunderpar 64, overtook John Schroeder in the stretch, and captured the $100,000 Southern open golf tournament today by three strokes.

title: FED SHIFTS PLAN ON EQUAL CREDIT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Retailers, bankers and others who deny credit to women would not be required to explain the reasons for the denial under proposed regulations for enforcement of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, which were issued today by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: EARLY FORECAST ON CORN REDUCED
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 7A further decline in the 1975 corn harvest was predicted today by one of the nation's leading private forecasters.

title: Gen. Georgi I. Khetagurov, A Top Soviet Commander
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 7 (UPI)Gen. Georgi I. Khetagurov, a top military commander, has died, the newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda said today. He was 72 years old.

title: New Vote Act Called Tonic for Both Major Parties
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7Encouraging signs for the future for this country's longailing political parties were reported this weekend in papers presented at the annual meeting of the American Political Science Association.

title: HAIG AJAMIAN
description: Haig Ajamian, who retired as chief of the documents and serials division of the City College library died Thursday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

title: Israel Shopping for Arms To Meet Changes in Sinai
description: Israeli arms procurement in the United States is about to accelerate, focusing on weapons to cope with the change in the military situation in the Middle East caused by the signing last week of an agreement on Sinai.

title: CHARLES H. STAPPER
description: Charles H. Stapper, vice president of the Austin Tobacco Company of Greeneville, Tenn., died Saturday of a heart attack at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 29 Alden Court, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Trenton Water Supply Is Near Normal
description: Nearly normal water service was restored to most Trenton residents yesterday, but businesses and industrial plants will continue to be restricted in water use at least unti tomorrow, unless they arrange for private supplies, city officials reported.

title: Authoritarian Rule Gains Wide Acceptance in India
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 7Two months ago, when the Government of the world's most populous democracy declared a state of emergency and began arresting thousands of its opponents, there were confident predictions that the new authoritarian position would not be tolerated.

title: A Toast to Manhattan
description: Elderly New Yorkers are often heard to mourn the glories of yesteryear. True, in the early 1900's the city was not in financial distress; but it was drearylooking town.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: The State Division on Aging said that its planned ombudsman program for elderly nursinghome patients. originally scheduled to begin operating on Aug. 1, was now expected to go into operation later this month.

title: City Schools Open Today, Face a Strike Tomorrow
description: The city's public schools will open for the new term this morning facing the possibility of a teachers' strike tomorrow and with overall educational prospects the gloomiest in many years because of the fiscal crisis.

title: Shipping/Mails
Spassky Says Soviet Is Balking Marriage To a Frenchwoman
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 7 (AP) Boris Spassky, the former world chess champion, plans to marry a French woman in Moscow, but she has been told to leave the country before the scheduled wedding date.

title: Chavez and Teamsters Intensify Fight
description: SALINAS, Calif., Sept. 7The job of the cortadore, the man who cuts lettuce from its thick roots, is hard work, even for the young men with strong backs who toil in the broad green fields of the Salinas Valley.

title: 12 Killed in Lebanon
description: Twelve people were reported taken from a bus in Tripoli, Lebanon, and shot to death by gunmen from the nearby town of Zgharta in a renewal of communal fighting. Page 3.

title: Hunter Gets 20th Victory On Shutout
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 7Under the impeccable direction of Catfish Hunter, the Yankees got their act together at Memorial Stadium today and defeated the Baltimore Orioles. 20.

title: JOSEPH FARKAS
description: Joseph Farkas, who had been chief historian for the Army Munitions Command, died of a heart attack last Tuesday while visiting Oxford, England. He was 63 years old, and formerly lived in Maplewood, N.J.

title: TV: Barbary Coast and Phyllis Bow
description: The explanation is familiar: Attempting to evaluate an entire television series on the basis of one episode, particularly the first, is patently unfair. But the new season, heralded by weeks of publicity, does generate curiosity, and the networks and reviewers once again perform their elaborate rituals on the perimeter of a gigantic nonevent. The fact is, according to the researchers at NBC, that 56 million homes, or 127 million people, will watch some part of network programing tonight in these United States of America. Some attention must, presumably, be paid.

title: Sudan Asks Flood Aid.
description: GENEVA, Sept. 7 (Reuters) The Sudan appealed today for emergency aid for about 75,000 homeless flood victims in central and eastern Sudan, the United Nations Disaster Relief office here announced.

title: A List of Suburban Cooking Schools
description: Like the cooking schools in New York City and on Long Island, which were listed Saturday, the schools in Westchester County and in nearby Connecticut towns cater to every taste. And it turns out to be a rather moveable feast: Some of the instruction takes place in the student's home, some in the instructor's, and other classes are held in adulteducation kitchens. The fact that a course is included in this list is not intended as an endorsement.

title: ROSA F. ROSENSTEIN
description: Rosa Fetner Rosenstein died yesterday in Tel Aviv at the age of 94. She and her husband, Max, founded the Myrtle Knitting Mills in Brooklyn in 1902.

title: Meadowlands in Midst of a Building Boom
description: SECAUCUSWorkmen put the finishing touches on the tennis court surfaces Wednesday, and the swimming pool should be delivered in the next couple of days.

title: About New York
description: The two bits that used to buy a shave and a haircut has become a popular coin in town. In New York, the place that once boasted fivecent cigars, fortwocentsplain, the neckelodeon and the fiveandtencent store, the quarter has become one of the more common building blocks of expenditure.

title: China Cites Trade Growth
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 7, Reuters)  The volume of China's foreign trade grew by seven and a half times from 1952 to 1974, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: Fateful Day in Albany
description: As the State Legislature reconvenes today, its agenda is simple and compellingto give quick approval to the package proposed by the Municipal Assistance Corporation. Such action now offers the only hope of preventing the catastrophe of New York City's default.

title: Boston Tests Magnet Schools Today to Lure Students
description: BOSTON, Sept. 7A new approach to desegregation, aimed at creating socalled magnet schools with programs so attractive that both black and white students are drawn to them voluntarily, will begin its first largescale test here when the schools open tomorrow.

title: . . . to World Stagflation
description: Still unclear is how much additional help will be reaching the poor nations as a result of Secretary of State Kissinger's plan, presented at the special session of the United Nations and further developed by Treasury Secretary Simon. The plan would make it possible for the United States to propose a substantial increase in benefits to the developing countries through international agencies without requiring the President to go to Congress for large appropriations.

title: Segregation Forces Work Behind Scenes in the South
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 7Although the battle over school desegregation has shifted from the South to the North, subtle new forms of discrimination now threaten the progress made in the South since the integration struggle began 18 years ago at Central High School in Little Rock, Ark.

title: Reds Clinch Crown In Record Fashion
description: Manager Sparky Anderson and his amazing Cincinnati Reds will have more than three weeks to get ready for next month's National League championship playoffs. The Big Red Machine, which has been flattening all opposition for the last three months, clinched its third Western Division title in four years with an 84 victory over the San Francisco Giants at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati.

title: 2,000 Hospital Employes Facing Dismissals in City
description: Dismissal notices will be received by 1,200 health and hospital's corporation employes on or about next Friday and 800 more will receive such notices Sept. 19, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr., president of the corporation.

title: PERSON IS SINGULAR ON JAZZ SAXOPHONE
description: It Often seems that the repertory of standard pop songs among contemporary jazz saxophonists is limited to I Remember April, Green Dolphin Street and Body and Soul. So it is a refreshing experience to find in Houston Person a saxophonist who not only knows that there are lot of other songs but also plays them in a way which does credit to both the original tune and to his own sensitivity as an improviser.

title: 6 Ferris Wheel Riders Finish Record Setting
description: LONG BRANCH, Sept. 7 (UPI)Six Monmouth County teenagers, who set a world record for continuous ferris wheel rides a week ago, finished their riding today amid cheers and applause from waiting families and friends.

title: Killanin, Drapeau Discuss TV Snag
description: LONDON, Sept. 7 (UPI)Lord Killanin, president of the International Olympic Committee, met today with Montreal Mayor Jean Drapeau in a bid to settle a dispute over television rights to the 1976 Olympics. The dispute threatens to black out coverage for countries outside North America.

title: Missing Brooklyn Girl Found, 3 Men Held on Rape Charges
description: A 21yearold Brooklyn woman who had been missing since she went shopping with her family last Friday night was found last night by the police in the back seat of a car. She told the police she had been held captive by three men who robbed her and forced to perform sex acts, the police reported.

title: Dr. David Tanchester, Innovator In Hospital Dentistry, Dies at 78
description: Dr. David Tanchester, chief of the dental service at the Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx for 50 years, died at the hospital Saturday. He was 78 years old and lived at the Beth Abraham Hospital.

title: Bradshaw Ailing After Steelers Win
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 (AP) Terry Bradshaw, Pittsburgh's starting quarterback, entered a hospital today for checks on a rundown feeling, diluting a bit the pleasure felt by Coach Chuck Noll about his Steelers' 2413 victory over the New Orleans Saints last night.

title: Canadian Riders Take Prix des Nations Event
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 7Canada's riders turned in a faultless performance today to win the final event of the Junior International jumping competition, the Prix des Nations.

title: Article 3  No Title
Bond Traders Made Wary By Surge in Money Supply
description: The sharp and unexpected upturn in the nation's money supply$2.6 billion in the banking week ended Aug. 27has given credit market participants an additional set of questions to wrestle with. Despite the fact that weekly changes in the money supply currency in circulation plus checkingaccount balancesare subiect to revision and do not, in themselves, presage a new trend, the credit markets reacted nervously last Friday to the latest Federal Reserve report.

title: G.O.P. Dispute Imperils Visit by Ford to Jersey
description: TRENTON, Sept. 7A simmering intraparty dispute involving disbursement of the money to be raised by President Ford at a Republican fundraising appearance in New Jersey next month was disclosed today by top party leaders in the state.

title: Memorial Services
description: MEADMeserole F., of Starr Ridge Road, Brewster. N.Y., who died Sept. 2, 1975. Memorial services will be held Tuesday, 11 A.M., Sept. 9, 1975, at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Brewster, N.Y.

title: LAMAR OTTSEN
description: WEBSTER GROVES, Mo., Sept. 7 (AF)Lamar Ottsen, chairman of the speedskating committee of the United States Olympic Committee, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at O'Hare Airport in Chicago. He was 62 years old.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BARD The Way I Feel is the title of an hourlong program of Nikki Giovanni reading her poetry with Billy Taylor and his orchestra and a chorus of three, including Cissy Houston. The program will be in Central Park's Delacorte Theater and begins at 8 P.M. today.

title: Bridge:
description: A spot card below honor rank can occasionally determine the fate of an important contract. On the diagramed deal, played in a rubber bridge game at the Gotham Club, 27 West 72d Street, West's club nine was the key to successful defense against five clubs.

title: 4 WOMEN BECOME EPISCOPAL PRIESTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Four women were ordained to the Episcopal priesthood today in an unsanctioned service that appeared certain to intensify the protracted conflict over the issue of women's ordination.

title: Furniture of Natural Wood: It's a Sight for Sore City Eyes
description: New Yorkers, who can't see the forests because of the city's concrete carpeting, are in better luck when it comes to looking for the treesor at least for wood that brings the outdoors indoors with its pristine beauty intact.

title: Cost of Driving a Car Rises by 14% in Year
description: DETROIT, Sept. 7 (UPI)Inflation and the rising price of gasoline have pushed up the cost of driving the family car by 14 per cent in the last year.

title: Article 1  No Title
Death Toll in Turkish Quake Now at 1,700
description: LICE, Turkey, Sept. 7 (Reuters)  The death toll in the earthquake that devastated part of eastern Turkey rose today to at least 1,700 as dazed survivors began staggering away from this wrecked town.

title: Namath Starts in 3531 Victory By GERALD ESKENAZI
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 7 Dramatically, Joe Namath made a powerful effort in his first start for the Jets since last year before limping off the field to roars of delight from most of the proRedskin crowd tonight.

title: Deaths
description: Applebaum, Samuel

title: PORTUGAL IS CALM AFTER TENSE DAYS
description: LISBON, Sept. 7This capital was calm today at the close of a politically stormy weekend that began with the fall from power of the controversial Gen. Vasco Goncalves and ended with the resignation of the Cabinet he had headed as Premier.

title: Oil Boom Spawns Disorder in Isfahan
description: ISFAHAN, Iran  In the central Iranian city of Isfahan, famous for its old mosques, worries seem to abound these days.

title: Tokyo Aide Plans to Renew Talks With Chinese on Pact
description: TOKYO, Sept. 7 (AP)Foreign Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said today he planned to meet Chiao Kuanhua, the Chinese Foreign Minister, in New York in late September to try to break the deadlock in the JapaneseChinese peace treaty talks.

title: In Memoriam
description: EDWARDSGordon F. Today and everyday. my best belovedest, forever. Suzie.

title: Inadequate Approach . . .
description: The annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in Washington last week have cleared away some of the underbrush blocking a joint approach by the nonCommunist world to what John N. Turner, Canada's Finance Minister, rightly called the crucial questions of our ageinflation, unemployment, Poverty and the future of the third world.

title: College Faculty Members Said to Lose to Inflation
description: DALLAS (UPI)In spite of increases in pay, college faculty members this year lost ground economically for the second consecutive year, according to the American Association of University Professors' Annual Report on the Economic Status of the Profession.

title: New Zealand Election Bringing Showdown in Leadership Styles
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sept. 7When New Zealanders go to the polls on Nov. 29 they will in fact vote for parties, not personalities, but whatever party wins will have a Prime Minister who will be a departure from the norm.

title: G.O.P. Dispute Involves Funds for Ford Dinner
description: TRENTON, Sept. 7A simmering Intraparty dispute involving disbursement of the money to be raised by President Ford at a Republican fundraising appearance in New Jersey next month was disclosed today by top party leaders in the state.

title: Quake Hits Yugoslavia
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 7 (AP)  A medium  strength earthquake caused minor damage but no casualties today in northwestern Yugoslavia, the Zagreb Seismological Institute reported.

title: How a Classical Music Fan Bought Station WNCNFM
description: Dr. Jesse Werner describes himself as a stereo enthusiast who likes to bathe in classical music while working or reading at home, so he was as dejected as thousands of others when the classical radio Station WNCNFM gave way last November to WQIVFM, a rock station.

title: Hiccups Blamed for Wreck
description: MANHATTAN, Kan., Sept. 7 (AP)Jimmy Rhodes, 27 years old, of Clay Center, and his wife, Christine, 21, received head cuts yesterday when their car struck a utility pole. Mr. Rhodes told the police he had blacked out, while holding his breath to get rid of the hiccups.

title: FORD NONPLUSSED ON PISTOL EPISODE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7President and Mrs. Ford, smiling and apparently relaxed, talked briefly at a party tonight about an episode in which a woman pointed a loaded gun at Mr. Ford Friday.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: We recently printed a recipe for a chili dish made with cubed beet and without tomatoes and stated that, to our minds, this was the true and genuine Southwest version.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: 4 KILLED, 8 HURT IN 2CAR COLLISION
description: HOWELL TOWNSHIP, Sept. 7Four persons were killed and two others were critically injured in a twocar collision last night that forced the Freehold Area Hospital to declare its first emergency since it opened in Monmouth County three years ago.

title: Budget Cuts Will Mean Bigger Classes And Less Personal Aid for City Pupils
description: The city's 1.1 million public school pupils will return to school today and encounter a new set of ABC's  Austerity, Budget cuts and Curtailed services.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Symphony Hits Audience Where It Lives
description: Generally speaking, lowincome New Yorkers do not go to concert halls to hear symphony orchestras. One symphony orchestra, however, specializes in coming to them.
