title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
To Nurses, the Runway Was an Unreal World
description: There's been a lot of talk lately that women attending conferences don't want to see fashion shows. The talk isn't necessarily true, especially when the fashion show has a twist, and the women attending the conference spend most of their time in far more serious pursuits, such as the nursing care of cancer patients.

title: Red Cross Wins at Belmont and Pays $10
description: With Belmont Park's con cessionaires doing a rushing business catering to the family trade yesterday and chalk players watching favorites lose in all nine races, Dixiana's Red Cross went about the business of collecting her fattest paycheck of the year.

title: CITY IS RATED HIGH IN TEACHER PAY
New Criminal Code Proposal Assailed
description: The American Civil Liberties Union says that parts of a pending revision of the United States Criminal Code are designed to perpetuate secrecy and stifle protest.

title: 4 Killed and 2 Injured In Jersey Car Collision
description: Four persons were killed and two were critically injured in a twocar collision yesterday on State Highway 33 near Fairfield Road in Howell Township. N. J.

title: Opera: Daughter of the Regiment
Czech Star's Defection Is Criticized by Family
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 7 (AP)We are crushed, Martina Navratilova's stepfather said today when a reporter told him that his tennis star stepdaughter had asked for asylum in the United States.

title: ROSA F. ROSENSTEIN
description: Rosa Fetner Rosenstein died yesterday in Tel Aviv at the age of 94. She and her husband, Max, founded the Myrtle Knitting Mills in Brooklyn in 1902.

title: Yonkers College Student Is Named Miss America
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 7 (AP) Miss New York, Tawny Elaine Godin, an 18yearold pianist from Yonkers whose family roots in America date back three centuries, was crowned Miss America 1976 here last night.

title: Britain, Short of Coal, Imports From Vietnam
description: LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP) Britain, whose rich coal fields fueled the Industrial Revolution, is temporarily short of coal and is importing thousands of tons from Vietnam, the National Coal Board said today.

title: DR. F. G. BLOEDORN, RADIOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Fernando G. Bloedorn, professor of therapeutic radiology at Tufts Medical School, died Saturday in New England Medical Center in Boston, where he was chief of that service. He was 61 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two New Jersey residents drowned and two were rescued when a fishing boat the four were in capsized Saturday in the ocean off Mattituck on Long Island. The two persons who drowned were Otha McCorvey, 51 years old, and Eular McMichael, 49, both of Jersey City. Mrs. McMichael's husband, Norman, 44, and Joseph Lewis, 38, of Bayonne were rescued.

title: Purchasing Agents Cite August Gains And Inflation Fear
description: The business recovery continues to chug along at a steady pace, although an unwelcome return of price increases gives cause for concern, according to the August report of the National Association of Purchasing Management, released over the weekend.

title: Vassar Enlarging Library
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 7 (AP)The Vassar College Library is building an addition that, with equipment and furnishings, will cost more than $3.5million. Scheduled for completion in the fall of 1976, it is intended to give the library, which now owns 475,000 books, space for 178,000 more and better facilities for storing and displaying manuscripts.

title: JOSEPH MONITTO
description: Joseph Monitto, founder and president of MonitorBoxart Corporation, maker of precision parts for the aircraft industry, died Saturday of a heart ailment at his home in Centre Island, L.I. He was 58 years old.

title: Ada Mei Fan Is Bride of Peter Warsaw
description: Ada Mel Fan, a cum laude graduate in June of Radcliffe College, was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Carlton Warsaw, head of the music department at the Brooks School in North Andover, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Donald R. Cutler performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. Joseph of Arimathea in Elmsford. N. Y.

title: Modesty on Newsstands Is Tried
description: On the newsstands operated by the Eastern Newsstand Corporation the men's (girlie or nudie or skin) magazines are all where we have gotten used to seeing them, right in front of the cash register. Their titles show, but now the blatant nudity on their covers is modestly covered by paper sleeves. They're banded, in the jargon of the magazine business.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: School Buses in Louisville Will Carry Guards Today
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 7Louisville and Jefferson County, still reacting to the shock of antibusing riots, looked forward nervously today to the start tomorrow morning of their first full week of courtordered busing of black and white schoolchildren between the city and its suburbs.

title: Pro Football Scoring
New Ballet Adds Little to Fete at Edinburgh
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 6The first performance at the King's Theater of Peter Wright's new ballet, El Amor Brujo, scarcely added luster to this year's Edinburgh Festival and is unlikely to occupy a significant position In the history of Britain's Royal Ballet. Yet this week's season of the Royal Ballet's smaller company, which has never been seen in the United States, was definitely a success, and the performances, each one led by Rudolf Nureyev and Lynn Seymour, guest artists, have been festival sellout.

title: British Troops in Ulster Blow Up Border Bridges
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 7 (UPI)  British army engineers started blowing up bridges leading to the Irish Republic today in what the army said was an attempt to halt armed incursions by guerrillas.

title: Welfare Rent Scale Modified by State; Cuts Are Assailed
description: A new maximum welfare rent schedule has been ordered by the state to take effect Oct. 1, and Community Action for Legal Services has decried a cut in allowances for single persons on home relief in New York City.

title: CHARLES H. STAPPER
description: Charles H. Stapper, vice president of the Austin Tobacco Company of Greeneville, Tenn., died Saturday of a heart attack at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 29 Alden Court, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: School Negotiations
description: The city's fiscal crisis has loomed over the teacher negonations from the start, but over the weekend it became a major factor in the talks. As one participant put it yesterday; The peculiar transterence of fiscal authority from elected officials to persons unknown was threatening the school system with a strike that both sides were struggling to avoid.

title: Melted Popsicle
description: In one of New York's lesser urban vicissitudes, bids are being taken on the New York Cultural Centerthe tiny popsicle palace on Columbus Circle that has had a brief, checkered career in the city's artistic life and is now for sale to anyone who wants it.

title: COMMUNIST FAIR A BIG HIT IN ITALY
description: FLORENCE, Italy, Sept. 7With the help of tortillas, pizza, posters and pop, the Italian Communist party is attracting thousands to a national festival here in hopes of further enflaming its acceptability.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ending Epidemics: In India, Flood Control Is the Best Medicine
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 7A flash flood on the Ganges River has paralyzed the economy of Patna, capital of Bihar State, and has set in motion the factors responsible for perpetuating cholera, typhoid fever, hepatitis, amoebic dysentery and other diseases endemic to the region. Indian public health experts consider floods largely responsible for seasonal variations in cholera and other infections.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1975

title: Westclox Plant Strike Ends
description: PERU, Ill., Sept. 7 (UPI)About 100 striking machinists agreed to a new contract today, ending a fourweek walkout that has idled 1.300 workers at the Westclox plant here. The vote by members of Local 1629 of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers was not disclosed. The union went on strike Aug. 10 after more than eight months of negotiations failed to bring accord on pension plan provisions.

title: Union Charges H.R.A. Discriminates Against Civil Service in Dismissals
description: The Human Resources Administration was accused last week of abusing regular employes by dismissing 300 or more Civil Service case workers while keeping highsalaried provisionals earning more than $5million a year on the payroll.

title: Books of The Times
description: In the long run, predictably, John Kenneth Gaibraith's new book, Money. Whence It Came, Where It Went, is not so much the definition and history its title leads one to expect as it is a diagnosis of our present economic ills. Or more precisely, an indictment of economic policy under the Nixon Administration and a set of prescriptions for future economic planning. For the economically sophisticated who wish to know where Professor Galbraith stands these days: his indictment takes Mr. Nixon's advisers to task for failing to compensate for the shortcoming of the Keynesian system that is, for failing to impose the necessary wage and price controls that he judges necessary in the light of the current wage price spiral and the difficulty of cutting government spending and raising taxes. As for his prescriptions for the future: Mr. Galbraith believes that (1) monetary, as opposed to fiscal, policy has about had it as a tool in economic management; (2) the balancing factor in economic management will have to be the national budget, and the decisive need here is to overcome its presently fatal inelasticity for dealing with excess demand; (3) Direct wage and price control where there is market power is inevitable, market power at present being what strong corporations and strong unions wield; (4) Monetary and economic management are inextricably a part of the larger problem of income distribution in the modern economy; (5) Planning for the supply and conservation of use of important products and services will, increasingly, be an aspect of monetary and economic management; and (6) the problem of instability in international exchanges will recur; no more in the future than in the past will unpredictability seem a solution.

title: 3 NATIONS LEAD IN JOBLESS HELP
description: PARIS, Sept. 5  Canada, West Germany and Japan lead the nonCommunist industrial world in benefits to the unemployed, according to a survey conducted by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Baby Alive After Transfusion That Her Parents Opposed
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 7 (UPI)A surviving twin infant given a blood transfusion over the objections of her parents, who are members of the Jehovah's Witnesses sect, clung to life today.

title: LEON TULCHIN
description: Leon Tulchin, founder and president of the Tulnoy Lumber Company of Brooklyn, the Bronx and New Jersey, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 71 years old and lived here.

title: Argument Leads Girl To Swim in the Hudson
description: A 17yearold girl who had an argument with her boyfriend Saturday night, according to the police, leaped into the Hudson River at 96th Street and swam more than two miles to 50th Street. where she was pulled out by the Police Department's Unit 4 an hour after the plunge.

title: Deaths
description: Applebaum, Samuel

title: In Memoriam
description: EDWARDSGordon F. Today and everyday, my best belovedest, forever. Susie.

title: SOME MINERS BEGIN RETURNING TO WORK
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Monday, Sept 8 (AP)  Miners reported to work early today at several southern West Virginia coal mines, but it was uncertain how widespread the return to work would be.

title: BENJAMIN MALTZ
description: Benjamin Maltz, president and founder of CenterMaltz and Associates Consulting Engineers, died Saturday at Mountl Sinai Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 70 Rice Avenue, Staten Island, and had offices there and at 335 Broadway.

title: Mozambique Leader Is Wed
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Sept. 7 (AP)Samora Machel, President of newly independent Mozambique, was married today to Grace Simbine, the country's Minister of Education and Culture. A number of other government officials and dignitaries attended the ceremony. It was the second marriage for Mr. Machel, whose first wife died several years ago.

title: Fiscal Crisis at a Glance
description: Because its budget is out of balance, and because incoming revenues flow erratically, the city must borrow hundreds of millions of dollars each month to meet expenses, including shortterm borrowing obligations that come due. But banks and other investors have refused, since early this year, to buy the city's notes and bonds.

title: 12 Taken Off Bus and Killed in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 7Twelve persons were reported tonight to have been taken from a passenger bus in the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli and slain by gunmen from the neighboring town of Zgharta.

title: HAIG AJAMIAN
description: Haig Ajamian, who retired as chief of the documents and serials division of the City College library died Thursday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

title: Scaglione's Guitar Recital Stresses Informal Styling
description: There was an informal, almost improvisational quality to Ronald Scaglione's guitar recital Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. In lieu of a printed program, Mr. Scaglione announced each number before he played it. There was no particular order or grouping, just an olla podrida of familiar guitar tidbits by Milan, Torroba, Sor, Tarrega, Bach and VillaLobos.

title: Huey Long's Legacy, 40 Years After Death
description: BATON ROUGE, Sept. 7Here lies Louisiana's great son Huey Pierce Long, says the inscription on his grave in front of the Capitol he built, an unconquered friend of the poor who dreamed of the day when the wealth of the land would be spread among all the people.

title: SIMON VOICES HOPE ON OIL ANDINFLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) Lowering oil prices and the inflation rate are longterm projects, but can be accomplished, Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today on NBC's Meet the Press.

title: Uganda Acts on Elephants
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 7 (UPI)Uganda has banned all elephant hunting, effective immediately, radio Uganda said yesterday. Skyrocketing ivory prices have caused officials to fear that the world's last great elephant herds could be wiped out in a decade.

title: City Schools Open Today, Face a Strike Tomorrow
description: The city's public schools will open for the new term this morning facing the possibility of a teachers' strike tomorrow and with overall educational prospects the gloomiest in many years because of the fiscal crisis.

title: Patriots' Plunkett Injured, Will Be Out for 3 Weeks
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 7 (AP)Jim Plunkett, the New England Patriots' star quarterback, suffered a left shoulder separation tonight in a National Football League exhibition game against the San Diego Chargers.

title: Rustlers Roam Range After HighPriced Crude Oil
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 4The oil industry's axiom that the higher the price of crude oil, the more incentive there is to find it, has produced a corollary: The higher the price of crude oil, the more incentive there is to steal it.

title: Drivers' Title Won By Lauda
description: NIONZA, Italy Sept. 9 (AP) Clay Regazzoni of Switzerland gave Ferrari a victory in its home race, the Italian Grand Prix, and Niki Lauda of Austria gave the Italian factory its first world drivers' championship since 1962 today. Lauda finished third, behind the defending world champion, Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, to become the seventh Ferrari driver to take the title, but the first since John Surtees of England.

title: A Popular Champion
description: The stocky, darkeyed player who won the men's singles title yesterday at the United States Open tennis championships in Forest Hills is one of the most popular competitors in the game. Not only opponents, but also officials and fans throughout out the world have come to admire Manuel Orantes, the 26yearold lefthander from Barcelona, Spain. His infectious smile, constant cheerfulness whether winning or losing and gracious Latin manners on and off the court have given him a reputation to complement his racquet artistry. Even when he is capturing tournament after tournamenteight on clay this yearhis foes find it difficult to vent their anger at a man who applauds their best shots, won't argue about close calls and purposely misses a point if he feels a wrong call has hurt his opponent.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: LEON TULCHIN
description: Leon Tulchin, founder and president of the Tulnoy Lumber Company of Brooklyn, the Bronx and New Jersey, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 71 years old and lived here.

description: By Reuters

title: DR. F. G. BLOEDORN, RADIOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Fernando G. Bloedorn, professor of therapeutic radiology at Tufts. Medical School, died Saturday in New England Medical Center in Boston, where he was chief of that service. He was 61 years old.

title: Music: Welcome Tenor
description: For its first presentation this season of Bizet's Carmen, given at the New York State Theater on Saturday night, the New City Opera introduced Kenneth Collins, a tenor making his debut with the company in the role of Don Jos

description: It is guesswork time again for New Yorkers who vote in the party primaries tomorrow. Perhaps 10 per cent of eligible voters will bother now that primaries have been shifted to an inconvenient time in Septemberafter a summer of noninformation and with so little lead time before the November election.

title: TALKS ARE PRESSED IN SCHOOL DISPUTES
description: TRENTON, Sept. 7 (UPI)School board officials and representatives of teachers associations held negotiations in several New Jersey communities today in an attempt to end. teachers strikes already under way and to avert others scheduled for school openings tomorrow.

description: GROTON, Conn., Sept. 5Luckily, the snappers have been running in the Thames River, and the cornfields along Gungywamp Road have been only lightly guarded.

title: Out witting Fish and Farmers Aids Groton Strikers
description: GROTON, Conn., Sept. 6Luckily, the snappers have been running in the Thames River, and the cornfields along Gungywamp Road have been only lightly guarded.

title: Administered Cost Inflation: Economists' Battle Heating
description: The recent wave of price increases announced in major industries such as steel and aluminum has sent a shiver down the spine of some of the nation's leading economists and has heated up an old debate about the power of big business to generate inflation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Nearly normal water service was restored to most Trenton residents, but businesses and industrial plants will continue to be restricted in water use at least until tomorrow, city officials reported.

title: Orantes Takes U.S. Open Title, Beating Connors by 64, 63, 63;
description: Like a matador taunting a bull, Manuel Orantes destroyed Jimmy Connors, 64, 63, 63, yesterday for the men's singles title in the United States Open tennis championships.

description: Striking lay teachers plan to increase their picket lines at five Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens as the first full week of the new fall term starts today.

title: CHINA IS PRESSING BIRTHCURB DRIVE
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 7Fortune cookies in Chinese restaurants in New York are unlikely to include this message: There are three sins against filial piety, having no offspring being the worst.

title: 12 Killed in Lebanon
description: Twelve people were reported taken from a bus in Tripoli, Lebanon, and shot to death by gunmen from the nearby town of Zgharta in a renewal of communal fighting. Page 3.

title: ZiffDavis in Magazine Research
description: Paul H. Chook, who suddenly departed the W. R. Simmons research operation in July, has been named to the newly created position of vice president for market planning and research of the ZiffDavis Publishing Company. The company says it is making a major commitment to magazine research and plans to take a leadership role in the field.

description: The Transit Police Department is now distributing to its men the profiles and pictures of suspected felons as it compiles a new rogue's gallery of the worst perpetrators of subway crimes.

title: Ayse Lutfiye Manyas Is Married to Robert Kenmore
description: Ayse Lutfiye Manyas and Robert H. Kenmore, former chairman of the Kenton Corporation, were married here Iast evening in the penthouse apartment of friends. The Rev. John Hammon of the Unitarian Church of All Souls performed the ceremony.

title: G.O.P. Picks Kansas City For Its 1976 Convention
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 7The Republican party's site selection committee voted unanimously tonight to hold the 1976 G.O.P. convention in Kansas City, Mo. The full national committee is expected to ratify the choice tomorrow.

title: Chavez and Teamsters Intensify Fight
description: SALINAS, Calif., Sept. 7The job of the cortadore, the man who cuts lettuce from its thick roots, is hard work, even for the young men with strong backs who toil in the broad green fields of the Salinas Valley.

title: ANDERSON PLEADS CITY'S CASE TODAY WITH FORD'S AIDES
description: Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader of the State Senate, will press on the Ford Administration in Washington today a proposal for Federal insurance for some municipal borrowing, then return to AIbany to try to pass a state program to help moneyshort New York City past its next brush with default.

title: LAMAR OTTSEN
description: WEBSTER GROVES, Mo., Sept. 7 (AP)Lamar Ottsen, chairman of the speedskating committee of the United States Olympic Committee, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at O'Hare Airport in Chicago. He was 62 years old.

title: Miss Fromme May Try to Act as Her Own Lawyer
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 7 (AP)  Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme will probably follow the lead of Charles Manson by attempting to serve as her own lawyer on a charge of trying to assassinate President Ford, her best friend says.

title: Manila Announces Testing Of PhilippineBuilt Missiles
description: MANILA, Sept. 7 (UPI)The Philippines testfired four rockets today in what the Government said was a successful experiment in Philippine development of ballistic missiles.

title: Fall Helps U.S.S.R. Take Riding Title
description: LUHMUEHLEN, West Germany, Sept. 2 (AP)Lucinda PriorPalmer of Britain won the European ThreeDay Equestrian Championship today ahead of Princess Anne, and the Soviet Union captured the team title after a fall in the final jumping event prevented the Britons from winning.

title: The Chiao Document
description: WASHINGTONThis is a big week for ChineseAmerican relations. The first official trade delegation from Peking has arrived, and is laying the groundwork far a major step forward in trade that will be the centerpiece of President Ford's visit to China, now planned for around Thanksgiving.

title: 350 Cyclists Tour Historic Spots in Jersey City
description: More than 350 bicyclists from New Jersey, New York and Connecticut took part in a tour that included the historical sites in downtown Jersey City, the abandoned Jersey Central Railroad yards, the waterfront and Liberty Park.

title: Angolan Refugees Arrive In Portugal on U.S. Flight
description: LISBON, Sept. 7 (UPI)Some 254 Portuguese refugees from Angola arrived in Lisbon tonight on an Americansponsored charter flight.

title: China Marking a Tibetan Anniversary, With Area Still Closed to Foreigners
description: PEKING, Sept. 7The 10th anniversary of the establishment of the socalled Tibetan Autonomous Region of China will be celebrated tomorrow, but with the area still closed to foreigners.

title: G.O.P. Picks Kansas City For Its 1976 Convention
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 7The Republican party's site selection committee voted unanimously tonight to hold the 1976 G.O.P. convention in Kansas City, Mo. The full national committee is expected to ratify the choice tomorrow.

title: Mets Are Routed By Cardinals, 124
description: The Mets ended their week of opportunity yesterday by taking a 124 pasting from the St. Louis Cardinals for their fourth defeat in six critical games, and by falling 7 games out of first place with 21 left to play.

title: EMHART SETS TENDER FOR MORE USM STOCK
description: The Emhart Corporation of Farmington, Conn., maker of builders' hardware and bottling machinery, announced, effective today, that it would make a tender offer to buy a million shares of the USM Corporation at $23 a share. With stick it now holds in USM, the nation's largest producer of shoemaking machinery, it would have a controlling interest, if the tender is successful.

title: Personal Finance: Maximum Social Security Benefits
description: When is the maximum Social Security pension not the same as the maximum a person about to retire can actually get? The answer to this question often dismays people on the verge of retirement. They discover that their maximum pensions will be much lower than those for people born later.

title: Treat You Like a Child
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept 7 (UPI)Lynette Fromme was described today by a jailer as eating a peanut butter and jelly sandwich and explaining that she had to confront President Ford because nobody was paying any attention to what she was saying.

title: A Night in the Pen at Midtown North
description: The blue unmarked sedan crawls along 10th Avenue, and out of the murky blackness appears a small figure, her babyfine white hair shimmering under a street lamp, her long bare legs emerging like Popsicle sticks from a baggy shirt that is the length of a man's pajama top.

title: RABIN SAYS SOVIET HURTS PEACE MOVE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (Reuters)  Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel said in an interview broadcast today that the Soviet Union was interfering with efforts to bring Peace to the Middle East.

title: Israel Shopping for Arms To Meet Changes in Sinai
description: Israeli arms procurement in the United States is about to accelerate, focusing on weapons to cope with the change in the military situation in the Middle East caused by the signling last week of an agreement on Sinai.

title: Change in Bentsen Strategy Indicated After Decline in Staff and Finances
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Benjamin L. Palumbo's sudden exit last Friday as director of Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen's Presidential campaign was attributed officially to personal reasons that nobody has yet chosen to explain. Whatever the reasons, the loss of Mr. Palumbo's promotional zeal and his New Jerseytrained savvy in bigcity Northern politics seems to mark a transition in the Texas Democrat's planning.

title: SCHWEIKER SEEKING INQUIRY ON KENNEDY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) Senator Richard S. Schweiker, Republican of Pennsylvania, is seeking to have the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence take a new look at the assassination of President Kennedy.

title: Georgia Flood Peril Ends
description: HELEN, Ga., Sept. 7 (UPI)A Unicoi Station State Park Spokesman said today that danger to this north Georgia community, which had been threatened with flooding from a leaky dam, was completely passed and called off an emergency alert. Technicians worked for three days to free jammed flood gates on the dam after seepage was discovered that could have meant a rupture in the clay structure and a flooding of Helen, two miles south. Divers freed the gates late yesterday and draining of the 50acre Unicoi Lake was begun.

title: TV: The Invisible Man
description: The Invisible Man, which makes its debut tonight on NBC at 8 P.M., is an exercise in witlessness so unrelenting that if one didn't know better, one might imagine that everybody associated with the program wanted it to turn out badly.

title: Army to Use Toxic Gasesin Alabama
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Sept. 7 The Army will start training 25 servicemen in the use of nerve gas and mustard gas. using live chemicals, at its Missile and Munitions Center and School at the Redstone Arsenal here next month.

title: World Football League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Air Canada Cutting Flights
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 7 (AP)Air Canada has announced a reduction of about 96 flights a week in domestic and international routes, effective tomorrow, because of declining passenger traffic. An airline spokesman said that the cutbacks, on 10 routes, would constitute less than 3 per cent of the airline's total flights.

title: Guardsmen in Boston for Busing Today
description: BOSTON, Sept. 7  National Guardsmen were called into Boston today to be held in readiness as hundreds of policemen called in sick in a contract dispute, with a hotly disputed courtordered busing program due to take effect tomorrow.

title: 3 Killed in Plane Crash
description: YARMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 7 (UPI)Three Maryland residents were killed in the crash of a twinengine plane attempting to land at Barnstable Municipal Airport last night. The State Police identified them as the pilot, Francisco Lopez of Silver Spring, Md., and Maria DeGartiez, 31 years old of Hyattsville, Md., and her daughter, Ofelia Lopez, 10.

title: The Americanization of Martina
description: Once they were the tired and the poor waving at the Statue of Liberty as they arrived, the women huddled in shawls. Martina Navratilova doesn't fit that immigrant image. In discussing her decision to defect to the United States from Czechoslavakia, the 18yearold tennis player displayed yesterday the casual rewards of having earned nearly $140,000 in prize money this year. She carried a Gucci shoulder bag and she wore Gucci loafers. She had on a thin brown sweater over a blue shirt and blue jeans. On her left wrist was an expensive gold watch, on her right several gold bracelets. She was shepherded by a Virginia Slims public relations person. Her manager has a Beverly Hills, Calif., address. All around her was the proper atmosphere of the West Side Tennis Club, where Manuel Orantes of Spain would shock Jimmy Connors for the men's singles title in the United States Open tournament. With her money and stature, she indeed had become too Americanized; as Czech tennis officials had complained. Too Americanized for them. But not for her. She's young and independent, not tired and poor, but she wanted what millions of immigrants before her wanted, she wanted what Czechoslovakia would not grant her.

title: Power Plant in Kansas Scrubs Pollutants From Dirty Coal
description: LA CYGNE, Kan.Incongruously situated in the middle of a lake on the Kansas Plain is a huge power plant whose example may help people in many other places breathe easier.

title: Sealyham Is Best at Tarrytown
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 7This seems to be the year of the Sealyham. For the fourth time in nine days, Ch. Dersade Bobby's Girl, the little Welsh import owned by Mrs. Dorothy Wimer of Churchtown, Pa., was gaited by Peter Green, also a native of Wales, to a bestinshow award. This time it was a Westchester, the East's most prestigious outdoor fixture, held at Lyndhurst, a National landmark, where a field of 2,619 turned out.

title: Japan Plans to Reorganize Her Troubled Oil Industry
description: TOKYO, Sept. 7The Japanese Government has embarked on a fundamental reorganization of the nation's financially troubled oil industry to make it more competitive with the major international oil companies.

title: Memorial Services
description: MEADMeserole F., of Starr Ridge Road, Brewster, N.Y., who died Sept. 2, 1975. Memorial services will be held Tuesday. 11 A.M., Sept. 9, 1975, at St. Andrew Episcopal Church, Brewster, N.Y.

title: Carter Wins in Midget
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 7 (AP)Pancho Carter captured the 23d Hut Hundred, this season's richest United States Auto Club midget race, today. Carter, the 1972 USAC midget champion, held a twosecond advantage over Bob Wente.

title: The Pardoner's Tale
description: There is a suddenness In the ending of summer. One day the sun, the air, the sea are different. The light goes unexpectedly early, and in the evening there is a Turner sky, clouds swirling on the horizon.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The National Transportation Safety Board will open public hearings today on the Eastern Airline jet crash that killed 113 persons at Kennedy International Airport on June 24.

title: Orr Is Reported Spurning W.H.A.
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 7 (AP)Bobby Orr, pro hockey's outstanding star, apparently has decided to spurn a $4million contract from the World Hockey Association and stay in the National Hockey League, the president of the W.H.A.'s Minnesota Fighting Saints said tonight.

title: FIRE OFFICIALS SAY CUTS HAVENT'T HURT
description: Fire Department officials say that the dismissal of nearly 900 fire fighters because of the city's fiscal crisis has had no significant impact on fire protection service so far, but that the burden on the remaining firemen has increased.

title: About New York
description: The two bits that used to buy a shave and a haircut has become a popular coin in town. In New York, the place that once boasted fivecent cigars, fortwocentsplain, the nickelodeon and the fiveandtencent store, the quarter has become one of the more common building blocks of expenditure.

title: U.S. PRESS IS PART OF SEOUL POLITICS
description: SEOUL, South KoreaThe article in the South Korean Government newspaper charged that distorted reports on Korea in American newspapers were rooted in the colonialism of the American white media.

title: Article 2  No Title
ORLEANS AND HAVENS SHARE PARK BILLING
description: Orleans, the rock group, and Richie Havens, the folk singer, contrasted without clashing Saturday at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park. Orleans, a quartet, appears to fit the stereotype pattern for a West Coast rock group. Dance with me/ I want to be your partner and If I was a king/ the throne would be love are the nottoo startling lyrics that come from the group, simple sentiments framed by light rock with nods at country, old blues, early rock, even reggae.

title: Geneva: First in War, Peace and Vermouth
description: Geneva has two major industriesthe care and feeding of international tourists and the care and feeding of international negotiators. In a more logical world, the two enterprises would be regarded as mutually exclusive; sensible leaders would recognize that the delights which attract the tourists serve only to distract and unnerve the negotiators.

title: Authoritarian Rule Gains Wide Acceptance in India
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 7Two months ago, when the Goveinment of the world's most populous democracy declared a state of emergency and began arresting thousands of its opponents, there Were confident predictions that the new authoritarian position would not be tolerated.

title: BENJAMIN MALTZ
description: Benjamin Maltz, president and founder of CenterMaltz and Associates Consulting Engineers, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 70 Rice Avenue, Staten Island, and had offices there and at 335 Broadway.

title: CITY IS RATED HIGH IN TEACHER PAY
description: New York City publicschool teachers are, on the average, better paid than their counterparts in other large cities, sand they rank at or near the top in major fringe benefits such as pensions, insurance and contributions to the union welfare fund. They also have the shortlest working day.

title: Libya Said to Annex an Area of Chad
description: LONDON, Sept. 7 (Reuters) The Sunday Times of London reported today that Libya had annexed part of northern Chad to develop uranium deposits she believes to be there.

title: Pact Ratified in Pawtucket
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 7 (AP)Municipal employes ratified a new contract with the city today, giving 385 workers a 20cent an hour raise and ending a threeday strike. However, Giovanni Folcarelli, a union leader, remained in jail where he was sentenced Friday to 60 days for contempt of court.

title: Amerace in Tender Offer For Anchor Coupling Shares
description: The Amerace Corporation of New York, an industrial hose maker, and the Anchor Coupling Company, Inc., of Illinois, a hoseassembly maker, said yesterday that Amerace would offer to buy all Anchor stock in a tender offer at $16 a share, making the deal worth $21.2million.

title: Army Sentries in Argentina Shoot 3 to Death in Error
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 7 (AP) Army sentries today shot and killed three young men they had mistaken for terror ists, the police reported.

title: Guardsmen in Boston for Busing Today
description: BOSTON, Monday, Sept. 8A hotly disputed courtordered busing program takes effect today with National Guardsmen standing by to help the police if need be.

title: ROBERT G. CALDER
description: Robert G. Calder, former executive vice president of Kesbec, Inc., a chain of gasoline service stations in the metropolitan area that was bought by Standard Oil Company (N.J.) with which he continued until his retirement, died Saturday in New Milford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Pawling, N.Y.

title: Bankers, in Key Role, Shun Spotlight
description: Although they have remained largely out of the spotlight during New York's fiscal crisis, three of the city's leading bankersDavid Rockefeller, chairof the Chase Manhattan Bank; William T. Spencer, president of First National City Bank, and Ellmore C. Patterson, chairman of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Companyhave played a deeply influential role in shaping the banking commuit's strategy.

title: HIGH COURT OPENS NEW TERM TODAY
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court is scheduled to open its fall term today with a heavy calendar that includes one of the most unusual issues ever to come before the justicesthe question of whether a judge's wife can participate in politics.

title: C.E. Ordered by State to Stop Dumping Toxic Waste
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation said yesterday that the General Electric Company would be prohibited' from dumping the toxic chemical PCB into the Hudson River from two upstate plants after Sept. 30, 1976.

title: ANDERSON PLEADS CITY'S CASE TODAY WITH FORD'S AIDES
description: Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader of the State Senate, will press on the Ford Administration in Washington today a proposal for Fedefal insurance for some municipal borrowing, then return to Albany to try to pass a state program to help moneyshort New York City past its next brush with default.

title: A List of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Hearings Opening Today on Kennedy Jet Crash That Killed 113
description: The crew of the Eastern Airlines jet that crashed at Kennedy International Airport June 24 had given themselves a cushion of extra air speed to cope with the vicious air currents known to be buffeting planes making landing approaches.

title: Seniors Title to Nagle
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Sept. 7 (AP)Kel Nagle Of Australia birdied three of the last seven holes in a comeback effort today and defeated Charles Sifford of the United States, 1 up, in the World Professional Seniors golf championship over the BideAWee Golf Club course.

title: A NEW SWISS STATE PROVOKES VIOLENCE
description: BERNE, Monday, Sept. 8 (Agence FrancePresse)Swiss policemen and groups. advocating autonomy clashed throughout the night after the third referendum proposal was defeated in just over a year on the creation of a new state.

title: U.N. TRADE TALKS MAY BE EXTENDED
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 7Shorn of the rhetoric it had earlier, the dialogue between rich and poor nations in the current special session of the General Assembly has quickly shown the complexity of the issues.

title: Watson Victor by 2 Strokes
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 7 Torn Watson, a 26yearold towhead who is learning every week how to cope with pressure, stood off a threat by Jack Nicklaus today and won the World Series of Golf by two strokes. Watson came through with two handsome clutch putts when a miss could have spelled disaster.

title: In Memoriam
description: SJOERLINGJussi. Though your voice was hushed IS years ago, its glorious sound still lives on. You will never really leave us. Amor ti vieta.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1975

title: Dredging Project Begins on Raritan
description: PERTH AMBOY, Sept. 8Work officially began today on dredging operations near here that will create a new deepwater cargo shipping facility at the site of the former Raritan Arsenal on the Raritan River in Middlesex County.

title: Trenton Plants to Reopen As Water Shortage Eases
description: TRENTON, Sept. 8Schools and industries will be permitted to reopen here tomorrow, further indicating the steady if shaky recovery of thsi city and its suburbs from the water shortage that hit the area last week when the local water system broke down.

title: Text of Nyquist's Letter to Chairman of HigherEducation Board Urging Tuition Fee
description: I am writing out of deep concern that the budgetary allocations available for financing City University expenditures for the 1975/76 academic year may not be sufficient to permit the university to continue to function effectively as an institution of higher learning.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY REJECTS BOND CUT
description: TRENTON, Sept. 8The state A.F.L.C.I.O. helped push an amendment through the State Assembly tonight that increased a proposed transportation bond issue by $40million over the objections of Governor Byrne.

title: James Gallagher, 54, Dies; Haskins & Sells Partner
description: James A. Gallagher, a partner of Haskins & Sells, the international public accounting firm, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home, 52 Bulson Road; Rockville Centre, L. I. He was 54 years old.

title: Women Score G.O.P. on Site
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) A group of Republican feininists criticized the Republican party today for deciding to hold its 1976 national convention in Missouria state that has not ratified the Equal Rights Amendment. Audrey R. Colour, Republican chairman of the National Women's Political Caucus, said the party should not reward the state for taking a stand in direct opposition to the Republican platform. The convention is to be held in Kansas City.

title: Shippers in Israel Say Suez Route Is Not Economical
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 8Politically, the newly won right to ship goods through the Suez Canal in foreign vessels has been hailed as a major Israeli gain, but from an economic standpoint, the Israel Shippers Council said today, it is not so attractive.

title: IncineratorConcern Suit Is Settled by Jersey City
description: NEWARK, Sept. 8Jersey City settled its civil suit against the North Jersey Incineration Company today for $500,000 in cash and the abrogation of a 17year garbagedisposal contract allegedly awarded on the basis of fraud and political kickbacks.

title: SADAT SAYS PACT HAS NO SECRETS
description: CAIRO. Tuesday. Sept. 9. (Reuters)  President Anwar elSadat says the EgyptianIsraeli agreement on Sinai does, not include any secret clauses nor was it a final settlement.

title: Justice Officials Bid Court Refuse Papers to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8The Justice Department contended today that Congress had ample reason to conclude that former President Richard M. Nixon would not be a trustworthy custodian, even temporarily, for his Presidential papers.

title: Voters Are Urged to Enter the Schools
description: Betty Dolen, the executive director of the city's Board of Elections, has urged all citizens entitled to vote in today's primary election to do so even if teachers strike the city's schools.

title: Congress Hears a Default Would Have Wide Effect
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 Bankers and brokers from across the country told Congress today that New York's fiscal plight already had increased rates for other cities and predicted that a default could make bonds unsalable, halt municipal construction and increase unemployment in other parts of the country.

title: V.A. Hospital in Ann Arbor Resumes Normal Routine
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 8 (UPI)The Veterans Administration hospital in Ann Arbor resumed a normal routine today, but under tightened security precautions, as the Federal Bureau of Investigation continued an inquiry into more than 50 recent mysterious cases of respiratory failure at the hospital, at least nine of which were fatal.

title: Nyquist Urges Imposition Of Tuition Fees at City U.
description: State Education Commission er Ewald Nyquist made public yesterday a call for charging all City University students tuition, with fulltime undergraduates to pay the same fees as State University students $650 a year for freshmen and sophomores, $800 a year for juniors and seniors.

title: Bethea Wins Fight On a Split Decision
description: Taking charge at the midway point of his mainevent match at the Felt Forum last night, Tom Bethea of Brooklyn scored a 10round split decision victory over Angel Oquendo of the Bronx in the first professional card at the Garden's auxiliary arena in nine months. It drew 1,922, paying $10.203.

title: . . . and One to Sustain
description: President Ford's Indicated willingness to accept a 45day extension of oil price controls removes any compelling reason for the Senate to vote tomorrow override his veto of continued controls. The national interest in fashioning a comprehensive program for energy conservation and development will best be served if Congress uses the proposed extension to cooperate with the White House in a gradual phaseout of controls, coupled with a dependable plan for reducing United States dependence on imported petroleum.

title: U.S. Open Had More of Everything
description: If one word can describe this year's United States Open tennis championships, it is more.

title: Louisville Busing Resumes as More Students Enroll
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 8The twoway busing of black and white school children between Louisville and its sub. urbs resumed uneventfully today after a weekend of violent protest by whites that resulted in injuries to at least 50 persons and led to 500 arrests. Each bus had a policeman or National Guardsman aboard.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Monday.

title: Fed Scales Down Rules Against Bias In Loans to Women
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) The Federal Reserve Board today published a sharply Scaleddown set of rules against sex discrimination in credit, prompting charges from women that it had sold out to the banking industry.

title: Missouri Upsets Alabama, 207
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. Sept. 8 (AP)  Missouri's unheralded Tigers, led by the power running of Tony Galbreth and an unrelenting defense, snapped secondranked Alabama's 22game regularseason winning streak with a stunning 207 upset tonight.

title: Frustration, Anger Mark Opening Day; 3 Schools Closed and Others Disrupted
description: Frustration and anger at the effects of budget cuts on school programs marked the opening yesterday of the city's 950 elementary, juniorhigh and seniorhigh schools.

title: One Name, 2 Teachers and One Is a Phony
description: For most of the last three years, Board of Education payroll and personnel records have listed two teachers named Malcolm B. Burman.

title: Why Chicago Is Solvent
description: CHICAGONaturally, New Yorkers proud of the importance of New York City to the nation and the world are mortified by its fiscal crisis.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: In a rush of poetic frenzy, Wayne Hanley of the Massachusetts Audubon Society writes in a recent newsletter that the spermy whale may still gyre and gimble in the wabe, if enough jojoba oil can be produced.

title: In Her 60's, She's Still Blondes' Cheerleader
description: She is somewhere in her sixties, yet she calls herself a girl. She thinks it's nice to be a sex object. She once held her salary down deliberately (to $25,000 a year) so as not to bruise her husband's ego. And she doesn't mind if a man picks up the check when she's invited him to a business lunch.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
SHOOTING GOES ON IN LEBANESE PORT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 8Sporadic street fighting continued this evening in the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli, where at least 31 lives have been lost in six days of violence, according to unofficial figures.

title: TV: Four Premieres of Comedy and Adventure
description: When the laugh track sounds as if it is on the verge of a nervous breakdown, the show is in trouble. Welcome Back, Kotter is in trouble. Set in a Brooklyn high school, the comedy is one of four new series having their television premiere this evening.

title: Former U.S. Financial Head Sentenced on Fraud Charges
description: SAN DIEGO. Sept. 8 (UPI)John B. Halverson, former president of United States Financial Inc., a real estate conglomerate, was sentenced to seven years in prison today on his no contest plea to fraud charges.

title: CAREY PLAN TO HELP CITY VOTED BY ASSEMBLY, 8070; SENATE TAKES UP DEBATE
description: ALBANY, Tuesday, Sept. 9 Governor Carey's emergency plan to hold off default in New York City was put to debate in the State Senate early this morning following passage by the Assembly last night.

title: Oilers Defeated By Colts, 2621
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 8 (AP)The Baltimore Colts broke out with 20 points in the second quarter and beat a disorganized Houston Oiler team, 2621, in a National Football League preseason game tonight.

title: TEACHERS VOTE TO STRIKE TODAY; A MILLION PUPILS HERE AFFECTED; SCHOOLS TO TRY TO REMAIN OPEN
description: The membership of the United Federation of Teachers voted yesterday to strike the city's 950 public schools this morning, a move that will disrupt the education, of more than a million pupils on the second day of the new term.

title: Canada's Cup Lead To Golden Dazy
description: DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP) Golden Dazy of the host Bayview Yacht Club took a 20 lead in the Canada's Cup yachting series today with a decisive victory over the challenger, Marauder of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club of Toronto.

title: ALFRED DUHRSSEN
description: Alfred Duhrssen, president of D. C. Properties, Inc., of Bronxvine, N.Y., and founder and retired president of Commercial Decal, Inc., of Mount Vernon, N.Y., died Sunday in New York Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 16 Sussex Avenue, Bronxville.

title: Soviet Parley Admits Dissident Scholar
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 8Pressure from American and other Western scientists was credited today with obtaining the reversal of a Soviet Government decision to bar a Soviet mathematician from an international seminar on computer technology in the Georgian capital of Tbilisi.

title: AIRLINE FARE RISE MEETS OPPOSITION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) The Council on Wage and Price Stability said today Unit ed Airlines should not be allowed to raise passenger fares 4.2 per cent to rflect anticipatd increases in jet fiel costs.

title: Prelate Charges Border Patrol Impedes Farm Labor Elections
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 8The Most Rev. Roger Mahony, chairman of California's new Agricultural Labor Relations Board, has sent a strongly worded telegram to Attorney General Edward H. Levi urging an investigation into acts of the United States Border Patrol that he said were endangering the conduct of the state's first set of farm labor union representation elections.

title: Surgery for Stukes
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 (AP)Charlie Stukes, the starting left cornerback for the Los Angeles Rams, will have to undergo surgery for an injured knee and could be nut for the National Football League season.

title: Free License Plates Curbed
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 8 (AP)  License plates with the initials PS, taxfree to California banks since 1929, will disappear under legislation signed yesterday by Gov. Edmund Brown Jr. Banks have had free license plates on automobiles and other vehicles that they own since 1929. The bill by Assemblyman Daniel Boatwright should increase the revenue to state and local governments by as much as $800,000 a year, a spokesman for Governor Brown said.

title: National Airlines Talks Halt
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) Talks between National Airlines and its striking flight attendants broke down today and both sides said no further discussions were planned. National has been shut down for eight days.

title: House Votes Bill to Help Poor to Insulate Homes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP)  The House adopted today legislation to enable lowincome persons to insulate their homes and save on energy bill??

title: SOYBEANS, CORN AND WHEAT DROP
description: Two crop forecasts released after trading Friday depressed prices of wheat, corn and soybeans yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. It was the first chance for the commodities to react to the reports.

title: A Mass Poison, Linked to C.I.A., Reported Found at Army Base
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8Two containers of a mass poison developed by the Central Intelligence Agency have been discovered hidden in a warehouse at Fort Detrick, Md., apparently in violation of a Presidential order, sources familiar with the matter reported today.

title: FrenchIraqi Nuclear Pact
description: PARIS, Sept. 8 (Reuters)Iraq and France initialed a nuclear cooperation agreement today and they expect to sign it next month, Premier Jacques Chirac said after conferring here with Saddam Hussein, Vice President of Iraq's Revolutionary Council.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: The New York Times/Jack Manning

title: Phillies Victorious Over Cardinals, 63
description: Greg Luzinski drove in three runs with a single and double as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 6.3, last night and narrowed the gap between thmselves and the secondplace Cardinals to a halfgame in the National League East Division.

title: Accent on Participation In Proliferating Centers
description: A revolution is taking place in the presentation of science to the public, young and old. While it is manifeat in science centers from Singapore to London, Munich, Prague and Warsaw, it is most dramatically evident at the Exploratorium in San Francisco.

title: Spassky Marriage Poses Moscow Test on Rights
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 8  Boris, Spassky, the former world chess champion, has posed a quiet challenge to the Soviet Union's sincerity in fulfilling the spirit as well as the letter of the humanitarian provisions of the Helsinki declaration.

title: Ford Reiterates View Of Denying Aid to City
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) President Ford has reiterated his belief that New York City should deal with its fiscal problems on its own and that it cannot expect help from his Administration.

title: Wheat Train Is Derailed
description: SOMERSET, Pa., Sept. 8 (UPI) A 66car Chessie System freight train carrying wheat destined for the Soviet Union dereailed yesterday at the mouth of a railroad tunnel. A railroad. otficial said 34 cars left the track, spilling an estimated $340,000 worth of wheat. There were no injuries.

title: Notes on People
description: The $90,000 Chestnut Hill house that Philadelphia's Mayor Frank L. Rizzo moved into last week has reportedly been improved by perhaps more than $300,000 worth of work, attracting the attention of a special grand jury investigating municipal corruption. Mayor Rizzo, a career police officer who says his only income is from his $40,000 salary and investments he made from savings, has reportedly turned over his financial records to the grand jury.

title: Park Service Restudies Policies Following Crater Lake Closing
description: MEDFORD, Ore., Sept. 8Water quality and leadership problems at Crater Lake National Park this summer have led to a reevaluation of policies in the National Park Service, an official of the service says.

title: Dow Climbs 4.14 to 840.11, But Declines Top Gains
description: The stock market ended mixed yesterday in sluggish trading as many investors remained on the sidelines awaiting the outcome of New York City's financial crisis.

title: Walking Horse Victor
description: SHELBYVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 8 (UPI)Ebony's True Grit, reserve grand champion last year, won the top honor Saturday night at the 37th annual Tennessee walking horse national celebration. The 8yearold bay stallion, owned by Long Leaf Stables of Shelbyville and Chatom, Ala., was ridden by Joe Fleming.

title: KALLINGER TRIAL GETS UNDER WAY
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 8Jury selection began today for a retrial of Joseph Kallinger on robbery charges.

title: FILM ON WELFARE TO OPEN PBS YEAR
description: The Miss America beauty pageant, which was broadcast Saturday night, is the special that traditionally heralds the start of a new commercial TV season. On public television, its equivalent as an opening burst is the newest Frederick Wiseman documentary, which this year will be Welfare, a 2hour and 47minute film scheduled for Wednesday evening, Sept. 24.

title: Prices Are Raised By FMC Corporation For Rayon Products
description: The FMC Corporation announced yesterday that its fiber division would increase prices on selected types of rayon staple and rayon tow by 4 cents a pound, effective Oct. 1. The American Cyanamid Company increased the price of its line of coating resins used for industrial finishes by 5 per cent to 10 per cent, effective Sept. 5.

title: MARGARET M'EVOY
description: Margaret Santry McEvoy, widow of Joseph P. McEvoy, who was a roving editor of Reader's Digest, died Sunday at her home, 231 East 48th Street. She was 72 years old.

title: Giant Ground Game Still Bogged Down
description: Now that the New York Giants have their two feet on the ground again, the first question confronting the club concerns its ground gameor lack of it.

title: Chess:
description: This year's fourth Las Palmas International Tournament, designated as a memorial to Ruy Lopez, the 16thcentury Spanish priest who advocated the opening named after him, was won by Ljubomir Ljubojevic.

title: TALKS BROKEN OFF
description: The membership of the United Federation of Teachers voted yesterday to strike the city's 950 public schools this morning, a move that will disrupt the education of more than a million pupils on the second day of the new term.

title: Congress Urged to Double Subsidy to Postal Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 Postmaster General Benjamin F. Bailar called on Congress today to double the Federal subsidy to the United States Postal Service, now about $920million a year.

title: Animal Feed Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration proposed today to ban certain industrialgrade, vegetable oil by products from animal feed. The agency said these byproducts had been shown to contain high levels of chemicals, such as the pesticides dieldrin and endrin.

title: HARTFORD DISPUTE ON PAPER REVIVED
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 8  A bitter dispute over the sale of The Hartford Times two years ago, involving allegations of fraudulent profit and loss figures, bogus circulation records and, on the sideline, a smoldering family feud, is scheduled to be reopened here this month.

title: A Veto to Override...
description: Whether the House of Representatives can override today President Ford's veto of the $7.9billion education appropriations bill will affect the economies of virtually every American community and the higher education opportunities of millions of students. Failure to override would be a particularly severe blow for the already strained budgets of the nation's cities, with their high number of poor children dependent on special instruction that is primarily financed with Federal dollars.

title: Security Will Be as Usual During President's Visit to 4 States This Week,
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8No unusual security precautions will be taken to protect Pres ident Ford when he travels later this week to New Hampshire, Missouri, Kansas and Texas, the White House said today.

title: Viking Is Scheduled Again For Mars TakeOff Today
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 8 (UPI)Space scientists will try again tomorrow to launch the second Viking spacecraft on a yearlong flight to Mars to search for life on the red planet.

title: Victories for Reason
description: In the Appalachian coal fields, neither the Ten Commandments nor the Bill of Rights normally enjoy greater respect than does the inviolability of a picket line. Since the turn of the century, any aggrieved unionists who stationed themselves outside the pit head could halt all production, however trivial their complaint.

title: London and Dublin in Rift Over a Hunted Terrorist
description: LONDON, Sept. 8A 21yearold Northern Irish woman, described by Scotland Yard as probably the most dangerous woman terrorist in Britain, emerged today as a source of dispute between the London and Dublin Governments.

title: FORGERY IS LAID TO A G.O.P. DONOR
description: John Del Mastro, a major contributor to the Suffolk County Republican party, was arrested yesterday on charges of forging an agreement with Chemical Bank to create a factitious corporation for launder ing funds involving other enterprises.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jackson Supports Accord
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said yesterday that he would, despite misgivings, support the accord.

title: Dance Festival Concludes With Numbing Variety
description: With a hint of autumn coolly blowing around the ankles, the New York Dance Festival concluded its season at the Delacorte Theater Sunday night with so mixed a program that one was slightly numbed. Variety is the favorite spice of the festival's life, but the closing program was almost as jumbled as an army meal tray.

title: Sire Stake Tonight
description: WESTBURY. L.I., Sept. 8 The Sire Stakes, a fourweek series of races with a total purse of more than $1.2million, opens tomorrow night at Roosevelt Series, with the $80,940 Sire Stakes for 2yearold trotting fillies.

title: Eleanor Levison Israel, 58, ExU.S. Protocol Official
description: Eleanor Levison Israel, assistant to the chief of protocol of the State Department in the Kennedy Administration, died yesterday at her home in Washington. She was 58 years old.

title: Conjugal Visits for Inmates To Be Allowed at Wallkill
description: Married inmates will be allowed to have conjugal visits in a New York State prison facility for the first time next year in an experimental program of family weekend visiting in the privacy of mobile homes or prefabricated cottages set up inside the prison walls, a state corrections spokesman said yesterday.

title: School Crossings Pose Danger With Layoff of 2,250 Guards
description: A 9yearold girl on her way to the opening of school yesterday was struck by an automibile but reported not hurt at an intersection where the school crossing guard, like 2,250 others in the city, had been laid off because of the city's budget crisis.

title: Upstate School Strike Ends
description: CLIFTON PARK, N.Y., Sept. 8 (UPI)A threeday strike by teachers in Saratoga County's Shenendehoah school district ended after 48 hours of bargaining over the weekend, the teachers and the school board announced last night.

title: Breakthrough in Panama
description: A formidable roadblock to a new Panama Canal treatyan imperative for amicable United States relations with Latin Americahas been removed after long uncertainty. That advance takes the form of a declaration of support by the Defense Department and the Joint Chiefs of Staff for the treaty negotiations being conducted by Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker. Gen. George S. Brown, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, emphasized the Pentagon's commitment by announcing it in Panama City after talks with that country's strongman, Gen. Omar Torrijos.

title: Dutch and Belgian Family Barges Straining
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 8Independent barge owners in Belgium and the Netherlands won important concessions in freight rates and working conditions last week after staging spectacular and costly blockades of ports and waterways.

title: SOARING COSTS SEEN IN QUICK DECONTROL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) Sudden decontrol of oil prices will not only drive up the cost of fuels but will also have a $2billionayear impact on agriculturemeaning another spurt in grocery bills, a Library of Congress study said today.

title: Mets' Title Hopes Sink In Twin Loss to Expos
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 8In English or French the Montreal baseball players generally are unknown. The Mets' pennant chances, though, are not unknown. In any language, they are dead.

title: Jets Ready For Regular Season Now
description: The Jets gave themselves the luxury yesterday of thinking how good they just might be, savoring the memory of stopping their third National Football League power in five weeks.

title: Humphrey Asks Compassion For City's Financial Plight
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that there was no useful purpose in allowing New York City to collapse in default.

title: Wesley Simpson, Designer And Textile Executive, 72
description: Wesley Simpson, a former textile executive and designer of fashion fabrics and husband of Adele Simpson, the fashion designer, died yesterday at their home, 5A East 78th Street. He was 72 years old.

title: T.V. Osborn Weds Sharon Kaufman
description: Sharon Anne Kaufman and Timothy Vance Osborn, seniors at Oberlin College, were married yesterday in the college's arboretum in Oberlin, Ohio, by the Rev. Maryell Cleary of the Olmstead Unitarian  Universalist Fellowship.

title: Utilities Still Putting Off Building of Power Plants
description: Although at a slower pace than last year, the nation's electric power companies are continuing to cancel and postpone construction of power generation facilities to meet future customer demand.

title: Memorial Services
description: LAMONTHelen Limb. A memorial tribute to Helen Dime Lamont, wife of our esteemed AdviseratLarge, Corliss Lenient, will he held on Thursday, Sept. 11, at 5 P.M., in the auditorium of The New Verb Ethical Culture Society, 64th St. and Central Perk West. Musical selections preccde the service. The Foundation of Thanatology mourns the loss of this beloved human being and joins in memorializing the legacies that her brilliant mind has given mankind.

title: Strike at Met Ends With a New Contract
description: Metropolitan Opera members of the American Guild of Musical Artists ratified a new contract containing several key concessions early yesterday afternoon and reported to work immediately.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A crowd of 300 people mostly elderly women, filled St. Nicholas Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx for the funeral of Margaret Doyle, the 75yearold widow who was found murdered in her apartment building last Wednesday.

title: Thai Convoy Is Ambushed
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 8 (Reuters)About 100 Communist guerrillas ambushed an official motor convoy in southern Thailand yesterday, killing two policemen and a woman and wounding 16 people, the police said today.

title: WALLACE LOMOE, 78, MILWAUKEE EDITOR
description: Wallace Lomoe, who retired in 1962 as executive editor of The Milwaukee Journal and vice president of the Journal Company, died Sunday at a rest home in South Haven, Mich. His age was 78.

title: Article 7  No Title
ACCORD REACHED BY CLOTHING UNION
description: The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America announced yesterday that the union had reached agreement on a new oneyear contract with the manfacturers of cotton garments and outerwear. The pact covering 95,000 workers in the two industries, provides for wage increases of 20 cents an hour for the cotton garment workers and 25 cents for the outerwear workers. The union said that the agreement also provided substantial improvements in the retirement and health and welfare programs, with the employers' contributions increased.

title: Suspect Offered to Free Bronfman, Lawyer Says
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 8The lawyer for Dominic Byrne, who is accused of kidnapping Samuel Bronfman 2d, the Seagram heir, said yesterday that Mr. Byrne had offered to free Mr. Bronfman before the $2.3million ransom was paid and that Mr. Byrne had been threatened, beaten and forced to participate in the Aug. 8 kidnapping.

title: Bridge:
description: Diagnosing a perfect fit, with no highcard strength wasted, often proves impossible, even for experts. If the right contract is a slam a devious bidding sequence, or perhaps a splinter bid, will sometimes solve the problem. At lower levels only overbidders hit the target, and they show losses on other deal when the fit is less than perfect.

title: Westchester Bill To Aid Consumers Passed Over Veto
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 8The Westchester County Board of Legislators today overrode County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's veto last week of a consumer protection bill. The vote was 15 to 2.

title: Market Place
description: The sale in July by Leon J. Levitz, a cofounder of the Levitz Furniture Corporation, of 8 per cent of his holdings recalls that company's role in the last breaths of a dying bull market in 1972.

title: Army Says It Misled G.I.'s With LSD Test Cocktails
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 The Army disclosed today that it had surreptitiously given LSD to soldiers in cocktails in much the same way the Central Intelligence Agency did in an experiment that led to the death of one of its subjects.

title: Memorial for Helen Lamont
description: There will be a memorial tribute to Helen Lamb Lamont, economist, author and educator, in the auditorium of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West at 64th Street, Thursday at 5 P.M. Mrs. Lamont, the wife of Dr. Corliss Lamont, author and lecturer, died July 21.

title: Middle East Deals: Bribery Held Pointless
description: American companies have no need to use bribery or gobetweens to obtain business in the Middle East, toplevel representatives of Saudi Arabia and Iran asserted yesterday.

title: Inland Steel Co. Is Fined For Dumping Waste Waters
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (UPI)Cook County Circuit Judge Nathan M. Cohen today fined the Inland Steel Company $1.9million on charges it violated state laws by dumping wastes from its East Chicago, Ind., steel mill into Illinois waters of Lake Michigan.

title: People and Business
description: The nation's fourth largest aluminum producer, Conalco. Inc., announced Yesterday the election of E. G. Chaves as president and chief executive officer. The 45yearold chief executive comes to the aluminum company from the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation where he had been a vice president and served as group executive for industrial products in Europe.

title: Inland Plans Appeal
description: Frederick G. Jaicks, chairman of Inland Steel, said his commany would appeal the Court's decision. He added: We think it wrong for Judge Cohen to rule against uswhen our facilities and programs have been found proper and acceptable by the regulatory authorities responsible for our operations . . . and who gave due consideration to Illinois water quality standards protecting Lake Michigan.

title: JUSTICE OFFICIALS BID COURT REFUSE PAPERS TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8The Justice Department contended today that Congress had ample reason to conclude that former President Richard M. Nixon would not be a trustworthy custodian, even temporarily, for his Presidential papers.

title: Bowie Steward: Horses Held Back
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 8 (UPI)One of three stewards at Bowie Race Course the day a race was allegedly fixed testified in Federal court today that he noticed some irregularities at the start of the races It looked to me as though some of the horses were being field back from running their best race, Merrill Macneille told a jury during the third day of the racefixing trial of seven persons, four of them jockeys. Macneille said the running of the race last Feb. 14 was so unusual that the stewards spent two hours the next day studying the videotapes and studied them again foul days later before notifying authorities of their doubts. The prosecution showed the tapes in court. The jockeys accused in the alleged race fix, all of whom finished out of the money, are Eric Walso, Luigi Gino, Ben Feliciano and Jesse Davidson.

title: CATHOLIC SCHOOLS CURTAIL CLASSES
description: Two of the five Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens struck by unionized lay teachers began the scheduled first day of classes yesterday with shorter school hours and half the normal number of students.

title: M.A.C. Plans Public Campaign To Sell Bonds of $50 and $100
description: ALBANY, Sept. 9The Municipal Assistance Corporation, currently unable to sell its bonds to major institutional investors, will try to market some of them directly to the public in denominations of $50 and $100, it was disclosed today.

title: Finnish Concern to Build A Pulpwood Plant in South
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 8 (AP)  A Finnish forest products company announced plans today for a $12million sawmill and a multimilliondollar pulpwood plant in south Mississippi.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

title: A Correction
description: In the recipe for zucchini pork hake published yesterday. Step 2 was incomplete. It should also have said to add the sour cream.

title: 3 TEACHER STRIKES ENJOINED BY COURTS
description: Superior Court judges in Massachusetts and Rhole Island ordered striking teachers back to work in three communities yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: 2 Flee a Paris Bank With $1.35Million and Free 7
description: PARS, Sept. 8 (AP)Two gunmen escaped with $1.35million tonight after releasing unharmed seven hostages seized during a bank holdup and eluding the police in a highspeed chase.

title: M.A.C. Planning a Public Drive To Market $50 and $100 Bonds
description: ALBANY, Sept. 8The Municipal Assistance Corporation, currently unable to sell its bonds to major institutional investors, will try to market some of them directly to the public in denominations of $50 and $100, it was disclosed today.

title: Monterey Cafe Destroyed
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Sept. 8 (UPI)Fire destroyed historic Cerrito's at the Wharf last night, a big ferry boat shaped cafe. It was opened 56 years ago.

title: GREECE SEEKING U.S. INVESTMENTS
description: ATHENS, Sept. 7  Greece has announced a major effort to attract foreign capital and technology, particularly from the United States, as part of a new fiveyear plan for economic growth.

title: House Republicans Draft Program to Follow if They Ran Things
description: WASHINGTON, Sept8Re publicans in the House of Representatives out of power, since the 1954 election, announced today a legislative program they would follow if they ran things.

title: TV INDUSTRY SHOWS 9% RISE IN REVENUES
description: Figures released by the Federal Communications Commission show that in 1974, a year of general industrial recession, the television industry reported revenues of $3.8biilion, up 9 per cent over the $3.5billion of 1973.

title: Anderson More Hopeful About Federal Aid to City
description: Anderson More Hopeful About Federal Aid to City

title: ASSEMBLY BACKS CAREY PROPOSAL TO ASSIST CITY
description: ALBANY, Sept. 8Amid warnings of a fiscal disaster and exchanges of partisan recriminations, the Assembly tonight passed and sent to the Senate Governor Carey's emergency plan to hold off default in New York City.

title: Jersey Assembly Rejects Cut In Bonds After Labor Warning
description: TRENTON, Sept. 8The state A.F.L.C.I.O. helped push an amendment through the State Assembly tonight that increased a proposal transportation bond by $40million over the objections of Governor Byrne.

title: STUDY FINDS GAIN IN READING SKILLS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8The functional literacy of 17yearold high school students has increased slightly in recent years, the National Assessment of Education Progress reported today.

title: Magnetism Particle Now Being Doubted
description: The reported discovery last month of a particle representing the basic unit of magnetism whose role with regard to magnetism would match that of the electron in electrical phenomenawas based in part on incorrect information about the experimental apparatus.

title: Utilities' Users May Face Cost of Exploring for Gas
description: A proposal by 12 gas utilities in the state to impose a special surcharge on their customers for two years to pay the companies' cost of participating in a natural gas exploration and development program has been endorsed by an examiner for the New York State Public Ser vice Commission, It was announced yesterday.

title: Nets Trade Paultz For Spurs' Jones
description: The Nets and the San Antonio Spurs, a pair of trading partners, got together again yesterday in a fiveplayer deal in which the Spurs obtained Billy Paultz while New York received Rich Jones and three pro basketball nobodies. In the last three months a total of eight Spurs and Nets have changed uniforms. In Jung, San Antonio swapped Swen Nater, the American Basketball Association's best rebounder, for Larry Kenon and Mike Gale.

title: South African Bank Chief Sees Rise of Inflation and Gold Price
description: The governor of the South African Reserve Bank warned yesterday that a new wave of worldwide inflation was in prospect due to various international economic pressures, including the trend toward reflation in major industrial countries.

title: U.S. Eases Its Restriction On Subsidizing of Rents
description: The Ford Administration yesterday raised the tenantincome limits in New York City for eligibility for rent subsidies under the nation's major new housing program for the poor and nearpoor.

title: SubwayEntrance Billboards Assailed
description: City Councilman Henry J. Stern said yesterday he would introduce a bill at the next Council meeting that would require community hoard approval for billboards to be placed at neighborhood subway entrances.

title: Advertising
description: The Tanner Publications Company, which publishes Encore, a biweekly news magazine for blacks, is planning to bring out a new magazine for black men and women in the military services.

title: Article 4  No Title
Family Barge Trouble
description: Though they won important concessions last week, it is unlikely independent barge owners in Belgium and the Netherlands can ultimately survive in competition with more modern and efficient forms of river transport on nothern Europe's busy canals and rivers. Details, Page 57.

title: Open Interest
