School vs. Education
description: By the age of six the average child will have completed the basic American education and be ready to enter school. If the child has been attentive in these preschool years, he or she will already have mastered many skills.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TAKI 183 Subway graffiti, of which the Washington Heights youth who signed his work Taki 183 was one of the fist in that genre, seems to be a form of tramp artthere are no rules for tramp art, the artists are generally untrained and they are mostly unrecognized.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: MONTESCUDAIO, Italy, Sept. 8 (AP)The Americanbred trotter, Wayne Eden, the first horse to be kidnapped in Italy, was released by his captors early today after three weeks. The horse was limping but in generally good condition, the police reported.

title: URANIUM CUT SET BY WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the nation's leading manufacturer of nuclear power plants for the production of electricity, announced yesterday that it would stop supplying uranium to about 20 electric utility customers by the end of 1978 because of the unprofitability of the business, and would begin an immediate program of allocating uranium it has in inventory or on order.

title: Nyquist Urges Imposition Of Tuition Fees at City U.
description: State Education Commissioner Ewald Nyquist made public yesterday a call for charging all City University students tuition, with fulltime undergraduates to pay the same fees as State University students $650 a year for freshmen and sophomores, $800 a year for juniors and seniors.

title: Union Offer Was Rejected By Board at the 11th Hour
description: The Board of Education rejected a lastminute compromise yesterday afternoon that had already been accepted by the United Federation of Teachers and would have headed off today's teachers strike.

title: I.R.S. Chief Opposes Curbs On Power to Get Bank Data
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) Taxpayers should be told when the Internal Revenue Service obtains their bank records, bu people and institutions should not have additional power to resist such action, the head of the I.R.S. said today.

title: Libya Denies News Report She Annexed Part of Chad
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 8 (Agence FrancePress)  A Libyan Foreign Ministry spokesman officially denied today a report in The Sunday Times of London yesterday that Libya had annexed territory in the north of Chad, the Libyan radio reported.

title: PRESIDENT TALKS OF HIS ENDURANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. S (UPI) President Ford said in an interview released today that he and Secretary of State Kisetnger were quite similar in their ability to bounce back after mental and physical pressure without suffering from the tension.

title: Pentagon Pledges No Bias In Arab Uniform Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8The American Jewish Congress said today that it had been assured by the Defense Department that the Pentagon would not discriminate against companies with Jewish owners in awarding contracts for manufacture of uniforms for the Saudi Arabian armed forces.

title: China Notes City Crisis Blames Capitalists
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 8 (Reuters)China told its people today that New York City was near bankruptcy because of the exploitation of monopoly capitalists.

title: A CAMBODIAN VIEW OF MAYAGUEZ CASE
description: Cambodian gunboats seized the American containership Mayagez last May 12 without the knowledge of the Communist Government in Phnom Penh, according to Ieng Sary, the Cambodian Deputy Premier.

title: Near Miss For Ford And U.S.
description: Mrs. Gerald Ford may be able to say courageously that, in the personal sense, the possibility of an assassination is just something a President's family has to live with. In the more general sense, however, the nation can hardly take the same fatalistic attitudeparticularly a nation that in less than a decade has seen a President assassinated, a leading Presidential candidate assassinated, a major Presidential candidate paralyzed for life after an assassination attempt, and a great racial and political leader assassinated.

title: New Age, New Plan
description: On June 5, 1947, in an address at Harvard, Secretary of State George C. Marshall presented a comprehensive plan for the economic recovery of the warravaged European nations.

title: Belkin, Citing Illness, Resigns as Yeshiva President
description: Dr. Samuel Belkin, president of Yeshiva University for 32 years, has resigned because of serious illness and has assumed the newly created post of chancellor.

title: ExEditor of Holiday, a Woman, 28, Beaten to Death on Coast
description: VISTA, Calif., Sept. 8 (AP)The niece of the president of the Curtis Publishing Company has been found beaten to death in a home here where she was vacationing. San Diego County sheriff's deputies reported.

title: WALLACE JONES
description: Wallace Jones, who retired in 1972 from The New York Times as an indexer in the news library after 52 years' service, died Sunday in the Nassau County Medical Center, Fast Meadow. He was 70 years old and lived at 4149 Harriet Road, Bethpage, L.I.

title: Israel Reports Oil Offers
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 8 (Reuters) The Israeli radio said today that a number of large international oil suppliers had offered to sell fuel to Israel to replace the supply from the Abu Rudeis oilfield, to he returned to Egypt under the latest interim peace agreement.

title: 6 in Family Die in Air Crash
description: HURRICANE, Utah, Sept. 8 (AP)  A Southern California man, his wife and four children were killed when their light plane crashed after circling over the home of relatives, officials reported. The victims were Barton Spendlove, about 38 years old, from the Los Angeles area, his wife, Louise, three girls aged 6, 16 and 17 and a boy, about 10, local fire officials said.

title: MERRILL DISPUTES JOB BIAS FINDINGS
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the nation's No. 1 brokerage house, took strong issue here yesterday with Government findings that it discriminated against blacks, women and Spanishnamed persons in its employment practices.

title: Westchester Indicts Its ExWelf are Aide In a Rebate Scandal
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 8A Westchester grand jury today indicted Joseph R. Schmitt, the county's former deputy commissioner of social services, for his alleged role in the Yonkers taxrebate scandal.

title: Ambiguities and Uncertainties Mark Crisis
description: To the main characters in the drama, the city's fiscal crisis has beenif nothing elsean educational exercise. Government leaders, accustomed to smoothing over their differences with the ambiguous language of political accords, have had to learn about the precise, demanding language of investors and bankers.

title: How They Stand Today
description: American League

title: 2 Yearlings Stolen at Keeneland Sale; Kidnapped Trotter Recovered in Italy
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 8 (AP)The theft of two yearling colts that were to have been sold at auction today has prompted Keeneland Race Course to strengthen its nighttime security force.

title: Ecuador's Cabinet Shuffled In Wake of Coup Attempt
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Sept. 8 (AP)  President Guillermo Rodriguez Lara reoganized his Cabinet today, a week after he crushed a revolt by about 100 soldiers led by the army chief of staff.

title: ISRAELSYRIA TALKS IN OCTOBER HINTED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 8 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt was quoted today as saying that contacts about an Israeli withdrawal on the Syrian front would start in October.

title: South Vietnam Revives Mail Service Abroad
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 8 (UPI)The General Post Office announced today that it would accept ordinary overseas air and surface mail to any point in the world.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The State Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, said yesterday that he had come away from his meeting with Treasury Secretary William E. Simon in Washington a little more optimistic of possible Federal help to keep New York City from bankruptcy but with no commitments.

title: SCHOOLS IN BOSTON OPEN UNDER GUARD
description: BOSTON, Sept. 8Boston's public schools began their courtordered, citywide busing program today with attendance off by more than a third, but with only scattered incidents of violence, confined almost entirely to the Charlestown neighborhood.

title: The Horse They Didn't Invite
description: Weights for the $250,000 Marlboro Cup came out yesterday, proving the New York racing secretary, Kenny Noe, capable of that quality of mercy which blesseth him that gives and him that takes. Conditions for the Governor Stakes on Labor Day let Wajima in with only 115 pounds, which was 10 pounds less than Foolish Pleasure had to carry, 15 pounds lighter than Ancient Title's load, and 19 pounds under the burden of 134 that was shouldered by Forego. The finish exactly reversed the order of those assignments, with Wajima first, Foolish Pleasure second, Ancient Title third and Forego fourth. Next Sunday's rich rumble at Belmont is a handicap, and for this Noe lets mercy season justice, showing compassion to the tooweights without unduly penalizing the others. Thus Forego comes down five pounds to 129 and Wajima gets 119, an increase of four. Ancient Title and Foolish Pleasure drop to 126 and 121, respectively.

title: U.S. Health Official Asks Immediate Ban On Hudson Pollutant
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) A Federal health official has called upon the Environmental Protection Agency to order an immediate halt to a brand of industrial pollution that New York State officials say may have caused irreparable damage to the Hudson River.

title: OFFER BY EMHART FOR USES SCORED
description: Charging that the Emhart Corporation of Farmington, Conn. was making a brazen attempt to seize the USM Corporation at bargain basement prices. William S. Brewster, USM chairman urged his stocxholders to reject Emhart's $23ashare offer for 1 million shares of of USM stock.

title: Westchester Indicts Its ExWelt are Aide In a Rebate Scandal
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 8A Westchester grand jury today indicted Joseph R. Schmitt, the county's former deputy commissioner of social services, for his alleged role in the Yonkers taxrebate scandal.

title: 4 GUILTY IN MAKING OF AN XRATED MOVIE
description: PATERSON, Sept. 8  The three  year  old indictments charging four defendants with sexual crimes during the making of the Xrated movie Deep Sleep here four years ago were dismissed today in exchange for guilty pleas by the moviemakers to disorderlypersons offenses.

title: Rockefellers Toss A HousewarmingIn 9 Installments
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8The Rockefellers began their serial housewarming last night, giving about 250 alphabetically chosen guests a chance to inspect the freshly decorated official VicePresidential residence that they do not, apparently, intend to live in for at least another six months, if ever.

title: Baeza Is Thrown
description: Braulio Baeza was tossed from William Wilmot's Gold and Myrrh while easing up that 4yearold colt following a between  races workout. Baeza removed himself from his mounts for the afternoon, but was expected to be ready for his ride on Wajima in the Marlboro.

title: Republicans to Seek Up to $25Million In Races for President and Congress
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 8The Republican National Committee, its influence boistered by the new campaign law, will try to raise up to $25million during the next year to help finance the party's Peesidential and Congressional campaigns.

title: Hoffa Case Witness Told to Plead Fifth
description: DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP)Anthony Giacalone was reported by his lawyer today to have refused to cooperate with la Federal grand jury investigating the disappearance of James R. Hoffa, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Music: Sinatra, Basie, Miss Fitzgerald
description: Despite the airy arrogance that Frank Sinatra drapes over most of his performance at the Uris Theater, he can still cut through the macho posturing when he wants to project a simple love song.

title: Yankees Win, 30, For May
Israel's Candid New U.N. Delegate
description: With his wellscrubbed wellbarbered hair, his slight Irish accent, his look of command, he could be any retired colonel dropping in at the clubto catch up on military gossip.

title: Ban on SnakeHandling Is Upheld in Tennessee
description: NASHVILLE, Sept 8 (UPI)  SnakeHandling and the drinking of poison in connection with religious ceremonies were banned today by the Tennessee Supreme Court.

title: President Kennedy's Birthplace Damaged in Apparent Busing Protest
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 8 (UPI)The birthplace of the late President Kennedy was damaged tonight in a fire apparently set to protest Boston's school desegregation.

title: Sihanouk Leaving China for Cambodia After 5Year Exile
description: PEKING, Tuesday, Sept. 9 (Reuters)Prince Norodom Sihanouk left here today for Cambodia after more than five years of exile in China.

title: Goldin Rejects Bills of an Impostor
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin has refused to pay bills of almost $5,000 sent to the city, for furniture and almost $8,000 for a Cadillac for the Commissioner of Penal Systemsbecause there is no such city official or commission.

title: Coal Miners Break Tradition, Return to Work Despite Pickets
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 8 (AP)Breaking a 50year tradition, coal miners refused to let pickets stand in the way of their return to work today after a monthlong strike that had idled up to twothirds of the nation's soft coal miners.

title: About the Jets . . .
description: Bill Demory, once the No. 4 quarterback who knew the Jets would keep only three, picked up his wife at the airport yesterday. He expects to be around now that Al Woodall has been placed on the injured reserve list and is out for the season. . . . Although there are only 49 men on the roster, and it must be trimmed down to 46 players today, there will be five cuts. The reason? The two performers from the College AllStars now are counted. Until today, each club had them as a free ride. . . I think I went in for another series after I got hurt, said John Riggins, about a groinmuscle pull. I don't think I'll be able to play next week. . . . Burgess Owens also said he did not think he could play Sunday. He was limping badly after someone stepped on his small right toe.

title: Both Young and Old Learning by Doing
description: Science and technology centers, by catering less to passive viewers and more to those who want to be involved in learning by doing, may well be the fastest growing segment of the museum field.

title: Yields Are Steady In Weekly Auction Of Treasury Bills
description: Yields remained virtually unchanged in the Treasury Department's latest weekly bill auction yesterday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Trade Unit Bids Treasury Study DumpedCar Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI)  The International Trade Commission voted, 42, today to ask the Treasury Department to investigate further allegations that imported cars were being dumped in the United States to the detriment of the domestic industry.

title: Grim Mood Dominates Turkish Rescue
description: LICE, Turkey, Sept. 8Relief workers dug bodies out of the wreckage of this earthquakeravaged village. today as occasional faint tremors continued to shake the rubblestrewn earth where more than 2,000 people may have been killed.

title: A Poison Linked to C.I.A. Reported Found at Base
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8Two containers of a mass poison developed by the Central Intelligence Agency have been discovered hidden in a warehouse at Fort Detrick, Md., apparently in violation of a Presidential order, sources familiar with the matter reported today.

title: Books of The Times
description: If I understand him, Richard Yates is saying, through the medium of his hero, John Wilder, that life in America is enough to drive a man to drink, or crazy, or both. (The word hero is used here because protagonist and principal character are stilted, but perhaps victim would be better. In fact, the way the novel is tending, victim may soon replace hero in general usage.)

title: Congress Hears a Default Would Have Wide Effect
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 Bankers and brokers from across the country told Congress today that New York's fiscal plight already had increased rates for other cities and predicted that a default could make bonds unsalable, halt municipal construction and increase unemployment in other parts of the country.

title: Treasury Bills Rise At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Boris Spassky, the former world chess champion, is testing the Soviet Union's sincerity in fulfilling the spirit as well as the letter of the humanitarian provisions of the Helsinki declaration. The 30,000word document deals mainly with the inviolability of frontiers and noninterference in internal affairs, but it also contains a few paragraphs, inserted at Western insistence, dealing with marriage between citizens of different nations. Mr. Spassky wants to marry a Frenchwoman, and he believes Soviet authorities might want to block the marriage. He has cited the Helsinki declaration in his behalf. [Page 3, Columns 58.]

title: TONIGHT'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Detroit at New York (8 P.M.) Bare (810) vs. Medical (1216).

title: People in Sports
description: Ed Westfall will be back with the New York Islanders this season after spending the entire summer as an unsigned free agent, according to the National Hockey League's central registry office.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Rivals Call Weight Of Forego Too Low
description: The stage was set yesterday at Belmont Park for the third running of the $250,000 Marlboro Cup with the announcement of weights for Saturday's 1mile fixture, but the assignments were not received with enthusiasm by some of the cast's supporting members.

title: PILOT TESTIFIES ON KENNEDY CRASH
description: The cargojet pilot who vainly pleaded with officials to change runways just minutes before an Eastern Airlines passenger jet crashed here in June wanted to a abandon his own landing attempt but was caught in a vicious downdraft, according to evidence made public yesterday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Pharmaceutical Association said yesterday it was asking its members to continue filling prescriptions under Medicaid despite state cutbacks in pharmaceutical service fees. Dispensing fees were reduced yesterday from $2.15 to $1.90 on each prescription. In addition, Medicaid patients are now to pay a 25cent surcharge on each prescription.

title: Issues in Teacher Dispute
description: PREPARATION PERIODS: The Board of Education wants the teachers to reduce their prep or free time periods, figuring it could save $35million to $90million a year. The teachers use these periods to prepare lessons. mark papers or rest between classes. Instead, the board would have the teachers meet more classes during the week, enabling a reduction in class size.

title: For the Skilled and Unskilled: A List of Cooking Schools in New Jersey
description: Cooking schools in New Jersey, as do their counterparts in the rest of the metropolitan area, offer something for everyone. The uncertain beginner can find a course that provides basic instruction, the knowledgeable cook can get pointers on an intermediate level and the accomplished amateur can turn to a school that offers classes in highly specialized dishes. The instruction also covers a wide rangefrom private classes to group instruction and from direct participation to onlooker. It should be pointed out that the quality of schools listed has not been evaluated and mention of a course should not be taken as an endorsement.

title: Perez Player of Month
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 (AP)Tony Perez, the Cincinnati Reds' first baseman, was named today National League player of the month.

title: Boston Blacks' Mood Fearful but Resolute
description: BOSTON, Sept. 8  Albert Willis Jr., big for his 11 years and handsome, gently nudged his younger brother and commented, Kenny's scared.

title: Business Briefs
description: The General Electric Company will repeat an earlier 1975 promotion with a rebate program of $2 to $5 on 29 small appliances starting immediately and running through Oct. 20.

title: Accent on Participation In Proliferating Centers
description: A revolution is taking place in the presentation of science to the public, young and old. While it is manifest in science centers from Singapore to London, Muniel, Prague and Warsaw, it is most dramatically, evident at the Exploratorium in San Francisco.

title: ANTIRED FORCES GAIN IN PORTUGAL
description: LISBON, Sept. 9AntiCommunist forces in the High Council of the Revolution made further gains tonight and imposed tough restrictions on press reporting of political activity within the armed forces.

title: 7 FOOD PLACES HELD VIOLATORS OF CODE
Monterey Cafe Destroyed
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Sept. 8 (UPI)Fire destroyed historic Cerrito's at the Whart last night, a big ferry boat ??ped cafe. It was opened 56 years ago.

title: Aspin Puts U.S. Arms Sales In 2 Years at $20.3Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI)  Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that the United States' foreign military sales during the last two fiscal years totoled an incredible $20.3billion, or $3billion higher than previously reported by the Pentagon.

title: Article 1  No Title
COLOMBIAN GENERAL SLAIN BY TERRORISTS
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 8 (AP)The inspector general of Colombia's army was assassinated today by terrorists who blocked his limousine with their own car and opened fire with submachine guns, hitting him in the face and chest. His chauffeur was seriously wounded.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI)The president of the National Football League Players Association today asked the N.F.L. owners to maintain the 47man squad limit for the 1975 season because of the number of serious injuries to firstline players. Kermit Alexander asked the owners to reverse their decision before tomorrow's player cuts, which will reduce N.F.L. squads to 46. Three more players must be cut next week to reach the 43man squad limit the owners adopted this year.

title: Byrne Offered to Free Bronfman, Lawyer Says
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 8The lawyer for Dominic Byrne, who is accused of kidnapping Samuel Bronfman 2d, the Seagram heir, said yesterday that Mr. Byrne had offered to free Mr. Bronfman before the 82.3million ransom was paid and that Mr. Byrne had been threatened, beaten and forced to participate in the Aug. 8 kidnapping.

title: Dr. John Cox, Historian, Dead; City College Professor Emeritus
description: Dr. John H. Cox, a professor emeritus of history at City College, died Sunday at his summer home in Bethel, Conn. He was 68 years old.

title: Malaysia Spurs Development Plans, But Poor People Get Little Benefit
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia Malaysia is speeding headlong down the road of development at a pace that her supporters say will in five years make her one of the most prosperous countries in Asia and that her critics say will blow her apart.

title: New Utrecht's Students In Boycott Over Busing
description: Only 193 of 3,000 enrolled students attended classes at New Utrecht High School yesterday, while 500 other Brooklyn residents demonstrated outside, as part of a series of boycotts and demonstrations against the forced busing of children to Madison High School.

title: 65% IN U.S. ARE SAID TO BACK AID TO CITY
description: While believing that New York City has been mismanaged, 65 per cent of the American people feel that it must be kept from going bankrupt, the Harris poll reported yesterday. The sample also showed that 12 per cent did not believe in saving the city from bankruptcy, and 23 per cent had no opinion.

title: CHINESE MISSION MEETS WITH FORD
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 8The highestranking trade mission from the Peking Government to visit the United States met with President Ford and Congressional leaders today.

title: Judge Denies Ban on Enforcing HighRise FireSafety Orders
description: A Federal judge has rejected an attempt to prevent the enforcement of new firesafety regulations in highrise office buildings here.

title: SENATORS EXPECT OIL VETO TO HOLD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8Key members of both parties agreed today that there were probably not enough votes in the Senate to override President Ford's expected veto of legislation that would extend price controls on oil for six months.

title: Recaptured Leopards Die
description: MANHATTAN, Kan., Sept. 8 (UP)Two leopards freed from the Sunset Zoo by vandals were recaptured yesterday but both died from tranquilizers, the county police reported. Someone cut the locks on cages holding the cats and two coyooes late Saturday. The police said they had few clues in the search for the vandals who opened the cages.

title: Air Laws Called Threat to Glass Makers
description: TRENTON, Sept. 8 (UPI)State Senator John J. Horn, Democrat of Camden, said today that the glassmaking industry would be driven out of New Jersey if the state's lairpollution laws were not relaxed.

title: Ulster Protestants Rule Out Coalition With the Catholics
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 8  Protestant political leaders voted overwhelmingly today against any sharing of administrative power with representatives of Northern Ireland's Roman Catholic minority.

title: FORD SEEKS HELP OF JEWISH LEADERS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8President Ford invited leaders of American Jewish organizations to the White House today to seek their support for his effort to obtain an overwhelming majority in Congress in favor of the stationing of American technicians in Sinai as part of the new EgyptianIsraeli agreement.

title: Center Aids Children With Learning Disabilities
description: CONVENT STATION, Sept. 8A $2million multiservice center for children with learning disabilities opened here today on the campus of the College of St. Elizabeth.

title: TIMOR GROUP CLAIMS A COMPLETE VICTORY
description: CANBERRA, Austraila, Sept. 8 (Reuters)A leftwing movement said today that it had gained control of Portuguese Timor after a month of bloody fighting with rival independence organizations.

title: Easing of U.S. Rules On Stock Ads Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) Federal restrictions on advertising in the securities industry should be relaxed, A. A. Sommer Jr., Commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

title: SCHOOLS IN BOSTON OPEN UNDER GUARD
description: BOSTON, Sept. 8Boston's public schools began their courtordered, citywide busing program today with attendance off by more than a third, but with only scattered incidents of violence, confined almost entirely to the Charlestown neighborhood.

title: Ford Interview Postponed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP)  President Ford postponed today a scheduled interview on the ABCTV evening news program. His press secretary, Ron Nessen, first announced that Mr. Ford would give a brief taped interview to the anchorman, Harry Reasoner, on this first day of broadcasting of a newformat ABC news show. Mr. Nessen later pointed to Mr. Ford's unusually heavy public schedule.

title: First AllAmerican Film Festival in France Is Held in Deauville
description: DEAUVILLE, France, Sept. 8 Deauville, since Second Empire days the smart resort for yachting, horseracing, gambling and the summertime highlife, turned itself into a cinema town this week with the first allAmerican film festival held in France.

title: Production of Steel Climbed 2% in Week
description: Steel production for the week ended Sept. 6 rose by 2 per cent and posted its fourth consecutive weekly gain, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. Thel week's output reached 2,078,000 tons and the production index hit 85.2.

title: Black Markets Bloom in Eastern Europe Behind Facade of StraitLaced Marxism
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 8Despite the theoretical risk of jail or execution for economic crimes in Communist countries, the black markets of Eastern Europe are thriving.

title: Assembly Backs Carey's Plan for City
Andrew Viglietta, 66, Dies; Columnist for L.I. Press
description: Andrew J. Viglietta, Wash ington columnist for The Long Island Press, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 510 East 77th Street.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Lorin Maazel has signed a contract with the Cleveland Orchestra that will keep him as music director of that organization through the 198081 season. The conductor joined the orchestra in 1972, after signing an initial fiveyear contract. The new contract is for four years. The announcement was made during the orchestra's current European tour.

title: Magnetism Particle Now Being Doubted
description: The reported discovery last month of a particle representing the basic unit of magnetism whose role with regard to magnetism would match that of the electron in electrical phenomenawas based in part on incorrect information about the experimental apparatus.

title: Utilities' Users May Face Cost of Exploring for Gas
description: A proposal by 12 gas utilities in the state to impose a special surcharge on their customers for two years to pay the companies' cost of participating in a natural gas exploration and development program has been endorsed by an examiner for the New Yak State Public Service Commission, it was announced yesterday.

title: Kansas City Calls G.O.P. Bid a Challenge
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 8The announcement that the Republican National Convention will be held in Kansas City next August was greeted here with restrained enthusiasm. It had been taken for granted for about a week that the party would pick Kansas City, so the emphasis today was on getting ready.

title: Trotter Released in Italy
description: Trotter Released in Italy

title: Union Tightens Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) The International Executive Board of the United Mine Workers imposed new rules today giving it more power to clamp down on unauthorized work stoppages.

title: Israel Parliament Speaker Is Invited by U.S. Congress
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 8 (UPI)Congressional leaders have invited the speaker of Israel's parliament, and a group of its members to visit Washington.

title: LAXALT SAYS REAGAN WILL CONTEST RACE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP)  Former California Gov. Ronald Reagan is likely to enter the race for the Republican Presidential nomination before Thanksgiving, a key supporter said today.

title: Article 3  No Title
Critics Rediscovering Obscure British Poet
description: LONDON, Sept. 8He vanished during a night patrol on the Somme on March 31, 1918. His body was never found. At the age of 27, Isaac Rosenberg slipped into an obscure death, mourned only by his family and a handful of fellow poets and critics.

title: Change at St. Bonaventure's
description: OLEAN, N.Y., Sept. 8 (UPI) St. Bonaventure's University's board of directors has selected the Rev. Mathias Doyle, 42 years old, as the school's new president. He is curently an associate professor of political science at Siena College in Albany. He will replace the Rev. Damian McElrath, who resigned last July.

title: No Other Links Found
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 8 (UPI)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation sifted today through hundreds of pieces of evidence taken from the attic apartment of Lynette Alice Fromme but said it had found nothing to link other persons to the alleged assassination attempt against President Ford.

title: CROSBY AND NASH HARMONIZE WELL
description: At one point during his and Graham Nash's warmly received, twohour concert Sunday night at the Beacon Theater, David Crosby said, I may not be the best, but I love doing it.

title: Court Denies McGovern Plea On Nixon Campaign Funds
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 8 (AP)A state court dismissed today a suit by Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, to recover more than $1million in damages from seven corporate donors of illegal contributions to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: POSTPONEMENT SET ON SOHIO OFFERING
description: The proposed offering of the common stock of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) has been deferred pending clarification of problems in connection with shipments to the North Slope of Alaska, the company announced yesterday.

title: ARMY MISLED G.I.'S IN TESTS OF LSD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 The Army disclosed today that it had surreptitiously given LSD to soldiers in cocktails in much the same way the Central Intelligence Agency did in an experiment that led to the death of one of its subjects.

title: CYPRUS PEACE TALKS AT THE U.N. FALTER
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 8Secretary General Waldheim tried today to avoid a breakdown in the new round of peace negotiations here between Greek and Turkish Cypriote leaders.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW MIXED TONE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday in dull trading. They dropped in the overthecounter market as volume decreased sharply.

title: 65% IN U.S. REPORTED TO BACK AID TO CITY
description: While believing that New York City has been mismanaged, 65 per cent of the American people feel that it must be kept from going bankrupt, the Harris poll reported yesterday. The sample also showed that 12 per cent did not believe in saving the city from bankruptcy, and 23 per cent had no opinion.

title: P.S.C. Moves to Reform Electricity Rate Structure
description: ALBANY, Sept. 8The Public Service Commission opened major investigation today in tended to reform the rates charged by the state's electric utilities as it heard testimony from spokesmen for lowincome consumers who filled a hearing room.

title: Corporate Crime
description: A Senator, three Representatives and Ralph Nader have urged the Ford Administration to establish a new division in the Department of Justice to deal with corporate criminality, to review existing laws and to take other steps to control what they view as a corporate crime wave. It is not necessary to adopt the specific proposals or the rhetoric of the petition to agree that it is time to begin working urgently to limit the extent and the effect of corporate crime.

title: SHOP TALK
description: It's occasionally possible to save money by spending it, and two purchases that could immediately and ultimately pay dividends are in the realm of recently, published books.

title: Summer Brave, Revised Picnic, Is Staged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 In his early, popular plays, William Inge looked at smalltown America  ordinary people with ordinary dreams. Despite the playwright's grasp of home truths, his name came to be synonymous with sentiment. At times his plays did seem to reach for affirmation, but there was always a cloud of darkness at the top of Inge's stairs, a sadness that culminated in his final, bleak plays and in his apparent suicide.

title: CANDIDATES CLASH IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 8 (AP)In a debate tonight eight days before New Hampshire's special United States Senate election, John A. Durkin, the Democratic candidate, again characterized Louis C. Wyman, his Republican opponent, as a pawn of the oil industry. This prompting Mr. Wyman to lift a 700page list of contributors and declare, There are no big oil contributions in here.

title: ISRAELI PORT USE OFFERED TO ARABS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8Israel offered today to allow free passage of goods to her Arab neighbors through her seaports, and proposed regional cooperation in the Middle East to share her advances in agriculture, irrigation and other technology.

title: Neighbors Bitter at Funeral of Slain Widow
description: A sea of heads, draped in Irish lace or crowned with the frosty locks of age, filled St. Nicholas of Tolentine Roman Catholic Church yesterday morning for the funeral of Margaret Doyle, a 75yearold widow who was found murdered last Wednesday, in the University Heights building where she lived.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Indictments charging four defendants with sexual crimes in making the Xrated movie Deep Sleep in Paterson, N.J., four years ago were dismissed in exchange for guilty pleas to disorderlypersons offenses. We have better things to do than clutter up the courts with matters invilving conspiracy to fornicate. Superior Cpurt Judge Charles S. Joelson said, The four defendants are Alfred Sole, 32 years the director. Andrew Muskat, 32, the producer; Kathryn V. Pope, 26, an actress, s, and Joseph Rose, 33, an actor.

title: Many Boston Students Switch to Parochial Schools
description: BOSTON, Sept. 9No one is fully sure where they have gone, but thousands of students appear to be pulling out of the public schools of Boston rather than participate in courtordered desegregation.

title: PLEDGES TO ISRAEL BY U.S. QUALlFIED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Secretary of State Kissinger has assured Israel privately, as part of the latest Sinai agreement with Egypt, that the United Stateswithin limitswould make every effort to be fully responsive to Israel's defense, energy and economic needs. But the actual language of United States commitments. seems less binding than Israel had initially sought.

title: Acrimony of '68 Gone From West Side
description: As a group of children trooped back into Public School 144 in Harlem after a nature walk early yesterday afternoon, a perky fourthgrader named Sylvia Caldwell turned her head toward the circle of picketing teachers outside the school on West 122d Street and said:

title: People in Sports
description: Vic Edwards, who became Evonne Goolagong's tennis coach and guardian when she was 13 years old, was dismissed yesterday as coach of the Pittsburgh Triangles, this year's World Team Tennis champions.

title: Democrats in Congress Offering Bill to Give Pipelines More Gas
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 9Senate and House Democrats introduced today emergency legislation to relieve the shortage of natural gas expected this winter.

title: Prof. Walter J. Derenberg Dies; Lawyer Was Copyright Expert
description: Prof. Walter J. Derenberg, a leading expert in copyright and trademark protection laws, died yesterday of a heart ailment in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 29 Washington Square West.

title: Ford OilPrice Veto Pushes Stocks Down
description: Investors' concern over inflation and higher interest rates sent the stock market sharply lower yesterday in ac??elerated trading.

title: Senate Intelligence Panel to Investigate Why C.I.A. Failed to Destroy Poisons
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence will investigate why the Central Intelligence Agency failed to destroy two supplies of poisonone a toxin derived from shellfish, the other a poison made from cobra venomthe committee chairman said today.

title: TV: Brooks and Robin Hood Legend
description: When Things Were Rotten is one of four new series making TV debuts this evening, and the production is not without distinctive characteristics. It is on ABC. It is on at 8 o'clock. And, as the audience should immediately guess, it is created by Mel Brooks, whose more recent credits include the films Blazing Saddles and Young Frankenstein.

title: Transworld Petroleum Tests Second Well in North Sea
description: The Transworld Petroleum Group announced yesterday the successful testing of a second well on Block 21/1 in the British sector of the North Sea. The well, a major discovery, flowed 18,827 barrels from four different depths.

title: Rich Family in Lisbon Struggles to Adjust to Revolution
description: LISBON, Sept. 9Eduardo Van Zeller is a wealthy Portuguese industrialist who, like most businessmen here, is having difficulties under the new regime but is trying to adjust and intends to stay.

title: HARBOR DESCRIBED AS GRAFTRIDDEN
description: New York harbor was described at a public hearing yesterday as the most graftridden port in the nation, a place where payoffs are routinely made to avoid tariffs and to Ret preferential treatment for loading places.

title: KENNEDYS' LETTERS ON MIDEAST FOUND
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Young Robert F.. Kennedy, writing to his father from the Middle East in April, 1948, discussed United States relations with the Arabs and added: I just wish they didn't have that oil.

title: Doctors Paid $100,000 a Year In Kidney Machine Program
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) The Government is paying some doctors more than $100,000 a year to provide mostly routine care for artificial kidney machine patients.

title: U.S. AIDES LINKED TTO GRAIN FRAUDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Fed eral officials responsible for the integrity of American grain standards have frequently yielded to industry pressures and ordered unjustified upgrading of quality ratings for export shipments, according to Government officials.

title: Fraud Losses at Banks Mushrooming
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9For American bank robbers, the pen and, to a lesser extent, the computerhave become mightier than the gun.

title: Eastern Jet Kept Safe Speed Before Crash That Killed 113
description: The pilot of the Eastern Airlines jet that crashed here in June maintained a safety margin of 9to20 knots of extra airspeed until just a few seconds before impact, according to documents introduced at a public hearing yesterday.

title: INDICTED BANK SUED BY 2 STOCKHOLDERS
description: Two stockholders of the Security National Bank have filed suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn seeking compensatory and punitive damages from the board of directors in office when the bank allegedly made more than $200,000 in illegal political contributions.

title: NEGOTIATIONS ON
description: ALBANY, Sept. 9The emergency plan to hold off default in New York City through a $2.3billion cash infusion and a statemandated restructuring of the city's fiscal management was signed into law by Governor Carey this morning, in the latest attempt to deal with the city's continuing financial agony.

title: Urge to Freedom
description: It is unlikely that Boris Spassky, the former world chess champion who lives in Moscow, and Martina Navratilova, the 18yearold Czechoslovak tennis star, have ever met. Yet, by a coincidence of timing this week, both these luminaries suddenly became new public symbols of revolt against the nastiness that so often characterizes Communistic bureaucratic repression.

title: As World Turns on CBS Will Expand to Hour Dec. 1
description: As the World Turns, the leading daytime soap opera on CBS, will join a number of others that have recently expanded from 30 minutes to an hour a day. The hourlong show will, start Dec. 1, running from 1:30 to 2:30 P.M., forcing cancellation of Edge of Night.

title: SHIFT IS RUMORED IN LEBANESE ARMY
description: BEIRUT, LEBANON, Sept. 9 As fierce fighting continued to rage in northern Lebanon between Moslems and Christians, Premier Rashid Karami announced tonight that he and President Suleiman Franjieh had agreed on a series of effective measures to bring peace to the poor, embattled region.

title: Article 3  No Title
Sigmund Arywitz Is Dead, Labor Leader on Coatt, 61
description: LOS ANGELES Sept. 9 (UPI)  Sigmund Arywitz, a longtime labor leader, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 61 years old.

title: Mostel, in Opera, Gets Zero for Conduct
description: LONDON, Sept. 9 (Reuters) The Broadway and film star, Zero Mostel, rolled into town recently for his first try at opera, and the British Broadcasting Corporation may never be the same.

title: Proposed Garbage Landfill Near Martin Van Buren Home Stirs Dispute
description: KINDERHOOK, N. Y.The Columbia County Board of Supervisors has decided that a sanitary landfill near Lindenwald, the home of Martin Van Buren, would not be unpatriotic, unsightly or a desecration of the memory of the eighth President.no debris would blow out, that only four or five trucks a day would be using the road, and that the trucks would not be a problem.

title: Our Lost Children
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Although Americans in recent decades have grown richer, our children have grown poorer. Many families no longer adequately perform the nurturing and supporting function that children need, emotionally and intellectually.

title: A Failure Here
description: Commissioner Ogden R. Reid of the State Department of Environmental Conservation has moved to stop two General Electric plants from dumping highly toxic chemical compounds into the Hudson River. The compounds, known as PCBs, are responsible for so high a degree of toxicity in fish that the commissioner felt compelled a month ago to warn against eating striped bass from the Hudson and coho salmon from Lake Ontario.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: An Embezzler Tells of Treading a Twisted Trail
description: Three years ago he was head teller at a major New York City savings bank. Two years ago he was spending up to $30,000 a day on the horses. One year ago he was a convict. Today the man who committed what is believed to be the largest embezzlement in savings bank history is a New York City taxicab driver, after having served 10 months in prison for his crime.

title: POLICE SERGEANT IS INDICTED HERE
description: A Bronx police sergeant was indicted on perjury charges yesterday by a grand jury that has been investigating the fatal beating of a 25yearold suspect who was being questioned in the Sedgwick Avenue police station last June 13.

title: State Publishers Elect Danzig President for 1976
description: BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Sept. (AP)Members of the New York State Publishers Association today elected Robert J. Danzig, publisher of the Albany Capital Newspapers, president for 1976 as they ended their twoday summer meeting here.

title: Bruno Gains Semifinals On Links
description: WILTON, Conn., Sept. 9Bob Bruno of the Pelham Country Club defeated AI Feminelli of Dellwood on the 19th hole at Rolling Hills C.C. today and reached the semifinal round of the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association championship.

title: Prisoner Shoots 2 Guards and Patient And Flees From Kings County Hospital
description: A 27yearold prisoner awaiting trial on murder charges yesterday critically wounded two correction officers and a wornan patient in a crowded hospital waiting room in Brooklyn using a gun concealed for him by an accomplice, the police said.

title: ROSEMARIE CARUTHERS
description: Rosemarie Falcone Caruthers, wife of Osgood Caruthers, assistant foreign news editor of The Los Angeles Times, died Saturday of cancer at the Santa Monica (Calif.) Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived in the Brentwood section of Los Angeles.

title: Suffolk Parties Said to Seek to Replace Feuding Aides
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 9Democrats and Republicans in Suffolk County are reportedly moving to replace Henry F. O'Brien, the county's District Attorney, and Eugene R. Kelley. the Police Commissioner and Mr. O'Brien's political rival.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The telephone number for the Essencial Cooking School in Hillsdale, N. J., was listed incorrectly in The New York Times yesterday. The number is (201) 6648968.

title: Expos Beat Mets in 10th, 21
description: MONTREAL. Sept. 9Mike Jorgensen, a former Met describd by his manager, Gene Mauch, before the game as not tough enough, was too tough for the Mets tonight.

title: I.B.M. Corp. Introduces A 50Pound Computer
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced yesterday its first portable computer, a 50pound unit priced far Iower than any other I.B.M. dataprocessing machine.

title: Pied Piperin One Ton Lead
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 9A year ago they were sailing the America's Cup races here to the accompaniment of great fanfare and much attention. A more competitive and interesting yachting series is being contested off Newport now. But apart from the competitors, who come from seven nations, almost no one appreciates what is going on. That's a tradition for you. The America's Cup has more than 100 years of momentum behind it while this event, the One Ton Class world championship is a comparatively new competition. It deserves more attention.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The telephone number for the Essencial Cooking School in Hillsdale, N. J., was listed incorrectly in The New York Times yesterday. The number is (201) 6648968.

title: CYPRIOTE PARLEY STILL DEADLOCKED
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 9Greek and Turkish Cypriote representatives blamed Oach other today for the deadlock In Cyprus peace talks as Secretary General Waldheim for the second day postponed the opening ceremony of their fourth round of negotiations.

title: Ford Tells Advisers Of Stand on City Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9President Ford today told a meeting of his economic advisers that there was no change in his strong opposition to Federal intervention in New York City's fiscal crisis, according to Ron Nessen, his press secretary.

title: Rookie Cut by Jets Stoical
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 9 Since his name starts with A, Tom Alward led the Jets todayhis name was on the top of the list of players cut as the New Yorkers trimmed their roster to 46.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: William Cahn, former Nassau County District Attorney, pleaded not guilty in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday at his arraignment on charges of income tax evasion, mail fraud, and perjury. He was released on his own recognizance without the formality of being fingerprinted or photographed. Mr. Cahn had been charged with doublebilling the county and the District Attorney's organization for more than $50,000 in expenses for attending conventions. After the arraignment, Mr. Cahn said I have been the beneficiary of the great system of justice in this country, and I now find myself a victim of that system.

title: MONTY PYTHON'S FULLY DIFFERENT
description: To augment the national program schedule of the Public Broadcasting Service that will begin this month, WNET/13 here has independently acquired new episodes of Monty Python's Flying Circus from the British Broadcasting Corporation; a 13part situation comedy from London Weekend Television, entitled No, Honestly, and a series of Tuesday night movies that will include the fourhour documentary by Marcel Ophuls, The Sorrow and the Pity, and Federico Fellini's Le Dolce Vite.

title: Stage: Royal Shakespeare Centenary
description: STRATFORD  ON  AVON, EnglandThe Royal Shakespeare Company at StratfordonAvon is celebrating this year a curious centenary not the centenary of the opening of the theater, but the centenary of the opening of the fund to build the theater! Oh well, it all helps to promote a little publicity for a company in jaunty artistic health yet ravaged with the worst financial disease of all, poverty.

title: Max H. Sklar, Industrialist And a Jewish Leader, 80
description: Max H. Sklar, chairman of the J. Sklar Manufacturing Company, makers of surgical instruments, died Monday of a heart ailment at the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived at 45 Sutton Place South and in Byram Conn.

title: Policy on Consultants Revised by Lockheed
description: The Board of directors of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has adopted a stringent new policy governing the solicitation, use and payment of international consultants, it was announced yesterday in Burbank, Calif.

title: City Schools Are Crippled As Teachers' Strike Starts
description: A teachers' strike crippled the city school system on the second day of the new term yesterday, forcing at least 260 schools to shut down and keeping nearly all of the 1.1 million pupils out of classes.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 9 (UPI)Engine sizes now in effect in United States Auto Club competition will remain unchanged. for five more years, USAC's board of directors voted yesterday. The board also agreed that the 1.8 milespergallon fuel formula should be continued next year. Furthermore, the board agreed that a valve be installed holding manifold pressure to 75 inches for qualifying and in the case of turbocharged engines, that the same limit also be maintained for races. At the present time, a pressure relief valve is set at SO inches and used only for qualifying.

title: Cultural Center to Close After 11 Years
description: The New York Cultural Center, the maverick art gallery conceived by Huntington Hartford and later adopted by Fairleigh Dickinson University, will close its doors on Sunday after 11 years of life, a victim of acute fiscal anemia.

title: About Education
description: Class size is one major issue in the city's teacher strike on which negotiators can get surprisingly little help from social scientists.

title: Notes on People
description: With anchors aweigh and eyes agoggle, the men of the nuclear submarine Finback put to see from Port Canaveral, Fla., on July 10 with a topless gogo dancer performing on deck. The story came out yesterday when a Pentagon spokesman confirmed that the Finback's skipper, 41yearold Comdr. Connelly D. Stevenson was relieved of command Aug. 1 and is now assigned to a desk job at the Norfolk, Va., naval base. He is preparing an appeal through Navy legal channels.

title: PANEL VOTES END TO TAX SHELTER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to close the avenues whereby individuals with large incomes legally avoid paying Federal income taxes by investing in farming operations that generate paper losses.

title: Advertising
description: The first television advertising for the New York State Lotteryaimed primarily at the impulse rather than the hard core buyerbreaks today on 20 stations throughout the state.

title: Unemployment Up in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 9 (UPI)Seasonally adjusted unemployment rose to 7.3 per cent in August, the Canadian Government reported today. It was the highest since June, 1961.

title: New Books
description: A Pattern of Peoples: A Journey Among the Tribes of Indonesia's Outer Islands by Robin HanburyTenison, foreword by Malcolm MacDonald (Scribners. $9.95).

title: House Overrides Ford Veto Of School Aid Bill, 37941
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The House of Representatives easily overrode today President Ford's veto of a $7.9billion education appropriations bill.

title: Pirates Lose, Lead Phillies by 6 Games
description: Andy Thornton delivered two key hits, a solo home run in the third and a runscoring single in the seventh, to spark Chicago to a 65 victory over the firstplace Pirates in Pittsburgh last night.

title: A Hobbyist's Recipes (Cont'd)
description: 3 carrots, slivered or chopped very finely

title: Ford Vetoes Oil Price Bill; Override Vote Set Today
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 President Ford vetoed a sixmonth extension of price controls on domestic oil today, declaring that the controls had caused a massive flow of American dollars and jobs abroad.

title: Satellite's Scarmings Back Theory on Peril to Ozone
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Satellite observations of fluorooarbons in the stratosphere support the hypothesis that the material, which is used in aerosol spray cans, may be breaking down the earth's ozone shield, according to participants in the satellite project.

title: Amtrak Ordering 125M.P.H. Trains For Run to Buffalo
description: The New YorkAlbanyBuffalo rail corridor is getting seven new Frenchdesigned turbinepowered trains capable of doing 125 miles an hour, and the first of the trains will go into service next summer.

title: A Cooking Hobbyist Who Enjoys Doing Everything Himself
description: WATCH HILL, R. I.When John W. Mazzola was a teenager growing up in New Jersey, his grandfather introduced him to the pleasures of gracious dining.

title: Carey Signs Aid Plan Imposing Fiscal Curbs on City
description: earlier this year by the state to sell bonds in behalf of the city. The M.A.C., after raising $2billion, found investors cold, to the city and demanding dramatic evidence that city officials would be forced to cut back severely.

title: STABILITY URGED IN RAW MATERIALS
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9The industrial union department of the A.F.L.C.I.O. made public today a study of raw materials that are vital to American industry and urged that the United States take steps to insure longterm raw materials stability.

title: Events Today
description: Films

title: U.S. Savings Banks and Associations Experiencing Sharp Drop in Deposits
description: The nation's savings banks and savings and loan associations, the prime sources of mortgage loans for housing, have begun to experience sharp decline in deposits.

title: Second Day of Boston Busing Quiet; Attendance Is Off
description: BOSTON, Sept. 9The second day of courtordered citywide busing for school desegregation was generally quiet today, but with attendance still markedly low.

title: Blacks in Boston Hail Marshals
description: BOSTON, Sept. 9  They wear red, white and blue armbands that say U.S. Marshal and they represent the Federal presence during the expanded desegregation of schools in Boston.

title: COMMON MARKET PROTESTS ON CARS
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 9 (AP)The European Economic Community voiced a stiff protest today on the continuation of the United States Government's investigation into charges that foreign cars were being dumped in the United States at less than fair value and were harming the American automobile industry.

title: Saving the City
description: The intricate series of maneuvers, commitments and legislative action through which New York City has been rescued from the disaster of default provides muchneeded reassurance of democratic society's capacity to overcome partisanship and selfish interest in the face of crisis.

title: Article 2  No Title
Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: American League

title: Oil Curbs and Inflation
description: President Ford's veto of the hill to keep controls on oil prices for six months longer could lead to a worsening of inflation and additional drags on the economic recovery if it leads to sudden and total decontrot of oil prices, according to a number of economic analyses, including those of the Congressional Budget Office.

title: Athletes Plead for More Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9We're all professionals, Frank Shorter told the President's Commission on Olympic Sports today, and proceeded to enliven its hearing with testimony on the fiscal frailties of America's amateur athletes. He called for a realistic approach to the needs of athletes.

title: U.S. Predicts a Rise In RedBloc Trade
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The Commerce Department sued yesterday a report predicting that United States exports of manufactured goods to socialist countries could rise to about $4.5billion by 1980, compared with about $717million in 1974.

title: Tenneco Planning to Build Chemical Plant in Fords
description: FORDS, Sept. 9 (AP)Tenneco Chemicals Inc. of Houston has confirmed that it is considering constructing a multimilliondollar chemical plant on a site adjacent to its present facility in Fords.

title: $1Billion Budget
description: Like the first Viking, launched from Florida on Aug. 20, the craft is designed to go into orbit around Mars and detach a lander equipped to search for evidence of lifeforms.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: In 36 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the prices of eyeglasses and contact lenses may not be advertised. As a result, consumers are paying 25 to 100 per cent more than they should be, Senator Charles H. Percy charged in a recent letter to the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Coaches Threaten Stoppage
description: The executive committee of the Public Schools Athletic League Coaches Association will recommend to the membership tonight that all coaching be halted unless the Board of Education restores the $982,138 cut from the city's $2.4million school athletic budget. The coaches will meet at 6 P.M. at the High School of Printing, 439 West 49th Street.

title: California Invites Ford
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 9 (AP)The State Senate voted 30 to 0 yesterday to invite President Ford to visit California again. The resolution thanked him for his visit last Friday and expressed regret for the alleged attempt on his life when a woman pointed a pistol at him as he shook hands at the edge of a crowd.

title: Fraud Losses at Banks Mushrooming
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9For American bank robbers, the pen and, to a lesser extent, the computerhave become mightier than the gun.

title: PRINCIPALS SPLIT ON SCHOOL STRIKE
description: Principals of Most of the city's high schools broke with their union yesterday by opening their schools in defiance of a call by the Council of Supervisors and Administrators to stay away in support of the teachers' strike.

title: Minister Sues to Bar School Gift of Bibles
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 9 (UPI)A retired Congregational minister filed suit in United States District Court today to stop the Zeeland public schools from handing out Bibles at high school granduation.

title: Senate Report on Safety Disputed by Nursing Group
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) The American Health Care Association, the nation's largest nursing home federation, disputed today a Senate report that ranked nursing homes as number one on the list of unsafe places to live.

title: Article 1  No Title
Savoy Quartet, in Central Park, Adds Toughness to Boogie Rock
description: The small audience that turned up for the Savoy Brown concert in Central Park on Mondayspart of the Schaefer Music Festivalshowed how tightly audience appreciation is geared to hit recording status. Savoy Brown, a British rock group of long and high standing, has played in New York often but this time it does not have a recording that reflects the current group on the market. The Savoys have gone through many personnel changes but the 1975 version, a quartet, stays close to the kind of music produced over the last few years, fairly high standard boogie rock, not too far out but not confined to basic chord changes.

title: About Real Estate
description: The term that describes what is happening between 44th Street and 45th Street on the east side of Seventh Avenue is interim operation.

title: MIDEAST TERMED IN CRUCIAL PHASE
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 9Wellplaced Israeli officials and political observers feel that the next two months will be a critical period for peace in the Middle East.

title: Latest Tout Is a Computer
description: In roughly the time it takes a tout to say Pssst!, a datacrammed computer analyzed the field for the $250,000 Marlboro Cup yesterday and picked Foolish Pleasure as the likeliest winner.

title: SCHOOL ATTENDANCE RISES IN LOUISVILLE
description: LOUISVILLE, Sept. 9 (AP)School officials reported attendance climbing in a sampling of Jefferson County schools today, a generally peaceful fourth day of courtordered busing to achieve integration.

title: India Expects Resumption Of American Economic Aid
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 9 (Reuters)Finance Minister Chidambaram Subramaniam said today he expected the United States to resume economic aid to India during the current financial year and supply at least 500,000 tons of wheat.

title: The Earth Trembles
description: In the manmade, small war on Cyprus last year some 300 Turkish combatants were killed until a halt was called; In the earthquake that has wrecked the town of Lice and nearby villages in eastern Turkey, the toll so far is 2,000. The tragedy of buried families and houses crushed like matchsticks in this earthquake prone region serves as a trembling reminder of the fragility of life in many corners of the world.

title: Gordie Howe Plans One More Ice Turn
description: TORONTO, Sept. 9 (AP)Gordie Howe, hockey's career leading scorer, will become the first playing president in hockey history when he skates for the Houston Aeros of the World Hockey Association in their season opener.

title: New Law Regulating Auto Repair Shops Called a Step Back
description: The city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Elinor C. Guggenheimer, charged yesterday that the new state law designed to protect consumers from incompetent or dishonest auto repairs would, in certain respects, mean less protection for New York City consumers than they had now.

title: California Invites Ford
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 9 (AP)The State Senate voted 30 to 0 yesterday to invite President Ford to visit California again. The resolution thanked him fo rhis visit last Friday and expressed regret for the alleged attempt on his life when a woman pointed a pistol at him as he shook hands at the cadge of a crowd.

title: BENTSEN IS GIVEN SPENDING LIMITS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The Federal Election Commission ruled today that Senator Lloyd Bensten, who is running simultaneously in 1976 for the Presidency and the Senate, cannot spend more on his home state campaign than his Republican Senate opponent spends.

title: Guard Callup Halts Bus Run
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 9 (AP)Pupils at two schools complained when the bus failed to show up to carry them to classes in Jefferson County's newly desegregated system. Officials checked yesterday and learned why John Jenkins, the bus driver, was absent. Mr. Jenkins was one of 800 National Guardsmen called to duty to maintain order in Jefferson County, which has been hit by a series of antibusing demonstrations.

title: New Bill Compounds Impostor's Chutzpah
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin, who has disregarded $13,000 in bills for furniture and a car sent to the city by Robert Swarz, a man accused of posing as a commissioner for a nonexistent city agency, was asked yesto reimburse the alleged imposter $1,995 for an upper East Side city apartment for my use.

title: Golden Voice of the Golden Boy
description: With two minutes to play in the first half, the Philadelphia Bell had the ball and Paul Hornung was down on the sideline with a microphone so the World Football League's television audience, if any, could hear King Corcoran, the quarterback, discuss tactics with Ron Waller, the coach. The Bell, like all professional teams, was prepared with a twominute drill in which plays are run swiftly one after another in the hope of scoring before time expires. The summit conference ended and Corcoran jogged back to the huddle. Hornung remained at the coach's elbow. The teams lined up and Waller saw the linebackers about to blitz.

title: An Egg Within an Egg
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. (AP)A White Rock chicken belonging to a San Antonio policeman, Herbert Koening, recently laid an egg containing an egg. The outer egg contained the usual yoke and white, as well as the second egg in a shell.

title: LEONARD ZNEIMER, TAUGHT RETARDED
description: Leonard Zneimer, founder and director of the Rhinebeck (N.Y.) Country School for the retarded, died yesterday of a heart attack at the Philadelphia International Airport. He was 60 years old and lived on Foxhollow Road in Rhinebecic.

title: Policemen Ousted in Strike
description: Skokie, Ill., Sept. 9 (UPI) Twentyone policemen were dismissed last night because of their roles in this summer's strike, reducing the force to less than half its normal complement. The Police and Fire Commission found the men in violation of department rule?? last July for failing to report for duty in a dispute over wages. Their dismissal increased to 26 the number of patrolmen ousted because of the strike.

title: DEMOCRATS TO OPEN CAUCUSES IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9In a break with tradition, Democrats in the House of Representatives voted today to open their party caucuses to the public when they discuss pending legislation.

title: State's Approval for Use Of Funds Held Needed
description: The focus on productivity as the key issue in the teachers' strike sharpened yesterday, and the president of the Board of Education said the deadlock could not be broken without intervention by Governor Carey.

title: U.S. Asks States to Show They Enforce Speed Limit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) The Department of Transportation directed the states today to furnish data showing that they were enforcing the 55mileperhour speed limit, and that they were monitoring the speeds at which motorists were driving.

title: Adamle Traded to Bears for Halfback
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 9 After the Jets' running corps was depleted by what Coach Charley Winner described as the worst series of injuries I've seen since coaching in the National Football League, the New Yorkers today acquired Carl Garrett of the Chicago Bears.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
SUIT SAYS SCHOOL FORCED DRUG USE
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Sept. 9 (AP)A suit has been filed here on behalf of 17 school children in nearby Taft alleging that school officials forced them to take a drug that in at least one case caused an epileptical seizure.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: W.P.A. During the Depression, the Works Progress Administration, a government work program that was the butt of many jokes about onthejob loafing, provided about 10,000 artists with $25aweek jobs that allowed them to produce paintings, rugs, sculptures, prints and murals.

title: Britain's 1975 Food Output Seen as Lowest Since 1947
description: LONDON, Sept. 9 (AP)Britain's food production for 1975 is likely to be the lowest in almost 30 years, the Ministry of Agriculture estimated today.

title: INDUSTRY IN TRENTON RESUMES OPERATION
description: TRENTON, Sept. 9 (AP)Industry in the Trenton area resumed operations Tuesday and public and parochial schools opened for the new term a week late as the city's water problems eased substanially.

title: Manson Follower Never Intended To Shoot at Ford
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 9 (AP)A lawyer says that Lynette Fromme told him in jail that she never intended to shoot President Ford.

title: Secretary of Interior Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9I think he's qualified, said Senator Quentin N. Burdick, Democrat of North Dakota, when asked his views on President Ford's nomination today of thomas Savid Kleppe, 56 years old, to be Secretary of the Interior. But. he added, I think I'm a pretty charitable fellow to support him.

title: Rock Art Shows a Supernova
description: On the morning of July 5, 1054, a minor star in the constellation Taurus appeared suddenly to explode into extraordinary brilliance. Ancient Chinese astronomers observed the event, which is now known to have been the supernova that created the Crab Nebula, and recorded that it was visible in daylight for 23 days before fading. It could be seen at night for another 633 days.

title: A Drive on Hidden Money Worrying India's Wealthy
description: BOMBAY, Sept. 9At an elegant dinner party in one of Bombay's many luxurious penthouse apartments the other night, a guest, making a gentle compliment, said that although the place settings were only sterling silver, our hostess is pure gold.

title: Weekly Market Basket
description: The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City was practically unchanged last week, according to the City Department of Consumer Affairs, with the arrival of grassfed beef providing no further relief from high meat prices and with seasonal declines in some fruit and vegetable failing to materialize.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Andrew Axt 2d, a commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said that as far as I can see, there will be no increase this year in PATH fares, but he did not rule out an increase next year. The fare on the 13.9mile Port Authority TransHudson rail system, which connects Newark, Jersey City and Hoboken with Manhattan, has remained at 30 cents since the authority took it over in 1962.

title: The President's Safety vs. Citizens' Rights
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 9How could it happen? appalled Americans asked last week after a young woman known to be an associate of the convicted murderer Charles M. Manson approached within arm's length of President Ford and pointed a loaded gun at him.

title: MILTON RECKORD, TOP M.P., 95, DEAD
description: Maj. Gen. Milton A. Reckord, chief of the Army's military police units in the European Theater of Operations in World War H, died Monday at Ford Howard Hospital, Baltimore. He was 95 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: KISSINGER CITES GAIN IN PORTUGAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 The gains by aniCommunist forces in Portugal during the last two weeks were described by Secretary of State Kissinger today as encouraging for the Ford Administration.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Detectives Group to Honor Two Firemen Here Tonight
description: Two members of the Fire, Department will be honored tonight by the Retired Detectives Association for distinguished service as the first recipients of the Vincent M. Canty Memorial Award, set up recently as a tribute to the late First Deputy Fire Commissioner and former chief fire marshal.

title: Sihanouk Returns to a Big Welcome in Phnom Penh
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 9  Five and a half years after being forced into exile, Prince Norodom Sihanouk returned to a triumphant welcome today in Phnom Penh, the capital of a Cambodia vastly different from the one he ruled for nearly three decades.

title: Surely Not Mr. Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Former President Richard Nixon is said by his friends to have recovered his health, but there is very little evidence that he has recovered his judgment or his sense of history.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: U.S. Official Denounces Critics of TooBlack Army
description: GARMISCH  PARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Sept. 9 (UPI)  A highranking American defense official today denounced suggestions that the volunteer United States Army had too many black soldiers.

title: Highlights of Fiscal Plan
description: ALBANY, Sept. 9The act passed by the special session of the Legislature and signed into law early this morning by Governor Carey provides the city with $2.3billion to stave off fiscal collapse at least until early December. But it transfers control of the city's budget from the local elected officials to a new statedominated board.

title: Key West Officials Held in Drug Case
description: MIAMI, Sept. 9In what law enforcement officias here described as a wholesale cleanup in the city of Key West, Federal, state and county drug agents arrested 15 persons in Key West today, including the city attorney and the fire chief, on charges of possession, sale and conspiracy to sell cocaine and heroin.

title: Miss Ashley Sparks The Skin of Our Teeth
description: When Thornton Wilder's The Skin of Our Teeth was first produced in 1942 and Sabina, the maid of all trades, paused in her flirtatious assault on mankind to comment on the play, I don't understand a single word of it, undoubtedly there were people in the audience who echoed that statement.

title: GATT Violation Is Seen
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 9If the Treasury endorses the dumping allegations, exports of European cars may become subject to heavy antidumping duties a prospect that makes it difficult for European manufacturers to plan ahead, Common Market officials said today.

title: Reported Crimes in July
Contract Awards
description: Two Spanish utilities have selected the General Electric Company to supply $219million worth of equipment for a new nuclear power plant in Spain. The Spanish companies are Hidroelectica Espanola and Compania Sevillana de Electricida.

title: 2.000th Shia for Suez
description: SUEZ, Egypt, Sept. 9 (UPI) The 2,000th tollpaying ship to pass through the Suez Canal since it reopened three months ago steamed through the waterway today. It was the Mount Explorer, owned by the Cove Tankers Corporation of New York.

title: Sihanouk Goes Home
description: Five and a half years after he was forced into exile, Prince Norodom Sihanouk received a triumphant welcome in Phnom Penh when he returned as titular head of state to Cambodia. Page 3.

title: Lightning Kills Woman, Baby in Arms Is Unhurt
description: KNOXVILLE, Iowa, Sept. 9 (UPI)A bolt of lightning so strong it vaporized electrical wiring killed a housewife yesterday, but did not harm an 18month old Vietnamese orphan she was holding in her arms, Dr. John Griffin, the Marion County medical examiner, reported.

title: Gun Owner Identified
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 9 (UPI)A retired draftsman was identified today as the owner of the gun used by Lynette Fromme in the attempted assassination of President Ford last Friday.

title: Landmark Restaurant Is Demolished by Fire at Point Pleasant Beach
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH, Sept. 9A midafternoon fire Destroyed Martel's Seabreeze, boardwalk restaurant and avern, here today.

title: Monday's Fights
description: New York(At Felt Forum) Tom Bethea, 177 pounds, Brooklyn, outpointed Angel Oquenda, 178, New York, 10 rounds; Mario Rosa, 161, Paterson, N. J., outpointed Chris Black, 161, New York, 10.

title: STRIKE MIGHT SAVE MILLIONS FOR CITY
description: The city's Board of Education could realize a saving of $4.5million to $5.5million each day that it does not have to pay its striking teachers, a board spokesman said yesterday. But this amount would be substantially reduced by subsequent losses of about $1million a day in state aid, depending on the extent of pupil attendance during the strike.

title: Drug Death Brought No Halt to Tests
description: Less than a year after a patient died in an Armysponsored experiment with an hallucinogenic drug at the New York State Psychiatric Institute, the Army gave the institute another contract for nearly $143,000 to continue experimenting on humans for four more years. an Army spokesman disclosed yesterday.

title: NEGOTIATIONS ON
description: ALBANY, Sept. 9The emergency plan to hold off default in New York City through a $2.3billion cash infusion and a statemandated restructuring of the city's fiscal management was signed into law by Governor Carey this morning, in the latest attempt to deal with the city's continuing financial agony.

title: Article 4  No Title
U.S. AIDES LINKED TO GRAIN FRAUDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Federal officials responsible for the integrity of American grain standards have frequently yielded to industry pressures and ordered unjustified upgrading of quality ratings for export shipments, according to Government officials.

title: TURKS CALLED LAX ON QUAKE RELIEF
description: LICE, Turkey, Sept. 9Turkish soldiers with submachine guns stood guard at the main entrance to this earthquakeravaged village today and grim army squads patrolled the rubblestrewn lanes.

title: Briefs on the Arts
