description: One hundred traditional art pieces from the national collection of the Government of Zaire will travel to museums throughout the United States beginning this fall.

title: Nicoma Colt Brings A Record $110,000
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 9 (AP)Listen John, a dark bay yearling by Speak John out of Nicoma, brought a record price for a colt of $110,000 tonight in the fourth session of the Keeneland Fall Yearling Sales.

title: Satellite's Scarmings Back Theory on Peril to Ozone
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Satellite observations of fluorooarbons in the stratosphere support the hypothesis that the material, which is used in aerosol spray cans, may be breaking down the earth's ozone shield, according to participants in the satellite project.

title: About New York
description: Bus riding in New York is in some ways much like a bus tour on longrange trips. You see the country Close at hand and yet you do not become part of it. The window glass filters out involvement even as it permits observation. To the rider with a seat and a window and an inquiring mind it may raise more questions than mere looking will answer.

title: 'Twas the Old Tunes, the Old Dreams, and Children Dancing
description: MIDDLE ISLAND, L. I.Nine Irish dancing girls from Bridie McCarthy's class in County Rockland were riding to the seventh annual Suffolk County Feis here the other day when a 7yearold in blue curlers suddenly turned green.

title: Books of The Times
description: At first, the notion of an illustrated history of World War II with a text by James Jones struck me as one of those superficially logical ideas that deeper down. makes no sense whatever. For while Mr. Jones, in temperament and as the author of one of the three or four best novels to come out of the war, seems to go with the subject like butter with bread, on closer reflection the obstacles seem insurmountable. The whole history seems far too vast and complexly episodic to be covered decently in what appears to be a rather thin coffeetable book, even for a military analyst with firsthand knowledge of both the European and Far Eastern theaters of battle. Mr. Jones's own experience de cidedly limited; he served in the war against Japan until he was sent home to recuperate from ankle surgery early in 1943, and he served as an enlisted man, cut off from strategic thinking and what they used to call the big picture.

title: HOFFA SON BELIEVES FATHER WAS SLAIN
description: DETROIT, Sept. 9 (AP)The son of James R. Hoffa, the missing former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said today for the first time that he believed his father was deadthe victim of assassinationbut does not know who killed him.

title: Rabin Says Soviet Must Now Court Arab Extremists
description: BONN, Sept. 9 (AP)  Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel says that Soviet influence in the Middle East is waning and that Moscow will react by increasing support to extremists in the Arab world.

title: POLICE SERGEANT IS INDICTED HERE
description: A Bronx police sergeant was indicted on perjury charges yesterday by a grand jury that has been investigating the fatal beating of a 25yearold suspect who was being questioned in the Sedgwick Avenue police station last June 13.

title: FARM UNION BEATS TEAMSTERS AGAIN
description: DELANO, Calif., Sept. 9The United Farm Workers defeated the International Brotherhood of Teamsters today in a collective bargaining representation election at the Lawrence Vineyards Company here. The vote Wall 150 to 110, with 22 workers against having any union.

title: BURKE DEFENDS SCHOOLAID BILL
description: TRENTON. Sept. 9  State Education Commissioner Fred G. Burke said today that legislation before the Assembly would limit rather than broaden the state's authority to intervene in local school affairs.

title: VIKING 2 LAUNCHED ON TRIP TO MARS
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 9 (AP)A Viking 2 spacecraft was launched today on a mission to join a sister ship and both are to seek signs of past or present life on Mars.

title: SENATE CURBS USE OF A CATTLE DRUG
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) The Serrate approved legislation today to end the use of the drug DES in cattle feeding until scientific studies on its cancercausing potential can prove it safe for human consumntion.

title: Cartoon Look at RentaCar Woes
description: The problems that the businessman faces in rentacar land will be the subjects of cartoons for a coming ad campaign from the Avis Rent A Car System. You know them, they're the second team that keeps trying.

title: Strike of Teachers Is First Challenge For New State Unit
description: Among the immediate tests facing the new sevenmember Emergency Financial Control Board in restoring investor confidence in the city is the as yet undefined role it will play in any settlement of the current teachers' strike and the credibility of any plan the board approves for cutting the city's current budget.

title: Udall Aide Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Set. 9 (UPI) John Gabusi, a top campaign aide in Aepresentative Morris K. Udali's quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, resigned today for personal reasons Mr. Udall is a Democrat of Arizona.

title: Prices of Grains Continue to Drop For 2d Day in Row
description: Carryover selling from Monday depressed prices of wheat, corn and soybeans further yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The selling in the last two days came following two crop estimates issued at the weekend.

title: Sihanouk Goes Home
description: Five and a half years after he was forced into exile, Prince Norodom Sihanouk received a triumphant welcome in Phnom Penh when he returned as titular head of state to Cambodia. Page 3.

title: On the Picket Lines, a Mournful Militance
description: All over New York, teachers mourned the school system yesterday. They were militant and even euphoric, the way strikers often are the first day they go out, but mostly they were unhappy and angry. They said the city had let them and their students down.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER OFF
description: Reversing the moderate gains of early in the day, prices closed lower on both the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market yesterday in continued light trading.

title: John McGiver, Actor, 62, Dies; Did TV, Film Character Roles
description: John McGiver, a Bronx schoolteacher who became a noted character actor on Broadway, in films and on television, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 62 yearsold and lived in West Fulton, N. Y., a small community some 40 miles west of Albany.

title: Strikes Bar Thousands From Schools in State
description: Strikes by teachers and school service workers seeking better conditions and higher pay kept thousands of New Jersey students from attending classes yesterday in districts around The state.

title: PLEDGES TO ISRAEL BY U.S. QUALIFIED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Secretary of State Kissinger has assured Israel privately, as part of the latest Sinai agreement with Egypt, that the United Stateswithin limitswould make every effort to be fully responsive to Israel's defense, energy and economic needs. But the actual language of United States commitments seems less binding than Israel had initially sought.

title: Bill Is Passed to Return Veterans Day to Nov. 11
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI)The House voted today to return to celebrating Veterans Day on Nov. 11 as originally designated, instead of the fourth Monday in October as declared in 1968 when Congress increased the number of threeday holiday weekends.

title: Regular Democrats Claim Victories
description: Regular Democratic organizations in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens apparently scored victories in yesterday's primary election in contests with reformers and insurgents for party nominations for a City Council seat in Brooklyn and Civil Court seats in all but four counties.

title: Lottery's Clover Club On Consumer Blacklist
description: TRENTON, Sept. 9 (UPI)A New Jersey consumer group removed the state lottery's Clover Club from its register of recommended services because a man from Milltown complained that he had been paid only $25 on a winning ticket he thought was worth $2,500.

title: Labor and Environmental Units Feud Over Road Funds in Byrne Bond Plan
description: NEWARK, Sept. 9A dispute between organized labor and environmental groups over a comparatively small portion of Governor Byrne's $900million capital needs bond program was viewed today as jeopardizing the entire bond package.

title: Under Soviet Communism, All Pickpockets Are Equal
description: NOW I realize why Congress recently legislated an unprecedented 65 weeks of unemployment benefits: because of a possibility that eight million people might pick up knives, guns and axes, and find themselves a position in the already sufficiently powerful army of American muggers.

title: Focus on Syria's Stand
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 9Syria has sharply criticized Egypt for agreeing to an interim accord with Israel, but her own position toward possible negotiations with Israel over the Golan Heights is fast becoming a bone of contention in the Abrab world.

title: Spanish Church Unit Asks Clemency for Two Basques
description: MADRID, Sept. 9 (UPI)A human  rights organization sponsored by Spain's Roman Catholic Church asked today that the government scrap a controversial antiterrorism law and spare the lives of two Basque separatists condemned to death last month for the killing of a policeman.

title: Rock Art Shows a Supernova
description: On the morning of July 5, 1054, a minor star the constellation Taurus appeared suddenly to explode into extraordinary brilliance. Ancient Chinese astronomers observed the event, which is now known to have been the supernova that created the Crab Nebula, and recorded that it was visible in daylight for 23 days before fading. It could be seen at night for another 633 days.

title: Jersey City Gets a SchoolBuilding Plan
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 9Mayor Paul T. Jordan today disclosed a $65million program for building and modernizing schools that he described as the largest every undertaken in New Jersey.

title: BROOKLYN SEEK SUBJECT OF SUIT
description: A group of students and instructors at Brooklyn College has filed suit to prevent the college's president from diverting funds earmarked for the SEEK and openadmission programs to regular academic programs.

title: CBS LEADS RATINGS ON OPENING NIGHT
description: CBSTV dominated the ratings on Monday, which was opening night of the fall in prime time. According to the New York overnight Nielsen ratings, the CBS lineup of programs averaged 50 per cent of the audience watching television here between 8 and 11 P.M.

title: 8 of 10 Members of Board Oppose Tuition at City U.
description: At least eight of the 10.memhers of the Board of Higher Education are standing by the concept of free tuition at the City. University of New York, despite a call by the. State Education Commissioner tol impose charges of $650 a yearl for freshman and sophomores and $800 for juniors and seniors.

title: Most Miners in West Virginia Return Except in One County
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 9 (AP)Most of West Virginia's coal mines were back in production today, but the monthlong wildcat strike lingered on in Logan County in the southern part of the state.

title: Psychiatrist Counsels on Care and Feeding of the Frisbee
description: Depressed by what he called the insanity of a Marine base, during a tour of duty some years ago, Dr. Stancil E. D. Johnson counterattacked with a Frisbee.

title: Market Place
description: The Japanese can be tough competitors.

title: Amtrak Is Ordering 7 HighSpeed Trains
description: The New YorkAlbanyBuffalo rail corridor is getting seven new Frenchdesigned turbinepowered trains capable of doing 125 mles an hour, and the first of the trains will go into service next summer.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger assured Israel privately, as part of the Sinai agreement with Egypt, that the United States would make every effort within certain limits to he fully responsive to Israel's defense, energy and economic needs. But the actual language of United States commitments. as disclosed to The New York Times by a highly reliable informant, seems less binding than Israel had initially sought. Many of the key provisions of the unpublished assurances and undertakings were qualified by references to the need for Congressional approval and the limits on American resources. [Page 1, Column 4]

title: State's Consumer Board Urges Reduced Phone Rate Increase
description: The operating head of the state's Consumer Protection Board asked the Public Service Commission yesterday to approve only $100million of $280million a year that a commission examiner is recommending be granted to the New York Telephone Company in rate increases.

title: NEW G.M. MINICAR COMPETES IN PRICE
description: DETROIT, Sept. 9The cheapest version of the new General Motors Corporation m.n car, the Chevette, is expected to sell for about $2,900 but most models will be in the same range as the subcompact Chevrolet Vega, with prices exceeding $3,000, according to auto industry sources.

title: Tennis Coaches Named
description: DENTON, Tex., Sept. 9 (AP)Mark Floyd and Casey Moore, graduate students, were named today to serve as North Texas State tennis coaches. Both were senior letter men last year for the Eagles.

title: To Open the Schools
description: A New York teachers' strike, damaging to a million pupils at any time, is a particular calamity in light of the city's desperate situation. At best, such an illegal shutdown has a devastating effect on children's perception of school and society; now its impact must be viewed against the backdrop of an embattled and enfeebled city whose ultimate recovery depends as much on faith in the stability of its institutions as on money itself. The closing of the schools, apart from the anguish it causes in thousands of homes, is a severe blow to this badly needed faith.

title: 8 of 10 Members of Board Oppose Tuision at City U.
description: At least eight of the 10 members of the Board of Higher Education are standing by the concept of free tuition at the City University of New York, despite a call by the State Education Commissioner to impose charges of $650 a year for freshman and sophomores and $800 for juniors and seniors.

title: The Yellow Star and the Pink Triangle
description: BY NOW nearly everyone knows about the Danes' resistance to Nazi antiSemitism during World War II, and how their resistance spared almost all Danish Jews from the barbarism that took the lives of six million other Jews. The Danish resistance was perhaps best symbolized by the reported willingness of King Christian X to appear in public wearing a yellow Star of David as a sign of fellowship with the persecuted minority.

title: National Welfare Rolls Show 1st Decline in Year
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI)Welfare roils declined last May for the first time since May, 1974, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today. Welfare payments also were down in May by $6,718,000 to nearly $736million.

title: 4 Concerns Reduce Wholesale Prices Of Industrial Sugar
description: The Amstar Corporation, the Sucrest Corporation, the National Sugar Refining company and the Corn Products unit of CPC International. Inc., all posted a price reduction of 65 cents a hundred pounds on wholesale prices for industrial sugars, effective today. The reductions brings the price of a hundred pounds of extrafine granulated sugar to $23.65 and drops the price of two other industrial grades of bulk granulated and liquid No. 2 sugar to $23.05 a hundred pounds.

title: U.S. Asks a Judge to Jail 2 in Patricia Hearst Case
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 9 (UPI)  Government prosecutors said today that they had asked a Federal judge to send two figures in the Patricia Hearst investigation to jail for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury.

title: OneHorse Stable A OneMan Stable
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 9 Fred Spencer, a former tool and die maker at the Grumman Corporation in nearby Bethpage, has found a way to beat the races for the last 16 years. How does he do it? By being the owner, trainer, driver and groom of a onehorse racing stable. I've had as many as three horses at one time, said the 63yearold Englishborn horseman after triumphing with his 4yearold gelding Nomad Hanover in last night's first race at Roosevelt Raceway. But I don't relish that type of modus operandi. It's too taxing.

title: L.I. Man Tied to Pornography Is Sentenced for Tax Evasion
description: Martin J. Hodas, described by police officials as a pornography king with links to organized crime, received a oneyear prison sentence yesterday for evading taxes on his Times Square peepshow operations

title: Unions Halt Fight Over Soviet Grain
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The White House announced today a temporary end to the labor dispute that has threatened to disrupt massive shipments of American grain to the Soviet Union.

title: Teachers Resume Negotiations In Strike at Catholic Schools
description: Negotiations were held for the first time yesterday since unionized teachers went on strike at five Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens last Wednesday, but no settlement was achieved.

title: PEAK RATES LOOM ON STATE'S NOTES
description: Underwriters are expected to offer $755million of New York State shortterm notes today at record newissue levels for the state. The final prices are subject to negotiation between the underwriting group, led by the Chase Manhattan Bank, and State, Controller Arthur) Levitt.

title: MRS. MAX HIRSON
description: Hazel Abbey Hirson, the wife of Max M. Hirson, senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Putney, Twombley, Hall & Hirson, died Monday at The Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital She was 80 years old and lived at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N. Y.

title: Business Briefs
description: Industry shipments of aluminum for the first half fell 43.6 per cent from the yearearlier level, the Aluminum Association reported yesterday. Shipments of ingot and mill products for the first six months fell to 4.3 billion pounds, the lowest level since the midnineteensixties, from 7.6 billion pounds a year ago. The trade association pointed out that mill product shipments at 3.5 billion pounds ran 39.2 per cent lower than a year ago, while ingot shipments just less than 782 million pounds were down 57.6 per cent.

title: Cuban Exiles in Miami Mark Tradition of Miracles
description: MIAMI, Sept. 9Thousands of Cuban exiles ended a fervent celebration of their devotion to Mary, mother of Jesus, yesterday with a statuecarrying boat procession and huge rally on Biscayne Bay.

title: Imetal Extending Offer For Copperweld Shares
description: Socit Imetal of Paris, which is seeking to acquire Copperweld Corporation of Pittsburgh for $111million, said yesterday that it had extended until Sept. 18 its tender offer to buy 2. 465,000 common shares and $4million principal value of 5 per cent convertible debentures. The offer was to have expired Sept. 11, but the Federal Court in Pittsburgh has issued a temporary order restraining Imetal's tender offer until a hearing can be held on Copperweld's petition to halt the offer. Federal Judge John L. Miller set the hearing for Sept. 15.

title: Peking Derides Dalai Lama; Asserts Rights Over Tibet
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 9 (UPI)China's main, newspaper said today that Tibet was an inalienable part of Chinese territory and that the Dalai Lama's hopes of regaining power were a daydream.

title: Lisbon's Newspapers Attack New Restrictions
description: LISBON, Sept. 9An effort by the armed forces to hide their dissensions by a form of press censorship was unanimously condemned today by newspapers of all political persuasions.

title: Jersey Loses Claim To Arena Land Site Of Widow's Suicide
description: Judge James Petrella has ruled in the Bergen County Superior Court that a 72yearold widow who killed herself rather than face eviction from her East Rutherford home by the New Jersey Sports & Exposition Authority actually owned title to almost all of the land claimed by the state.

title: Stocking Stuffer Leads Hunters
description: GREENVALE, L. I., Sept. 9Mr. and Mrs. August Busch Jr.'s Stocking Stuffer collected a firstplace ribbon in the model test and finished second in two other classes over fences today to take the lead for the regular conformation hunter championship at the opening of the Nassau County Horse Show.

title: More Planes and Troops Sought for Angola Airlift
description: LISBON, Sept. 9The airlift of Portuguese refugees from Angola is too limited and is threatened by a lack of troops to protect it on the ground, a Portuguese director of the operation said here today.

title: Wallace Signs Death Penalty
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala. (UPI)Saving I hope we'll see some electrocutions in this state, Gov. George C. Wallace today signed into law a bill restoring the death penalty in Alabama.

title: Mayor Speaks Tonight On Three TV Channels
description: Mayor Beame will appear in a live broadcast from Grade Mansion tonight at 6:03 on Channels 2, 4 and 7.

title: Israelis and Egyptians Confer In Geneva on Sinai Pact Details
description: GENEVA, Sept. 9Amid strict security precautions, Egyptian and Israeli delegations met twice today to discuss how to carry out the agreement on Israel's withdrawal in Sinai.

title: About New York
description: Bus riding in New York is in some ways much like a bus tour on longrange trips. You see the country close at hand and yet you do not become part of it. The window glass filters out involvement even as it permits observation. To the rider with a seat and a window and an inquiring mind it may raise more questions than mere looking will answer.

title: Levitt Screens City Job Applicants
description: ALBANY, Sept. 9State Controller Arthur Levitt has begun interviewing prospective appointees for the post of deputy state controller for New York City, a job politicians here describe as the invisible Mayor.

title: Sinatra, Basie and Ella Fitzgerald Appear for Audience of Old Admirers
description: Despite the airy arrogance that Frank Sinatra drapes over most of his performance at the Uris Theater, he can still cut through the macho posturing when he wants to project a simple love song.

title: WINE TALK
description: If you have $100 to spare and are free on Thursday nights, you might consider Robert Miltner's course at the New School called, simply, Wine.

title: CHASE ASKS 7.80%
description: Chase Manhattan Bank informed State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday that the state would probably have, to pay record interest rates for notes issued to meet New York City's cash needs and for some of the state's own needs as well.

title: GOV. GRASSO CALLS ON BUSINESS' AID
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 9Gov. Ella T. Grasso today promised tax relief for Connecticut's business community, and asked in return for extensive help in rebuilding the confidence of the people in their business and government institutions.

title: Eleanor Higgins Dawson, World Swimming Official
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 9Eleanor Higgins (Bobby) Dawson, a national and international swimming official for many years, died yesterday at YaleNew Haven Hospital. She was 67 years old and was the widow of Edwin P. Dawson.

title: Issues in Teacher Dispute
description: PRODUCTIVITYBoth sides agree that classes should be kept as small as possible, but they cannot agree on how this should be done. The board wants to increase the amount of time that teachers spend with pupils by cutting back the number of preparation periods granted to teachers. The union believes that laidoff teachers should be rehired, but the board says it has no money to do that.

title: West Bengal State Frees 7 Arrested During India Crisis
description: CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 9 (Reuters)  Seven opposition leaders arrested under India's state of emergency have been released by the West Bengal government after a review board said there were insufficient grounds for detaining them.

title: People and Business
description: A prominent New York banker has sought to assure the utilities industry that sufficient funds will be available for them in the capital markets to meet operating and expansion needs in the years ahead.

title: Underworld Figure Dies
description: MARION, Ill., Sept. 9 (AP) Willie Daddano, 61 years old, a longtime associate of Chicago underworld figures, has died in prison, the acting warden of the Marion Federal Penitentiary, Fred A. Frey, announced today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Set Back Tigers
description: Stumbling and staggering near the end of a trying season, the Yankees and Tigers mixed together 30 hits, five walks, four stolen bases, two errors, two wild pitches and 15 runs and steeped them tor 2 hours 47 minutes last night at Shea Stadium.

title: City Schools Are Crippled As Teachers' Strike Starts
description: A teachers' strike crippled the city school system on the second day of the new term yesterday, forcing at least 260 schools to shut down and keeping nearly all of the 1.1 million pupils out of classes.

title: Unions Halt Fight Over Soviet Grain
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The White House announced today a temporary end to the labor dispute that has threatened to disrupt massive shipments of American grain to the Soviet Union.

title: Felony Arrests Dropped by 15.3% in July While 3,000 Policemen Were Dismissed
description: Felony arrests in the city declined 15.3 per cent last July, a month in which the Police Department dismissed 3,000 rookies and reassigned thousands of veteran officers back to street patrol duty.

title: CHASE ASKS 7.80%
description: Chase Manhattan Bank informed State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday that the state would probably have to pay record interest rates for notes issued to meet New York City's cash needs and for some of the state's own needs as well.

title: Split Widens in Ulster Protestant Front
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 9The split among Ulster's Protestant politicians widened today when William Craig, long a hardline Protestant leader, resigned as head of his party's 12member delegation to a constitutional convention. He quit over the issue of talks with the leading Roman Catholic party.

title: Tomahawks Lose, Trail in Series, 21
description: QUEBEC CITY, Sept. 9 (AP)Larry Smeltzer, goalie, stopped 50 shots and added 5 assists as the Quebec City Caribous defeated the Long Island Tomahawks, 149, tonight and took a 21 lead in their National Lacrosse League semifinal playoffs.

title: U.S. HINTS AT AID FOR POOR NATIONS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 9The United States has submitted a 39page informal working paper to the General Assembly's current special ecoromic session hinting at major American commitments for development assistance.

title: T.V.A. SCORES PLAN BY WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority and the Virginia Electric and Power Company yesterday criticized the decision of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation to abandon its contracts to supply uranium to about 20 utilities by the end of 1978.

title: Federal Aides Back Retention of Ceiling On Savings Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) Ceilings on interest paid on savings accounts must be retamed even if they discriminate against unsophisticated depositors, the heads of three Federal agencies said today.

title: Bridge:
description: A worthwhile international effort recently resulted in the publication in New York of a major book written in France. translated in South Africa and printed in Taiwan. It is The Mathematical Theory of Bridge, by Emile Borel and Andre Cheron, written in 1939 and now translated and edited, with great accuracy and attention to detail, by Alec Traub of Cape Town, South Africa.

title: To Save on Home Canning, Be Sure to Home Grow, Too
Court Voids a Claim by Jersey To Land Near Sports Complex
description: Judge James Petrella has ruled in the Bergen County Superior Court that a 72yearold widow who killed herself rather than face eviction from her East Rutherford home by the New Jersey Sports & Exposition Authority actually owned title to almost all of the land claimed by the state.

title: Lockhart Back in Camp After Mystery Trip
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 9For a while today it appeared that Carl (Spider) Lockhart had played his last game for the New York Giants.

title: IND on West Side Removes Billboards After Complaints
description: Billboards on three subway entrances on Central Park West were removed yesterday by the Transit Authority as a result of public complaints that the signs obscured views of the park.

title: In Memoriam
description: GOODMANAl K., Sept. 10, 1959. Remembering you today as we always do with much love. Nellie, Fredye, Ted, Elinor, Ronald and grandchildren.

title: Hanoi Plans to Expand AdultEducation Effort
description: PERSEPOLIS. Iran, Sept. 7The North Vietnamese Government, profiting from the return of peace to Indochina, plans to double its secondary education programs for adults within the next two or three years, a senior official of Hanoi's EduCation Ministry has reported here.

title: Fire Bombs Thrown in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Sept. 10 (UPI)A group of young men tossed nine gasoline bombs at the home of Foreign Minister Kiichi Miyazawa today from an adjacent building. The police said that two of the fire bombs landed in the yard of Mr. Miyazawa's home and burst into flames. Policemen guarding the residence put out the fire. No one was injured.

title: HOUSE UNIT LIMITS OIL TAX SHELTERS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The House Ways and Means Committee, over the objections of the Ford Administration, voted today to lessen the opportunities that persons with high incomes have for reducing their Federal income taxes by, making invetments in oilwell drilling venture.

title: Senate Hearing Is Told That Pentagon Conducted Drug Tests With Virtually No Outside Supervision
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The secret experiments with LSD and other drugs that the Defense Department conducted were performed with virtually no outside supervision or review, although the Food and Drug Administration had the responsibility for such supervision and review for more than a decade, military and civilian officials testifed today.

title: Film: Before Nightfall
description: Just Before Nightfall was shown at the 11th New York Film Festival. The following excerpt is from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 9, 1974. The film is being shown at the Paris Theater, 58th Street west of Fifth Avenue.

title: GERARD BLOOMFIELD OF ECONOMIC PANEL
description: Gerard M. Bloomfield, a lawyer who was a member of the Mayor's Economic Council, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 69 years old and lived it 4680 Fieldston Road in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: The Furs Are Upstaged By the Entertainment
description: Just as soon as the Ben Kahn customers return to town after roughing it at the Hamptons and other watering places, the furrier invites a thousand or so of them to a fashion show. The purpose, naturally, is to lure them into buying fur coats. But to make the sell seem softer, each year there's a stuntsometimes several stunts.

title: A Jersey School Band Will March in Venezuela
description: RIDGEFIELD, N. J., Sept. 10 The high school football team will have to play its first game without the inspiration of the marching band, the baton twirlers or the majorette.

title: PORT'S TRUCKERS LINKED TO GRAFT
description: NEWARK, Sept. 10Testimony before the bistate Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor here today disclosed that a third of the 75,000 trucks that worked the piers each year were involved in illegal payments amounting to more than $150.000 a year.

title: Doubleday Cites Gains; Bars Media at Meeting
description: Doubleday & Co., Inc., the publishing house, said yesterday at its annual stockholders meeting that business in its first fiscal quarter ended July 31 was better than in the yearago period.

title: Calley Loses Appeal
description: The courtmartial conviction of William L. Calley Jr. for the murder of 22 Vietnamese civilians at My Lai was reinstated yesterday by a Federal appeals court. The Army has not commented on the ruling. Page 26.

title: George Thomson, 83, Nobel Physicist, Is Dead
description: LONDON, Sept. 10  Sir George Thomson, an eminent physicist and like his father, Sir Joseph Thomson, a Nobel Prizewinner in physics, died tonight at his Cambridge home. His age was 83.

title: Industry Cleared in Investigation Of Shortage of Canning Jar Lids
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) A sevenweek investigation of the home canning jar ?? shortage turned up no evidance that the shortage had been contrived by the industry, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Wilson Sees Mrs. Thatcher
description: LONDON, Sept. 10  Prime Minster Harold Wilson called. in Margaret Thatcher, the Conservative party leader, for an hour's talk on the Irish situation.

title: Horowitz, Near 71, Will Return Soon To Concert Stage
description: After 22 years of onandoff retirement from the concert stage and what has often seemed to be a diffident approach to musicmaking of almost any kind, Vladimir Horowitz, announced yesterday that he would play at least 20 concerts this season, including a Carnegie Hall appearance on Nov. 16, his first tour of California in a quarter of a century and a series of recitals in the Middlewest.

title: Municipal Suppliers Grow Wary About City's Ability to Pay Bills
description: A number of companies that sell their products to New York Cityitems ranging from trucks and desks to baseball bats and light bulbshave become concerned in recent weeks about the city's ability to pay its bills.

title: Desert Wave Kills Woman
description: BARSTOW. Calif.. Sept. 10 (AP)  A 23yearold woman was killed when her car was swept off a Majave Desert highway by what one witness described as an eightfoot wall of water from a flash flood, the California Highway Patrol has reported. Identification of the woman was withheld pending notification of next of kin, officials said.

title: CONVICTED SLAYER GETS A NEW TRIM
description: A Federal judge has ruled that a Bronx man in prison almost 10 years for murder must be released or given a new trial within 60 days on the ground that the police obtamed his confession with severe beatings and a pattern of lawlessness which shocks the conscience.

title: Quaker Oats Dividend Up
description: The Quaker Oats Company announced yesterday an increase in the dividend on its common stock to 21 cents a share from 20 cents. The dividend is payable Oct. 20 to shareholders of record Sept. 22.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Assembly Institutions, Health and Welfare Committee has released a bill that would impose a statewide ban on pay toilets.

title: Tennis Is Going On and On
description: There was a time when the tennis season just about ended with Forest Hills. But now it goes on for 12 months a year with hardly a free week. Some players want to rest, others keep going for more money and glory.

title: Ford Seeks Additional Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)  President Ford asked Congress yesterday to appropriate an extra $1.5million for salaries and expenses of the stall of the Domestic Council, his top advisory group on domestic policy. In a letter to the House Speaker Representative, Can Albert, Democrat of Oklahoma, Mr. Ford said they money would be spent during a 15month period ending Sept. 30, 1976, and that it was needed to cover increased staff costs resulting from additional tasks assigned to the council.

title: CONGRESS UNITS ACT TO OPEN NIXON FILES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)Two Congressional panels moved today to force nearly complete public disclosure of 42 million White House documents that former President Richard M. Nixon contends belong to him.

title: Tanker Refloated in Boston
description: BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP)A 600foot Liberian tanker carrying No. 2 diesel fuel that ran aground while entering Boston Harbor last night was refloated with the rising tide just before midnight, the Coast Guard said today. There was no pollution and no serious damage or injury when the Atlantic Prestige ran aground near the Deer Island Channel at low tide, the Coast Guard said.

title: Plunging Into Crowds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10One day in 1970, President Nixon was telling Vice President Agnew how to campaign. Don't let the Secret Service get in the way of the photo car, he warned. If anybody is going to shoot you, he'll shoot you.

title: The Proceedings In the U. N. Today
CAIRO DENIES REPORT OF BID TO KILL SADAT
description: CAIRO, Sept. 10 (UPI)A radio report from Baghdad today said that there had been an assassination attempt against President Anwar elSadat of Egypt last week, but a spokesman for the President said that the report has no foundation.

title: Perjury Charge Dropped As Fearful Witness Balks
description: A university professor's fear of testifying in a case connected to the Joseph Gallo murder led yesterday to dismissal of a perjury indictment against a man reputed to be linked to organized crime.

title: Spanish Embassy In Lisbon Bombed On Basques' Behalf
description: LISBON, Thursday, Sept. 11 (Reuters)Bombs exploded in the Spanish Embassy, the Sheraton Hotel and near the office of the Spanish national airline here early today.

title: Owner of Rundown House Liable for Decay of Area
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that owners of abandoned, unsecured buildings are responsible for the deterioration in realestate values that such buildings cause in a neighhood.

title: CAREY DELINEATES NEW BOARD'S ROLE
description: Governor Carey, who will head the new board running city fiscal affairs, said yester day that the board would not operate on a piecemeal basis by becoming involved in such matters as the current teachers' strike.

title: CRIME FIGURE FAILS IN BID FOR FREEDOM
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)A Superior Court judge refused today to free from jail Anthony Louis (Bobby) Manna, a reputed Mafia figure who has spent the last three years behind bars for refusing to answer questions about organized crime.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ECHOES OF 1850 On this date 125 years ago, Jenny Lind, known as the Swedish Nightingale and born Johanna Maria Lind, made her American debut before 7,000 in a concert at the Castle Garden, at the southern tip of Manhattan Island.

title: Typical' Teacher Is 33 And She Earns $17,350
description: The typical New York teacher is a white woman, about 33 years old, a graduate of the City University with a master's degree, has eight years' experience in the school system and earns about $17,350 a year.

title: Union Leaders Keep Eyes On Teachers' Negotiations
description: Leaders of city employe unions and labor relations offidals here are watching the teachers' strike closely for cues on how collective bargaining is going to work under the wage freeze and the new restrictions imposed by the city's emergency fiscal plan.

title: BORDEN MAY CLOSE CHICAGOAREA UNIT
description: Borden, Inc., announced yesterday that it was considering closing it s milk processing plant in Woodstock. III., and abandoning the Chicagoarea milk markets after 83 years because of chronic industry oversupply.

title: Avedon Show: The Place to Be Seen
description: Not everyone in the world was at the Marlborough Gallery Tuesday night. It just looked that way.

title: Far East and Near South Meet in City Cafe
description: If you choose one from Column A and one from Column B, you could find yourself dining on beef with shrimp ding and chitterlings. Or perhaps pig's feet to mein.

title: Beirut Acts to Put Troops Between Battling Factions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10Lebanese troops have been ordered to take up positions between warring Christian and Moslem factions in the Tripoli area of northern Lebanon, Premier Rashid Karami announced tonight.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: MIAMI BEACH  Juan Hidalgo, 134, Dominican Republic, knocked out Rocky Orengo, 136, Puerto Rico, 7 rounds.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Viking 2 Heads for Mars; Craft Is Called Just Fine
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 10 (UPI)Viking 2 followed 4.8 [million miles behind its twin spacecraft today on their search for life on Mars.

title: Senate RollCall Vote on Ford Oil Bill Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate upheld today President Ford's veto of a sixmonth extension of oil price controls:

title: Phone Service Will Aid Voters' Registration
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Governor Byrne announced today that the state was providing a tollfree  telephone number, 800 7928844, that unregistered voters could call from anywhere in the state to get registration forms.

title: Chess:
description: The favorite daydream of the Walter Mitty of the game goes something like this: He sits down to face one of the world's top players, produces an opening innovation that spellbinds the renowned theoreticians, creates a brilliant attack that cascades with startling sacrifices and accepts his opponent's resignation with sportsmanlike reserve, all to the thunderous applause of the multitude.

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, Sept. 10 (UPI)In the most optimistic outlook yet from the slumping United States auto industry, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Thomas A. Murphy, predicted today that new car sales would jump by more than 20 per cent in 1976.

title: QUIET LOUISVILLE ACCEPTING BUSING
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 10Outside Westport High School yesterday during a break in classes, three white girls and a black girl sat on the sidewalk comparing schedules.

title: SENATE VOTE FAILS TO OVERRIDE FORD ON OIL BILL VETO
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The Senate failed today, by six votes, to override President Ford's veto of legislation that would have continued price controls on oil through February.

title: Brokers Seek Ban On Merrill's Plan To Shun Exchange
description: An organized effort by Wall Street stockbrokers to block plans of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fermer & Smith, Inc., to sell stock to small Investors without going through normal New York Stock Exchange channels began to take shape here yesterday.

title: C.I.A. Views on Use Of Poison Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence has evidence that the Central Intelligence Agency considered operational use of the shellfish poison kept in As laboratory, including making suicide pills for agents and aggressive actions, sources familiar with the events said today.

title: Lewis W. Jones, 76, Dies; Led Interfaith Conference
description: Lewis Webster Jones, a former president of the Nationa?? Conference of Christians and Jews and, earlier, president 0f Rutgers University, died yesterday of pneumonia in a hospital in Sarasota, Fla., where he lived. He was 76 years old

title: Philippine Rebels Vow to Keep Up Fight for SelfRule
description: LAKE LANAO, the Philippines, Sept. 4Despite a recent and wellpublicized claim by President Ferdinand E. Marcos that the Moslem rebels in the southern Philippines had accepted a ceasefire, rebel leaders in the villages and jungle around this remote blue tropical lake insist that they will fight on until their demands for autonomy are met fully.

title: $15Million Project Is Proposed to Help Refugee Children
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 10 (AP)The Ford Administration has announced a $15million aid program for the current school year to school districts enrolling Vietnamese or Cambodian refugee children.

title: At San Gennaro Time Everybody Is Italian
description: Everybody knows about the Feast of San Gennaro. It's New York's funnel of love for things Neapolitan, a gantlet of clams, sausages and pepper, calzone, gelati and zeppole (to say nothing of games of chance) that runs the length of Mulberry Street from East Houston to Park Row.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1975

title: 141 Let Me Linger Takes Maskette
description: Laffit Pincay Jr., who has been America's leading moneywinning jockey for the last five years, brought home his first stakes winner in two months yesterday. The triumph was scored at Belmont Park with Oak Crest Stable's 141 Let Mc Linger in the $57,640 Maskette Handicap after a stirring duel through the stretch during which the 3yearold daughter of What a Pleasure staved off Honorable Miss to win by a nose.

title: Meany Details Pact on Sales to Russia
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O. said here today that the most important part of an agreement ending a labor dispute that has halted shipment of American wheat to the Soviet Union was President Ford's new method of dealing with Moscow on wheat sales.

title: Advertising
description: It would probably be safe to say that few local publications have received the national press coverage that has been accorded the City of San Francisco magazine recently.

title: Bridge:
description: Fully many a bridgeplayer, as the poet Gray almost said, was born to bid unseen and waste his card play on the desert air. It is almost impossible to become, or having become remain, a player of the highest class lacking regular opportunities to play with and against players of equal stature.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: DUBLIN OPPOSES ANY INTERVENTION
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 10  Ireland's Minister of Defense shook the country today when he appeared to rule out any military intervention in Northern Ireland, no matter what political situation arose there.

title: Pied Piper Victor In One Ton Race
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10As a spectator event, yacht racing will never challenge gogo dancing or even the roller derby. But today's race at the One Ton Class world championships sailed on Rhode Island Sound was an exception.

title: To Erick Hawkins, a Bicentennial Is a Reason to Dance
description: Unlike most other dancers and choreographers, Erick Hawkins appears to have been celebrating the Bicentennial not only this season but also during most of his career.

title: Jazz Group Files With F.C.C. to Block Purchase of WRVR
description: The Citizens Committee to Save Jazz Radio, a recently formed group, said it filed a petition yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission to block the sale of WRVRFM by the Riverside Church to the Sonderling Broadcasting Corporation.

title: J. M. McCullough, Economist For Scudder, Stevens, Died
description: James A. McCullough, chief economist for the Wall Street firm of Scudder, Stevens & Clark from 1952 until his retirement three years ago, died Sept. 2 in Homestead, Fla. He was 66 years old.

title: Top U.S. Olympic Aide Warns Against Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)The top Olympic official in the United States told a Presidential commission today that the International Olympic Committee would not tolerate Federal intervention to resolve disputes between athletic organizations.

title: AVICE PILAT, 70, DIES, MENTAL HEALTH AIDE
description: Avice Riddle Pilat, former chief of administrative services in the New York City Department of Mental Hygiene, died yesterday at her home, 130 Park Row. She was 70 years old.

title: Oil Roadblock Broken
description: The failure of the Senate to override the President's veto of extended oilprice controls offers an opportunity to break the long impasse on energy policy. Congress and the White House should now negotiate an energy policy that will meet national needs for years to come.

title: TV ABC's On the Rocks Finds Fun in Prison
description: On the Rocks, a new series on ABC, uses a Puerto Rican accent to ask the question: can a prison be funny? Answer: yes, if the accent belongs to Jose Perez, who plays Hector Fuentes on the program. Hector quickly establishes the fact that he is only here due to tragic circumstancesI got caught.

title: Plan Is Offered on Missiles for Jordan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Key members of Congress have proposed a compromise to the Ford Administration that would permit the sale of 14 batteries of Hawk antiaircraft missiles promised to King Hussein of Jordan by the United States.

title: Eximbank Plans Increase For Its Interest Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) The ExportImport Bank said today it would increase its maximum interest rates from 9 per cent to 9 per cent to increase earnings and improve the bank's competitive position with foreign lenders.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
House Spy Unit Gets Crisis Data With Order to Keep Them Secret
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Representative Otis G. Pike, chairman of the House Select Committee on Intelligence, said late today that the Ford Administration was delivering materials in response to committee subpoena, hut under the condition that the documents not be made public.

title: INDEPENDENT TV GETS NEW SHOWS
description: Independent stations  those not affiliated with commercial networkssurvive on movies, sports and reruns of old series, earning them the soubriquet of yesterday's networks.

title: House Votes to Ban Foreign Aid For HumanRights Violations
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 10 (UPI)The House of Represent??tives today approved a $2.87billion twoyear foreign aid authorization that would deny assistance to countries regularly violating human rights. For the first time, the authorization contains no military aid.

title: Controller Testifies He Had No Time To Relay Plea for a Runway Change
description: The traffic controller who was urged by the pilot of a cargo jet to change runways because of remendous wind shear shortly before the Eastern Airlines crash here in June tetified yesterday that he had not had time to relay the appeal to hi supervisor.

title: Vintage Cars Crank Up for a Rerun of 1908 Race
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Marian Teague smiled through cool, blue eyes, smoothed her silvergray flair and confessed that she was a backseat driver.

title: 'Sharks' Treasure'
description: Call it Yaws. (cl. Webster's New International Dictionary: "Yaw . . . deviate from one's own course; move or cause to move erratically.")There are plenty of sharks in "Sharks' Treasure," which opened yesterday at the De Mille and neighborhood theaters, but they are puny and don't pay proper attention. They move in circles, erratically.Their distraction will be shared. Cornel Wilde, whose work as a director occasionally raised a spark of interest, has made a home movie. The home needs cleaning.Mr. Wilde stars as a charter-boat captain who takes on a crew and finds sunken treasure near a Caribbean island. He poses in a brief, black bathing suit, lectures on the dangers of smoking and shows his fitness by doing one-hand push-ups.A gang of homosexual convicts comes on board and ties up the crew. The leader, a big, bearded man, capers around the deck and alternately beats and caresses a small, blond convict. The small convict cries a lot.Sometimes the camera mounts to the mast and films everything straight down. Either it is taking a correspondence course in cinema esthetics or it is trying to get out of the way.Eventually Mr. Wilde and his crew untie themselves and manage to eliminate the convicts. By this time the sharks have long since left and if the audience is wise it will have taken the hint.

title: Excerpts From Beame Speech on City's Fiscal Plight
description: During the past several months the City of New York and its people have been subjected to an ordeal that few other institutions in the world could endure. The imminence of crisis and fiscal disaster has been hanging over our heads, creating an atmosphere of uncertainty among our people; generating alarming headlines here and throughout the world; and commanding the total energies of local and state officials seeking to find solutions.

title: Assassination Study Bid Blocked by Coast Senate
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 10 (AP)  An attempt to get the California Legislature to support a new investigation into the assassination of President John F. Kennedy has been blocked.

title: CoOp City Tenants Offer Plan To Bar Rise in Carrying Fees
description: A tenants' steering committee at CoOp City in the Bronx yesterday proposed a series of measures that it says could eliminate the need for increases in maintenance charges.

title: Poland Soccer Victor
description: CHORZOW, Poland, Sept. 10 (AP)A crowd of 100,00 packed the Chorzow stadium today to see the Polish national soccer squad crush the Netherlands, 41, in a group match for the European championship.

title: Stocks Dip Sharply; Trading Pace Slows
description: The stock market fell sharply yesterday for the second consecutive session in slower trading.

title: U. S. Five to Play Suns
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 10 (AP)  The United States basketball team that will he competing next month in the Pan American Games will play an exhibition contest Oct. 6 against the Phoenix Suns of the National Basketball Association.

title: 3 New Encephalitis Cases Are Reported in the State
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10 (AP)The Department of Health announced today that three new cases of encephalitis had been confirmed in New Jersey, bringing to five the number of cases discovered in the state this summer.

title: MUSICIANS' UNION RESUMES TALKS
description: The musicians' union and the League of New York Theaters yesterday resumed negotiations on terms of a new threeyear contract covering Broadway musicals as well as straight dramatic works using recorded music.

title: Mets Beaten by Pirates, 84
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10Once a potent challenger to the Pirates, but lately just a club to fatten up on, the New York Mets lost to Pittsburgh, 84, tonight. The defeat, their sixth in a row, dropped them another rung closer to elimination in the East Division race, 10 games behind first place with 17 to play.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Beirut Acts to Put Troops Between Battling Factions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10Lebanese troops have been ordered to take up positions between warring Christian and Moslem factions in the Tripoli area of northern Lebanon, Premier Rashid Karami announced tonight.

title: Books of The Times
description: Rhetoric recollected in tranquillity: this is William Buckley's most effective polemical tool. He uses it gleefully on Senator George McGovern, showing that gentleman changing his tune so atonally that not even Leonard Bernstein, as the author puts it, could orchestrate him. Rhetoric recollected in tranquillity is the most lethal form of quoting out of context. Not that Mr. Buckley fails to give the full content of Senator McGovern's remarks: what he does is to separate them from the hysterical atmosphere of acceptance that reduced them to mere onomatopoeia when they were uttered. Like a doctor, he examines each statement in all its nakedness, under the pitiless light of the present. In a best of all possible worlds, people mean what they say and say what they mean. Mr. Buckley intends to live, if he can, in that world.

title: Ridgefield School Band Off to March in Venezuela
description: RIDGEFIELD, Sept. 10The high school football team will have to play its first game without the inspiration of the marching band, the baton twirlers or the majorette.

title: SUIT CHARGES U.S. AIDS ARAB BOYCOTT
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday charging Rogers C. B. Morton. the Secretary of Commerce, With aiding Arab countries in their boycott of business interests that are directed or owned by Jews or that support Israel.

title: Beame Says He and Others Share Blame in City Crisis
description: Mayor Beame said last night that he accepted the responsibility, along with officials past and present, for using all sorts of fiscal gymnastics to have the city provide its traditional broad range of public services.

title: Cubs' Madlock Out With Thumb Injury
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP)Bill Madlock, the Chicago Cubs' third baseman and National League batting leader, has an incomplete fracture of the right thumb and may he lost for the Cubs' remaining 16 games, the team said today.

title: Johnson Captures Final Of Westchester P.G.A.
description: WILTON, Conn., Sept. 10Howie Johnson of the Sunningdale Country Club, in Scarsdale, N.Y.. defeated Bob Bruno of the Pelham (N.Y.,) C.C., 2 up, at Rolling Hills C.C. today and won the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association tournament.

title: NO BIRCH MEMBER, COORS MAINTAINS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)Joseph Coors, the brewingcompany executive who is a nominee to the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, denied today that he had ever belonged to the John Birch Society.

title: CAREY DELINEATES NEW BOARD'S ROLE
description: Governor Carey, who will head the new board running city fiscal affairs, said yester day that the board would not operate on a piecemeal basis by becoming involved in such matters as the current teacher' strike.

title: I.S. 201 Teachers Are Defying Strike
description: While most of the city's teachers were out on strike yesterday, 39 of 41 teachers at Intermediate School 201 in Community School District in Harlem were in their classrooms.

title: Santana Triumphs In Tennis, 61, 64
description: WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Sept. 10 (UPI)Manuel San tana of Spain, former Wimbledon champion, and Jose Edison Mandarino of Brazil advanced to the final of the Marlboro tennis tournament today.

title: Aide to Opposition Leader Is Arrested in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 10 (AP)The chief secretary to Kim Young Sam, leader of the opposition New Democratic party, was arrested today on charges of having violated en emergency decree banning almost all kinds of antiGovernment activity.

title: Coonskin Controversy Waning After 3 Weeks
description: When first screened last November at the Museum of Modern Art, the movie Coonskin by Ralph Bakshi touched off a controversey that nowthree weeks after it began appearing at two theaters hereappears to have waned.

title: ISRAEL AND EGYPT DISCUSS SPECIFICS
description: GENEVA, Sept. 10 (Reuters) Israeli and Egyptian negotiators held detailed discussions today on how Israel will withdraw her forces from the Eastern coast of the Gulf of Suez under their new Sinai agreement, a United Nations communiqu said

title: Britain's Payments Deficit Narrows for the Quarter
description: LONDON, Sept. 10 (Reuters) Britain's second quarter current account balance of payments deficit narrowed to a seasonally adjusted $495.9million from a revised 1975 first quarter $666.8million deficit the Treasury said today.

title: GEN. FERENBAUGH, 75 A KOREA COMMANDER
description: Lieut, Gen. Claude B. Ferenbaugh, former deputy commanding general of the Eighth Army in Korea and deputy commanding general, United States Forces. Far East, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 75 years old.

title: Negritude and the United States
description: Negritude is, on the one hand, the sum of the qualities of the values, as they are called today, that characterize the civilization of the black people, like the sense of Communion and that of Rhythm; it is, on the other hand, the way in which every black lives or understands the living of those values.

title: Sandman Financing Drive Is Under Inquiry in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10  The New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission is ending a long investigation of the financing of Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s unsuccessful Republican campaign for Governor in 1973, it was learned today.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Once a month, on the average, a large new nuclear power plant starts up in the United States, and another abroad. In 10 years at this pace, some 20 per cent of the world's electricity could be generated by the heat from fissioning atoms of uranium and plutonium.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Cattlemen Seek Bill Passage
description: The American National Cattlemen's Association, of Denver is seeking passage of a bill which would permit the American cattle industry to collect funds from its members to underwrite research programs and to provide information helpful to consumers, it was announced yesterday. The proposed Beef Research and Information Act probably will be voted on in the House later this month and prompt Senate action after that is expected the association said.

title: Amex Index Dips 0.97 to 84.12; NASDAQ List Also Shows Drop
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market dropped yesterday in slightly stepped up trading.

title: Little Support Reported For Public Transit Tax
description: The chairman of two legislative committees said yesterday that he saw little possibility of either statewide or regional taxes to support public transit.

title: A Day in La Vida Magnifica of Manuel Orantes, the Tennis Conquistador
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 10A pleasantlooking young man in blue jeans and a darkred polo shirt walked into the American Airlines terminal at La Guardia Airport in New York City yesterday and a buzz began.

title: Yugoslavia, Output Off, Cracking Down on Loafers
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 10 Yugoslav workers spend too much time talking about work and not enough doing it, according to Communist analysts, who believe that the time is at hand for a judicious national crackdown on loafers.

title: C. B. BOLLESROGERS
description: Charles Bolles BollesRogers, assistant commissioner of the American Red Cross during World War II, died last Thursday at a retirement home in Sea Island, Ga. He was 91 years old.

title: Teachers in Archdiocese Vote to Strike on Tuesday
description: Lay teachers voted last night to strike next Tuesday at 12 Roman Catholic High Schools in Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island and upstate if no agreement is reached with the Archdiocese of New York by tomorrow.

title: Plunkett's Backup Gets Big Chance
description: Neil Graff prepared himself a hundred times for the moment he would step in and replace the cannonarmed Jim Plunkett as quarterback of the New England Patriots.

title: House Backs Bill on Saint
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Despite a charge that the action tended to smack of a churchstate connection, the House has approved a bill to declare a day to honor Elizabeth Seton. Mother Seton, the first naturalborn United States citizen to be designated a saint by the Roman Catholic Church, would be honored on Sept. 14, when the formal church canonization ceremonies are to be conducted in Rome. The resolution calling on President Ford to declare a national Saint Elizabeth Seton Day, was passed by voice vote yesterday.

title: Dallas Board Votes to Bus 18.000 in Desegregation Plan
description: DALLAS, Sept. 10 (UPI)The Dallas School Board, working under a courtordered deadline, voted 5 to 4 today on a desegregation program that would involve the busing of 18,000 students, twothirds of them nonwhite.

title: Louisville Press Adopts Code for Covering Bus Dispute
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 9In an unusual action in American, journalism, Louisville's newspapers and radio and television stations have adopted a voluntary set of guidelines for they coverage of the area's school busing troubles.

title: South Africa Welcomes Aide With White Wife
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 10 (Reuters)South Africa is ignoring the violation of its Immorality Act by the Information Minister of the Ivory Coast here on an official visit with his white wife.

title: Class Size Emerges as Central Issue
description: When the teachers struck the city's schools Tuesday morning, the battle cry on their lips was class size. They talked of 50 and 60 students in a class, which they regarded as wholesale and intolerable violations of the classsize maximums in their previous contract.

title: G.O.P. CONVENTION TO BE THE BIGGEST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) The Republican party's 1976 Presidential convention will have at least 2,259 delegates, making it the largest in the party's history.

title: U.N. MAY EXTEND SPECIAL SESSION
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 10Secretary General Waldheim said today that United States proposals to narrow the gap between industrial and developing nations were so detailed and complex that an adjournment of the special session and its reconvening early next year was a possibility.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: As the debate triggered by the recent CBS television film on hunting, The Guns of Autumn, increases, there comes a quiet observation from the National Wildlife Federation asking whether the time has come for those other than sportsmen to share the cost of wildlife habitat acquisition.

title: Depressed Bond Mart Stalls City U. Building
description: The construction of new buildings for City University campuses in Queens and on Staten Island has been indefinitely postponed until statehacked construction bonds fare better in the credit markets, state officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Strikes Across the State Keep Thousands of Students Home
description: Thousands of students stayed out of school throughout the state yesterday as strikes by teachers and school service workers continued.

title: State Notes to Cost Up to 8.70% in Interest
CORRECTIONS
description: A United Press International dispatch published in The New York Times last Saturday reported the arrest of four suspected bank robbers near Nashville, Tenn. According to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, one of the defendants was incorrectly identified as Sam Buckmaster of Atlanta. This defendant is Theo D. McDaniel, who, the F.B.I. said, was carrying the identification papers of Mr. Buckmaster, an Atlanta real estate man.

title: SENATE VOTE FAILS TO OVERRIDE FORD ON OIL BILL VETO
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The Senate failed today, by six votes, to override President Ford's veto of legislation that would have continued price controls on oil through February.

title: U. F. W. Wins Lettuce Ranch
description: SALINAS, Calif. Sep. 10 (AP) Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers scored a major victory today in the battle with the teamsters to represent farm workers, winning an election at InterHarvest, the nation's biggest lettuce ranch.

title: NEW IN SPENDING LAW CURBS COAST RACE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8One major result of the Watergate scandals was a series of lawsnational, state and local restricting the raising and spending of money in political campaigns.

title: Genesco Loss Is Indicated
HENRY A. LEVINSON
description: Henry A. Levinson, a specialist in corporate law, died Tuesday at Huntington (L. I.) Hospital. He was 36 years old and lived in Syosset.

title: Red Sox, Orioles: 2 Splits, No Gains
description: Willie Horton's tworun homer in the eighth inning helped the Detroit Tigers gain a 53 victory over the Boston Red Sox and a split of their doubleheader last night in a game that meant little to Detroit but a lot to Boston.

title: ANTIISRAEL DRIVE HELD PERIL TO U.N.
description: Israel's delegate to the United Nations said yesterday that the move to oust his country was the largest single act of international antiSemitism and the most concentrated attack on our people since 1933, when Hitler launched his attack.

title: Grossbritannien: BananenRepublik?
description: LONDON Writing in his diary for 1640, just twenty years after the departure of the Pilgrim fathers for a happier and more prosperous shore, the London barrister John Greene gave his considered opinion of the current, and as usual deplorable, state of England.

title: Cyprus Negotiations at U.N. Called Off
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 70Peace negotiations between Greek and Turkish Cypriote leaders were called off today without new talks being fixed.

title: Mennea Equals Mark
description: PALERMO, Sicily, Sept. 10 (UPI)Pietro Mennea of Italy equaled his European record of 10 seconds in the 100meter dash today during a track meet between Italy. and Finland. Mennea shares the European mark with Valery Borzov of the Soviet Union. The world record is 9.9 seconds.

title: Appeals Court Reinstates Caney CourtMartial Conviction in My Lai Killings
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 10 (AP)The Army courtmartial conviction of William L. Calley Jr. for the murder of 22 Vietnamese civilians at My Lai was reinstated today by a Federal appeals court.

title: VICTIM POSITIVE IT WAS KALLINGER
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 10 A robbery victim pointed at Joseph Kallinger from the witness stand today and said she was positive he was the man who broke into her home last December and bound and robbed her, and three cardparty guests.

title: U.S. ENVOY URGES STRONG TOKYO TIES
description: TOKYO, Sept. 10The United States Ambassador to Japan, James D. Hodgson, said today that Japanese and Americans cannot remind themselves too often that though our two countries have many interests and aspirations in common, we do have many differences in heritage, tradition, culture and language.

title: Aggressive NoHelp ...
description: At great risk to its own solvency, New York State has integrated its resources and taxing powers with those of New York City to stave off the nationwide damage that would follow metropolitan default. One might expect that this homeric example of restructuring by city and state in recognition of a fiscal emergency that could rock the general economy would bring some expression of support from the absentee element in the new equation, the Federal Government.

title: SAMUEL C. SLAYMAKER
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Sept. 10 (AP)  Samuel C. Slaymaker, former head of the Slaymaker Lock Company and a national officer of the Presbyterian church, died yesterday at a home here. He was 79 years old.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A public offering of 1.5 million common shares of the Toledo Edison Company common stock at 20 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. Inc.

title: C.I.A. Views on Use Of Poison Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence has evidence that the Central Intelligence Agency considered operational use of the shellfish poison kept in its laboratory, including making suicide pills for agents and aggressive actions, sources familiar with the events said today.

title: 2 Million Students Across U.S. Idled By Teacher Strikes
description: Thousands of whistleblowing teachers picketed school board offices in Chicago's Loop yesterday while a band of youngsters, staging a counterdemonstration, marched around the Chicago City Hall carrying signs saying, We want an eduation now.

title: Portuguese Move to Reduce Influence Of Communists at Top Military Levels
description: LISBON, Sept. 10  A move to reduce and even eliminate Communist influence from the highest levels of the Portuguese armed forces has begun concurrently with negotiations for a new coalition cabinet.

title: Gallo Winery Is Focus of U.F.W.Teamster Fight
description: LIVINGSTON, Calif., Sept. 10  Workers at the E. and J. Gallo Winery here went to the polls today to decide whether the United Farm Workers or the International Brotherhood of Teamsters shall represent them.

title: 500 TV Sets Face Recall
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (UPI)The Admiral group says that! 500 of its color television sets! distributed since 1973 may have a defect in a cord that could cause a user to receive a shock. Admiral said yesterday that it was developing a program to make repairs at the company's expense.

title: Rossetti Sees A 5050 Chance
description: Frank G. Rossetti, the Manhattan Democratic leader who has been the target of some reformers. estimated, after assessing the results of Tuesday's primary, that his chances of being reelected were 5050. He said he had lost some and won some in contests for the district leaders, who will elect the county leader. Other observers see Mrs Rossetti's appraisal as modest one and believe he is virtually certain of victory.

title: Miss Fromme Indicted Under Law on Presidents' Assassinations
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 10 (AP)Lynette Fromme, a follower of a convicted murderer, Charles Manson, was indicted today on a Federal charge of attempting to assassinate President Ford.

title: BOARD AND U. F. T. STUDY PLAN TO END TEACHERS' STRIKE
description: The Board of Education and the teachers' union were considering a new plan yesterday that, officials on both sides said, might end the teachers' strike that has closed more than onethird of the city schools and disrupted over a million pupils.

title: Vermont Tax Rise Sought
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 10 (UPI)  Gov. Thomas Salmon today called the Vermont Legislature into special session Sept. 29 to consider his proposal to increase the state's 3 per cent general sales tax by at least one percentage point. In addition, Governor Salmon said he had ordered a cutback in state spending of $3million for this fiscal year.

title: 2 HELD IN BERLIN CALLED PLOTTERS
description: BONN, Sept. 10A man and a woman arrested by the West Berlin police in a raid yesterday were identified today by Peter Lorenz as members of the leftist group that kidnapped him last winter, when he was Christian Democratic candidate for Mayor.

title: A Lovable Villain Is Fun for Children
description: It seems that no character in children's plays is ever allowed to be truly had. So it is with Count Villainova, a lovable antihero who, though sly, remains funny.

title: BOARD AND U.F.T. NEAR AGREEMENT IN SCHOOL STRIKE
description: The Board of Education and the teachers' union appeared to be near agreement early today on a plan that officials on both sides said might end the teachers' strike, which, has closed more than onethird of the city schools and disrupted over a million pupils.

title: Grant Asks Landlords of All Stores for 25% Rent Cut
description: The W. T. Grant Company, which lost 5111.3million in the fiscal first half ended July 31 and $177million in the prior fiscal year, has asked the land lords of its 1,069 stores for a 25 per cent reduction rents for at least the next two years.

title: Chile to Play In Sweden; Fillol Balks
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 10 (UPI)The Chilean Tennis Federation said today it would go ahead and play Sweden in the Davis Cup semifinals despite the withdrawal of its top player.

title: Consumer Board Hales P.S.C. Into Court
description: The State Consumer Protection Board has asked the Supreme Court in Albany to review a State Public Service Commission decision that has cost upstate consumers $92.1million in higher electricity and as rates.

title: GiftWrapped Bomb Injures Chilean Newspaper Director
description: SANTIAGO, Chile. Sept. 10 (AP)A bomb concealed in a giftwrapped book exploded today in the hands of the director of one of Chile's most proGovernment newspapers.

title: Colombian Cabinet Resigns, President Bids Them Stay
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 10 (AP)All 13 members of President Alfonso Lopez Michelsen's Cabinet submitted resignations today, but he turned them down and continued the ministers in office.

title: Beame Sharing Blame With  Others
description: Republican legislative leaders in Albany.

title: American League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: City Suppliers Concerned About Bills
description: A number of companies that sell their products to New York Cityitems ranging from trucks and desks to baseball bats and light bulbshave become concerned in recent weeks about the city's ability to pay its bills.

title: Avedon's Lens Celebrates Celebrity
description: Art begets antiart. Politics spawns antipolitics. Both in literature and in public life, the exploits of heroes give way to the depredations of antiheroes. Is it any wonder, then, that in the world of glamour and celebrity, where fashions in culture enjoy an authority second only to the fashion of hemline and neckline, the same antiphonal impulse should make itself felt? In an age of sweeping reversals, glamour too will search out ways to perpetuate its spell by negating all customary expectation.

title: Senate Overrides Education Bill Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10President Ford lost a fiscal battle with Congress today as the Senate voted overwhelmingly to override his veto of a $7.9billion education appropriation bill.

title: Mrs. Johnstone Wins
description: DENVILLE, N.J., Sept. 10Mrs. David Johnstone of Montclair today captured her second consecutive Garden State Women's Golf Association 36hole championship with a fivestroke margin of vitory at the Rockaway River Country Club.

title: Soft Touch Will Close
description: The Soft Touch, a new play by Neil Cuthbert, scheduled to make its Broadway debut Sept. 21 at the Golden Theater, will close Saturday after a twoweek run in Boston's Wilbur Theater. Alan Arkin staged the work. The producers are Gene Persson in association with Ted Chapin and Pangloss Productions.

title: British Unit Affirms That an I.R.A. Chief Is Off Wanted List
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 10The British Army said today that it had advised its troops here that the chief of staff of the Provisional Wing of the Irish Republican Army was no longer a wanted man in Northern Ireland.

title: Calley Loses Appeal
description: The courtmartial conviction of William L. Calley Jr. for the murder of 22 Vietnamese civilians at My Lai was reinstated yesterday by a Federal appeals court. The Army has not commented on the ruling. Page 26.

title: Canada's August C.P.I. Up
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 10 (UPI)The rising cost of food, shelter and transportation pushed the Consumer Price Index 1 per cent higher in August, Statistics Canada said today. The index advanced to 141.2 points in August from its level of 139.8 points in July, when the C.P.I. increased 1.4 per cent over the previous month. The total C.P.I. reflected an annual inflation rate of 11.1 per cent over August, 1974.

title: Charles Seligson Is Dead at 74; N.Y.U. Bankruptcy Law Expert
description: Charles Seligson, a leading specialist in bankruptcy law and creditor rights, died of cancer yesterday in the Memorial SloanKettering Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 115 Central Park West.

title: Price Rise Is Shown In Grain Futures
description: The news that the longshoremen's union had agreed to resume loading grain on ships for the Soviet Union imparted strength to grain futures markets yesterday. As a result of the White House announcement late Tuesday, farmers tended to withhold some grains for markets, buoyed by the thought of possible further grains sales to the Soviet Union.

title: OIL COMPENSATION SET BY VENEZUELA
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  Venezuela will pay about $930million compensation to 22 foreign oil companies she nationalized last month. Mining Minister Valentin Hernandez announced here today. The amount was lessl than expected.
