title: Turkey Plans to Forbid Opium Area Expansion
description: ANKARA Turkey, Sept. 10 (Reuters)Turkey will restrict opiumpoppy areas next year to this year's levels in response to international concern that the fields are a source of illicit heroin. Deputy Premier Turman Feyzioglu said today.

title: SYRIA DENOUNCES SINAI AGREEMENT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 10Syria attacked the new disengagement agreement between Egypt and Israeli today, charging that it would perpetuate the Israeli occupalion and sow discord among the Arabs.

title: Houston Lighting Defers Building of Nuclear Plant
description: The Houston Lighting and Power Company announced yesterday that it was deferring indefinitely the construction of the 2.400megawatt Aliens reek nuclear power plant in Austin County, Texas.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Article 1  No Title
NOTES COST STATE AS MUCH AS 8.70%
description: The state agreed yesterday to record high interest rates of up to 8.70 per cent on $755million in notes being issued this week for its own needs and for emergency relief to a cashstarved New York City.

title: 5 FOOD PLACES FAIL HEALTH INSPECTIONS
description: The Health Department has listed five more food establishments for having failed their second healthcode inspection and warned that violations persisting at a third inspection Could lead to closing orders.

title: Players' Group Rejects Offer Of Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)By an overwhelming margin, the members of the National Football League Players Association have rejected a management offer for a new contract and set the stage for a strike vote with the opening of the season only two weeks away.

title: Trenton Is Studying Water Breakdown; Loss at $10Million
description: TRENTON, Sept.10 (UPI)Officials here began investigation today into the $10million mechanical fiasco that flooded a filtration plant, drained the city reservoir and left residents with only a trickle of water most of last week.

title: CITY CONSIDERING FREEZE ON FUNDS FOR NEW HOUSING
description: Top city officials have recommended to Mayor Beame that, because of the fiscal crisis, the city suspend its plans to finance the construction or rehabilitation of virtually all the housing it has planned for the next few years, it was learned yesterday.

title: Carey Said to Be Ready to Replace D.A. in Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 10 Governor Carey has decided to appoint a special state prosecutor to supersede Henry F. O'Brien, the Suffolk District Atorney, with regard to his investigation of alleged corruption involving Eugene R. Kelley, the county Police Commissioner, a high source in Albany disclosed tonight.

title: People in Sports
description: In addition to being known for her tennis prowess, Chris Evert is also gaining a solid reputation for her earning power. Miss Evert, who is not yet 21 years old, has surpassed her own record for the most money won in a year by a female athlete. With the $25,000 first prize she earned at the United States Open, her earnings so far this year total $280,927. according to the United States Tennis Association. In 1974 Miss Evert won $261,460.

title: Six Plead Guilty in New Orleans To Corruption in Grain Trading
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Six defendants pleaded guilty in Federal court in New Orleans today to charges resulting from an investigation of alleged corruption in the grain export trade and irregularities in the inspection and grading of grain for export.

title: Mr. Meany's Baling Hook
description: In the best diplomatic tradition, the negotiations between the heads of two superpowersPresident Ford of the United States and President Meany of the A.F.L.C.I.O.over the union boycott of Soviet grain shipments have aided in a facesaving truce.

title: CITY CONSIDERING FREEZE ON FUNDS FOR NEW HOUSING
description: Top city officials have recommended to Mayor Beame that, because of the fiscal crisis, the city suspend its plans to finance the construction or rehabilitation of virtually all the housing it has planned for the next few years, it was learned yesterday.

title: The Screen
Yankees And Gura Win, 82
description: The Yankees in general and Bobby Bonds in particular passed up a chance to turn an unimportant game into an interesting affair at Shea Stadium last night.

title: Stage: Old Vic's Phedre
description: LONDON, Sept. 10The French drama has traditionally never had any particular regard for the classicsfeeling that classic themes should be expressed with contemporary immediacy, and their playwrights from Racine to Anouilh have enthusiastically plundered the Greeks and Romans to enrich the French theater.

title: Beanie Says He and Others Share Blame in City Crisis
description: Mayor Beame said last night that he accepted the responsibility, along with officials past and present, for using all sorts of fiscal gymnastics to have the city provide its traditional broad range of public services.

title: Mr. Kissinger's Agreement
description: BOSTON, Sept. 10It is understandable that members of Congress and others should feel some skepticism when Henry Kissinger emerges from a long bout of private negotiation with a triumphant piece of paper in hand. It is right that Americans should be concerned about longterm financial and peacekeeping commitments in an area of the world as sensitive as the Middle East.

title: HEARINGS ENDED ON U.S. LIBRARIAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10The Senate Rules Committee concluded its hearings today on the confirmation of Daniel J. Boorstin, the historian, as Librarian of Congress, an appointment that has stirred strong expressions of both opposition to and support for the Pulitizer Prizewinning author.

title: PLAN TO MAP MOON IS WEIGHED BY NASA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is considering resuming exploration of the moon in 1980 with a lowcost, unmanned satellite, that would map the entire lunar surface from orbit.

title: People and Business
description: Jean L. Loyer said yesterday he intended to take appropriate legal actions over his dismissal late last month as president and chief executive officer of the Howmet Corporation. He said in a telephone interview from Greenwich, Conn., that he had requested an appraisal of his shares last Friday and on Tuesday he was told that his services had been completely terminated.

title: Rockefeller Associate Is Named To Head Federal Power Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10President Ford nominated today Richard L. Dunham, a longtime associate of Vice President Rockefeller, to be a member and chairman of the Federal Power Commission.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein Gains
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 10  Judy Cooperstein of Glen Oaks, winner in 1971 and 1974, rallied today to win the last two holes in defeating Mrs. George Holzkamp of the Nassau Country Club, I up, in the quarterfinals of the fifth annual women's Long Island matchplay championship at the Nassau Country Club.

title: Study Suggests Relaxation Can Cut Abnormal Heartbeats in Cardiac Patients
description: A Boston study has suggested that a simple relaxation exercise, practiced by patients with heart disease for about half an hour each day can reduce the frequency of abnormal heartbeats that are associated with an increased risk of sudden death.

title: BARGES LEAVING ICY PRUDHOE BAY
description: PRUDHOE BAY, Alaska, Sept. 10  With winter approaching at this northern terminus of the Trans  Alaska Pipeline, eight barges carrying cargo needed to develop the North Slope oil fields have turned back with their million  dollar cargo to southern ports.

title: Mrs. Robson A Winner in Two Sports
description: Walking in circles usually leads to nowhere. But it has brought Mrs. Alan Robson fame in two sportsdog and horse shows. In the canine rings, she has had more than 60 champions and her basset, Ch. Slippery Hill Hudson, is the topwinning hound in America. In equestrian circles, she was the horsewoman of the year in 1971 and currently has the leaders in the open fine harness, harness pony and amateur harness pony divisions.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Corrections Officers Benevolent Association offered a $5,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of Joseph James, also known as John Lee Harrell, the prisoner who escaped Tuesday from Kings County Hospital Center after shooting two correction officers and a woman patient. The association is also offering $1,000 rewards for information leading to the arrest and conviction of two alleged accomplices, a woman and a man. Information should be given to the police at 2870311.

title: The Last September for Henry Aaron?
description: In the quiet dignity of his personal protocol, Henry Aaron hasn't confirmed that this is his last September as a home run hitter. But the hints are there.

title: ...Need for SelfHelp
description: What is now unmistakable is that only Congress can now bring the Federal Government into its proper and necessary role of aid not merely to this city but to all cities and states confronted with kindred problems. The first area of needed helpstressed anew by Mayor Beame in his television speech last eveningis in welfare, a field in which New York has become the repository of hundreds of thousands of dispossessed and dispirited Americans, especially from the rural South and Puerto Rico.

title: Personal Finance: Interest From Insurers
description: Beginning this month, life insurance companies doing business in New York State will be required on new policies to pay interest on claims from the date of death or maturity of the policy.

title: Philippine Rebels Vow to Keep Up Fight for SelfRule
description: LAKE LANAO, the Philippines, Sept. 4Despite a recent and wellpublitized claim by President Ferdinand E. Marcos that the Moslem rebels in the southern Philippines had accepted a ceasefire, rebel leaders in the villages and jungle around this remote blue tropical lake insist that they will fight on until their demands for autonomy are met fully.

title: REAGAN STUMPING IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 10Ronald Reagan made a campaign visit to politicallysensitive New Hampshire tonight and promised to return as a candidate in its 1976 primary if he should decide to challenge President Ford for the Republican nomination.

title: Giants Drop Athas, Add Two; Vote on Strike Looms in N.F.L.
description: Pete Athas, starter at left cornerback since 1971, was dropped yesterday as the New York Giants continued to move out the old guard.

title: 3 BUILDINGS BURN IN THE SOUTH BRONX
description: Three fires  all described by officials as suspicious destroyed abandoned buildings within a few blocks of each other in the South Bronx last night after local fire companies had been sent off in response to a false alarm, leaving the area without firstline protection.

title: Shelton L. Brooks, Wrote Darktown Strutters Ball'
description: Shelton Leroy Brooks, the composer and lyricist who wrote The Darktown Strutters Ball and Some of These Days, the latter popularized by Sophie Tucker, died Saturday in a sanitarium in Los Angeles. He was 89 years old.

title: ASHLAND GETS BID FOR CANADIAN UNIT
description: Ashland Oil, Inc., announced yesterday it had received a tentative offer from Brascan Ltd., of Toronto to purchase Ashland's 85 per cent interest in its Canadian subsidiary for $171.5million or more. Brascan is an international investment company.

title: Baby Formula Sales in Third World Criticized
description: An Americanbased multinational company likes to tell how, after the Biafran War, in Nigeria, it chartered a plane, filled it with Similac, the company's infant food product, and flew it into Lagos, the capital of faminestricken Nigeria, where Similac has enjoyed a profitable market ever since.

title: Players Attacked in Japan
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, Sept. 12 (AP)Four players of the Central League's Chunichi Dragons, including Ron Woods, an American, were injured tonight when they were assaulted by fans at Hiroshima Stadium.

title: Treasury Aide Says OPEC May Not Increase Oil Price
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The Treasury raised the possibility today that the 13nation oil cartel may not increase prices at its Sept. 24 meeting in Vienna.

title: Market Place
description: Investors are wondering whether the stock market's setbacks of the last six weeks represents a temporary profit taking interruption in the bull market that began in January or the resumption of a longterm bear marker that began more than five years ago.

title: TREASURY RAISES ITS NEEDS FOR CASK
School Attendance Picks Up in Boston, but White Absenteeism Still High
description: BOSTON, Sept. 10School attendance picked up here today, the third day of citywide public school integraton, but there was evidence of white flight from the school system as the result of the desegregation efforts.

title: F.C.C. WILL REOPEN A. T. & T. RATES CASE
description: The Federal Communications Commission has decided to reopen the controverial hi/lo rates case of the American Telephone and Telegraph Cornpany.

title: U.S. Retail Sales Fell 0.8% In August to $49.5Billion
description: After rising strongly for four consecutive months, retail sales in the United States fell 0.8 per cent in August to $49.5billion, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 10 (AP)Telly's Pop, owned by Telly Savalas, the actor, and ridden by Fernando Mena, captured the $111,925 Del Mar Futurity for 2yearolds today on the final day of Del Mar's 43day meeting. The winner slipped inside and took the lead at the halfmile pole but lugged inward in midstretch and broke stride after opening up a fourlength lead over Lexington Laugh. Mena kept matters in hand, straightening Telly's Pop for a 1length victory over Lexington Laugh, with Body Bend third in the onemile race.

title: Article 2  No Title
Rites for Bishop Anand
description: There will be a memorial service for the Right Rev. Kenneth D.V. Anand, Assistant Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark, at 10 A.M. Saturday in Trinity Cathedral, Newark. The Right Rev. George E. Rath. Bishop of the diocese, will officiate. Bishop Anand, who was also vicar of the Church of the Transfiguration in Towaco, N.J., died July 27, while vacationing in India, where he was born.

title: After Protests, Turkey Steps Up Assistance to Quake Victims
description: LICE, Turkey, Sept. 10Under pressure from opposition political groups, newspapers and Kurdishminority militants. Turkish Government officials declared today that earthquake??esistant housing would be provided for the inhabitants of this battered village.

title: Excerpts From Beame Speech on City's Fiscal Plight
description: During the past several months the City of New York and its people have been subjected to an ordeal that few other institutions in the world could endure. The imminence of crisis and fiscal disaster has been hanging over our heads, creating an atmosphere of uncertainty among our people; generating alarming headlines here and throughout the world; and commanding the total energies of local and state officials seeking to find solutions.

title: Contract Awards
description: A $318million order for a complete telecommunications plant has been received from the Algerian stateowned company known as Sonnelec by Standard Electricia, S.A., Madrid, Spanish subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Riot Police Ready
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 10 (UPI)Hans Fjelner, provincial police chief, said today he would use 1,500 riot policemen to prevent violence at the SwedenChile tennis series in the southern town of Baastad.

title: Sandman Campaign Financing Is Under Investigation in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10  The New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission is ending a long investigation of the financing of Charles W. Sand man Jr.'s unsuccessful Republican campaign for Governor in 1973, it was learned today.

title: Hope in the Schools
description: The still tentative plan whereby the teachers would return to New York City's public schools in an effort to work out the controversies over class size and teaching schedules is a sensible move toward ending what has been an indefensible and illegal strike against the city's children. Unless the plan proves merely a mask for evading the realities of the fiscal straitjacket within which the Board of Education and all its employes must operate, it could represent a major contribution toward establishing the credibility of the dramatic and broadbased rescue effort on which the city's hopes for a return to solvency depend.

title: JOHN SANDERSON, 85, A PAINT EXECUTIVE
description: John McE. Sanderson, former technical director of the plastics and resins division of the American Cyanamid Company, died last Friday at Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston. He was 85 years old and lived in North Andover, Mass. He had lived for many years, until 1972, in Babylon, L.I.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: PANEL WILL SEEK NEW CASH FOR CITY
description: State officials and legislators yesterday formed a task force aimed at coming up with recommendations to provide the city with cash if it cannot sell its bonds when it returns to the credit markets in December.

title: PollTakers Say Most Americans Oppose Isolationism
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10A panel of leading conductors of public opinion polls said today that although most Americans are mistrustful of Presidents, preoccupied with domestic issues and doubtful about benefiting from dtente, they are not becoming isolationists.

title: U. S. Crude Oil Output in Week Off to Lowest Level Since 1966
description: Crude oil production in the United States fell to 8.26 million barrels a date last week, the lowest level since August, 1966, according to figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Issues in Teacher Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTS: The United Federation of Teachers, headed by Albert Shanker, representing 60,000 teachers and 20,000 other employes in the city's 976school system.

title: BankRobbery Conviction
description: Richard R. Ford, 30 years old, of Lawrence, Mass., has been convicted in Federal Court here of robbing a bank outside Middletown, N. Y., of $203,000 on Oct. 20, 1971. Mr. Ford, who heard the verdict Tuesday night, is currently serving a sentence of eight to 10 years in Massachusetts State Prison in Walpole for assault with intent to kill and escape.

title: Rhodesia Reports 8 Killed
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 10 (AP)  Rhodesian forces have killed eight more black guerrillas in the northeastern operational area, a Government communique said today.

title: Notes on People
description: Government, and particularly Congress, needs people who understand science to properly place technological issues in the context of other national issues, said Harrison H. Schmitt, the astronaut, announcing his decision yesterday to seek the Republican nomination for Senator from New Mexico, his home state. Senator Joseph M. Montoya, the Democratic incumbent, has said he will run again and Dr. Schmitt faces at least two probable competitors in the primary.

title: BRIDGEPORT BRASS INCREASING PRICES
description: The Bridgeport Brass Company, a division of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation, said yesterday it was increasing the base prices of all product lines except water tube from 2 cents to 3 cents a pound, effective next Monday.

title: ERIC THOMPSON, ARCHEOLOGIST, 76
description: LONDON, Sept. 10Sir Eric Thompson, the archeologist and authority on Mayan civilization died yesterday in a hospital in Cambridge. He was 76 years old.

title: PANEL WILL SEEK NEW CASH FOR CITY
description: State officials and legislators yesterday formed a task force aimed at coming up with recommendations to provide the city with cash if it cannot sell its bonds when it returns to the credit markets in December.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A United Press International dispatch published in The New York Times last Saturday reported the arrest of four suspected bank robbers near Nashville, Tenn. According to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, one of the defendants was incorrectly identified as Sam Buckmaster of Atlanta. This defendant is Theo D. McDaniel, who, the F.B.I. said, was carrying the identification papers of Mr. Buckmaster, an Atlanta real estate man.

title: 7County FireFighting Plant Would Ignore Political Lines
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)Fire companies in seven counties have informally adopted a mutual emergency aid plan that would eliminate political boundaries in responding to major fires and disasters.

title: Subway Riding Here Down 8.2% During First 5 Days of Fare Rise
description: Subway ridership in the first five days of the new 50cent fare declined by 8.2 per cent from the same period last year, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Lebanese troops have been ordered to take up positions between warring Christian and Moslem factions in the Tripoli area of northern Lebanon. Announcing this move, which risked arousing Moslem and leftist groups, Premier Rashid Karami coupled it with word that Maj. Gen. Iskandar Ghanem, the army chief disliked by both groups, had been replaced. [Page 1, Columns 34.]

title: SUIT CHARGES U.S. AIDS ARAB BOYCOTT
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday charging Rogers C. B. Morton, the Secretary of Commerce, with aiding Arab countries in their boycott of business interests that are directed or owned by Jews or that support Israel.

title: Hearing Set on U.S. Bid To Halt Pennsy Default
description: Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia will hold a hearing today on a petition of the Federal Government seeking to restrain the First National City Bank of New York from declaring the Penn Central Railroad in default on a $1.1million payment of principal and interest that was due on Aug. 15 on a second equipment loan.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Wednesday.

title: Rossetti Sees 50% Chance of Reelection
description: After assessing the results of Tuesday's primary, Frank G. Rossetti, the Manhattan Democratic leader, estimated yesterday that his chances of being reelected to another twoyear term as county leader were 5050.

title: BLACKS ORGANIZE PROISRAEL GROUP
description: The formation of an organization to support Israel and to counter what was described as antiSemitism among Amercan blacks was announced here yesterday by a group of prominent black leaders.

title: Article 1  No Title
Obeying the Law
description: It is too soon for definitive judgment, but the early returns from Boston and Louisville indicate that 1975 is not the year to write off school integrationeven when it results from courtordered busing. There has been relative peace in Boston which, given last year's experience and the dire predictions of August, seems a substantial accomplishment. In Louisville the metropolitanwide busing plan ordered by a Federal judge is proceeding not only in peace but with strong indications that the integration program may succeed quite well.

title: FOOD STAMP STUDY ASSAYS THE LOSS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The Department of Agriculture reported today that almost all food stamp recipients who are not on welfare are financially eligible to receive the stamps, but it said that about onequarter of nonwelfare recipients receive more benefits than they should.

title: House Panel Votes to End 2 Additional Tax Shelters
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)  The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to end tax shelters in the movie and equipment  leasing businesses.

title: Pilots Accept Wage Cuts
description: Flight engineers and pilots of Pan American World Airways agreed yesterday to give up another $2million in wages to avert a major furloughing and job downgrading program scheduled to take effect Oct. 1, United Press International reported here. Pan Am pilots and flight engineers had already agreed to give up $12.7million in pay to avert layoffs and job downgradings.

title: Ancient Title Sharp In Marlboro Drill
description: With the zero hour for tomorrow's $250,000 Marlboro Cup Invitational approaching, added focus was thrown on the clock yesterday for the third running of the 1mile race at Belmont Park. A few hours before it was announced that seven horses officially had been entered in the Marlboro, John L. Greer's Foolish Pleasure and Mrs. Ethel Kirkland's Ancient Title went through final blowouts. The clockers found Ancient Title's work impressive. Foolish Pleasure's? It was only soso.

title: STOPGAP OIL BILL STALLS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The House of Representatives unanimously approved today stopgap legislation that would extend price controls on oil through the end of next month.

title: The Contemplative Man's Recreation
description: MENEMSHA, Mass., Sept. 11Dexter Goodwin, a bigcity type from Branford, Conn., who has found happiness on Martha's Vineyard, is a large, sunny man around whose brow clouds gather when he goes fishing. He was telling, just for illustration, about several fruitless days of angling on this island with his friend Ken MacKenzie, the Yale baseball coach, and young Kenny. Finally, he said, we went to the Peach at Lobsterville, we were ?? up abreast, maybe 10 yards from end to end, fishing the surf.

title: Request by Archdiocese For Mediation Rejected
description: A union of lay teachers rejected a request by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York for state mediation yesterday, increasing the possibility of a strike next week at 12 Catholic high schools in Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island and Orange, Dutchess and Westchester counties.

title: Tomahawks Lose; Trail Series, 3 to
description: QUEBEC CITY, Sept. 11 The Quebec Caribous scored three goals in 21 seconds early in the final period en route to a 1511 victory over the Long Island Tomahawks tonight in the semifinals of the National Lacrosse League playoffs before 6,694 fans.

title: State Aides Hid U.S. Role in Drug Death
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The New York State Attorney General's office agreed to cover up the Federal Government's involvement in a death in an Armysponsored drug experiment in Manhattan after the Federal Government agreed to pay half of an $18,000 settlement to the widow, previously secret documents reveal.

title: New State Court Rules Take Effect; Reforms Strengthen Hughes Directive
description: A rule assuring dueprocess guarantees to individuals who face commitment to mental hospitals took effect in New Jersey this week.

title: NoHit Bid Fails, But Tiant Wins, 31
description: Luis Tiant pitched 7 2/3 innings of nohit ball and finished with a threehitter yesterday as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Detroit Tigers, 31, in Boston.

title: 3 Inmates, 2 Guards Are Hurt in a Melee At Nashville Prison
description: NASHVILLE, Friday, Sept. 12 (AP)  Convicts went on a rampage last night when the kitchen at the Tennessee State Prison ran out of pork chops and began substituting baloney for supper. One prisoner was shot and two other prisoners and two guards were injured.

title: SYLVIA SYMS FORMS CHARACTERS IN SONG
description: One of the advantages of having sung as long as Sylvia Syms hasand during her performance this week at the Grand Finale, 210 West 70th Street, she is not the least bit shy about admitting that she made her first album in 1951; is that one acquires a tremendous repertory of songs from which to choose. Miss Syms has the further advantages of a keen sense of musical and lyrical values and a reputation as a sensitive interpreter that induces songwriters to bring her material that is rather special, much as they do with Mabel Mercer.

title: Robert G. Sproul, 84, Dies; Headed U. of California
description: Robert Gordon Sproul, president of the University of California for 28 years, died Wednesday at his home in Berkeley after a long illness. He was 84 years old and had retired in 1958.

title: ELIZABETHTOWN GAS GETS RATE INCREASE
description: NEWARK, Sept. 11 (UPI)Elizabethtown Gas Company, which serves 180,000 customers in New Jersey, was granted a $7million rate increase today with a rate schedule designed to encourage conservation of natural gas.

title: Genet's Deathwatch Explores the Psyche of Murder
description: I tried every form and shape so as not be a murderer, say the convict Green Eyes in Jean Gent's Deathwatch (at the East 4th Street Theater in the Cambridge Ensemble production). For Green Eyes, who is awaiting a death sentence, murder is something beyond the will. Some people are born to be criminals and no amount of yearning for misfortune can alter one's destiny.

title: STOCKS DEPRESSED BY RATE WORRIES
description: Concern over the prospect of an upturn in interest rates kept stocks under pressure yesterday in light trading.

title: Bluefish Providing Action for Anglers
description: When, after a long, hot summer of stable weather, northeast striped bass anglers talk with each other about the lack of action such conditions inevitably create, they smile and say, Just wait for the first good storm of early fall. After a good storm or two the bass will begin hitting again.

title: 200 Years Ago Today, the Second Continental Congress Met to Weigh War and Peace
description: When the Second Continental Congress resumed sessions in Philadelphia on Sept. 12, 1775, the agenda was insurrectionat the best of times an enterprise of risk, at the worst of times a venture of despair.

title: 6.400th Fantasticks Is the Record
description: Tonight, for the 6.400th time, a halfdozen actors will crowd onstage at the Sullivan Street Playhouse, take down a white cloth sign and stuff it into a box. The Fantasticks, says the sign.

title: PORTUGAL LOSING EDUCATED ELITE
description: LISBON, Sept. 11Doctors, and agronomists, engineers and economists, business managers and specialists in tropical medicine have left Portugal by the thousands since the leftwing's revolution in April, 1974.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Thursday, Sept. 11, 1975

title: HOUSE PANEL CUTS DEFENSE BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10A House Appropriations subcommittee, responding to the new budgetary guidelines adopted by Congress has cut the defense budget by the unusually large amount of about $7billion, Congressional sources disclosed today.

title: BYRNE 10 SUPPORT LATEST BOND PLAN
description: TRENTON, Sept. 11Governor Byrne announced todaythat he would support the amended $923  million bond issue approved by the Assembly on Monday, even though he conceded that the borrowing plan lacked a consensus.

title: Portugal Says Spinola Faces Arrest on Return
description: LISBON, Friday, Sept. 12 (Agence FrancePresse) Gen. Antnio de Spinola will be arrested and tried by a military court if lie, returns to Portugal, the ruling High council of the Revolution announced at the end of an allnight meeting early today.

title: The Gun Is Pointed, Miss Fromme Says; Judge Ejects Her
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 11  Lynette Alice Fromme, appearing for arraignment on an indictment accusing her of attempting to assassinate President Ford, was removed from a courtroom today after she told a Federal judge: The gun is pointed, your honor, the gun is pointedwhether it goes off is up to you.

title: CORRECTION
description: The producer of the documentary film Khrushchev Remembers was misidentified in an article in The New York Times yesterday. The producer is Harold Mayer.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Seven men were indicted on charges of stealing $100,000 worth of fashionable Yves St. Laurent men's suits. The suspects are Vincent Santa, Pasquale DeFellipo, Stanley A. Diamond, Joseph DeLuca and James DeFellipo, all of Queens in New York City, and Morris. Spiers and Michael Scarano, both of Old Bridge. They were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Newark.

title: Egypt Appears to Take Over Voice of Palestine Broadcasts in Bitter Dispute Over New Sinai Accord
description: CAIRO, Sept. 11The Egyptian Government appeared today to have taken over the local broadcasts of the Voice of Palestine, the official network of the Palestine Liberation Movement.

title: Bill on Homosexuals Is Defeated
description: Homosexuals Lose

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: The Teacher Dispute
description: The United Federation of Teachers, headed by Albert Shenker, representing 60,000 teachers and 20,000 other employes in the city's 976school system.

title: Two Are Tied at 73 For Seniors Lead
description: BAY SHORE, L.I. Sept. 11 John Humm of Rockville Links and Gus Ganzenmuller of Nassau were tied for the lead at 73 today after the opening round of the 24th annual Long Island Senior Golf Association championship over the par72, 6,590yard Southward Ho course. Jim Manzone of Crab Meadow, winner of the last four titles, carded a 77.

title: Winners
description: GREENVALE, L.I., Sept 11 Moving Spirit, Velvet Tux, Market Rise and Kim Song all captured hunter championships today at the Nissau County Horse Show, but they had something else in commonall were ridden by Rodney Jenkins.

title: A's Rise to Heights Jenkins Against Key Foes Aboard 4
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 11 Back in the nineteenthirties and fifties, when New York Yankee teams were putting together strings of championships unparalleled in baseball history, they made classic a pattern of victory: late in the season they would meet their chief pursuers headon and crush them.

title: Books of The Times
description: I was attracted to R.M. Koster's second novel, The Dissertation, as much by wonder and curiosity as by anything elsea wonder and curiosity aroused both by the author's unusual vita and by his flamboyant first novel, The Prince, which made the list of nominees for the National Book Award in 1973. For Mr. Koster appears truly a man of parts, as the expression used to go. He is an American from Brooklyn by way of Yale and New York University, who now professes English at a university in Panama. He is businessman with interests in two Miami nightclubs and a Central American rice plantation. He is a member of the Democratic National Committee. And he has previously written seven novels, the first six of which were stillborn, as he himself puts it, and the seventh of which, the aforementioned The Prince, managed to catch the violence and chaos of Central American politics without getting bogged down in Central American metaphysics.

title: DR. S. L. FRIEDMAN, 66, A HOSPITAL PLANNER
description: Dr. Sigmund L. Friedman, director of planning at Long Island College Hospital, died of cancer yesterday. He was 66 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Nervous traders did enough selling on the Chicago Board of Trade to cause prices of corn and soybeans to drift lower yesterday, ahead of the crop report issued after the close of trading. Some of the selling also could be traced to reports that China did not plan to buy additional supplies of grains in world markets because of some crop improvements in recent weeks.

title: Hunter Gets 21st Yankee Victory, 102
description: Henry Aaron made what could be his last appearance as a baseball player in New York last night, but he didn't play. He was in the Milwaukee dugout with a bad back while the Yankees were beating the Brewers, 102.

title: FRENCH SET TAX ON ITALIAN WINES
description: PARIS, Sept. 11In an attempt to put more cheap French wine back on the nation's tables and bars, the Government imposed a tax on Italian wines today.

title: FORECAST ON CORN IS REDUCED BY 3%
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 11American farmers are still expected to harvest a record corn crop next month, though it may be smaller than the Agriculture Department or the grain trade had expected earlier.

title: Business Briefs
description: BONN, Sept. 11 (Reuters)West Germany today moved to bolster its flagging economy by cutting its bank rate to help industry borrow money more cheaply. The cut, from 4 to 3 per cent effective tomorrow, came just two weeks after Bonn announced a $2.20billion public investment program designed mainly to shore up the shaky construction industry.

title: PRIME RATE RISE IS HELD POSSIBLE
3 Troubleshooters on New Fiscal Board
description: Albert V. Casey is no stranger to the financial problems of ailing giants. He took on a classic case, American Airlines, early last year as president, chief executive officer and shortly afterwards chairman as well. He entertained Federal feelers for the chairrpanship of the United States Railway Association at about the same time.

title: Filling the Gap at Home, When Strikes and Crises Block Opening of School
description: As school strikes and disturbances affected more than two million students in 11 states this weekNew York, Illinois, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts and Rhode Island being the hardest hitthey raised the question in the minds of many parents about what educational activities they and their children ought to try at home.

title: U.S. Agencies Act to Ease Impact of a Default by City
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11New and more comprehensive plans to insulate the nation's economy from the effects of a possible default of New York City bonds have been made by the three Federal agencies that regulate the nation's banks, it was disclosed today.

title: Senate Panel Completes Work on Measure to Strengthen Federal Grain Inspection System
description: WASHINGTON, Sept.11A Senate subcommittee completed action today on emergency legislation designed to strengthen the Federal graininspection system and help prevent irregularities of the type that have been charged as a result of an investigation of alleged corruption in the grainexport trade.

title: Soviet Foreign Aims Suffer Setbacks
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 11In the wake of its success at the European security conference in Helsinki, the Soviet Union has encountered a variety of foreignaffairs frustrations that extend well beyond the bypassing of Moscow in the recent EgyptianIsraeli disen gagement accord.

title: Beame Demands Clean Streets in 10 Days
description: Mayor Beame told Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh and Mr. Groh's chief aides yesterday that heads will roll unless the city's streets are cleaned up within 10 days.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1975

title: PRESIDENT WEARS PROTECTIVE VEST
description: PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Sept. 11President Ford, evidently wearing a protective vest beneath his clothing, plunged into scores of large crowds today as he politicked across southern New Hampshire.

title: Amex Approves Merrill's OddLot Plan
description: The American Stock Exchange, in a surprise development, gave tentative approval yesterday to plans by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the brokerage house, to offer its customers an opportunity to buy small amounts of stock without having to go through the Amex.

title: SENATE UNIT SETS COORS VOTE DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)The Senate communications subcommittee, which has been studying for more than a year the nomination of Joseph Coors to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, put off a confirmation vote today for three weeks.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.9 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 206 from 206.9 last week.

title: SUIT SEEKS TO BAR PENSIONFUND USE
description: ALBANY, Sept. 11A court test on the use of state pension funds to help financially distressed New York City was initiated here today by the Police Conference of New York, Inc., a group that represents 45,000 officers in 201 upstate police departmens.

title: BEAME COUNTING CITY'S BLESSINGS
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that many private businesses, are bent over double beneath la debt burden worse than News York City's and predicted that the city would get out of its financial troubles more quickly than the companies would.

title: S.E.C. STRENGTHENS REPORTING RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted new regulations today requiring the nation's 3,800 largest public companies to provide more financial information in both quarterly and yearend reports filed with the commission.

title: Elder Leader With 65
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Sept. 11 (AP)Lee Elder, in a slump since his heralded appearance in the Masters last spring, mastered the No. 2 course at the Pinehurst Country Club with a sixunderpar 65 today and took the firstround lead in the $200,000 World open golf tournament.

title: BEY WILL DIRECT SUFFOLK INQUIRY
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., sept. 11Governor Carey has appointed Joseph Hoey, a former United States Attorney for the Eastern District in New York, as his special prosecutor to investigate both the Suffolk District Attorney and the Suffolk police Commissioner, sources close to the Governor disclosed today.

title: CHEMICAL BANK RULED A USURER
description: A Civil Court judge ruled yesterday that the Chemical Bank had been engaging in usury and the unauthorized practice of law in routinely suing for and collecting lawyers' fees from people who defaulted on loans.

title: AGREEMENT FAILS ON A PLAN TO END TEACHERS' STRIKE
description: A plan to end the crippling teachers' strike fell apart yesterday when the agreement became bogged down over what the Board of Education contends were matters of substance in its planned public announcement and the union says were merely matters of wording.

title: Ford to Lift Price Of '76 Cars by 5%
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11The Ford Motor Company announced today increases of 5 per cent, or $215, on the average retail price of its 1976 model cars.

title: The Pop Life
description: A few weeks ago, this observer remarked that rock was essentially a white male music, and recently received a heated letter of protest for his pains.

title: Metropolitan Brief
description: A 16month investigation of allegations of corruption in the awarding of towing, gas station and other contracts by the Long Island State Park and Recreation Commission produced its first indictment. Victor LaGuardia, head of the Triple Arc Collision Corporation of 63 Smith Street, Hempstead, L.I., was indicted by a Federal Grand Jury in Brooklyn on four counts of perjury.

title: Cot Sanders' Chicken War Ends
description: Harland D. Sanders, the colonel who founded the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation, and Heublein, Inc., the liquor and food conglomerate, have settled their differences out of court.

title: Met Devoting 10 Galleries to Opulent Art of Islam
description: A new and dazzling installation of Islamic art, a culture never before given prominence by the Metropolitan Museum, will go on public view this month. The 10 new galleries, funded by a gift of some $500,000 from Arthur A. Houghton Jr., former president of the museum and trustee emeritus, will provide a complete survey of this strikingly sensuous and opulent artfrom architectural elements to paintings, manuscripts, rugs, ceramics, metalwork, glass, jewelry and textiles.

title: Minta Durfee, Actress, 85, Dies; Former Wife of Fatty Arbuckle
description: Minta Durfee, the actress who was married to Roscoe (Fatty) Arbuckle and became Charlie Chaplin's first motionpicture leading lady, died Tuesday in Woodland Hills, a Los Angeles suburb.

title: CORRECTION
description: The producer of the documentary film Khrushchev Remembers was misidentified in an article in The New York Times yesterday. The producer is Harold Mayer.

title: MOSCOW BIDS U.N. BAN ALL ATESTS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 11The Soviet Union put forward today a draft for a treaty that would prohibit underground tests of nuclear weapons as well as the tests in the atmosphere, space and water prohibited by the 1963 testban treaty.

title: People and Business
description: John E. Fisher, president of the Nationwide Insurance Companies, warned yesterday that auto and homeowner insurance will become hard to obtain unless rates are raised to offset what he termed the massive claims payout for losses.

title: Senate Panel Votes To Reject Ford Bid On a 5% Pay Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) The Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee voted today to reject President Ford's recommended 5 per cent Federal pay increase ceiling and give Government employesincluding themselvesan 8.66 per cent salary rise.

title: G.O.P. in a Partial Accord On Splitting Dinner Funds
description: TRENTON, Sept 11New Jersey Republicans today achieved a partial resolution of their dispute over the division of the proceeds of President Ford's fundraising dinner here next month.

title: U.S. Loses in Volleyball
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 11 (AP)The Soviet Union national volleyball team defeated the United States, 31, in a threeoffivegames match at the University of Dayton last night. The United States defeated the Soviet team, 1513, in the second game of the match. It was the first time an American team has won a game from the Russians since 1968.

title: Philippine University Focus of Conflict in Moro Revolt
description: MARAWI, the Philippines, Sept. 4Its bank has been robbed by a gang of heavily armed soldiers, its radio station has been shot up, its president has been ousted for alleged corruption. The Philippine Government has poured millions of dollars into it in an effort to win the allegiance of Moslem dissidents, while Moslem rebels use it to recruit their guerrillas.

title: PRESIDENT WEARS PROTECTIVE VEST
description: PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Sept. 11  President Ford, wearing a protective vest beneath his clothing, plunged into scores of large crowds today as he politicked across southern New Hampshire.

title: Aluminum Rapped As Bat Material
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 (UPI)  A former National League batting champion, Dick Groat, testifying in United States District Court in a patent suit, said today use of aluminum bats in the major leagues would turn spray hitters into sluggersand make present ball parks obsolete.

title: Ulster's Major Catholic Party Boycotts Constitutional Parley
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 11Northern Ireland's constitutional convention reconvened today, but the major Roman Catholic political party boycotted the session and called for early adjournment.

title: Samdech Returns
description: Mere outsiders can only guess at the intricate dealings that brought Prince Norodom Sihanouk back to his capital this week, after fiveandahalf years of exile. They are as mysterious as is his real status in the emerging power structure in Phnom Penh. The only point of clarity is that Prince Sihanouk is not a man to be ignored, whether by friend or foe, or anyone in between.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: City Bicentennial Unit Gets A Fiitancial Lease on Life
description: The New York City Bicentennial Corporation received a new lease on life last night when the Board of Estimate, after a frequently acrimonious, fourhour debate, agreed to provide $500,000 in city funds to keep the commission in business through June.

title: PORTUGUESE FAIL TO FORM CABINET
description: LISBON. Sept. 11Efforts to form a coalition cabinet of national unity were delayed today as two of the three political parties scheduled to participate refused to talk to each other.

title: Broad British Laws Proposed To Curb Racial Discrimination
description: LONDON, Sept. 11  The British Government, expressing worry about the race situation here, today proposed farreaching laws to deal with discrimination and new measures to counter bias in employment, housing, schools and clubs.

title: Cowboy Clothes by a Man Who Should Know
description: Larry Mahan, one of the top rodeo cowboys in history, came to the wild, wild East the other day toting his line of Western shirts for female cowpokes.

title: Guam Tri Deactivates Arms
description: TOKYO, Sept. 11 (AP)Vietnamese troops and civilians have removed or deactivated 170,000 shells, bombs and mines in Quang Tri Province in two months, the North Vietnamese press agency reported today.

title: U.S SAID TO GIVE A PLEDGE TO SEEK SYRIAISRAEL PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The United States has assured Egypt as part of the recently concluded Sinai agreement with Israel that it will make a serious effort to help bring about further negotiations between Israel and Syria for another accord on the Golan Heights.

title: STOPGAP OIL BILL STALLS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The House of Representatives unanimously approved today stopgap legislation that would extend price controls on oil through the end of next month.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Shannon Wall, president of the National Maritime Union; Joseph Curran, his predecessor, and seven other unon officials were notified in United States District Court in Newark yesterday that they were potential defendants in a Federal grandjury inquiry into alleged incometax evasion and racketeering in the union hierarchy. In a hearing, United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein advised the subpoenaed men that their plans to be represented jointly by one lawyer, and not individually, could prejudice their different interests during the investigation. The inquiry by Mr. Goldstein's office was originally disclosed in July.

title: City Is Pondering Cuts in Construction Beyond the $345Million Already Saved
description: Further sizable cuts in city construction spending this year in addition to the $345million worth of cityfinanced projects already slashed from the capital budgetare being considered by the Beame administation.

title: Treasury's Plans to Raise Cash Deflate Bond Prices
description: Prices in the Government and corporate bond markets ended lower yesterday in response to the Treasury's announcement late Wednesday that it needed to raise more money by the end of the year than originally estimated. The Treas ury's new estimate of its cash needs was increased to a range of $44billion to $47billion from the $41billion estimated last month.

title: Kern Revue Is Canceled
description: Jerome Kern at the Gate, a revue with music by the late composer, which had been scheduled to open at the Gate Theater on Sept. 16, has been canceled indefinitely by its producer, Art DLugoff. The show has been giving Monday previews since Aug. 18. William E. Hunt was the director. The cast included Loretta Abbott, Herb Downer J. J. Jepson and Rosamond Lynn.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The way New York City conducts its daytoday businesshow its scores of agencies manage their personnel and their budgetswill undergo substantial change if voters at the Nov. 4 election approve the second of nine propositions submitted to reform the City Charter.

title: GROUP IS FORMED TO AID CANDIDATES
description: TRENTON, Sept. 11 (AP)Robert F. Goheen, former president of Princeton University, today announced the formation of a bipartisan group that will try to aid those Assembly candidates from both major political parties who it feels deserve election.

title: A Book by Hoffa Accuses Fitzsimmons of Mob Link
description: James R. Hoffa, who has been missing since July 30, has charged Frank E. Fitzsimmons, his successor as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, with selling out to mobsters and making vast loans from the billiondollar teamster pension fund to known mobsters.

title: California Farm Elections Proving a Seesaw Battle
description: DELANO. Calif., Sept. 11For a while this morning, as the sun cut through the ground haze that baked the farmlands of the San Joaquin Valley, Cesar Chavey was basking in the warm glow of the results of the first week of farm labor elections in California.

title: Boyle Is Given Three Life Terms In '69 Murder of the Yablonskis
description: Boyle Gets Life

title: City's Woes Fan Bond Dealers' Problems
description: For Wall Street's municipal bond dealers, New York City's financial crisis has been a yearlong headache.

title: About New York
description: There are certain myths about New York that just will not go away. For instance, there's the image of the New Yorker as a cosmopolitan person who knows which side is up when the chips are down, a citizen who can drop in any place and take over, so watch out for him.

title: Garrett Goes to Work for Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., Sept. 11 The locker where Carl Garrett dressed in a Jets' uniform today for the first time belonged once to Mike Adamle, who was traded to Chicago for Garrett.

title: Egyptians and Israelis Talk For 5 Hours on Sinai Issues
description: GENEVA, Sept. 11Egyptian and Israeli representatives, defining procedures to carry out the interim peace agreement than five hours today.

title: Reay Backs Chile On a Neutral Site
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 11 (UPI)Two other members of Chile's Davis Cup team refused today to play the semifinals Sept. 1921 in Sweden because of a death threat to Jaime Fillol and the tennis federation insisted the playing site be moved to a neutral country.

title: MACY PROFIT UP 31% IN 4TH PERIOD
Teamwork on Aid
description: Passage by the House of Representatives of the International Development and Food Assistance bill signaled a good deal more than simply completion of the first step in the foreign aid authorization process. It also marked approval by the whole House of a unique cooperative effort in which the Ford Administration has adopted some constructive foreign aid departures initiated in the House.

title: HOUSE PANEL CUTS DEFENSE BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10A House Appropriations subcommittee, responding to the new budgetary guidelines adopted by Congress, has cut the defense budget by the unusually large amount of about $7billion, Congressional sources disclosed today.

title: Bill Introduced On Blackout Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)  Representative Torbert MacDonald, Democrat of Massachusetts introduced legislation today to continue permanently to prevent the National Football League and other pro sports from blacking out the televising of home games sold out in advance.

title: China: Image and Reality
description: DENVER The American public mind does not cope easily with the People's Republic of China. This is largely the fault of the missionaries, businessmen, diplomats and intellectuals who have over the years shaped our images to serve their own or their patrons' purposes.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States has assured Egypt that it will make a serious effort to help bring about further negotiations between Israel and Syria for another accord on the Golan Heights. The New York Times learned yesterday that in addition to the secret undertakings assumed by the United States on Israel's behalf in the published and unpublished documents making up the recent Sinai agreement there was also an unpublished memorandum outlining American assurances to Egypt. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: RISE IN CAR OUTPUT EXPECTED FOR WEEK
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11American auto production this week is expected to total 164.983 units, up 29.4 per cent from 127,513 cars built last week when plants were closed for Labor Day.

title: Market Place
description: Shares of ChrisCraft Industries, Inc., a major producer of pleasure boats, have been heavily traded in recent days, leading to speculation that individual investors or a group of investors are hoping that a $36million judgment in favor of ChrisCraft will be allowed to stand.

title: The Two Majorities
description: CAMBRIDGEThere are now two majorities in American politicsa conservative majority and a Democratic majority. But aren't the Democrats the liberal party?

title: Strike Fine of U.M.W. Is Reset at $700,000
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 11 (AP)The United Mine Workers international union was fined $700,000 today for the onemonth wildcat coal strike that at its peak idled 80,000 miners in a halfdozen states.

title: Bridge:
description: Memories of the foottapping controversy in Bermuda that rocked the bridge world six months ago are brought back by the recent publication of the American Contract Bridge League's annual world championship book. ($6.95 from the league, 2200 Democrat Road, Memphis, Tenn., 38116).

title: Stocks Decline on the Amex and Counter Markets
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market dropped again yesterday as trading remained slow.

title: Ailing A. M. America on ABCTV Is Forging a New Format
description: A.M. America, which began last January as ABCTVs entry in early morning news and information programing, is undergoing substantial changes and, on Oct. 27, will assume a new format and introduce a largely new cast of personalities, Frederick S. Pierce, president of ABC Television, said yesterday in an interview.

title: SOVIET MISSILE TESTS SET FOR BARENTS SEA
description: MOSCOW, Sept 11 (UPI)The Soviet Union announced today that it would test missiles in the icy waters of the Barents Sea. The move appeared to put political pressure on neighboring Norway, a member of the North Atlantic Alliance.

title: Debut Next Sept. 1 Seen For Meadowland Track
description: CARLSTADT, Sept. 11 David A. Werblin, chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, said today that current engineering reports indicate the race track the agency is building here should open no later than Sept. 1, 1976, to be followed by the football stadium A month later.

title: About Real Estate
description: Consider the case of Guido Teichner. He is an engineer, 31 years old, who bought a 48family elevator apartment house in Washington Heights last week for $102,000 in cash. That comes to about $2.125 an apartment.

title: MOONLIGHTER WINS JACKPOT IN LOTTERY
description: GILLETTE, Sept. 11 (AP)A machinist who cleans schools at night to make ends meet won $250.000 in the Jersey Jackpot lottery drawing today.

title: Plan Is Approved to Reexamine Data in Robert Kennedy Slaying
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11A state judge approved today a plan to name seven firearms experts as a panel to conduct a reexamination of ballistics evidence in the Robert F. Kennedy assassination case.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SOOTHING There is, of course, music galore at Lincoln Centerjazz, opera. rhythm and blues, rock and symphony. And across the street from Lincoln Center. at Cleo's restaurant, there's more music: more but different.

title: Landslide Perils Utah Village; Residents Plan to Ease Effect
description: MANTI, Utah, Sept. 10If Hollywood decides to make a new disaster movie called Landslide! this central Utah town could, as Brigham Young once said in another context, be the place.

title: Article 2  No Title
Italians' Apathy Over Kidnappings Is Shaken by Girl's Murder
description: ROME, Sept. 11Of all the kidnapping episodes in Italy in recent months, none has so shocked Italians as that of Cristina Mazzotti, an 18yearold high school student who was kidnapped and murdered even though her family paid a ransom of more than $1million.

title: U.S. Agencies Act to Ease Impact of a Default by City
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11New and more comprehensive plans to insulate the nation's economy from the effects of a possible default of New York City bonds have been made by the three Federal agencies that regulate the nation's banks, it was disclosed today.

title: Tramp Art: Lost Craft Springs to Life
description: This is surely the most outrageous example of tramp art I've ever seen, Helaine Fendelman said admiringly the other morning as she shoved a 300pound, elephantinelegged desk against a museum wall. It's also the best piece in terms of sculptural detail and sheer magnitude.

title: Ethel Griffies, Who at 97 Was Oldest Working Actress, Dies
description: Ethel Griffies, who in recent ears was the oldest working actress in the Englishspeaking theater, died Tuesday in London after a stroke. She was 97 years old.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: No Excuse for Delay
description: All that seems left of the issues between the Board of Education and the striking United Federation of Teachers is a need for recognition by both sides that their sole remaining task is to allocate in the best interest of education the reduced teaching personnel available to the schools under the board's rigid austerity budget. The tentative agreement in principle on an approach to that problem removes any excuse for further delay in ending the illegal walkout in New York's public schools.

title: British Airways Begins Campaign
description: British Airways. owned by the country that took second place in the American Revolution, is launching an advertising campaign on Monday that celebrates the Bicentennial with British tongueincheek charm. The theme is, Come home, all is forgiven and Robert Morley, the jolly round actor, is still the star.

title: Mexico Gets Chinese Pandas
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 11 (UPI) China has given Mexico City a pair of pandas, Peking reported today.

title: SENATE UNIT SETS COORS VOTE DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)The Senate communications subcommittee, which has been studying for more than a year the nomination of Joseph Coors to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, put off a confirmation vote today for three weeks.

title: U.S. Jury Seeks to Learn If Carey Helped Brother
description: A Federal grand jury her is looking into allegations that Governor Carey intervened with Government officials to assist his brother's oil company more than a year ago, when the Governor was a Brooklyn Representative in Congress.

title: Notes on People
description: Edward Zelenin, a dissident Soviet painter who had applied to emigrate to France, has been arrested, only a few days before the scheduled opening in Moscow of an unauthorized outdoor show of unofficial art next Sunday. The dissident artists' show would mark the anniversary of their exhibition that was closed last year by policemen using bulldozers.

title: Boyle Is Given Three Life Terms In '69 Murder of the Yablonskis
description: MEDIA, Pa., Sept. 11 (AP)W. A. Boyle. who once counseled Presidents of the United, States as head of the powerful United Mine Workers, was sentenced to three consecutive life terms today for ordering the 1969 murder of a union rival.

title: Beame Demands Clean Streets in 10 Days
description: Mayor Beame told Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh and Mr. Groh's chief aides yesterday that heads will roll unless the city's streets are cleaned up within 10 days.

title: Echoes From City's Empty Schoolhouses
description: At Julia Richman High School on the East Side yesterday, a supervisor called some teachers into his office. The teachers were on strike; the supervisor was not, and he wanted to explain his position.

title: Spain Trying Five Accused of Killing Madrid Policeman
description: MADRID, Sept. 11Five alleged members of an extreme leftwing organization went on trial near here today accused of having killed a policeman. They face death sentences if found guilty.

title: Tale of 2 Cities Boston by Day, and Night
description: BOSTON, Sept. 11We almost, made it through oncealmost, Deputy Police Superintendent Joseph Rowan was saying at 1 o'clock this morning.

title: CHEMICAL BANK RULED A USURER
description: A Civil Court judge ruled yesterday that the Chemical Bank had been engaging in usury and the unauthorized practice of law in routinely suing for and collecting lawyers' fees from people who defaulted on loans.

title: Signs of 1973 Mideast War Eluded U.S.Spy Agencies
description: WASHINGTON. Sept 11The United States intelligence community acknowledges that it failed to predict the 1973 ArabIsraeli war and that several intelligence agencies even predicted that there would be no war only hours before the hostilities broke out, according to a secret report made public today.

title: Met 8, New Conference For Football, Is Formed
description: Don Kelleher knew he would stump the crowd with his challenge. Guess how much our budget is. Just guess, said the president of the Manhattan College football team, one of eight local club teams that have just formed the Met 8 football conference. Most of the modest guesses were off by about $10,000.

title: Destroy the Monster
description: The disclosure that the Central Intelligence Agency hoarded a supply of deadly poisons in direct contravention of Richard Nixon's order to destroy such poisons in 1969 is only one more bit of evidence that this agency is a Frankenstein's monster that must be destroyed.

title: FREDERIC B. POWERS
description: Frederic B. Powers, formed chairman of the Westchesterl County Republican Committee and chairman of the Rawl Plug Company, manufacturer of expansion bolts, died Wednesday in New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center. He was 68 years old and lived at 180 Overlook Road, New Rochelle.

title: Broad British Laws Proposed To Curb Racial Discrimination
description: LONDON, Sept. 11  The British Government, expressing worry about the race situation here, today proposed farreaching laws to deal with discrimination and new measures to counter bias in employment, housing, schools and clubs.

title: TV Review
description: Does anyone remember Sierra. an NBC series about youthfully pretty boys and girls learning to become forest rangers in the great outdoors? A year ago, consensus would probably have awarded it a rusty antenna as worst new series of the year. This season, the prize is likely to go to Mobile One. which gets under way on ABC tonight at 8 o'clock, although a close contender could be Barbary Coast, also on ABC, Mondays at 8 P.M.

title: U.S SAID TO GIVE A PLEDGE TO SEEK SYRIAISRAEL PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The United States has assured Egypt as part of the recently concluded Sinai agreement with Israel that it will make a serious effort to help bring about further negotiations between Israel and Syria for another accord on the Golan Heights.

title: Byrne's Lawyer Seeks 3d Brordman Abductor
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 11 The lawyer for Dominic Byrne, who is accused with Mel Patrick Lynch of kidnapping Samuel Bronfman 2d, said today that a third person had been involved in the abduction and was being sought as a witness.

title: Al U.N., A NEW AIR OF CONCILIATION
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11We are speaking to one another, we are no longer barking at one another, Foreign Minister Gamal Mohammed Ahmed of the Sudan told the special session of the United Nations General Assembly the other day.

title: Carey Puts 3 Executives On Fiscal Control Board
description: Governor Carey appointed three wellknown business executives yesterday to round out the new Emergency Financial Control Board and immediately called the first meeting of the board in its mission of trying to repair the city government's financial structure.

title: Federal Judges Consider Rules On LawyerCompetency Tests
description: BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Sept. 11The issue was that of competency as legal educators squared off today against prominent trial lawyers. Their audience was more than 50 Federal judges who must decide if minimum qualifications should be required for lawyers seeking to practice in Federal trial courts in New York.

title: Karpov Maintains His Lead In Milan Chess Tourney
description: MILAN, Italy, Sept. 11 (Reuter)The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, drew with Lajos Portisch of Hungary today to maintain his lead in the final round of the Milan grandmasters tournament.

title: Tuttle's Art On Display At Whitney
description: To Mies van der Rohe's famous dictum that less is more, the art of Richard Tuttle offers definitive refutation. For in Mr. Tuttle's work, less is unmistakably less. It is, indeed, remorselessly and irredeemably less. It establishes new standards of lessness, and fairly basks in the void of lessness. One is tempted to say that, so far as art is concerned, less has never been as less this.

title: Japan's Tight Controls Keep Guns at a Minimum
description: TOKYO, Sept. 10If Lynette Fromme, who aimed a pistol at President Ford last week, had tried to get a handgun in Japan, she would have found it much tougher than in America.

title: Mrs. Ford, in Letter, Expands on Interview
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)  Following is the text of a letter that Betty Ford sent to Lorena Chevalier of Dallas, who had written to Mrs. Ford after the First Lady said in a television interview that she wouldn't be surprised if her 18yearold daughter told her she was having an affair. The White House said the letter was similar to others sent to persons who had written about her comments.

title: E.F. Hutton Is Sued By Merrill on Hiring
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the nation's No. 1 brokerage house, filed an antitrust suit yesterday against E. F. Hutton & Co., Inc., the nation's second largest broker in sales, asking at least $3million, and accusing Hutton of hiring four Merrill Lynch salesmen and then attempting to lure away 4.000 Merrill Lynch customers.

title: JUDGE WILL NOT JAIL 2 HEARST WITNESSES
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 11 (UPI)A Federal judge rejected today the Government's attempt to jail two reluctant witnesses for their refusal to testify before a grand jury investigating the Patricia Hearst case.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)Union members on three more teams have voted to reject a contract offer by the National Football League owners. This put the total vote at 86810 against accepting the collective bargaining agreement. A spokesman for the N.F.L. Players Association said today's results of the voting by the Chicago Bears, the Houston Oilers and the New York Giants had been received, leaving only the Minnesota Vikings, Philadelphia Eagles and Cincinnati Bengals yet to be counted.

title: Touring Boulez Takes Beethoven Back Home
description: BONN, West Germany, Sept. 11 (UPI)Pierre Boulez conducted the New York Philharmonic today in Beethoven's Seventh Symphony in the composer's hometown, which earned him a standing ovation and eight curtain calls.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: One of these days, when the chips are really down, when New York City has defaulted in what has become an annual disaster, when the market has crashed for keeps, when it costs a dollarmake that fiveto get through a subway turnstile, when the reservoirs are mud flats and the Metropolitan Museum is up for grabs and Lincoln Center has gone pornocome Armageddon on Manhattan, the last relic and defender of the, good old days is going to be some honest little Italian restaurant down in Greenwich Village.

title: HERBERT B. KRAMER
description: Herbert B. Kramer, senior partner in the law firm of Roe & Kramer, 444 Madison Avenue, died Thursday at the Harkness Pavilion. He was 52 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Pocket Calculators Reduced in Price By HewlettPackard
description: The HewlettPackard Company said yesterday that effective immediately it had reduced the price of the HP55 scientific pocket calculator from $395 to $335 and the price of the HP45 advanced scientific pocket calculator from $245 to $195.

title: Byrne's Lawyer Seeks 3d Bronfman Abductor
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 11 The lawyer for Dominic Byrne, who is accused with Mel Patrick Lynch of kidnapping Samuel Bronfman 2d, said today that a third person had been involved in the abduction and was beine sought as a witness.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Advertising
description: A number of top agency people around town believe that good advertising and marketing could help the sale of Big M.A.C. Bonds. The Municipal Assistance Corporation, however, has neglected to avail itself of the proffered volunteer help of a few of the best known men in the advertising business.

title: Bundesbank Ordered to Pay German Unit of Hill Samuel
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 11 (Reuters)  The Frankfurt Civil Court ruled that the Bundesbank must pay Hill Samuel & Co., O.H.G., the German subsidiary of Hill Samuel & Co., Ltd., $3.9million damages over the closure of Bankhaus I. a Herstatt, K.G.A.A. in June last year, a court official announced today.

title: City and Senior Police Officers Arrive at Accords
description: The city and various groups of superior police officers reached agreement yesterday on ne wcontracts, dating back to July 1, 1974, and providing for retroactive pay increases for the first year ranging from $1.500 to $1,675.

title: Memorial Services
description: LAVINEdwin. Memorial servier Monday, Sept. 15, ?? at 3, at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Ave. at 53d St.

title: Genya Ravan Evokes Joplin Manner
description: Genya Ravan, who is at Reno Sweeney, 126 West 13th Street, has had a variegated past. Her first major public appearance was as the lead singer of a group called Goldie and the Gingerbreads, one of the first women's rock bands. She reappeared between 1969 and 1971 as the singer in a jazzish rock band called Ten Wheel Drive, and after that she made appearances and records as a solo artist, under her original name of Goldie Zelkowitz and as Genya Ravan.

title: Auto Mechanic Finds Pipe Bomb No Problem
description: MADISON TOWNSHIP, Sept. 11 (AP)An auto mechanic who found a pipe bomb under the hood of his car used a technique he pick up while watching television to disconnect the explosive.

title: The Gun Is Pointed, Miss Fromme Says; Judge Ejects Her
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 11  Lynette Alice Fromme, appearing for arraignment on an indictment accusing her of attempting to assassinate President Ford, was removed from a courtroom today after she told a Federal judge: The gun is pointed, your honor, the gun is pointedwhether it goes off is up to you.

title: M.A. C. Seeks $610Million City Requires Next Week
description: Working under extreme pressure, the Municipal Assistance Corporation moved yesterday to put together a multifaceted package of financing arrangements designed to speed $610million to the city for its cash needs next week.

title: GoldmanCase Grand Jury Checks on Payoff Charge
description: A special state grand jury is investigating whether Irving Goldman funneled $100,000 from the Shubert Foundation, which he headed, to pay off top Transit Authority police officials to protect his vending machines in the city's subway system.

title: N.B.A. Told Players Will Go to Camps
description: The waiting by National Basketball Association owners, general managers and coaches as to whether players will report to training camp is over. The N.B.A. Players' Association decided yesterday to attend the training camps on schedule, despite the absence of a new contract with the owners.

title: TV Is Forging a New Format Ailing A. M. America on ABC
description: A.M. America, which began last January as ABCTVs entry in early morning news and information programing, is undergoing substantial changes and, on Oct. 27, will assume a new format and introduce a largely new cast of personalities, Frederick S. Pierce, president of ABC Television, said Yesterday in an interview.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) /4/0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: ARMY SAYS CALLEY WILL BE ON PAROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) The Army said today that it would not attempt to put former Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. back under custody despite an appeals court ruling reinstating his My Lai conviction.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 6%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.16billion, up 6 per cent from the yearearlier $1.1billion. Total retail store sales were about $11.53billion up 6 per cent from last year's $10.86billion.

title: City Seeks to Block U S. Plan for Tolls on Bridges
description: Mayor Beame directed the Corporation Counsel yesterday to take legal action to prevent Federal environmental officials from forcing the city to impose tolls on the East and Harlem River bridges.

title: India Frees Two Americans After Reducing Spying Count
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 11 (UPI) Two former San Francisco taxi drivers, jailed for two and a half years on charges of spying, left for home today after pleading guilty to lesser charges of narcotics smuggling.

title: Final Approval Is Granted For Memorex Settlement
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 (AP)Final approval has been given to a settlement awarding $3.6million to more than 20,000 persons who bought Memorex Corporation stock at allegedly inflated prices.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: AGREEMENT FAILS ON A PLAN TO END TEACHERS' STRIKE
description: A plan to end the crippling teachers' strike fell apart yesterday when the agreement became bogged down over what the Board of Education contends were matters of substance in its expected public announcement and the union says were merely matters of wording.

title: Israelis Attack Lebanon
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 11Israeli planes struck at southern Lebanon this afternoon.

title: SIR DENYS LOWSON, BRITISH FINANCIER
description: LONDON, Sept. 11Sir Denys Lowson, a former Lord Mayor of London and one of the richest and most controversial financiers in Britain, died last night. He was 69 years old.

title: IMETAT DEFENDS ITS STOCK OFFER
description: Guy de Rothschild, chairman of Socit Imetal of Paris, which has made a tender offer totaling $111million for the Copperweld Corporation, defended the offer yesterday in a letter to Representative John H. Dent chairman of the Congressional Labor Standards subcommit.

title: EXPOSURE ORDERED FOR NIXON'S TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)The Senate ordered today the broadest possible public exposure of 42 million documents collected by the Nixon Adminst ration.

title: Strife Eases in North Lebanon as Army Moves In
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 11Opposition from leftist leaders in the embattled city of Tripoli today delayed the deploying of army troops in a buffer zone east of the city.

title: In Memoriam
description: SCHWATIrving H. Sept. 12, 1974. Death can ne?? separate those bound by tics of true love.

title: Soviet GrainStabilizing Talks Begin
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 11  A threeman American delegation arrived in Moscow today to begin negotiating for a longterm agreement to stabilize Soviet purchases of American grain.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein, Mrs. Larkin Gain
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 11 Mrs Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks and Mrs. Vincent Larkin of the National Country Club moved into the final round today in the fifth Women's Long Island matchplay championship at the National Course.

title: The Militant Doves
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  In the next couple of weeks, Secretary of State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko of the Soviet Union will be meeting both in Washington and New York in a new effort to control the arms race.
