title: Carey Puts 3 Executives On Fiscal Control Board
description: Governor Carey appointed three wellknown business executives yesterday to round out the new Emergency Financial Control Board and immediately called the first meeting of the board in its mission of trying to repair the city government's financial structure.

title: City Rules Governing Rent Are Held Unconstitutional
description: A Brooklyn Civil Court judge has ruled that the city's rent regulations, which affect 1.5 million apartments, are unconstitutional as they are currently being administered.

title: Terror in Colombia
description: Assassination of the inspector general of the Colombian Army on the streets of Bogot is a grim reminder that both urban and rural terrorism persist this important Andean country despite the imposition of modified martial law. The murder of Gen. Ram6n Rincn Quiones, evidently related to his vigorous pursuit of guerrillas in northern Colombia, comes five weeks after the kidnapping in Bogot of an American business executive, Donald E. Cooper, from whom nothing has been heard.

title: Mrs. James McGranery, 67. A Lawyer in Capital, Dead
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 11Mrs. James P. McGranery, a lawyer, civic leader and widow of the Attorney General under President Harry S. Truman, died here on Tuesday in Georgetown University Hospital. She was 67 years old.

title: Hans Swarowsky, 75, Dies; Conductor Was a Teacher
description: VIENNA, Sept. 11 (AP) Hans Swarowsky, a conductor, died yesterday after spending several weeks in a Salzburg hospital with inflammation of the lungs, the Austrian news agency A.P.A. reported. He would have been 76 years old next Tuesday.

title: WILSON BAKER, 60. SHERIFF IN SELMA
description: SELMA, Ala., Sept. 11 (AP)Wilson Baker, the sheriff of Dallas County and Selma's public safety director in the turbulent civil rights demonstrations of 1965, died of a heart ailment today. He was 60 years old.

title: A STRIKE IS CALLED AT SPRUCE FALLS
description: A strike was called yesterday, to begin this afternoon, at the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, Ltd., a Canadian newsprint producer in which The New York Times Company owns a 49.5 per cent interest.

title: MEDICAID FRAUD CHARGED UPSTATE
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 11The former owner of a Rochester nursing home was indicted to on charges of stealing $363.000 in Medicaid funds through the home.

title: Arthur H. Sloggatt, 58, Dies, Mirror Editorial Cartoonist
description: Arthur Hastings Sloggatt, editorial cartoonist for The New York Mirror until its closing and a widely syndicated artist whose work appeared in more than 30 newspapers through the Universal Press Syndicate and Hearst Headline service, died Wednesday in Harkness Pavilion. He was 58 years old and lived in Merrick, L.I.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: How Schools AgreementWas Achieved and Lost
description: At 9 A.M. yesterday the B??ard of Education was expected to announce an understanding it had reached three hours earlier with the United Federation of Teachers for a ceasefire in the school strike.

title: Lockheed Consulted Embassy on Agent
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11Correspondence of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation released by a Senate subcommittee today shows that the company consulted the American embassy in Indonesia in an effort to select a sales agent with influence with the Indonesian Government.

title: About New York
description: There are certain myths about New York that just will not go away. For instance, there's the image of the New Yorker as a cosmopolitan person who knows which side is up when the chips are down, a citizen who can drop in any place take over, so watch out for hire.

title: Mrs. Ruckelshaus Says a Woman Should Preside at G.O.P. Parley
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Jill Ruckelshaus, former counselor to President Nixon and a leading Republican feminist, called on her party today to chose a woman to chair its Presidential nominating convention, as Democratic officials have already agreed to do.

title: Concert
description: The great mass culture heroine of 19thcentury America was Jenny Lind. The Swedish nightingale, as she was known, had a reputation that was shrewdly fostered by P. T. Barnum, the great showman. He was her manager, and when she arrived in this country in 1850, she was greeted at dockside by thousands. They gathered in front of her hotel, where she was serenaded by firemen's hands. Her appearance inspired skits and burlesques in the theater and one of the more notable was She's Come! Jenny's Come! The climax of this furor, of course, was her debut concert on Sept. 11 at Castle Garden, now Castle Clinton, at the Battery.

title: Stage: Absent Friends
description: LONDONIn the theater, is there a specific diffrence between British and American humor? Well, of course, the usual answer given is that American comedy tends to be more verbal, whereas the British favor comedies and farces more of situation and character.

title: Indians Release Journalist Jailed During Crackdown
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 12 (AP)The Indian Government today released a leading journalist, Kuldip Nayar, the first promment person known to have, been freed since Prime Minister Indira Gandhi began arresting Government opponents on June 26.

title: DIAMOND ABSOLVED OF ANY WRONGDOING
description: ALBANY, Sept. 12State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today that there was no evidence of criminality in the use of state trust funds in 1972 by a member of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's Cabinet.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: On the basis of information supplied by the Hygrade Food Products Corporation, it was reported incorrectly in The New York Times yesterday that Richard T. Berg resigned earlier this week from Hygrade to become chief executive officer of Wilson & Co. Mr. Berg is the new executive vice president of Wilson. Kenneth J. Griggy is Wilson's president and chief executive officer.

title: CHAMPLIN SELLING NORTH SEA HOLDING
description: The Champlin Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of the Union Pacific Corporation, announce& yesterday that a definite agreement had been signed for the cash sale of its interest in British North Sea oil exploration. The purchaser of the interest, which is located in Block 211/18 in the British North Sea northeast of Scotland, is the Deutsche Erdolversorgunsgesellscharft G. m. b. H.Deminex, a West German company.

title: Dr. Frithiof Borgeson, 76, Taught at N.Y.U. 37 Years
description: Dr. Frithiof Borgeson, a member of the faculty of the New York University School of Education for 37 years, died Thursday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old and had lived in Harwich Pines, Mass., since his retirement in 1966.

title: Lockheed Documents Disclose A $106Million Saudi Payout
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12From 1970 through mid1975, the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation paid or committed $106million in agents' commissions in Saudi Arabia alone, according to company documents that have been released by a Senate subcommittee.

title: 4,500 Teachers to Be Laid Off in Month
description: The Board of Education released figures yesterday showing that 4,542 teachers and supervisors have been, or are scheduled to be, laid off this month because of budget cuts.

title: Art: Kolar Recycles Poetry Into Collages
description: We are, it seems, to have something of a Czechoslovak season at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum this fall. A few weeks henceon Oct. 10we shall have the opening of a large retrospective exhibition of the work of the Czechoslovak painter Frantisek Kupka 18711957), one of the pioneer figures in the early history of abstract art. This eagerly awaited eventthe first major survey of Kupka's art to be mounted in Americawill be preceeded by a sizable show of the work of Jiri Kolar, perhaps the foremost of living Czechoslovak artists. This exhibition, consisting of nearly 300 items, opened yesterday, and will remain on view at the Guggenheim, Fifth Avenue at 88th Street, through Nov. 16.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Mario Iavicoli, a lawyer who is the stale's key witness in the trial of James Joyce, Camden County Democratic Chairman, on charges of bribery, testified that Mr. Joyce twice sought a payoff in exchange for favors. Mr. Joyce, who also is vice chairman of the Camden County Municipal Authorities, is charged with seeking $175,000, in bribes from Mr. Iavicoli in return for dropping litigation against a concern the attorney represented, and for favorably awarding a $5million sewerage contract.

title: Treasury Bills' Yields Advance at Auctions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: MILFORD H. CORBIN
description: Milford H. Corbin, president from 1949 to 1957 of StandardToch Chemicals, Inc., died Thursday apparently of a heart attack. He was 74 years old and lived at 860 Fifth Avenue.

title: U.S. WILL HALT AID TO CITY DRUG UNIT
description: Federal officials have decided to cut off financing of the city's Addiction Services Agency, citing mismanagement and excessive administrative costs.

title: Paris to Pay $2Million To Kidnappers in Chad
description: PARIS, Sept. 12 (AP)The Government announced today that it was ready to pay $2.2million in ransom for a kidnapped Frenchwoman held by Moslem rebels in northern Chad for 16 months.

title: Article 1  No Title
Haledon Teachers Return
description: HALEDON, Sept. 12Teachers in the Manchester Regional, High School reached agreement on a oneyear contract at 3 A.M. today, clearing the way, for the reopening of the school this morning after a threeday strike.

title: Close of Special Session At the U.N. Is Delayed
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 12The close of the specall session of the General Assembly was delayed today by disagreements between industrial and developing nations.

title: Refugee's Early Fortune Turns to Trouble
description: CAMAS, Wash.  Within hours of landing here last spring among the first of 130,000 South Vietnamese refugees to seek new homes in the United States, Nguyen Dinh Tri had found a job, earned his driver's license and purchased a used car.

title: GERTRUDE DRISCOLL, CHILD PSYCHOLOGIST
description: Dr. Gertrude P. Driscoll, professor emeritus of education at Teachers College, Columbia University, died Thursday after a long illness at the Medford Leas retirement colony in Medford, N. J. She was 77 years old and except for the last three years had lived on Cape Cod following her retirement in 1963.

title: COMMUNISTS GET NATO INVITATION
description: BONN, Sept. 12  If their governments agree, military observers from the Soviet Union and other Communist countries of Europe will be able next month, for the first time, to watch a series of exercises by troops of the United States, Canada and West Germany.

title: TV Review
description: Irwin Allen's Swiss Family Robinson has less to do with the Johann Wyss novel than with creating situations for special effects. What Irwin Allen, the producer, hath wrought for the films The Poseidon Adventure and The Towering Inferno he is now attempting to inflict on television, using a scale suitably reduced for the small screen. The result transforms what is supposed to be a shipwrecked Swiss family struggling for survival on a tropical island into allAmerican mannequins getting back to nature and roughing it in a setting that could be Malibu or Nantucket. All of this is seasoned lightly with minidisasters.

title: Farm Union Leads Teamsters In Coast Bargaining Elections
description: DELANO, Calif., Sept. 12As the first week of elections for farm labor union representation neared a close today, the United Farm Workers had won 22 elections and the rival teamsters union 13.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein Wins Golf Final
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 12 Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks successfully defended her women's Long Island matchplay golf championship today at Nassau Country Club. She defeated Mrs. Vincent Larkin of the home club, 7 and 5, in the 36hole title match.

title: Mutch Victor On Magic Dust
description: GREENVALE, L. I., Sept. 12With Ronnie Mutch riding, Jackie Strumph's Magic Dust won the local working hunter championship today at the Nassau County horse show.

title: Arson Laid to ExRochester Fire Chief
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 12Joseph J. Nalore, who served as chief of the Rochester Fire Department for four years, and three underworld figures here have been arrested on arson charges stemming from a fire that destroyed the warehouse of a suburban tire company in 1971.

title: Article 4  No Title
A State Financing Agency Warns It Faces Bond Crisis
description: In the latest aspect of the government credit crisis, the state's Housing Finance Agency has turned to Governor Carey for emergency assistance to deal with its own mushrooming problems in the borrowing market.

title: Detente Built on Human Rights Instead of Diplomatic Rites
description: Almost lost amidst the diplomatic backslapping that accompanied the recent Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, in Helsinki, was Leonid I. Brezhnev's stern warning against interference in the internal affairs of his country and its friends.

title: Strikes in Canada Curb Newsprint Output 33%
description: Strikes in the Canadian newsprint industry, which began on a limited scale in July, have now spread to the extent that almost a third of that country's capacity has been shut down. The Canadian industry exports about 90 per cent of its newsprint to newspapers in the United States.

title: TWO SENATORS SUED FOR $360,000 FARES
description: American Airlines yesterday sued Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, and the estate of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, for nearly $360,000, United Press International reported.

title: Blade and Blather
description: I am shaving and it worries me. It has become so complicated. Not like the old days when you smeared a little soap on the jowls, lifted a razor and scraped your face. Nowadays you don't have a razor anymore. You have a shaving system. I am always nervous in the presence of systems, and people keep interrupting with bulletins from the television set.

title: A. ALAN GROSSMAN
description: ROCKLAND, Me., Sept. 12A. Alan Grossman, Knox County Judge of Probate since 1960, and the first chief justice of the Maine Probate Judges Assembly, died at his home here yesterday. He was 64 years old.

title: ROBERT F. ARDREY
description: Robert F. Ardrey, senior executive director of the Children's Specialized Hospital in Mountainside, N.J., died Thursday at the Elizabeth (N.J.) Genjeral Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 55 Duncan Hill Road, Westfield, N.J.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Kupferman Marries Fran Liner
description: Associate Justice Theodore R. Kupferman of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday afternoon married Fran Liner, executive vice president of Projects Plus, Inc., a fundraising concern that creates and directs special events for charitable organizations.

title: Campaign Against Noise in the State Falters for Lack of Funds and Outcry
description: NEWARKA once highly publicized campaign against noise in New Jersey, which both residents and transients consider one of the most earsplitting states in the union, has quietly dropped into the lowest priority for antipollution programs.

title: BEAME APPOINTS A DEPUTY MAYOR FOR CITY FINANCES
description: Kenneth S. Axelson, a senior vice president and director of the J.C. Penney departmentstore chain, was appointed as the city's Deputy Mayor for Finance by Mayor Beame yesterday.

title: TransitBond Issue
description: TRENTON, Sept. 12In view of rejection of large transportationbond issues in past New Jersey referendums, the issue proposed last month by Governor Byrne was no given much of a chance of winning voter approval in November, and Mr Byrne knew it.

title: City's New Deputy Mayor
description: When Kenneth strong Axelson was growing up on the South Side of Chicago, he held the dismal view of New York City so widely shared by residents of the nation's second city. But now that I'm a resident of this side of the Hudson River, the city's new Deputy Mayor for Finance said yesterday, things look different to me.

title: TV: All the Entertainer
description: Howard Cosell's Saturday Night Live weekly series doesn't begin on ABC until next Saturday at 8 P.M., but Cosell followers can see their curious hero tonight at 8 o'clock on The Muhammad Ali Variety Special. The sportscaster briefly joins the boxing champion to resume one of the more successful acts in show business.

title: Orange County Again Halts Relief Bill
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., Sept. 12For the second time in 30 days, the Orange County Legislature has rejected a bill that would have provided $5.5million to maintain welfare services in the county through the end of the year.

title: Wilt's View of the Holzman Barrier
description: As inconspicuously as possible for a 7foot1inch impresario, Wilt Chamberlain had stopped by the New York Knicks' office for a quick social hello yesterday and now he was waiting for an elevator that would take him upstairs to the Madison Square Garden arena floor. He was there to promote his role as the coach of the American women's volleyball team that will appear in the Garden tomorrow. When the elevator doors opened, Wilt stepped back as two husky workmen struggled to wheel a heavily loaded dolly into the corridor. On the dolly were 10 big cartons of envelopes. For perhaps a minute the workmen pushed and pulled, trying, to get the wheels of the dolly across the uneven slit between the elevator and the floor. Huffing and puffing, they nally dropped their hands in frustration. You look, Wilt said, like you need a little help. His massive arms unencumbered by a chocolate sleeveless shirt, he reached down. grabbed the rope attached to the dolly and lifted the load into the corridor as if it had been a baby in a stroller. The workmen stared and thanked him. Wilt smiled, entered the elevator and the doors closed.

title: Frederick Elfers, U. S. Aide In Africa, Is Killed in Crash
description: Frederick D. Elfers, deputy chief of mission at the United States Embassy in Tananarive, Madagascar, since June was killed Wednesday in an automobile accident while returning from Nairobi. He was 38 years old.

title: Groh Acts to Clean Up City As Demanded by Mayor
description: Still smarting from a tonguelashing by Mayor Beame, Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh moved yesterday to implement the Mayor's order that he clean up the city streets in 10 days. He reassigned all 11 borough commanders, three assistant superintendents and a district supervisor.

title: DOLLAR IN GAINS; GOLD PRICE DROPS
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 12 (UPI)The dollar advanced on European markets today, hitting 11month highs in Frankfurt and Amsterdam. The price of gold dropped to its lowest price in almost a year on the London bullion market.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two fire bombs were hurled into the rear of a policeman's house in the Bronx early yesterday morning, but caused only minor damage and no injuries. The officer, Robert J. DeBrino of 4310 East Tremont Avenue, had been threatened on Monday, and the police are investigating a possible connection with a case in which Officer DeBrino has been testifying. The police refused to identify the case for fear, they said, of prejudicing a possible prosecution.

title: LIBYAN ROLE SEEN IN LEBANON STRIFE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The Libyan Government of Col. Muammar elQaddafi has sent tens of millions of dollars to Lebanon in the last six months to support leftist Moslem groups battling Christian forces in that country, United States officials said today.

title: Price of Times to Be 25c Outside 50Mile Radius
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that effective Monday it will increase the price of its weekday issues to 25 cents from 20 cents outside a radius of 50 miles from the city, except on Long Island, where the price will remain at 20 cents.

title: Ridgefield H.S. Band Parades in Venezuela
description: BARQUISIMETO, Venezuela, Sept. 12 (UPI)The Ridgefield, N.J., High School band paraded in front of President Carlos Andres Perez today at the opening of the ninth annual Divine Shepherdess fair in this agricultural center.

title: TERI JAFFE
description: Teri Jaffe, vice president of WAIF, a unit of the Travelers' Aid Society, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 59 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: After being pushed in a wheel chair to his first courtroom appearance since last April, Associate Justice William O. Douglas told newsmen in Yakima, Wash., that despite a crippling stroke, he intended to stay on the Supreme Court as long as the work remains interesting and challenging.

title: Ford Vows Not to Be Hostage to Threats
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12President Ford, defending his frequent plunges into crowds of wellwishers, declared here today that he had no intention of allowing the government of the people to be held hostage at the point of a gun.

title: FELON ADMITS GUILT IN THREAT ON FORD
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif. Sept. 12 (UPI)A convicted felon today pleaded guilty in United States District Court to threatening the life of President Ford three weeks before Lynette Alice Fromme pointed a pistol at Mr. Ford here a week ago.

title: BEAME APPOINTS A DEPUTY MAYOR FOR CITY FINANCES
description: Kenneth S. Axelson, a senior vice president and director of the J.C. Penney departmentstore chain, was appointed as the city's Deputy Mayor for Finance by Mayor Beame yesterday.

title: STEIN CRITICIZES ECONOMIC PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Herbert Stein, the immediate past chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that the program for national economic planning that is being advocated by key Senators, professors and labor and business leaders simply would not work, even if it could be enacted.

title: Antioues: Pottery Clues
description: MORRISVILLE, Pa.Three British pottery experts appearing here this week were able to correct some misconceptions, confirm some suspicions and clarify what until now has been merely guesswork in identifying where and when certain English ceramics were produced.

title: Ailing Mrs. Peron Will Go On Leave
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 12President Isabel Martinez de Pern will take a leave of absence from office, beginning tomorrow, and hand over her duties to the President of the Senate, Italo A. Luder, the Government announced today.

title: Dow Index Off by 3.37 in Light Trading
description: A mild rally attempt in early trading faded yesterday and stock prices posted their fourth consecutive decline in continued light turnover.

title: Council Negotiating for Blacks In Rhodesia Expels an Official
description: LUSAKA. Zambia, Sept. 12 Joshua Nkomo, who headed the Zimbabwe African Peoples Union before it was disbanded, was expelled last night from the African National Council, throwing negotiations on the future of Rhodesia into confusion.

title: Toward War in Ulster
description: Brian Faulkner, former Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, now sees that volatile province hurtling toward civil war, a prognosis recent political developments make it difficult to challenge. The coalition of militant Protestant Unionists in Ulster's constitutional convention has rejected, by a vote of 37 to 1, any sharing of power with the Catholic minority, even in an emergency stopgap government.

title: PARLIAMENT UNION CONDEMNS ISRAELIS
description: LONDON, Sept. 12Representatives from the parliaments of 70 nations that have been meeting here today adopted a resolution calling for total withdrawal of Israel from all occupied Arab territories and condemning her for what it described as acts of repression and violation of human freedoms in those territories.

title: Jerkens Counts on Step Nicely
description: Allen Jerkens scuffed at the ground with a boot, stuck his hands into the pockets of a beige windbreaker and said it would take a miracle for his horse to win.

title: Sihanouk Meets Cabinet
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept 12 (AP)Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Cambodian Head of State, has presided over his first Cabinet meeting since his return Tuesday after five years of e??le in China and said he was very satisfied with the reconaction work Radio Phnom Penh reported today. The broadcast said the Cabinet meeting was held Wednesdayday.

title: Leftist Front in Timor Holds a Victory Celebration
description: DILI, Portuguese Timor, Sept. 11A burst of gunfire echoed and reechoed today through the hot, humid air here as the leftwing Timorese Liberation Front held a victory celebration.

title: Sound Aimed Accurately by New Speaker
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12CBS, Inc., has introduced a new directional loudspeaker with baffles that enable sound to be aimed accurately toward the center of the room, or wherever highfidelity enthusiasts want it. The DVX speaker, which is manufactured by the Electro Music division of CBS in Pasadena, Calif., was invented by Benjamin B. Bauer, vice president and general manager of the CBS Technology Center, Stamford, Conn. He was granted Patent 3,903,989 this week.

title: SEOUL ASKS 5 YEARS FOR RIVAL LEADER
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 12A Government prosecutor demanded a fiveyear prison term today for South Korea's leading opposition figure, Kim Dae Jung. Mr. Kim, charged with violation of election laws, was the opposition Presidential candidate in the 1971 election.

title: Vintage Furniture Traveled Well From French Village to 34th Street
description: The village of FleuryenBiere lies hidden away on a back road about 40 miles south of Paris in the drowsy, lush farm country that the artists of the Barbizon School immortalized during the 19th century.

title: A Week When Fashion City Lived Up to the Name
description: New York, which fancies itself Fashion City in its lighter moments, celebrated fall with a wild burst of fashion shows, entertainments and social gatherings this week.

title: TexasArlington Upsets T.C.U., 247
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Sept. 12 (AP)The University of Texas at Arlington intercepted five Texas Christian passed and upset the heavily favored Horned Frogs, 247, tonight in college football. Texas Christian, of the Southwest Conference, had won five consecutive meetings between the two schools and appeared on their way to another with a quick firstquarter touchdown on Ricky Wright's 2yard run.

title: GovernmentBacked Cooperatives in Guatemala Aiding Indians
description: QUEZALTENANGO, GuatemalaIn the nearby village of Xecam, the little houses now have tiled roofs. Around the town of Cajole., the corn is growing two feet higher than four years ago, and at El Novillero, a new rabbit farm is providing villagers with regular protein for the first time in their lives.

title: U.S. WILL HALT AID TO CITY DRUG UNIT
description: Federal officials have decided to cut off financing of the city's Addiction Services Agency, citing mismanagement and excessive administrative costs.

title: U.S., Britain Tied In Wightman Play
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 (AP) Virginia Wade of Britain and Chris Evert of the United States triumphed as expected tonight and evened the Wightman Cup tennis competition, 11, after two matches.

title: Mel Torme, at 50 Buddy's Place Star, Extends His Range
description: This should be a happy birthday for Mel Torme. The onetime Velvet Fog, was singing with the CoonSanders Orchestra at Chicago when he was 4, acting in radio soap operas at 9, had his first song recorded by Harry James when he was 16, was the drummer in Chico Marx's band when he was 17 and had his own vocal group, the MelTones, when he was 20. He is 50 years old today and, far from burning himself out as a Wunderkind, is still expanding his capabilities.

title: State Housing Unit Sells $52.3Million Note Issue
description: The New York State Housing Finance Agency announced yesterday the negotiated sale of $52.3million of oneyear bondanticipation notes at an interest rate of 9 per cent.

title: 7 Race for Marlboro Cup; Magician in Tough Test
description: Seven top thoroughbreds, all with impressive credentials in stakes races, were tuned up and ready to go yesterday as New York Racing Association officials were awaiting an enthe thusiastic turnout for this afternoon's third running of the Marlboro Cup Invitational. There will be a pot of $250,000 at stake for the 1mile contest that is considered the top handicap event of the year. The winner will receive $150.000, with second place worth $55,000 and third $30,000.

title: Lost and Found in Cab; Briefcase and a Friend
description: When Vincent Ryan, a Boston businessman, left his briefcase containing important papers in a cab here Wednesday he thought he would never see it again.

title: CHILEANS TO FREE ALLENDE MINISTERS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 12 (Reuters)Chile's military Government ordered today the release of three former Cabinet, ministers and nine other members of the civilian government overthrown in the Sept. 11, 1973, coup.

title: City Opera Adds Epilogue For a Magical Hoffmann
description: Tito Capobianco's production of Les Contes d'Hoffmann was greeted warmly when it first appeared at the New York State Theater in October, 1972. But for various reasons the New York City Opera hasn't mounted the work since the spring of 1973, and its reappearance in the repertory Thursday night found it with not only an almost entirely new cast but also with an added scene.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Friday.

title: Recreational and Procreational Sex
description: BALTIMOREThe need for a new ethic of recreational sex is not a luxury or an option. It is an imperative from which there is no escape. Our old ethic is, like Venice, sinking imperceptibly into the sea. We have succeeded neither in shoring up the old customs and morality of sexual relationships nor in restructuring them to meet the new tide of history.

title: Reagan Shuns VicePresidency
description: DALLAS, Sept. 12 (UPI)Mr. Reagan said today that he was not interested in the VicePresidency and would be a candidate for President or nothing in 1976.

title: BRITAIN'S INFLATION HITS RECORD 26.9%
description: LONDON. Sept. 12 (AP)Britain's annual rate of inflation rose last month to a record 26.9 per cent and the country's trade deficit for August was the worst of the year, the Government announced today:

title: C.I.A. AIDES HELD LIABLE FOR CRIMES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) The Justice Department has ruled that whatever immunity they may have enjoyed in the past, Central Intelligence Agency employes will henceforth be subject to Federal prosecution for criminal offenses just as any Federal employe, Senator Charles H. Percy said yesterday.

title: FRED H. PAUL
description: Fred H. Paul, who was treasurer of the Caltex Petroleum Corporation for 21 years until his retirement in 1968, died yesterday in St. Petersburg, Fla., where he lived. He was 68 years old.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Grow Tunneling Corporation, a subsidiary of Alpha Portland Industries, Inc., has been named sponsoring contracter in a $29.7million contract for sewer work on Staten Island, by the department of water resources of New York City's environmental protection agency.

title: For the Arizona Cattleman's Family, School Was School, And Home Was School
description: Y FATHER had a way of commanding obedience from his children. He said, I'll keep you home from school. In the first decade of this century our school was a oneroom, allgrades affair, three miles from our cow ranch in the Sierra Ancha mountains in central Arizona. The school was not alluring in its offerings. Suppressed by drab walls, it was dominated by the heating stove. Squatted like a fat toad, its pot belly belched when the teacher opened its glowing mouth to feed in mesquite wood. Pupils sitting near it suffered in stinging heat. Desks a few feet away were curtained by the cold, and their occupants studied in a cloak of goose bumps.

title: A Once Troubled School In Boston Is Now Tranquil
description: BOSTON, Sept. 12Daniel Kearns, a strapping, freckled man who has seen much in his 22 years with the Boston public schools, was gazing over the sixthgrade assembly. The sea of little faces spread before him looked like a Seurat canvas, hundreds of tiny colored dotsblacks, browns, tans, white, yellows.

title: Turner, Key Trudeau Aide, Withdraws From Cabinet
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 12 (AP)Finance Minister John J. Turner, long regarded as the heir to Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's post, has left the Cabinet, in what could foreshadow a major reorganization.

title: CAR IN HOFFA CASE TO BE HELD BY U.S.
description: DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP)A car belonging to the son of a reputed Mafia figure, which the Federal Bureau of Investigation believes may have been used in the apparent abduction of the former International Brotherhood of Teamsters union president, James R. Hoffa, will remain in the custody of the Government, a judge ruled today.

title: LIBYAN ROLE SEEN IN LEBANON STRIPE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The Libyan Government of Col. Muammar elQaddafi has sent tens of millions of dollars to Lebanon in the last six months to support leftist Moslem groups battling Christian forces in that country, United States officials said today.

title: Upper or Downer?
description: With everything at a permanent low in City Hall and nowhere to go but up. the only thing that seems be doing so is an elevatorintended to take the body politic from the basement to the second floor. This will cost $26,524 for plans and another $250,000 to build, which is hardly an austerity in these pennypinching times. Most of the money is expected to come from a Federal grant for the handicapped; accommodations for the handicapped are commendable, but the interior of City Hall is still unprotected from the architectural onslaughts of successive administrations. This one, to its credit, has been trying to restore both history and order.) A ludicrously delayed landmark designation is scheduled to come shortly.

title: 102 IND and BMT Runs To Be Dropped in January
description: The elimination of 102 daily train trips on IND and BMT subway lines, beginning Jan. 11, was announced by the Transit Authority yesterday.

title: THEFT OF F.B.I. FILES BRINGS 9YEAR TERM
description: NEWARK, Sept. 12 (UPI)John Digilio, a reputed underworld boss, convicted on charges of masterminding a plot to steal files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on his suspected loansharking operation, was sentenced today to nine years in prison and fined $10,000.

title: NEWS GUILD BALKS AT PROFESSIONAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12At hearings before the National. Labor Relations Board today, the Newspaper Guild argued that if reporters, editors and cartoonists were separated from other newspaper employes in labor negotiations it would virtually destroy the collective bargaining relationship and practices in the news media.

title: Able Nathan Asks Flowers for Egypt
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 12Israelis streamed to the waterfront here today with flowers for the people of Egypt.

title: A Prisoner Is Slain And 10 Wounded In Tennessee Riot
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 12 (AP)One inmate is dead of stab wounds, and state officials said that 10 other inmates were shot by guards in a riot at the Tennessee State Prison. An additional 26 personstwo of them guardswere injured.

title: Peking Summer: Fun Is Scarce
description: PEKING, Sept. 12Summer in downtown Peking is a testament to boredom. A policeman quietly trying to sort out a minor bicycle accident quickly draws a crowd of 25 to 50 people. A conversation between a policeman and a foreigner seeking directions will draw many times that number. The bolder excitementseekers sit along the driveway leading into the Peking Hotel and watch the comings and goings of all those strangelooking foreigners.

title: ExMavor Heads Lottery
description: TRENTON, Sept. 12 (AP)Former Mayor Henry Luther of ParsippanyTroy Hills took the oath of office today as director of the state lottery.

title: Bogota Holds 80 Students
description: BOGOTA, Colombia Sept. 12 (Reuters)Troops and police arrested SO Colombian students trying to demonstrate here last night against the Chilean military's overthrow of President Salvador Allende Gosseas two years ago.

title: People and Business
description: The financially troubled Singer Company announced yesterday that Donald P. Kircher, its 60yearold president and chairman, has taken an indefinite leave of absence from the company because of ill health.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: 25Mile Park Planned Along Whippany River
description: MORRISTOWN, Sept. 12 (UPI)The State Conservation Foundation announced plans today for a 25mile park, including cycling and hiking trails, that will run along the Whippany River through six communities.

title: Market Place
description: It is widely believed that major banks concentrate their stock protfolios in a few favored holdings. Yet a computer study just out clearly indicates that there is no uniform pattern of limited investment horizons among the nation's leading Federally chartered banks.

title: CENTERS FOR AGED FREE OF FUND TEST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 12The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has agreed not to limit use of certain federally supported senior citizens' centers to the poor or near poor, for at least six months.

title: CRIMINAL CHARGES URGED BY A JUDGE IN TEACHER STRIKE
description: A state judge yesterday found Albert Shanker and other teachers' union leaders in willful violation of a nostrike court order, but held off imposing penalties, including a possible 30day jail term, until Tuesday in an apparent attempt to get stalled settlement efforts moving again.

title: Questionable Payments Being Studied by Merck
description: Merck & Co., one of the world's largest drug houses, said yesterday that a few Merck people had been involved in questionable payments to employes of foreign governments.

title: 102 IND and BMT Runs To Be Dropped in January
description: The elimination of 102 daily train trips on IND and BMT, subway lines, beginning Jan. 11, was announced by the Transit Authority yesterday.

title: Carey Appoints Hoey to Study PoliceD.A. Conflict in Suffolk
description: Governor Carey formally announced the appointment of Joseph P. Hoey yesterday as: special deputy attorney general to investigate both the Suffolk County District Attorney and the Suffolk Police Commissioner.

title: President Bars House Unit From Seeing Secret Data
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 President Ford ordered today; that the House Select Committee on Intelligence he cut off from all classified documents, and he forbade Administration officials to testify before the committee on classified matters. He also demanded the return of classified material now in the committee's hands.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: MELVILLE F. DAVIDOW
description: Melville F. Davidow, who retired in 1967 as vice president of Davidow Suits, Inc., manufacturer of women's suits and sportswear, died yesterday at a nursing home in Fairfield. Conn. He was 86 years old and lived at 936 Fifth Avenue.

title: Dolphins Develop Fan Lag
description: Suddenly, the Miami Dolphins seem to be just another pro football team again.

title: Mother Seton's Day Will Be His, Too
description: ROME, Sept. 12  Carl Kalin, 73 years old, spry and an avid golfer, was in Rome today, sightseeing with his wife, Anne, walking the streets and still somewhat bewildered by what happened to him 12 years ago.

title: Ford Vows Not to Be Hostage to Threats
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12President Ford, defending his frequent plunges into crowds of wellwishers, declared here today that he had no intention of allowing the government of the people to be held hostage at the point of a gun.

title: Evidence Theft Is Laid to Crime Force
description: NEWARK, Sept. 12  The United States Attorney's office here disclosed today that it had ordered an investigation into charges that Federal agents and lawyers for United States Organized Crime Strike Forces improperly had obtained evidence they had presented in a milliondollar Federal stock fraud case.

title: U.S. SMASHES RING FOR STOLEN BONDS
description: A plot by organized crime groups to cash in on stolen United States Series E savings bonds has been smashed, according to Federal officials, with the arraignment in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday of four persons on charges of conspiring to forge and cash $250,000 worth of stolen bonds.

title: State Unit Adopts Sesame Formula For Racial Series
description: ALBANY, Sept. 12 (UPI)The State Education Department has adapted Sesame Street and ElectricCompany formula for a new television series aimed at the racial attitudes of elementaryschool pupils.

description: A state judge yesterday found Albert Shanker and other teachers' union leaders in willful violation of a nostrike court order, but held off imposing penalties, including a possible 30day jail term, until Tuesday in an apparent attempt to get stalled settlement efforts moving again.

He also demanded the return of classified material now in the committee's hands.

title: A's Split and Lose Ground to Royals
description: A troika is a Russian sled pulled by three horses and that's how the first three men in the Oakland batting order performed in helping the A's defeat the Minnesota Twins, 114, in the first game of their twilightnight doubleheader at Bloomington, Minn., last night.

description: Through these languid trading days on Wall Street, a campaign of lastditch resistance is building up against the Congressionally mandated reform of the nation's stock exchanges.

description: Joseph J. Nalore, a retired Fre Chief in Rochester and three underworld figures were indicted on arson charges.

description: THE ERICK HAWKINS DANCE COMPANY, ?? toe Hudson Philharmonic, Joel Thome, conducting. Artistic director and choreographer, Erik Hawkins; lighting design, Mark Goodman. At Carnegie Hall.

title: City's New Deputy Mayor
description: When Kenneth Strong Axelson was growing up on the South Side of Chicago, he held the dismal view of New York City so widely shared by residents of the nation's second city. But now that I'm a resident of this side of the Hudson River, the city's new Deputy Mayor for Finance said yesterday, things look different to me.

title: Spain Sentences 3 to Death for Slaying of Policeman
description: MADRID, Sept. 12  Three members of an extremist leftwing group today were sentenced to death by a military court for killing a policeman.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Facing Up to Reality
description: The sudden swing from nearagreement in the teachers' strike negotiations to the present outpouring of pessimism defies all logic and reason. When the Board of Education calls the outlook bleak and union president Albert Shanker says, we're pretty far apart, it appears all too clear that the persistence of fiscal delusions carried over from the old days of backdoor settlements now constitutes the real roadblock to a settlement.

title: On Women as Priests
description: The ordination of four more women as Episcopal priests last Sunday in Washington was less spectacular ?? the priesting of 11 women 13 months ago in Philadelphia, but the latest rite could have some greater implications.

title: Prime Rate Raised To 8% From 7%
description: The First National City Bank of New York, reacting to the sustained upward trend in in terest rates in the credit markets, raised its prime lending rate yesterday to 8 per cent from 7 the highest level since early March.

title: Books of The Times
description: We wept, not because we were frightened but because we were so dirty. This was a veteran of World War I telling about Gallipoli, and here is a very different voice, just before the dismal butchery of the Battle of the Somme:

title: Kallinger's Defense Lawyer Says Client Is Innocent or Was Insane
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 12 (AP)Joseph Kallinger's lawyers opened their case today, saying that Mr, Kallinger was innocent of an alleged fatherson robberybut, they added, even if he had committed the robbery, he would still be innocent on grounds of insanity.

title: AMEX ENDS MIXED IN QUIET TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market finished mixed yesterday in desultory trading.

title: Average Sale Sets Keeneland Record
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 12 (UPI)The fourday 32d annual Keeneland September Yearling Sales ended last night with a total 1,228 horses selling for $11,688,000 at a record average price of $9.318 a head, breaking the previous high of $8,163 set in 1973.

title: The Teacher Dispute
description: The United Federation of Teachers, headed by Albert Shanker, representing 55,000 teachers and 20,000 other employes in the city's 976school system.

description: ROME, Sept. 12  Carl Kalin, 73 years old, spry and an avid golfer, was in Rome today, sightseeing with his wife, Anne, walking the streets and still somewhat bewildered by what happened to him 12 years ago.

title: City Tracking Down $1.2Billion U.S. and State Owe It
description: The Bureau of the Budget has identified, and is now using a computer to track down, $1.2billion in uncollected revenue owed the city by the Federal Government and the state over the last four years.

title: SUSPECT IN HOLDUPS OF HOTELS IS SEIZED
description: An alleged member of a group of armed robbers who got $860,000 in jewels and other valuables in recent holdups at the New York Hilton and Gramercy Park Hotels was arrested on the East Side yesterday, the police said.

title: Cardinals Stop Mets, Not Vail
Redskins Defeat Colts
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 (AP) Billy Kilmer threw touchdown passes of 84 and 2 yards as the Washington Redskins scored 17 paints in the second quarter and trounced the Baltimore Colts, 2410, in an N.F.L. exhibition game tonight.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: ETHNIC STEW Armenian, Philippine, Chinese, Haitian, Israeli, Italian; Polish, Lithuanian, Swedish, Hawaiian, Mexican, Russian and Greek dance groupsamong others will be performing today and tomorrow during the third annual One World Festival at St. Vartan Cathedral, Second Avenue and 35th Street.

title: The Bard: Losing That Pound of Flesh
description: I hope that he that looks upon me will take me without weighing.

title: Schools in Louisville Quiet; Bans on Rallies Are Lifted
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 12 (AP)Most of the remaining restrictions on demonstrations and rallies in Jefferson County were lifted today, and 100 off the 400 state police called in to help control antibusing disturbances last weekend were sent home.

title: Japanese Auto Industry May Curb Sales to Britain
description: TOKYO, Sept. 12 (UPI)Japan's automobile industry is ready to accept a Government request to voluntarily curb automobile exports to Britain, industry sources reported today.

title: Lisbon Reported Planning Slowdown in Socialization
description: LISBON, Sept. 12 Military and political leaders trying to form a new coalition government are reportedly working on an economic nd political program that Isa designed to slow the socialization of Portugal's economy.

title: 2 Charges Dropped In Tax Case on Gift Of Nixon's Papers
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12Two of four criminal charges have been dropped in the case against Frank DeMarco Jr., the lawyer accused of preparing false documents to give former President Nixon a tax advantage on a donation of his VicePresidential papers.

title: Congress Expected to Accept Sinai Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 When the possibility of Americans being sent to Sinai surfaced during recent Middle East negotiations some members of Congress expressed concern over another Vietnam, but so far no significant opposition has developed in Congress to the Administration's request to station 200 Americans in the Sinai passes.

title: Amateur Players Will Make a Big StepFrom White Plains to Ireland
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept 12The majority of the amateur theatrical groups that dot New York's suburban communities are accustomed to performing familiar comedies or musicals before local audiences. Some aspire to dramatic merit and attract regional attention. Tonight, one groupthe Fort Hill Players of White Plainswill move from the community to the international stage.

title: N.C.A.A. Appeals Curb on TeamSize Rule
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12 (AP)The legal fight of Bear Bryant, the Alabama football coach, over National Collegiate restrictions on the size of a traveling team landed in a Federal appeals court today.

title: Lyle Expecting to Become A Former Yankee in 1976
description: Pat Dobson already has made it known he doesn't want to, return to the Yankees next season under the same conditions he played this season. Now two more Yankees have made similar statements, although with different meanings.

title: Chiefs Beat Bills, 97, on 3 Field Goals
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 12 (UPI)Jan Stenerud kicked three field goals of 29, 32 and 40 yards to lead the Kansas City Chiefs to a 97 victory over the Buffalo Bills tonight in the final preseason game for both National Football League teams. Both finished with 33 wonlost exhibition records.

title: Pacific Exchange to Sell 522 More Memberships
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 (Reuters)The Pacific Stock Exchange says its members had approved the sale of 522 additional memberships to provide financing for an options trading facility.

title: Federal Aides Studying Violence in Boston Busing
description: BOSTON, Sept. 12Justice Department officials here are investigating about a dozen incidents of violence in connection with courtordered busing for school desegregation here for possible Federal prosecution.

title: Tomahawks Top Caribous, 2010
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 12 Ted Greves scored five goals, including three in the first period, to tie a National Lacrosse League playoff record as the Long Island Tomahawks routed the Quebec Caribous. 2010, tonight before 3,976 fans at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Italy Planning Countermeasures For French Tax on Her Wines,
description: ROME, Sept. 12 (Reuters)Italy, branding the new French tax on Italian wine imports illegal, decided today to take countermeasures that will be announced after an emergency meeting of the Common Market Commission in Brussels on Monday.

title: NIGERIA DISMISSES 102 MORE OFFICIALS
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 12 (Reuters)Nigeria's new military Government today dismissed 102 federal officials, including five permanent secretaries, in the largest single purge since the country's recent change of government.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: On the basis of information supplied by the Hygrade Food Products Corporation, it was reported incorrectly in The New York Times yesterday that Richard T. Berg resigned earlier this week from Hygrade to become chief executive officer of Wilson & Co. Mr. Berg is the new executive vice president of Wilson. Kenneth J. Griggy is Wilson's president and chief executive officer.

title: Mayoral Revival
description: Thanks, I needed that, says the man in the television commercial after a hard slap in the face. The man might be Mayor Beame, who has been acting much more like a mayor in the week since he agreed to surrender many of his basic powers to a statedominated board than he did in the dazed months during which the city almost slid into default.

title: 136 Leads By Shot In Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Sept. 12 Winds gusting from 2025 miles an hour and difficult pin placements on rolling greens that are tricky to begin with combined today to keep scores relatively high in the second round of the World oven golf tournament.

title: New Regime Blames Mujib for Dacca's Ills
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Sept. 12 (UPI)The new Bangladesh Government says the staggering economic and social situation of the country was the fault of the regime of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, who was assassinated in a coup on Aug. 15.

title: Soybean and Corn Futures Up As Crop Figures Are Lowered
description: Most soybean and corn prices jumped the daily limits on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday on the basis of the lowerthanexpected crop figures for both commodities issued by the Government late Thursday. At the close prices were up the daily limit or within a penny a bushel of the limit.

title: JANET K. BIRD
description: Janet K. Bird, who for some years was coowner of Toby Children's Clothes, a couturier shop here, died Thursday at her home, 20 East 74th Street. She was 70 years old.

title: Failures and Successes: 8 Years of Taylor Law
description: The number of publicemploye strikes since the Taylor Law was passed by the Legislature in 1967 has averaged fewer than 20 a year amid thousands of negotiations in the eightyear period. But the statute's dispute procedures and penalties have failed to prevent major walkouts In some complex and hightly charged situations, such as the current teachers' strike here.

title: Chile Davis Team to Go To Sweden
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 12 (AP)In a surprise decision tonight, Chilean tennis officials announced they will send a team to Sweden next week for the Davis Cup semifinals with that country.

title: Sulzberger Sees Rising Conflict Of Press vs. Courts on Secrecy
description: BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Sept. 12  Arthur O. Sulzberger publisher of The New York Times, said tonight that there was increasing conflict between the government and the judiciary, on one side, and the press, on the other, over the issue of secrecy.

title: Army Nerve Experiments As Late as 1974 Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The former chief of the Army's drug testing program disclosed today that the Army was experimenting on soldiers with a potent, incapacitating psychochemical known as BZ until as recently as later last year. As in the Army's LSD tests, he said, the subjects were never told what they were to receive or exactly how it might affect them.

title: UNREST IN LEBANON REPORTED QUELLED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 12The northern Lebanese towns of Tripoli and Zgharta were reported to he quiet tonight after about 2.000 army troops had settled into a buffer zone between them.

title: Greek Junta's Prison Officials Sentenced on Torture Charges
description: ATHENS, Sept. 12The commander of the prison camp in which political prisoners were tortured during the military dictatorship was sentenced today to 23 years in prison. His predecessor and successor as commandant received sentences of 20 years.

title: Article 3  No Title
C. Towner French, 64, Led Capital Navigation Institute
description: C. Towner French, who served two terms, 1963 to 1965, as president of the Institute of Navigation, died Sunday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 64 years old.

title: Chinese Trade Delegation Ends Visit to New York
description: The toplevel trade delegation that arrived a week ago from China ended a fourday visit to New York yesterday with a group of bankers. The delegation is in the United States for the purpose of learning about the American economy and technology.

title: A Series for Students On TV if Strike Lasts
description: If the New York City teachers' strike continues next week. WCBSTV, Channel 2, plans to broadcast a special program called Score from Monday through Friday until the strike is settled. The program will replace the What's My Line? broadcast from 9 to 9:30 A.M.

title: Prime Rate Raised To 8% From 7%
description: The First National City Bank of New York, reacting to the sustained upward trend in in terest rates in the credit markets, raised its prime lending rate yesterday to 8 per cent from 7 the highest level since early March.

description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company had only an 8 per cent decline in sales in the second quarter ended Aug. 23 despite closing 1,200 stores, or more than a third of all its units this year, Grant C. Gentry, president, told a business meeting here yesterday.
