description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 12President Isabel Martnez de Pern will take a leave of absence from office, beginning tomorrow, and hand over her duties to the President of the Senate, Italo A. Luder, the Government announced today.

title: A State Financing Agency Warns It Faces Bond Crisis
description: In the latest aspect of the government credit crisis, the state's Housing Finance Agency has turned to Governor Carey for emergency assistance to deal with its own mushrooming problems in the borrowing market.

title: New Haven's Mayor Is Upset in Primary
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 12This city's Democratic party organization suffered a stunning upset last night when Frank F. Logue, who was running on an antimachine platform, defeated Mayor Bartholomew F. Guida for the mayoral nomination in the party's primary.

title: Dance: Erick Hawkins
description: Thrilling and joyful are not adjectives much in use in reviews nowadays but nonetheless they are the only words that come to mind in describing Thursday night's concert by the Erick Hawkins Dance Company and the Hudson Valley Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall.

title: Cunningham Opts for Woman Senator
description: The Democratic state chairman, Patrick J. Cunningham, who is likely to play a major role in the selection of a Democratic senatorial candidate next year, says it would be very timely to have a woman senator from New York.

title: Call Girl Supplier Sentenced
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (AP) A woman who told the authorities that she supplied call girls to Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, has been sentenced to 60 days in jail, placed on three years' probation and fined $3,000. Superior Court Judge Joseph J. DiGiuseppe sentenced the woman, Alex Flemming, 42 years old, yesterday. She pleaded guilty last July to pimping and pandering charges.

title: Article 2  No Title
RAPIDAMERICAN REPORTS LOSSES
description: Despite gains from discontinued or tobesold operations in both periods, the RapidAmerican Corporation, a diversified consumer goods company, had losses in both the second quarter and for the first six months of this year. Sales were up in the quarter but were lower for the initial six months.

title: Peru Signs Pact Forming Iron Ore Exporting Group
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 12 (Reuters)  Ambassador Alberto Urzua of Peru signed an agreement here today clearing the way for formal establishment of an Iron Ore Exporting Nations Association.

title: City Tracking Down $1.2Billion U.S. and State Owe
description: The Bureau of the Budget has identified, and is now using a computer to track down, $1.2billion in uncollected revenue owed the city by the Federal Government and the state over the last four years.

title: Decision Reserved On Use of Pensions Of State to Aid City
description: ALBANY, Sept. 12Supreme Court Justice J. Franklin Mahoney of Troy today reserved decision on a lowercourt ruling that it is unconstitutional to use state employe pension funds to keep New York City financially stable.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1975

title: DEMOCRATS SPLIT ON OIL PRICE CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Attempts by Senate Democrats to stretch a proposed interim revival of oil price controls beyond Nov. 1 and restrict President Ford's powers during that period have irritated some Democrats in the House of Representatives, as well as Administration officials.

title: China's National Games Open With a Spectacle
description: PEKING, Sept. 12China began her Third National Games today with one of the most colorful and spectacular displays she has ever staged.

title: Government Urges Checking Accounts For State S. & L.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) The Federal agency that regulates savings and loan associations announced today it is proposing to let statechartered institutions offer checking accounts.

title: ROCKEFELLER BACKS OPTION ON BUSING
description: DALLAS, Sept. 12  Vice President Rockefeller, barnstorming in the South again, said today that he favored giving communities local option on busing to bring about racial integration of schools.

title: Confusing Bargaining
description: The progress of the teachers negotiations during the last 10 days has been reported to the outside world by the two sides who have a stake in what comes out, and by the mediators, who do not. Basically, the accounts that emerged during the strike that developed Tuesday could be pieced together and reconciled to produce an accurate picture of where things stood. But in the last day or so, the signals have become confused and the language contradictor.

title: U.S. to Close an Air Base In Northeastern Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 13 (Reuters)  The United States will pull all its aircraft out of Nakhon Fhanom air base in northeast Thailand, once the command center for the United States air war in Indochina.

title: DISSIDENT MINERS RELEASED BY U.S.
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 13Two dissident members of the United Mine Workers, described as leaders of the wildcat strike that spread into neighboring states and closed West Virginia coal fields for more than a month, have been released from Federal custody here after purging themselves on contempt charges.

title: BRIDGE
description: All bridge players have days when everything seems to go wrong. They are plagued by bidding misunderstandings, losing finesses and bad breaks while their opponents have a golden touch in every area of the game. They begin to feel like the unfortunate Sisyphus, who was condemned by the Greek Gods to push a stone uphill that was fated to roll down again before it reached the top.

title: U.N. GROUP BACKS BAN ON TORTURE
description: GENEVA, Sept. 13 (AP)The United Nations Congress on Crime Prevention and Treatment of Offenders has approved a draft declaration banning torture.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: FORD CHALLENGED ON DEREGULATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The General Accounting Office has challenged the accuracy of a statement by President Ford that the expense of Government regulation and the higher prices charged by monopolistic industries may cost the average American family $2,000 a year.

title: Montclair Is Getting Mozart
description: MONTCLAIRThe seldom heard Divertimento in E Flat for String Trio by Mozart, a, horn trio by Brahms and six works by contemporary American composers will highlight the Montclair Chamber Music Society's second season this fall.

title: Colorado Triumphs
description: BOULDER, Colo. Sept. 13 (AP)David Williams, Colorado's quarterback, and Terry Kunz, fullback, operating behind college football's biggest offensive line, wore down California in the second half and the Buffaloes posted a 3427 victory today.

title: The life and former life of Aisin Gioro P'u Yi
description: Aisin Gioro P'u Yi, the last Emperor of the Ch'ing dynasty, had a truly odd life. Born in 1906, he was named Emperor of China in 1908 when his childless uncle died. Under the control of regents, he reigned until his enforced abdication in 1912. The republicans, however, let him remain in the Forbidden City with a large entourage and a generous allowance, and he was given a traditional imperial education. He was briefly restored to the throne by a warlord in 1917, but his privileges were rescinded in 1924 when Feng YUHsiang forced him out of the palace complex. P'u Yi took refuge with the Japanese, first in their Peking legation, and then in the Japaconcession in Tientsin.

title: Her secrets were every woman's secrets
description: In 1955 when only seven women in 100 used hair coloring (and none of them admitted it), an advertising copywriter named Shirley Polykoff was given the Clairol account. Because she wrote ads the way method actors create characters, she reached into her own life to invent an ad campaign that had emotional truth. And if anyone knew the truth about being blonde, it was Shirley Polykoff.

title: Women's Volleyball at Garden Is Part of a Twin Bill Today
description: Some were too small to play basketball and others were apprehensive about playing contact sports. For those women there was volleyball, a noncontact sport, frequently play ed in highschool gymnasiums, at backyard and beach parties, or wherever there was space to string up a net and field a willing team.

title: Change, Even In Central America
description: MEXICO CITYAn unusual combination of popular movements is transforming Central America from a forgotten mosaic of banana republics into an area of political unrest.

title: Births
description: Brand

title: Ohio State Triumphs, 21 to 0; Penn State and Army Victors
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 13Ohio Slate got revenge today by defeating Michigan State, 210, in their football season opener.

title: Two poets made and dead by war
description: The First World War both killed and made two English poets, Wilfred Owen and Isaac Rosenberg. Ever since their names have stood for a murderous titanism of subject: the poet as a flare, brilliant, shortlived, sacrificial, the voice of crisis. Now the concurrent publication of these first biographies invites us to link their names again. One notices, however, how different the poets were as men, how much the war answered to Owen's needs, how reluctantly Rosenberg acknowledged it.

title: Jolley's Colt Triumphs in Rich Race
description: CHICAGO (AP)  Honest Pleasure broke out of a pack of colts today and captured the $234,000 ArlingtonWashington Futurity at Arlington Park.

title: MRS. A. HARRY MOORE
description: Jennie Moore, the widow of Gov. A. Harry Moore of New Jersey, who died in 1952, died yesterday in the Jersey City Medical Center. She was 89 years old and lived in Jersey City. She leaves a sister, Mrs. F. Raymond Clee.

title: Affectless but effective
description: Warhol speaks! High time too. No contemporary artist has had more, or more contradictory, interpreters. Prophet or observer, pernicious corrupter or satiric reformer, prescient or a puton? Our expectation is that at last Warhol will interpret himself to us. And he does thisby not doing it.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: GEORGE ROGERS, BUILT PIERS HERE
description: George W. Rogers, chairman of the George W. Rogers Construction Corporation, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 575 park Avenue and Easton, Conn.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Two private eyes: Jacob Asch, operating out of Los Angeles, and Milton Milodragovitch, known as Milo, who works in a small town in the Pacific Northwest. Asch already has made an appearance in print, in Arthur Lyons's The Dead Are Discreet, published last year. Now he does his stuff in ALL GOD'S CHILDREN (Mason/Charter, $6.95). Milo is making his first appearance in THE WRONG CASE by James Crumley (Random House, $7.95).

title: Cornelia Brotherton Bride of a Lawyer
description: Cornelia Brotherton, personnel director for the San Francisco office of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, architects, was married yesterday afternoon to Jerome Sapiro Jr., a partner in the San Francisco law firm of Cullinen, Burns & Helmer.

title: Deborah Moody Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Whitson Jarvis Moody of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Engle Moody, to Andrew Bedell Chacos, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Chacos, also of Bethesda. Miss Moody is a senior at RandolphMacon Women's College. Her father is president of the American Security and Trust Company in Washington. Mr. Chacos, a graduate of the University of North Carolina, is with the Treasury Department in Washington. His father is professor of health education at Montgomery College in Rockville, Md.

title: Members of Hare Krishna Are Excluded by Japanese
description: TOKYO, Sept. 13 (Reuters)Japan has barred further members of the Hare Krishna religious sect from entering the country and will not renew the visas of at least 29 missionaries known to have arrived in the past 18 months, the Justice Ministry said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: BUSINESS ROUNDUP

title: Headliners
description: Mr. Spassky Has Been Checkmated

title: Weiskopf leading World Golf on 206
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Sept. 13  Tom Weiskopf, who is playing his best golf since his best season in 1973, shot three straight birdies on the closing holes today to pass Pat Fitzsimons and take the lead on the third day of the $200,000 World open golf tournament.

title: Intervention Urged At Brooklyn College
description: An internal City University memorandum has strongly urged the university's central administration to intervene in a growing crisis at the School of Contemporary Studies, an experimental division of Brooklyn College.

title: Book Ends
description: Saleswise. A month or so ago we reported that business in the bookstores was down in May. Now it turns out that the booksellers' fortunes took a change for the better, beginfling in midJune. According to the American Booksellers Association, which regularly surveys 45 key stores, business in July was up front 5 to 10 per cent over July of last year even 30 per cent in a few stores. The increase was reflected in both unit sales and dollar volume. Although this may be a part of the midsummer 5 per cent increase in retail sales as a whole over last year, the hook sellers also attribute the phenomenon to two hot titles of the season, namely Jaws and Ragtime. Jaws, of course, achieved a second paperback life due to the popularity of the movie (and its accompanying publicity hype). while Ragtime is simply a widely praised hardcover novel that has caught the public fancy. Last summer, the booksellers say, there such books.

title: Offshore Money Fund for Foreigners
description: The oncealmighty American dollar is on its way again, this time as the investment vehicle for the world's first offshore money fund, which is scouting for wellhealed foreign interest in the Middle East and Asia.

title: L.I. RABBI RECASTS KOL NIDRE THEME
description: ELMONT, L.I., Sept. 12Like many of his colleagues, Rabbi Samuel Z. Glaser of the Elmont Jewish Center confronts the challenge of conveying the probing themes of Yom Kippur to a congregation with a loosI ening grasp of Hebrew.

title: Sarah F. Russell to Be Married Next Month to John N. Etchart
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Fortune Russell of Bronxville, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Fortune Russell, to John Newton Etchart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Etchart of Glasgow, Mont.

title: Climatic Changes by Aerosols in Atmosphere Feared
description: Although attention in the debate regarding the role of fluorocarbon aerosol sprays has hitherto focused on public health questions, it has now been proposed that they could alter world climates.

title: Lawyers' Group Presses Fight For More Bilingual Teachers
description: Lawyers for the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund said yesterday that despite the budget cuts and teacher layoffs in the school system, they would continue their court fight to have the Board of Education hire additional bilingual teachers.

title: Oilers Down Bears, 2413
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (UPI) Dan Pastorini drove Houston 82 yards in five plays in the fourth quarter tonight to lead the Oilers to a 2413 victory over the Chicago Bears.

title: Brooklyn Offering Free Dance Class
description: Free classes in modern, exercise and ballet dancing has started at the Brooklyn War Memorial Recreation Center, a spokesman for the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration has announced.

title: Leading State Department Economist Joins Talks at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 13Assistant Secretary of State Thomas O. Enders, the key economist in the State Department, arrived here from Washington today to join in tense consultations between industrial and developing nations in a lastminute search for a consensus.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: EDINBURGH For a teacup, it was quite a storm. At the end of June, I visited London. and finding Britain's Royal Ballet in a large and windy tent in Battersea Park, I went along to see what was happening. I was not precisely entranced by what I saw and used this one performance as an excuse to voice a few discontents about the course the Royal Ballet has been taking in recent years. The article was widely reprinted in excerpts in England, and soon photostated copies of the complete article were being handed around in London dance circles. The tights had hit the fan.

title: St. Louis Downs UConn in Soccer
description: STORRS, Conn., Sept. 13  Larry Hulcer beat the defensive back to the goalmouth and drove in a 7yard shot after a low dribble of 10 yards at 9:12 of the first overtime period to give St. Louis a 21 soccer victory over Connecticut today.

title: Hotels Sprucing Up for the Democratic Convention
description: The 50yearold Roosevelt Hotel, in new red, white and blue decor, is stressing its history as a political headquarters. The Waldorf Astoria is looking forward to welcoming Hubert Humphrey and many other top political guests. Even the owner of the little Wentworth on the West Side is investing in American flags, a fresh paint job and new advertising brochures.

title: Corning, N. Y.: Hometown Absorbs the Shock
description: CORNING, N. Y.High on a hill overlooking this town of 17,000 inhabitants, 40 men and women were gathered at a Ushaped table in the drawing room of the former home of Amory Houghton, retired chairman of the board of the Corning Glass Works.

title: Free Cultural Bus Is Aproved by City
description: A group of Brooklyn edcuational and cultural institutions has received city permission to operate a private bus service to carry 500 staff members and students among the institutions.

title: Horses and girls and Lionel Trilling
description: Benvenuto Cellini tells us that no one under 40 should write the story of his life. Had he read a dozen of the early autobiographies written recently by young people whose names will not be carved on obelisks, prison walls or golden saltcellars, he might have made more of a fuss about his point. Cellini assumed that no one would trouble the reading public with personal details before he had done something splendid. His assumption has not endured. The quest not for glory but for a sensibility is the fashion now, as is a close look at experiences that are not exceptional but common to us all. The trick is to make a real book from the most ordinary material.

title: Homer Wilson 3d Weds Miss Lageman
description: Deborah Victoria Lageman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Lageman of Lloyd Harbor, L.T., was married yesterday afternoon to Homer Bowes Wilson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Jr. of Framingham, Mass.

title: Henry Miller the seer and passionate clown
description: In 1938 Henry Miller showed the owner of the Obelisk Press in Paris an outline he had made for a book about America. Though Miller claimed he had lived out his attachments to his native land, he intended to revisit it one last time, write a book of his impressions, and then pass on to Tibet.

title: Wood. Field and Stream: Tilefishing Up
description: A brilliantly colored, hardfighting, deepwater denizen of the Atlantic coast regarded by many as one of the most palatable marine fishes is gradually gaining attention from sporting anglers, although from off the Northeastern states a long run to sea is required to reach him.

title: 3D MAN WATCHED BRONFMAN PAYOFF
description: When Edgar M. Bronfman paid $2.3million in ransom to rthe kidnappers of his son, Samuel Bronfman 2d, a man other than the two arrested later for the crime was at the scene observing the payoff, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Residents Are Still Angry About Garbage
description: Two days after Mayor Beame's warning to the city's Sanitation Commissioner that his department must either shape up and get the city clean or else ship out. New Yorkers were still complaining. yesterday about reduced garbage pickups, although many noted that the streets and gutters looked cleaner than in recent weeks.

title: The Indians' Manager
description: When the baseball season started, he often joked that his full name had become, Frank Robinson comma the first black manager. He was a sociological curio. He also was a nonsociological slugger. He hit a home run in his first atbat as the Cleveland Indians won their opener. To ease his cerebral decisions, he had hoped to continue to be a productive designated hitter but a painful shoulder ailment has limited him to a .241 average with nine homers and 24 runs batted in, not bad for only 28 hits but nowhere near the usual Frank Robinson output. By necessity, he has had to be more manager than playermanager. Perhaps that has been a blessing because he couldn't depend on his bat to bail out his belfry.

title: F.D.A. Limits Use of Drug in Treatment of Slipped Disks Pending an Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The Food and Drug Administration has put strict limits on the use of a drug called chymopapain pending completion of a scientific study of its value in treating patients suffering problems with vertebral disks.

title: The Fords as Impresarios: Who Plays the White House And Why?
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. One night last May, the President of the United States and the Shah of Iran sat side by side in the East Room of the White House and watched AnnMargret execute a series of sexy, razzledazzle nightclub routines while dressed in a red, white and blue chorusgirl outfit which became briefer and briefer as the evening progressed.

title: Philip Piro Jr., Medical Student, Fiance of Patrice Tavoulareas
description: Mr. and Mrs. William P. Tavoulareas of Sands Point, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patrice Ann Tavoulareas, to Philip Anthony Piro Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Piro of Moorestown, N. J.

title: Testing the Sales Pitch for OutofState Land
description: Most of the thousands of letters received by New York area residents with glowing offers of land in recreational and retirement communities are ignored.

title: The First Casualty
description: Much of the German populace was stunned by the quick ending of World War I. The government had kept it in the dark about reversals, defeat and the need for armistice. Many refused to believe that the causes for the war's end were military. The country had not lost on the battlefield, but was sold out at the top. Ironically, these people would not believe the conquered government, because they had believed too well the losing government. They only called the liars Liars! when they stopped lying.

title: Bell 2510 Loser
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP)Rufus Ferguson scored two touchdowns in the first 12 minutes and sparked the Portland Thunder to a 2510 World Football League victory over the Philadelphia Bell tonight.

title: Music: 15 Songs of Japan
description: A curious program consisting of 15 Japanese songs in the first half and Faure's Requiem in the second was presented Friday night by Toshiaki Kunii, baritone, and the New York Vocal Repertory Chorus led by Leo Warbington.

title: Football and UnionBusters
description: The New England Patriots walked out on strike yesterday while the other players in the National Football League tried to decide whether to follow suit or to instruct their representatives to keep on butting their heads against the stone wall called the National Football League Management Council. Negotiating Committee. Most were expected to choose the latter course not because there any valid reason to believe management wil bargain in good faith but because they prefer almost any alternative, no matte. how unpromising, to a repetition last summer's costly strike.

title: Nemo's Almanac
description: Competitiveness is becoming disreputable, but one of its keenest and more harmless manifestations  the literary competitionis going strong. Among connoisseurs of literary competitions, the most coveted laurel has long gone to firstplace mention in Nemo's Almanac, an English contest published annually in pamphlet form. Nemo was started in 1892, by one Mrs. Larner (whom The Times Literary supplement ?? as an enterprising governess). Over the past four years it has more than tripled its readershipa group constituting the most literate body of obsessivecompulsives in the world.

title: RUSSIAN SPY SHIP SHADOWED BY U.S.
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 13Navy and Coast Guard ships and planes are keeping under constant observation a Soviet intelligence ship that is operating close to the California coast near the Navy's Pacific Firing Range, where its newest, highly classified submarine missiles are being tested.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Events Today
description: Art Show: 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., Emmons and West End Avenues, Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn.

title: Karpov Plays to a Draw In Italian Chess Tourney
description: MILAN, Italy, Sept. 13 (Agence France Presse)Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the world chess champion, drew with Grandmaster Lajos Portisch of Hungary here today in the wourth match of the Milan international chess tournament final to strengthen his chances of victory.

title: Cost of North Sea Oil Upsets British Hopes
description: ABERDEEN, Scotland  The euphoria that erupted in Britain six years ago over the discovery of North Sea oil has evaporated.

title: Why Survive?
description: Something must be done about a society that buries its aged before they are dead, declaring them hopelessly senile or ill, denying them freedom of choice or movement or expression, making simple survival difficult and selffulfillment impossible. We treat our aged shamefully, and we hurry away to avoid the awful humanness of their despair. And unless we can change the attitudes and stereotypes that act to oppress the aged, we too will be treated the same way.

title: World One Ton Sail Taken by Pied Piper
description: NEWPORT, R. L. Sept. 13 A second place in the final 318mile offshore race, a wild, windy affair, gave Pied Piper, skippered by Lowell North of San Diego, Calif., the world championship of the One Ton class today. The race ended this morning when a dozen yachts returned to port after two days and nights at sea in winds which blew up to 35 knots.

title: Letters to The Editor
description: Meters

title: Byrne's Bond Proposal Facing Senate Test
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne's proposal to spur the state's economy by means of a multimilliondollar bond program was reported this weekend to be m serious political trouble.

title: Affirmative Chaos . . .
description: Federal policies toward affirmative action to increase the representation of women and racial minorities in college and university faculties are meeting with stiffening opposition. Instead of creating greater harmony and erasing old injustices, these efforts have given rise to new hostilities and suspicions.

title: Mayor Alioto Planning Active Role at Democratic Convention as Elective Career Appears at End
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 After seven and a half years. the last hurrah approaches for Mayor Joseph L. Allow, barred from seeking reelection, with the taste of his latest labor settlement still bitter on the taxpayers' tongues.

title: Unemployment Insurance for Employers
description: Many plans have been advanced to get the unemployed back to work sooner than the Ford Administration's programs now envisage. All run up against a common objection they presume sharply higher Government spending (or its equivalent, the forgoing of tax revenues), raising the specter of reinvigorated inflation.

title: Private, Antibusing Passion but Public Moderation
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  What might have happened in Richmond and in Detroit, but did not, has happened in Louisville. The divide has finally been crossed: Black children are riding buses from the inner city to the suburbs, and white children are riding them the opposite way, to achieve overall racial balance in the schools of a major metropolitan area.

title: Shanker, a Skilled Negotiator, Faces a Straightforward Rival
description: In at least one sense, Albert Shanker is a man who knows how to put his best foot forward. In the six weeks of negotiations with the school board, the teachers' union leader has shown a knack for knowing just what offers to present first to the other side, encouraging them into a receptive mood, then hitting with his hard demands.

title: Cosmos Lose in Rome
description: ROME, Sept. 13The New York Cosmos concluded their European tour at the Olympic Stadium tonight, losing to Roma. 31. Pel, who had scored six goals in the last three games on the tour was held scoreless before a crowd of 49,700.

title: Hearing Made More Difficult by Phone
description: People with hearing problems have used the telephone with relative ease for years, thanks to electromagnetic leakage on the lines that allowed hearing aids to pick up conversations only.

title: Dr. Joseph Alexander Dead at 77; Lung Expert, AllAmerica Guard
description: Dr. Joseph Alexander, a specialist in the study and treatment of lung diseases and a member of the National Football Hall of Fame, died at nome Friday. He was 77 years old and lived at 451 West End Avenue.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: BIRMINGHAM SPRAYS TO CHECK EPIDEMIC
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 13 (AP)  A lowflying airplane sprayed 1,900 pounds of insecticide over Birmingham today, in an effort to halt an epidemic of St. Louis encephalitis.

title: Wake Forest Wins
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 13 (AP)Jerry McManus ran for one touchdown and passed to Bill Miliner for two others in leading Wake Forest to a 3022 Atlantic Coast Conference victory over North Carolina State tonight.

title: Auburn Is Upset, 31 to 20
description: AUBURN, Ala., Sept. 13 (AP)  Unheralded Memphis State, led by Kippy Brown at quarterback, ran up a quick 240 lead over seventhranked Auburn today, then fought off a fierce comeback attempt to post a dramatic 3120 upset.

title: Stanford Victim in 34to14 Rout
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 13Penn State's football coach, Joe Paterno, has done well recruiting on Long Island for more than a decade. Chuck Herd, flanker back, 19711973, and Al Vidello, placekicker, 1971 and 1972, are recent examples.

title: New Indoor Soccer League Organized
description: Two former executives with North American Soccer League teams, have formed the Major Soccer League, have named themselves president and commissioner and plan to operate indoors in the summer.

title: What Has Been Disclosed May Be the Smallest Part
description: Taken to court by the Watergate special prosecutor and the Securities and Exchange Commission, a number of major corporations have admitted making illegal domestic political contributions and paying kickbacks and bribes in their dealings with foreign countries. But investigators believe that what has been disclosed so far is only a fraction of a broad pattern of corporate corruption at home and abroad.

title: The Region
description: The latest casualty of New York City's financial crisis is its public school system. Because of budget cutbacks involving the dismissal of about 4,500 teachers, the 55,000 still working had been asked to accept longer days and to sacrifice some benefits won in past years. They refused and went out on strike.

title: Pursuing The Fox On Foot
description: CLAWING my way through the undergrowth in St. Leonard's Forest, some 40 miles south of London, I heard a horn sounding plaintively and jogged off to investigate. A crowd was peering into a thicket. Give him a chance to run, someone said. We moved back. Everybody keep very quiet. Suddenly the silence was broken by a shout, Fox away! Reynard streaked past me through the undergrowth like a bullet, the hounds following in hot pursuit. It was a hunt and I was a footfolloweran unmounted observer who follows the riders.

title: Sanford Is Planning to Enter 20 Presidential Primaries
description: DURHAM, N. C.Two men in this century who were presidents of universities, Dwight D. Eisenhower and Woodrow Wilson, were also Presidents of the United States, but neither ran for the office while he was also running his university.

title: French Stirred by Chad Captive
description: PARIS, Sept. 13For the last 17 months, Franoise Claustre, a 38yearold French archeologist and anthropologist, has been held hostage by a relatively small band of rebels on the edge of the Sahara in northern Chad.

title: Wolff Seeking Support for Bill to Cut Federal Income Taxes for Regular Commuters
description: PORT WASHINGTON The 39 Representatives from New York State have been asked by Representative Lester L. Wolff to support his legislation allowing a Federal income tax deduction for the cost of regular commuting to and from work on all forms of mass transit.

title: Wajima Now Rated A $600,000 Bargain
description: The next time a horse auctioneer warns a bidder against letting a $600,000 yearling get away, it may be hard to ignore him.

title: HALF OF GUARDSMEN PULL OUT OF BOSTON
description: BOSTON (UPI)Half of a 600man National Guard contingent assigned to this city forthe first week of a courtordered school busing plan this year was redeployed from the city today.

title: SUEZ CANAL TRADE GROWING SLOWLY
description: CAIRO, Sept. 13The number of ships passing through the Suez Canal is growing slowly.

title: World Bank Helping Sarajevo to Combat Polluted Air and Water
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, Sept. 11Known since Roman times for its supposedly therapeutic thermal springs, Sarajevo now has some of the most unhealthy air in the world and a water supply so dangerous that typhoid and diphtheria remain endemic.

title: New Air Force Chief in Iran
description: TEREHAN, Iran, Sept. 13 ReutersThe Shah of Iran today appointed Gen. Fazael Tadayon as commander f the Air Force in place of Gen. Mohammed Khatami, the Shah's. brotherinlaw who was killed in a hangglider accident yesterday. The glider plunged intomountains after being caught by high winds, a spokesman said

title: 10 Southern and Border States Weigh Holding Regional Presidential Primary
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 13Legisative leaders from 10 Southern and border states called Thursday for a thorough study of the feasibility of holding a regional Presidential primary, an idea that has already been debated inconclusively in New England and the Far West.

title: 4th Graders Make Bicentennial Quilt
description: SAG HARBORThe art of quiltmaking has come a long way since the days when women gathered around the table for a session of stitchery and gossip.

title: TV VIEW
description: The entertainment side of television huffed and puffed mightily in an attempt to generate a modicum of interest in the new season, but the few truly significant moments of programing were monopolized by a 90minute news essay on hunting. CBS News's The Guns of Autumn was broadcast on Friday, Sept. 5. Even before the program was put on the air, the National Rifle Association and other hunting interests overreacted to the project with a predictability bordering on the absurd.

title: A saint for all reasons
description: She vaguely remembers being sick, she said, but then she got well, and she doesn't recall much more. The barefoot brunette in the cutoff jeans and the halter top looked almost apologetic. Although she has a bunch of clippings stuffed into a drawer, along with her diploma from the New Vogue Beauty School and a dried flower from some forgotten bouquet, she hardly ever looks at the stories that tell how 4yearold Ann Theresa O'Neill was suddenly stricken with acute lymphatic leukemia and recovered, in a way that the Catholic Church has declared miraculous. In fact, Ann and her husband Bob went steady for two years before somebody even remembered to tell him about it. They dragged out this scrapbook one night, he recalled, and they started talking, and I said, Are kidding?

title: COAST OPERA BOWS WITH TROVATORE
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Sept. 1?? (AP)An international dream cast lighted up a gloomy stage production of Verdi's ?? Trovatore to make the opening of the San Francisco Opera's 53d season a night to remember.

title: JOHN CLARKESON
description: NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 13 (AP)John. Clarkeson of Wellesley, principal designer of the Massachusetts Turnpike and the Southeast Expressway, died yesterday at the NewtonWellesley Hospital. He was 65 years old.

title: Kings Point Sells Yacht Because Of Costs
description: KINGS POINTThe big, black schooner, America, given last May to the United States Merchant Marine Academy here, hag proven to be suet a white elephant that she has been sold for an undisclosed sum.

title: Deborah Dunn Becomes Bride
description: Deborah Wood Dunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ervin Stanley Dunn 2d of Southport, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Cameron Warner Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cameron Clark Jr. of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Francis X. Cheney performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Dunn home.

title: Saudi Arabia, as Studied by Students
description: Six business students from William and Mary College in Virginia took an all expensespaid, threeweek trip to the Middle East this past summer and came back to report that contrary to the misconceptions of most Americans, Saudi Arabia is not inhabited by barbarians who fight on camels across oilsoaked deserts.

title: Strikes Mute School Bell
description: TRENTONAs teacher unrest over salaries and rights in New Jersey's public schools mounted last week, strikes erupted throughout the state, turning backtoschool week into stayathome week for thousands of children.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Country music purists who feel that Robert Altman's film Nashville conveys an inaccurate picture of the world's country music capital are likely also to maintain that the two recent country ballads which have both become national hitsJessi Colter's plaintive I'm Not Lisa and Freddy Fender's lugubrious rendition of Before the Next Teardrop Fallsare hardly country music at all. The traditional country ballad, after all, possesses a simple melody and a sentimentladen lyric. Acoustic guitars, a lazy country fiddle, rhythmic banjo licks, mournful pedal steel guitarthese are the instruments the country ballad depends upon to accompany endless tales of love lost, found or unrequited.

title: GEORGE A. M'MORAN
description: George A. McMoran, senior vice president and chief financial officer of the Cunningham & Walsh advertising agency until his retirement in 1971, died Friday at the Mount Pleasant Hospital in Point Pleasant. N.J. He was 66 years old and lived at 421 Beacon Boulevard, Sea Girt. N.J.

title: Hobart Trounces R.P.I. Eleven, 307
description: GENEVA, N.Y., Sept. 13 (AP)Rich Kowalski rushed for 197 yards and three touchdowns today as Hobart trounced Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 307, in college football.

title: TOKYO IS CAUGHT IN THE DOLDRUMS
description: TOKYO, Sept. 13This city is in the doldrums, which is most surprising for a place that is usually so vibrant.

title: INVESTING
description: New York City's fiscal crisis has sent municipal bond yields to their highest levels ever and has cast a pall over what once were regarded as giltedged investments.

title: MAINE TO SALVAGE DAMAGED TREES
description: MILLINOCKET, Me., Sept. 13 More than 58,000 cords of wood from trees blown down by 100mileanhour winds in a 3,310acre area of Baxter State Park last November will soon be salvaged by the Park, Authority.

title: Aspirin Tried in Heart Cases
description: While researchers probe for new discoveries to fight the ravages of heart disease, several doctors at hospitals in Queens and Long Island are participating in an ambitious project to learn if an answer is already waiting in everyone's bathroom medicine cabinet.

title: Trenton Officials to Seek A 60% WaterRate Rise
description: TRENTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)Trenton officials said today that they would seek a 60 per cent water rate increase to improve the city's water system, which broke down last month.

title: Untraditional Japanese Art Shown
description: Japanophiles who are searching for the traditional Japanese characterists will find only part of them at the Japanese Artists of Brooklyn show now at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: ... Misguided Policies
description: The council draws a dismal but persuasive picture of present Federal policies which have created chaotic duplication. Guidelines are often inconsistent and mordtored by competing agencies staffed bybureaucrats who know nothing about academic life. Seldom, says Dr. Clark Kerr, the council's chairman, has a good cause spawned such a badly developed series of Federal mechanisms. One inherent weakness in Federal tactics is the implausible threat of withholding all Federal funds from an entire university in retaliation for some limited violation. Another flaw is what Dr. Kerr calls resort to governmental finetuningdemanding specific percentages in individual departmentsrather than concentrating on broad institutionwide goals and the establishment of better grievance procedures to deal quickly with individual cases.

title: BUYING POWER OFF NEARLY 5% IN 1974
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Although Americans earned more in dollars in 1974 than they did in 1973, their buying power decreased by nearly 5 percent, according to the Census Bureau.

title: U.S.C. Routs Duke, 357; Bell Excels
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (UPI)Ricky Bell, debuting as Anthony Davis's replacement in the University of Southern California attack. scored four touchdowns and rushed for a school record 256 yards on 34 carries last night to lead the defending national champion Trojans to a 357 victory over Duke's Blue Devils.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Successful as the play was during its original production halfway through World War II, there have always been people besides Sabina who hated The Skin of Our Teeth. Neither Thornton Wilder's reputation for making experimentation charming nor the brilliance of that first companyTallulah Bankhead, Fredric March, Florence Eldridge, Florence Reed, and Montgomery Clift were all in itcould keep Cadillacs from rolling away at intermissiontime. Not all of them, not even too many of them. But some. And, as I left the Mark Bellinger after a preview of the revival that has come to us from the Kennedy Center in Washington, a young man ahead of me was expostulating to his young woman, What are they going to do with that play?, quite as though this were still its first mounting and there was serious fixing ahead.

title: Japan's Fast Trains Popular
description: TOKYO, Sept. 13 (Reuters)The total of passengers who have used the highspeed trains of Japan's Shinkansen line since they started service Oct. 1, 1964, reached 900 million this week, according to Japan National Railways. The line, initially linking Tokyo with Osaka, now extends from the capital to the southern island of Kyushu. Express trains operate at average speeds over 100 miles an hour.

title: Contract Talks With City U. Group Approaching Critical Stage
description: The Professional Staff Congress, representing 17,000 members of the instructional staff at the City University of New York, and the Board of Higher Education are approaching a critical period in their contract negotiations, union officials say.

title: Encounter: In Pursuit of Paradise
description: MY first morning on the beach in Acapulco, a young Mexican sat down beside me. He was selling tickets to the Nave Vikinga, a yacht that toured the Laguna de la Cuesta and entered a paradise of tropical birds.

title: Helen Hanhart, Stephen Starr Have Nuptials
description: Helen Hanhart of Havertown, Pa., a designer of formal gowns for women, was married yesterday to Stephen Starr Phillips of Philadelphia, a lawyer there with the firm of Pepper, Hamilton & Scheetz.

title: Trenton Offers Latin American Art
description: TRENTONThe revolution of taste and sensibility in LatinAmerican art is aptly outlined in the State Museu m's principal fall exhibition, Panorama of Contemporary Latin  American Artists.

title: Gail Schiefelbein Wed to Jules M. Bacal
description: Gail Linnea Schiefelbein, a marketing supervisor with Trans World Airlines, was married yesterday to Jules Michael Bacal, a senior vice president and associate creative director of the Benton & Bowles advertising agency. The ceremony was performed by Criminal Court Judge Milton Shallick at the Patio Hotel in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: AnnaLouise Angerer Has Nuptials
description: AnnaLouise Angerer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Otto Angerer of West Caldwell, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon, to Keith Terrot Glover, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Marsh Glover of Chatham, N. J.

title: Legendary Peace Victor In Nassau County Show
description: GREENVALE, L.I., Sept. 13 Christien Platten, 21yearold senior at Simmons College in Boston, had the amateurowner jumper division all to herself today at the Nassau County horse show.

title: Fine Art In a Rare Setting
description: THE 29room mansion was designed by Stanford White around the turn of the century. It abounds with paintings by the likes of Monet and Degas, Whistler and Mary Cassatt along with Chinese porcelains and fine period furniture. The HillStead Museum, it's called, but it is more than a museum: There are family portraits scattered among the masterpieces, and there is an extraordinary sense of living presence here, an evocation of the lifestyle of those who once walked in these rooms.

title: New & Novel
description: Circus

title: Computer Analysis: Jets Must Run More
description: Bud Goode has advice for the Jets about the National Football League season, which begins next Sunday. The advice, to a team that has Joe Namath, is to run the ball more About and pass it less. Who is Bud Goode to make such a seemingly ridiculous statement? He is a mathematician and a computer analyst in Los Angeles who has turned his skills to football in recent years with amazing results.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Mary Mahoney Sets Oct. 11 Bridal
description: Mary B. Mahoney, an assistant treasurer in the Chase Manhattan Bank's treasury department, plans to be married Oct. 11 to James J. Maguire Jr. of Rhinebeck, N.Y., special assistant in Senator James L. Buckley's Albany office.Announcement of their engagement has been made by Miss Mahoney's parents, Mr and Mrs. Robert F. Mahoney of New York and Red Hook, N.Y. Her father is a retired city magistrate and a former partner in the law firm of Mahoney & Mahoney. The prospective bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maguire of Mineola, LI. His father is retired from Rheingold Breweries.

description: TodayBerks County K.C. allbreed and obedience. Fairgrounds, Kutztown, Pa.; 1,752 does; 9 A.M.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Julie Nixon Eisenhower is putting her life together again.

title: 7 Flee Rikers I. Jail
description: Seven inmates escaped from the men's jail on Rikers Island last night by cutting through a cell wall and were being hunted by corrections officers. Page 43.

description: The municipal tax rate of $2.43 per $100 valuation would have decreased to $2.19 this year if the Westmont Shores subdivision in Lavallette nad been annexed. The figures were transposed in a story in this section last Sunday.

title: The Nation
description: President Ford and the Democrats in Congress are still deadlocked over energy policy after more than a year, but now price controls on domestic Oil have expired and, for the moment, the tactical advantage seems to be with the President.

title: Gerard Molloy Weds Miss Schwarting
description: Kathleen Suzanne Schwan ing and Gerard F. X. Molloy were married yesterday morning in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Cathedral in Rockville Centre, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas F. Sinnott.

title: North Carolina Gains Support in Opposing River Power Project
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Qualified support from the Interior Department has revived a faltering fiveyear campaign by environmentalists and state officials in North Carolina to preserve miles of Appalachian wilderness along the New River from Inundation by a giant hydroelectric power project.

LISBON REPORTS 3PARTY ACCORD
description: LISBON, Sept. 13Portugal's Premierdesignate, Vice Adm. Jos Pinheiro de Azevedo, announced tonight that the Socialist, Popular Democratic and Communist parties had reached agreement on a general program that would take a more moderate revolutionary course and guarantee representation of the major political parties.

title: Yanks, Indians Split In Battle for Third
description: The Yankees kept themselves three games on the good side of .500 last night by splitting a doubleheader with the Cleveland Indians at Shea Stadium.

title: Refugee Family From Vietnam Starts Life Anew in a Mansion At Old Westbury
description: OLD WESTBURY  Peter Nguyen Mai Bach, 48, was mowing the lawn of the 16acre Thomas Hitchcock estate here. His wife, Ann Nguyen Thi Kim Thuan, meanwhile, was dusting the mansion's furniture and two of their six children were vacuuming the floor.

description: Projecting fewer than 200,000 apartment starts this year, the lowest number in at least 15 years, the Advance Mortgage Corporation has termed the present housing recession not only the deepest of the postwar era, but the most universal in its impact.

title: U. S. Women Trail in Cup Tennis, 31
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 (UPI) Virginia Wade and Ann Haydon Jones won the doubles, 62, 63, today and gave Britain a commanding 31 lead in the annual Wightman Cup tennis series with the United States.

title: Bengals Top Saints, 200, On Passing
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 13 (AP) Ken Anderson completed 13 of 19 firsthalf passes, engineering drives of 82 and 89 yards, and led the Cincinnati Bengals to a 200 National Football League exhibition victory tonght over the New Orleans Saints.

title: Retirement Is Busy For Montclair Dean
description: MONTCLAIR  Although M. Herbert Freeman retired in July as dean of graduate studies at Montclair State College, the 67yearold educator is not going fishing. Instead, he intends to continue his career, which spans 44 years.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: 73 Boats Seek Governor's Cup As Port Is Host to a Yacht Race
description: Against a backdrop of skyscrapers and waterfront piers. 73 sailing yachts cut a 17andahalfmile course along the Hudson River, past the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge to Gravesend Bay and back yesterday in the second annual Governor's Cup Race.

title: Anybody Not Named George
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13This is the exhibition season for Presidential politics as well as for pro football, and the news from the political camps is about as exciting as a scoreless tie.

title: Louis Oshins, Football Coach At Brooklyn 21 Years, Is Dead
description: Louis R. Oshins, who had been the football coach and allround leader of sports at Brooklyn College from 1927, when the Flatbush institutions took up the gridiron sport, until 1948, died of cancer Aug. 6 at his home in Belize, formerly British Honduras. He was 73 years old and also had a home in Brooklyn.

title: Article 1  No Title
Stock Car Drivers 1, 2 In IROC
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., Sept. 13 (AP)David Pearson defeated Bobby Allison by the length of a car, giving the 100mile first leg of the International Race of Champions auto series a stockcar finish today.

title: U. S. Site in Ethiopia Attacked; 8 Missing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13A United States Navy communications facility near Asmara, Ethiopia, was attacked last night and eight persons, including two American servicemen. were missing, the Defense Department said today.

title: The Migrant Hawks
description: The hawks are migrating. Find one of their migration routes, which usually follow the great valleys of this country, and with any luck at all you will see the big birds moving slowly but steadily south. Most of the migrants are broadwinged hawks, but with them will probably be a few falcons and pigeon hawks.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I recently bought a.house with radiant heating coils buried in the concrete floor. The concrete is covered with linoleum tiles which are ugly, although they are in good condition. I don't want to cover them with a rug because of an allergy problem so I would like to know if they can be painted, and if so, what type of paint I should use.J.P., Garden City South, N.Y.

title: Miss M'Namara Of Boston Plans Oct. 25 Wedding
description: Carole McNamara, a secu rity analyst with Standish, Aver & Wood, Inc., in Boston, and Euan Malcolmson, an investment counselor with Fort Hill Investors in Boston, plan to be married Oct. 25.

title: A SHEIK WHO HATES TO GAMBLE
description: JIDDA. He's the man who can make us spend a cold winter, if he likes, who can force our factories to close down, compel our banks to stop payment and bring us to our knees. His power is terrifying because he's the chief administrator oil, the raw material on which our industrial and technological civilization is founded. He is Sheik Ahmed Zaki alYamani, Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister. No other country produces so much oil as his. No other country has such extensive reserves. It will still have oil when other countries have exhausted their supply. For this reason, Saudi Arabia can exert control over the members of OPEC, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, whose ministers are scheduled to meet in Vienna Sept. 24 to consider the possibility of another increase in the price of oil.

title: A novelist with opinions
description: Pamela Hansford Johnson was once beloved of Dylan Thomas and is now the wife of C. P. Snow. And why, you may well ask, should I start a review of her book, subtitled A Personal Record, with this sexist description instead of noting that she has published 14 novels, a play, a critical volume on Proust and a moral essay, On Iniquity, inspired by a particularly nasty British murder case of some years ago? Because her book is much more interesting when she is recalling her experiences with friends and tamely, acquaintances and lovers. than when she is communicating her ideas and opinions That's not too surprising, after all, [or someone who's a novelist by trade. Novelists don't need opinions, indeed it can be argued that they're better off without: think of Cline and Dostoevsky, think of those essays of Tolstoy on history: Let us, therefore, thank Miss Johnson for her reminiscenses but not for her views, which run from the banal to the curmudgeonly.

title: Cuts in Postage Rates Go Into Effect Today
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The United States Postal Service will lower the postage rates, by one cent for postcards effective tomorrow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy 4214 Victor; Goodwin Scores 4
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 13 (AP)A sophomore tailback, Gerry Goodwin, scored four touchdowns, equalling a modern Academy record, as Navy routed the University of Virginia, 4214, in the 1975 football opener for both teams today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Striking carpenters in New London and Windham Counties in Connecticut who had stalled work on several construction projects accepted a new twoyear contract and agreed to end their twomonth walkout. The 900 carpenters had been on strike since July 11.

description: Stocks finished lower last week as many issues showed sizable declines in more active trading.

description: FERRARI 308GT 2+2

title: Mrs. Gandhi Is Urging Antialcohol Campaign
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 13 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India has called for a nationwide movement to bring back Prohibition in India.

title: ROCKEFELLER BUSY ON TRIP TO SOUTH
description: NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 13Vice President Rockefeller completed today his second trip to the South in less than a month, having visited three states, made five speeches, held four news conferences and a television interview, attended four receptions for Republican party dignitaries, sat through half a University of Oklahoma football game, presided over a fundraising dinner and shaken many hundreds of hands in the space of two days.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Every day sees another horror story, and there is no doubt that the City of New York is in crisis. But at least there have beenfor the music lover, at leasttwo extraordinarily fine pieces of news in the past few weeks. One was the announcement that WNCN would return to the air. Now insomniacal or maniacal music lovers can listen the whole night throughto a complete Ring, perchance, or all 32 Beethoven piano sonatas, as suits the oftenfrenzied pleasure of the WNCN programmers.

title: Robin Brenner Fiancee
description: Robin Lee Brenner, news director for radio station WKTK in Baltimore, plans to be married In November to James Michael Sherman, a mortgage broker with G. A. Thompson & Co., here. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Carl Brenner of Hampton, Md., parents of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lawrence Sherman of Stone??igh, Md.

title: Bertolaccini In Women's Golf Lead
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 13 (AP)  Sylvia Bertolaccini carded a oneoverpar 72 today and took a onestroke lead after the second round of the $40,000 Southgate open, a Ladies Professional Golf Association event at the Leawood South course.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: In coming

title: Article 4  No Title
A Brick Terrace That Doesn't Call For Cement And Mortar
description: One of the simplest and easiest ways to build a masonry terrace or walk around the outside of the house is to pave the surface with bricks laid in a bed of sand. In addition to using either new or old brick (the material most often used for terraces of this kind), the homeowner can also use precast, flat concrete patio blocks or similar masonry units which can be purchased from building supply houses and masonry dealers in many areas.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The films of Franois Truffaut are full of quotationssome of the disenchanted will say too full. The quotations are always relevant to the multilevelled films Truffaut makes with such seeming effortlessness, yet they aren't essential to the primary pleasures. They are dividends. The quotations, which may be images as easily as lines of prose, are sometimes salutes to mentors and colleagues. Sometimes they are simply comic references and sometimes they mean exactly what they say.

title: Byrne Marks Bicentennial Of the Founding of Salem
description: SALEM, N.J., Sept. 13Governor Byrne joined with the consuls general of England and Sweden at a daylong festivity marking the 200th anniversary of this rural community, one of the first to be settled in New Jersey.

title: Marcia C. Mills Bride at Home
description: Marcia Curtis Mills, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence P. Mills of Broadalbin. N.Y., was married there yesterday to Richard Vickery Wakeman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wakeman of Marion, Mass. The Rev. John Mills, cousin of the bride, performed the Episcopal ceremony in the family chapel at the Mills home.

description: Sunday, September 14, 1975

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Every year I come back from vacation to the inevitable mountain of mail and the letter on top of the pile that says, This is to inform you of a perfectly dreadful situation that is about to become desperate. . . . There are variations on this theme for the next six inches down to the top of the desk. It is the jolt back to reality.

description: On Bribery

title: The gentle Brautigan and the nasty seventies
description: Five or six years ago, a popular college dormitory poster featured Richard Brautigan (perennial campus favorite) smiling shyly and extending, in invitation, a telephone receiver. Beside his head, in large type, was his San Francisco telephone number.

title: Soviets Would Like to Export European Security System
description: MOSCOWThe Kremlin, looking back at the results of the recent European Security Conference, is now suggesting that the nations of Asia might benefit from a similar system of security and cooperation. The Government newspaper Izvestia even went so far as to explain in detail just how the principles adopted at Helsinki could be applied on the Asian continent.

title: 3D MAN WATCHED BRONFMAN PAYOFF
description: When Edgar M. Bronfman paid $2.3million in ransom to the kidnappers of his son, Samuel Bronfman 2d, a man other than the two arrested later for the crime was at the scene observing the payoff, according to law enforcement officials.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Defense Department has deferred a planned 8,000man reduction in support troops in West Germany because it believes the reduction would weaken the combat strength of the United States Army in Europe. The decision, disclosed by a highranking Army officer, is the first reversal of a muchpublicized Pentagon policy in recent years of getting rid of fat in the armed forces through the elimination of support troops and headquarters staffs. The policy has beep an important part of Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger's budget strategy in trying to persuade Congress to accept a larger defense budget and to endorse an increase from 13 to 16 Army divisions. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: ART VIEW
description: The politics of dtente is a wondrous thingurging us, as it does, to believe that the earth is flatand no less wondrous are the cultural policies that have followed in its wake with a promptitude that can be effected nowadays only by commissars operating on large budgets under government fiat. The astronauts keep their rendezvous in space, the Bolshoi performs the operas of Prokofiev at Lincoln Center, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art dispatches its prized Old Masters to Moscow. God's in his heaven, you might say, and all's right with the world! Right?

title: 49ers Trounce Packers
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 13 (UPI)The San Francisco 49ers took advantage of three interceptions from Green Bay's quarterback, John Hadl, and two Packer fumbles to defeat the Packers, 243, tonight.

title: New Radio Rules Provide Distress
description: As any TV viewer can tell you, the way to reach the Coast Guard, Navy, or Lloyd Bridges in an emergency at sea is to start tapping out three dots, followed by three dashes and three dots again. The more sophisticated would just yell Mayday into the radio. But there's a little more to it, and the Federal Communications Commission's rules changes have been responsible for numerous inquiries at the Third Coast Guard District on Governors Island in recent months.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (AP)Two Bulgarians and two Russians became the first titleholders in the world GrecoRoman wrestling championships in Minsk today. Kamen Lozanov of Bulgaria won the under220pound class by pinning Andrjei Skazidliewski of Poland. Alexander Tomov of Bulgaria took the over220 class by default when Roman Codreanu of Rumania was unable to compete because a gashed eyebrow. Nelson Davidyan of the Soviet Union won the under136 class, outpointing Jaziemerz Liepen of Poland, and Vitaly Konstantinov of the Soviet Union was crowned under115 titleholder.

title: Boy Scouts Here to Consolidate Borough Offices, Shutting Four
description: The Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America has voted to close borough offices in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island and centralize operations at its Manhattan office.

description: More details of the IsraeliEgyptian agreement on Sinai have leaked out, and they show that the pact is more complex and the American role more extensive than at first believed.

title: Fashion
description: In the beginning, there was the join cloth. Before that, Paleolithic man (or his woman) had sewn together animal skins using bone needles threaded with thongs. But sartorially speaking, these crude coverings belong in the prehistory prologue of the annals of men's clothing.

title: Forrest Harold Anthony Weds Kathryn Lee Kinney in Jersey
description: Kathryn Lee Kinney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Marks Kinney Jr. of Westfield, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Forrest Harold Anthony, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Chase Anthony of Orting, Wash.

title: Metropolitan Small College Football: Post Montclair State Appear Strongest
description: College football teams have increased in number throughout the New York metropolitan area in recent years, contrary to the decline of the sport in some other regions. One of the causes for the increase is that many of the football programs at such colleges as Seton Hall, St. Peter's William Paterson, Kean and Fordham had modest beginnings as club teams or lowbudget varsities.

title: The Transfigured Hart
description: A boy and a girl independently discover an albino deer in the woods. The boy, Richard Plante, is an introverted lovestarved orphan and the most erudite 12yearold you'll ever meet. His favorite books, practically learned by heart, include folklore, bestiaries, collections of Grimm, Asbjnsen, Yeats and Robert Graves's The White Goddess. His bearing the name of Richard is no accident, but a signal that his heart, though damaged by rheumatic fever, is rich. And people who are rich in heart see a unicorn where others see only a deerat least, so the author is trying to tell us.

title: The Pay Squeeze Passes SixDigiters By
description: The seesaw of inflation recession, along with the wheel of fortune, may have put some former sixdigitayear top executives on the unemployment line. But it has been kind to most.

title: Will School Buses Ever Get to the End of the Line?
description: Even as its advocates have begun to question their own wisdom, school busing to achieve racial desegregation remains the focus of both hopes and resentments, especially in the magnifying environments of large cities. This year, busing plans are in operation in Louisville and Boston, and though the attitudes of whites and blacks is similar in both places, what is happening in the two cities is, so far, quite dfferent.

title: For Norway, Oil Means Slow Wealth
description: STAVANGER, Norway Norway is a new oil nation with a differencean industrialized country with a far more varied domestic energy base than is normal elsewhere and one that is determined to get rich slowly as an exporter of oil and a supplier of oilrelated equipment and services.

title: Mayersons Have Child
description: A daughter was born Sept. 5 to Dr. and Mrs. Donald J. Mayerson at New York Hospital. The child has been named Katharine Mann. Dr. Mayerson, a staff psychiatrist at Roosevelt Hospital, is also a film critic for Cue magazine.

title: Design
description: The chief spokesmen for the firm of Venturi and Rauch, Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown, are known primarily as theoriststo their dismay. Their calls for an ordinary architecture to replace the sterility of orthodox modernism have brought them much respect but, at least until recently, relatively few building commissions.

title: Anatomy of a garmentcenter firm
description: On the Thursday before Memorial Day weekend a few seasons ago, in the dowdy showroom of Sportwhirl, the Seventh Avenue sportswear maker, a buyer from Abraham & Straus named Alan Ulick let it drop that his customers might just be ready for something called palazzo pants. Elasticized at the waist, flared sharply from the knee to a 24inch bottom and loose as pajamas, they seemed like a fresh look for home entertaining. As it happened. Sportwhirl had just such an item in stock. The only problem was that the pants had been designed for the coming fall in doubleknit wool. Local stores do not order heavy wools at the onset of summer. Just the same, Arthur Goodman, the precise and usually wary 61yearold president of the family firm, also had a good feeling about palazzo pants He suggested that A & S try out a batch at its Brooklyn store that weekend. To get a better feel for any developing sentiment, he also persuaded a buyer at Bloomingdale's to put palazzo pants on the sales floor at 59th Street.

title: Antiques Sale to Aid Montclair Students
description: MONTCLAIRThe Kiwanis Club of Montclair will sponsor an antiques show next Friday and Saturday for the benefit of its scholarship fund. It will be held at the Woman's Club of Upper Montclair on Cooper Avenue.

title: Cowboys Edge Steelers
description: IRVING, Tex., Sept. 13 (UPI)Clint Longley, reserve quarterback, revived a sputtering Dallas offense with two long secondhalf scoring drives tonight to lead the Cowboys to a 1716 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Zeroing in on Oil Industry Competition
description: WASHINGTON  The debate on oil price controls has given the public a preview of still another emotionladen oilindustry issue that is pushing its way from the wings towards the center of the political stage.

title: Paperbacks
description: THE DEVIL AND JOHN FOSTER DULLES, by Townsend Hoopes. (AtlanticLittle, Brown, $4.95.) A biography and impeachment of Eisenhower's Secretary of State and the cold war policy he fostered: effective as a lawyer's brief, lacking perspective as history.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: New evidence is in on the potential effect of some aerosol cans on the ozone layer that protects the earth from the sun's ultraviolet rays. The findings are based on samples of the upper atmosphere by high altitude balloons and U2 aircraft. Taken together, they support the hypothesis that the planet's stratospheric blanket is being thinned by fluorocarbons, chemical compounds that are a common spray can propellant.

title: The Nuclear Overkill In Western Europe
description: BONNThe United States has maintained a 7,000warhead arsenal of tactical nuclear weapons in Western Europe since the 1950's. Now there is growing pressure, from Congress and from independent critics in Washington, to take another look and come up with a new answer to the perennial question: How much is enough?

title: State Acts to Speed Payments To Counties to Ease Relief Bite
description: Because of what he termed The tight financial situation of many counties, Stephen Berger, the state's Social Services Commissioner, announced steps yesterday to accelerate payments to the counties of the state's share of welfare. Medicaid and social service costs for the remainder of the year.

title: Skimmers Survived Rains
description: OCEANVILLEThe Black Skimmer colony at the Brieantine Wildlife Refuge has had a successful breeding season, despite severe setbacks during the heavy rains of July.

title: Giants Drop Strike Gesture And 3113 Game to Dolphins
description: MIAMI, Sept. 13  The Giants knuckled under to the Miami Dolphins tonighton and off the field.

title: Kureji gorufua (crazy golfers)
description: Long before dawn on any Saturday or Sunday, in winter or summer, rain or light snow, when Japanese streets are otherwise silent, the people you see are most likely carrying golf bags. Some have risen as early as 2:30 A.M. in order to be on time, though most of them will have had reservation slips made as far as a year in advance. They are headed for one or another of Japan's 1,000 golf courses (the construction of two more ought to be completed by the time you read this), where they may pay as much as a $40 greens fee.

title: MA.C. ARRANGES $100MILLION SALE OF BOND PACKAGE
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation has arranged to place $100million of its bonds in the portfolios of savings banks and insurance companies here, a step that nearly completes the $2.3billion in financing to tide the city over to December.

title: Coleus and Other Leafy Curiosities Go to College
description: That seasonal phenomenon, the autumnal migration of the college student, is at its peak. Packed along with the more traditional guitars, tennis rackets, frisbees, hifi's, jeans, sneakers and books, other essentials of survival are green plants: philodendrons, avocado trees and rubber plants.

title: Without Funds, Urban Neighborhoods Disintegrate
description: CHICAGOThe couple, both college professors and with a combined annual income in excess $40,000, went to seven Chicago banks seeking a conventional mortgage loan in order to purchase a 20yearold, brick house in Austin, an aging, Workingclass section of this city. All seven banks said no without giving a reason.

title: He Knows What's Cookin'
description: FORT LEEGuy Wilhelm is one executive who does not get bored with eating at home. His wife, Ellinor, provides him with a 200meal menu.

title: FORD VOWS CURB ON SOCIAL OUTLAYS
description: DALLAS, Sept. 13President Ford declared here today that he was, fed up with pessimism about America and deterMined to reverse a trend toward social spending that literally threatens our whole, economy.

title: Susan H. Mabry To Marry Oct. 4
description: Mrs. Thomas Dabney Mabry Jr., of Allensville, Ky., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Susan Haven Mabry. to Robert Kennedy Menees of Guthrie, Ky. The wedding is planned for Oct. 4.

description: Fiction

title: BERWIND P. KAUFMANN
description: Berwind P. Kaufmann, professor of biology at the University of Michigan from 1965 until 1970, died Friday at a retirement home in Mrytle Beach. S.C. He was 79 years old.

title: The World Economy: Searching for Strength
description: The last two or three years have marked a set change in the conduct of Western economic policy. Inflation in the industrial world may still be running at rates once considered unthinkable. But unemployment is also nearing record levels and, with the recession still deepening in many countries, everyone's thoughts are turning to reflation.

title: It Works When the Parties Permit It
description: The public learned again last week that legislation was incapable of preventing strikes by public employes, even when substantial penalties hang over the strikers. If a union decides it has absolutely no recourse but a walkout, as the United Federation of Teachers decided on Monday, the fact that it is illegal is no deterrent.

description: GAINESVILLE, Sept. 13 (AP)Florida scored a 4014 victory over Southern Methodist tonight as Don Gaffney ran 6 yards for a touchdown and passed to Wes Chandler for two more.

title: New Charter for Essex Urged
description: MAPLE WOODSupporters of changing the form of Essex County's government have confidently opened a campaign urging that their proposal be put to the voters in a referendum on the November ballot.

description: A Federal judge has permanently enjoined the sale of Child Psychology. a college textbook first published in 1973, ruling that it infringed on the copyright of Child Development and Personality, a basic textbook in psychology first published in 1956.

description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 13 (UPI)  Matthew Reed accounted for three touchdowns and Ron Slovensky kicked three field goals tonight to lead the Birmingham Vulcans to a 3324 W.F.L. victory over the San Antonio Wings.

description: ROME, Sept. 13The Council on Foreign Relations in New York has scheduled a dinner meeting on Italy next month but its Communist guest of honor will probably not be able to enter the United States to attend.

title: She met everyone, including Ho Chi Minh
description: Somebody once told Susan Mary Alsop that she and her friend Marietta Tree were like Henry James heroines. Susan Mary was a spirited young American woman discovering Europe, and the way of life she chronicles in this collection of letters to Marietta is surprisingly like that embalmed in James's novels: house parties in the great country houses of England, a costume ball in a palazzo in Venice, chilly receptions in Paris drawing rom.

title: Pets Abandoned by Vacationers Create Major U.S. Problems
description: At this time of the year invariably there is a problem at resort areas created by irresponsible pet owners. People return home and abandon pets they enjoyed during the summer. Reports are heard of how dogs have joined packs and caused great havoc.

description: BOSTON, Sept. 13This city's new school desegregation program is the focus of the most extensive and farreaching involvement by colleges and universities, as well as business, ever undertaken in a public school system in the United States.

description: LAMBERTVILLEStepping into The People's Store, a landmark here since 1859, was always like stepping back at least 100 years in time.

description: TRENTON  Just like the Republicans. New Jersey Democrats are feuding over party fundraising, with State Senator James P. Dugan, the Democratic state chairman, under attack for organizing a dinner next month that is restricted to heavy contributors.

description: To the Editor:

description: An alleged member of a group of armed robbers who got $860,000 in jewels and other valuables in recent holdups at the New York Hilton and Gramercy Park Hotels was arrested on the East Side yesterday, the police said.

description: AWATERSHED in the national campaign against pay toilets was reached this month when legislation banning such facilities was passed in New York State. Leaders of the campaign, however, viewed it as only a start toward dealing with a much larger problemthe lack of public restroom facilities in the country as a whole.

description: Karen Linda Blanchard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis O. Blanchard of Stamford. Conn., was married there yesterday to Scott Eliot Martin, son of Leonard E. Martin of Webster Groves, Mo., a judge of the Magistrates Court of St. Louis County, and the late Mrs. Martin. The Rev. Donald F. Campbell performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church. The bride will keep her maiden name. She ??nd her husband, a graduate student in urban planning at Harvard university, are graduates of the College of Wooster.

title: Endpaper
description: I wasn't horn in New Jersey. I discovered it. Uncle Sam sent me to Fort Dix in 1953, when I fought The Battle of the Turnpike, as the hardened vets called the drive every weekend from the South Jersey Army post to New York City. I made the dangerous drive along the turnpike often in my two years of active duty, I was awarded the Battle of the Turnpike commendation medal with chrome clusters.

title: A True Compromise Will Not Come Easily
description: WASHINGTONDepending on which side one is on, the yearlong stalemate between Congress and President Ford over energy policy appears to be a classical case either of Congressional ineptitude or presidential irresponsibility.
