title: Food
description: What really keeps people from going on a diet? The small portions? The unsavoriness of the food? The limitation of choices? Plain boredom with dieting? Or is it a little of everything? None of these reasons should stop even the gourmet, because with a serious knowledge of food and a prolific imagination, anyone can prepare good, copious, diversified and lowcalorie meals, using only fresh and natural ingredients of the highest possible quality. My idea is not systematically to eliminate butter, cream, flour, eggs, etc., from the table, but rather to utilize such highcalorie foods only when absolutely necessary and in the smallest possible quantities. Hence, a balanced meal, highly palatable and very low in calories. This fare does not take into account economic considerations or special health problems, but strives only to be distinctive, tasty and nonfattening. On this page are recipes for a complete meal for six. Generous portions of all four dishes, plus a fourounce glass of a dry fruity wine such as a Pouilly Solutr or a Montagny, amount to only 484 calories.

title: Red Bank Church to Dedicate Its New Organ Today
description: RED BANK  Latenight strollers along Broad Street last week might have wondered if a phantom of the opera had taken over the United Methodist Church. Not so. What they heard were the lastminute preparations for the formal dedication of a new organ today.

title: OREGON TO WEIGH POLICE DATA CURB
description: SALEM, Ore., Sept. 13Gov. Robert W. Straub has ordered the state legislature into special session next Tuesday to correct a state law that unintentionally clamped a tight lid on all police and court records.

title: Student Supplies Include Tape Recorders
description: All over the United States, high school students are invading their own communities, armed with notebooks, tape recorders and cameras, and they are capturing cultural qualities that, in many cases, might otherwise disappear.

title: Sooners Win 21st In a Row
description: NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 13 (AP)Oklahoma buried Oregon, 627, today, extending college football's longest unbeaten streak to 30 games. It was Oklahoma's 21st straight victory.

title: Rice Upsets Houston
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Rice University turned a series of big plays, including touchdowns on Gary Cox' 70yard punt return and Larry Brune's 86yard interception return, into a 247 upset of Houston tonight.

description: LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 13 (AP)Terry Luck tossed a 5yard scoring pass to Bobby Thomas in the second period and Mike Coyle kicked a 37yard field goal in the third, leading Nebraska to a 107 football victory over Louisiana State today.

title: Diplomats Question Charge That Saigon Holds Foreign Nationals as Hostages
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 13 Between 7,000 and 10,000 foreign nationals want to leave South Vietnam, but there seems to be little substance to reports that many are being held hostage, according to Western diplomats, relief workers and travelers who recently arrived here from Saigon.

description: Cordelia King Westwater daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William King Westwater of Columbus, Ohio, and Harbor Point, Mich., was married last evening to Mark Robinson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Wallace Robinson of Columbus and Deer Isle, Me.

title: Mets Conquer Cards by 62 As Webb Wins, Gets 3 Hits
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13The New York Mets found a consistent batter tonight. They also came up with an effective pitcher. And they discovered a new clutch hitter. It was all the same guy, Hank Webb, who pitched and batted the Mets to a 62 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals in Busch Stadium.

title: Armenians Hold One World Festival Here Just for the Fun of It

description: STAVANGER, NorwayThere is a story told here of how the Phillips Petroleum group struck it rich because of stubborn Norwegian bureaucracy, a story that both Norwegian and American oil company officials avow is true.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)  The Government says some ministers broadcast betting tips disguised as scriptural tips on a Washington radio stationand included testimonials of those who used the tips to win at an illegal numbers game.

title: Miss Whitcomb Plans Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. James H. Whitcomb of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Prescott Whitcomb, to James Kelly Ahern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Ahern of Lake Forest, Ill.

title: New Products for the DoItYourselfer
description: Graphite, one of the most effective and widely used nongreasy lubricants, is now available in a spray paint that can be used to solve many lubricating problems around the house. Called SlipPlate, and manufactured by Superior Graphite Co., 20 North Wacker Drive, Chicago, III. 60606, this spray paint dries to a gray film which provides an exceptionally slick surface that is not only ideal for lubricating sliding windows, door latches, overhead garage door tracks, saw blades and similar sliding and moving parts, it also adds a rustpreventive film that protects all kinds of metal against corrosion. Since it is heatresistant it can be used for moving parts on barbecues. And, since it is moistureresistant, it is also excellent for applying to the underside of mowers to keep grass from stick ing, and to chutes of snowthrowers to keep snow from sticking. SlipPlate comes in a 14ounce can which sells for $2.99. It won't rub off or smear when dry.

description: AT a private luncheon in New York recently, a prominent European Government official was asked about the state of economic conditions in his country, as well as elsewhere on the Continent, and he replied rather wryly:

As a consequence, the Legislature has established scores of committees and commissions to study all kinds of public questions that are then quickly forgotten.

description: BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP)Rico Petrocelli and Doug Grffin broke out of batting slumps in a threerun fourth inning tonight and the Boston Red Sox went on to beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 63, for a split of a daynight program.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Watergate has left Washington a city ravaged by honesty. I am not sure I didn't like it better in the old days when nobody came clean about anything until they'd been pistolwhipped, wrapped in chains and rowed out into the middle of the Potomac with lead weights tied to their ankles.

title: Maria Tallchief Steps Back Into Ballet

Are you looking at your arms? The four young dancers look at their arms. The woman shakes her head. Every day of our lives, we are here to be as absolutely perfect as possible.

title: Rising Costs and Shortages Spur Wave of Pesticide Thefts at Farms
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13The nation's newest crime wave is not in the streets but down on the farm. Thieves are making fast money stealing pesticides, the chemicals used to kill insects and weeds.

title: African Music
description: The Western tendency to dismiss African music as primitive and uninteresting clearly arises from the same cultural and social racialism that has consistently demeaned the American vernacular musics rooted in rhythm and improvisation. The chief objection towards approaching the musics of Africa as art, however, probably stems from a basic distrust of any art that does not declare itself as such by our standards. We celebrate our art in terms of artists and their artifacts. African musicians have neglected to establish either cults of personality or a system of notation. Even the phonograph record fails to capture completely a music that is inextricably bound to the mundane matters of life.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Manager Billy Martin of Yankees, on how he feels after a victory: Everything looks nicer when you win. The girls are prettier. The cigars taste better. The trees are greener.

title: Survey Finds Ford Leading Humphrey By 8Point Margin
description: President. Ford would lead Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, one of the Democrats' two strongest Presidential contenders, by a margin of 50 to 42 per cent if the two men faced each other now in a Presidential election, according to the latest Gallup Poll. Eight per cent would be undecided.

title: Events by the Dozen at Oradell Fair
description: ORADELL  Ap oxenpull, frogjumping contest and frog jumping contest and bluegrass music will be among the attractions at the Oradell Bicentennial Country Fair next Saturday and Sunday. It will be held at the Benbyre Farm at 850 Ridgewood Road.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Abby Schutzer Wed To Andrew Crisses
description: Abby Cindy Schutzer, daughter of Godfrey Schutzer, Village Justice of Lake Success, L.I., and Mrs, Schutzer, was married last night to Andrew Michael Crisses, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Crisses of Massapequa Park, L.I. Rabbi Morton L. Gordon performed the ceremony at the Lake Success Golf Club.

title: Mideast Paradox
description: The irony of this month's momentous diplomatic achievements in the Middle East is that the fact of a successful negotiation contains within itself the seeds of a more sweeping danger than existed before: The danger of complacency, the belief that a problem has been solved, that stability is already at hand between Israel and the Arabs.

title: City and Westchester Back Bill To Have U.S. Pay 75% of Relief
description: An effort to increase the Federal Government's share of family welfare and Medicaid costs to 75 per cent has begun in Congress, with the backing of the city's Human Resources Administrator and Westchester's County Executive.

title: Greetings
description: Brief

title: The Teacher Dispute
description: THE PARTICIPANTS

title: AIDE IN COLORADO BESET BY TROUBLE
description: DENVER, Sept. 13A black Lieutenant Governor who has, been embroiled in controversy was being tested for a possible heart ailment today after being hospitalized early yesterday with what the hospital called severe chest pains.

title: 19thCentury Police Station to Be Sold by City at Auction
description: A 19th  century former Brooklyn police station that resembles an ancient castle is one of more than 400 buildings and lots scheduled to be sold Tuesday and Wednesday in what a Department of Real Estate spokesman has called the largest public city auction in the last decade.

title: For younger readers: surreal and lexicographical
description: On a bimulous night, the otters sing rhymes about katydids while the snails march down to the fern deep grove at the midnight end of the garden, where the trees eucalyptus back and forth under the lacy sky. On such a night, people who observe injunctions to eat spaghetti with pineapple sauce and wear nothing orange can juggle peaches or pretend to be helicopters.

title: Internal Controversy Hampering Ecology Unit
description: TRENTONThe environmental movement in New Jersey, under increasing attack from labor and industrial interests, now finds itself embroiled in a major controversy within its own ranks, a struggle that has seriously weakened the power of the more than 200 local ecology agencies in the state.

title: Money Is Time
description: The political and financial leaders of New York State have decided to buy three months' time for New York City at a very high price. The cost of jerrybuilt solvency until December includes an historic loss of selfrule by the city and the investment of $2.3billion to bring about an improvement in its financial healthby any standard a highrisk enterprise.

title: TV Notes: Hard Luck, Sexism and Maybe a Surprise Hit
description: Some TV series are doomed before they begin. Two seasons ago the hard luck show was Calucci's Department. This year it's Three for the Road, a new CBS series that is slotted at 7 o'clock on Sunday nights and is about the peregrinations of a freelance photographer and his two young sons. It will be aired as scheduled tonight in most cities but is not given much hate to last more than 13 weeks, the minimum length of a contract.

title: Howard Hughes, beyond the law
description: Since 1970, Howard Hughes has shunned the United Statesflitting about its perimeter, as ghostly as the Flying Dutchman, slipping to the Bahamas, Nicaragua, Vancouver, back to Nicaragua, over to London, back to the Bahamas. More than a year ago, Hughes and his retinue of functionaries moved into the Xanadu Princess, a luxury resort hotel on Grand Bahama Island. But this time, after posting a phalanx of guards to insure his privacy, the billionaire departed from his routine. He bought the hotel outright.

title: Stroke Victim Is Jailed As Drunk in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 (UPI)  A police inspector said today that two patrolmen who locked a stroke victim in a drunk tank for 14 hours acted in a callous and indifferent manner.

title: Chinese Doctors in Senegal
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Sept. 13 (Agence FrancePresse)An 18member Chinese medical team has arrived here to work in the Casamance district in southern Senegal for two years.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE FIRST NATIONAL CITY BANK and other New York banks raised their prime rate from 7 per cent to 8 per cent. . . . Meanwhile, the West Germany central bank lowered its discount rate from 4 per cent to 3 per cent. . . . A House Appropriations subcommittee was reported to have cut the proposed $98billion defense budget by $7billion. . . . Gold closed in London on Friday at $147.25 an ounce, down from $153.25 a week earlier.

title: Miss Boas Fiancee Of Mark L. Claster
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Boas of Great Neck, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Gail Boas, to Mark Lee Claster, who is in his second year at the Hofstra University Law School. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Claster of Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Of Things To Come
description: Yes, of course, THE CHALK GIANTS by Keith Roberts (Berkley/Putnam $6.95) is too ambitious. How else can a reviewer describe a novel that attempts to chronicle the rise of a new, postnuclearholocaust civilizationwars, religion, politics, philosophy, literature and allin less than two hundred pages? But having faulted Roberts for his lack of proportion, let me immeditely add that The Chalk Giants is far more successful than it has any right to be.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: And Dr. Billy Graham pointed out that the Lord had His tape recorder going too
description: A decent interval of silence, say 10 years, would seem to be the least that Richard Nixon owes the republic after committing various crimes and then repeatedly, shamelessly, lying about them to the courts, his own lawyers, committees of Congress and the Amercan people in news conferences, official statements and televised speeches complete with American flag, bust of Lincoln and invocations of the deity's blessings upon each and every one of you.

title: Crisis Turns Democrats To Fiscal Conservatism
description: The gravest financial crisis in New York City's history has shifted the Democratic party in the nation's most liberal city and state markedly toward fiscal conservativism and at the same time reshuffled the power structure in the state.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Although amateur photography is considered a hobby, there are actually many amateurs who use cameras and take photographs not as an escape from their work, but to contribute to it. The idea of using photography as an and in many fields of endeavor is not new, of course, but, this workconnected use of photography has multiplied greatly during the past decade because of the automation of 35mm equipment, the development of fast films and compact electronic flash units, and the widespread use of sophisticated Polaroid cameras and inexpensive, Instamatictype pocket cameras.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Lament or P.S.A.L. Track
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Drinking Age of 21 Upheld
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Sept. 13 (UPI)The State Supreme Court has unanimously upheld a state law setting the drinking age at 21.

title: FreeFood Center Struggling
description: HEMPSTEADA summer time crisis that caused one of the two free food distribution centers in Nassau County to close briefly last month is ending slowly as the churches that support them return to their postvacation schedules.

title: Theater: Chichester Fails to Bloom
description: CHICHESTER, England For the theatrically inclined American tourist, the city of Chichester, at least during the spring, summer and fall seasons of the Chichester Festival has a great deal to offer. It is a beautiful lazy city of peculiarly English charms. The cathedral, the pleasant streets, even the antique shops are all redolent of England's southern counties, and, of course, it is a decent departure point for other beauty spots. It does lark a major hotel but he assured that the Little London restaurant is among the best in all of southern England, so be sure to book.

title: Zaire Drafts Failing Pupils
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Sept. 13 (Agence FrancePresse)Pupils in Zaire who fail their final secondary school examinations must report for military service within 30 days, under a law signed by President Mobutu Sese Seko and promulgated here this week.

title: Everything Was Tried, Nothing Worked
description: On June 10, the Municipal Assistance Corporation was created to rescue a creditless New York City. The corporation was to borrow money for the city because the city was no longer able to market its own securities. With the corporation, Governor Carey said, there was finally hope that New York's constant crises would be abated.

title: Art: Landscapes Shown in Montclair
description: MONTCLAIRThe Landscape of the Imagination exhibition, which opens the 197576 art season at the Montclair Museum, is a journey into an idyll, a kind of pastoral and placid haven.

title: Schools Absorb Aid Cuts
description: MONTCLAIRThe general public seems to be relatively unconcerned as New Jersey school boards continue to tighten their belts and adopt a variety of measures to absorb the $40million cutback in state aid to education.

title: Tennessee Routs Maryland
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 13 (AP)  Stanley Morgan scored three touchdowns, the first two on runs of 50 and 70 yards, tonight as Tennessee routed Maryland, 268.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: One of the most entertaining aspects of the art photography worldindeed, of the contemporary, art world in generalis the enthusiasm with which it discovers each season new ways of doing things that are in fact old and very familiar ways. A case in point is Picture Puzzles, an exhibition of 39 photographs by Man Ray, Frederick Sommer. Clarence John Laughlin and Robert Cumming at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: U. S. PUTS OFF CUT IN SUPPORT FORCE IN WEST GERMANY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The Defense Department has deferred a planned 8,000man reduction in support troops in West Germany because of concern that the combat strength of the United States Army in Europe would be weakened too much.

title: GERMANS TO JOIN IN REGATTA HERE
description: German yachtsmen have disclosed plans to send at least 35 sailing craft to join the 13 huge squareriggers for a Hudson River marine parade next July 4 as part of the nation's Bicentennial celebration.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, Sept. 13 (AP) Workmen hung a huge tapestry of Mother Elizabeth Ann Seton from St. Peter's Basilica today and set up more than 20.000 seats for the first canonization of a nativeborn American.

title: Is Wall Street Biased?
description: It took the surfacing last week of a 54page report on practices at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith to make at least semiofficial what blacks, women and other underprivileged groups have long thoughtthat the securities industry is an employer biased on grounds of race and sex.

title: WALTER E. JOHNSON
description: Walter E. Johnson, who retired in 1963 as professor of voice and head of the voice department at the Westminster Choir College, died last Sunday at the Lakes Region Hospital, Laconia. N. H. He was 82 years old and lived in Tamworth, N. H.

title: Kentucky Victor, 278
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 13 (AP)Sonny Collins ran for 120 yards and Kentucky took advantage of Virginia Tech errors toddy for a 278 football victory over the Gobblers before 56,613 fans.

title: Five Foreign Journalists Picked as Nieman Fellows
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Sept. 13 (AP)Harvard University announced yesterday the selection of five journalists from foreign countries to join the 197576 class of Nieman fellows in journalism at the university.

title: Three novels
description: Can a midget find happiness and selffulfillment as the shortstop of a softball team that plays in drag? The answer, as you guessed, is no. Pogo is not happy with the Brooklyn Bimbos, who rollick through the South challenging local talent to a game and inviting rednecks to pay to see their shenanigans. Pogo is with the Bimbos but not of them. He is on the run from a bad superpimp whom he once doublecrossed.

title: ... and Necessity
description: A second early step to be taken is Congressional action to assure Israel of its military security, after the withdrawal of its forces from the imposing defenses of the Sinai mountain passes.

title: What's Doing in WILLIAMSBURG
description: BICENTENNIALHardly a town in the East lacks plans for celebrating the nation's 200th birthday with a historic commemoration of some kind between now and July 4, 1976. Colonial Williamsburg, on the other hand, is celebrating the Bicentennial every day, simply by looking and behaving just about as it did 200 years ago. Nowhere else in the country can observers find so authentic a restoration on so grand a scale: the whole of Colonial Virginia's capital as it existed in the turbulent days before, the Declaration of Independence. A visit to Colonial Williamsburg means walking the same streets, sitting in the same halls of government, relaxing in the same taverns where Washington, Jefferson, Patrick Henry and other Virginia leaders of the 1770's walked, worked and imbibed. In the last 49 years, the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, aided originally by John D. Rockefeller's millions, has restored 88 original buildings from the 18th century with meticulous care. Other buildings have been completely reconstructed on original foundations. The result has been to give back to the 20th century the charming 18thcentury town that was the seat of government of Britain's biggest American colony and this country's most populous original state.

title: There Is Pressure to Reduce U.S. Forces
description: TOKYOSince the fall of South Vietnam four months ago, President Ford and his senior officials have issued regular assurances that the United States intends to stand by its security commitments. Nowhere has that been more true than in Northeast Asia, where a war scare in Korea flared up briefly after the events in Saigon.

title: COURT UPHOLDS CHANGE IN NASSAU
description: An order by Justice Joseph Liff of State Supreme Court for Nassau County to establish a 15member legislative body as an interim form of government until a permanent plan is adopted has been unanimously affirmed by the Appellate Division.

title: Macmillan Dictionary For Children
description: Frankly, the problem with reviewing dictionaries is that I usually find the language stilted, the plot thin and the characterizations skimpy. Besides, it's hard to turn the pages if you have the flu, are an expectant mother or are riding the commuter train. Some of my best friends read dictionaries (one even took one to lunch with her), but generally, they leave them around on the coffee table opened casually to the word, ipsis' sima ver'ba. I'm very uncomfortable around people with large vocabularies and do not trust anyone who can spell hemorrhoid from memory.

title: 50th Year Begun By Choir College
description: PRINCETONThe Westminster Choir College began its 50th year last week as the only college of its type in the United States. To celebrate its golden anniversary, the college has planned a series of concerts that will enable many of its 450 students to perform with several major symphony orchestras around the country.

title: IN FRENCH GUIANA LURE OF NEW LIFE
description: PARIS, Sept. 13 (AP)  In three weeks 15.000 people have responded to a Government call for settlers in French Guiana, the last foreign possession on the South American mainland.

title: Nancy L. Hayward Plans Oct. 4 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ellice McDonald Jr. of Montchanin. Del., have announced that Mrs. McDonald's daughter, Nancy Lloyd Hayward, and A. Ward Burian are to marry Oct. 4. The future bridegroom is the son of Arthur J. Burian of Boca Raton, Fla., and Margaret W. Burian of Remsenburg, L. I.

title: 48 Killed in Costa Rica As Bus Goes Over Cliff
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 13 (AP)  Fortyeight passengers died today when a bus carrying 60 persons plunged over a cliff into a salt marsh near the Pacific port city of Puntarenas, the police reported.

title: Nassau Prisoners Are Given a Chance to Work on the Outside
description: EAST MEADOW  This time I think I have a chance to make it, John said. To me, the program is good . . . I've been in here before, he added quietly.

title: Astor Residence In Basking Ridge Gets a New Life
description: BASKING RIDGEThe former John Jacol Astor residence, ith wits crystal chandeliers, mahogany paneling, marble mantles and a new wing housing Police Headquarters and an auditorium for public meetings, will be dedicated next Sunday as municipal complex for affluent Bernards Township.

title: New printers, new writers and a new literature
description: Here is a book that will do much toward dispelling the myth that the American and British expatriates who wrote and published in Paris during the twenties and thirties came easily by their triumphs. Indeed, it might well be asked if there ever existed, outside of legend, a glamorous era now known as Paris in the twenties when material considerations were tossed to the winds and wildly unbridled emotions and talents were the order of the day. A number of Americans who were there as witnesses to and participants in the literary activities of that moment have never ceased to deplore that accurate chronicles of what actually took place have either not been published or, if published, not given their just due.

title: State Is Pressing Equal Opportunity for Students and Faculty
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Education has managed to avert any major confrontations stemming from the busing of children or the merger of school districts and it is now hoping that Its recently instituted requirements calling for equal opportunities for students and faculty members also will be accepted.

title: On Rooting Cuttings of House Plants
description: Leaves of succulent plants particularly sedum, echeveria, can be rooted easily in a moist medium such as a halfandhalf mixture of builder's (not beach) sand and peat or in perlite or vermiculite. Select a few sturdy leaves, insert them in the wet medium, keep out of strong sunlight and be patient. When roots form, little plants can be potted in a sandy soil separately.

title: DOROTHEA H. FORREST
description: Dorothea H. Forrest, retired supervisor of the treasury department of the Western Electric Company here, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, N. J. She lived at 515 Main Street, Chatham, N. J.

title: Chambord: A Majestic Chateau With a Skyline Like Constantinople
description: BEDROOMS, and discreet speculation about who slept in them, have always been a lively topic in Franceway back to the storied nights of liege lords and troubadours.

description: KELLOGG, Idaho, Sept. 13 (UPI)Children found a year ago to have extremely high levels of lead in their blood have a higher than expected prevalence of mild anemia and show minimal degrees of slowing in nerve conduction, a study group has reported.

description: TOKYO, Sept. 13A Japanese Socialist leader who is about to visit the United States, says that Americans need to understand the role of his party better because it is getting closer to power here.

title: Housing Permits Show a Gain in Suffolk
description: The pace of housing construction, severely depressed in the state and in the nation generally, fell far Iess sharply in Suffolk County during the first six months of this year than in most other places in the state.

description: Marianne Chisholm and John W. Galuchie Jr. were married yesterday afternoon at St. Raphael's Roman Catholic Church in Trenton. Msgr. William E. McGuire performed the ceremony.

description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 13 (AP)The father of a 21yearold adopted woman has asked a judge to allow her to die.

There are, apparently, plenty of people willing to sit through a sales pitch for New Mexico land in exchange for a free meal. Recently, I was one of them.

description: DENVERThe nation is now looking more and more to the West for solutions to the energy crisis. People loosely suggest that our petroleum crisis can easily be solved by developing oil shale and that the West, with its vast quantities of coal, can furnish a permanent solution to our energy troubles.

Porter, an A.F.L.C.I.O. trouble shooter from Fort Smith, Ark., here to help the United Farm Workers in the initial round of secret ballot representational elections under the state's new farm law.

Mrs. Miller is the former Mary Anne Morecock. Mr. Miller is an assistant general counsel of Standard Brands here.

Watkins Glen Racing Seminar Helps Fans Further Education
description: One of the unusual activities during the Grand Prix of the United States at Watkins Glen every year is the Inside Track Seminar, which offers a chance for fans to fluffier their education in motor racing. This years oneday school has been set for Saturday, Oct. 4, and the faculty that has been assembled is an outstanding oneMario Andretti of the United States, Sweden's Ronnie Peterson and Jody Scheckter of South Africa, all drivers; Don Nichols, who heads the American Shadow team, and Chris Econornaki, editorpublisher of National Speed Sport News and resident racing expert for ABCTV.

description: As a seemingly bounteous new musical season gets underway, attention is focused on the appearance of two conductors and on the touchandgo labor situation at the Metropolitan Opera. The conductors of note are Leonard Bernstein, who is due to lead both the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera, and Sarah Caldwell, who will make a debut with the same two orchestras. In addition, of course, numerous glittering recitals, debuts, premieres, revivals and events that defy description are in the offing. Herewith, a sampling of the season's highlights:

description: ATLANTA, Sept. 13 (AP)Nick MikeMayer kicked a 41yard field goal with 2:3 remaining tonight and gave the Atlanta Falcons a 1714 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles in an N.F.L. preseason game.

title: Court Rebukes a Judge For Jailing a Woman
description: DENVER, Sept. 13 (UPI)The Colorado Supreme Court has rebuked a district judge who jailed a woman on contempt charges for refusing to accept the terms of a divorce settlement.

title: Advice From Moscow
description: The Kremlin's leading Americanologist, Georgi A. Arbatov, is annoyed over United States pressure on the Soviet Union to implement the Helsinki Declaration's planks calling for increased contacts and greater civil rights. The United States ought to take care of its own problems first and leave the Soviet Union alone, he writes in Izvestia. In the Soviet Utopia, Mr. Arbatov implies, such Watergaterelated offenses as wiretapping, Government invasions of privacy and the like are unknown. The reality, unfortunately, is that in the Soviet Union there is no right of privacy, no secret beyond the claim of the K.G.B.'s right to know, no letter it cannot open, no telephone call it cannot record, no citizen it cannot imprison without right of counsel or habeas corpus, no psychiatric or medical record it cannot see at its wish. What the Nixon Administration tried to obtain by burglary, the Soviet secret police can and do obtain by a phone call.

title: Carol Norris Reinhardt Is Fiancee
description: Carol Norris Reinhardt, who is in her fourth year at the University of Pennsylvania Medical School in Philadelphia, plans to be married Dec. 27 to Frank Hassler Jr., who is on the staff of the Philadelphia Child Guidance Clinic.

title: How Not to Manage the City
description: The New York Legislature has passed and Governor Hugh Carey has signed legislation designed to stave off financial default by New York City and to restore investor confidence in the city's borrowing ability. But what good will such legislation do if the city persists in supporting inept financial management and improvident public planning, as represented for one bad example by the proposal to build a new West Side Highway from the Battery to 42d Street at a possible cost to the city of $110million?

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Virgil Hancock of Bellaire, Tex., won election to his first term as president of the American Numismatic Association at the A.N.A.'s 84th annual convention in Los Angeles late last month. He Avon by a sizable margin of 2,600 votes out of approximately 15,000 votes cast. His victory may have important ramifications for all collectors, not just A.N.A. members. The A.N.A. is, after all, the only truly national numismatic organization, but it has rarely realized its full potential for vigorous leadership and action on behalf of the hobby in general (preferring, instead, to exert its energies within itself). The hope that Mr. Hancock's election may turn this situation around is based on two major factors.

title: Paterson to Stage Annual Art Show
description: PATERSON  The eighth annual Art in the Park show will be held at Eastside Park here next Sunday.

title: QUAKE SPOTLIGHTS TURKISH POVERTY
description: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey, Sept. 10Horsedrawn carriages still clatter through this city in eastern Turkey. Peasant children wait for hours beside the highways, trying to sell melons to passersby. Until a few years ago, bears prowled the hinterland.

title: Patriots Vote to Strike And Refuse to Play Today
description: One week before the start of the regular seson, the National Football league's labor problems surfaced with a strike vote by the New England Patriots yesterday.

title: Jazz Notes: RockJazz Makes It in the Clubs
description: The most notable trend in jazz clubs this season promises to be the rising popularity of young, rockinfluenced jazz groups. Because most of the audience that has created the new boom in jazz clubs is a young crossover from rock, impresarios are on the lookout for new, young musicians and are passing by many of the old, established names in jazz.

title: BUSING PLAN FILED BY DALLAS BOARD
description: DALLAS, Sept. 13The las Independent School District Board filed a complex desegregation plan in Federal Court here last week that proposes busing 18,000 students to achieve racial mix in 73 schools, but would do nothing to desegregate 46 schools in predominantly black and MexicanAmerican neighborhoods.

title: Unions, Management Ride on S.S. Subsidy
description: WASHINGTONA group of Congressmen met with President Ford last June to discuss his campaign to force American businessmen to compete harder by reducing Government regulation. The Congressmen agreed that there was too much economic regulation. The next day a Senate committee approved new regulations to protect American ship operators from foreign competitors who win business by charging less.

title: CHESS
description: The Catalan Opening, a combination of the classical Queen's Gambit with a King's Fianchetto formation, is undergoing an enormous revival. It had declined in popularity after World War II, when the general opinion was that its subtle, ethereal centerplay was insufficient to provide a lasting initiative.

title: Holy Cross Loses to Cadets, 447
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 13.Leamon Hall, a 19yearold sophomore quarterback, came off the bench to throw two touchdown passes, and Army took advantage of Holy Cross mistakes to score a 447 victory today in the opening college football game of the season for both teams.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Convicted of conspiracy to smuggle 264 pounds of hashish into Turkey, three young Americans were sentenced first to death and then to life imprisonment in December, 1973. In May, 1974, their terms were cut to 24 years by the Turkish National Assembly.

title: DEDICATION URGED FOR YOM KIPPUR
description: On the eve of Yom Kippur, which begins as sundown today, Jewish spiritual and secular leaders said in statements that the holiday's precept of penitence called on all mankind for rededication to religious and ethical values.

title: Coming Up on BroadwayThe Busiest Season in a Decade
description: After a triumphant return to economic health last season, and having sailed through the usually, treacherous summer doldrums with barely a financial hiccup, the Broadway theater has embarked upon what looks like its most active and interesting season in more than a decade. So active, in fact, that there aren't enough theaters to go around. A number of last season's hits. such as Equus, The Wiz and Same Time, Next Year, are still entrenched with the prospect of long runs ahead. The result is that many incoming shows, even some with heavyweight credentials, will have to wait in the wings until vacancies occur.

title: Pentagon Discloses $2Million Increase In Price of an F14
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Sept. 14The price of the controversial F44 Tomcat fighter which is being bought by both the United States Navy and the Government of Iran, has increased by $2million a plane this year, according to the Department of Defense.

title: Charge Recanted in Sex Case Against L.I. Official
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept 14 A key witness against Henry F. O'Brien, the Suffolk District Attorney who was charged recently with sexual abuse involving a 21yearold unemployed handyman, has recanted his earlier testimony and has told investigators that he made the accusation because he had been pressured into it by the Suffolk police.

title: Hatchet Man Beimont Victor As Assault Stirs Memories
description: The $43,750 Assault Handicap, named after the great handicap star of three decades ago, had its first running at Belmont Park yesterday before a familyday crowd of 27,131. But only oldtimers who watched Greentree's Hatchet Man win the 1 mile contest, seemed to know about Assaultthe horse.

title: Giants Left RedFaced By Dolphins
description: MIAMI, Sept. 14  The cynics were criticizing the New York Giants here today, saying they couldn't even execute a 30minute delay of the opening kickoff against the Miami Dolphins last night without fumbling their protest.

title: Adams Saga, a $5.2Million TV Project With Cast of 1,100, Ending Taping Here
description: In the vast, fourstory brick building that once housed 20th CenturyFox's Movietone News studios, 1,100 actors and actresses and carpenters, cameramen, makeup men and women, electricians, and hundreds of wardrobe men and women, researchers, telephone operators, soundmen, engineers, directors, producers and painters are winding up 19 weeks of work filming WNET's $5.2million television series. The Adams Chronicles, to be shown starting next January.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State auditors recommended yesterday that $2.25million be deducted from future state aid payments to the city for New York City Community College in downtown Brooklyn. Their report, released by State Controller Arthur Levitt, indicated that this was the difference between the amount of aid advanced by the state for the college's budgets in the fiscal years 1963 through 1975 and the $28,791,281 in aid that was actually due for that period.

title: Lebanon's Violence Stirs Fear for Nation's Future
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 14A contagion of political and communal violence has spread a mood of almost helpless foreboding in Lebanon.

title: Whitworth Golf Victor With 69213
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 14 (AP)Kathy Whitworth, bundled from head to toe against a biting wind and occasional drizzle, carded a twounderpar 69 today and won the $40,000 Southgate open golf tournament.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an Associated Press dispatch that appeared in The New York Times last Friday, it was incorrectly reported that W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers, is serving a prison term for illegally using union funds in the 1968 election in support of President Nixon. The money involved supported Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and other persons.

title: Broncos Triumph Over Cards, 2117
description: Otis Armstrong ran 41 yards to set up a touchdown plunge by Jon Keyworth and scored twice himself from a yard out to lead the Denver Broncos to a 2117 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday in a National Foot ball League preseason finale in Denver.

title: Lebanon's Violence Stirs Fear for Nation's Future
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 14A contagion of political and communal violence has spread a mood of almost helpless foreboding in Lebanon.

title: Rare Ibis and Osprey Spotted As Fall Bird Migration Peaks
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 14The great autumn bird migrationsix or seven crucial weeks a year packed with more water, marsh and shore birds than a bird watcher could ever hope to watchis at its peak right now throughout the metropolitan region.

title: Pro Football Dispute
description: THE PARTICIPANTS

title: Justice J. Courtney McGroarty Of State Supreme Court Dead
description: State Supreme Court Justice J. Courtney McGroarty died yesterday in Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 70 years old and lived at 489 Rugby Road in Flatbush.

title: Stillborn Cyprus Talks
description: A new round of negotiations at the United Nations for a Cyprus settlement has been stillborn because the Turkish Cypriote leader is unable to keep a commitment made in Vienna six weeks ago. At that time Rauf Denktash promised to bring to New York specific proposals for a territorial division of the island between the Greek Cypriote and Turkish Cypriote communities.

title: 3 CONVENTION AIDES CHOSEN BY STRAUSS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic National Chairman, announced today his selection of three key officials for the 1976 Democratic convention in New York City.

title: Gillespie, Patriarch of Trumpet, Is Active Star of Tribute to Dizzy
description: The concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday evening was called A Tribute to Dizzy Gilespie but the most active paricipant throughout the evening was the subject, Mr. Gillespie, He led a big band made up argely of members of his earler big bands in the arrangerents those bands once played. He led his present quartet as veil as a quintet with Lalo Schifrin on piano and James Moody on alto saxophone that approximated his quintet of he nineteensixties. He presided over an allstar group made up of Stan Getz on tenor ??axophone, John Lewis on piano, Percy Heath on bass, and Max Roach drums.

title: Church in a Theater Gives Spirited Welcome to Vicar
description: The Rev. Henry H. Sturtevant was installed as vicar of the Off Off Broadway St. Clement's Church yesterday afternoon in a service performed by the Rt. Rev. Paul Moore Jr. The installation included a psalm reading by Ossie Davis, a magic show and a procession of wellwishers bearing such gifts as a bottle of whisky to help the vicar, as the donor put it, to join them symbolically in spirits.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Advertising
description: Thomas K. Myers, a 43yearold advertising man who came up on the client side, is ending his second year as president and chief operating officer of Norman, Craig & Kummel confident that he is delivering the growth and profitability demanded by the agency's parent company and its chief, Norman B. Norman.

title: Ethiopia Seeks 8 Abducted by Raiders
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 14 (AP)Ethiopian security forces searched Eritrea Province today for two Americans and six Ethiopians abducted by raiders who attacked a United States Navy satellitetracking station near Asmara.

title: U.S.Born Mother Seton Is Declared a Saint
description: ROME, Sept. 14 Before 100,000 people in St. Peter's Square, Pope Paul VI today declared Mother Elizabeth Ann Bayley Seton the first United Statesborn saint.

title: Center for Childbirth A HomeLike Setting
description: The Maternity Center Association has completed a new nonhospital childbearing center where a woman can give birth in a homelike setting surrounded by her family and go home her baby within 12 hours of delivery.

title: Counselor Is Held in Rape Of 18 W omen in the Bronx
description: A former high school track star who was hired as a counselor at a Rockland County orphanage despite four pending rape charges against him was seized by an undercover police dragnet yesterday morning and accused of raping 18 Bronx women since last November.

title: DR. JACOB GEIGER
description: Dr. Jacob Geiger, a physician who started one of the first hospital blood banks in the country at the Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx in 1921, died Saturday of cancer at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 85 old and lived at 250 East 73d Street.

title: U.S. Called Key to City's Fiscal Survival
description: Some of the nation's leading academic experts on big cities say that although New York has temporarily weathered its financial crisis, its continuing survival depends on major changes in longterm relationships with the Federal Government.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TODAY, SEPT. 15

title: . .. Not Minding the Store
description: Judged in terms of optimum conduct of the public's business, this frenetic schedule cannot be justified. Legislative negotiations are still needed to break the long deadlock between Congress and the White House over oil policy. The Administration is providing nothing like the forceful leadership in behalf of energy conservation that the situation requires.

title: Consensus on Recovery Wanes
description: Although Administration economists are still holding to their earlier forecasts of a smooth recovery, private analysts are not so sure. The revival of inflation and the rise in interest rates this summer have shaken the confidence of many economists outside Washington, stirring worries about the return of the recession, which went away only a few months ago.

title: On the Road . . .
description: A President naturally wants to travel freely into different regions of the country and keep in touch with the people whose hopes and problems are his chief concern. As the leader of his party, he also has a responsibility to campaign for lesser candidates when he thinks that would be useful. In both these roles, President Ford is acting within the traditions of his office.

title: Mets' Ace Lasts 2 In 62 Card Victory
Parking Rides Altered For Jewish Holy Day
description: The Traffic Department announced yesterday the suspension of some alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations for today, Yom Kippur.

title: Corsicans Battle Police After HomeRule Rally
description: AJACCIO, Corsica, Sept. 14 (AP)  Some 200 Corsican youths demanding more home rule for this French island threw paving stones and bottles at riot policemen from the mainland tonight and three of bombings were reported.

title: Japan, in Reversal of Economic Policy, Plans Urgent Effort to End Recession
description: TOKYO, Sept, 14The Deputy Premier of Japan, Takeo Fukuda, has disclosed that his Government will soon start an urgent $6billion effort to catapult the Japanese economy out of its lingering recession.

title: Dr. William LaTourette, Top Hutton Research Aide
description: Dr. William J. LaTourette, a senior vice president and director of research at E. F. Hutton & Co., Inc.. stockbrokers, died Saturday in San Antonio, Tex., where he commuted weekly In give courses at the local campus of the University of Texas. He was 50 years old and lived on West Saddle River Road in Upper Saddle River, N.J.

title: Bridge :
description: Long, cold Northern winters breed cardplayers, so it is not surprising that all the Scandinavian countries have large bridge populations and strong national teams.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: One or the most engrossing and enlightening letters ever to reach our desk arrived recently, pursuant to a column in which we discussed the much bruited notion that a great deal of French haute cuisine was brought to France by the Italian chefs of Catherine de Medici. The letter came from Barbara K. Wheaton of Cambridge, Mass. She asks whether, in our opinion, Catherine's cooks were really all that influential?

title: The Why of Busing
description: BOSTONCarl McCall is a promising black political figure in New York, a former newspaper and foundation executive who was elected to the State Senate last year from Manhattan. But he was born and brought up in Roxbury, Boston. He talked about that in a conversation the other day.

title: Norris Harkness 3d, Led The Photographic Society
description: Norris W. Harkness 3d, a former camera editor of The Sun and past president of the Photographic Society of America, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 580 Park Avenue.

title: 5 Remain Free as 3 Rikers Escapees Are Recaptured on an Island Nearby
description: Three escapees from the men's city prison on Rikers Island were captured yesterday in an abandoned building on nearby North Brother Island as an intensive search continued for the other five prisoners who had fled with them Saturday night.

title: Nine Puppies Are Born To the Fords' Retriever
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)President Ford's golden retriever Liberty became a mother of nine today.

title: About New York
description: The point at which an old house becomes a treasured collector's item, to be preserved and venerated whatever the cost, is difficult to say. It is even harder to say in New York, where until recent years the tendency has been to knock down yesterday's homestead and build something that will make more money.

title: Music: Tasteful Survey of Black Spirit
description: We hear a lot nowadays about black music, and there certainly are works that legitimately qualify as such. But there is, and has been for several centuries, music by black composers that need not be put into any racial pigeonhole. Blackinfluenced, yes; but black in a narrow sense, no.

title: Pentagon Discloses $2Million Increase In Price of an F14
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Sept. 14The price of the controversial F14 Tomcat fighter which is being bought by both the United States Navy and the Government of Iran, has increased by $2million a plane this year, according to the Department of Defense.

title: Phils Solve Cubs' Hex, Stay on Pirates' Track
description: All season, Chicago had been a nemesis to Philadephia, but yesterday, with the help of Mike Schmidt and Dick Allen, the secondplace Phillies shook off the whammy by outclubbing the Cubs, 137, in Chicago.

title: JOHN RABEN DIES; LAWYER WAS 58
description: John R. Raben, a senior partner in the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, with which he had been associated since 1939, died yesterday of cancer in New York Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 775 Park Avenue.

title: BEAME TO MONITOR STREET CLEANING
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that he would make his own spot check to monitor the Sanitation Department's progress in cleaning the city's streets.

title: 3 Democratic Contenders Give Views To a Party Liberal Group in Midwest
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 14The first of five regional meetings of Democratic liberals focused somewhat fuzzily this weekend on three candidates for the 1976 Presidential nominationRepresentative Morris K. Udall of Arizona, Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana and former Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Three prisoners who escaped Saturday night from the New York City Men's House of Detention on Rikers Island were recaptured in an abandoned building on nearby North Brother Island in the East River. Five inmates who escaped with them were still being sought by prison guards and the New York police. The eight men had cut through a steel wall of a cell and had escaped up an air duct to the roof.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1975

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jersey's public school districts ended the last fiscal year with a total surplus of $60million despite warnings by school officials that state aid reduction would lead to sharp service cutbacks. The State Department of Education said in a survey that the surplus$52.3million expenses and $5.8million in capital accountswas reported from various school districts across the state.

title: U.S. Called Key to City's Fiscal Survival
description: Some of the nation's leading academic experts on big cities say that although New York has temporarily weathered its financial crisis, its continuing survival depends on major changes in longterm relationships with the Federal Government.

title: Books of The Times
description: MUHAMMAD ALI. By Wilfrid Sheed. 256 pages. Illustrated. Crowell. $19.95.

title: Summer Pets Are Left on Own
description: The beaches and cottages are empty now, since the summer people returned to jobs and classes. But many animal shelters around the New York area are now jammed with the pets of summer.

title: The Latin Examination
description: Tum Germani agris suis expulsi ad Rhenum pervenerunt...

title: TOTH, CELLIST, PLAYS SECURELY IN DEBUT
description: Andor Toth Jr., cellist of the New Hungarian Quartet and member of the Faculty of the Oberlin Conservatory of Music. made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night with Marc Neikrug, composerpianist, as the assisting artist.

title: KARPOV IS WINNER IN CHESS AT MILAN
description: MILAN, Italy Sept. 14 (AP) Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, won the $12,000 Milan international chess tournament tonight, gaining a draw in his final match against Lajos Portisch of Hungary.

title: H. E. BRANDLI
description: H. E. Brandli, who retired in 1954 as president of the Cities Service Oil Company, marketing susbidiary of the Citier Service Company, died Saturday at his home, 25 East 83d Street. He was 90 years old.

title: SPECIAL SESSION OVER POOR LANDS IS CLOSING AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Monday, Sept. 15The General Assembly's special session on the plight of the third world moved early today toward a weary and potentially grim end after delegates worked well into the night in search of a formula for narrowing the chasm between rich and poor lands.

title: U.S. Women Lose at Net To Britain
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 (AP)  The British won the Wightman Cup tennis competition against the United States for the second straight year today. The decisive victory was scored when Glynis Coles overpowered Mona Schallau, 63, 76.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Rare Ibis and Osprey Spotted As Fall Bird Migration Peaks
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 14The great autumn bird migrationsix or seven crucial weeks a year packed with more water, marsh and shore birds than a bird watcher could ever hope to watchis at its peak right now throughout the metropolitan region.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Week of Decision: The Feudal Mind
description: This is the week of decision in several sports. Take the Yankees. When they awoke yesterday they had 14 games left and their magic number was five; any combination of New York defeats and Boston victories adding up to five would eliminate them from the championship race, if that really is a race. For weeks now, it has been clear that the Yankees were worse than anybody anticipated That leaves one question to be cleared up: who brought out the team's true nature? Not Bill Virdon, for he is long gone.

title: Inner Tube Prize Won A 2d Time by Engineer
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH, Sept. 14Bill Jones, a 31yearold engineer, won his second con secutive innertube grand prix today, the third time in five years he has won the summerending ocean event here.

title: The Teacher Dispute
description: The United Federation of Teachers, headed by Albert Shanker, representing 55,000 teachers and 20,000 other employes in the city's 976school system.

title: In Memoriam
description: GRIEN F. Anthony, September 15, 1953. Sorrow's Crown of Sorrow is remembering Happy Hours.

title: Britain Appears on Verge Of a National Steel Strike
description: LONDON, Sept. 14 (Reuters)  Britain's steel industry seemed to be heading for a nationwide shutdown today after blast furnacemen walked out at the country's newest and biggest blast furnace, at a British Steel Corporation plant in Llanwern, Wales, over a wage dispute.

title: Tomahawks Eliminated
description: QUEBEC CITY, Sept. 14The Quebec Caribous scored six goals on eight shots in the second period to eliminate the Long island Tomahawks, the defending champions from the National Lacrosse League playoffs, 1812, tonight before 9,640.

title: Yom Kippur Sermons Here Call Holy Day One of Hope
description: Rabbis emphasized in their Yom Kippur sermons last night that the sacred holiday was one of hope that imposed on mankind the obligation to improve the human condition.

title: MICHAEL RAPUANO, LANDSCAPE EXPERT
description: Michael Rapuano, a landscape architect who served as president of the American Academy in Rome from 1958 to 1968, died Saturday, apparently of a heart ailment, in Newtown, Pa., where he lived. His age was 71.

title: 3 Groups Criticize Plan to Block U.S. Meat Inspection Takeover
description: WASHNGTON, Sept. 14A quietly developed plan that would enable thousands of state  inspected slaughtering plants to begin shipping meat in interstate commerce, under consideration in the Department of Agriculture, has been attacked by a combination of Congressional, consumer and packing industry forces.

title: Duquesne University Aide Quits Alter Student Paper Disclosure
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14A Duquesne University administrator resigned yesterday, one day after the student newspaper reported he had falsified parts of his rsum when he applied for a job last year.

title: Bar Is Told It Fails to Help In Settling Minor Disputes
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 14The legal profession shares the blame for much of the violence, bitterness and dissatisfaction in American society because it has failed to provide the kind of substantive relief for routine grievances that other societies supply as a matter of course, the California State Bar Association has been told.

title: New Orchestra Making Its Debut Here ...
description: A new symphony orchestra will make its debut tomorrow night in Carnegie Hall. It is called, with simplicity and accuracy, the New Orchestra. It was created to play contemporary music only, and in this it may be unique. Chamber ensembles that specialize in the modern repertory  and New York abounds in these can be found in almost any large city, but a full symphony orchestra, in this case numbering 90 players and dedicated to the same purpose, is unknown in the United States.

title: Ashe Tops Draw at Coast Net
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14The Wimbledon champion, Arthur Ashe, topseeded for the 49th renewal of the Pacific Southwest open beginning tomorrow, says, One of the top four seeds should win it.

title: Mrs. Wallace Prayed in Tongues in '72
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 14 Cornelia Wallace has disclosed that she prayed in tongues with the Rev. Oral Roberts, while her husband, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, was recovering from wounds inflicted in an assassination attempt, and that she then learned the meaning of the baptism of the Holy Spirit.

title: School Compromise
description: The compromise settlement reportedly in the making in the teachers' strike seems to stay within the draconian money limits made necessary by New York City's closeness to financial disaster. That is the most affirmative thing that can be said for it.

title: Floats and Bands Mark AfroAmerican Parade
description: Hundreds of thousands of people lined the sidewalks between the trees or peered out of their apartments on Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard in Harlem yesterday in the crisp autumnlike air to watch the floats and blaring bands of the seventh annual AfricanAmerican Day parade.

title: Billions for Mideast, 0 for City
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11When President Ford sat down for breakfast with Congressional leaders last week and briefed them on the Middle East settlement, some of his listeners were surprised that no price tag was mentioned.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Nancy Hauser Dance Company, a moderndance troupe from Minneapolis, will open the new Dance at Hunter series at the Hunter College Playhouse on Friday end Saturday. Five other groups, ranging from Indian classical dance to mime, will also perform there through December.

title: The Miracle Occurs Daily at St. Joseph's
description: YONKERS. Sept. 14Room 308 has a single bed, empty today, with a blue bedspread on it. It is simply furnished: a dresser, a nightstand, four chairs, a telephone and a television receiver high up on the front wall. At the hallway entrance is a half door, a flower print curtain inside its wooden frame.

title: Rembrandt's The Night Watch Slashed
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 14Rembrandt's priceless masterpiece, The Night Watch, was slashed and disfigured today by a man armed with a bread knife who fought off a museum guard and told bystanders that he did it for the Lord.

title: ...While the Cultural Center Closes Its Doors
description: The demise of the New York Cultural Center, which yesterday closed its doors at 2 Columbus Circle for the last time, removes from the local art scene an odd but not uninteresting phenomenon. Its loss, while very far from being in any way central or catastrophic to New York art life, is nonetheless saddening.

title: TEACHER RESISTS PAYING SCHOOL TAX
description: TRENTON, Sept. 14  Although many New Jersey residents have strongly endorsed tax reform and the imposition of a state income tax, perhaps no one would appear to have stronger convictions on the issue than Richard Hixon, a professor of communications at Livingston College at Rutgers University.

title: Soviet Balks AvantGarde Artists on Outdoor Show
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14Soviet authorities have headed off a repetition of last year's controversial outdoor art exhibit.

title: Venezuela Is Aiding Poor Nations on Oil
description: Venezuela, which inspired the creation of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries 15 years ago, is devising plans to help poor nations finance OPEC's fourfold increase in oil prices since 1973.

title: Congress Leaders Fight Curbs on Slush Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The new Federal Election Commission has suddenly found itself the target of the Senators and Representatives who set it up because of what some regard as overzealousness in monitoring the finances of Congressmenone of the functions for which the panel was created.

title: Shiko Munakata, Artist, Dies; Honored for Woodblock Prints
description: TOKYO, Sept. 14 (AP)Shiko Munakata, an internstionally known woodblock artist whose rustic works featured Buddhist images and historic Japanese scenes, died of cancer yesterday at his home here. He was 72 years old.

title: Deborah Hinckley Married to Banker
description: Deborah Burnham Hinckley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Hinckley of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon, to David Theodore Berghorst, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Oren Berghorst of Cadillac, Mich. The Rev. Dr. Bradford Hastings performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: National Strike by Women Is Called for on Oct. 29
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) The National Organization For Women called today on all women to go on strike Oct. 29 to show the nation how much it depended on them.

title: G.O.P.'s Struggle in Background
description: Although the attention of most politicians was focused on the almost inevitable strains between Governor Carey and Mayor Beame during last week's special session of the Legislature on an emergency city aid package, the sharpest conflict involved the two Republican legislative leadersWarren M. Anderson of Binghamton, the Senate majority leader, and Perry B. Duryea of Montauk, L. I., the Assembly minority leader.

title: Amtrak Seeks 543 More New Goaches To Meet Doubling of Ridershipby 1980
description: Amtrak, the national ran passenger system, proposes the purchase of 543 more new coaches for its 25,000mile network in addition to the 727 new cars now being built and delivered.

title: LUXEMBOURG PLAN KEEPS MEN IN JOBS
description: ESCHSURALZETTE, Luxembourg  After a three  week shutdown dut to a world steel slump, the blast furnaces are spewing red smoke once more over this gray industrial town on Luxembourg's border with France.

title: LONG BRANCH UNIT UPHELD IN INQUIRY
description: LONG BRANCH, Sept. 14Superior Court Judge Merritt Lane Jr. has ruled the City Council and a citizens advisory committee it appointed here may continue to investigate the Police Department.

title: World Football League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: FURTHER DIP SEEN FOR BOND PRICES
description: The decline in prices accompanied by higher yieldsthat affected both the Government and corporate bond markets last week probably has further to go over the short term, according to analysts in the fixedinome field, The chief reason, they add, is the huge borrowing appetite of the Treasury that results from rising Federal expenditures.

title: Portuguese Premier Cites Support by High Military
description: LISBON, Sept. 14  Portugal's new centerleft government, scheduled to be announced in a few days, will count on strong military support to reverse a widely denounced trend toward Communist domination of the country.

title: Rizzoli on the Square
description: When S. Klein shut its bargain doors after half a century in Union Square, it marked the end of an era. But the doomsayers of this historic area of soapboxes and shopping bazaars have little time to gloat. New York has a habit of building, sometimes ruthlessly, on the past and keeping its options open for any and all comers. Out goes Klein's; in comes Rizzoli.

title: Strike by Patriots Cancels Jets Game
description: The pro football game between the New York Jets and the New England Patriots, scheduled for the Yale Bowl in New Haven, was canceled yesterday after the Patriots' players maintained their earlier refusal to play. On Saturday they had voted, 392, to strike the game, a preseason contest for which the Jets were to be the host

title: Sulka Is Striving to Regain Its Traditional Eminence
description: Sulks, battlescarred but not defeated by the flamboyant developments in men's fashions, is making a bid under new corporate and design leadership to win men back to sane shirts and traditional ties.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an Associated Press dispatch that appeared in The New York Times last Friday, it was incorrectly reported that W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers, is serving a prison term for illegally using union funds in the 1968 election in support of President Nixon. The money involved supported Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and other persons.

title: Thermometer Plunges To 46, Tying Record
description: The temperature dropped to 46 degrees yesterday, tying the record low reading for the date that was set 64 years ago, according to the National Weather Service.

title: Personal Finance:CreditCard Abuse Before Bankruptcy Filing
description: Can a person accumulate a lot of bills on a credit card and get away without paying by filing for personal bankruptcy soon afterward?

title: Text of Pope Paul's Address
description: ROME, Sept. 14 (AP)Following is the official text of the homily delivered in English today by Pope Paul VI at a mass at the Vatican in which Mother Elizabeth Ann Bayley Seaton was canonized a saint:

title: Decision to Renew License of WPIX Disputed by F.C.C. Unit as Erroneous
description: The Broadcast Bureau of the Federal Communications Commission, a staff office of the agency, has disputed the decision handed down by an F.C.C. Administrative law judge last December to renew the license of WPIX here and disqualify the competing applicant for Channel 11.

title: Strike by Patriots Cancels Jets Game
description: The pro football game between the New York Jets and the New England Patriots, scheduled for the Yale Bowl in New Haven, was canceled yesterday after the Patriots' players maintained their earlier refusal to play. On Saturday they had voted, 392, to strike the game, a preseason contest for which the Jets were to be the host team.

title: Thousands at Maryland Shrine Pay Homage to Mother Seton
description: EMMITSBURG, Md., Sept. 14 (UPI)  Some 35.000 pilgrims crowded this tiny mountain hamlet today to pay homage and visit the shrine of Elizabeth Ann Bayley Seton on the day of her canonization.

title: Mrs. Peron, on Leave, Flies to a Country Club
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 14 (Reuters) President Isabel Martinez de Peron, her country nearly bankrupt and ravaged by political crises, left Buenos Aires today after tearfully handing over executive power to the Senate president, Italo Luder.

title: John Sebastian Concert Closes Possibly Last Schaefer Season
description: The cold night air was ful?? of nostalgia and defiance Saturday night at the Wollman Rin?? in Central Park, The occasion was what may well have been the last in the 10 years of Schaefer Music Festival performances there. John Sebastian was the fitting headliner and both he and Ron Delsener producer of the serves since its inception, kept urging the caparity audience to write letters to Mayor Beame, stressing the importance of the festival over the Parks Department's ecological concerns.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AMIGOS New York City is celebrating Mexican Independence Week with, among other things, a collection of craftsmen such as silversmiths and weavers to demonstrate their talents in the Rockefeller Center Channel Gardens area off Fifth Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets at noon today.

title: Article 1  No Title
Sports News Briefs
description: Leonard Dahl, a 38yearold Staten Island amateur golf champion, won the New York City public links crown in a suddendeath playoff yesterday. Dahl ran in a birdie 4 at the first extra hole on the LaTourette course to beat 18yearold Frank Darby, a St. John's freshman. Junior honors went to 16yearold Kevin Joyce of Tottenville High School, who scored a 79 to win by four strokes. Will Ireland, a 58yearold tugboat pilot from Sandy Hook, captured the men's senior crown by five shots with an 82. Susan Morrison, despite an 8 at one hole, won the women's title by four shots with an 89. She is a physical education teacher at Newtown High in Queens. Mrs. Neil McNally of Sunnyside, Queens, took the women's senior title at the second extra hole, beating Rita Hellman of Dougiaston, Queens, after each had 92's.

title: Greetings
description: STARR Mr. And Mrs. Jacob, 1095 Pack Ave?? with all their relatives end friends a very healthy and happy New Year and thank them for their kind New Year wishes.

title: U.S.Born Mother Seton Is Declared a Saint
description: ROME, Sept. 14Before 100,000 people in St. Peter's Square, Pope Paul VI today declared Mother Elizabeth Ann Bayley Seton the first United Statesborn saint.

title: Blacks Are 20% of Boston But Have Limited Power
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14The sleek John Hancock Building towers gracefully over the Boston skyline, a symbol of the city's economic power.

title: Nicklaus Victor in Playoff
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Sept. 14  Jack Nicklaus won his fifth golf tournament of the season today with a flourish, rounding out a year in which he feels he has played better golf than he did in his sevenvictory year of 1972.

title: CITY SCHOOL BOARD WEIGHS REHIRING OF 2,000 LAID OFF
description: The Board of Educationis considering the possibility of using about $25million in unspent salaries and strike penalties to rehire 2,000 laidoff teachers to help reduce class sizes and improve school conditions.

title: Negotiators Make No Progress In Teachers' Strikes in State
description: New Jersey teachers and Board of Education officials in Hoboken and Englewood reported little progress in their contract negotiations yesterday as some 120,000 students in the two communities faced the prospect of no school this week.

title: SPECIAL SESSION OVER POOR LANDS IS CLOSING AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 14  The General Assembly's special session on the plight of the third world moved tonight toward a grim end, with delegates working virtually around the clock in search of a formula for narrowing the chasm between rich and poor lands.

title: LINDO C. JOHNSON
description: Lindo Cornish Johnson, president of Harry T. F. Johnson Real Estate, Inc., died Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived at 53 Moore Road, Bronxville, N. Y.

title: GENE O'GRADY TOOMEY
description: Gene O'Grady Toomey, a former president of the Washington Square Writers Club and widow of Edward A. Toomey, a research chemist who operated drug stores, died yesterday in Southampton (L. I.) Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived in Gondola Gardens, North Sea Rord, Southampton.

title: The Consumer and the Carpet Industry: Knotty Problems
description: The basement of the modest, threebedroom house in Massapequa, L.I., where Vincent and Jenny Palladino live does double duty: For their children, it's a television and recreation room; for them, when they have more than a few guests, it's a party room.

title: Stage: A Joe Orton Festival in London
description: LONDONJoe Orton nowadays seems an archetypal figure of the nineteensixties, with all its irreverence, thoughtful violence and questioning. His career effectively started in 1964 with a play in London, and subsequently on Broadway, Entertaining Mr. Sloane. and was ended by his murder in 1967, although his last play, What the Butler Saw, was produced posthumously two years later. These two plays, together with Loot, represent Orton's main claim on posterity's attention.

title: Yankee Goes 7 in 62 Verdict Over Indians
description: Catfish Hunter showed the Cleveland Indians yesterday that he is a better pitcher with two days rest than most pitchers are with the usual four.

title: 3 Groups Criticize Plan to Block U.S. Meat Inspection Takeover
description: WASHNGTON, Sept. 14A quietly developed plan that would enable thousands of state  inspected slaughtering plants to begin shipping meat in interstate commerce, under consideration in the Department of Agriculture, has been attacked by a combination of Congressional, consumer and packing industry forces.

title: EVE GROSZ FORMAN
description: Eve Grosz Forman, a found er in 1972 of Yonkers Prep, the alternative high school for that city, died Saturday of leukemia at her home in Yonkers. She was 45 years old and was the wife of Robert S. Forman.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1975

title: ISAAC HAYES SINGS IN NEW DISCO STYLE
description: Until a couple of years ago, Isaac Hayes was one of the biggest names in black music. His gloomy, bald, chainencrusted presence loomed everywhere, it seemed, and his music a sometimes glutinous, sometimes fascinating blend of whispers, soul shouts and tricky, extended instrumentalswas as influential as it was popular.

title: Congress Leaders Fight Curbs on Slush Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The new Federal Election Commission has suddenly found itself the target of the Senators and Representatives who set it up because of what some regard as overzealousness in monitoring the finances of Congressmenone of the functions for which the panel was created.

title: TeenAlters Happy to Shape Up and Ship Out
description: It was a Sunday morning and, as on almost every Sunday, 10yearold Norma Cerrito was up early. She was dressed in her denim work fatigues, waiting for the bus that would take her from her Brooklyn home to Port Richmond on Staten Island. Three hours later Norma was at the helm of a 23foot motor boat  by then dressed in her sailing whites  cruising toward the Verrazano  Narrows Bridge, taking her orders from her skipper, another Brooklyn youngster.

title: Spanish Pilgrims Clash With Vatican Protestors
description: ROME, Sept. 14 (UPI)A group of Spanish pilgrims in Rome for a Holy Year visit clashed outside St. Peter's Square today with demonstrators demanding legalized abortions. The encounter, halted immediately by the police, went unnoticed by the more than 100,000 people attending Pope Paul VI's canonization of Mother Seton.

title: U.S. Strategy to Tempt OPEC Members To Cut Oil Prices Is Urged by Professor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14For two years, M. A. Adelman, the oil economist, has been urging the Government to try to sovi it little confusion, perhaps ultimate havoc, in the ranks of the 13nation oil cartel, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Is This Big Parking Lot Where Brazil Used to Have the Amazon Region?
description: The largest of the remaining natural areas left on this planet to succumb to man's insatiable hunger for power and domination, or to civilization's alleged material needs, is the vast Amazon region with its great, yet extremely fragile, rainforest ecosystem.

title: CITY SCHOOL BOARD WEIGHS REHIRING OF 2,000 LAID OFF
description: The Board of Educationis considering the possibility of using about $25million in unspent salaries and strike peizalties to rehire 2,000 laidoff teachers to help reduce class sizes and improve school conditions.

title: Mayor Forcing the Departure Of Commissioner of Commerce
description: Mayor Beame has requested the resignation of the Commissioner of the city's Department of Commerce and Industry as the first step in eliminating that department altogether.

title: And Now the I. R. S.
description: WASHINGTONThe next Government spying operations to come under Senatorial scrutiny will be those of the Internal Revenue Service.

title: In Black Forest, the Hunt Is On
description: OBERBERGEN, West Germany Sept. 9Heribert Kalchreuter, a 36yearold forester, got up at 4 A.M. the other day, as he does every morning during the hunting season, and walked down the grassy knoll behind his rustic house to look for whitetail deer.

title: JANE S. CURLEY
description: Jane S. Curley, a retired teacher in the public schools of northern and central New Jersey, died Saturday in the Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J. She was 66 years old and lived at 361 Gilbert Street, Ridgewood.

title: Uranium Costs Up; Shortage Feared
