description: Uranium  a vital fuel in the nuclear production of powergives evidence that it soon may be in very short supply.

title: Desegregation Starts Smoothly For Schools in Stockton, Calif.
description: STOCKTON, Calif., Sept. 14 (AP)Southbound school buses carrying mostly white students and northbound buses with mostly minority students crossed the Calaveras River for the first time two weeks ago.

title: Citizens Band Radios Get Eased Rules Today
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 14 (UPI)Changes go into effect tomorrow that are intended to make Federal regulations easier for users of Citizens Band radios.

title: Opera: Ariadne Is Back
description: Sarah Caldwell's production of Richard Strauss's Adriadne auf Naxos remains one of the New York City Opera's strongest offerings, and thus its first appearance during the company's fall season yesterday afternoon was most welcome.

title: Jury to Investigate Bergen County Jail; Inquiry May Affect Election for Sheriff
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 14A grand jury is scheduled to begin investigating allegations Tuesday of drug traffic in the Bergen County Jail.

title: NO TALKS ARE HELD IN CATHOLIC STRIKES
description: No negotiations took place yesterday to settle a strike at five Roman Catholic schools in Brooklyn and Queens or to head off another threatened walkout tomorrow at 12 Roman Catholic schools in Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: A new state program that will assist elderly people in paying the cost of prescription drugs is to take effect next Jan. 1, according to Ann Klein, Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies.

title: Cleveland Sprayed To Kill Mosquitoes That Carry Disease
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 (AP)A plane flew over the Cleveland area today, spraying insecticide that city officials hope will kill swarms of mosquitoes and rid the city of further cases of encephalitis.

title: Memorial Services
description: LAVINEdwin. Memorial service Monday, Sept. 15, Promptly at 3, at St, Thomas Church, Filth Ave, at 53d St.

title: Famed Belgian Statue Gets Historic Rating
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 14 (Reuters)The Belgian Cabinet has decided to designate as a historic monument the MannekenPis, the 350yearold statue of a small boy urinating. It is a tourist attraction.

title: Dream of Jewish State Near Buffalo Is Recalled
description: As Jews everywhere observe Yom Kippur today and offer prayers for the safety of the Jewish state of Israel, Jews in Buffalo recall the dream that died stillborn 150 years ago therethe creation pf a Jewish homeland on Grand Island, a mile and a half from Niagara Falls.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: 60% of Deserters Leave Amnesty Service
description: HALF MOON BAY, Calif., Sept. 14When Saigon collapsed last spring, so did Gary Della Bitta's pledge to complete alternative service in the amnesty program created by President Ford one year ago in an executive order to bind up the nation's wounds.

title: Shopping Hints
description: If you're in the market for carpeting how can you be reasonably certain you are making a good choice at a good price? Experts on the industry make some suggestions:

title: EDWARD P. M'GUIRE
description: Edward P. McGuire, who had been a mailroom employe of The New York Times since 1941, died Friday of Pneumonia in Westchester Square Hospital, the Bronx. He was 64 years old and lived at 20 East 190th Street.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: GLENN E. RIGGS DIES; A RADIO ANNOUNCER
description: Glenn E. Riggs, a former network radio announcer in New York whose career spanned over 47 years, died Friday at his home in Malaga, Spain. He was 68 years old and had retired in 1972.

title: StrifeTorn Timor, Short of Food, Asks World Help
description: DILI, Portuguese Timor, Sept. 13The civil war in Portuguese Timor has created a food shortage that could become a major problem.

title: Article 2  No Title
GENE RONZANI DEAD; EXPACKERS COACH
description: LAC DU FLAMBEAU, Wis., Sept. 14 (UPI)Gene Ronzani, a former coach of the Green Bay Packers and an outstanding athlete at Marquette University, died here Friday at his cottage. He was 66 years old.

title: Petty Rallies From 8th to Win at Dover
description: DOVER, Del., Sept. 14 (AP)Richard Petty, who lost eight laps while his pit crew fixed a damaged tie rod, charged back from eighth place and scored a splitsecond victory in the Delaware 500 Grand National stock car race today.

title: Enmity Toward the Foreign Legion Grows in AutonomyMinded Corsica
description: CORTE, Corsica Relations between Corsicans and the French Foreign Legion, the man in the cafe said simply, are not good. His sister had married a legionnaire, and so he knew a little of the story from both sides.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL. ASSEMBLY

title: Farmers Market in Paterson Is Thriving
description: PATERSON  Young couples push plump babies in aluminum strollers. Housewives combine forces to buy in bulk. Gourmets ferret out fresh herbs or exotic condiments. And the elderly buy as if their lives depended on it.

title: Youth Shoots His Brother In Dispute Over Stereo
description: A 17yearold youth shot his 16yearold brother in the back last night, according to the police, who said the brothers had been arguing over who would use stereo earphones in their Harlem apartment when the shooting occurred at about 11:30 P.M.

title: Chile Team Persuaded to Go
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Sept. 14Yamile Prajoux cried during the longdistance telephone conversation with her son, Belus, yesterday.

title: An American Saint
description: Canonization is a rare event in the life of the Roman Catholic Church. A saint has to be not only a good man or woman but a person of heroic virtues and unique sanctity. After years of study and analysis of the evidence of her life and work, the church has now inscribed the name of Elizabeth Ann Seton in its calendar of saints.

title: Surgery for Indian Suspect
description: ARKANSAS CITY, Kan., Sept. 15 (AP)One of six South Dakota Indians charged last week with violating Federal firearms laws was in fair condition today after surgery for injuries suffered when the group's car exploded on the Kansas Turnpike. Robert Eugene Robideau, 28 years old, was recovering from injuries to his eyes and face.

title: Europe's Minorities Are More Vocal, if Not More Violent
description: PARIS, Sept. 15  Conflicts between ethnic minorities and their governments have been flaring up again in Western Europe.

title: LOUISIANA'S JAILS ARE BEING PACKED
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 15A Federal judge's order to stop sending prisoners to the overcrowded Louisiana State Penitentiary has created a ripple effect. Parish or county, prisons are now being packed because their inmates can no longer be sent to the state institution.

title: Bill to Seek Food Stamp Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)Senator Lawton Chiles. Democrat of Florida, said today that he would sponsor legislation to remove 650,000 undeserving persons from food stamp rolls at a saving of $250million yearly. He said that the theory behind food stamps had been to help feed the hungry poor, but that somewhere along the line, the intent and the results have been distorted so that too many people are involved at too great a cost. The Senator will introduce the legislation tomorrow.

title: WorldCircling Schooner Sails In With a Glum Fish Story
description: The Norma & Gladys docked at Fulton Street and the East River yesterday, carrying with her a crew from Newfoundland and a story about the Grand Banks fishery. The story was that the fishery is being fished out.

title: RISING RATES FACE TREASURY'S NOTES
description: Interest rates continued to rise yesterday as the credit markets braced for the sale of 83billion of twoyear Treasury notes that are expected to carry rates of 8 per cent or more.

title: LAWSUIT CAUSES CHURCH DISPUTE
description: FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 15 A suit by five Roman Catholics, including two nuns, against the Most Rev. Daniel T. Cronin, Bishop of Fall River, has led to a controversy over whether the five plaintiffs have been excommunicated for their action against the Bishop.

title: Article 1  No Title
Senators Hear C.I.A. Sent A Poison to Kill Lumumba
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence has heard testimony that the Central Intelligence Agency transferred poison to an African outpost in 1961 for use in killing Patrice Lumumba, the Congolese leader, but that the poison was never administered, sources familiar with the testimony said today.

title: ExJunta Leader Charges Athens Reneges on Pledge
description: ATHENS, Sept. 15 (Reuters)Demetrios Ioannides, strongman of the former Greek junta, today accused the current Government of going back on an agreement that no officer would be prosecuted for taking part in the 1957 coup that set up a military dictatorship.

title: Chief of Mine Academy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The Interior Department announced today the appointment of Michael G. Zabetakis as superintendent of the National Mine Health and Safety Academy at Beckley, W. Va. Mr. Zabetakis, a mine safety researcher from the United States Bureau of Mines, has been acting superintendent of the new academy for the last year.

title: 2 on L I. Sued for Libel Over Kickbacks
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 15The motherinlaw of Assemblyman Joseph M. Margiotta, hairman of the Nassau County Republican Committee, has charged in a $1million suit that she was libeled when her former superior said on a television program that she had requested a 1 per cent salary kickback to the Republican party from a former county emplove.

title: 27 Major Banks of Grant's Agree to Subordinate Loans
description: The W. T. Grant Company, the store chain, which lost. $111million in the 26 weeks ended in July, reported yesterday that its 27 major banks had formally agreed to subordinate $300million of loans to Grant's debts to venders.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: Connecticut's deerhunting regulations have been substantially changed this year, but any attempt to tersely describe them leaves one crying for madder music and stronger wine, for they are an incredible blend of sound management procedures and political expediency.

title: Sadai Assails Pressure By Palestinians and Soviet
description: CAIRO, Sept. 15President Anwar elSadat, in a defiant and angry speech, pledged tonight that no amount of pressure from the Soviet Union, the Palestinians or any other source would cause Egypt to deviate from the policy he had chosen for her.

title: Against Themselves
description: Not for the first time, the displaced peoples of Palestine are being illserved by powerhungry terrorists who claim to represent their interests, but succeed only in perpetuating bitterness and suffering. Yesterday's Palestinian raid upon the Egyptian Embassy in Madrid was properly perceived by President Sadat as an affront to the whole Arab world, to responsible governments far better placed than freewheeling criminals to bring a bettering of the Palestinians' lot.

title: The Fight for Disability Benefits in Pregnancy
description: A cause that has managed to unite women from feminists to members of the Right to Life movement is the right to disability benefits for time lost due to pregnancy.

title: Tanner Battles to 3Set Victory
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15Roscoe Tanner, the lightning southpaw server from Lookout Mountain, Tenn., was under inspection at the Pacific Southwest open tennis championships today. The new Davis Cup captain, Tony Trabert, was taking a look here at four of the six players he had picked for the squad in preparation for the 1976 firstround series with Venezuela Oct. 17 to 19 at Tucson, Ariz.

title: Business Briefs
description: Investors who buy stock on credit reduced their indebtedness during August for the first time this year, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday. The quality of credit, meanwhile, a barometer of customer vulnerability, declined sharply in August after a modest deterioration in July. Margin debt fell $80million to $5.24billion in August from $5.32billion in July.

title: PENTAGON YIELDED TO FORD ON CANAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The White House succeeded in breaking a deadlock in the Pentagon on controversial aspects of a new Panama Canal treaty last summer, permitting the Ford Administration to, resume stalled negotiations in Panama this month, toplevel Washington officials said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Lobby Employers Facing State Fines

title: Court Frees Journalist in India; Others May Now Seek Release
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 15 (AP)A New Delhi high court overturned the jailing of a prominent journalist today, ruling that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi must be prepared with specific charges to back up her use of the Internal Security Act to arrest critics of her Government.

title: Pulling Out Plums
description: A small but significant step has been taken by the State Office of Court Administration to control patronageone of the venerable hidden powers of political leaders that causes cynicism about the evenhandedness of the judicial system in New York. Under a new set of guidelines, plums handed out to certain specialists practicing in the courts will be carefully recorded and supervised when compensation exceeds $100.

title: Rockefeller Opens Exhibit In London for Bicentennial
description: LONDON, Sept. 15 (UPI)Vice President Rockefeller and Prime Minister Harold Wilson today opened an exhibition, The World of Franklin and Jefferson, as a prelude to American Bicentennial celebrations.

title: Violence Flares in Beirut and Tripoli; 12 Leftists Killed in Clash With Army
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 15Scattered sniping and machinegun fire emptied streets in several outlying Beirut neighborhoods today, while in the northern city of Tripoli armed men raided police stations and occupied the town hall

title: PROF. TINGYEE KUO, EXPERT ON EAST ASIA
description: Prof. Tingyee Kuo. founder of the Institute of Modern History of the Academia Sinica on Taiwan in 1955 and its director until 1972, died Sunday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 552 RivIerside Drive.

title: 11 INDICTED BY U.S. OVER SHIP LOANS
description: Two major Greek shipowners, five of their business associates and four former bank officials have been indicted here on Federal charges involving a scheme that allegedly caused more than $60million in bank loans to be obtained fraudulently.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept 15 (UPI)Charles O. Finley received $100,000 from Gene Autry last year for the right to sign Dick Williams as manager of the California Angels, the Oakland A's owner said in an interview published today. Finley said Autry had approached him about Williams's services after the A's owner successfully blocked the New York Yankees from hiring Williams. Autry said he planned to dismiss Bobby Winkles as his manager, according to Finley. He asked me to release Dick so he could sign him immediately. I told him I would release Williams and void a court order only if he gave me a hundred thousand dollars. Autry thought about that for a minute, then agreed to pay.

title: RICHFIELD SHIPMENT TO OIL FIELD DELAYED
description: LONDON, Sept. 15 (Reuters) The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that bad weather was delaying shipment of equipment to the Prudhoe Bay oil field.

title: Public Defender Is Named to Protect Rights of Girl in Coma Since April
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 15 Superior Court Judge Robert Muir Jr. today appointed a public defender to protect the rights of a 21yearold girl who has been in a coma since April and whose parents are seeking permission to withdraw mechanical lifesustaining procedures from her.

title: Advertising
description: I've got a 10,000acre oil field out there, said Arthur C. Elliot, salesman, speaking figuratively. And nobody's drilling, added William J. Lucano, an associate, in the same vein.

title: Waldheim Sends Greetings
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15  Secretary General Waldheim sent his congratulations today to newly independent Papua New Guinea and paid tribute to the Australian Gov ernment for bringing the territory toward its new status. It is the 10th United Nations trust territory to gain independence. Only the Pacific Islands administered by the United States remain under the United Nations' aegis.

title: Chad Tribal Chief Seeks Release of Frenchwoman
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, Sept. 15 (AP)The chief of the Toubou tribe left here today on what sources said was probably a mission to obtain the freedom of a Frenchwoman being held by Toubou rebels under threat of death.

title: Hearing Draws Foes of Utah Power Plant That Would Be Near National Parks
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 15Organized opposition to power plant construction in southern Utah made its first major public appearance today as Federal hearings began on the huge proposed Kaiparowits project.

title: Upgrading the Legal Profession
description: In the last several years, few issues have so divided the legal profession as the proposal to require minimum qualifications for lawyers seeking to practice in the Federal trial courts in New York, Connecticut and Vermont. The proposal, which would require wouldbe Federal trial lawyers to take five courses either in law school or afterward, was debated once again last week at a meeting in Buck Hills Falls, Pa., of lawyers, legal educators and judges from the three states that make up the Second Judicial Circuit.

title: Credit Rater Warns State On Additional Aid to City
description: Standard & Poor's, the investment rating service, warned yesterday that any further state emergency assistance to the city would jeopardize the state's credit rating and fiscal integrity.

title: People and Business
description: If bankrupt railroads qualify for Federal aid, can the rest of the troubled industry lag far behind? This prospect is raised by Representative Brock Adams, Democrat of Washington, who called on Congress yesterday not only to approve a plan for consolidating bankrupt Northeast and Midwest railroads in a new system called Conrail, but to vote Federal aid for the entire railroad industry.

title: M.A.C. Forced Into Role of Selling City, With Its Budgetary Functions Unused
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation has been forced to become a fulltime borrowing agency devoted to selling the city to local and national investors, without ever exercising the budgetary functions it was given when it was formed in June.

title: SEOULTOKYO TALK IS NONCOMMITTAL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 15A Japanese delegation declined today to make a commitment to contribute now to South Korean security and economic development, underscoring the continuing lukewarm relations between the northeast Asian neighbors.

title: LIFE IS PEACEFUL IN MEKONG DELTA
description: MY THO, South Vietnam, Sept. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)  Since the war ended the Mekong Delta has apparently become a peaceful land, and My Tho, with its floating houses and promenades along the majestic Mekong River, is one of its most attractive cities.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A program of heirloom appraisals and lectures on antiques at the Larchmont (N.Y.) Yacht Club will take place on Thursday and not in April, as reported in The New York Times on Sunday.

title: Pope Appeals for Saving of U.S. Schools
description: ROME, Sept. 15 (AP)Pope Paul VI urged United States churchmen today to make untiring efforts to preserve the Roman Catholic school system, begun in the early 19th century by St. Elizabeth Ann Seton, the first nativeborn American saint.

title: KENTUCKY FILES ANTIBUSING SUIT
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 15 (AP)A suit designed to spark the enactment of a constitutional amendment that would end school busing to achieve desegregation was filed in Federal court today by Gov. Julian Carroll.

title: Delbert Mills of RCA Dies; Consumer Products' Chief
description: Delbert L. Mills, who was senior executive vice president of RCA Corporation for consumer products and components from 1967 to his retirement in 1970, died Saturday in Naples; Fla., where he was active in real estate and banking. He was 67 years old.

title: Liza D. Pulitzer Is Bride Of Robert Lee Terry Jr.
description: Liza Davis Pulitzer, daughter of Lilly Pulitzer, the designer, was married in Palm Beach, Fla., last evening to Robert Lee Terry Jr., a freelance cinematographer.

title: Scott, Jet Receiver, Out for Year
description: The Giants, the Jets and the 24 other teams of the National Football League trimmed their rosters yesterday to the required 4 players in advance of the scheduled start of the season on Sunday.

title: Rationing Medical Care
description: Vice President Rockefeller has created a ministorm by asserting that government cannot afford to give everyone first class medical care. Mr. Rockefeller's critics feel particularly betrayed because as Governor of New York he was an outspoken advocate of national health insurance and a decade ago sponsored the most generous state Medicaid law in the nation.

title: P.L.O. Dissociates Itself
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 15The Palestine Liberation Organization tonight dissociated itself from the hostagetaking in Madrid, but a radical Marxist group issued a statement endorsing it.

title: Ford Says Grain Sales Will Resume, but Ban Remains
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15President Ford assured farm organization officials today that grain sales to the Soviet Union would be resumed, but he refused to lift a moratorium on such sales until Moscow accepts a longterm agreement designed to lessen the impact on domestic food prices.

title: Emergency Actions Seen Little Aid in Gas Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) Even if the coming winter is mild, emergency actions can make only a small dent in the expected shortages of natural gas, top energy officials said today.

title: Pennsy Scores U.S. Plan To Compensate Railroads
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (Reuters) The Penn Central Company said today a Federal plan to compensate stockholders and creditors of bankrupt Northeastern Railroads is unfair, unreasonable and transparently confiscatory.

title: Chinese Formally Open Trade With the Common Market
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 15 After three years of cautious contacts, China formally opened diplomatic relations with the European Common Market today.

title: Chess:
description: Larry Christiansen won the United States Junior Invitational Champiohship in Norristown, Pa., for the third time this year. The only consolation his fallen opponents have now is that he became 20 years old during the 1975 event and thus ineligible for the 11th competition in the series, planned for next June.

title: Aerosol Cans Get the Squeeze
description: The stories about the possible dangerous effects aerosol on the atmosphere are having their impact on the marketplace. Manufacturers of products sold in aerosol cans are rushing out with new containers that do not use the suspect fluorocarbon propellant.

title: Senators Hear C.I.A. Sent A Poison to Kill Lumumba
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence has heard testimony that the Central Intelligence Agency transferred poison to an African outpost in 1961 for use in killing Patrice Lumumba, the Congolese leader, but that the poison was never administered, sources familiar with the testimony said today.

title: CHAVEZ SEES VOTES ON COAST TAINTED
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif. Sept. 15 (AP)  Cesar Chavez, leader of the United Farm Workers, said today that all the elections held under California's new farm labor law have been 'tainted.

title: Credit Rater Warns State On Additional Aid to City
description: Standard & Poor's, the investment rating service, warned yesterday that any further state emergency assistance to the city would jeopardize the state's credit rating and fiscal integrity.

title: YONKERS COUNCIL RESISTS 2 COURTS
description: YONKERS, Sept. 15Can a city and its governing council be held in contempt of court? Yonkers may find out next Monday if its Council continues to withhold permission for Sarah Lawrence College to build new dormitories.

title: Sermons on Yom Kippur Urge Basic Rights for Jews in Soviet
description: As Yom Kippurthe 24hourperiod of fasting and prayerended at sundown yesterday, rabbis in sermons called on the Kremlin to grant Soviet Jews religious freedom and their right to emigrate, and cited Israel's willingness to achieve a permanent peace in the Middle East.

title: HERBERT WINTER
description: Herbert Winter, a founder and partner in Winter Wolff & Co., a steel export and import concern, died Saturday of a heart attack in Paris, while on a business trip. He was 77 years old and lived at 35 East 75th Street.

title: Exit Mrs. Peron
description: Isabel Martnez de Pern has finally taken a Ieave of absence as President of Argentina, officially for reasons of health but there are doubts that the 44yearold former dancer will ever return to the Casa Rosada in Buenos Aires. Her political fate may depend in large part on how effective her replacement, Senate President Italo Luder, proves in restoring order, rebuilding unity in the Peronist movement and reviving a moribund economy.

title: Back to School . . .
description: The proposed settlement in the weekold teachers' strike is working its laborious way through the wrapup process, with hopes high that classes will reopen tomorrow. Essential as is a swift end to the damaging interruption in the education of a million children, the peace terms reflect only dim awareness by either the United Federation of Teachers or the Board of Education of the desperateness of the city's financial crunch.

title: Basin Petroleum And Reserve Oil Co. Agree on a Merger
description: The Reserve Oil & Gas Company and Basin Petroleum Corporation announced jointly that they had signed a definitive merger agreement, which would result in Basin's becoming a wholly owned subsidiary of Reserve Oil. The transaction would involve about four million Basin shares for a total of about $40million.

title: U.P.I. Appoints Winship As News Feature Director
description: Frederick M. Winship, assistant managing editor of United Press International, will direct the news agency's worldwide newsfeature and enterprise service, it was announced yesterday by Paul. G. Eberhart, the agency's managing editor.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Pro Football's Stubborn Quarterback
description: After more than 17 months without a first down in their labor dispute with the club owners, the National Football League players appear to be realizing that Ed Garvey is too stubborn to he a winning quarterback.

title: France Invites 27 Lands To Meet on Economic Ills
description: PARIS, Sept. 15  France has invited major developed and developing countries to reconvene a preparatory meeting on energy and other problems of the world's rich and poor nations in Paris on Oct. 13.

title: Eritreans Threaten to Kill 4 Americans Unless U.S. Halts Arms Aid to Ethiopia
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 15 (AP)Eritrean rebels threatened today, to kill four American prisoners held in a mountain cave in northern Ethiopia unless the United States halted arms supplies to Ethiopia's military Government.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1975

title: N.F.L. Talks Are Pressed
description: Representatives of the National Football League Management Council and the players' association met in closed session late last night in Washington in an attempt to solve the labor dispute that jeopardizes the start of the regular season on Sunday.

title: Boys of Winter Break New Ice on Long Island
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 15Wearing a white bandage over his brow, Pete Stemkowski stood out like a sore eye today as the New York Rangers opened their National Hockey League training camp. A full complement of 34 players skated under the watchful eye of a new coach, Ron Stewart, at a new site, the Nassau County Arena.

title: ULSTER PROTESTANT REJOINS COALITION
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, ept. 15William Craig, leader of a Protestant party, today vithdrew his resignation as head of the 12 members of his party elected to a convenion deliberating Ulster's contitutional future.

title: Male Sex Debility Traced to Marijuana
description: A new study of men who smoked marijuana daily under controlled conditions has shown that the drug can interfere with production of reproductive hormones, in some cases suppressing the male sex hormone, testosterone, to levels that could result in impotence or infertility.

title: U.S. May Impose Embargo on Import Of Some Tuna Fish
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The Commerce Department announced today that it intended to impose an embargo on some imported tuna fish, a move that could cut off much of the tuna sold in the United States.

title: O. P. KRETZMANN, LED VAUBAN U.
description: The Rev. Dr. O. P. Kretzmann, president, emeritus of Valparaiso University in Indiana, died Sunday. He was 74 years old.

title: Wildlife Unit Plans Data Bank to Help To Save Bald Eagle
description: A computerized data bank will be set up by the National Wildlife Federation in its headquarters in Washington as a Bicentennial project to help to save the American bald eagle from extinction.

title: Truck Spill Halts Traffic
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (UPI)  A truck spilled 150 gallons of two chemicals that combine to form a poisonous gas on the Hollywood Freeway in the rush hour this morning, tying up traffic for nearly an hour. Five fir company units washed down the chemicals, muratic acid and chlorine, and California highway patrolmen closed all lanes of traffic in both directions and nearby surface streets.

title: Papua New Guinea Celebrates Independence
description: PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea, Tuesday, Sept. 16At the stroke of midnight a fireworks display lit up the Port Moresby sky to signal the beginning of independence for Papua New Guinea.

title: France Invites 27 Lands To Meet on Economic Ills
description: PARIS, Sept. 15 France has invited major developed and developing countries to reconvene a preparatory meeting on energy and other problems of the world's rich and poor nations in Paris on Oct. 13.

title: VERA RICHARD
description: Vera Van Buren Richard, a member of the board of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service and the Hospital for Special Surgery, died yesterday at her home in York Harbor, Me. She was 82 years old and maintained a second home at 1060 Fifth Avenue. Her late husband, Harold C. Richard, was a banker.

title: People in Sports
description: The New York Knicks have signed Larry Fogle, their secondround draft choice, to a multiyear contract.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Top Horses, RSVP:
description: The nation's top thoroughbred of 1975 could be decided by the $350,000 National Championships on Nov. 1 at Santa Anita in Arcadia, Calif.

title: Army Rebuilding Town It Is Going to Make Disappear
description: Giant metal cranes loom over the area as residents flee. Growling earthmovers carve up the yards and topple the trees, knock over the houses and haul the remnants away.

title: Fed Outlines Plan That Helps Protect Credit Card Users
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 15. (Reuters)The Federal Reserve Board today outlined measures designed to give credit card holders greater legal protection including refusal to payif they feel they have been sold shoddy or defective merchandise.

title: Minneapolis Enjoying Heyday as an Upbeat Metropolis
description: MINNEAPOLISOn aging but still elegant Summit Avenue in St. Paul, where F. Scott Fitzgerald once resided at number 599, they still like to call Minneapolis Mill City.

title: Neither Side Happy
description: Neither the Board of Education nor the United Federation of Teachers is altogether pleased with the contract settlement they were attempting to work out last night, but both sides thought that under the cir cumstances it was the best they could do. The board, unhappy about the proposal to shorten the school day, nonetheless thought it would make real productivity gains in wresting two free periods from some teachers. The union, facing the loss of their previously won gain, consoled itself with the possible rehiring of 2,000 teachers.

title: Plane Hijacker Killed in San Jose, Calif.
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 15 (AP)A gunman seeking to flee aboard an airliner that he had hijacked was shot and killed by a police marksman today after two hours of violence that left one of his four hostages critically wounded.

title: Contract Awards
description: A contract totaling about $90million for the design and construction of an addition to the Gresik cement plant in Indonesia, has been received by the MorrisonKnudsen International Company, Boise. Idaho. The company said the contract represents the third expansion of the plant, which it orientally built in 1955.

title: WALTER HERBERT, 73, OF SAN DIEGO OPERA
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) Walter Herbert, director of the San Diego Opera, died yesterday at the age of 73.

title: Bridge:
description: Bridge enthusiasts who scour the emporiums of Fifth Avenue for books on their favorite game seldom realize that they are looking in the wrong place. By far the biggest collection of bridge books for sale in New York City is to be found in an obscure brownstone at 39 West 94th Street, the offices of The Bridge World Magazine (telephone, 8665860).

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CLASS. The Cafe Carlyle, which has attracted a clientele of wealth and royalty, has been described as small, oblong, dark, comfortable room. On the other hand, Bobby Short, the impeccable superclub singerpianist, has been described as an inventive, faultless dresser. And tonight the faultless dresser returns to the dowdy room to begin his eighth year there.

title: Court Asked to Rule On P.U.C.'s Powers In a Noise Dispute
description: TRENTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)New Jersey's Public Advocate asked the Appellate Division of Superior Court today to direct the Board of Public Utility Commissioners to act on alleged noise pollution by Erie Lackawanna freight trains traveling through North Jersey at night.

title: Coast Area Hit by a Quake Reportedly Sank 6 Inches
description: OROVILLE, Calif., Sept. 15 (AP)The Oroville area, shaken last month by an earthquake that measured 6.1 on the Richter scale, has sunk about six inches in relation to the Sierras, according to a Federal study.

title: Lawyer Gets Post
description: ALBANY, Sept. 15 (AP)Victor Kovner, a member of the Manhattan law firm of Lankenau, Kovner Bickford and longtime advocate of changes in the state's court system, was appointed by Governor Carey today to the Temporary State Commission on Judicial Conduct. The commission investigates complaints against judges and recommends disciplinary action. It would be replaced by a permanent commission with broader powers under a proposed state constitutional amendment to be toted in November.

title: Memoriam Services
description: CROSSH. Page, Memorial service Wednesday, September 17 at 11 A.M, at St. James Church, Madison Ave. at 71 St.

title: Fillol Says He'll Play In Sweden
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15Jaime Fillol will play for Chile against Sweden in the Davis Cup, after all.

title: Free Time of Teachers a Factor
description: The city's Board of Education has enough teacherssomething close to 50.000to provide one for every 22 pupils if all could be used in classrooms. Even allowing for those unavailable because of contracted preparation periods or specialized subjects, this would be one for every 32 pupils.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: CEMETERIES

title: Books of The Times
description: Even if you don't care at all about sailing, or don't happen to recall the outcome of the 1974 America's Cup competitionin which the United States 12meter yacht Courageous, skippered by Ted Hood, thrashed Australia's Southern Cross in four straight racesthe clouds of impending disaster gather early in this lively narrative by Roger Vaughan. The Grand Gesture:

title: Sadat Assails Pressure By Palestinians and Soviet
description: CAIRO, Sept. 15President Anwar elSadat, in a defiant and angry speech, pledged tonight that no amount of pressure from the Soviet Union, the Palestinians or any other source would cause Egypt to deviate from the policy he had chosen for her.

title: Striking Chicago Teachers Plan To Set Up Alternative Schools
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) Striking teachers prepared today to set up alternative schools in An attempt to get the city's 530,000 public school pupils back into the classrooms.

title: Wanted:
description: We are in a fiscal mess. We invited with Federal and state acquiescence and support too many blacks and Puerto Ricans when we manifestly had neither room nor jobs for them. The effects were not merely regional but nationwide. We induced cheap labor to come here to glut a fullup market. We created a huge relief program only part of which should on any reasonable theory fall on New York. We have had little sympathy and aid from Washington.

title: BYRNE ASKS U.S. AID FOR MERCER COUNTY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)President Ford was asked today to declare Mercer County a Federal disaster area because of the damage done by the breakdown of the area's water filtration plant on Aug. 31.

title: Army Rebuilding Town It Is Going to Make Disappear
description: NORTH BONNEVILLE, Wash.This town is disappearing. Giant metal cranes loom over the area as residents flee. Growling earthmovers carve up the yards and topple the trees, knock over the houses and haul the remnants away.

title: Chapin Asks High Court To Review Perjury Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Dwight L. Chapin, onetime appointments secretary to President Nixon, asked the Supreme Court today to review his perjury conviction.

title: SENATOR ASKS BAN ON SPRAY CAN GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, urged Congress today to ban the use of spray can gases, saying that it will take a decade to clear up the damage that such gases may already have done to the earth's ozone radiation shield.

title: NURSING HOMES ASK FIRE RULES CAUTION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)  The nation's largest nursing home federation has asked Congress to avoid an overzealous approach to fire safety in nursing homes.

title: President Signs Order Ending Clemency Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)President Ford signed today an Executive order terminating the Presidential Clemency Board, created a year ago to help Vietnam war resisters clear their records and return to normal lives.

title: WISCONSIN DISPUTES DEMOCRATS' RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15Attorney General Bronson C. LaFollette of Wisconsin filed suit in Federal District Court here today against the Democratic National Committee challenging the 1976 delegate selection rules of the national Democratic party.

title: State Relief Aide Looks to U.S. Funds
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Sept. 15 (AP)  County officials should look to the Federal Government, and not the state, for more money to help pay for welfare programs, a top official of the State Social Services Department said today.

title: OPEC ECONOMIC UNIT TO BEGIN OIL TALKS
description: BEIRUT, Sept. 15The Economic Commission of the Ogranization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is scheduled to convene tomorrow in Vienna with several important member states pushing for an increase in the price of oil.

title: Off Broadway Opera Troupes Thrive
description: Like the theater, opera has its Off Broadway companies, which put on productions varying greatly in quality, kind and interest. The companiesabout 30 have some sort of permanencemay be of workshop origin, the outgrowth of a vocal studio, a school operation or just the result of one person's love for opera.

title: 2 School Strikes Persist, With Settlement at College
description: NEWARK, Sept. 15Teachers' strikes that delayed the return to classes of thousands of New Jersey students this month narrowed to two school systems, those in Hoboken and Englewood, as the 79 faculty members of Gloucester County College ended their walkout this morning.

title: Dow Stock Index Off 6.10 In Light Holiday Trading
description: Stocks declined for the fifth consecutive session yesterday in extremely light turnover reflecting the Yom Kippur holiday. The decline was characterized by a lack of buying interest with price changes mostly minor.

title: Growing Charismatic Movement Is Facing Internal Discord Over a Teaching Known as Discipling
description: The fastgrowing charismatic movement is facing its first major difficulty as a result of a controversial teaching about church authority.

title: Ford Signs 3 Proclamations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) President Ford signed three annual proclamations today, naming Oct. 9 as Leif Ericson Day. Oct. 11 as General Pulaski Memorial Day and the week of Oct. 12 as National School Lunch Week.

title: ExTexas Official Seeking Study of F.B.I.Oswald Ties
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept, 15 (AP) Former State Attorney General Waggoner Carr has urged the United States Senate to investigate possible connections between Lee Harvey Oswald and the Federal Bureau of Investigation or the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Irish Top Eagles By 173
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 15 Dan Devine's debut as the Notre Dame football coach was a rousing success as the Irish shattered the high hopes of Boston College with a 173 victory tonight before a record crowd of 61,501 in Schaefer Stadium.

title: F.T.C. Asserts Safeway Stores Cheated on Ads for Food Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission accused Safeway Stores Inc, the nation's largest supermarket chain, today of cheating consumers by advertising food at sale prices but selling it at regular prices. The loss to shoppers, one commission lawyer said, has been substantial over the years, although no complete dollar estimate has been made.

title: . . .Those Tiny, Trendy Purses
description: America's top designers are showing undernourished little handbags in their resort collections, but the trend was picked up even earlier by handbag manufacturers. The big news in their current collections is small, smaller, smallest.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: John J. Fitzgerald, 70, Dies; Retired General in Guard
description: John J. Fitzgerald, a retired major general in the New York National Guard who commanded the artillery of the 42d Infantry Division, died Sunday at his home, 17 Oswego Avenue, Long Beach, L. I. He was 70 years old.

title: Edward Dodd Dies at 58; President of Diamond Salt
description: Edward M. Dodd, president and chief executive officer since 1970 of the Diamond Crystal Salt Company in St. Clair, Mich., died there on Saturday. He was 58 years old.

title: Imetal Starting to Fight In Bid to Add Copperweld
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15Societ Imetal, the French firm controlled by the Rothschild family that wants to purchase the stock of the Copperweld Corporation, began to fight back today against efforts by Copperweld to block the sale.

title: Sliding Oil Prices Set by Australians To Aid Exploration
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 15 (AP)  The Australian Government is introducing a sliding scale of oil prices to encourage more domestic exploration, but some major companies say it is unfairly distributed and inadequate.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: As one of its fall events, the Jewish Museum at Fifth Avenue and 92d Street will exhibit Jewish Experience in the Art of the 20th Century.

title: New Saint Is Honored in Surroundings Linked to Formative Events in Her Life
description: A jubilant throng of New Yorkers yesterday honored the newest Roman Catholic saint as one of their own in the environs where many of the formative events of her life took place.

title: AUGHT OUTPUT UP BY 1.3%, INDICATING GAIN IN RECOVERY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15Industrial production rose strongly in August, further evidence of recovery in the economy, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: $199 Flight Is Urged To Coast and Back
description: Pan American World Airways made a new effort yesterday to gain an entry into the 48state domestic market by proposing a New YorkSan Francisco roundtrip fare of $199.

title: All Knocks Out Punch Lines in His Debut in Manila
description: MANILA, Sept. 15Muhammad Ali, clowning, versifying, alternately taunting and fraternizing, entertained several hundred Manitans who turned out to welcome him today.

title: SANITATION FORCE PUSHES CLEANUP
description: Working under the glare of intensive publicity and the scrutiny of an angry Mayor, the Sanitation Department yesterday bent to the task, ordered by Mr. Beanie, of cleaning up the city by Saturday.

title: In Memoriam
description: LOREN, Alexander  September 12, 1975. Dear Brother, Only Heaven knows why foul assassins would take your sweet, gentle life. May they Quickly be apprehended but never absolved before their god. Pleasant Dreams, Brother Jerry.

title: F.E.A. MAY REQUEST OILCOMPANY DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)The Federal Energy Administration proposed today to require detailed financial reports from all petroleum refining companies and a random sampling of producing and marketing firms.

title: U. N. TALKS FAIL TO REACH ACCORD
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Tuesday, Sept. 16For the fourth consecutive night, delegates were working to wind up the special session of the United Nations General Assembly by overcoming remaining, disagreements on ways to bridge the gap between rich and poor nations.

title: STANLEY YARMUTH, LED CONGLOMERATE
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 15 (UPI)  Stanley R. Yarmuth, who developed National Industries, Inc., into a publicly owned conglomerate that listed revenues of $807.1million last fiscal year, died today. He was 50 years old.

title: American League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Strike Talks to Resume
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Negotiations are scheduled to resume tomorrow at 11 a.m. between the Electric Boat Company and 10.000 members of the Metal Trades Council who have been on strike 12 weeks.

title: Bail Plea for Miss Fromme
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 15 (UPI)  Lynette Alice Fromme, accused of attempting to assassinate President Ford, is to return to court tomorrow to ask for reduction of her $1million bail. Her lawyer has objected to her being designated as a high risk defendant, meaning that her trial should be held within 60 to 90 days.

title: Garden Lists 10 Soviet Heavyweights
description: A team of 10 heavyweights from the Soviet Union will face a squad from the United States in a oneday amateur boxing tournament at Madison Square Garden Nov. 14. Headine the Soviet team will be the world amateur heavyweight champion, Ivor Vysotsky. The American team Will be led by four heavyweights who are expected to compete in the PanAmerican Games next month in Mexico City. The most prominent is Mike Dokes of Akron, Ohio, the national Amateur Athletic Union titleholder.

title: GUARD SUCCUMBS TO INMATE'S SHOT
description: George Motchau, a 45yearold prison guard, died yesterday of gunshop wounds inflicted by a prisoner who escaped from his custody at Kings County Hospital last Tuesday.

title: East's Netmen Win Super Senior Event
description: The East defeated the West, 13 matches to 5, in the second annual Super Senior tennis team competition for the Redgrave Trophy at the West Side Tennis Club yesterday.

title: Two Ford Appointments
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) President Ford today named former Representative William G. Bray, Republican of Indiana to be a member of the American Battle Monuments Commission. Mr. Bray succeeds the late Rear Adm. Leslie E. Gehres. Mr. Ford also appointed Donald B. Siniff, a University of Minnesota biologist, to the Marine Mammal Commission for a term expiring May 13, 1978. Mr. Siniff, from MarineontheSt. Croix, Minn., succeeds A. Starker Leopold, whose term expired.

title: TWO RICH TEXANS GO ON TRIM TODAY
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 15The wiretapping trial of two wealthy oil men, Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt, opens here tomorrow.

title: Twizzlers and Nibs Seek to Resolve Identity Crisis
description: WESTFIELD, Sept. 15If you are one of the many Americans who can't tell a Nib from a Twizzler, don't fret. The condition is merely temporary, or so Y & S Candies, Inc., earnestly hopes.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1975

title: Delegates of 40 Nations Meet in Las Vegas to Coordinate Global Monitoring of Environment
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 15A new phase in efforts against pollution was marked today as some 800 scientists, engineers and public officials from 40 nations met for five days of discussions about monitoring of the environment.

title: MRS. HARRY FORSYTH
description: Joan Whitridge Forsyth, widow of Harry Forsyth, a trustee of the Seamen's Bank for Savings, died Saturday in a nursing home in Salisbury, Conn. She was 86 years old and lived at 116 East 63d Street.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN FUTURES TRADE
description: Trading was slow in most commodity futures markets yesterday mostly because of the Jewish holiday observance. On the nation's largest exchange, the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat and soybeans drifted lower and corn held virtually steady.

title: Children Now Welcomed Where Bunnies Romped
description: McAFEE, Sept. 15 Changing economic conditions and a management decision to alter the image of the former Playboy Club Hotel are bringing about a new look to the $33million resort at Great Gorge in this tiny Sussex County community.

title: Lockheed Plans to Sell Airport on West Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (Reuters)  The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced today that it was selling the HollywoodBurbank Airport, which it owns.

title: Lies Laid to Key Witness on Suffolk D.A.
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 15 A key witness in the sodomy case against, Henry F. O'Brien, the Suffolk County District Attorney, has sworn to investigators that Roger Barry. Petersen, the 21  year  old unemployed handyman who made the accusation against the prosecutor, lied and that Mr. Petersen even passed a lie detector test and then boasted about it.

title: New Saint Honored as One of City's Own
description: A Jubilant throng of New Yorkers yesterday honored the newest Roman Catholic saint as one of their own in the environs where many of the formative events of her life took place.

title: Notes on People
description: Thirteen influential faculty members at the University of Virginia are trying to have canceled the scheduled appearance on the Charlottesville campus of Nguyen Cao Ky, former Premier and Vice President of South Vietnam tomorrow night.

title: MOST BANKS RAISE PRIME RATE TO 8%
description: An 8 per cent prime ratethe highest since early March  became prevalent in the banking industry yesterday amid forecasts that still loftier charges are in store during the remainder of 1975. Some estimates range as high as 9 per cent by year end.

title: Citicorp Plans to Merge Its Upstate Banking Units
description: Citicorp announced plans yesterday to merge its upstate banking subsidiaries in Albany, Syracuse and Rochester into CitibankWestern in Buffalo.

title: Waldheim Fears Mideast Complacency
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15Secretary General Waldheim warned today that the Sinai agreement must not be allowed to create dangerous complacency and called for a Middle East settlement that would include recognition of the rights of the Palestinian people.

title: FOUR PALESTINIANS SEIZE CAIRO ENVOY IN SPAIN AND FLEE
description: MADRID, Tuesday, Sept. 16 Four Palestinian guerrillas invaded the Egyptian Embassy here yesterday and threatened to kill the Ambassador and two aides unless Egypt scrapped her new accord with Israel. But they flew to Algiers early today with five hostages.

title: Papua New Guinea Celebrates Independence
description: PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea, Tuesday, Sept. 16At the stroke of midnight a fireworks display lit up the Port Moresby sky to signal the beginning of independence for Papua New Guinea.

title: Fresh Signs of Moslem Religious Fervor Are Worrying Turkey's Liberals.
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept 15New schools for Moslem clerics are being built. Beerdrinking and pornography are being frowned upon. Some Cabinet ministers are praying five times a day.

title: U. S WILL REVIEW ISRAELI ARMS NEED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The United States has agreed with Israel as part of the recent Sinai accord to conduct a joint study of Israel's defense needs and to develop a contingency plan for military supply in case of a new Middle Eastern emergency.

title: Even a Split End Has Rights
description: Suppose you were under contract to the firm that employs you for, say, three years, at a specified salary and under specified working conditions. During the three years, in your opinion, your value to your employer rises considerably, and the working conditions to which you originally agreed become outmoded or inapplicable to your status. Your employer is not willing either to increase your salary or to make the changes in your working conditions you believe warranted.

title: 7 FOOD SPOTS CITED AS CODE VIOLATORS
description: The Health Department has cited seven more food businesses for failing their second Health Code inspection and warned that they now faced closing orders if the violations persist upon a third and final inspection. The names of the establishments and the results cited follow:

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices drifted down on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, with the Amex market value index closing at 82.67, off 0.61. Volume moved up to 1,127,000 from 1,120,000 despite the Jewish holiday observance.

title: Intelligence Hearings On Radio, TV Today
description: Radio stations WNYCAM and WBAIFM will broadcast live the public sessions of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence this week. The hearings are scheduled to begin at 10 A.M. today.

title: Scotts' Role, if Any, in Hearst Case Remains Baffling
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 15Jack and Micki Scott, the sports activists, have in recent months raised the hopes of both the authorities and the family of Patricia Hearst that they might help to find the missing 21yearold girl, or at least provide clues to her condition and feelings.

title: Soviet Grain Talks Called Satisfactory
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15 (Reuters) Soviet and American officials recessed talks on a longterm agreement for Soviet purchases of United States grain, and an American spokesman said their discussions were satisfactory at a preliminary level.

title: Thais to Quit South Korea
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 15 (AP)Thailand has decided to withdraw her contingent of SO soldiers from the United Nations peacekeeping forces in South Korea at the end of this year's United Nations General Assembly, Foreign Minister Chatichai Choonhaven said today.

title: Male Sex Debility Traced to Marijuana
description: A new study of men who smoked marijuana daily under controlled conditions has shown that the drug can interfere with production of reproductive hormones, in some cases suppressing the male sex hormone, testosterone, to levels that could result in impotence or infertility.

title: German Wage Claim Hit
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 15 (Reuters)Economics Minister Hans Friderichs said today the 8 per cent wage claim by 200.000 North RhineWestphalia steel workers is not designed to bring an economic upturn that will at least lead to a fall in unemployment in the medium term. He declined to propose a lower wage claim target.

title: Jack Bell, Gannett Columnist, Chief A.P. Political Writer, Dies
description: Jack Bell, a columnist for the Gannett News Service since his retirement in 1969 as chief political writer for the Associated Press, died yesterday in Georgetown University Hospital in Washington after having suffered a massive stroke on Saturday. He was 71 years old.

title: 2 Injured in London By Bombs in the Mail
description: LONDON, Sept. 15Two letter bombs, mailed in Dublin, exploded when they were opened here today, injuring two women slightly.

title: A Trio That Shows Art's Effect on Rock
description: B.G.B., a tacky little club at 315 Bowery near Bleecker Street, has been presenting young local rock bands for several months. First there were a few tentative bookings, then a fullfledged festival, and now things have been regularized with unknown bands on week nights and bands that have made something of a cult name for themselves on weekends.

title: Richard Hartshorne, 87, Dead; Was Senior U.S. Judge in Jersey
description: Richard Hartshorne, retired senior judge of the Third United States District Court in Newark, died Sunday at a Bryn Mawr, Pa., nursing home. He was 87 years old and had moved with his family to Philadelphia less than a month ago after having resided in East Orange. N. J., for 58 years.

title: Film: Little Damage in Tidal Wave
Amstar Increases Wholesale Prices Of Industrial Sugar
description: The Amstar Corporation raised the wholesale price of industrial sugar 20 cents a hundred pounds, effective today. This brings the price for a hundred pounds of extrafine granulated to $23.55 and raises the price for two other industrial gradesbulk granulated and liquid No. 2to $22.95 a hundred pounds.

title: 2 Pamphlets Explain Some Ballot Questions
description: The League of Women Voters has issued Facts for Voters '75, explaining the eight constitutional amendments and one proposition that will be put to the electorate throughout the state on Nov. 4.

title: 2 Quit Cabinet in Mrs. Peron's Absence
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 15 (AP) Acting President Italo Luder accepted the resignations of two Cabinet ministers today, in his first day on the job since President Isabel Martinez de Pern left on a vacation.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Ford Hints at C.I.A. Curb
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (UPI)President Ford said in an interview with the Chicago SunTimes today that he might strip the C.I.A. of its authority to conduct secret political operations in foreign countries.

title: 32 Islanders at Farmingdale Rich in Hones and Energy
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 15The New York Islanders' hockey and tennis training camp opened today for 32 giddy players.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special Session on Development and International Economic Cooperationmeets at 9 A.M. to close. 30th regular sessionopens at 3 P.M.

title: Gromyko to See Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union will meet President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger at the White House on Thursday, the State Department said today.

title: Humphrey Would Take Draft
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 15 (AP)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, has sent word to a potential hacker that he would accept a draft for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1976 if national convention delegates become deadlocked. The message was contained in a letter from a Humphrey aide to Ohio state Representative Edward .T. Orlett.

title: Catholic High School Strike Awaited
description: Eleventhhour negotiations and mediation to avert a strike against 12 Roman Catholic high schools in the Archdiocese of New. York broke down last night, 12 hours before a strike deadline of 8 o'clock this morning.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Shutdown Feared
description: LONDON, Sept. 15  At 6 A.M. yesterday, a small union local in a Welsh steel town sent one of its members, a waterman. into a huge new blast furnace that the stateowned British Steel Corporation says it needs to survive. He was told to check the cooling pipes. He refused.

title: MUST OUTPUT UP BY 1.3%, INDICATING GAIN IN RECOVERY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15In dustrial production rose strongly in August, further evidence of recovery in the economy, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: School Buses in Collision
description: LOUISVILLE. Ky., Sept. 15 (AP)Two Jefferson County school buses collided today, and 37 children received minor injuries.

title: 2 Youths Sought in Slaying Of Brooklyn Store Owner
description: A 53 yearold man was stabbed to death early yesterday evening in his Brooklyn liquor store, the police said, and two youths were seen fleeing from the scene shortly after the slayin.

title: THIRD MAN IS KEY IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 15The key figure in New Hampshire's special Senate election tomorrow is a 45yearold unemployed technical writer who stands about as much chance of winning as does the late Daniel Webster.

title: . . . Lesson Unlearned
description: The striking teachers, to be sure, will be making a contributionalbeit an involuntary onetoward reemployment for some of their laidoff colleagues. The school board, for the first time, intends to exact the full twoforone penalty in lost pay mandated by the Taylor Law prohibiting Civil Service strikes. The Corporation Counsel's office has tentatively ruled that, subject to final review by the new statesponsored Control Board, the estimated $25 million from this source can go to put dismissed teachers back on the payrolla valuable aid in easing pressure on class size.

title: Papua New Guinea in Brief
description: Papua New Guinea, in joining the ranks of the world's independent states, is seeking to change its image as the stone age island. Its size, about 180,000 square miles, and population, roughly three million, it is comparable to New Zealand. But with a wide range of tribal groups speaking a variety of languages, a sense of national identity and unity appears to be a major problem.

title: The Teacher Dispute
description: The United Federation of Teachers, headed by Albert Shanker, representing 55,000 teachers and 20,000 other employes in the city's 976school system.

title: Buyers' Fees at Auctions Stir London Controversy
description: LONDON, Sept. 15A controversy has erupted over a decision by Sotheby's and Christie's, the two largest fineart auctioneers, to introduce a 10 per cent levy for all buyers.

title: HEARING IS SOUGHT IN KIDNAPPING CASE
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 15 (AP)Gov. Thomas P. Salmon of Vermont asked Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut today to hold a hearing before ordering the extradition of a Jericho, Vt., woman charged with conspiracy to kidnap her daughter.

title: 5th Straight Rise
description: Steel production for the week ended Sept. 13 rose 4.6 per cent, the largest weektoweek increase this year and the fifth consecutive weekly gain, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute in Washington.

title: SCHOOL PARLEYS MEET LATE SNAGS; SHANKER HOPEFUL
description: Lastminute snags delayed an expected agreement last night between the teachers' union and the Board of Education, but Albert Shanker, the union's president, said he was still hopeful that the problems could be resolved soon.

title: U. S. WILL REVIEW ISRAELI ARMS NEED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The United States has agreed with Israel as part of the recent Sinai accord to conduct a joint study of Israel's defense needs and to develop a contingency plan for military supply in case of a new. Middle Eastern emergency.

title: JEWS SEEK SUPPORT FOR AID TO ISRAELIS
description: Responding to American public opinion polls that protested largescale assistance to Israel, a group of Jewish organizations has started a drive to win support for the United States Government's pledge to aid Israel.

title: A Hero at Arms
description: My old stickup man, John, stepped out of the shadows and pointed his gun. As usual, sir, I'll start with your wallet, he said. I gave it to him, commenting that I was delighted to see he had still not found honest labor.

title: Grace Note to the Fashions of the '70's . . .
description: One of the engaging sidelights of the resort collections opening on Seventh Avenue this month is the prevalence of little handbags swinging on a chain from shoulder or waistline.

title: Bomb Found After Threat
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 15 (AP)A pipe bomb was found Saturday on the 13th floor of the Federal Building, one day after a woman identifying herself as a spokesman for the New World Liberation Front telephoned a bomb threat, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. The woman called The Associated Press and said the bomb would explode at 3 P.M. Friday. The 39floor building was evacuated, but at the time no bomb was found.

title: PCB IN FISH STIRS NEW STATE STUDY
description: Unhealthy levels of the toxic chemical PCB have been found in fish in three more state waterways, prompting the State Environmental Conservation Department to begin planning a broadened campaign to detect, analyze and possibly combat the compound.

title: Catholic Schools Issues
description: The Lay Faculty Association of New York, representing 328 teachers at 12 high schools, with 12,000 students, in the Archdiocese of New York.

title: James Archibald Keillor, Altman's Vice Presidents
description: James Archibald Keillor, who retired in 1963 as vice president and generalmerchandise Manager of B. Altman & Co., died Sunday in Mather Memorial Hospital, Port Jefferson, L. I. He was 86 years old and lived on North Country Road, Wading River, L. I.

title: Hancock Sues Builders For Defects in Tower
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company today filed suit to recover damagespossibly as much as $50million  in connection with the design and construction of the 60story John Hancock Tower, which was plagued by falling window glass.

title: Hong Kong Swimmers Haven't Caught Jaws
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 15The movie Jaws hasn't come here yet, and apparently most people still haven't heard of it, either.

title: Moscow Offers to Talk About Visas of Newsmen
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15  The Soviet Government reported today that it was prepared in principle to issue multipleuse exit and entry visas to American correspondents accredited in Moscow.

title: Belgium Recovery Weighed
description: PARIS, Sept. 15 (Reuters)Foreign demand appears to be the only factor capable of starting a real economic recovery in Belgium. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today in its annual report on the country's economy.

title: French Planning to Defy Ruling on Duties for Wine
description: PARIS, Sept. 15 (AP)French officials indicated tonight that they would defy the European Common Market's executive commission and continue to levy import duties on Italian wine.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer of Paterson was cleared by the Passaic County Prosecutor, Burrell I. Humphreys, of any criminal wrongdoing in overspending his legal election budget limit in May, 1974.

title: Grumman Confirms Rise In Price of F14 Fighters
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Sept. 15 (AP)  The Grumman Aerospace Corporation acknowledged today that the cost of its F14 Tomcat fighter had increased $2million per plane this year, but attributed the increase to the Government's cut in the company's rate of production.

title: British Car Maker in Receivership
description: LONDON, Sept. 15  Today marked the end of a novel experiment in Britain. A man who thought he could get along and prosper with British labor by running a company the American way conceded faliure, and decided to go into receivership.

title: Boston School Attendance Up to 70% in Second Week
description: BOSTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)1 Citywide attendance reached a high for the new school term today during the peaceful start of the second week of a Steppedup plan to integrate public schools by busing.

title: Great Gorge! Children Now Romp in a Playboy Club
description: McAFEE, N.J. Sept. 15 Changing economic conditions and a management decision to alter the image of the former Playboy Club Hotel are bringing about a new look to the $33million resort at Great Gorge in this tiny Sussex County community.

title: Market Place
description: Some shareholders of Bush Universal, Inc., have studied in dismay a 200page proxy statement issued jointly by their company and Katy Industries, Inc., in an effort to decide what to do about a plan to merge the two companies.

title: TORY CHIEF, HERE, DEPLORES STATISM
description: Margaret Thatcher, on her first visit here since becoming leader of the Conservative party in Britain, charged last night that 30 years of expansion of the welfare state had caused major damage by curbing Brit ish growth.

title: MIDDLE EAST BANKER CITED IN SAUDI DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (REUTERS)  A Middle East hanker has received a $4.5million agent's fee in connection with a controversial contract to train Saudi Arabian national guardsmen, Representative Les Aspin said today.

title: FOUR PALESTINIANS SEIZE CAIRO ENVOY IN SPAIN AND FLEE
description: MADRID, Tuesday, Sept. 16Four Palestinian guerrillas flew to Algiers today with three hostages from the Egyptian Embassy here after a day in which they forced their way into the embassy and threatened to blow it up unless Egypt scrapped her disengagement agreement with Israel.

title: SCHOOL PARLEYS MEET LATE SNAGS; SHANKER HOPEFUL
description: Lastminute snags delayed an expected agreement last night between the teachers' union and the Board of Education, but Albert Shanker, the union's president, said he was still hopeful that the problems could be resolved soon.

title: 56% in Harris Poll Fear Recession Will Last a Year
description: The American people believe by a 56 to 28 per cent majority that the nation will he in a recession this time next year, according to a Louis Harris survey released yesterday. The figures reflect a higher degree of pessimism than at any time since March.

title: C.B.O.E. to Add 8 Stocks
description: Eight new stocks will be added to the stock option trading program of the Chicago Board Options Exchange on Sept. 22, the exchange said yesterday. It listed the stocks as Occidental Petroleum. Control Data, General Dynamics. UAL, United Technologies, Raytheon. Holiday Inns and the Southern Company.

title: Senate Backs Transit Aid For Small Urban Districts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)  The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill permitting Federal operating subsidies for mass transit systems in areas with populations of less than 50,000.

title: Red Sox Advance Another HalfStep
description: Dwight Evans drove in four runs with four hits and Fred Lynn and Jim Rice each drove in their 100th runs last night at Fenway Park in leading the Boston Red Sox to a 97 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Montreal at New York (8:05 P.M.) Carrithers (33) vs. Matlack (1611).

title: New Car Sales Off 7.5% From '74 in First 10 Days of September
description: DETROIT, Sept. 15American new car sales were off 7.5 per cent in early September compared with the like period last year, but the annual selling rate was up from August due to early deliveries of some 1976 models by the General Motors Corporation dealers.

title: Egypt and Israel Resume Talks On Application of Sinai Accord
description: GENEVA, Sept. 6 (Reuters)Egyptian and Israeli negotiators resumed talks here today on the application of their Sinai agreement. The session was ap: parently unaffected by the Palestianian raid yesterday on the Egyptian Embassy in Madrid.

title: ASSEMBLY OPENS 30TH U.N. SESSION
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 16The General Assembly opened its 30th session today, electing Premier Gaston Thorn of Luxembourg as President and admitting three countries to membership in the United Nations.

title: Senate Backs Parole Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)The Senate voted today to reorganize the Federal parole system by creating a ninemember United States Parole Commission that would include a national appeals board that prisoners could petition if they were denied freedom. The House has approved a similiar measure.

title: Old Masters Thrill Coast Tennis Fans
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16?? a night of nostalgia Torben Ulrich, 46yearold guru of the circuit, outlasted Frank Sedgman, 57, 61, 7.6, and took the Grand Masters title at the Pacific Southwest open tennis championships yesterday at Pauley Pavilion.

title: About the Islanders . . .
description: Tickets for the Islanders' first 12 regularseason games will go on sale today at the Nassau Coliseum and all metropolitan area Ticketron outlets. Tickets will also be sold for the three home preseason games against the Pittsburgh Penguins Tuesday, Atlanta Flames Sept. 29 and the New York Rangers Oct. 5. . . Al Arbour, the Islander coach. buckled the legs of his players yesterday with sets grueling wind sprints and a short scrimmage in the morning followed by a twohour scrimmage in the afternoon. After the scrimmage Arbour kept the players en the ice for more skating exercises. Oh, it's brutal, moaned Joe Fortunato, a left wing who was the Islanders' thirdround draft choice. Other hopeful rookies chatted in the exercise room. Sudbury, what a place that is, said Rich Hansen, a true Islander, from Northport. L. I., who played junior hockey in Sudbury, Ontario, Arbour's home town. Rock City they call it, said Fortunate. That's all you see up there is rocks.

title: Antipollution Rules Called Too Strict For Papermakers
description: Adherence to regulations emanating from the clean water and air legislation passed by Congress in 1972 would prove deleterious not only to pullp, paper and paperboard mills but also to consumers of paper, it was indicated yesterday by a study made for the American Paper Institute.

title: Ford Defends Israel Aid, But Denies Commitment
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Ford said today that the United ?? would supply Israel with very substantial military weaponry in the aftermath of the new EgyptianIsrael agreement in Sinai, but insisted that American diplomatic, political and defense assurances did not constitute a security treaty with Israel.

title: Market Place
description: Less than one month ago Gordon J. Phillips, who works at the Veterans Hospital on Kingsbridge Road in the Bronx, wrote a check for $4,669.61 for municipal bonds priced to yield 8 per cent in taxexempt interest.

title: Preamble and Excerpts From U.N. Summary of Development Text
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16Following are the text of the preamble to the resolution adopted at the close of the special General Assembly session on development and international economic cooperation and excerpts from the unofficial United Nations summary of the resolution:

title: Russians Favor Stability in Grain Buying
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 16  The head of an American negotiating team said today that the Soviet Union had apparently accepted the principle of longterm commitments to buy grain from the United States.

title: ALLBRITTON TO BUY ALL STOCK IN PAPER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Joe L. Allbritton, the embattled; publisher of the financially faltering Washington Star, an nounced today that the family owners of more than 99 per cent of the closely held stock in Washington's remaining ofternoon newspaper had agreed to sell him their shares.

title: Durkin, Democrat, Voted New Hampshire Senator
description: CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 16John A. Durkin, a 39yearold Democratic moderate, won a decisive victory today over Louis C. Wyman, a fiveterm conservative Republican Representative, in a rematch of last November's deadlocked New Hampshire Senate election.

title: 40 AT BROOKLYN HOLD A THREEHOUR SITIN
description: About 40 students from Brooklyn College's Bilingual Minicollege yesterday staged a threehour sitin at the office of John W. Kneller, president of the college.

title: 76 LAG IN UPTURN IS CALLED LIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said today that the economic recovery, which now looks very strong, is likely to slow appreciably by the middle of next year, leaving 7 to 7.5 million Americans still unemployed at the end of 1976.

title: Scorn and Envy at Moscow Show
description: MOSCOW (UPI)We have seen how capitalism is rotting, a visitor wrote, hut with what a sweet smell.

title: Groh's Job Outlook Brightens As Cleanup Progress Is Made
description: Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh took to the streets yesterday and, with five days left of the 10 Mayor Beame gave him to clean up the city. announced that things had greatly improved.

title: Meeting Slated Today to Plan Next Step
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y. Sept. 16  The New York Giants did not vote to strike today, but they did vote to hack the New England Patriots and the New York Jets if either or both were locked out.

title: What's New on Blooming dale Rd., in White Plains
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 16 Bloomingdale's opened its largest branch store here today, a fourlevel structure faced with mirrored glass and ringed by a 1,200car parking area for the carriage trade of modern suburbia.

title: Mr. Justice Douglas
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Supreme Court of the United States will begin hearing arguments in the autumn term on Monday, Oct. 6, and this raises the delicate question of the health of Mr. Justice William O. Douglas, who suffered a stroke last New Year's Eve and has been trying to recover ever since.

title: Coke Backs LernerBernstein Show
description: CocaCola is an angel. It will be the sole hackerto the tune of $900,000for 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, the new Broadway musical about the White House by Man Jay Lerner and Leonard Bernstein.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: What's New on Bloomingdale Rd. in White Plains
description: WHITEPLAINS, Sept. 16 Bloomingdale's opened its largest branch store here today, a fourlevel structure faced with mirrored glass and ringed by a 1,200car parking area for the carriage trade of modern suburbia.

title: Nuclear Arms and the Stakes in Korea
description: DALLASSeveral times in recent months, Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger has indicated that the United States would resort to the use of tactical nuclear weapons if conventional forces failed to halt serious aggression in certain vital parts of the world. The two areas specifically mentioned were Europe and Korea.

title: TREASURY NOTES ATTRACT PUBLIC
description: The Treasury auctioned $3billion of twoyear notes yesterday at an average yield of 8.44 per cent. Public participation in the sale was extremely heavy. This return on the notes bearing an 8 per cent coupon was slightly less than estimates made by the investment community prior to the announcement.
