Most people had expected the Treasury notes to carry rates of about 8.50 per cent.

title: Panel Urges a Major Overhaul Of Jersey Motor Vehicle Laws
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16A study commission has recommended a major overhaul of the state's motor vehicle laws.

title: TEACHERS VOTE TO RETURN BUT MANY OBJECT TO PACT; SCHOOLS OPEN TOMORROW
description: Members of the United Federation of Teachers, amid much dissatisfaction, yesterday voted to end the teachers' strike and school officials quickly announced plans for a resumption of classes tomorrow morning for the city's 1.1million pupils.

title: A Store Decorator Goes Independent
description: David Bell moved swiftly about his sundrenched office the other afternoon, scooping up color charts, illustration pads and carpet and wall covering sample books.

title: Compromise Is Set on Jordan Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The Ford Administration and Congress reached agreement today on a compromise that would allow Jordan to receive 14 batteries of Hawk antiaircraft missiles temporarily blocked on Capitol Hill.

title: Books of The Times
description: BRING ON THE EMPTY HORSES. By David Niven. 369 pages. Illustrated. $9.95. I began to wonder about David Niven's qualifications as a writer when, on page 16 of Bring On the Empty Horses, he described Lana Turner as ridiculously beautiful. On the same page, he talks about hummingbirds who whizzed merrily about with their tiny waistcoats of turquoise, vermillion. and gold flashing in the sunlight.

title: Neal Says Vote Taken to Spur Bargaining
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., SEpt. 16In a confusion  filled locker room where, according to one player, it took an hour to explain what we were voting about, the New York Jets voted today to strike the National Football League.

title: Lebanese Say Israeli Raid On a Camp Is Turned Back
description: SAIDA, Lebanon, Sept. 16 (Reuters)  Lebanese troops and Palestinian guerrillas tonight drove off Israeli gunboats that tried to approach the Palestinian camp at Rashidiyah, south of Tyre, local residents said.

title: Civil Rights Unit Deplores Plight of the Navajo Tribe
description: DENVER, Sept. 16The Federal Commission on Civil Rights reported today that the country's largest Indian reservation was as subject as ever to Government red tape and shortsightedness despite a fiveyear Federal policy of Indian selfdetermination.

title: WALLACE ASSAILS FOREIGN POLICY
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 16Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, who built his political reputation on domestic issues, lashed out today at United States foreign policy, which he said had left the nation without a single friend who has any military power of significance.

title: Carey, Beame and Wagner Plan a City Booster Group
description: Governor Carey met privately yesterday with Mayor Beame and former Mayor Robert F. Wagner to plan an association of business and civic leaders for promoting a more positive image of the city and lobbying for investor support.

title: An End of Student Suspensions Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The Children's Defense Fund called today for virtually ending the practice of suspending youngsters from school, declaring that 97 per cent of the more than one million suspensions that occur each year are not for violent or dangerous offenses.

title: Dangerous Settlement ...
description: Settlement of the weekold strike by the United Federation of Teachers has been reached at a high cost to the city and its children. Even allowing for a union leader's need to present a contract in what for him is the most favorable light, Albert Shenker is all too right in boasting that the Board of Education has abandoned virtually all of its negotiating demands. In addition, the union has extracted from the board a settlement that dangerously ignores New York's desperate financial condition.

title: Seoul Holds Dissident Poet Due to Be Set Free Today
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 16 (AP)The military's Judicial authorities reinstated a life sentence imposed on the dissidents poet Kim Chi Ha today to keep him in custody pending trial on charges of violating antiCommunist laws.

title: Boorstin Nomination Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)The Senate Rules Committee unanimously approved today the nomination of Daniel J. Boorstin to head the Library of Congress but cautioned the Pulitzer Prizewinning historian on his future writing activities. It has been charged that Dr. Boorstin used employes of the Smithsonian's Museum of History and Technology, which he once headed, to help him in his writings.

title: Advertising
description: At around 10 o'clock yesterday morning Eugene H. Kummel, president and chief executive of McCannErickson, swooped out of his office bound for the airport, a flight to Chicago and a sales meeting of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

title: MRS. FRANCIS KEALLY
description: Mildred Tabor Keally, wife of Francis Keally, an architect, died Monday at New Milford (Conn.) Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at 131 East 66th Street.

title: MALCOLM G. KISPERT
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16 (AP)Malcolm G. Kispert, secretary of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology since 1971, died Saturday at his home in Dover. He was 52 years old. Earlier, Mr. Kispert was vice president for academic administration from 1961 to 1971.

title: Snipping and Nipping
description: For those who like to quaff while being coiffed there is now a unisex hair saloon of sorts on the East Side. Only its official name is sober: Haircutting by Jason.

title: Red Smith
description: The Devine Era dawned Monday night in that idyllic corner of the sports world where there is no Rozelle rule, no Management Council, no players' union and no strike, lockout or sitin. The event came to pass in Foxboro, Mass., on a playground abandoned by the New England Patriots. In its first football game under Devine guidance, Notre Dame ground down Boston College, 173, before more witnesses than the Patriots ever saw. It remains to be seen whether Dan Devine is a Notre Dame coach in the lofty tradition of Knute Rockne, Frank Leahy and Ara Parseghian or heir to the slightly frayed mantle of Hunk Anderson, Elmer Layden, Ed McKeever, Hugh Devore and Terry Brennan. When he was athletic director and coach Missouri with the rank of full professor his intellect commanded widespread admiration but on taking charge of the Green Bay Packers he turned stupid.

title: Stein Will Hold Hearings On Medicaid Mill Abuses
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein charged yesterday that the lives of one million children are potentially endangered by fraudulent practices of Medicaid mills, and announced that he would expose the situation at a series of public hearings beginning Sept. 30.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Asserts Boston Officials Gave Poor School Bus Service
description: BOSTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)Federal District Judge W. Arthur Garrity scolded Boston school officials today for what he called slipshod busing practices that resulted in an opening week horror show for some students bused to class under his desegregation plan.

title: How N.F.L. Clubs Stand on Dispute
description: The various positions taken by the 26 teams of the National Football League with regard to the current labor dispute follow:

title: Miss Fromme Loses Fight To Be Free, but Bail Is Cut
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 16Lynette Alice Fromme lost her fight today to be released fin her own recognizance pending trial on the charge that he attempted to assassinate President Ford, but her bail was cut from $1million to $350,000.

title: GLEN A. LLOYD, 80, LAWYER, IS DEAD
description: Glen A. Lloyd, a lawyer and former chairman of the board of trustees of the University of Chicago, died Sunday at his ranch near Alamosa, Colo. He was 80 years old and lived also in Libertyville, Ill.

title: Modern Museum and France in Art Deal
description: PARIS, Sept. 16A series of agreements designed to increase and facilitate the exchange of art masterpieces between France and the United States was approved today by New York's Museum of Modern Art and French cultural authorities.

title: LEBANESE LEFTIST ACCUSES THE TIMES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 16 (Reuters)The Lebanese leftwing leader Kamal Jumblat said today that he had decided to file a $40million suit against The New York Times for its report quoting American officials as saying that Libya had spent millions of dollars in support of Lebanese leftwing Moslem groups.

title: Selection of a Jury Goes on at the Trial Of 2 Hunt Brothers
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 16Lamar Hunt, the owner of the Kansas City Chiefs football team and a promoter of professional tennis, ran his sports and oil enterprises from the spectator seats at the Federal courthouse here today.

title: People in Sports
description: While suffering with a 711 wonlost record last season with the Chicago Cubs, Burt Houton slipped into pitching oblivion. At 24 years old he became the forgotten man of the Cubs' pitching staff, in disfavor with the management and the fans, a mopup pitcher, often used when games were hopelessly lost. Early this season, the righthander, who relies heavily on a knucklecurve ball, was traded to the Los Angeles Dodgers. Now he is bringing hack memories of Don Drysdale and Sandy Koufax.

title: C . A.B. Is Accused of Ignoring Its Rules on Fiscal Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 16Ignoring its own rules, the Civil Aeronautics Board failed to require its top employes to file financial disclosure statements in 1970, 1971 and 1973, the General Accounting Office said in a report made public today.

title: Meat Paces Rise in Prices In the City's Market Basket
description: With bottom round roast prices rising 12 cents a pound to an average of $1.90 and bacon 8 cents a pound to $2.35, the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City rose 0.8 per cent last week, the city Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

title: NEW RULE SOUGHT FOR BIGCITY RADIO
description: Richard E. Wiley, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said yesterday that he would recommend to the full commission an experimental suspension of the fairness doctrine on contrasting views for radio stations in the larger cities. The doctrine would still apply to television.

title: British Output Index Rose
description: LONDON, Sept. 16 (Reuters)  The British index of industrial production for all industries rose to 100 in July seasonally adjusted from 99,5 revised in June (base equals 1970), the Provisional Central Statistical Office figures showed today, This compared. with 109 in July last year.

title: James J. Matles, a Top Official Of Electrical Workers, 66, Dies
description: James J. Matles, general secretarytreasurer of the independent United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers Union and a founder of the Committee for Industrial Organization, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 66 years old and lived at 303 West 66th Street. He had been attending his union's annual convention in California, which ended last week.

title: Pavel Sukhoi, 80, Designer Of Soviet Military Aircraft
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 16 (Reuters) Pavel Sukhoi, a leading designer of military aircraft, died yesterday. He was 80 years old.

title: Unchecked Censure of Police Viewed by Levi as Dangerous
description: DENVER, Sept. 16 (UPI)Attorney General Edward H. Levi warned today that unchecked, criticism of law enforcement's past overzealousness could lead to a dangerous excess of hesitancy in the futures

title: 76 LAG IN UPTURN IS CALLED LIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said today that the economic recovery, which now looks very strong, is likely to slow appreciably by the middle of next year, leaving 7 to 7.5 million Americans still unemployed at the end of 1976.

title: Couple Awarded $4Million In Suit on Accident Claim
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 16 (UPI)A Superior Court jury has awarded $4million in punitive damages to a policeman and his wife who sued their insurance company after it refused to pay on their automobile accident claim, court records showed today.

title: PERJURY BY POLICE TARGET OF A RULING
description: NEWARK, Sept. 16 (AP)Federal Judge Herbert J. Stern issued an opinion today designed to deter New Jersey policemen from committing perjury to obtain search warrants.

title: Women Get Backing As Rhodes Scholars
description: American administrators of the Rhodes Scholarships have announced plans to make women eligible for the prestigious fellowships beginning next year.

title: Nyquist Again Urges Tuition at City U.
description: State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist has renewed his recommendation to the Board of Higher Education that all students at the City University be charged tuition starting with the spring semester.

title: Future of Colleges Is Said to Depend On Nontraditional
description: Dr. John C. Sawhill, in his first major education address since he became president of New York University, said yesterday that the future of private institutions of higher learning depended to a great extent, on their ability to attract the nontraditional or over30 age groups as new students.

title: CARY ROBERTSON
description: LOUISVILLE, Sept. 16 Ky. (AP)Cary Robertson, who began his newspaper career as a police reporter for The Louisville CourierJournal in 1929 and became Sunday editor, died last night. He was 73 Years old.

title: Product Safety Agency Issues Swimming Pool Slide Standard
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission, in existence since May, 1973, has issued its first proposed safety standard under the Consumer Product Safety Act, a set of requirements for swimmingpool slides.

title: Horse Groups Going to Court To Fight OTB in Connecticut
description: Connecticut's horse industry saddled up yesterday for an allout attack against the forces of offtrack betting. In their advance communiques, the horse people promised a sensational announcement that would interest the entire racins industry and sporting world. The announcement, at a meeting in Hartford, was that a suit aimed at invalidating the Connecticut offtrack betting law would be filed today. It also will seek to strike down contracts under which races from New York thoroughbred and harness tracks would be televised and wagered on at horseless minitracks in Connecticut.

title: FALCON SEABOARD AND MAPCO IN DEAL
description: Mapco, Inc. of Tulsa, Okla., engaged primarily in the production of oil, gas and coal, and operation of pipelines, announced an agreement in principle yesterday to merge with Falcon Seaboard, Inc., of Houston, in an exchange of stock valued at $93.3million.

title: Diana Kennedy's English Muffins
description: (Adapted from a recipe in Mrs. Beeton's Book of Household Management)

title: Mrs. Court Victor
description: TOKYO, Sept. 16 (UPI)Margaret Court and Helen Gourlay of Australia advanced tonight in a $50,000 women's tennis tournament. Mrs. Court defeated Kris Kemmer Shaw, 62, 61, and Miss Gourlay had little trouble beating Laurie Fleming Rowley, 61, 61.

title: Catholic Schools Issues
description: The Lay Faculty Association of New York, representing 328 teachers at 12 high schools, with 12,000 students, in the Archdiocese of New York.

title: PRESIDENT READY TO DEFY HOUSE BID FOR VIETNAM DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Ford said today that he would defy a subpoena ordering him to turn over classified documents on the Vietnam War to the House Select Committee on Intelligence unless the committee adopted procedures to safeguard sensitive materials.

title: The Zirconium Complex
description: Right Guard contains no zirconium. So what, you say, passing the whole thing off cavalierly, but those five words have changed my life.

title: Chase Plans to Buy Some REIT Assets For $150Million
description: The financially troubled Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, the nation's largest real estate investment trust, said yesterday that its advisor, the Chase Manhattan Bank, had agreed to buy $150million of the trust's assets, subject to certain conditions.

title: WINE TALK
description: There are some things that cannot be oversimplified. Wine lore is one of them. It is like telling people they can learn to play the piano hi 10 lessons.

title: Kallinger Takes the Stand In Second Murder Trial
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 16 Joseph Kallinger testified at his robbery trial today that he was 1,000 years old and was a butterfly before he received his present bodily form.

title: Money Supply vs. Rates
description: Interest rates have been moving up, knocking the stock market down and raising worries about the strength and steadiness of the economic recovery. On Friday the First National City Bank of New York raised its prime interest rate  the charge to its most creditworthy corporate customers  to 8 per cent, and this week major banks all over the country followed the Citibank lead up from 7 per cent. Just three months ago the base lending rate at Citibank was at 6 per cent.

title: INTEGRATION PLAN IN DALLAS UPSET
description: DALLAS, Sept. 16A school desegregation plan, filed by the Dallas Independent Shool District last week, was thrown out of court today after a Federal judge ruled the plan was constitutionally lacking.

title: IRENE HAYES, 79, FLORIST HERE, DIES
description: Irene Hayes, the Park Avenue florist, died yesterday, apparently of a heart ailment, at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at 2 Sutton Place South.

title: Half Hollow Hills School Dispute Narrowed
description: MELVILLE, L. I., Sept. 16 I really think I'm going to jail,

title: Soviet Testing Missiles in Barents Sea
description: The Soviet Union began missile tests yesterday in the Barents Sea, an area strategically important to both the Russians and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Tiant, Red Sox Top Orioles, 20
description: Rico Petrocelli and Carlton Fisk hit home runs and Luis Tiant outdueled Jim Palmer last night as the Red Sox defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 20, at Fenway Park. The victory raised Boston's American League East lead to 5 games over Baltimore and reduced its magic number to 7. Any combination of Red Sox victories and Orioles losses totaling seven will give Boston the division title. The teams meet again in Boston tonight.

title: Plans for a Nuclear Plant Put Off in Pennsylvania
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP).Plans to build a nuclear power plant on the Susquehanna River in southern Lancaster County in Pennsylvania were suddenly suspended today after the company that was to supply the reactors backed out of the deal. The action will eventually lift electric rates.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Midland Glass Company says it will test the constitutionality of a State Environmental Protection Department regulation setting tough air pollution standards for glass manufacturers. The Freehold company has signed an order agreeing to install $4million worth of smokestack pollutioncontrol equipment, but it said it will file an immediate appeal with the Superior Court.

title: Party Fight Snags Attempts to Set Up Coalition in Lisbon
description: LISBON, Sept. 16Negotiations for a new Portuguese coalition Cabinet were at a standstill again today as a result of a fight between the Communist and Popular Democrats over ministerial posts.

title: Gas Hoses Slashed at 10 Gulf Stations
description: Gasoline pump hoses in 10 Gulf Oil Company service stations in the North Jarsley area were cut by vandals yesterday, and a man who identified himself as a Jewish militant claimed responsibility for the incidents In retaliation ford what he said was Gulf's enormous monetary contributions, to the Arab propaganda effort.

title: Beame Proposes Dinkins For Position of City Clerk
description: David N. Dinkins, whose tax problems in 1973 forced him to withdraw as the first black nominee for Deputy Mayor, has been recommended by Mayor Beame for City Clerk, a $37,344ayear position.

title: For Specialist in Mexican Food, There Will Always Be an England
description: Question: What do 50 pounds of unslaked powdered lime, a pound or dried whole hominy, four pigs' heads, crumpets and English muffins add up to?

title: Axelson Sworn In as Aide To Mayor on Fiscal Affairs
description: Before a vigorously applauding crowd composed of the city's financial hierarchy, Kenneth S. Axelson was sworn in yesterday as the city's Deputy Mayor for Finance by Mayor Beame, who called him the man who is going to help us get out of our problems.

title: Jets and Akins Join Patriots' Strike
description: A player strike spread through parts of the National Football League yesterday following rejection of a sixpoint propotal presented to the New England Patriots by the Management Council on behalf of the team owners.

title: When a Bank Run by Women Opens, The Reason Is Not Always Feminism
description: When six women and three men got together here early in 1973 to organize the First Women's Bankit's to have its formal opening in midOctober  they knew they were being pioneers. What they couldn't know was how quickly their lead would be followed.

title: Builder's Employe Says He Bribed 100 Officials
description: A former employe of one of the city's major construction companies testified yesterday that for two years he bribed about 100 officials in the city's Buildings. Fire and Highway Departments to expedite documents and overlook building violations.

title: Stocks on American Exchange And OTC List Show Declines
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over the counter market dropped again yesterday in stepped up trading.

title: Puerto Rico Storm Is Now a Hurricane; 5,000 Are Homeless
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 16 (AP)Eloise, a tropical storm that grew into a hurricane, slashed past Puerto Rico today, and it was feared that at least a halfdozen persons had perished. The storm left more than 5,000 homeless and dozens of villages flooded.

title: Amalrik to Quit Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 16 (Reuters) Andrei Amalrik, the dissident who has been ordered out of Moscow by the police, said today that he had found a room in a cottage where he hoped to live. He was detained last Saturday and released the following morning after having been given three days to leave the capital. Since his release in May after five years in prison and exile he has been barred from residence in Moscow.

title: A Dieter's Dream Comes True: Canneloni Florentine That Is Legal
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn.In the new research and development center in the Foodways National plant in this community south of Hartford, the battle of the bulge has also become a battle against boredom.

title: Lebanese Clashes Go On, With Four Killed in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, Sept. 17Sniping, heavyweapons fire and the occasional explosion of rockets continued to paralyze life yesterday in southeastern neighborhoods of Beirut. Violence was also reported from the northern costal city of Tripoli, where armed leftists Monday effectively took over.

title: BANGLADESH ACTS TO GAIN STABILITY
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 16One month after the military coup d'tat in which Sheik Mujibur Rahman was killed, the new Government of Bangladesh has a hold on the critically impoverished country that is still far from secure.

title: Gilliam, Vikings Talk After N.F.L. Approves
description: The National Football League gave its blessing yesteerday to John Gilliam's return to the N.F.L., and the wide receiver and the Minnesota Vilings almost immediately went into negotiations in Minnesota.

title: Notes on People
description: Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis has been retained as a consulting editor at Viking Press, Thomas H. Guinzburg, president of the New Yorkbased publishing house, announced yesterday.

title: Hearing Set on Removal of Devices Keeping Girl in a Coma Alive
description: MORRISTOWN, Sept. 16Superior Court Judge Robert Muir Jr. today set Monday as the tentative starting time for a hearing on whether a court can authorize the withdrawal of lifesustaining medical processes from a person whose condition is considered hopeless and whose chances of recovery deemed nonexistent.

title: U.S. Documents Accompanying the Sinai Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Following are the texts of three documents relating to the recent Sinai agreement between Israel and Egypt. The first is a memorandum of agreement between Israel and the United States relating to

title: Excerpts From Budget Office's Study
A Judge in Buf falo Allows Then Rejects TV in Courtroom
description: A Federal judge in Buffalo announced yesterday that he would take the rare step of admitting television cameras to his courtroom to record the closing arguments in a school segregation case. Last night he called off the plan, citing a judicial ban that he said he had not been aware of.

title: Gonadal Shield for Patients Being XRayed Is Proposec
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration says that radiation shields should be used routinely by children and men and women of reproductive age when they undergo Xray examination.

title: Wilson Asks Communists To Ease Curbs on People
description: BUCHAREST, Sept. 16 (Reuters)Prime Minster Harold Wilson of Britain, on a visit to Rumania, called on ComMunist governments tonight to ease restrictions affecting ordinarypeople.

title: Hawthorne Teachers Picketing; Hoboken Strikers Will Stay Out
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)New Jersey teachers walked picket lines in Hawthorne today and 418 teachers in Hoboken unanimously rejected a judge's recommendation to return to class during the latest round of courtordered contract talks.

title: Archdiocese Lay Teachers Strike Nine High Schools
description: More than half, of the unionized lay teachers at Roman Catholic high schools in the Archdiocese of New York went on strike yesterday, forcing 10,000 students in the New York City area to attend classes conducted by a reduced staff.

title: Article 1  No Title
...What Weapons?
description: A sterner test of the Taylor Law's deterrent effect will come in proceedings still to be concluded in the State Supreme Court before Justice Irving H. Saypol and in the State Public Employment Relations Board. Justice Saypol will have to decide Friday whether send United Federation of Teachers' leaders to jail for criminal contempt, a move that would be selfdefeating in making them synthetic martyrs, lionized by their members as latterday inheritors of the tradition of Eugene V. Debs and other union heroes.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Carpet Panel Disbands
description: The Carpet and Rug Institute's consumer action panel, which had been listed in a New York Times article on Monday as a place to which complaints about carpets could be directed, has been disbanded.

title: Contract Awards
description: Siemens. A.G., Munich, West Germany, and Asea, A.B., Stockholm, have jointly received a $45.9million contract from Iran for the delivery of an assembly of eight, outdoor electric switching stations.

title: Social Reforms Aplenty
description: Already, I hear the voices of morality and general outrage. So let it be. I am concerned with the human condition.

title: Stage: A Little Night Music Goes Cockney to London's Delight
description: LONDONIn a very curious way the backbone of Broadway is the musical. In London's West End theater it features less prominently. Which considering the product is probably just as well. At the moment In London there are a number of longrunning musicals, such as Billy and Jesus Christ Superstar, even Hair and Godspell, which have already been reviewed in these pages, but perhaps the pattern of the West End musical can be seen in three of the latest successes, Harold Prince's A Little Night Music, Happy End and The Black Mikado.

title: Dow Falls Below 800 Level To Finish Day Off by 8.06
description: The stock market continued sliding yesterday under the weight of rising interest rates and the United States Treasury's heavy financing requirements.

title: Madrid Guerrillas Handed Over to Palestinian Official
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 16Four Palestinians who seized the Egyptian embassy in Madrid yesterday and flew here with their hostages after Cairo rejected their demands to scrap the Sinai agreement were turned over today to the representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization here.

title: Vail Fails As Mets Win in 18
description: Mike Vail started the game with a 23game hittng streak and ended it in a slump. The Mets' exciting rookie walked his first time at bat and made a variety of outs in his seven efforts. His batting average plummeted 22 points. If that had happened in the stock market, financial experts would have warned of a depression.

title: Tennis Association Plans Higher Prize Money Tournaments for Fringe Players
description: There is a no man's land in tennis where frustrations run high, where a player is too old to compete in the junior ranks and not quite ready to give the leading pros a battle. Although he may he a potential star, he finds it hard to get into the bigtime tournaments or even the qualifying rounds. He becomes a fringe player.

title: Rangers' 5Man Goalie Union Gets Scrutinized by Stewart
description: LONG BEACH, L. L, Sept. 16After the New York Rangers finished their first scrimmage of the training season this morning, the skaters left from one side of the rink while a troop of goalies crossed the ice and went out the other side into a separate locker room. They've got their own union, Ron Stewart, the Ranger coach, said jokingly.

title: U.S. Involvement in Mideast Must Grow, Dayan Asserts
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Sept. 16Moshe Dayan, the former Israeli Minister of Defense, warned tonight that if Americans do not want to face another Vietnam in the Middle East they must be prepared to become more deeply involved even at the risk of haying to confront the Soviet Union.

title: The Rayburn Myth
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16There is a widespread misconception that the House of Representatives has failed to perform effectively this year and that weak leadership is the reason.

title: Homosexual Airman Argues at Hearing Ouster Is Unlawful
description: HAMPTON, Va., Sept. 16 (UPI)  Attorneys for Sgt. Leonard Matlovich of the Air Force argued today that the mlitary was unlawfully trying to impose on him the moral standards of the majority by requiring his discharge for admitting that he was a homosexual.

title: REVISIONS PROPOSED FOR ELECTRIC RATES
description: Economic efficiency and covering the cost of service should be the chief considerations of the State Public Service Commission in reforming electric rate structures, and economic consultant to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz told the commission in Albany yesterday.

title: Greenspan Sees No Big Upurge In Prices After Summet's Rises
description: In a speech heavy with caution, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said herd yesterday that the doubledigit inflation, of martinet was an aberration and probably no the start of another major upsurge in prices.

title: About Real Estate
description: Until a few years ago it was possible to ride an escalator from the ground floor of the fourstory Airlines Building at 80 East 42d Street to a high mezzanine where the major airlines sold flight tickets.

title: Recipes From England And Mexico (Cont'd)
description: Diana Kennedy's Crumpets

title: Brewers Win, 52; Yanks Eliminated
Soviet Grain Position
description: The Soviet Union was reported to have accepted the principle of longterm commitments to buy grain from the United States, a step that could prevent American foodprice surges caused by sudden Soviet purchases. Page 63.

title: Pro Transactions
description: HOCKEY

title: Durkin, Democrat, Voted New Hampshire Senator
description: CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 16John A. Durkin, a 39yearold Democratic moderate, won a decisive victory tonight over Louis C. Wyman, a fiveterm conservative Republican Representative, in a rematch of last November's deadlocked New Hampshire Senate election.

title: PRICE WATERHOUSE AND GULF OIL CITED
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, 16 past and current officers and the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse & Co. were named yesterday in a suit filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn charging them with concealing illegal political contributions, United Press International reports.

title: Turner and 3 Former Associates Fined in Violation of S.E.C. Rule
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 16 (AP)A sobbing Glenn W. Turner, a sharecropper's son who parlayed Iii gift of gab into a business empire he later lost, was fined $5,000 today, ending what he termed a sevenyear battle with the Federal Government.

title: Against Public Strikes . . .
description: The Board of Education's pillowsoft contract with unionized teachers and the recent victimization of San Francisco by striking police and firemen point up afresh the unevenness of the bargaining balance between beleaguered cities and unions in control of their vital services.

title: COAST JUDGE GETS SIRHAN TRIAL DATA
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (UPI) A prosecutor said today that there had been substantial irregularities in handling exhibits connected with the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy in 1968, and handed over the pistol and part of the fatal bullet fired by Sirhan B. Sirhan, Mr. Kennedy's convicted assassin, to a county judge.

title: FLORIDA TO FREE 2 IN DISPUTED DEATHS
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 16 (AP)Two men who spent 12 years in prison, eight of them on Death Row, for a pair of brutal murders another man confessed to nine years ago will be freed Friday.

title: AN ARMENIAN HERE GUILTY OF SPYING
description: An Armenian diamond cutter living here as a permanent resident alien pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court Brooklyn to charges that he had conspired to turn over to the Soviet Union secret NATO and United States defense documents.

title: Local Elections in Norway Show a Trend to the Right
description: OSLO, Norway, Sept. 16 (Reuters)Norwegians turned right in their twoday municipal and regional elections, almost complete returns showed today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1975

title: F.B.I. Chiefs Linked To Oswald File Loss
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14Top officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigationprobably including former Director J. Edgar Hooverordered the destruction of a letter in which Lee Harvey Oswald, assassin of President Kennedy, conveyed violent threats about 10 days before he killed the President, according to a source familiar with the meeting where this decision was made.

title: School Design Reflects Education Shifts
description: No building type has undergone quite so radical a change in the last decade as the school building, and the changes indicate how closely intertwined design and daytoday function can be. New teaching methods have required buildings that are more open and flexible than those old redbrick schoolhouses with their rows of identical desks inside rows of identical classrooms that still dot the cityscape. Architects, rather than leading in this case, have usually fitted their designs around these new demands. But by enshrining educational change in concrete, the new buildings themselves have become symbols of the new education.

title: Senate AntiToxin
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence is trying to find out why the Central Intelligence Agency has been storing shellfish toxin and cobra venomenough to kill thousands of people  along with instruments designed for their delivery, including a silent poisondart gun that could kill without a trace. It should find outespecially in view of former President Nixon's order for the destruction of this deadly stockpile and this country's announcement to the world that it had in fact been destroyed.

title: Roderick Stephens Dead; Won '31 Atlantic Yacht Race
description: Roderick Stephens, an amateur yachtsman and a retired retail fuel merchant in the Bronx; died Thursday at his home at 530 East 23d Street. He was 89 years old.

title: TV: Ethnic References of Beacon Hill Stirring Controversy
description: Although Beacon Hill is not having an easy time in the survival game of audience ratings, the new CBS series (Tuesdays at 10 P.M.) is having no difficulty arousing passionat,e reactions to its portrait of masters and servants in a Boston household of the nineteentwenties. Based very loosely on the British series Upstairs, Downstairs, which has won Emmy Awards for public television here, Beacon Hill is proving unusually adept at offending large segments of the viewing audience.

title: Ford Defends Israel Aid, But Denies Commitment
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Ford said today that the United States would supply Israel with very substantial military weaponry in the aftermath of the new EgyptianIsrael agreement in Sinai, but insisted that American diplomatic, political and defense assurances did not constitute a security treaty with Israel.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE OLD GANG There are, according to a recent count, at least 947,878 people in New York city who are 65 years old and older. And today is their day in Central Park. Officially it's the Sixth Annual Senior Citizens' Carnival and Awards Presentation.

title: U.S. DRUG AGENCY REPORTED BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15A report by a White House study group, to be made public next month, will recommend the preservation of the Justice Department's embattled Drug Enforcement Administration, but with some significant changes in the agency's operations, according to Federal officials familiar with the report.

title: Union Solidarity Lacking in Votes on Pact
description: When Albert Shanker had finished his prosettlement speech to the United Federation of Teachers delegate assembly at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum yesterday morning, a small group in frontrow seats rose to sing Solidarity Forever.

title: School Design Reflects Education Shifts
description: No building type has undergone quite so radical a change in the last decade as the school building, and the changes indicate how closely intertwined design and daytoday function can be. New teaching methods have required buildings that are more open and flexible than those old redbrick school houses with their rows of identical desks inside rows of identical classrooms that still dot the cityscape. Architects, rather than leading in this case, have usually fitted their designs around these new demands. But by enshrining educational change in concrete, the new buildings themselves have become symbols of the new education.

title: For Chorus Line, a Moon Shot of Broadway Lighting
description: The wistfully tough showgirl steps to the front of the stage. She throws her head back and shades here eyes with her hand. What's the matter, Sheila? the director calls out. That light, she replies. What color is it? Got anything softer?

title: PENNSY TRUSTEES FAULT RAIL PLAN
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Railroad charged yesterday that the United States Railway Association's plan for reorganization of the bankrupt Northeastern railroads was nationalization . . . on terms that amount to confiscation.

title: New Head of Assembly
description: LUXEMBOURG  The leader of Luxembourg, the President of the current session of the United Nations General Assembly, is noted in Western Europe for an ability to cut through to the main issues within becoming entangled in details.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Metropolitan Opera has announced a new plan to attract young adults who do not qualify for its student and children's series. The plan will offer people 35 years of age and younger a package of orchestra seats for three operas, librettos for each opera, a backstage lour and a trial subscription to Opera News magazine for $30. Purchased separately, the tickets and other items would cost between $55 and $73.

title: Highlights of Agreement
description: The following are highlights of the Memorandum of Agreement between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers.

title: Dollar Hits a Peak For Year Abroad; Pound Still Lower
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 16 (UPI)The dollar reached its highest levels of the year on European money markets today, spurred mainly by the relatively favorable economic outlook in the United States. Gold fell in Zurich, Switzerland, to $147 an ounce from $148.50 and in London to $147.50 from $148.50.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Joseph Kallinger, accused of carrying out a threestate fatherson crime spree, took the stand today in his robbery trial in Harrisburg, Pa., and reluctantly testified that he talked directly to God, that he was 1,000 years old and that he was once a butterfly.

title: NURSING AIDES SEEKING TO QUIT
description: Officials of the Metropolitan Nursing Home Association informed the State Health Department yesterday that most of its members wanted to get out of the nursing home business.

title: SHOP TALK
description: If you like pleasant ambiance, service and good food, get out your checkbook and head for one of the city's justly renowned restaurants.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 16 (AP)If the Baltimore Orioles and Boston Red Sox finish in a tie for the American League Eastern Division lead, the title would be decided by a onegame playoff in Baltimore on Tuesday night, Sept. 30, the Orioles said today.

title: Chevette Introduced as an Answer to Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Chevrolet introduced the Chevette today, a new small car that the General Motors Corporation hopes will heat hack rising import sales in the same way that the Vega did after its introduction in 1970.

title: U.N. ADOPTS PLAN FOR POOR NATIONS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16Rich and poor countries, at the end of 16 days of intensive but generally restrained debate, unanimously agreed today on measures to narrow the gap dividing them.

title: Simon Asserts Some Investors Now Expect the City to Default
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 16Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today that some bankers, brokers and private investors dealing in New York bonds expected the city to default.

title: Subway Here Used To Assess Threat Of a Germ Attack
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Central Intelligence Agency secretly used the New York City subways to test the vulnerability of subway systems to a biologicalwarfare attack, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence learned today.

title: From the Idea to Its Fruition, the Artist in HandBlown Glass Does It All
description: CELO, N.C.William Bernstein was being cautious with this one, the second crystal eagle he had tried that day.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1975

title: Business Briefs
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Sept. 16 (Reuters)Ecuador will not be bound by future price rulings by the Organization Petroleum Exporting Countries, the country's Natural Resources Minister. Jaime Duenas, said today.

title: Hugh M. Redhead, Ad Executive In Detroit, Is Killed in Air Crash
description: Hugh M. Redhead, a leading Detroit advertising executive, was killed Friday in a plane crash near Uniontown, Pa. He was 55 years old and lived in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: COLBY DESCRIBES C.I.A. POISON WORK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Central Intelligence Agency operated an 18year, $3million supersecret project to develop poisons, biochemical, weapons and such devices as dart guns to administer them, the agency's director testified today.

title: KENDALL J. MAU
description: Kendall J. Mau, an assistant vice president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, died yesterday at his home in Ramsey, N.J. He was 57 years old.

title: Two Policemen A re Slain; East Side Gunman Escapes
description: Two police officers were shot and killed last night on the Lower East Side after stopping a car for an unknown reason. The two officers, one of them a sergeant, were gunned down shortly after 9 o'clock on East Fifth Street near Avenue B.

title: Bridge:
description: It is not long since prominent Californian bridge teacher, Frank Thomas, disclosed the surprising news that Sherlock Holmes was a bridge player.

title: Missiles for Jordan
description: The Administration and Congress reached agreement on a compromise to allow Jordan to receive 14 batteries of Hawk missiles from the United States. Page 3.

title: New Books
description: A History of Golf, Illustrated, by Henry Cotton, forward by Sam Snead (Lippincott, $16.95).

title: About Education
description: Mixed in with demands for salary increases, the issue of class size is coming to the forefront this fall in teacher strikes in the region and in other parts of the country.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Following is the White House transcript of a news conference held by President Ford today in the Oval Office of the White House:

title: Japanese Premier Lists Plans to Fight Recession
description: TOKYO, Sept. 16 (Reuters)Premier Takeo Miki outlined before Parliament today a program to pull Japan out of recession through vast Government spending on public works, aid for medium and small businesses and plans to lower the bank rate.

title: Fromme Roommate Held
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept 16 (UPI)Susan Murphy, a roommate of Lynette Alice Fromme, was arrested today for a probation violation as she left a court hearing for Miss Fromme. She was on probatilon after a conviction for petty theft.

title: CHINA OPENS TALK ON AGRICULTURE
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 16China opened a najor national conference on agriculture today attended by a large number of senior leaders, including Teng Hsiaoping, the first ranking Deputy Premier, and Chairman Mao Tse  tung's wife, Chiang Ching.

title: ... Debt to the Children
description: When the schools reopen tomorrow, the teachers' first priority must be to give the lie to their own leadership's prestrike propaganda campaign of fear. The parents must be reassured that there was simply no truth to union scare tactics aimed at persuading them that the city's austerity budget condemned their children to inferior schooling.

title: Missiles for Jordan
description: The Administration and Congress reached agreement on a compromise to allow Jordan to receive 14 batteries of Hawk missiles from the United States. Page 3.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: COLBY DESCRIBES C.I.A. POISON WORK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Central Intelligence Agency operated an 18year, $3million supersecret project to develop poisons, biochemical weapons and such devices as dart guns to administer them, the agency's director testified today.

title: Local Boards Assail Cuts In Pupils' Time in Classes
description: Widespread hostility appeared to be emerging in community school boards yesterday to the agreement mandating shorter school days to end the teacher strike, even though it developed that some board members had earlier suggested such cutsbut as a matter of local option.

title: 4 CONCERNS PARE GASOLINE PRICES
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (UPI) Four oil companies reduced the price of gasoline at the wholesale level today to bring to rive the number of companies that have lowered prices since controls were lifted Sept. 1.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: One of the companies that recently decided to stay in front of the national trend to abolish the socalled fairtrade laws was L'Eggs Products, makers of women's hosiery. L'eggs, based in Winston  Salem, N.C., announced that it would no longer fairtrade its products even in states that still allowed the practice, which enables a Manufacturer to force retailers to maintain a certain price.

title: NASA EXPECTS DATA ABOUT OZONE BY '77
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)The space agency expects enough information to be gathered in the next two years to resolveM the question of whether spray can gases are damaging the ozone layer that protects the earth from harmful radiation.

title: Filing of False Data Laid to Insurers
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16 (AP)A state insurance official said today that the country's largest property insurance rating organization based a current application for auto insurance irate increases on wrong and incomplete financial information.

title: Profit Declines at Commonwealth Oil
Women Get Backing As Rhodes Scholars
description: American administrators of the Rhodes Scholarships have announced plans to make women eligible for the prestigious fellowships beginning next year.

title: EDMUNDE. THOMAS, REALTY FINANCIER
description: Edmund E. Thomas, who was president and a governor of the Real Estate Board of New York from 1962 to 1965, died Monday at Community Hospital, Glen Cove, L.I. He was 72 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: About New York
description: New York is so big that it is constantly getting away from us. By the time a New Yorker believes he knows the town pretty well, he runs into a new neighborhood or some little enclave he had never known about.

title: PENTAGON RAISES ATOM TOLL COUNT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Defense Department has significantly increased its estimates of civilian casualities that would result from a selective Soviet nuclear strike against military bases in the United States.

title: 5 Indicted in Plot to Pay For Jersey City Contracts
description: NEWARK, Sept. 16A Fedral grand jury today indicted five persons among them a New York City officialand two Brooklynbased corporations on charges of conspiring to bribe Jersey City authorities for the purpose of winning $33million in building and reconstruction projects.

title: F.B.I. Chiefs Linked To Oswald File Loss
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14Top officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigationprobably including former Director J. Edgar Hooverordered the destruction of a letter in which Lee Harvey Oswald, assassin of President Kennedy, conveyed violent threats about 10 days before he killed the President, according to a source familiar with the meeting where this decision was made.

title: Old Tires Haven't Reached End of Road
description: Rubber tires as play items have a respectably ancient history (at least as ancient as the automobile). Children in backyards have been gliding through the air on tire swings for generations. And in recent years, these swings have become popular in playgrounds.

title: Brooks Atkinson To Receive Award
description: Brooks Atkinson, former drama critic for The New York Times, will receive the 25year News Achievement Award of the Society of Silurians, Paul Buiar, president of the news group, announced yesterday. The award will be presented at the society's dinner on Oct. 20 at the Riverboat, Fifth Avenue at 34th Street.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Tucson Gas and Electric Company is expected to offer one million shares of $2.89 preferred stock, at $27.50 a share. through underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch and Blyth Eastman Dillon & Co. The stock, rated Aminus by Standard & Poor's, is expected to yield 10.509 per cent.

title: Clemency Board Ends; President Praises It
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)President Ford today praised his outgoing Presidential Clemency Board for its diligence in seeking to reconcile opponents of the war in Vietnam.

title: TALLY 10,6516,695
description: Members of the United Federation of Teachers, amid much dissatisfaction, yesterday voted to end the teachers' strike and school officials quickly announced plans for a resumption of classes tomorrow morning for the city's 1.1million pupils.

title: Stennett Gets 7 Hits As Pirates Win, 220
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP)Rennie Stennett set a modern major league record with seven straight hits today as the Pittsburgh Pirates trounced the Chicago Cubs, 220, in the most lopsided shutout in modern major league history.

title: Britannica Yields to Criticism, Alters Soviet Republic Articles
description: The Encyclopaedia Britannica which is crowded with facts, is now trying to cope with an awkward onethe need to revise all 15 of its articles on the 15 republics of the Soviet Union.

title: Barcelona Rightists Demand A Crackdown on Guerrillas
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 16 (Reuters)Hundreds of rightwing demonstrators raising their hands in the Fascist salute paraded through Barcelona today in a protest demanding tougher action against urban guerrillas.

title: HARVEY JOHNSON, 80, EXFEDERAL JUDGE
description: OMAHA, Sept. 16 (UPI)Harvey M. Johnson, a Federal judge who in 1974 ruled against President Richard M. Nixon in a Florida canalconstruction case, died yesterday of complications following surgery. He was 80 years old.

title: Portugal's Universities, Now in Chaos, Are Looking Urgently for Guidelines
description: LISBON, Sept. 16Where are Portuguese universities going? People ask this with increasing concern, and almost no one seems to have an answer.

title: U.N. ADOPTS PLAN FOR POOR NATIONS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16Rich and poor countries, at the end of 16 days of intensive but generally restrained debate, unanimously agreed today on measures to narrow the gap dividing them.

title: PRESIDENT READY TO DEFY HOUSE BID FOR VIETNAM DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Ford said today that he would defy a subpoena ordering him to turn over, classified documents on the Vietnam War to the House Select Committee on Intelligence unless the committee adopted procedures to safeguard sensitive materials.

title: Facts for Voters
description: This is the year of the long ballot for New Yorkers. In the polling booth it means that every voter will have to be a student of government as well as a judge of candidates. It will be impossible to make decisions and choices intelligently, or at all, without prior information and contemplation. To wait until the Nov. 4 Election Day will be too late.

title: A.M.C's Pacer Model Sets Production Mark
description: DETROIT, Sept. 16 (UPI)Officials of the American Motors Corporation said today that production of the new Pacer had passed the 100,000 mark, less than eight months after output began. The company is preparing to increase production for the second time since the car was introduced on Jan. 13.

title: Noted Bookbinder Turns A New Leaf in His Field
description: The guild of bookbinders is so small and special that it is not often that a member breaks out into international prominence. But Philip Smith, a 47yearold Briton, has achieved such excellence in the field and brought so many new ideas to it that his books have been exhibited ??oth here and abroad and have become part of private and public collections, including those of the British Museum, the Victoria and Albert Museum and the New York Public Library.

title: People and Business
description: Clifford D. Sherd, who is 63 years old, announced yesterday that he would retire as chairman and chief executive officer of the American Cyanamid Company, effective Dec. 31.

title: Two Policemen Are Slain; East Side Gunman Escapes
description: Two police officers were shot and killed last night on the Lower East Side after stopping a car for a routine traffic check. According to the police, the two officers, one of them a sergeant, were shot shortly after 9 P.M. when they ordered the car to a halt in front of 537 East Fifth Street, between Avenues A and B.

title: A Familiar Accord
description: The agreement reached between the teachers and the Board of Education matches in broad outline the contract package worked out this summer by most of the other municipal unions with they city and the Municipal Assistance Corporation. The specified wage increases will, in all likelihood, be frozen; the teachers will give back one work rule (in this case, some preparation periods), and they apparently will get roughly 2,000 of their laidoff people rehired.

title: Pozole de Jalisco
description: (A pork and hominy soup or stew)

title: Futures Prices of Grains in Rebound
description: Corn, wheat and soybeans rebounded sharply in prices on the Chicago Board of Trade in commodities trading yesterday.

description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Crimes Against Homosexuals Analyzed
description: A preliminary analysis of killings involving homosexuals has indicated that persons who murder homosexuals are most likely to be heterosexualsat least outwardlywho have a strong fear or hatred of homosexuality, or who may themselves be fighting homosexual tendencies.

title: 3 Soviet Helicopter Men Still Detained by Chinese
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 16 (AP)The Soviet Union said today that three helicopter crew members who landed in China last year were still in Chinese custody.

title: Nine Pawtucket Teachers Jailed for Defying Injunction
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 10 (AP)Nine officers of the Pawtucket teachers' association were sent to jail today on contemptofcourt charges, stemming from their defiance of a backtowork injunction.

title: As New York Vote on Equal Rights Nears, Two Sides Speak Out
description: Sandra Turner says confidently that all of the polls are on her side and that so is the side of right. Still, she has one recurring nightmare: that many of the voters who favor the state Equal Rights Amendment won't go to the polls on Nov. 4.

title: Poor Work Is Found at Welfare Centers
description: Slovenly work standards in welfare centers and weak supervision of the staffs contributed significantly to overpayments that might run into millions of dollars, Controller Arthur Levitt reported yesterday.

title: Encephalitis in West Virginia
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Sept. 17 (AP)Laboratory tests have confirmed that the St. Louis strain of encephalitis has spread into West Virginia, state health officials said today. The tests showed that two person in Charleston hospitals had contracted the disease. In addition, four cases of suspected encepha litis were reported yesterday in Parkersburg.

title: Books of The Times
description: NIGHTWORK. By Irwin Shaw. 344 pages. Octetcarte. $8.95.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Stoney rates for Wednesday.

title: Elderly Enjoy a Carnival in Park Plus a Movie Chase
description: Thousands of elderly New Yorkers yesterday took hayrides, watched magic shows and learned to bake bread at a carnival in Central Park held to pay tribute to the city's 11.8 million elderly.

title: New Missiles for Mideast: A Destabilizing Factor
description: The possibility that Israel, after discussions with the United States, will acquire mediumrange surfacetosurface missiles is regarded by qualified informants in Washington and Western Europe as a Military significant step toAnalysis ward expanded warfare in the Middle East. Both Israel and the Arab states have aircraft capable of carrying heavy payloads of nonnuclear or nuclear bombs. But the advent of such missilesa similar Sovietbuilt one is in the Arab arsenalsmeans the introduction of increasingly accurate vehicles that are more difficult to destroy in flight than fighterbombers.

title: THE NATION EDITOR IS RETIRING AT 70
description: Somewhat like the man who came to dinner, Carey McWilliams, an oldfashioned. American radical, arrived in New York in 1951 to edit a special issue of The Nation, and stayed on and on and on until, now nearing 70, he has decided to retire and write the books he had taken advances on more than 26 years ago.

title: Dave Anderson
description: His consecutivegame hitting streak has ended at 23, the longest in the major leagues this season, but 23yearold Mike Vail's future with the New York Mets has only begun. He will play center field this winter in the Venezuelan League as indoctrination for a possible transfer next season from left field. His batting style doesn't need any adjustments, judging by his performance in the month since being promoted from the Tidewater, Va., farm team in the International League, where he won the batting title with a .342 average. He's an aggressive hitter, says Tom Seaver, and that's the first aspect of a good hitter. He hits to all fields, he's got a good idea of the strike zone. Mike Vail belongs in the big leagues now. The romanticists would call it his dream come true. But the romanticists don't know about the reality. Mike Vail's marriage broke up because his former wife believed he never would make the big leagues. She didn't want the hassle of a minor league life. After four months, their marriage was annulled early this year.

title: A Black Lung Rally in Capitol Seeks Improvements in the Law
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17More than 1,500 coal miners, their wives and miners' widows, swarmed over Capitol Hill to day in an orderly demonstration for sweeping improvements in the Federal black lung compensation program, already controversial because of its unexpectedly high cost to they Government.

title: STUDENT IS RAPED IN COLUMBIA DORM
description: A 22yearold Columbia University student was raped at knifepoint in her dormitory room at Hudson Hall on West 114th Street, the police reported yesterday.

title: Music: A Mixed Debut
description: The New Orchestra asked no quarter in its inaugural concert on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, and it gave none. The mostly young, entirely brave, ensemble took on a program that placed a strain on both players and listeners. For their part, the performers bore up admirably: under the night's two conductors, Arthur Weisberg and Charles Wuorinen, the New Orchestra sounded equal to any problem a modern composer might wish to throw at it.

title: Fiscal Crisis Called '76 Campaign Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17Democratic Presidential candidates and potential candidates predicted today that the New York City fiscal crisis would be a major issue in the 1976 Presidential campaign.

title: Market Place
description: The conventional wisdom in Wall Street is that institutions account for perhaps 70 per cent of the dollar volume of public trading and as the dominant influence determine which stocks go up and down.

title: Piscatorial Tone Enhances Rauch Kennel
description: Thomas Rauch, an ardent fisherman, gives a piscatorial touch to his kennel. All our English cockers  and we have 14are named after fishing flies, says the fancier from Royal Oak, Md. In addition the Rauches have a dumber spaniel, a greyhound and Yorshire terriers.

title: School Board Plans Strike Penalties
description: The Board of Education is planning to go ahead with the legally required penalty procedures against individual teachers who participated in the weeklong strike, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1975

title: KATHERINE C. LIPPERT
description: Katherine C. Lippert, former art director of Scholastic Magazines, Inc., publisher of classroom materials, died yesterday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital She was 63 years nil and lived at 202 Scribner Avenue, Norwalk.

title: ITALY'S PREMIER SEEKS REDS' AID
description: ROME, Sept. 17The Italian Government has called on the country's restive unions to show restraint in negotiations for new threeyear contracts.

title: Hermitage Art Draws Eager Crowd
description: A line of eager visitors was already waiting when the exhibition of Master Paintings from the Hermitage and the State Russian Museum, Leningrad opened at 10 A.M. yesterday at M. Knoedler & Co., 21 East 70th Street. By 10:15 both floors of the gallery were crowded with the intent and happy faces of people who had come expecting a great artistic treat and looked as if they were fully satisfied with what they saw.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Defense psychiatrists testined that Robert Mottershead, on trial in the slaying of his two children, was insane at the time of the Aug. 16, 1974, killings. Mr. Mottershead, a Little Silver stockbroker, pleaded not guilty on the ground of insanity when the trial opened Tuesday in Freehold. He contended he had been distraught over his wife's imminent death from cancer, and because of business troubles.

title: National News Council Scores A Weekly's Article on Rainiers
description: The National News Council agreed yesterday with a complaint about two articles that said Prince Rainier and Princess Grace were living apart, but it found without merit four other unrelated complaints.

title: State Rebuts Testimony Of Insurance Association
description: TRENTON, Sept. 17Though a major segment of the insurance industry contends it can no longer afford to write automobile policies in the state because of unrealistic rates, some companies as recently as last year were paying agents substantial commissions to bring in new business, Phillipp K. Stern, chief propertyliability actuary for the State Department of Insurance, said today.

title: . . . How Durable?
description: The United States did express reservations about some passages in the 6,000word Assembly document, while promising to join in most of the specific undertakings. These reservations, coupled with the fact that Washington for years shunned exactly the kind of positive approach to the poorer nations that it has now embraced, leave open to question just how vigorously the Ford Administration is prepared to follow through on its proposals.

title: PRICES DECLINE IN GOLD FUTURES
description: Following lower prices for gold in London, gold futures here moved to new contract lows on the Commodity Exchange. The October delivery closed at $142, an ounce, down from $145 9/10 on Tuesday, after being as low as $141 4/10 during the session.

title: U.S. Pilot Blamed for Crash That Killed 157 in Nigeria
description: LAGOS, Nigeria. Sept. 17 (Reuters)The American pilot of a Boeing 707 jetliner was blamed today for the air crash in 1973 in which 157 homewardbound Moslem pilgrims died.

title: The Cast
description: THE TOOTH OF CRIME, the Performance Group in a play by Sam Shrnard; a film by Ken Kohland and lames McCarthy; directed for the stage by Richard Schechter; produced for the stage by the Performance Groun Runring time: 97 minutes. At the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue and 75th Street.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company announced yesterday a price of $12.25 a share on its offering of six million common shares to existing shareholders. Of the total, 3.9 million will be offered to shareholders on the basis of one new share for each 15 shares held as of record yesterday. The balance will be offered through a supplemental subscription.

title: ABC'S GOLDENSON TALKS OF GADGETS
description: Leonard H. Goldenson, chairman of the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., yesterday called it an unproductive exercise to think of the new communications technologiescable TV, pay television, video cassettes, video disks and home satellite receivers  as the key to the future of visual recorded entertainment.

description: ALBANY, Sept. 17Governor Carey today disclosed the outlines of what he described a a reorganization of the top administrative echelon of the State Mental Hygiene Department. The agency, which has come under much criticism in the last year, cares for about 53,000 persons in 55 institutions at a cost of about $1billion a year.

title: The Theater: Boy Meets Boy, a Musical
description: The Actors Playhouse in Sheridan Square was a busy theater during the heyday of Off Broadway, but it closed several years ago, a victim of the economic squeeze. Last night the producer Edith O'Hara reopened the house with a new musical, Boy Meets Boy. The theater deserves a welcome, which is more than can be extended to the show.

title: MADRID TRIAL OUSTS MILITANTS' COUNSEL
description: MADRID, Sept. 17 (Reuters) Lawyers defending five leftist militants accused of murdering a police officer were expelled from court today shortly after courtmartial proceedings opened.

title: Shetlands Are Not So Tiny They Can't Restrain Big Oil
description: LERWICK, Shetland IslandsWe were trawling over a piece of bottom where we'd been dozens of times before, said the first mate of the Sunbeam. When we heaved up to see what the catch was, there was nothing. The net was ripped.

description: CORK, Ireland, Sept. 17 (AP) Mary Penelope Hillyard, owner of the famed Blarney Stone, died in a fire yesterday, her husband, Maj. J. M. Hillyard, said today.

description: A spokesman for the Transit Authority said yesterday that as far as could be determined now no one in that agency had any knowledge of a secret Central Intelligence Agency project in which the city's subways were used to test the vulnerability of subway systerns to a biologicalwarfare attack.

No, No, No
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE E WERE married at the Griboyedov Street registry office in Moscow on May 4, 1974. The ceremony had been delayed a month; someone put pressure on Irina's mother to request a postponement (although Irina was then 35, Soviet law required her mother's permission for her to marry a foreigner). But we did get married, and we were supremely happy.

title: People and Business
description: James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, asserted in Washington yesterday that there should be no further argument as to whether the capital shortage threat is real.

title: Namath Excused From Session
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 17The New York Jets put on a show of solidarity today, staying out of official team practice for the second day in their strike against the National Football League, but working out for an hour 45 minutes on their own at a nearby public park.

title: Cyprus Stalemate: Still No Compromise
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 14The outlook for the Cyprus problem seems gloomier than lever following the breakdown of the fourth round of peace talks in New York last week. Diplomatic analysts here now feel that the current deadlock between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes is likely to continue. Accordingly, the results of that stalemate would also persist: corroding tensions between Greece and Turkey, deepening divisions between the two Cypriote communities, hardship and discontent among 180,000 Greek Cypriote refugees and thousands of displaced Turkish Cypriotes.

description: BASEBALL

description: EDDYPaul Dawson. Memorial service for Adelphi University President Emeritus, Paul Dawson Eddy. Saturday, September 20, at 4 P.M Cathedral of the IncarnaNon, Garden City, Long Island, N.Y.

title: Witnesses at Kallinger Trial Differ
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 17 Defense and prosecution toxicologists disagreed today on whether breathing toxic fumes in his shoe repair shop could have deranged Joseph Kallinger before the time he is alleged to have robbed four women here of $20,000 in cash and jewelry. In addition, psychiatrists for both sides disagreed on Mr. Kallinger's mental condition prior to the time of the alleged robbery.

title: Haddad to Head New State Unit With Broad Investigative Powers
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut announced yesterday the appointment of William F. Haddad, former newspaper reporter and government official, to a $40,000ayear post as director of a new office to investigate such areas as municipal bond dealing, electronic surveillance and alleged economic discrimination by Arab oil interests.

description: BRAVIN1st Lt. Joseph Simon, Quangtri, Vietnam, Sept. 19, 1968. In proud and loying memory of our Joey, who believed in the psalm Drag me not away with the wicked, and with the workers of ?? who sneak peace with their neighbors, but evil is in their hearts. Our tears are mingled with pride. Restsoldier sonrest with your fallen comrades in honor and peace ?? the dawn of Thy promised resurrection.

title: Advertising
description: Time Inc. and Audits & Surveys, the research company, unveiled for the press yesterday the Timesponsored audience study of 10 top consumer magazines in which Time magazine shows up quite a bit better than it did in recently issued syndicated studies.

title: Screen: Tooth of Crime
description: The Tooth of Crime is nighttime opera, a black vision of a presentday phenomenonthe rise and fall of the stars of pop culture, suddenly famous and suddenly extinguishedas if it were the bloody and dangerous rite of some primitive tribe. It is the present seen as the barbarous prehistory of inhuman future.

title: Four Murdered Officers Served Together
description: There was a macabre link in the lives of four policemen, all from the Ninth Precinct on the Lower East Side, all shot to death on patrol here.

title: State Attorney General Is Intervening In the Court Case of Girl Long in Coma
description: MORRISTOWN, Sept. 17State Attorney General William F. Hyland today announced that his office would enter the Superior Court case that will examine whether a court can authorize a guardian to withdraw lifesustaining medical procedures from a terminally ill patient, thereby allowing her to die.

title: Mrs. Harry O'Donnell, 56, Wife of Carey Aide, Is Dead
description: Margaret McTiernan O'Donnell, wife of Harry J. O'Donnell, communications director for Governor Carey, died yesterday in Albany Medical Center. She was 56 years old.

title: Ford Aides Hint Tax Plans Depend on Spending Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17A further big upsurge of Federal Government spending in pros pect for the next fiscal year has become a complicating element in the decision facing President Ford on whether to recommend extension of the temporary 1975 tax reduction that expires Dec. 31.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Sept. 17 (UPI)The National Union of Blastfutmacemen announced today it would begin a nationwide strike Sunday that would shut down the steel industry in England and Wales.

title: 'Swept Away' Is a Wertmuller Film With Solid Appeal
description: Summer. A blue Mediterranean seascape seen through sunlit mist. In the distance a handsome white yawl moves with the light breeze. On the soundtrack we hear some jazzy instrumental music that recalls the score of every Italian film about the sweet life you've ever seen, but there's a point to it in the film. It pollutes air that once was as pure as it looked.As the camera nears the yacht, the music gives way to the bickering of the yacht's well-heeled passengers. The mood that from a distance had seemed so serene turns suddenly, abrasively indolentand furiously funny. People who have nothing to do, no visible responsibility to anything except tan skin, angrily debate capitalism, Communism, consumerism, the role of the Vatican in Italian life, while complaining about a crewman's smelly T-shirt.This is the beginning of Lina Wertmuller's most entertaining new Italian comedy, "Swept Away (By an Unusual Destiny in the Blue Sea of August),f" which opened yesterday at the Cinema II Theater."Swept Away" is Miss Wertmuller's fourth film to be released in this country. It follows "The Lizards," which was shown in New York several years ago as part of a Festival of Women's Films, "Love and Anarchy" and "The Seduction of Mimi," and it's played by the two actors, Giancarlo Giannini and Mariangela Melato, who were so remarkable in the latter two films. It's also by far the lightest, most successful fusion of Miss Wertmuller's two favorite themes, sex and politics, which are here so thoroughly and so successfully tangled that they become a single subject, like two people in love.The shape of the film is as artificial as a fairy tale or a cartoon strip. Raffaella (Miss Melato), the rich, beautiful, acid-tongued Milanese who has chartered the yacht, and Gennarino (Giannini), the swarthy Sicilian deckhand whose T-shirts offend her, are marooned for several weeks on the only Mediterranean island not yet occupied by German tourists. They are Popeye and Olive Oyl locked in passionate combat.The way Gennarino folds his pants and shirtquickly, neatly, according to careful training that has become habit, you know he is a man who believes all things have their place, including women, who belong in the house with the children. Raffaella is an intelligent, selfish, superficially liberated slob who has never picked up anything in her life if there was an outside chance someone else would pick it up for her.He is a Communist with the dedication of a first-century Christian. She is a capitalist because, for her, the system has paid off. More important, he is a man and she is a woman, for which there is hell to pay on both sides."Swept Away" is the story of their tumultuous, slapstick courtship, his systematic humiliation of her (as she sees it) until, suddenly, she submits to her love for him and becomes in the process truly liberated. Feminists, I suspect, will debate a number of plot points as if Miss Wertmuller had set out to write a treatise and not to make a love story, some of whose meanings are not easily translated into feminist agitprop.More easily apparent are the director-writer's concerns about the Italian society that bred these two people and turned them into the mixed-up, wrong-headed characters they are, capable occasionally of unexpected, if imperfect nobility. Her sympathies appear to be more with Gennarino than Raffaella, but that's a matter of politics, not sex, and he is, on the surface, a male chauvinist pig of a classic type."Swept Away" is less a film about ideas than about previous commitments, for which neither character can be held completely accountable. The enormous appeal of the comedy has to do with the way, briefly, each character, is able to overcome those commitments.It also has to do with the performances of Mr. Giannini and Miss Melato, who tear into their roles with a single-minded intensity that manages to be both hugely comic and believable, even in the most outrageous of situations. They are the best things to happen to Italian comedy since Marcello Mastroianni and Sophia Loren squared off in the nineteen-sixties.

title: MixedUse Complex In Queens Debated Before Planning Unit
description: The City Planning Commission last night heard arguments on permission to create a special zoning district that would permit construction of a proposed $150million commercial, residential and office complex in the Rego Park section of Queens.

title: Article 1  No Title
ELECTION AGENCY MAY MODIFY RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The Federal Election Commission, facing a revolt by the Congressmen who created it, will apparently water down its proposed crackdown on Congressional slush funds.

title: POISON ARMS BAN IS CITED BY HELMS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17Richard Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence, told a Senate committee today that he had issued an oral command to halt the C.I.A.'s biochemical weapons program and to destroy its stockpiles, but that he had never followed up to find out if his order had been carried out.

title: Senate Panel Passes Bill To Tighten Rules on Grain

title: Mahan, Leading Cowboy, Brings His BullRiding Act Into Town
