The signing of a oneyear, nooption contract reported to be worth about $ 75,000 came one day after the National Football League had modified its rules to permit Gilliam to return. Gilliam played with the Chicago Winds of the W.F.L. until the team folded last month.

title: Flood Warning in Utah
description: MANTI, Utah, Sept. 17 (UPI) Residents of this town of 1,800, threatened by an earthslide that could set loose a flood, received emeregncy help today from the National Weather Service. A flash flood warning system was being installed at the site of the earthslide, which has been accelerating for several weeks and in some places is now moving at several feet a day.

title: AMEX STOCKS OFF AS VOLUME FALLS
description: Despite a brief rally in the afternoon, stock prices closed lower yesterday in quiet trading on the American Stock Exchange. Stocks in the overthecounter market closed mixed.

title: CHICAGO TEACHERS REACH AN ACCORD
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 17  A tentative agreement in the 11day strike by Chicago's public school teachers was reached this afternoon.

title: Rothschild Calls Copperweld U.S. Investment Choice
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 (AP) Baron Guy de Rothschild, the French financier, said in Federal District Court here today that his company believes the Copperweld Corporation is the hest American company it could invest in despite legal problems in taking over the company.

title: The Coleman Octet On Bill at Boomer's In Rambling Show
description: The nine musicians who, for some reason, were billed as the George Coleman Octet at Boomer's at 340 Bleecker Street on Monday and Tuesday, have enough talent to stock two or three jazz groups. As a matter, of fact, four of them are in a quintet, Keno Duke's Contemporaries, which will be at Boomer's next Monday and Tuesday. When it is playing as a full ensemble, the octet has a distinctively rich, fullbodied sound and an intense, swaggering attackthe sound built around four saxophones and a flugelhorn, the swagger propelled by a strong fourpiece rhythm section. When it breaks down to support individual soloists, the group retains these same qualities  but only up to a point. The soloists have flair and even individuality, particularly Danny Moore on flugelhorn: Harold Mahern, piano; Frank Strozier, on alto saxophone, and Mr. Coleman on tenor saxophone. But, except for Mr. Mahern, they seem determined to make the least of their potential by stretching out their solos to, and even beyond, a point of diminishing returns.

title: Screen: Poisonous 'Bug':Story of Beetles That Set People Afire
description: Movie companies have the right to make bad pictures and reviewers the right to say unkind things about them. Normally, that is that: The public buys tickets, or not, the producer makes money, or not, and not much other harm is done. "Bug," which opened yesterday at Loews State 2 and Cin, raises a different problem.To put it by analogy: If a restaurant reviewer eats a poor meal, that's one thing. If he gets ptomaine poisoning, that's another. "Bug" is decidedly poisonous.It is not simply a scary picture, nor simply a violent one. It is a cruel picture. Not necessarily because of the theme which is as improbable as, but not necessarily more harmful than, those of dozens of other pictures.An earthquake releases from the depths of the earth a swarm of ash-eating beetles with the property of setting objects, people and animals violently on fire. Cars explode, people burn up, buildings are set ablaze. The beetles are badly adapted to surviving above ground until a mad scientist develops a new, resistant strain. There are horrendous explosions at the end, and as far as the viewer can tellthe narrative is pretty fuzzythe new beetles swarm out to destroy the world.So far, so bad. In the classical horror film the horror was somehow overcome at the end. Stakes were driven through the vampires. Civilization, in some fashion, fought back. In "Bug"as in "Rosemary's Baby," an earlier film by the same producer, William Castleevil won and civilization was not only ineffective, but also virtually compliant.Horror pictures need upbeat endings as no other kind of movie does, precisely because they are pure fantasy. Who could stand a fairy tale in which the witch ate Hansel and Gretel and staved in business?But there is worse. The fear and loathing of small, crawling, barely visible creatures are a lot more basic and widespread than the fear, say, of white sharks. Spiders, mice, snakesthese are specific children's nightmares. The movie does vile things with this susceptibility. A girl answers the telephone and a beetle hidden in the receiver sets her ear on fire. A housewife is thumbing through a cookbook and a beetle gets in her hair and sets her hair on fire. A cat plays with a beetle and is horribly burned to death. All this is done with highly competent special effects and relentless, unending screaming.For some inexplicable reason "Bug" is rated PG. This means that parents should advise their children whether or not to go. Most parents will not be able to see "Bug" before deciding. This review urges them to decide no. "Bug" is sick, and literally sickening.

title: Bridge:
description: It is not uncommon for an expert to retire for a year or two from the tournament scene and then make a successful reappearance. But ail records in this area were eclipsed in San Francisco over the Labor Day weekend when a star of the thirties returned after an absence of almost 40 years and captured a major title.

title: TV:
description: For a series supposedly obsessed with authentic detail, Beacon Hill has made some startlingly stupid blunders. Putting a wealthy IrishAmerican family on Brahmin Boston's Beacon Hill in the nineteentwenties was a major one. A confusion of accents is in the crowded minor category. The Irish brogues are wobbly things at best, except for Paul Rudd's depiction of Brian, the chauffeur, whose lilt is entirely on key. And all other accents have a tendency to swerve into a flat Boston a so suddenly that even insensitive ears are regularly being jolted.

title: Screen: 'Ali the Man':Portrait of the Fighter Finds Him an Enigma
description: On the eve of his third bout with Joe Frazier, Muhammad Ali is still as much an enigma as a charismatic, enduring champion to judge by "Ali the Man," which, with the previous "Ali the Fighter," arrived at the Penthouse yesterday. As a documentation of a long career that, according to Ali, includes 280 fights, it is a slick, surface, fragmented portrait that is not especially penetrating or memorable. It is largely the Ali the public already knows, a truly fascinating figure but one whose heart and mind are rarely exposed fully.Out of an amalgam of color footage directed by Rick Baxter, old black-and-white film dating back to the callow Cassius Clay of Olympics fame, and a Richie Havens recording session intercut into the action, the Muhammad Ali that emerges appears to be all things to all men. Ali's philosophies are represented in discussions with black kids in Harlem, in projecting his feelings about his Muslim faith and in his somewhat confusing attitude on violence in the ring.This production, which ranged from Harlem to Tokyo, as well as stops at bouts and training camps in this country, also manages to focus on his wartime confrontation with the armed forces and the conflict between his faith and Army service that made the front pages, which unfortunately doesn't add to these old records. And, there's a good deal of highly stylized footage of Ali jogging through sylvan settings against the background of Mr. Haven's plaintive music ("don't let them try to keep you down"), as well as constant chatter by the champ, who, at one point, makes it comic when he says, "I hate fighters who talk too much."Of course, there are clips for the fight fans too. A succession of knockout in slow motion, as well as prefight, stagy, vociferous clashes with such opponents as Jerry Quarry and Sonny Liston, are fleeting and, like much of "Ali the Man," it merely illustrates but doesn't really reveal a highly complex, controversial human being.The associate attraction, "Ali the Fighter," the documentary of the first Ali-Frazier fight, which was released here in January, 1974, as "The Fighters," is highly recommended, however, both as an excellent fight film and as an incisive view of the principals and the fight game, which isn't a game at all.

description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 17The Nassau County police, who six weeks ago received a large salary increase from an arbitration panel, will have to wait for their raise as a result of a decision today by the State Supreme Court.

title: West Coast Grain Moving
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 17 (UPI)A Liberianflag vessel sailed from Puget Sound for the Soviet Union this week with about $7.75million worth of grain loaded in Portland and Seattle,, a spokesman for the local office of cargill, Inc., said yesterday. The chartered vessel Grischuna took on 672,000 bushels of wheat in Portland and 1,142,000 bushels in Seattle, the cargill office said.

It is too early to be sure the corner will stay turned; but this sixteenday session at least brought a dramatic turnaround of the Assemblyfrom incendiary rhetoric and confrontation to reality and genuine negotiation.

title: Son of Watergate
description: The circling and snarling about how the House Select Committee on Intelligence will handle classified information may sound like a straight replay of former President Nixon's bitterend fights with Congress. Yet what in fact is at stake is a more highly evolved secondgeneration Watergate issue of a quite different kind. This controversy does not involve issues of executive privilege and criminality. Rather, the question is whether, in the wake of Watergate, Congress will at last actually begin to exercise its oversight functions with respect to the nation's most sensitive agencies.

Wearing glasses and a gray sweater over an opencollared gray shirt, Arnsparger sat on a blue bench under a warm sun on the Pace University campus.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Israel's Defense Minister, Shimon Peres, asked the United States to supply his country with battlefield support missiles. He told the National Press Club in Washington that his Government was ready to guarantee that they would be armed only with nonnuclear warheads. He said the Lance missile, with a 60mile range, and the Pershing, with a 450mile range, were needed to offset missiles supplied by the Soviet Union to the Arabs. [Page 1, Column 3.]

title: U. S.Israel Pact on Geneva
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17Following is the text of a previously unpublished memorandum of agreement between the United States and Israel dealing with the Geneva peace conference. It was signed by Secretary of State Kissinger and by Foreign Minister Yigal Allan.

title: The Cast
description: BUG, directed by Jeannot Szwarc; screenplay by William Castle and Thomas Page, based on The Heghaestus Plague by Mr. Page; director of photography, Michel Hugo; edited by Alan Jacobs; produced by Mr. Castle; released by Paramount Pictures. At Loews State 2, Broadway and 45th Street, and Loews Cine, Third Avenue at 86th Street. Running time: 100 minutes. This film is classified PG.

title: European Football
description: EUROPEAN CUP

title: House Unit Approves Easing Arms Embargo Against Turks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (Reuters)A bill to relax the United States arms embargo against Turkey was approved today by a House committee after President Ford had warned that a continued ban could jeopardize American security interests in the eastern Mediterranean beyond repair.

title: FERTILIZER SUPPLY EXPECTED TO FALL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)  Government experts say natural gas shortages are expected to keep farm fertilizer supplies in the current 197576 season slightly below last year's level.

title: JOHN J. CROSBY DIES; POLICE REPORTER, 69
description: John J. Crosby, who covered, stories out of the old Police Headquarters on Centre Street for more than four decades, died Tuesday in Oak Ridge, Tenn.

title: Nero Is Favored in 19Horse Jug Today
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 17 (UPI)A recordtying field of 19 pacers, including Nero, go after a record $147,813 purse tomorrow in the 30th Little Brown Jug. The field of 3yearolds is the largest since 1961, when Henry T. Adios defeated 18 others over the halfmile Delaware County Fairgrounds track and it forces this year's Jug to be divided into two divisions with a raceoff for the top four finishers in each. A horse must win two heats to take the Jug, so if a third winner emerges from the first raceoff, there will be a fourth and final heat later.

title: Only Congress Itself
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The Senate Intelligence Committee, with its televised hearings on secret C.I.A. poisons, provides the immediate drama in Washington. But the parallel House investigation may have a more profound impact on the larger issues raised by American intelligence activities in recent years. The reason lies in contrasting attitudes toward the crucial question of executive secrecy.

title: Woman Is Said to Place Key Figure at Site
description: While a massive manhunt quickly spread from the Lower East Side into New Jersey and Pennsylvania, the police held in protective custody yesterday a woman who they believed could identify the gunman or gunmen who shot and killed two police officers on Tuesday night.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Du Pont Export Prices Cut On Antiknock Compounds
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., announced yesterday reductions in export prices for its lead antiknock compounds by an average of 5.6 per cent, retroactive to Sept. 1. A spokesman said the move followed a similar reduction by the Ethyl Corporation earlier this month.

title: Weeden & Co. Plans A Move to Jersey To Cut Security Tax
description: Weeden & Co., the big New York brokerage house, disclosed yesterday that it was planning to move nearly half of its New York operations to New Jersey next spring to avoid new city taxes on securities.

title: Homosexual Sergeant Asks Air Force That He Not Be Discharged
description: HAMPTON, Va., Sept. 17 (UPI)Telling an Air Force hearing about his first night in a homosexual bar, a rootlesst childhood in a military family and his Vietnam service, T.Sgt. Leonard P. Matlovich pleaded, repeatedly today that he not be discharged from the service because of his homosexuality.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Giants, Lions Raise Strike Total to Five
description: The pro football strike picked up little momentum yesterday. The New York Giants joined the three other striking teams, the Jets, New England and Washington, and the Detroit Lions did, too, in a halfhearted fashion. But five other teams voted not to strike and to play. The owners, through their management council's executive committee, want to play, too.

title: 2 Special Phones Open For Word on Slayings
description: The police have set up two telephone numbers for people who have information about the shooting of Sgt. Frederick Reddy and Police Officer Andrew Glover.

title: New Flu Strain Reported
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 17 (UPI)A new strain of Asian influenza called AScotlandhas made its appearance, hut epidemiologists say they have no reason to expect a major epidemic during the approaching flu season. The National Center for Disease Control here said this week that reports from the World Health Organization showed only sporadic and scattered cases of influenza in other areas of the world.

title: MEDIATION OFFICE ON ECOLOGY SET UP
description: An experimental environmental mediation service, believed to be the first in the country, has been so successful in its first effort to solve a major, longstanding environmental conflict in the Northwest that it is being established as a permanent unit, the Ford Foundation announced here this week.

title: Ballistics Expert in Sirhan Case Says Bullets Have Deteriorated
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17Questions concerning the present condition of ballistics evidence were raised today at the second day of hearings in the courtordered reexamination of the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

title: New Clashes Erupt In Much of Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon Thursday, Sept. 18Heavy firing broke out in wide sections of Beirut early today, and the Governmentrun radio warned all residents to stay off the streets.

title: Poll Made for State Democrats Indicates Buckley Would Defeat Any of Five Candidates
description: Senator James L. Buckley, who won a first term with a minority of the vote in 1970, would, as of now, defeat five potential Democratic Senate candidates, according to a poll commissioned by the Democratic State Committee.

title: U.S. Note: Safety and High Yield, Too
description: The hot new issue for investors in 1975 suddenly has become the Treasury note, a giltedged security backed by the full faith and credit of the United States Government.

title: NATO Arms Team Reported to Choose U.S. Gun and Shell
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  An American tank gun and a United States shell capable of penetrating new Soviet armored vehicles have been selected by a threenation NATO evaluation group for the next generation of NATO tanks, informed government sources said today.

title: United Merchants Loss
description: United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., the large producer of textiles, has reported a quarter loss of $24.05million compared with a profit of $5.29million a year ago. Page 59.

title: PRICES OF BONDS SCORE ADVANCES
description: Aggressive bidding for the Treasury's twoyear notes auctioned Tuesday helped send prices higher yesterday in the government and corporate bond markets as trading increased. Both markets had been depressed in recent days following forecasts of higher Treasury cash needs than had been expected because of rising Government expenditures.

title: POLL ??NDS WOMEN GAIN VOTER FAVOR
description: A woman running for public office today will find a more receptive atmosphere than ever before, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Preserved Treasure
description: Good news is rare in New York City these days, but those who believe that this metropolis has a future as a city and not just as an exercise in crisis accounting are gladdened by word that a way has been found to save the Gold Room of the landmark Villard Houses on Madison Avenue.

title: Undercover Drug Agent Is Indicted on 15 Counts
description: An undercover detective whose arrest on a Federal indictment 18 months ago in part resulted in the end of an unusual investigation of the garment district was indicted yesterday by a special state grand jury, on bribery and extortion charges.

title: Catholic Schools Issues
description: The Lay Faculty Association of New York, representing 328 teachers at 12 high schools, with 12,000 students, in the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Jet Uses SideLooking Radar To Search for New Gas Sites
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 17A jet plane equipped with radar devices that look sideways may be a key to finding prospective sources of natural gas, official of two companies involved in the project said here today.

title: Egyptians Refuse to Allow Abie Nathan to Use Canal
description: CAIRO, Sept. 17 (Reuters)Egypt has refused to allow Abie Nathan, the Israeli peace campaigner, to sail his ship through the Suez Canal, Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt said tonight.

title: A Large Surplus Shown In Balance of Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The United States basic balance of payments swung into surplus in this year's second quarter while the balance on current account showed a record surplus of $4.1billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A Gift of Eloquence
description: The Blarney Stone is a limestone rock that is said to confer eloquence on all who kiss it. It is set in a turret below the battlements on the southern side of the castle, which was built about 1446 by Cormac Laidhiv McCarthy, Lord of Muskerry. One must hang, head downward, to kiss the stone.

title: RELEASED EGYPTIAN GIVES ARAFAT CREDIT
description: MADRID, Sept. 17 (Reuters) The Egyptian Ambassador to Spain, taken hostage by Palestinian guerrillas in his embassy here on Monday, said today that the direct intervention of Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, helped end the siege.

title: LOSS IS REPORTED BY TEXTILE MAKER
description: United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., reported yesterday a net loss of $24.05million in the fourth fiscal quarter ended June 30 against a ngt profit of $5.29million in the yearearlier quarter. The company is one of the nation's largest textile producers, has commercial factoring and finance operations and also owns the Robert Hall retail clothing chain.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Omen for 1976
description: The runoff of New Hampshire's deadlocked Senate election has resulted in a democratic victory in both a small d and a big D sense.

title: The Newest Senator
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17John Anthony Durkin, New Hampshire's Democratic Senatorelect, recently characterized the last 10 months of uncertainty as the most frustrating period of my life. More typically, the sharptongued Mr. Durkin also described it as a long damn election night.

title: Suffolk Police State Tactics Reported Against Friends of County Prosecutor
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Sept. 17  Henry F. O'Brien, the Suffolk County District Attorney, charged today that the Suffolk police had continued to intimidate and urge his friends and former clients to provide evidence of homosexual activity against him.

title: Stock Prices Are Mixed, but Dow Gains
description: Stock prices turned mixed yesterday with some bargain hunting in bluechip and glamour issues lifting the Dow Jones industrial average to its first gain in six trading days. However, declines again led advances, reflecting continued investor uncertainty.

title: BEAME VISIT FINDS REFUSE MEN GONE
description: Mayor Beame made a surprise visit to a Sanitation Department garage at 57th Street and 12th Avenue yesterday and found that more than half the workers had quit at least 30 minutes early.

title: FORD IS REBUFFED BY A HOUSE PANEL ON OFFER OF DATA
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 17Representative Otis G. Pike, chairman of the House Select Committee on Intelligence, refused today to accept a lastminute offer of classified intelligence materials from the White House on the ground that they were incomplete, had been screened in advance and delivered on the condition that they not be made public.

title: Turkish Village Leveled
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 17 (Reuters)A tremor today destroyed the 80 houses still standing in the southeastern town of Hani, hit by a violent earthquake last week, local officials said. Injuries were slight.

title: Paris Presses Ransom Bid
description: PARIS, Sept. 17 (AP)France announced today that she had made a new attempt to get Chad rebels to accpet the $2.2million ransom she is offering for the life of a Frenchwoman held prisoner for 17 months. Radio broadcasts have failed to bring any response from the Touhou rebels who live in northern Chad and have threatened to execute Francoise Claustre, an arche ologist, next Tuesday if their demands are not met.

title: SOVIET BORROWING MORE IN THE WEST
description: PARIS, Sept. 17The Soviet Union and its Eastern European allies have become large borrowers in international capital markets, bankers in Europe reported today.

title: How N.F.L. Clubs Stand on Strike
description: The various positions taken by the 26 teams of the National Football League:

title: Durkin Victory to Cost G.O.P. 5 Committee Seats in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) Five Republican Senators will lose their committee assignments because of John A. Ourkin's victory yesterday in New Hampshire's special Senate election, while three other Republicans will he shifted to lowerranking panels.

title: Woman Is Held Briefly as Link to Suspect
description: While a massive manhunt quickly spread from the Lower East Side into New Jersey and Pennsylvania, the police yesterday questioned at least 35 persons in seeking the identity of the gunman or gunmen who shot and killed two police officers on Tuesday night.

title: Killer Given Life in Attack In School at Penns Grovel
description: SALEM, Sept. 17 (AP)David Gary has been sentenced to life imprisonment for the Feb. 24 shotgun slaying of the Rev. Thomas Quinlan at St. James Regional Grammar Shool in Penns Grove.

title: 5th Rikers Fugitive Seized While Trying To Swim to Freedom
description: The fifth of eight prisoners who escaped last Saturday night from the Men's House of Detention on Rikers Island was recaptured yesterday in the East River. The three other prisoners are still missing.

title: H. Walton Cloke, 56, Dies; Public Relations Executive
description: H. Walton Cloke, a public relations executive and a former correspondent for The New York Times, was killed Friday in a plane accident near Uniontown, Pa. He was 56 years old.

title: House Panel Decides to Revise Sports Franchise Tax Shelter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The House Ways and Means Committee decided today to close off part of the route whereby wealthy individuals can realize large tax savings by buying and selling the franchises of professional sports teams.

title: ISRAELI MILES OUT ANY NUCLEAR USE OF U. S. MISSILES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Defense Minister Shimon Peres today asked the United States to supply Israel with battlefield support missiles and said that his Government was ready to guarantee that they would be armed only with conventional warheads.

title: At I. S. 59, the Return of the Teachers Is Marked by Uncertainty and Rancor
description: The teachers returned to their empty classrooms yesterday and began brushing up lesson plans for 1,300 youngsters who will come back to Intermediate School 59 in Springfield GarIdens. Queens, today.

title: Phyllis Wins Top TV Rating For the Networks' New Series
description: Phyllis, a Monday night situation comedy on CBS that stars Cloris Leachman, was the highestrated of the new network series last week, the opening of the season. But rating experts regard its de??ut as a qualified success because it precedes All in the Family, which led all other programs in the national Nielsen ratings. All in the Family has been moved this season from its accustomed Saturday night time period. Hit shows of its caliber usually influence the viewing for programs that precede and follow them.

title: 4 Guards Stabbed And One Is Beaten By Attica Prisoner
description: A 30yearold inmate at the Attica Correctional Facility apparently went berserk yesterday and stabbed four guards, one critically, and clubbed a fifth before being subdued by other guards and inmates.

title: ANTIBUSING MEASURE APPROVED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)The Senate approved today antibusing language that would prevent the Department of Health, Education and Welfare from using Federal funds to compel communities to bus pupils as a means of school desegregation.

title: BEEF PACKER GIVEN DATE TO STAND TRIAL
description: OMAHA, Sept. 17 (AP)A Federal judge today ordered Frank R. West, founder and president of the bankrupt American Beef Packers, Inc., to stand trial Oct. 14 on charges that he conspired to defraud Midwestern livestock raisers out of more than $20million.

title: Areas of Colorado and Utah Favored in Oil Shale Projects
description: DENVER, Sept. 17 (AP)The Interior Department's Oil Shale Environmental Advisory Panel received a recommendation today calling for development of two in situ prototype oil shale projects in Colorado and Utah.

title: 2 COMPANIES SEEK CABLETV RATE RISE
description: The two cable television companies serving ManhattanManhattan Cable TV and Teleprompter Manhattan Cable TV have petitioned the Board of Estimate for permission to raise their monthly charge.

title: Journalism Review Folds
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (UPI) The Chicago Journalism Review will cease publication after next month's issue because of mounting financial troubles and a lack of support from the working press.

title: Tanner Wins, Amritraj Is Upset
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17They met for the first time today in the Pacific Southwest open tennis championships, but Bernie Mitton and Roscoe Tanner belong to an exclusive club of six menthose who have beaten Jimmy Connors this year. Mitton did it at Chichester and Tanner at Nottingham, English tournaments held just before Wimbledon.

title: Cubs' Burris Tops Mets, 52
Southern Governors Seek Deregulation of Oil Prices
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.. Sept. 17 (UPI)  The 41st Southern Governors Conference concluded today with many Governors urging Congress to deregulate oil prices and to remove regulations on natural gas sales.

title: 100 Flee as Tanker Crashes
description: CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 17 (UPI)About 100 persons were ordered from their homes in a subdivision near here yesterday when a gasoline tanker truck overturned, killing its driver and spilling hundreds of gallons of gasoline, the police said. Steve Malone, the 49yearold driver, was killed when he attempted to turn the rig around at the top of a hill near his home, the police said. The tanker overturned and crushed the cab.

title: Domestic Output of Crude Oil Hits Lowest Level in 9 Years
description: Crudeoil production in the United States fell to 8.24 mil lion barrels a day in the week, ended Sept. 12, its lowest level since August, 1966.

title: POISON ARMS BAN IS CITED BY HELMS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17Richard Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence, told a Senate committee today that he had issued an oral command to halt the C.I.A.'s biochemical weapons program and to destroy its stockpiles, but that he had never followed up to find out if his order had been carried out.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2  No Title
LIBRARY AIDES LOSE ON PRINCETON UNION
description: PRINCETON, Sept. 17  Library assistants at Princeton University defeated, 97 to 72, a proposal to unionize with representation in the American Federation of State. County and Municipal Employes of the A.F.L.C.I.O.

title: ISRAELI RULES OUT ANY NUCLEAR USE of U. S. MISSILES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Defense Minister Shimon Peres today asked the United States to supply Israel with battlefield support missiles and said that his Government was ready to guarantee that they would be armed only with conventional warheads.

title: JOURNALIST SEEKS TO REPLACE SCOTT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17George R. Packard, a journalist who once worked for the Central Intelligence Agency, announced today his candidacy for the seat now held by Hugh Scott, the 74yearold United States Senate minority leader, who is a pillar of Pennsylvania's Republican party.

title: Woman in Oregon Dam Counts Salmon Parade
description: TROUTDALE, Ore. For eight hours a day, Beverly Bennett sits in a carpeted room deep inside the cement bowels of the massive Bonneville Dam near here staring at a fivefootsquare window. In front of her eyes silently parade the populations of another world, an underwater world whose secrets researchers have yet to fully fathom.

title: Camco Acquisition Is Planned in Bid By NL Industries
description: NL Industries, an international manufacturer of chemical and metal products with annual sales of $1.6billion, has made an acquisition proposal to Camco, Inc., of Houston, maker of oil well equipment. The proposal is for an exchange of 1,379,486 outstanding common shares of Camco for shares of NL Industries on the basis of one share of Camco for .95 shares of NL Industries.

title: Newfoundland Vote Keeps Conservatives in Power
description: SAINT JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Sept. 17 (AP) Premier Frank D. Moores and his Conservative party government maintained control of Newfoundland's 51seat Legislature in provincial elections yesterday.

title: State Cites 20 Employers As LobbyLaw Violators
description: Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo forwarded to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday the names of 20 employers of lobbyists who failed to file, by a Sept. 12 deadline, statements of money spent for lobbying activities.

title: OREGON REPEALS ACT CURBING POLICE DATA
description: SALEM, Ore.. Sept. 17The Oregon Legislature repealed last night a fourdayold law that unintentionally required arrest reports and court records to be secret.

title: DADAP'S MUSIC BEST IN ROMANTIC MOOD
description: Michael Dadap, a Philippine guitarist who made his debut here in 1974, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night for a program in the series called New Talents of the Guitar presented by Aran??iuez Guitar Strings.

title: Ford Aides Hint Tax Plans Depend on Spending Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17A further big upsurge of Federal. Government spending in prospect for the next fiscal year has become a complicating element in the decision facing President Ford on whether to recommend extension of the temporary 1975 tax reduction that expires Dec. 31.

title: College, School Results
Top Inspector Says A.I.D. Is Strangled in Red Tape
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The State Department's evaluator of foreignassistance programs has charged that the Agency for International Development, as presently constituted, cannot succeed in its mission of administering American aid abroad.

title: Personal Finance:
description: In times of economic downturn, consumer frauds usually become widespread. There are more people attempting to commit frauds, victimizing the unwary who fall for free or cheap offers.

title: First Woman to Head Major British Party Makes Some Political Points as She Winds Up Tour Here
description: At Precisely 11 A.M. yesterday, Margaret Thatcher, the British Conservative party leader, stepped up to the lectern in front of several hundred members of the Foreign. Policy Association, placed her watch before her, said thank you for the gracious introduction, ticked off on her fingers the major points she would make in her speech and spoke for exactly 30 minutes.

title: Ulster Protestants Reject a Coalition With the Catholics
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 18  The allProtestant Unionist coalition voted overwhelmingly today to reject the mainly Roman Catholic Social Democratic and Labor party as a partner in a government of Ulster.

title: CHARLIE ROUSE PUTS RHYTHM INTO SEXTET
description: Charlie Rouse, the tenor saxophonist who followed along in the scintillating wake of Thelonious Monk's piano in Mr. Monk's quartet for many years, is leading a group of his own this week at the Five Spot, 2 St. Mark's Place.

title: House Passes Measure Cutting School Lunch Cost
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI)The House passed today a compromise bill that reduces the price of school lunches for low  middle  income children when free lunches are served to povertylevel students.

title: Mideast Arms Race ...
description: The first visible consequence of the new Sinai pact between Egypt and Israel is an upgrading in the deadliness of the military hardware which the United States is preparing to make available to both Israeli and Arab sides of the conflict.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FISHING LINE The Seafood Playhouse, a restaurant at 209 West 48th Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, is presenting these days what is said to be the first chorus line in a major Broadway nightclub since the closing of the Latin Quarter in 1969.

title: 100,000 Indochina Refugees Resettled; 34,992 Are Still at Three Camps in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Resettlement of Vietnamese and Cambodian refugees who fled their homelands last spring passed the 100,000 mark this week, the Ford Administration announced today.

title: Stock Index Adds 15.56; Gain Best Since Aug. 28
description: Stock prices registered their best gains of the month yesterday in an upturn fed by expanded bargain hunting in bluechip and glamour issues and declines in Treasury bill rates in the debt market.

title: Next Task for Jets: Catching UP to Bills
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 18  The Jets' two  day  old strike, designed to force an agreement between the players and management, as well as to show support for the New England Patriots, ended today, perhaps successfully.

title: Agency Is Accused of Bias In Adoption of Cambodians
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (AP) A Roman Catholic man and a Jewish woman testified yesterday that an adoption agency refused to let them adopt Cambodian children in Operation Babylift because they were not evangelical Protestants.

title: Unpublished Work By Joyce Is Found
description: Kenning James Joyce usually means purswhoing him by wordtracks and wisecracks, Doublin back over the grail to find that demned effusive simpletell.

title: Notes on People
description: Twice turned down for the honor when Richard M. Nixon was President, Linus C. Pauling, tile twotime winner of the Nobel Prize, yesterday received from President Ford the nation's highest award for persons in his field, the National Medal of Science.

title: Catholic School Strike Angers Parents
description: As public schools reopened yesterday, many parents of 14.000 parochial school students looked with frustration and anger as strikes by lay unionized teachers continued at 14 Roman Catholic high schools in the city and Westchester County.

title: 2 Suspects Are Identified In Slaying of 2 Policemen
description: The police have identified the two suspects in the kiling of two police officers on Tuesday night, but fear that releasing either their names or pictures would jeopardize any court case that might be brought against them.

title: Broker Is Not Guilty In Slaying of Children
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 18 (UPI)  Robert Mottershead, a 45yearold Little Silver stockbroker, was judged innocent by reason of insanity in the shooting death of his two children, who were slain in their beds on Aug. 16, 1974.

title: Sports Today
description: Practice runs for Trenton twin 200's, at Trenton (N.J.) International Speedway, 2 and 5 P.M.

title: Well, I Love Her, Father Says Upon Hearing News
description: Well, I love her, Randolph A. Hearst said last night of his daughter Patricia, who called him a fascist pig when she was a fugitive.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1975

title: U.S. Cost of Sinai Surveillance Outlined
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18A House committee was told today that it will initially cost the United States $7million to $10million to establish the facilities for 200 civilian technicians and post them in the Sinai passes to monitor the latest EgyptianIsraeli agreement.

title: NICOLA MOSCONA, IXET BASS, IS DEAD
description: Nicola Moscona, the Greek bass who sang leading roles with the Metropolitan Opera for 25 years and was chosen for many performances by Arturo Toscanini, died, apparently of a heart attack, Wednesday in Philadelphia, where he taught at the Academy of Vocal Arts. He was 68 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: Many a bridge Walter Mitty sits at home dreaming of international success. If only I had the chance, he muses, I could play as well as any of them  perhaps better.

title: Doubt Is Voiced on Impact Of U.S. Plan on Poor Lands
description: While the proposals on economic development made by the United States at the recent special session of the United Nation General Assembly have had a dramatic political impact, their concrete economic impact will be slight, according to a number of economists who deal with international issues.

title: India Assails Ford for Crisis Remarks
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 18The Government of India today sharply rebuked President Ford for his criticism of the state of emergency under which thousands of political dissidents have been arrested in this country.

title: U.S. Officials Surprised
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18State Department officials expressed surprise today at Jordan's refusal of the Hawk antiaircraft missiles under the compromise conditions that had been worked out by the Ford Administration and Congress.

title: Closings Startle Theater Patrons
description: Broadway on a night at the beginning of the most prosperous theater season in years: taxicabs pull up to the theater, people get out, look anticipatingly at the brightly lit marquee. A Chorus Line, Chicago, The Wiz. The soldout sign is up at the box office. The lobby is filled, but the theater is empty. The musicians are on strike and the show does not go on.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx called for a Federal investigation to determine whether property owners here were violating incometax laws by claiming deductions for payments of local realestate taxes even though they might not be making those payments. He said that the I.R.S. [Internal Revenue Service] apparently has no way of knowing whether or not the owner eventually pays the taxes, or even whether he ever intended to pay them in the first place.

title: Thais Reject Chinese Oil As Too Waxy to Refine
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 18Serious production problems have been discovered in connection with the crude oil from China and the Thai Government has suspended all barter deals involving the Chinese oil.

title: 5 to 10% Price Rise In Oil Seen by Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) Iran disassociated itself today from oil cartel extremists and said it would support a modest oil price increase when the 14member organization meets next week in Vienna.

title: British Unemployment Rises
description: LONDON, Sept, 18 (Reuters) British unemployment in September rose 29,900 from August to 997,000 seasonally adjusted and excluding those who left school and adult students, the Department of Employment said today. This represents 4.4 per cent of the working. population and is 394,000 higher than in September last year.

title: H.E.W. Firm on New Standards For DayCare Center Personnel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The Department of Health, Education and Welfare is not planning to relax standards for daycare center personnel that are scheduled to take effect next month although it is under pressure to do so.

title: Defense Is Rangers' Chief Liability and Islanders' Chief Asset
description: The New York Rangers have a problem that the New York Islanders could solve if the teams cared to merge, a fantasy that could occur only in the minds of hockey fans.

title: Wife of Disabled Veteran Wins $250,000 in Lottery
description: MENLO PARK, Sept. 18 (UPI) Carol L. Lauton of Bayonne, the wife of a disabled veteran of World War II, won the $250,000 top prize today in the, Jersey jackpot lottery.

title: A Jury Finds Kallinger Guilty On All Charges in Harrisburg
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 18 After deliberating less than one hour, a jury of six men and six women today convicted Joseph Kallinger of burglary and the binding and robbery of four women at a suburban home here last Dec. 3.

title: About the Giants . .
description: Craig Morton, the quarterback, twisted his right wrist last Saturday night against Miami and had an ice pack on it after yesterday's practice. But he said it would be O.K. . . . Henry Stuckey, cornerback, and Willie Young, offensive tackle, won't he ready to play in Sunday's opener in Philadelphia. Jim Stienke will move into Stuckey's spot while Toni Mullen apparently will switch from guard to tackle and Dick Enderle will step into Mullen's spot. . . Doug Van Horn, Giant player representative, called the labor situation chaos, explaining there are 26 teams doing 26 different things. He added that it could be a sign of weak union leadership and said, Maybe we need a new leader. . . . Giants have canceled their annual kickoff luncheon, which had been scheduled for the Americana Hotel today.

title: Glomar Explorer Now Free To Sail Despite Tax Dispute
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (UPI)The Glomar Explorer which retrieved part of a sunken Soviet submarine, is free to go to sea again while the Federal and county governments wrangle over her tax status in a stalled court action.

title: Arthur J. Michaels, 85, Dies; Textile Importer, Designer
description: Arthur J. Michaels, the founder and president of the A. J. Michaels Company here, a designer and importer of textiles, died yesterday at the United Hospital in Port Chester. N. Y. He was 85 years old and lived on Manursing Island, Rye, N. Y.

title: Undoing Justice
description: Through an action ostensibly designed to placate sentiment against forced school busing, the Senate has started a process that could unravel Title VI of the Civil Rights Act, one of the major legislative accomplishments of the nineteensixties.

title: Belmont Jockeys
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Unpublished Work By Joyce Is Found
description: Kenning James Joyce usually means purswhoing him by wordtracks and wisecracks, Doublin back over the grail to find that demned effusive simpletell.

title: Dinkins Named City Clerk In a Quick Vote by Council
description: The City Council, acting with unusual speed, elected David N. Dinkins as City Clerk yesterday and half an hour later Mayor Beame swore him into the $37,344ayear position. The Mayor had recommended him for the post earlier this week.

title: Contract Awards
description: Shipping and Coal Company, Rotterdam, the Netherlands, has received a $46.5million contract for coal from the United States Defense Supply Agency.

title: SPERRY WEIGHING DEAL WITH XEROX
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation said yesterday that it was seriously considering whether to buy the Xerox Corporation's computer customer base.

title: A Girlish Fugitive In a TShirt, Smiling
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Sept. 18She didn't look like the focus of a nationwide search. She didn't look like an heiress. She looked, instead, like someone who might stand unnoticed in an allnight cafeteria.

title: LaidOff Policemen Here March In Washington Over Job Losses
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Two thousand laidoff New York City policemen and firemen marched silently around the Capitol today and then stood in formation in a heavy rain to hear New York Congressmen decry their loss of jobs.

title: Card of Thanks
description: NICOLSGeorge H. Nicols. The family of the late Honorable, George H. Nicols, Supreme Court Justice of the State of New York, Kings County wish to thank all their friend for their kind expression at condolence and sympathy extended to them during their recent sorrow.

title: INFORMATION COST TARGET OF MAYOR
description: At the behest of his management advisory board, Mayor Beame has ordered a study of the city's scattered information apparatus aimed at reducing the number of people engaged in public and community information, ending duplication and leading eventually to the creation of a centralized news bureau.

title: House Panel Votes to End Escape From Tax by Rich
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a change in the tax laws that would terminate, almost without exception, the ability of highincome individuals to escave all Federal income taxes.

title: About Real Estate
description: The season is over in the Rockaways, and Robert and Peg Donlon are drawing a breath of satisfaction with their salty evening air.

title: Explosion in Seattle Store Is Linked to Hearst Arrest
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 18 (AP)A bomb exploded at a Seattle grocery store tonight shortly after a television station received a call saying a bomb would go off in retaliation for the arrest of Patricia Hearst.

title: Homosexual Sergeant Described By Doctor as No Risk to Security
description: HAMPTON, Va., Sept. 18 (AP) An Mr Force discharge board was told today that T.Sgt. Leonard P. Matlovich, a homosexual, would not he a security risk or involve other servicemen in homosexuality if permitted to remain in the military.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This effectively puts an end to everyone I know who was a member of the S.L.A.Charles Bates, the Federal Bureau of Investigation agent in charge of the Patricia Hearst case. [20:5.]

title: Harris Opens His Headquarters Here in 1976 Bid, Emphasizing Volunteer Effort
description: Fred Harris yesterday opened the first public headquarters in the city for the 1976 Presidential campaign and offered this lesson from his populiststyle race: There's a kind of people's loophole in this new campaign finance lawthey don't include the value of volunteer services.

title: Monsanto Plans Price Rises
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that its Monsanto industrial Chemicals Company planned to raise prices of several specialty chemical products, effective Oct. 1. It said that the prices of Santicizer plasticizer would be increased by 12 cents a pound to 75 cents and paratolueneesulfonyl chloride would be raised by 10 cents a pound to 65 cents. These chemicals are used in fluorescent pigments, laminated adhesives, lacquers and dyestuffs.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
OTB Is Warned On Garden Bid
description: Governor Carey warned yesterday that any contract for the purchase of Madison Square Garden had damn well better be in the financial interest of New York City.

title: OIL COORDINATION IS URGED BY C.E.D.
description: Closer international coordination among oil producers, consumers and the developing nations was urged yesterday by the Committee for Economic Development.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Hot, scratchy, binding, drab. Robert Diamond, a director of television shows and father of an 8yearold boy, remembers those suits of his childhood.

title: Mortgage Rate Rise Threatening Housing
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18Homemortgage rates are moving up again, threatening to cause more problems for the nation's housing industry just as it is inching out of its worst recession in more than a decade. Most of the country's largest savings and loan associations and many commercial banks have raised their basic homemortgage rates by onequarter to onehalf of a percentage point during the last two weeks or so.

title: Rough Nearby Waters Affect Anglers' Catches
description: AREA A  Until strong winds roughened the waters off the New Jersey coast in the last two days, fishermen were reporting good catches of blues, striped bass, weakfish and fluke. Blues averaging 10 to 14 pounds with an occasional catch of up to 20 pounds) were hauled in off the Ridge by chumming or trolling. Blues were also reported abundant on a 15mile stretch of shore line from Ortley Beach to Island Beach. Fresh mullet was the most popular bait. Weakfish in the Ortley Beach area were also being taken on plugs and mullet. At Barnegat, fluke in the 12to15pound range were taking sand eels and squid. The best striped bass fishing apparently is around Seaside Park, where fishermen using plugs reported catches of up to 25 pounds.

title: 2 IN LUNDY FAMILY SLAIN IN BURGLARY
description: A double murder in an apparent burglary in welltodo Forest Hills Gardens took the lives yesterday of the sister and brotherinlaw of the owner of Lundy's, a longestablished seafood restaurant in Sheepshead Bay.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: First and third prizes in the piano division of the 24th International Music Competition in Munich have been won by Americans. Diane Walsh of Washington, who lives here, was awarded the only first prize in the entire competition which also had violin, organ, bassoon and windquintet categories. Miss Walsh, a graduate of the Juilliard School where she studied with Irwin I reundlich, made her debut hers last year sponsored by Young Concert Artists.

title: JUDGE IN WARNING TO L. I. TEACHERS
description: RIVERHEAD, LI., Sept. 18 A state Supreme Court justice told the striking teachers of the Half Hollow Hills school district today to return to their classrooms tomorrow morning as evidence of good faith.

title: Inquiry Into Killing Of Robert Kennedy Ends First Phase
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18The first phase in the courtordered reexamination of the Robert F. Kennedy assassination case was completed today after the chief ballistics expert in the case ended his testimony.

title: Sanitation Head Restores Jobs to 2 He Suspended
description: Commissioner Robert T. Groh yesterday reinstated two Sanitation Department officers he had suspended Wednesday after Mayor Beame, in a surprise visit to their garage, had discovered they had permitted their men to quit work early.

title: Israeli With drawal Moves In Sinai Already Started
description: SUDR, Sept 18Israeli soldiers this week cleared antitank minefields from this area, which is to be the first to be evacuated under the new interim agreement with Egypt. And barbedwire entanglements that had surrounded the minefields were gathered today and trucked to a new front.

title: Fireproof Plaster in Buildings Called Continuing Cancer Peril
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.., Sept. 18 A plaster compound used in countless buildings put up from the nineteenthirties to 1973 presents a continuing cancer hazard to occupants, an international scientific conference was told today.

title: Luis Cardinal Concha Cordoba, Former Colombia Primate, Dies
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 18. (Reuters)Luis Cardinal Concha Cordoba, former primate of the Roman Catholic Church in Colombia, died here today of heart failure following complications of a stomach ailment. He was 84 years old and had been retired for the last nine years. His death leaves the Sacred College of Cardinals with 123 members.

title: The Theater: O'Neill's Only Comedy
U.S. and Soviet Sign Pact To Ship Grain at $16 a Ton
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 18  The United States and the Soviet Union last night signed a 15month agreement increasing the rate at which grain is to be transported on American ships to $16 per metric ton from $9.50.

title: A Girlish Fugitive In a TShirt, Smiling
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Sept. 18She didn't look like the focus of a nationwide search. She didn't look like an heiress. She looked, instead, like someone who might be standing unnoticed in an allnight cafeteria.

title: FIGHTING IN BEIRUT EXPANDING AGAIN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, Sept. 19Rival gangs battled with automatic weapons, mortars and rockets in several parts of Beirut last night as the Government remained divided over whether to use troops to restore order.

title: Flooded Indian City Starts Back
description: PATNA, India, Sept. 14Gautama Buddha, the founder of Buddhism, cast a triple curse on this ancient city 2,000 years ago. On some provocation that is lost in obscurity, the holy man decreed that Pataliputra, the original name of Patna, which is now the capital of Bihar State, would go through the ordeals of fire, feud and flood year after year.

title: FIGHTING IN BEIRUT EXPANDING AGAIN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, Sept. 19Rival gangs battled with automatic weapons, mortars and rockets in several parts of Beirut last night as the Government remained divided over whether to use troops to restore order.

title: Federal Reserve Officials Tell Women They Will Revise Rules on Credit Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Officials of the Federal Reserve Board have promised a group of women members of Congress to make some changes in the proposed regulations outlawing discrimination against women in the granting of credit.

title: New Yeast in the Old Internationalism
description: WASHINGTONFrom 1964 to 1974 we as a people underwent a gradual but truly profound change in our sense of national priorities. Domestic concerns pressed steadily to the forefront. Internationalist sentiment eased. Support for isolationist positions grew.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was erroneously reported in The New York Times on Wednesday that a bill now pending in the British Parliament would make it illegal for an educational trust to discriminate on the basis of sex. Actually, the bill would permit, but not require, trusts such as the Rhodes scholarships to disregard allmale or related conditions now in their charters.

title: UNION FUND USE IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: A special state grand jury is investigating allegations that officials of the Housing Patrolmen's Benevolent Association may have embezzled thousands of dollars in union funds.

title: Landlord Didn't Know Who His Tenants Were
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18  When Jerry Prill's wife, Anna, called him this morning and told him there were some people there who wanted to show him some pictures, he was annoyed.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was erroneously reported in The New York Times on Wednesday that a bill now pending in the British Parliament would make it illegal for an educational trust to discriminate on the basis of sex. Actually, the bill would permit, but not require, trusts such as the Rhodes scholarships to disregard allmale or related conditions now in their charters.

title: Officials Wary as Ford Plans a Return to Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18President Ford will visit California tomorrow in his first return to the state since a pistol was pointed at him two weeks ago in Sacramento.

title: For 2,000 Button Collectors,
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 18 M. W. (Freddie) Speights was standing next to some burning garbage five years ago. He was 50 years old and depressed. His publishing business had just gone broke. Then, there in the ashes, he found the makings of a new lifebuttons.

title: A Drastic Revision Is Backed For World's Airline Treaties
description: A detailed proposal for a drastic revision of the 30yearold structure of international air treaties was put forward yesterday by a former State Department official.

title: 2 Radicals From WelltoDo Families
description: In many ways, the Harrises, Emily and William, are the stereotype young revolutionaries of America's turbuleht late nineteensixties and early seventies. They came from white, uppermiddleclass families, families with money and a more or less conservative outlook.

title: PANAMA TO DISCLOSE CANAL DISCUSSIONS
description: PANAMA CITY, Sept. 18 (Reuters)Brig Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, Panama's Chief of Government, has called for is full public account of the talks on a new canal treaty despite repeated insistence on secrecy from the American side.

title: People in Sports
description: Before David Thompson, a threetime allAmerica at North Carolina State stopped off at Gallagher's Steak House yesterday to pick up his Tanqueray Award for excellence in amateur sports, he stopped off at Intermediate School 201 in Harlem to give a clinic with a North Carolina State and Denver teammate, Monte Towe. Towe demonstrated passing techniques and Thompson put on a show that included dunk shots. Thompson got a note from a member of the youthful audience, Ronnie Wright, that said: I would enjoy learning your basketball:

title: Odds Favor Jets But Not the Giants
description: There is a feast awaiting pro football fans this weekend with four games scheduled for television. The New York teams will be playing at the same time Sunday Jets at Buffalo (Channel 4) and Giants in Philadelphia (Channel 2) at 1 P.M. The second game will be the RamsCowboys in Dallas, Channel 2, 4 P.M.

title: 5 IN SPAIN DOOMED IN A POLICE SLAYING
description: MADRID, Sept. 18 (AP)Three men and two women who said they were pregnant were sentenced to death today or the shotgun slaying of a policeman last Aug. 16.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $1.11 billion, up 7 per cent from the yearearlier $1.04billion. Total retail store sales were about $11.74billion, an increase of 7 per cent from last year's $10.94billion.

title: Honoring Dr. Pauling
description: The international acclaim accorded Dr. Linus Pauling but embarrassingly denied him by his own country during the McCarthy era and the Nixon Presidencyhas at last been made unanimous. President Ford's award of the National Medal of Science to him at the White House yesterday is more than welcome recognition of his pioneering achievements in molecular chemistry. It is also a signal to the American scientific community that independent research and independent political views can coexist in a society dedicated to free inquiry.

title: DOROTHY LATTA
description: Dorothy Park Latta Horner, who headed the upper school and Latin department of the Lenox School for Girls until her retirement in 1968, died Wednesday at High Ridge House in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She was 76 years old and lived here.

title: Dietzel Is Named To Post at Indiana
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Sept. 18 (AP)Paul Dietzel was named athletic director at Indiana University today, ending a yearlong search for a successor to retired J.W. (Bill) Orwig. The university board of trustees, in a telephone vote, unanimously approved the appointment John W. Ryan, the Indiana president, said.

title: Striking Teachers Reach An Accord in Hawthorne
description: HAWTHORNE, Sept. 18 Striking teachers in the Hawthorne school district reached a tentative contract settlement late today and agreed to return to their classrooms tomorrow morning pending a ratification vote.

title: FALSE TROOP DATA IN VIETNAM CITED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18A former Vietnam specialist for the Central Intelligence Agency today quoted to a House committee from what he said were previously undisclosed military and diplomatic cablegrams supporting his previous assertions of a deliberate effort to undervalue the strength of Communist forces in South Vietnam.

title: SENATE SUPPORTS FORD ON 5% LIMIT ON FEDERAL RAISE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The Senate voted today to limit pay increases for members of Congress and 3.5 million other Federal employes to the 5 per cent proposed by President Ford.

title: LANNON F. MEAD
description: Lannon F. Mead, since 1966 chairman of the hoard of the Regina Corporation, manufacturers of vacuum cleaners arid floorpolishing machines, a division of the General Signal Corporation, died yesterday in Rahway. N..I,, where he lived. He was 74 years old.

title: Levitt Names a Staff Aide Special Controller for City
description: After a lengthy search for an outside expert to serve as the new special deputy state controller for the city, Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday turned to his own staff and named Sidney Schwartz, currently the state's chief auditor in the city.

title: Oil Imports Reduced
description: PARIS, Sept. 18The major industrialized Western countries have reduced their imports of oil by 6 per cent from 1973, but the reason reportedly has more to do with the world slump in economic activity than any effort at conservation.

title: Rock Island Seeks Link With Mopac
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (UPI)The bankrupt Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad has decided to seek a merger with the Missouri Pacific, William Gibbons, the Rock Island's courtappointed trustee, said today.

title: Shift in Third World's Views Shown in U.N. Session
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18The outcome of the special session dealing with the global economic and social north  south lopsidedness is widely viewed at United Nations headquarters as a reflection of the growing awareness in the third world that it needs the advanced nationsespecially the United Statesand will need them for quite some time.

title: GROMYKO CONFERS AT THE WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union met today with President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger to discuss a new treaty limiting nuclear arms and later said that some differences remained.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: Las Vegas, Nev.Leroy Miley, 135 pounds, Las Vegan, outpointed Gene Prado, 133, Los Angeles, 10 rounds.

title: Lawrenceville Concert To Aid Music Archive
description: LAWRENCEVILLE  Teresa Brewer, the singer, and the World's Greatest Jazz Band, led by Bob Haggart and Yank Lawson, will join forces here tonight in support of a repository and research archive for American popular music that has been started at the Lawrenceville School. Miss Brewer and the jazz hand will give a concert at the Kirby Arts Center as a benefit for the Robert. Thiele Center for American Popular Music, which is currently housed in the school's John Dixon Library.

title: Wallace May Get Royalties on Sales During Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The Federal Election Commission ruled today that Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama could legally keep as personal income up to $150,000 in royalty payments from the sale by his campaign staff of medallions, watches and other material carrying his likeness.

title: NIXON TAX LAWYER ON TRIAL ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18The Government opened its case today in Federal District Court against Frank DeMarco Jr., the lawyer accused of preparing false documents to give President Nixon a substantial tax deduction on a donation of his VicePresidential papers to the National Archives.

title: Problems Mark Schools As the City Pupils Return
description: The city's 1.1 million pupils returned to school yesterday and, in many instances, found oversized classes, confused conditions and general discontent over the outcome of the weeklong teachers' strike.

title: 7 Food Businesses Called City Health Code Violators
description: The Health Department has cited seven more food establishments for failing to correct violations found at initial inspections. Those named are:

title: Triple Pays $11,338
description: A $2 triple bet on the first three finishers in the ninth race at Belmont Park yesterday was worth $11,338. Turn of Fate won and paid a winning mutuel of $126.80. Royal Beat was next, at the place price of $11.80, and Kitchie's Girl returned $9.20 for show.

title: U.S. Aide Killed in Munich
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 18 (AP)Robert Wood, a United States Consular official who worked closely with West German lawenforcement agencies, fell to his death yesterday from the 14th floor of a Munich apartment house, American officials said. They said Mr. Wood, 41 years old, of Baltimore, was apparently alone in the apartment, rented by an Italian friend who was not in Munich at the time.

title: Article 1  No Title
PILOT FOR SAIGON CALLED RED AGENT
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 18The South Vietnamese Air Force pilot who unexpectedly bombed the presidential palace in Saigon last April was the son of a Vietcong official and had been a secret Communist agent for years, according to a Communist newspaper that has become available here.

title: BUSINESS LOANS SHOW DROP HERE
description: Business loans at major New York banks declined, in midSeptember for the first time in at least 15 years, indicating that the national economic recovery heralded by numerous economists remains sluggish at best.

title: P.U.C. Grants Jersey Bell $59.9Million Rate Rise
description: NEWARK, Sept. 18 (AP)The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners today granted New Jersey Bell a rate increase to provide more than $59.9million a year.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The State Charter Revision Commission for New York City has proposed some dramatic and controversial governmental reforms that would significantly alter the balance of power on questions of city policy among the Mayor, Board of Estimate. City Council, Controller and Council President.

title: LEVITT APPOINTS AIDE TO CITY POST
description: After a lengthy search for an outside expert to serve as the new special deputy state controller for the city, Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday turned to his own staff and named Sidney Schwart, currently the state's chief auditor in the city.

title: FOOTBALL TEAMS END THEIR STRIKE
description: The strike in the National Football League ended yesterday and the season will open on schedule this Sunday. A temporary agreement was reached between the N.F.L. Players Association and management early yesterday and the five striking teams agreed to go back to work, which meant practicing for Sunday's games.

title: Troubled Rank Dismisses Chief Executive
description: LONDON, Sept. 18  The Rank Organization, the British entertainment conglomerate whose movies begin with a man striking a gong, ended a week of turmoil in the executive suite today by dismissing its chief executive officer.

title: Dollar Soars in Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 18The dollar shot up against the Japanese yen under heavy buying on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today, reaching 300 yen for the first time in eight months.

title: Market Place
description: If the holders of debt securities of the seven bankrupt Northeastern railroads soon to be merged into Conrail, a Governmentsupported railway, are confused and depressed, it is understandable.

title: SENATE SUPPORTS FORD ON 5% LIMIT ON FEDERAL RAISE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The Senate voted today to limit pay increases for members of Congress and 3.5 million other Federal employes to the 5 per cent proposed by President Ford.

title: NONNEW YORKERS SEEK TO HELP CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Two academic celebrities, an academicpolitician and a businessmancelebrity are forming a national organization called NonNew Yorkers to Save New York.

title: 9 Broadway Theaters Are Shut As Musicians Begin a Walkout
description: Unionized musicians struck Broadway in a contract dispute last night that shut down all of the nine musical productions of a young fall season billed as one of the biggest in years.

title: People and Business
description: The appointment of David E. C. Steel, deputy chairman of the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., as chairman of the company was announced yesterday in London.

title: TV Review
description: With the new season's general level of mediocrity, television executives have enough to worry about, but now they are nervously preparing to contend with Space: 1999, a sciencefiction series produced in Britain. Space: 1999 is not a network show. It is being syndicated station by station, and it has already been sold to 155 stations, the vast majority of them network affiliates.

title: And After 40 Days Manhattan Was Covered, And, Lo!, America Was Again Pure
description: Despite a recent poll that showed that the majority of Americans favored Federal help for New York's financial problems, many people west of the Hudson do not like the city. Other large cities are also unpopular, of course, but New Yorkparticularly Manhattanis the bestknown and thus the stereotypical American city, so that television comics will joke only about muggings in Central Park even though the crime rate is much higher in Detroit or Philadelphia.

title: PARIS DEAL NEARER WITH WESTINGHOUSE
description: PARIS, Sept. 18The French Government and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation are moving toward an agreement in which Westinghouse would reduce its 45 per cent interest in the Framatome Corporation, a key company in French nuclear technology, and the French atomic energy agency would acquire an important stake.Robert Kirby, and France's Minister for Industry, Michel d'Ornano, had conversations here this week that showed a convergence of views on objectives and produced a schedule to pursue them, the ministry said yesterday in a statement.

title: Two Shots In The Dark
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The Democratic party's victory on economic issues in the New Hampshire Senatorial election, and the Congressional Budget Office's predictions of continued high inflation and unemployment in the last quarter of 1976, have sent a shudder through the Republican party and depressed its hopes of winning next year's Presidential election.

title: Business Briefs
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 18 (Reuters)Compensation for the assets of foreign oil companies nationalized by Venezuela last month will be paid in 10year Government bonds bearing 6.5 per cent interest, Finance Minister Hector Hurtado said here today. There will be no cash payments, he said.

title: Man Ruled Insane In Slaying of Priest Free After 2 Years
description: NEWARK. Sept. 18, (AP)A 27  year  old Brick Township man held two years in Marlboro State Psychiatric Hospital as insane since his acquittal in the fatal shooting of a Roman Catholic priest was looking for a job today and trying to readjust to the outside world.

title: AINSWORTH L. SMITH, A GASTRIC SURGEON
description: Dr. Ainsworth L. Smith, leading Brooklyn gastric surgeon who retired in 1970, died Wednesday at his home in Miller Place, L.I. He was 77 years old.

title: MISS SOMOGI LEADS A DONIZETTI OPERA
description: Judith Somogi is pursuing her conducting career with easy authority at the New York City Opera.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold!, rices Thursday. London: Morning fixing $147.90, us. changed; afternoon fixing $139.50, down $3.40.

title: Warnings For Mr. Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18There may be at least two political warnings for President Ford in the unexpectedly large victory of Democrat John Durkin in the special New Hampshire Senate election. Both have more to do with Mr. Ford's own prospects than with the length of his political coattails.

title: 9 Broadway Theaters Are Shut As Musicians Begin a Walkout
description: Unionized musicians struck Broadway in a contract dispute last night that shut down all of the nine musical productions of a young fall season billed as one of the biggest in years.

title: Giardino Rejects Nyquist Proposal for City U. Tuition
description: Alfred A. Giardino, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, rejected yesterday the suggestion of State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist that the City University immediately impose tuition, but said the proposal would be included, along with other fundamental issues, in a forthcoming longterm review of university operations.

title: Senate's Hearings on Coors Raising Questions About Public Broadcasting
description: Three days of confirmation hearings last week on the controversial nomination of Joseph Coors to the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting ended unresolved. But the Senate Commerce Committee appeared to indicate that approval of Mr. Coors, executive vice president of the Adolph Coors Brewing Company and head of a syndicated television news service known as TVN, might be possible if he were willing to resign as chairman of the news organization. There was no request that he give up his 80 per cent interest in the concern, however.

title: Defendant Born in Detention Camp
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 (UPI)  Wendy Masako Yoshimura, arrested today with Patricia Hearst, is a JapaneseAmerican artist who was born in a relocation camp. She disappeared in 1972 after being indicted in a plot to bomb a Navy Reserve Officers Training Corps building at the University of California.

title: Miss Hearst's ExFiance Unsure She'll See Him
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 18 (AP)Steven Weed, 28 years old, who was engaged to marry Patricia Hearst, said today he was relieved at news of her safe capture. Obviously, I want to see her. he added.

title: Business Records
description: Thursday, Sept. 18, 1975

title: The Missing Element
description: Better late than never would seem the proper comment for Mayor Beame's sudden, but welcome, war on the refuse that befouls so many of the city's streets. The unannounced mayoral descent upon a Sanitation Department garage is the latest in a series of swift moves that have confirmed what New Yorkers learned to their sorrow long ago: A major factor in the city's filthiness is the amazing and continued ability of large numbers of Sanitation Department employes to dodge work in every imaginable way.

title: NATO Hesitance Reduces U.S. Negotiating Ability at Talks on Cuts in Forces
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18United States diplomats will return to the Vienna conference on reduction of military forces in central Europe later this month with some new hope for progress, but also with somewhat less negotiating flexibility than they expected.

title: STATE IS CRITICAL OF GAS UTILITIES
description: SPRING LAKE, Sept. 18New Jersey's chief energy spokesman said today that the state's naturalgas industry was not doing enough to encourage fuel conservation among customers.

title: New Books
description: Angels: God's Secret Agents, by Billy Graham (Doubleday, $4.95). Religious tract.

title: EDITH H. PROSKAUER, ACTIVE IN CHARITIES
description: Edith Harris Proskauer, who had been active in charitable causes here, died yesterday at her home in Delmonico's Hotel, Park Avenue at 59th Street. She was 85 years old.

title: 6 Students Are Suspended In College Hazing Death
description: CHEYNEY, Pa., Sept. 18 (AP)  Six Cheyney State College students, all from nearby Philadelphia, were suspended today in connection with the hazing death of a Coatesville freshman.

title: Ryder Cup Golf Starts Today
description: LIGONIER, Pa., Sept. 18It's true the British once won at Fort Ligonier, named after one of their field marshals. But that was in 1758, and it was French and Indian forces they beat, not the Americans. And they had the help of a colonel named G. Washington.

title: . . . and Net Security
description: A totally different set of constraints operates on the Administration's proposal to sell fourteen batteries of Hawk antiaircraft missiles to Jordan. King Hussein has an immense personal stake, both inside his country and among his Arab brethren, In obtaining a modern air defense system; the United States, for its part, has an interest in strengthening his position against the more radical Arab forces around him.

title: JORDAN PLEASED OVER ACQUISITION
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 18It's a home run all the way around. Mayor Paul T. Jordan said, making no pretense of concealing his joy over the decision by Weeden & Co., the big New York brokerage house, to move part of its New York operations here next spring.

title: Transportation Bond Issue Clears Jersey Legislature
description: TRENTON, Sept. 18Governor Byrne's $600million transportation bond issue cleared the New Jersey Legislature today amid warnings that it was already fatally crippled by opposition of environmentalists and by New York City's fiscal crisis, and that there was not enough time to sell it to the voters in November.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1975

title: Senators Are Told of Test Of a Gas Attack in Subway
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Army scientists secretly spread simulated biological poison on two subway lines in Manhattan in the mid nineteensixties to test the vulnerability of the New York subway system to a biological warfare attack, a Department of Defense engineer testified today.

title: COURT TO WEIGH NONMEDICAL HELP
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn has approved the convening of a threejudge constitutional court to determine whether the rights of a believer in Christian Science were violated when she was refused Medicaid reimbursement for treatments administered by Christian Scientist practitioners and nurses.

title: Quiet Section Troubled By Lundy Double Slaying
