description: Elaing Lundy did not keep her appointment for a permanent wave at the John Christie Salon de Coiffure yesterday, and the news about her is reaching the neighborhood quickly.

title: SURGEON IS CLEARED OF DRUG CHARGES
description: A jury in State Supreme Court here yesterday acquitted Dr. Daniel Manfredi, a surgeon, of charges of illegally prescribing amphetamines to an undercover agent posing as a patient.

title: Soviet Orbits 8 Satellites
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 18 (UPI)The Soviet Union put eight satellites into earth orbit yesterday using a single rocket, the press agency Tass reported. They were numbered 761 through 768 in the cosmos series.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Department of Health reported confirmation of six new cases of encephalitis, raising to 11 the number of confirmed cases this year in the state. Dr. Joanne E Finley, the State Health Commissioner, said one of the new cases involved a 78yearold Philadelphia woman who died in a New Jersey hospital Sept. 12.

title: Saudis Curb Arms Agents
description: TAIF. Saudi Arabia, Sept. 18 (Reuters)  A Government decree today banned any concern that enters into an arms deal with the state from paying commissions to any agent. The move follows a disclosure in Washington that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation had paid la Saudi entrepreneur $106million over five years.

title: PORTUGUESE REDS YIELD ON CABINET
description: LISBON, Sept. 18Portugal's Communists abandoned their fight today for greater representation in the prospective militarycivilian Cabinet, apparently opening the way to its completion shortly.

title: Books of The Times
description: Thomas Cook began as a temperance crusader and an evangelist preacher. In his second career as the father of modern tourism, he offered his flocks the intoxication of travel and the combined heaven and hell of strange lands. He must have been one of the most opportune men in the history of Britain, for no one knows what Victorian romanticism might have degenerated into if he had not come along.

title: Canadian Is Winner in ShotPut
description: ROME, Sept. 18 CAP)Bishop Dolegiewicz of Canada won the shotput with a distance of 63 feet 9 inches today in the opening of the World University Games for track and field.

title: ARAB INVESTMENT SHOWING A SHIFT
description: LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP)Arab oil nations are beginning to shift their investments from Britain to the United States and Western Europe, the Bank of England reported today.

title: On Broadway and at Met, Issue Is Money
description: In both the theater and the Metropolitan Opera labor disputes the basic issue is economic. The musicians want more money than their employers say they can afford to give them.

title: SING SING GUARD SLAIN IN HOLDUP
description: A Sing Sing prison guard was shot to death last night in a Harlem bar during a holdup by three gunmen, the police reported.

title: About New York
description: The weather is changing, marking a new season in New York in a time of change that heralds a beginning so much more dramatically than do the dreary days that tailgate Jan. 1.

title: PATRICIA HEARST IS SEIZED BY F.B.I.; LONG HUNT ENDS IN SAN FRANCISCO; HARRISES AND 3D COMPANION TAKEN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18Patricia Hearst, the wealthy kidnapping victim who proclaimed herself a revolutionary and was accused of being a bank robber, was captured here this afternoon by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: In Memoriam
description: GOTTFRIEDOscar, Darling, how can I ever forget your birthday or you.

title: CITY AND WEEDEN CONFER ON MOVING
description: The City's Economic Development Administrator, Alfred Eisenpreis, conferred yesterday with Weeden & Co., the brokerage house, in an effort to head off Weeden's plans to move a major part of its operations to Jersey City, N.J., to avoid the city's stock and bond transfer taxes. Weeden disclosed its longthreatened move a day earlier.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.1 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and slightly to 206.1 from 206 last week.

title: New Highs for Dollar
description: The dollar rose yesterday to new highs for the year on most European markets. Page 58.

title: U. S. Steel Asking Increase in Duties On E.EC. Imports
description: The United States Steel Corporation filed yesterday countervailing duty complaints with the Treasury Department seeking relief from alleged unfair trade practices by seven European Economic Community nations.

title: GAS PLANT SUBSIDY ASSAILED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18A crucial part of the Ford Administration's energy program to subsidize the production of highcost synthetic pipeline ga refined from coal came under broad attack today in a House committee.

title: 2 IN LUNDY FAMILY SLAIN IN BURGLARY
description: A double murder in an apparent burglary in welltodo Forest Hills Gardens took the lives yesterday of the sister and brotherinlaw of the owner of Lundy's, a longestablished seafood restaurant in Sheepshead Bay.

title: The Pop Life
description: Linda Ronstadt's last album, Heart Like a Wheel, was the record that made her a superstar. But No. 1 albums that result in two No. 1 singles are hard to follow. Miss Ronstadt has always made lovely records, but one had every right to wonder if her next record could be as extraordinarily satisfying and strikingly commercial as the last one.

title: Young Architects Display Recent Visionary Designs
description: One of the things that the new exhibition Work by Young Architects at the Institute for Architecture and Urban Studies at 8 West 40th Street makes clear is that young architects are not building many buildings these days. Economic conditions have squeezed the less experienced  not to mention many of the more experiencedout of the business of getting things built, and many have taken refuge in doing visionary, fantasy designs instead.

title: PUERTO RICO ASKS FOR DISASTER AID
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 18Puerto Rico began digging out today from the mud and rubble left by Tropical Storm Eloise, which caused 28 fatalities and at least $60million in damage to the island.

title: GSW in Offer for Westinghouse Unit
description: GSW, Ltd., announced yesterday that it had made a formal offer to acquire the appliance assets of Westinghouse Canada, Ltd., which is 75.2 per cent owned by the Westinghouse Corporation of the United States. GSW noted that its offer now matched the price that would have been paid by White Consolidated Industries of Cleveland had not White's offer been blocked by Canada's Foreiga Investment Review Board.

title: Ozone Dispute Held Costly to Industry; Delay in Curb Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI)The controversy over whether some spray can gases are imperiling the vital ozone layer over the earth has significantly damaged the aerosol industry even though the theory is unproved, an official of a major can maker said today.

title: SIMON SAYS NATIONS NEED AID ON OIL COST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (Reuters)  Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today the major industrial nations still face serious financial problems because of higher oil prices. He said they need an international financing fund that has been proposed.

title: INQUIRY IS BEGUN ON SUFFOLK PLOT
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 18 Joseph P. Hoey, the special state prosecutor for Suffolk County, is investigating reports that there was a plot to blackmail Henry F. O'Brien, the Suffolk District Attorney, and that it was allegedly conceived by Roger Barry Petersen, who has accused Mr. O'Brien of sodomy.

title: UTILITY CHAIRMAN TERMED OVERPAID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The Federal Power Commission has said that it believes Charles H. Tenney 2d, chairman of the Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., in New York State, is overpaid.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA, State Theater, Lincoln Center, Strauss's Salome. 8

title: 19Month Search for Miss Hearst Began With Abduction by S.L.A.
description: On a foggy night 19 months ago, Patricia Campbell Hearst was dragged screaming from her Berkeley, Calif., apartment by a white woman and two black men who covered their escape with rifle fire.

title: NUCLEAR FINE FACED BY CHICAGO UTILITY
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 18A $25.000 fine was levied today against the Commonwealth Edison Company, the Chicagobased electric utility, by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for having failed to comply with commission regulations at the utility's Quad City nuclear power station near Cordova, 150 miles from here.

title: Kiefer Keeps Shot Lead In Met. Open on 72140
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 18Jack Kiefer of Emerson Country Club, the New Jersey open champion who shot a 68 in the first round of the Metropolitan Golf Association's open champion, carded a 38, 3472 today and maintained, his onestroke lead at par140 after 36 holes.

title: Red Smith
description: I am afraid, Watson, that I shall have to go, said Holmes, as we sat down together to our breakfast one morning.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: When it offers dinner at $18.50, which means about $23 after tax and minimum tip for the waiter or $25 you remember the Captain but forget the wine, a restaurant invites comparisons with the best in the city. Chez Pascal, which has been in operation at 151 East 82d Street for about four months now, meets the challenge successfully enough to make a reviewer ponder a fourth star. Star number four, however, has to depend on consistent performance over an extended period, so let's wait a while, in spite of the fact that we have enjoyed some fourstar dining at this new place.

title: ANDREW HUTTON
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18  Andrew Hutton, a British journalist who recorded the events each day of four recent United Nations confer ences in a breezy, unofficial news digest, died yesterday in London, according to word received here. He was 30 years old.

title: FOOTBALL TEAMS END HEIR STRIKE
description: The strike in the National Football League ended yesterday and the season will open on schedule this Sunday. A temporary agreement was reached between the N.F.L. Players Association and management early yesterday and the five striking teams agreed to go back to work, which meant practicing for Sunday's games.

title: Giants Find Unity In Labor Trouble
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 18Unlike last year's football players' strike, no picket signs adorned the Giants' practice site today. There weren't even any pickets. That's because there weren't any strikers. There weren't any strikers because there wasn't any strike.

title: Advertising
description: While almost every packaged  goods company has been rushing to market with new products hoping to build its share of the market, the William Wrigley Jr. Company has stood fast with its Spearmint, Doublemint and Juicy Fruit chewing gums.

title: The Layered Look
description: The RollsRoyce or maybe the Seville customer was the object of some presentations on Seventh Avenue this week as resort collections kept rolling along. Over on Fifth Avenue, the woman who has only a Buick or an MG in her garage was being lured by European fashion collections and, occasionally, the designer himself with an intriguing accent appeared, to lend a special gloss to his wares.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The Assocation of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.5 billion tonmiles, 7.1 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same week totaled 482,105 cars, 7.6 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 10 per cent below last year.

title: DROP CONTINUES IN GOLD FUTURES
description: The sharp drop in gold futures continued yesterday, with the October contract on the Commodity Exchange dropping to a new low of $135 an ounce before closing at $136 1/10, off $6.40. In two days it has dropped almost $10 an ounce.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND 0TC CLIMB
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter marekt rose yesterday as traders took advantage of lower prices that resulted from several days of declines.

title: NursingHome Official Accused Of Allowing Filth and Hazards
description: The operator of the Westchester Nursing Home was indicted yesterday on charges of permitting filthy and hazardous conditions in the home, at 245 East Prospect Avenue, Mount Vernon.

title: Mets Win on Kingman Clout
description: You're never out of it until you're out of it, Yogi Berra used to say. The Mets may still believe it. Down 40 to the Chicago Cubs last night at Shea Stadium, the Mets came back to win, 75, when Dave Kingman homered with two out in the last of the ninth.

title: KALLINGER GUILTY ON ALL CHARGES
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 18 After deliberating less than one hour, a jury of six men and six women today convicted Joseph Kallinger of burglary and the binding and robbery of four women at a suburban home here last Dec. 3.

title: Ashe Beats Warwick in Coast Tennis
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18Arthur Ashe, the Wimbledon champion, defeated Kim Warwick, one of the rising Australians, 62, 64, today as the four topseeded players reached the quarterfinal round of the Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament.

title: Rally in Bonds Continues As Pace of Trading Gains
description: The bond market's rally, sparked by the Treasury's sale of $3billion in twoyear notes on Tuesday, continued to move ahead yesterday. Prices in both the Government and corporate sectors advanced in steppedup trading. Dealers said that since most bond specialists had expected the notes to carry rates of about 8.5 per cent, the actual average yield of 8.44 per cent has acted as a spur to prices.

title: Man Is Not Guilty in Children's Slaying
description: FREEHOLD, Sept 18, (UPI)Robert Mottershead, a 45yearold Little Silver stockbroker, was judged innocent by reason of insanity in the shooting death of his two children, who were slain in their beds on Aug. 16, 1974.

title: Jordan Refuses Missiles On the Terms Set by U.S.
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 18  Jordan rejected today conditions set by President Ford for the sale of Hawk antiaircraft missiles as insulting to national dignity and indicated she might buy Soviet surfacetoair missiles instead.

title: Dollar Rises to 1975 Highs on European Markets
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 18 (UPI)The dollar made fresh gains on most European money markets today, again reaching new highs for the year, while the price of gold sank to its lowest level in more than a year. The pound fell to another low against the dollar, but held modest gains against Continental currencies.

title: Facts in Musicians' Strike
description: Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. I. Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.

title: Survivors of Arnhem Recall Heroism in the Face of Defeat
description: Gen. James M. Gavin remembers parachuting into a turnip patch with a member of the Dutch Resistance at his side. Lieut. Comdr. Arnoldus Wolters remembers packing into the invasion glider for his return to the Netherlands a teddy bear for an infant daughter he had never seen. Mrs. Cornelius Ryan remembers the sight of her authorhusband limping across the bridge at Arnhem that he had written about.

title: Doubt Is Voiced on Impact Of U.S. Plan on Poor Lands
description: While the proposals on economic development made by the United States at the recent special session of the United Nations General Assembly have had a dramatic political impact, their concrete economic impact will he slight, according to a number of economists who deal with international issues.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 18 (AP)Pytor Korol of the Soviet Union and Zbignev Kaczarek of Poland each lifted a total of 688 pounds in the lightweight division of the world weightlifting championships today, but Korol was declared the winner because he weighed less.

title: Project to Sage Parrot Is Begun
description: A program to renovate and protect the nesting sites of one of the nation's most endangered birds, the Puerto Rican parrot, has been announced by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: Murakami Leads Golf
description: SHIZUOKA, Japan, Sept. 18 (AP)Takashi Murakami, Japan's World Cup player, carded a fiveunderpar 67 today and took the firstround lead in the $83,000 Shizuoka open golf tournament. The 31yearold Japanese pro had five birdies and no bogeys on the 7.082yard, par72 course, putting him one stroke ahead of six players.

title: Jack Howard to Retire As Scripps President
description: Jack R. Howard, president of the E. W. Scripps Company and general editorial manager of the ScrippsHoward Newspapers, announced yesterday that he would retire on Dec. 31, in accordance with company policy. He became 65 on Aug. 31.

title: Suddenly the Questions Are as FarReaching as Ford's Travels
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Critics used to complain about Presidents secluding themselves in the White House or at personal vacation enclaves. Not so with President Ford.

title: WILLIAM CONNAUGHTON
description: William G. Connaughton, who had been an investment er here for many years before retiring in 1959, died Sept. 9 in New Smyrna Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 87 years old.

title: Charge That Bronfman Planned Abduction Is Called Ridiculous
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 18An assertion by the lawyer for one of the accused kidnappers of Samuel Bronfman 2d that the heir to the Seagram whisky fortune masterminded his own abduction was characterized today by District Attorney Carl A. Vergari as absurd and ridiculous.

title: Profits and G.N.P. Revised Upward
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Both corporate profits and the Cross National Product for the second quarter were revised upward today by the Commerce Department.

title: FirstClass Stamp Of 13 Cents Sought By Postal Service
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) The Postal Service proposed today an increase in the cost of a firstclass stamp to 13 cents from 10 cents, effective shortly after Christmas.

title: Little Brown Jug Postponed by Rain
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 15 (AP)The Little Brown Jug, the middle jewel of pacing's triple crown, was postponed because of rain today and faced an uncertain future tomorrow.

title: Excerpts From the Letter Giardino Wrote to Nyquist
description: My Dear Joe: Thank you for your letter received on Sept. 8, expressing your concern regarding further budgetary reductions that may adversely affect the effective functioning of City University.

title: FORD PRICES PINTO AS LOWEST IN U.S.
description: DETROIT. Sept. 18The Ford Motor Company announced today that a special 1976 model of its subcompact Pinto would be priced at $2,895, making it the lowestpriced car buil in the United States.

title: Phils Cut Pirates' Gap to 6
description: Home runs by Mike Schmidt and Greg Luzinski and Steve Carlton's fourhit pitching carried the Philadelphia Phillies to a 41 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates last night.

title: March in Philadelphia Protests DayCare Cat
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (AP)  More than 400 women and children marched to City Hall today to protest cuts to the city's daycare program

title: Joint Onassis Venture With Uco Oil Confirmed
description: WHITTIER, Calif., Sept. 18 (UPI)  The Greekbased Onassis shipping empire and the Uco Oil Company of Whittier, Calif., have formed a partnership to conduct petroleum refining and shipping activities, a Uco spokesman confirmed today.

title: Hunt Families Watch Selection of Jury
description: LUBBOCK. Tex., Sept. 19Several factions of the farflung family of H. L. Hunt, the late oil billionaire, sat together in Federal District Court here this week to watch selection of jury to try two members of the family on wiretapping charges.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 During the last six months, President Ford has repeatedly attacked Government regulation for contributing to inflation and hampering the economic development of the United States.

title: 7 for 7Twice in a Century of Baseball
description: Much too quickly, Rennie Stennett of the Pittsburgh Pirates has dissolved into the small print of the box scores. His accomplishment of seven hits in seven times at bat in the Pirates' 220 conquest of the Chicago Cubs deserves to be chiseled in marble. It deserves to be hailed in song in Panama where he grew up. It deserves to be toasted in Three Rivers Stadium with champagne. To appreciate what the 24yearold second baseman did, consider that only one of more than 10,000 players had done it previously in a nineinning game in virtually a century of majorleague baseball. Consider that it had been 83 years since Wilbert Robinson, known best as Uncle Robby when he later managed the Brooklyn Dodgers had seven hits for the old Orioles of Baltimore in an 1892 game. Consider that if it takes that long for another major leaguer to do it, the deed will occur in the year 2058, perhaps on the moon. The record had lasted so long it was almost unknown. Not even Rennie Stennett was quite sure of what he had accomplished.

title: Jordanians Accept U.S. Missile Terms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Jordanian officials informed the United States privately today that King Hussein had dropped his apparent objections and had agreed to accept all the conditions imposed by President Ford for the sale to Jordan of 14 batteries of Hawk antiaircraft missiles.

title: The Politics of Tuition
description: Leaders of the City University believe that the muchpublicized debate with state of= fials over continuation of the university's notuition policy is essentially a smokescreen for more basic political issues, and they have settled on a strategy of pushing for more time before making any concessions. This is the conclusion that has emerged From interviews with presidents of the colleges in the City University system as well as from public and private statements of other educators involved.

title: Citibank's Prime Rate Is Maintained at 8%
description: The First National City Bank of New York maintained its prime lending rate at 8 per cent yesterday, indicating that the basic charge on business loans would remain stable for another week.

title: Kissinger Says U.S. Considers Purchases of Oil From Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States had begun to explore with the Soviet Union longterm purchases of Soviet oil.

title: ARMY DISCLOSES 3 NEW COVERUPS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The Army disclosed today that it had coveredup the cause and circumstances of the deaths of three civilian employes who in the nineteenfifties and nineteensixties died of rare diseases that were then being studied at Fort Detrick, Md., for possible combat use.

title: Suspect Seized in Death Of Guard During Escape
description: An alleged murderer who shot and fatally wounded a correction officer while escaping from Kings County Hospital last week was captured in Brooklyn early yesterday, several hours before a funeral service was held for the victim in a Staten Island church.

title: Ponty Puts Stress On Improvisations In JazzRock Band
description: JeanLuc Ponty, who will be at the Other End, 147 Bleecker Street, through tomorrow night, is a musician of overflowing gifts. The trouble is that he doesn't make very interesting music.

title: Rossetti Reelected Head Of Manhattan Democrats
description: With solid support from black and Puerto Rican district leaders, Frank G. Rossetti, who has been Manhattan Democratic leader since 1967, was reelected by the organization's executive committee yesterday for another twoyear term.

title: SHORT INTEREST SHOWS ADVANCE
Former Shelter Island Ferry Now Carries Cars in Maryland
description: OXFORD, Md.A pair of stately swans, escorted by a halfdozen brown mallards, paddle smoothly under the timbered ferry slip here, gliding forward like surfers on the tumbling wave of a fullastern propeller wash. Gunning the engine from the white wheelhouse, Capt. Gilbert C. Clark brings his 50yearold doubleend ferry boat to a practiced, gentle hump against the creaking automobile ramp.

title: Susan's Girl Favored in Beldame Stakes Todays.
description: Ross Fenstermaker, a young trainer from Delco, Idaho, felt he had just cause yesterday morning to look forward to this afternoon's 37th running of the $100,000added Beldame stakes at Belmont Parkwith considerable optimism. The reason was a nifty workout by Fred W. Hooper's prosperous and steadygoing Susan's Girl. The 6yearold mare had been caught blazing threeeighths of a mile in 0:34 over a sloppy main track.

title: Notes on People
description: After five months of almost total seclusion in Taiwan, Nguyen Van Thieu, former President of South Vietnam, yesterday left Taipei for Britain, and at the airport he dismissed as pure Communist propaganda reportsthat he had removed a large portion of the national gold reserves from Saigon when he left before the Communist takeover there.

title: U.S DELAYS SEEN ON ARMS TO ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger has reportedly taken the position that Israel would have to stand in line with American forces for the new weapons she wants from the United States.

title: WQXR Week to Raise Funds for Met
description: Radio station WQXR is devoting most of its programing next week to the Metropolitan Opera in a tribute whose purpose is, at least partially, to help raise money for the financially pressed company.

title: Baer Tours Farms Again And Decries Conditions
description: VINELAND, Sept. 19  As semblyman Byron M. Baer took another farm tour today, his first since his arm was broker on a tour of a South Jersey farm last summer.

title: Down the Garden Path
description: Governor Carey has set precisely the right tone for review of any deal that emerges from the months of backdoor effort by Madison Square Garden to ease its own financial burdens by loading them on the bowed back of New York City, via the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR, on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station.

title: Court Rejects a Nixon Bid To Resign From State Bar
description: An attempt by former President Richard M. Nixon to resign from the state bar has been rejected by a New York court because he has not admitted wrongdoing in connection with the Watergate scandal, sources familiar with the secret legal proceeding said yesterday.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, Korngotd's Die Tote Stadt. 2; Offenbach's Les Contes d'Hoffmann, 8.

title: Dignity Restored
description: The news that Dr. Frankenstein is alive and flourishing in Washington will surprise no one who follows world politics and international death plans. Politicians everywhere commonly view science primarily as an instrument for conveying death to disagreeable peoples, and if science is at the service of death in Washington, it is not a unique alliance of genius and hack. The same alliance functions around the earth, and has through the centuries.

title: TEACHERS PRESSED IN CONTEMPT CASE
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday gave Albert Shenker and other teacherunion leaders until Wednesday to show why they should not be held in criminal contempt for illegally conducting the fiveday school strike that ended Tuesday.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Abzug Supporters Adopt Revised Buckley Slogan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17Isn't it about time we had a Senator? was the slogan James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican, Used when he was campaigning in 1970.

title: Clemency Board Minority Finds Program Distorted by Majority
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  President Ford's Clemency Board was stacked with antiwar liberals who distorted the intent of the program, urged prison inmates to apply and voted clemency in cases involving civilian felony convictions, including rape and murder, four board members say.

title: First Federal Arrest Is Made in School Busing Strife in Boston
description: BOSTON, Sept. 19United States marshals made their first Federal arrest over this city's school desegregation program this afternoon in a day of street turbulence in South Boston.

title: Court Rejects a Nixon Bid To Resign From State Bar
description: An attempt by former President Richard M. Nixon to resign from the state bar has been rejected by a New York court because he has not admitted wrongdoing in connection with the Watergate scandal, sources familiar with the secret legal proceeding said yesterday.

title: TV Channels Selected By Use of Pushbuttons
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19In its new color television equipment, the RCA Corporation has added a pushbutton method of channel selection. For any one of the 82 channels available in the United States, the user will press two of the numhers from zero through 9. Wayne W. Evans. an engineer with the RCA Consumer Electronics division in Indianapolis, WAS granted Patent 3,906,3M this week for the tuning method used as the basis for the new line of products.

title: LISBON INSTALLS COALITION CABINET AFTER LONG CRISIS
description: LISBON, Sept. 19A new Portuguese coalition Cabinet, strongly opposed to Communist rule, was sworn in tonight.

title: It's Over for 2 Wrongly Held 12 Years
description: STARKE, Fla., Sept. 19After 12 years in jail for someone else's crime, Freddie Pitts and Wilbert Lee walked out of prison here today, into the bright autumn sunshine and new lives as free men.

title: GOLD FUTURES UP, REVERSING SLUMP
description: After a sharp decline since Monday, gold futures moved up a little yesterday, possibly due to bargain hunting by traders. The October delivery on the Commodity Exchange closed at $136 7/10 an ounce, up from $136 1/10.

title: RICHARD G. CONANT
description: Richard G. Conant, who for many years was an executive of the Wellington Sears Company, textile concern here, died Monday at his home in West Southport, Me. He was 85 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: When a civilization is no longer around to speak for itself we use the bits and pieces it leaves behind to make a picture of what it was like. Archeology is a fundamental contribution to human awareness; without it, our past would virtually be at the mercy of its own prose writers.

title: Seatrain Captures Jug Pace
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 19 (AP)Sea train, lightly raced and lightly regarded, defeated the favorite, Nero, in the first division and then defeated Polaris Lobell in the raceoff today to win the Little Brown Jug, the middle jewel of pacing's triple crown.

title: Former Shelter Island Ferry Now Carries Cars in Maryland
description: OXFORD, Md.A pair of stately swans, escorted by a halfdozen brown mallards, paddle smoothly under the timbered ferry slip here, gliding forward like surfers on the tumbling wave of a fullastern propeller wash. Gunning the engine from the white wheelhouse, Capt. Gilbert C. Clark brings his 50yearold doubleend ferry boat to a practiced, gentle hump against the creaking automobile ramp.

title: Corsicans Struggling to Save Imperiled Traditions
description: BASTIA, Corsica  One after the other they say they feel, like American Indians being forced onto a reservation. Like the Americans, the Corsicans don't like it very much.

title: TEACHERS' WALKOUT ENDS IN ENGLEWOOD
description: HAWTHORNE, N.J.. Sept. 19 (AP)A tentative settlement was reached this morning in the 11day Englewood teachers' strike.

title: C.I.A. Suit Opposed
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 19 (AP)The federal Government has asked United States District Court here to suspend a suit dealing with Central Intelligence Agency surveillance of mail because it could interfere with a Justice Department investigation. A statement filed by Deputy Assistant Attorney General Kevin T. Maroney argued against continuation of the suit brought by Prof. Rodney Driver of the University of Rhode Island. The court has Issued no decision on the Gov??ment request.

title: Impact on Midtown Grows As Stage Strike Goes On
description: A musicians' strike silenced Broadway's nine musicals again last night, and an apparent lack of progress in negotiations confronted the theaters and related midtown businesses with heavy losses of weekend patronage.

title: Smith of Rhodesia Foresees Sharing of Power With Blacks
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 19 (AP)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that he sees the possibility of this white  ruled nation someday having a black prime minister and a multiracial cabinet.

title: 7 N.F.L. Sellouts To Be Televised
description: Seven of the first weekend's 13 National Football League games are sellouts and will be shown on home television, the league announced yesterday.

title: Shah Says View Will Be Influential in OPEC
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 19 (AP)  The Shah of Iran says his country will insist on no more than a 15 per cent increase in oil prices when the ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meet in Vienna next Wednesday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Two Wrongly Jailed 12 Years Go Free
description: STARKE, Fla., Sept. 19After 12 years in jail for someone else's crime, Freddie Pitts and Wilbert Lee walked out of prison here today, into the bright autumn sunshine and new lives as free men.

title: Oldest Known Hulk Is Found Off Greece
description: ATHENS, Sept. 19Underwater explorers in Greece have identified the wreckage of an early Bronzeage ship that they believe to be the earliest known shipwreck ever found.

title: COSELL TV SHOW STARTS TONIGHT
description: The most unusual of this season's prime time television shows. Saturday Night Live With Howard Cosell, has its premiere at 8 o'clock tonight on ABCTV. Some may also regard it as the most bizarre of shows, since in many ways it is a variety show version of Monday night football, or what the television industry calls a spinoff.

title: Lisbon's New Path Reflects Will of Voters
description: LISBON, Sept. 19  After a political crisis and a threat of civil war. Portugal has announced the formation of a government that reflects the results of last April's elections. for a constituent assembly, with two essentially social democratic; groups, the Socialist and Popular Democratic parties, dominating the Communists.

title: STREETS CLEANER IN BROOKLYN AREA
description: The BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, where residents have often complained that they got only minimal attention from the Department of Sanitation, appeared relatively free of litter and garbage yesterday, the seventh day of Mayor Beame's 10day crash cleanup.

title: Jordanians Accept U.S. Missile Terms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Jordanian officials informed the United States privately today that King Hussein had dropped his apparent objections and had agreed to accept, all the conditions imposed by President Ford for the sale to Jordan of 14 batteries of Hawk antiaircraft missiles.

title: On Quitting Spain
description: WASHINGTONDoes the security of the United States require military bases in Spain, and if so what price should we pay for them?

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SAILING, SAILING If you get up late today, you will bave missed the boat. Sponsored by the South Street Seaport Museum, a special spectator ferry leaves from Whitehall Terminal (the foot of Whitehall Street in Lower Manhattan) with space for 1,500 to watch the ninth annual Mayor's Cup Schooner Race. (Schooners are twomasted, woodenhull, woodenmast sailing vessels.)

title: Fat Thin Fat Thin Fat Thin Fat...
description: A man who is both plump and candid likens the graduated size markings on the suits in his closet to the Plimsoll lines on a ship's hull.

title: SCHOOL TO MARK 210TH BIRTHDAY
description: FRANKLIN TOWNSHIP, Sept. 19In the year 1766 King George III of England signed a charter authorizing the establishment of Queen's College and a grammar school in New Brunswick in the colony of New Jersey.

title: Sweden, Chile Tie In Tennis
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, Sept. 19 (AP)Guarded by the biggest police force in the tournament's history, Sweden and Chile split the first two singles matches today in their Davis Cup semifinal round competition.

title: Vincent Papa and 15 Others Indicted on Drug Counts
description: Vincent C. Papa, a convicted major narcotics dealer, and a Queens police officer were among 16 persons cited by a Brooklyn Federal grand jury yesterday in two separate inlictments charging conspiracy to receive, buy, sell and conceal heroin and cocaine worth several million dollars.

title: Solomon, Ramirez, Tanner Gain
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19In a marvelous 150minute match that had the crowd in hysterics and provoked a standing ovation, Harold Solomon of Silver Spring, Md., twice hauled himself out of the abyss and defeated Dick Stockton of Dallas, 46, 76, 76 today to reach the semifinals of the $100,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament.

title: ECONOMISTS HAIL AUGUST INFLATION
description: Private economists yesterday welcomed the news that inflation slowed dramatically in August. But they, like the Ford Administration, expect consumer prices to move up faster again than the August rate during the remainder of this year.

title: James A. Kennedy, 59, Dies; Led Economic Consultants
description: James Andrew Kennedy, founder and principal executive of Today's Consumer, Ltd., an economic consultant firm for commercial banks and savings institutions at 109 East 29th Street, died of cancer Thursday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 59 years old and lived here.

title: In Memoriam
description: PASACHOFFDr. Harry D. In memory of our dearly beloved.

title: Orr Faces Surgery; To Miss 8 Weeks
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 19 (UPI)Bobby Orr has suffered damage to his left knee again and will undergo surgery on it for the fourth time tomorrow, the Boston Bruins said today. Orr will be sidelined through the first month of the National Hockey League season, which opens Oct. 7.

title: Satisfied F.B.I. Agent
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19  The news conference speaker was an immaculate fellow in a suit that was creased, not wrinkled, a spotless, crisp shirt and a care fully knotted tie. And he handled the questions with a touch that echoed his sartorial neatness.

title: Arab Group Pledges $25Million to End Crisis in UNESCO
description: PARIS, Sept. 19A group of Arab countries has pledged some $25million to the United Nations Educational, Srcientific and Cultural Organizationmore than enough to replace the funds the United States is withholding because of UNESCO's antiIsraeli actions.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: FIREMEN APPROVE 2YEAR CONTRACT
description: The membership of the ??niformed ??ghters Association approved a twoyear contract with the city and a wage freeze, but rejected a plan for firemen to contribute $10 each to help laidoff firemen, the American Arbitration Association reported yesterday.

title: Man Slain After Skipping Fare And Assaulting Transit Officer
description: A man who had refused to pay the 50cent fare at a Brooklyn subway station was shot and killed last night when he allegedly lunged with a knife at a transit police officer who was pursuing him, the police reported.

title: Art: Paintings by Appel on View
description: No one denies that painting is a material mediumno one in his right mind, anyway. But is there not something else involved? Paint squeezed directly from the tube always has a lovely, seductive, sensuous quality, at its first appearance at least, but it nonetheless requires the creative intervention of mind to rescue it from esthetic inertia. The quality of pigment counts for little where it is unredeemed by this quality of mind.

title: LISBON INSTALLS COALITION CABINET AFTER LONG CRISIS
description: LISBON, Sept. 19A new Portuguese coalition Cabinet, strongly opposed to Communist rule, was sworn in tonight.

title: Four Seized for Smut Involving Children
description: The use of children in pornographic publications led to the arrest yesterday of four men employed in four stores in the Times Square area where such materials are sold.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rose yesterday for the second straight day as volume advanced sharply on both marts, trading on the Amex reached a high for two months.

title: 35 HARVARD COINS FOUND IN CANADA
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 19 (UPI) The police raided two safety deposit boxes in a downtown bank today and recovered 35. rare Greek and Roman coins, part of a collection stolen from a museum at Harvard University two years ago.

title: Catholic School Talks Are Set for Next Week
description: A state mediator has called a meeting for next week between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and lay teachers at 325 Catholic elementary and high schools in the city and upstate in an effort to avert a strike threatened for Monday.

title: Panel of Prominent Citizens Formed To Help City Reverse Its Fiscal Slide
PATRICIA HEARST IS REFUSED BAIL PENDING HEARING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19A United States district judge ordered Patricia Hearst held without bail today because he questioned whether she might not run away again.

title: Portuguese Troop PullOut From Angola by Nov. 11 Set
description: LUANDA, Angola, Sept. 19 (Reuters)  Portugal will withdraw her troops from Angola by Nov. 11, the date scheduled for independence, according to the Portuguese High Commissioner here.

title: PAUL C. EATON
description: Paul C. Eaton, dean of students at the California Ins?? of Technology from 1947 to 1967, when he retired, died, apparently of a coronary attack, in the Maine Medical Center in Portland Thursday evening. He was 69 years old.

title: U.S. Grand Jury Investigates Maraziti
description: NEWARK, Sept. 19 (AP)A Federal grand jury here has subpoenaed documents from the House of Representatives, in connection with its investigation of whether Joseph J. Maraziti improperly applied for additional funds from the House Administration Committee to pay for what has been alleged was a no show research assistant when he was a member of the House.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)  Investors redeemed $787.9million of mutual funds in August, $35.1million more than they purchased, the Investment Company Institute said today. Sales of mutual funds totaled .$752.8million in August, down from $813million in July, the I.C.I. said. Redemptions were down from July's $1.052billion. Money market funds, however, showed an increase of sales over redemptions for the first time since May, the said.

title: $10,000 Won by Boy Poses Lottery Problem
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 19 (AP)  A 16yearold boy who apparently won the Connecticut $10,000 instant lottery may end up with nothing at all.

title: Owner of Vehicle Is Identified In the Slaying of Two Policemen
description: The owner of the car used by the men who murdered two police officers on Tuesday night was identified yesterday as Nelson Hernandez, a suspected drug dealer on the Lower East Side.

title: U.S. Ryder Cup Team Wins 6 of 8 Matches
description: LIGONIER, Pa., Sept. 19The American team of golf professionals routed their BritishIrish counterparts today in the opening round of the 21st Ryder Cup matches. The Americans won six of their eight matches, lost one and tied one.

title: CITY U. UNION SEEKS MEDIATOR FOR TALKS
description: The Professional Staff Congress, the City University's faculty union, petitioned the State Public Employment Relations Board yesterday to mediate the impasse that has developed in its contract negotiations with the Board of Higher Education.

title: Apartments for Elderly: Helping Hand, Not a Nursing Home
description: SILVER SPRING, Md.We lived in D.C., in a beautiful house with a beautiful yard. We had a store, a grocery store. But then my wife got sick, said Louis Eisenberg. She died in 1974.

title: WOMAN IN COMA HAD TAKEN DRUG
description: NEWARK, Sept. 19Kareni Ann Quinlan took a tranquilizer and consumed alcoholic beverages just before she suffered the collapse that has resulted in a coma from which physicians have said she will not recover, it was disclosed today by George Daggett, the Sussex County Prosecutor.

title: Sketches of Members of the New Portuguese Cabinet
description: Jose Pinheiro de Azevedo

title: St. Barnabas Is Seeking Funds for Its Burn Unit
description: LIVINGSTON, N.J.The National Burn Victim Foundation and St. Barnabas Hospital are making a major effort to make operational the 12bed burn treatment unit at St. Barnabos Medical Center here, the only such facility in the state.

title: Facts in Musicians' Strike
description: Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. I. Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.

title: Mets Beaten by Phils, 43, And Bow Out of East Race
MAY DAVIE DEAD; A CIVIC LEADER
description: May Davie, a civic and political leader here, died yesterday of heart failure at her home. She was in her 80's and lived at 71 East 71st Street and in Newport, R. I.

title: Penn State and Pitt to Battle Top Football Powers Today
description: If we're not careful in college football we'll look as ludicrous as some of those things in pro football.

title: Article 4  No Title
Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Air Force Sergeant Feels He Is a Patriot Fighting for Freedom
description: HAMPTON, Va., Sept. 19T. Sgt. Leonard Philip Matlovich, a onetime Goldwater conservative who flew the flag each day from an 18foot staff in front of his apartment, says that he is still a patriot. He served three tours in Vietnam, was severely wounded when he stepped on a land mine there and can, when he chooses, wear the Bronze Star and the Purple Heart on his Air Force blues.

title: Kissinger and Gromyko Discuss Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 An Administration official said to day that between 85 and 90 per cent of the work had been completed for a new accord with the Soviet Union to limit strategic weapons, but that im portant differences still held up an agreement.

title: Cold Trail Led to the Fugitives
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19A cold trail that led to a set of fingerprints in a Pennsylvania farmhouse eventually wended its tortuous way to Patricia Hearst in a secondfloor Mission District apartment here yesterday.

title: White Captures Met. Golf Crown
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 19 Carlton White 2d of Washington Valley, who will turn to the Professional Golfers Association tour this October, won the Metropolitan Golf Association's 60th anniversary open championship at Metropolis Country Club by three strokes today.

title: Assisting Spaniards, Ignoring Portuguese
description: The dinner party was about to break up. Suddenly another man of the 1930's remarked, You know, I turn on the radio every morning and listen tensely for the report from Lisbon. I'm interested, I said to him, because I do the same.

title: Arab Group Pledges $25Million to End Crisis in UNESCO
description: PARIS, Sept. 19A group of Arab countries has pledged some $25million to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organizationmore than enough to replace the funds the United States is witholding because of the agency's antiIsraeli actions.

title: Britain Orders an Inquiry On Plight of Newspapers
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 (Reuters) An urgent inquiry into the immediate problems of Britain's national newspapers is to be made at the request of the Labor Government, it was announced today.

title: Hamptons Art Benefit Yields $108,675
description: A controversial auction at Sotheby Parke Bernet of works by Long Island artists brought $108,675 Thursday evening for the benefit of Guild Hall, the arts center in East Hampton. Of the 90 paintings, drawings and sculptures by wellknown and lesserknown artists, only slightly more than half were sold, with few going at their minimum estimates.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A new Portuguese coalition Cabinet, strongly opposed to Communist rule, was sworn in last night. The 15member Cabinet, led by Vice Adm. Jos Pinheiro de Azevedo, a leftist navy career, officer, as Premier, includes one Communist, the Public Works Minister. [Page 1, Column 4.]

title: Bridge
description: Many situations at the bridge table represent sheer agony: A player has little to guide him in making a decision that is likely to swing more than 1,000 points. The most common of them is perhaps this:

title: Upstate TakeOver Of Power Company Receives a Setback
description: ALBANY, Sept. 19An attempt by the voters of Massena, N. Y., to take over an operate the local power company received a setback here today when a Public Service Commission examiner issued a complicated earnings estimate for the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation facilities in the upstate town.

title: Woman, 78, Slain on East 97th Street
description: At 78yearold woman who was the caretaker and lease agent for several apartment houses on East 97th Street was found stabbed to death yesterday morning in her apartment.

title: A Scab's View of L.I. School Strike
description: MELVILLE, L. I., Sept. 19 The striking teachers call Gladys Singer scab. They carry picket signs with her name on them. But Mrs. Singer continues to work as a substitute in her own school district.

title: PRINCE RISE RATI DOWN IN AUGUST LOW FOR 3 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The Consumer Price Index rose by twotenths of I per cent in August, the smallest rise in three years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Police Fix the Time of Death in Lundy Double Slaying
description: A noise that sounded like the slamming of a door early Thursday morning on a quiet street in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, is now believed by the police to have been the sound of the shot that killed 67yearold Elaine Lundy during the double murder that also took the life of her 80yearold brotherinlaw.

title: MORGAN STANLEY IN A PARIS DEAL
description: Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc., which already owns twothirds of the Parisbased firm of Morgan & Cie. International, said yesterday that it would acquire the remaining third from Morgan & Cie., S. A., the Paris unit of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York. The extent of Morgan Stanley's investment to acquire the interest was not disclosed. Subject to approval of regulatory authorities, the transaction is expected to be completed by the end of 1975.

title: Patty Hearst: Case 74364
description: With the arrest of Patricia Hearst and William and Emily Harris in San Francisco, the long chase has come to an end. Apparently ended, too, is the small band of revolutionaries that called itself the Symbionese Liberation Army. To the credit of the Federal Bureau of Investigationand in contrast to the fiery shootout of May, 1974, that turned into a smoldering grave for six of Miss Hearst's fellowrevolutionariesthe final chapter of the search was peaceful and almost anticlimactically routine.

title: 19 Injured Slightly As 2 Bus Accidents Jam Lincoln Tunnel
description: Two accidents involving four buses closed one New Yorkbound tube at the height of the rush hour yesterday morning. Nineteen persons were slightly injured and traffic was delayed up to two hours.

title: Javits Aide Is Stabbed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) Robert Amador, a 21yearold legislative intern to Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, was stabbed in an attempt robbery and fight last night, the District of Columbia police said. Mr. Amador, was listed in critical condition in a local hospital. Arrested on a charge of assault with intent to kill was a district resident, William D. Hallman, 24, the police said.

title: PRINCE RISE RATE DOWN IN AUGUST LOW FOR 3 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The Consumer Price Index rose by twotenths of I per cent in August, the smallest rise in three years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Syrians Seek to Mediate As Beirut Strife Worsens
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, Sept. 20Fighting continued in Beirut yesterday, with the southeastern suburbs of Ain elRummaneh and Chiyah resounding to sniper, rocket and mortar fire.

title: Yale and Old Saybrook Close Books on 1718 Tiff
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 19Yale University and the Town of Old Saybrook, Conn., kissed and made up here today, ending a 257yearold tiff over a handful of overdue books and a few bruised knuckles.

title: W age Panel Says Price Competition Lacking for Steel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  The staff of the Council on Wage and Price Stability says the American steel industry is one of limited competition and therefore can resist basic market forces that might otherwise force down prices.

title: Cold Trail Led to the Fugitives
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19A cold trail that led to a set of fingerprints in a Pennsylvania farmhouse eventually wended its tortuous way to Patricia Hearst in a secondfloor Mission District apartment here yesterday.

title: CANCER PERIL IN AIR ANTIWAR ACTIVIST AND WATER STUDIED GUILTY OF SABOTAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)  The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had begun an investigation to determine the extent of a possible new cancer threat in both the air and water.

title: Bronze Age Wreck Is Found off Greece
description: ATHENS, Sept. 19Underwater explorers in Greece have identified the wreckage of an early Bronze Age ship that they believe to be the earliest known shipwreck ever found.

title: Met Musicians Plan To Report Monday For First Rehearsal
description: The Metropolitan Opera orchestra, whose members voted Thursday to authorize a strike, plans to report to work fort the first scheduled rehearsals Monday.

title: Shows Open
description: Shows that are not affected by the strike: Absurd Person Singular; Ah Wilderness! Equus, Sanie Time Next Year, Sherlock Holmes, The Ritz, Dance With Me and The Leaf People, Which is in preview. Off Broadway plays and shows at Lincoln Center are not involved.

title: Erroneous Complaint
description: In an editorial last Wednesday, Against Public Strikes, the Board of Education was reproached as having ignored in past teachers' strikes the Taylor Law mandate that strikers be docked two days' pay for every day off the job. That penalty was not inserted in the law until April 1, 1969, largely as an outgrowth of illegal strikes by New York City teachers and sanitationmen in 1968. In that year the school board provided a variety of expedients to keep teachers from losing any pay for their time away from the classroom, another factor in the Legislature's adoption of the twoforone penalty. This year's school strike represents the first occasion for its application. We regret the error.

title: MARJORY B. CLARK
description: Marjory Blair Clark, Eastern director of the camp and hospital council of the American Red Cross during World War II, died Wednesday at her home in Hightstown, N.J. She was 83 years old and formerly lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: ETHICS ISSUE SEEN IN WEIGHING GRAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19An Agriculture Department official testified today that a basic defect in the country's scandalridden graininspection system was an inherent conflict of interest in the current system, under which private agencies inspected and graded grain with random Federal supervision.

title: Garrett Leaving S.E.C.; Casey Quits the Eximbank
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The resignation of Ray Garrett Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and of William J. Casey, a former chairman of the S.E.C. who is now the head of the ExportImport Bank, were announced today by the White House.

title: People and Business
description: Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman of the RCA Corporation, announced yesterday the establishment of a new management organization to direct the company's expanding business.

title: City Hospitals Propose Budget For Wishful Thinking Projects
description: Yesterday, the day after Mayor Beame told his cabinet not to come up with wish lists for capital projects, the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation disclosed its proposed budget, with some requests its officials conceded could be described as wishful thinking.

title: Accord at British Steel Ends Threat of Strike
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP)Peace returned to Britain's steel industry today  36 hours before a potentially crippling national strike that had been set to begin Sunday.

title: Article 1  No Title
Sports News Briefs
description: Dan Issel, one of the American Basketball Association's hottest properties, was traded yesterday to the Baltimore Claws, a new franchise that replaced the defunct Memphis Sounds. In return, the Colonels, the defending A.B.A. champions, received a reported $600,000 and the rights to Tom Owens, a center and forward who signed last Wednesday with the Houston Rockets of the National Basketball Association. Owens played for the Sounds last season.

title: U.S. PLANS TO SHIFT PATRICIA HEARST
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 The Federal authorities made plans today to transfer Patricia Hearst and her two companions in the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army to Los Angeles to be arraigned on a total of 55 felony charges growing out of events that preceded the deaths of six other Symbionese terrorists here last year.

title: Theater Owners Focus on Change in Work Practices of Musicians
description: A key point of contract negotiations between striking theater musicians and their employers is the determination of management to eliminate what it considers inefficient and costly work practices as necessary conditions for granting reasonable pay increases.

title: Statue of St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Is Defaced by Paint
description: Black paint was ?? by a vandal early yesterday on a statue of St. Elizabeth Ann Seton in lower Manhattan.

title: BLACKLUNG AID PLAN SOFTENED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) A proposal to make all underground coal miners automatically eligible for black long disability benefits after 15 years on the Job seems doomed, despite an intense lobbying drive by thoudsands of miners.

title: Levi to Keep a Watergate Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Attorney General Edward H. Levi has decided to let the special Watergate prosecutor's office remain open indefinitely to prepare arguments against pending or expected appeals filed by convicted Watergate figures.

title: Challenge to Defeatism
description: With the Ford Administration increasingly resistant to Federal help for New York and other hardpressed cities, it is encouraging to see the first strong signs of Congressional inclination to step into the void.

title: Alan Baker Makes City Opera Debut In 'Die Fledermaus
description: The season's fourth performmice of Die Fledermaus at the New York City Opera one Thursday night had many of the ingredients of delight. Johanna Meier ad Alan Titus sang and intrigued splendidly as Rosalinda and Gabriel von Eisenstein, those dimwitted parodies of the Count and Countess Almaviva, and several others in the cast also showed they understood Strauss's lighthearted, never heavytooted. style.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Dan Issel, one of the American Basketball Association's hottest properties, was traded yesterday to the Baltimore Claws, a new franchise that replaced the defunct Memphis Sounds. In return, the Colonels, the defending A.B.A. champions, received a reported $600,000 and the rights to Tom Owens, a center and forward who signed last Wednesday with the Houston Rockets of the National Basketball Association. Owens played for the Sounds last season.

title: MARCOS DISCLOSES OUSTERS OF 2,000
description: MANILA, Sept. 19 (UPI)President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today he had dismissed 2,000 Government and military officials as traitors to his New Society program and warned that the purge had only begun. Several department heads were dismissed on charges of corruption.

title: 2 Basques Are Reported Killed In Battles With Spanish Police
description: MADRID, Sept. 19 (Reuters) The police said today that two Basque nationalist guerrillas were killed and at least 18 persons arrested in raids that led to gun battles in Madrid and Barcelona yesterday.

title: M.A.C. Considers Agency's Plea for Aid
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, which helped design the elaborate fiscal rescue mechanism for the city, is now considering whether it should come to the aid of the New York City Educational Construction Fund, an independent, agency that faces possible default within a week.

title: Jack Alexander, 73, Editor For Saturday Evening Post
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (AP)Jack Alexander, former newspaperman and editor of The Saturday Evening Post, died Wednesday at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 73; years old.

title: Depressant's Role Not Fully Understood
description: The precise mechanism by which nervoussystem depressants such as alcohol, barbiturates and some tranquilizers, produce coma is not fully understood.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS SOVIET GRAIN DEAL
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 19 President Ford, on the road once againthis time in oil and grainrich Oklahomasaid today he was giving priority attention to a longterm grain arrangement with the Soviet Union and warned that the United States is headed for deep trouble because of Congressional inaction on energy.

title: Holdup Man Seized In a Subway Chase On East Side IRT
description: A man believed to have taken $400 in a beauty parlor holdup last night and then fired two shots at his pursuers in a chase along First Avenue was seized by the police when he ran down to subway tracks to elude capture.

title: Homosexual G.I.'s Ouster Is Recommended by Panel
description: HAMPTON, Va., Sept. 19A threemember panel of Air Force officers took 4 hours 27 minutes today to conclude that T.Sgt. Leonard P.. Matlovich, a homosexual, was unfit for military service. The panel recommended that he be severed from service with a general discharge.

title: All the Stars That Are Fit to Read
description: PRINCETON, N. J.Recently, 186 scientists issued a publie statement informing us that the practice of astrology has no rational or factual basis. If their purpose was to deter horoscope readers, they would have done better to tell us that astrology is based on hard scientific evidence. For the appeal of the occult is that it is irrational, fantastic and does not attempt to confuse its devotees with mere facts.

title: Stage: Zippy Ice Follies
description: Nothing too serious is likely to happen on ice except sudden death. For every man or woman who has fallen in love on an icerink there must have been a hundred who have lost their hearts in a ballroom. Perhaps this is why there is a special innocence to an ice show. It is also the frictionless show, the zipless yet zippy movements, the showbiz mixture of a circus and a TV spectacular, the strange sense of artistry without art that makes this kind of dancingontherocks so interestingly uncompelling and yet at the same time quite compellingly interesting.

title: ELLINGHAUS SEES BORROWING CURB
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 19William M. Ellinghaus, a member of the Emergency Financial Control Board established by the state to oversee New York City's finances, said today that it is quite unlikely that the city would be able to borrow money again on its own by December.

title: After a Long Vigil, Hearsts Embrace Fugitive Daughter in a California Jail
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19Patricia Hearst, the former fugitive who once denounced her mother and father as pigs, was reunited with her parents early this morning in a stark jailhouse conference room.

title: A cab's View of L.I. School Strike
description: MELVILLE, L. I., Sept. 19 The striking teachers call Gladys Singer scab. They carry picket signs with her name on them. But Mrs. Singer continues to work as a substitute in her own school district.

title: WELFARE CONTINUED IN ORANGE COUNTY
description: GOSHEN, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP)  Facing a court order, Orange County Legislators backtracked today and agreed to continue financing the county's welfare programs through the end of the year.

title: PATRICIA HEARST IS REFUSED BAIL PENDING HEARING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29.A United States district judge ordered Patricia Hearst held without bail today because he questioned whether she might not run away again.

title: Court Discloses GrossiKatz Dealings
description: NEWARK, Sept. 19Judge Melvin P. Antell today dissolved a seal on two documents that describe the business and political dealings of Anthony J. Grossi, president of the Board of Public Utilities Commissioners, with George Katz, a garbage contractor and longtime friend.

title: RHONDA G. LORINCZI
description: Rhonda Goodkin Lorinczi, a Former lawyer here, died of encephalitis Tuesday in Washington, where she lived. She was 37 years old.

title: NOV. 4 TRIAL IS SET FOR MISS FREE
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept 19Lynette Alice Fromm pleaded not guilty today to a charge of trying to assassinate President Ford.

title: A Waterbed That Doesn't Make Waves
description: In 1970 the waterbed was the bed of the future. Everyone wanted to buy oneor at least try one out. But enthusiasm for it faded somewhat when owners discovered that it came with more than a few unpleasant, if not dangerous side effects, among them seasickness and cold and leaky mattresses.

title: Bengali Visits Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Sept 19 (AP)A special envoy of the new Bangladesh Government left Moscow today after three days of talks with Soviet leaders, the official Soviet press agency lass reported. The envoy, identified as M. Ahmed, brought a message to President Nikolai V. Podgorny, Tass said.

title: DISSIDENTS SEIZED BY SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 19 (AP)At a time when South Africa seeks to improve her image abroad, the Terrorism Act is being used as the basis for the arrest of a string of political dissidents.

title: U. N. Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19  The General As sembly voted today to send hack to the Security Council, for immediate and favorable consideration the applications of North and South Vietnam for membership in the United Nations.

title: Impact on Midtown Grows As Stage Strike Goes On
description: A musicians' strike silenced Broadway's nine musicals again last night, and an apparent lack of progress in negotiations confronted the theaters and related midtown businesses with heavy losses of weekend patronage.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Antiques: Bronze Zoo
description: French 19thcentury animaliers, those anatomical and sometimes impressionistic decorative bronze sculptures, are now enjoying a modest revival after decades of scorn.

title: Prices of Stocks Rise Sharply On Favorable Economic News
description: Encouraging news on tne inflation fronta sharp decline in the rate of growth in the consumer price index for August aided stock prices yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average closed with a sizable advance for the second consecutive day accompanied by increased volume.

title: Fairfield Porter, 68, a Realist In an Age of Abstract Art, Dies
description: Fairfield Porter, an artist whose realist style influenced many younger painters, died Thursday in Southampton, L. I., where he had lived since 1949. He was 68 years old.

title: TV Review
description: TV Review

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP SLIGHTLY HERE
description: Consumer prices in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area rose a bit in August as declines in the prices of some foods offset increases in the cost of apparel and of transportation, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday.

title: The Korean Triangle
description: The shifting tripartite relationship among the United States, South Korea and Japan is once again coming under farreaching reexamination in all three capitals, now that the initial fears of postVietnam defeatism have faded among the Asian allies.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATH MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES P:00 A.M. TO P4 MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) ??0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Wedding Held For Miss Rule
description: In the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church here yesterday afternoon Marguerite Stewart Rule, a model, was married to Yerger Johnstone, a vice president with Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc., investment bankers. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony.

title: SLAYER OF A PRIEST RETURNS TO CUSTODY
description: TOMS RIVER, Sept. 19 (AP)John Kelly 3d, who spent two years in a mental institution after being acquitted by reason of insanity in the murder of a priest, was back in custody today after three days of freedom.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn where residents have often complained that they got only minimal attention from the Department of Sanitation, appeared relatively free of litter and garbage yesterday, the seventh day of Mayor Beame's 10day crash cleanup.

title: Garrett Leaving S.E.C.; Casey Quitting Eximbank
description: circles when they were first announced.

title: Experts Expect Cartel to Retain Its Cohesion
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 19 With an important meeting ofl the 13nation oil cartel days away, government and industry analysts agree that despite deep production cutbacks this year the oil exporters continue to stand together and probably will raise prices.

title: ELLINGHAUS SEES BORROWING CURB
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 19William M. Ellinghaus, a member of the Emergency Financial Control Board established by the state to oversee New York City's finances, said today that it is quite unlikely that the city would be able to borrow money again on its own by December.

title: Disbarring Mr. Nixon?
description: Although former President Nixon was pardoned by his successor in the White House for any wrongdoing related to the Watergate crimes, he now faces the judgment of his peers in the legal community in New York. This may conic as close as any semiofficial body can to defining Mr. Nixon's Watergate activities and recording a quasilegal judgment on his character and Presidency.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Court of Appeals in Albany unanimously affirmed a decision by the Appellate Division granting the State Supreme Court in Nassau County the power to form a 15member interim government to replace the present County Board of Supervisors. Beside's voting in November for legislative candidates from equalpopulation districts, county residents will also be able to vote on propositions calling for a modified weightedvoting system for the Board of Supervisors and for a modified form of the legislative body.

title: Italian TV Censors Pass La Dolce Vita
description: ROME, Sept. 19 (AP)Fifteen years after La Dolce Vita arrived on the screen, Federico Fellini's epic of modern Roman decadence has finally gone past the Italian television censor.

title: British Raise Air Fare
description: LONDON Sept. 19 (Reuters) The British Civil Aviation Authority today raised its floor price for a return LondonNew York or LondonToronto ticket on charter fights to $243 from $214 beginning in April.

title: Indians Beat Hunter, 32, for Peterson's 10th in Row
Jets' Injuries Fade Away In Countdown to Opener
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 19 The New York Jets went through their final major workout today before the opening of the National Football League season, and for the first time in 1975 they were virtually intact.

title: Solomon, Ramirez, Tanner Gain
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19In a marvelous 150minute match that had the crowd in hysterics and provoked a standing ovation, Harold Solomon of Silver Spring, Md., twice hauled himself out of the abyss and defeated Dick Stockton of Dallas, 46, 76, 76 today to reach the semifinals of the $100,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament.

title: Walkout Stirs Fears Over Forthcoming Musical Productions
description: Adela Holzer has two shows running on BroadwayThe Ritz and Sherlock Holmes. which she coproduced. Both are straight plays, and with all musicals closed by a musicians' strike, business has shown some improvement. But Mrs. Holzer is not concerned about the possible profits. She has a big worryher incoming show, the Scott Joplin opera Treemonisha.

title: Programs to Keep the Aged Out of Institutions
description: The growing movement to keep children out of institutions and in home settings has a parallel in regard to the elderly.

title: HARBORING INQUIRY WILL BE CONTINUED
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 19 (UPI)The Government intends to pursue its grand jury investigation into charges that Patricia Hearst and three other fugitives were harbored in Pennsylvania in the summer of 1974 and will explore the possibility of calling Miss Hearst as a witness.

title: Homosexual G.I.'s Ouster Is Recommended by Panel
description: HAMPTON, Va., Sept. 19A threemember panel of Air Force officers took 4 hours 27 minutes today to conclude that T.Sgt. Leonard P. Matlovich, a homosexual, was unfit for military service. The panel recommended that he be severed from service with a general discharge.

title: BURNS PROPOSES PUBLICJOB PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 19 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested today that it would be better to tackle unemployment by providing lowwage government jobs for anyone willing to take them than by further pumping up the economy through budget deficits and a rapid rise in money and credit.

title: Market Place
description: The longsuffering shareholders of the Aguirre Company followed with resignation the progress of Hurricane Eloise as it struck Puerto Rico Tuesday.

title: JOSEPH SHAPIRO, 89, JEWISH LEADER, DIES
description: Joseph George Shapiro, a national leader of the Reform Jewish movement, died Thursday at the Carolton Nursing Home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 89 years old and lived in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Dr. K. R. Krauss, Miss Veague Wed
description: Pamela Chiles Veague, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Veague Jr. of New Ipswich, N. H., was married there yesterday afternoon at her parents' home to Dr. Kenneth R. Krauss, a New York cardiologist. He is a son Mrs. Samuel Krauss of New York and the late Mr. Krauss. The Rev. Fay Gemmell, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony with Rabbi Samuel Umen.

title: Pirates Eliminate 2 Pursuers
description: If anyone is going to stop the Pittsburgh Pirates from winning their fifth National League Eastern Division title in six years, it will have to be the Philadelphia Phillies, who won last night to remain six games back with nine games to play.

title: Hearst on Flight to Coast Tells of Relief at the News
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19When Randolph A. Hearst was sitting in the Essex House barbershop in New York City yesterday afternoon and heard on the radio that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had apprehended William and Emily Harris on the street here, he waited until the barber finished cutting his hair before he went upstairs to call the F.B.I.

title: Matt Helm, Bronk in Detective Ranks
description: Matt Helm is a private detective played by Tony Franciosa. His new series begins tonight at 10 on ABC. Bronk is a police detective played by Jack Palance. His new series begins tomorrow night at 10 on CBS. And the new television season proceeds apace along familiar ruts.

title: Utility Plans Offering
description: The Northern Indiana Public Service Company registered yesterday two million common shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission. A public offering of the shares will be made through underwriters headed by Dean Witter & Co., Inc., and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc.

title: BUICK IS HALTING IMPORTS OF OPELS
description: DETROIT, Sept. 19 The Buiok division of the General Motors Corporation said it had stopped importing the Opel from West Germany because currency changes had driven up the price of the cars so they are no longer competitive.

title: Gold Drops Sharply to $136.50
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 The price of gold dropped sharply again today on world markets. Normally unshakable bullion dealers here expressed fears that the selling was beginning to feed on itself.

title: 12 Criticize New Vote Law in High Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Senator James L. Buckley and 11 other challengers of the new Federal campaign financing Jaws told the Supreme Court today that the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia had wholly failed to examine the impact of the new laws and instead uncritically deferred to Congress when it upheld nearly all of the new legislation last August.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Inmate furloughs have been suspended at the Yardville Youth Reception and Correction Center pending a review of the program that allowed a convicted murderer to escape and allegedly kill again. The accused man, Anthony Richard Sistrunk, 20 years old, of Salem, who escaped Dec. 14, 1973, while on a furlough to visit a relative, was arrested in Florida last Saturday and brought New York City to face charges of killing Police Officer Michael McConnon. 27 years old, during a bank robbery last January.

title: Contract Awards
description: A group of major Japanese companies and the Island Creek Coal Company, a unit of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, have agreed for the unit to import 1.66 million tons of coal annually for three years, beginning in April, 1976. Occidental said the agreement is worth about $300million.

title: Prosecutor Says Woman in Coma Had Taken Drug and Alcohol
description: NEWARK, Sept. 19Karen Ann Quinlan took a tranquilizer and consumed alcoholic beverages just before she suffered the collapse that has resulted in a coma from which physicians have said she will not recover, it was disclosed today by George Daggett, the Sussex County Prosecutor.

title: Shows Closed
description: The shows closed by the strike of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians:

title: Court Postpones Decision in Gandhi Case
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 19The Supreme Court, delivering at least a temporary setback to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, today postponed a decision on her appeal against her conviction in June of violating election laws.

title: NUMISMATICS
