description: Quietly and without fanfarewith not even a press releasethe Mint has taken a step that should recapture the goodwill of hundreds of thousands of collectors who have purchased the threepiece, 40 per cent silver uncirculated Bicentennial coin set at the muchprotested original price of $9. Every buyer is being given the opportunity by means of computer cards already mailed out by the Mintto return the set (or sets) for a full $9 per set refund.

title: ZAMBIA TIGHTENS ECONOMIC REINS
Ford Gives 13 Scientists National Medal at Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20President Ford presented the National Medal of Science, the Government's highest scientific honor, to 13 scientists this week.

title: Solar Energy Is Called the Solution to Power Pollution, Reportedly Tripled Since 1940
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 20 New calculations of the pollutional residues of power generation indicate that eventually the world will have to turn almost entirely to solar energy, an international environmental conference was told this week.

title: Munich's Beer Fete Starts
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 20 (Reuters)The Munich Oktoberfest opened today with the traditional tapping of the first keg of beer. Brewers expect five million visitors to quench their thirst on the special October brew. The festival originated in 1810 as part of the wedding festivities for the Crown Prince of Bavaria.

title: Cool Weather Puts Head on Cabbage and Cauliflower
description: Culinary folklore insists that a frost puts flavor into cauliflower. To the cauliflower grower, this is an exaggeration. Cold weather is ideal, said Robert Roosa of the Long Island Cauliflower Association, a farmers' cooperative, but you don't need frost. The weather we have been having for the past few weeks is fine. We can look for tight, nicely headed cauliflower, and a good year.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: The idea that a national economy should be planned has had continuing appeal in the United States and elsewhere. In fact, nothing is more natural than to believe that the best way, or indeed the only way, to ensure that an economy will serve the national interest is to have the government identify the national interest, make a plan for achieving it, and enforce the plan.

title: Moscow Artists Close Own Exhibit in a Dispute
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20  With cries of Take down the paintings, unofficial artists today disrupted their own art show to protest the removal of 41 paintings by the authorities the night before.

title: Confident U.S.E.T. Mexico CityBound
description: The United States Equestrian Team's PanAmerican Gaines squad  jumping, threeday and dressage departs for Mexico City Tuesday with solid hopes of returning home with some important medals. The horses and grooms, plus Dennis Murphy of the jumping team, will leave from Kennedy Airport tomorrow morning. The rest of the riders, along with the coaches, Bert de Nemethy, Jack Le Goff and Col. Bengt Ljundquist, will depart from Newark Airport 24 hours later.

title: Jersey City Held Worst In Quality of Life Study
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 20 (UPI)Portland, Ore., is the best and Jersey City the worst large American city to live in, according to a study released today measuring quality of life standards ranging from swimming pools to smog to sexual discrimination.

title: Oil Spills Laid to U.S. Steel
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (UPI)An environmental group says the United States Steel Corporation has violated Federal law by failing to report eight oil spills to the Securities and Exchange Commission in an 18month period. Karen Ward staff researcher for Citizens for a Better Environment, said Thursday the nation's largest steel producer reported only 36 of 44 oil spills during the period. She asked the S.E.C. to investigate the company's reporting practices.

title: Livingston Discontinues Segregated Dormitories
description: PISCATAWAY  Five allblack and Puerto Rican dormitories on the Livingston College campus of Rutgers University have been discontinued this year. And if a random sampling is any indication, students who lived in these houses last year do not like the change.

title: Rutgers Evaluates Night Law Classes
description: NEWARKThe quality of students and instruction in the new parttiversity's law scime evening prowams at Rutgers Unhools compares favorably to the fulltime day programs, according to officials at both schools.

title: Saigon Today Is Less Fun, Less Corrupt, And Cheaper
description: SAIGON  Deep changes are taking place in South Vietnam where the remants of the society and habits engendered by a long war still coexist, nearly five months after the change of regime, with efforts to harmonize the ways of life in the North and South of this warwracked country.

title: British Workers Underpaying Wives
description: LONDON, Sept. 20Between 20 and 25 per cent of British husbands gave their wives no increase in housekeeping money this year although prices went up 25 per cent or more.

title: LETTERS
description: Semipublic

title: Late Score By Express Beats Bell
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 20 (AP)Alfred Haywood, a fullback, burst 17 yards for a touchdown in the fourth quarter tonight that gave the Jacksonville Express a 1610 victory over the Philadelphia Bell in a World Football. League game.

title: Article 18  No Title
description: Alexander M. Bickel, who died at age 49, was a quintuple threat, although he did not compartmentalize his various roles: he was intellectual provocateur to a generation of students (after training at Harvard Law, he taught at Yale). Constitutional scholar (among his books The Least Dangerous Branch: The Suprem Court at the Bar of Politics), political journalist (contributing editor, The New Republic), public man (political campaigner, talk show guest, Congressional testifier) and controversial advocate (he represented The New York Times in the Pentagon Papers case, although to the disappointment of civil libertarians he underplayed the First Amendment. his strategy prevailed as the U.S. Supreme Court decided 6.3 against the Government).

title: June Graduates Find More Jobs Than Expected
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 20The graduating seniors in the class of '75, who in June were thought to have the poorest chances for employment since the Great Depression, are faring better than the fore?? had expected.

title: EriePenn Central Link in Suspension, Ronan Says
description: NEWARKThe heralded plan to give the ErieLackawanna Railroad's Bergen County lines direct access to midManhattan by means of a connection with the Penn Central main line in Secaucus is in suspension, according to William J. Ronan, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: ALEXANDER LEAF (M.D.): YOUTH IN OLD AGEThe . . . effects of inactivity . . . on the body are easily recognized. . . . Mental laziness . . . may have equally deleterious . . . effects upon our Intellects. Thus It should be possible by appropriate exercises to retain mental as well as physical activity.

title: Interior Department Advances Plan to Sell Coal Leases to Private Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Under mining industry pressure, the Interior Department has moved to resume the leasing of billions of tons of federally owned Western coal reserves to private energy companies without obtaining the public comment of environmentalists, Western Governors and others.

title: Post Sets Back Ashland Behind Strong Defense
description: GREENVALE, L.I., Sept. 20 C.W. Post College, behind a strong defense and the runing of Frank Prochilo, registered an 183 victory today over Ashland College.

title: Surveillance Report Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20A State Department official has confirmed that there have been reports of surveillance of United States officials in Teheran by persons presumed to be Iranian terrorists.

title: ART VIEW
description: Max Beerbohm once observed about Maurice Hewlett, a writer now pretty much forgotten, that He sees his characters steadily, brilliantly, from top to toe. Not a turn of the wrist, not a wrinkle nor a buckle, escapes his hawklike eye. And he makes us partakers of his vision. In the round we see them, these fair ladies and their gallants, these proud virgins and generous wantons, these knights with clanking harness and beetling brows. We visualize them as distinctly as we visualize the people who pass us in the street. They are solid, mobile, lifesized. But is there life inside them? They are often very violent. They express, very picturesquely and delightfully, all the symptoms of love, hatred, despair, political ambition, religious fervor, and whatnot. They are very eloquent. There is nothing they cannot express.. .. But somehow, for me at least, they do not seem quite real. When I close the book that has revealed them to me, they do not enter into my spiritual life. I feel about them as about the ladies and gentlemen who, when the curtain falls between them and me, retire to their dressing rooms, and cleanse themselves of grease paint, before driving home to supper.

title: Anne Parkin Wed To William Griffin
description: Anne Goulding Parkin, director of admissions at Briarcliff College, and William Amos Griffin, Briarcliff's vice president for development, were married yesterday afternoon in the Eastminster United Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh. The Rev. Dr. W. Paul Ludwig performed the ceremony.

title: History's the Think on Fall House Tours
description: From 19th century Irish factory workers' houses in Paterson, N. J., to Colonial fieldstones in historic Connecticut hamlets, dozens of private homes will be open this fall for the curious to visit and for charity and local preservation groups to profit by. Many tours also feature craft demonstrations, music, sales of local handicrafts and outdoor festivities.

title: Bring on the Empty Horses
description: This is a book about Hollywood and incidentally a masterful selfportrait. Inasmuch as what David Niven recalls is mostly what he saw, smelled and tasted, you wonder, after putting it down, how he managed to bring it off without making it sound like a book starring David Niven produced by David Niven directed by David Niven from an original a screenplay by David Niven. This does not happen because of a talent for selfeffacement, which is one of the many things Niven did not learn in Hollywood, the others being a resolute amiability and thoughtfulness. That talent serves him as a pillar supporting what might easily be the best book ever written about Hollywood.

title: ...And Back Roads Of Massachusetts
description: WITH the advent of autumn, thousands of Northeasterners who haven't given a hoot about trees all year head for the hills to partake of New England's annual color spectacular. For most motorists from the New York metropolitan area, the Berkshires in the westernmost part of Massachusetts have long been a favorite fall foliage destinationwith predictable results: bumpertobumper traffic along U.S. 7 in and out of Great Barrington, Stockbridge and other major towns. But for those who would avoid the Berkshire crowds, there is a pleasant alternative, 30 miles to the east. In the Pioneer Valley, made up of the three Massachusetts counties  Hampden, Hampshire and Franklinsplit by the Connecticut River on its northsouth course, the leafer will find a pleasing scenic mix of forests and farmland and small New England villages, with a varied collection of sites worth visiting. What the valley may lack in Berkshire chic, it makes up in travel ease.

title: Notes: The SevenDay Unlimited Bus Pass
description: IN the spirit of '76 during this autumn of '75, the nation's two transcontinental bus lines, Greyhound and Continental Trailways, are both offering a special Bicentennial deal: unlimited mileage for seven days. Greyhound's sevenday offering is called the Ameripass and its price has the ring of independence about it: $76. The sevenday Eagle Pass of Continental Trailways is $75.

title: He's in Tune With Today
description: Creator is a heavy word. Very heavy, especially when applied to fashion designers. They're translators or adaptors more often than inventors.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: INFLATION SLOWED ABRUPTLY in August with the Consumer Price Index rising only 0.2 per cent following a rise of 1.2 per cent in July. . .The basic United States balance of payments in the second quarter went into a surf plus position while the balance on current account showed a record surplus of $4.1billion. . . Industrial production in August rose 1.3 per cent, the largest of four consecutive monthly increases and the largest since October 19??. . . The Treasury sold $3billion in twoyear notes at an average yield of 8.44 per cent.

title: Cleanup Avoids Woes
description: Fall cleanup is essential to good garden housekeeping. It's not only for neatness' sake, but for the good health of soil and plants.

title: National League
description: New York 9, Philadelphia 7. (11 inn.).

title: Headliners
description: It took less than an hour for a Harrisburg, Pa. Jury to find Joseph Kallinger guilty of nine counts of burglary, robbery and false imprisonment. Jurors said they were convinced of Mr. Kallinger's guilt at the start of their deliberation, and debated only the question of his sanity. Following sentencing, Mr. Kallinger, alleged protagonist in a series of robberies and sex offenses last winter in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and Maryland, is expected to be extradited to New Jersey, where he will stand trial for the murder of a 21yearold nurse last January. His conviction last week could result in a sentence of more than 100 years in prison.

title: Memorial Services
description: STEPHENSRoderick. Memorial service Monday, Sept. 22, 11:30 A.M. at the Community Church, 40 E. 35 St., N.Y. City. Contributions to the New York University Medical Center, 550 First Ave., New York, N.Y. 10016, in lieu of flowers.

title: With Strike Sidelined, N.F.L. Will Kick Off Today
description: Perhaps entertainment has a higher priority in our society than education. The schools in several parts of the country this September did not open on schedule because of labor strife. But the National Football League will. The league's 56th season begins its fourmonth stand today and even the New England Patriots are ready. At least Chuck Fairbanks, their imperturbable coach, says they are.

title: State Cites Nursing Home Here On Poor Quality of Patient Care
description: The State Health Department has accused Charles Sigety, operator of the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home at 175 East 96th Street, of providing poor patient care and failing to provide a clean, healthful environment.

title: Arkansas Gas Shortage Feared if Refugees Stay
description: FORT SMITH, Ark., Sept. 20 If the State Department does not relocate thousands of Viet namese refugees now at Fort Chaffee, serious shortages of natural gas could result this winter in the industrial center of Arkansas, W. R. Walker, president of ArkansasOklahoma Gas Corporation has warned.

title: Birthplace of TV To Hail DuMont
description: PASSAIC  This industrial city, which calls itself The Birthplace of Television, will stage its own TV spectacular next month as part of its Bicentennial celebration.

title: A ThreeDimensional Microscope
description: Since Anton van Leeuwenhoek first observed wee animals (they were bacteria and protozoa) under a crude microscope almost three hundred years ago, natural scientists' knowledge of the very small has expanded by quantum jumps. One of the more dramatic windows on the microcosm has opened in the last decade. It is the scanning electron microscope.

title: Miss Livingston Is Wed To Robert C. Edmonds
description: Catharine VanBrugh Livingston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Livingston of New York, was married yesterday afternoon at Oak Hill, her family's ancestral home in Linlithgo, N.Y., to Robert Coles Edmonds. He is a partner in the New York law firm of Hatfield, Brady & Taft.

title: Howard Seen No. 1 In Soccer
description: The college season is under way and everything and everyone points toward Howard University as the top soccer team in the nation.

title: House Backs New Mint
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) Harkening to arguments that American pockets and vending machines gobble up coins at an ever increasing rate, the House voted yesterday to authorize $60million for a new mint in Denver. The new facility, designed to produce more than 25 billion coins a year, would replace an existing mint with a 4.5 billion capacity.

title: 62Yard Field Goal Sets N.C.A.A. Mark
description: AMES, Iowa, Sept. 20 (AP)  Dave Lawson of the Air Force Academy set a National Collegiate Athletic Association record today when he kicked a 62yard windaided field goal in the first half of a game against Iowa State. The Air Force lost, 1712.

title: A Pride of Burrites Gathers Yet Again To Tilt With History
description: The smoking pistol was about the only piece of Burr paraphernalia missing from the Aaron Burr Association's annual meeting yesterday as about 30 Burr descendants and Burr devotees, or Burrites, assembled to discuss politics and history.

title: Stylishly conservative
description: People dress with style in New York; in Chicago they dress functionally, says Chuck Hughes, who left Chicago five years ago to pursue a career in the Madison Avenue advertising world. Now, at 29, as an account executive at Young and Rubicam, he feels that he prefers New York's stylishness, as long as it's practical (platform shoes are not practical). Although his wife. Cindy, and most of his friends consider him a conservative dresser. Hughes thinks he has become somewhat flashy; he does admit, however, that his occupation demands a tieandsuit image.

title: An Ideological Block
description: The Federal budget cannot be restored to balance until the nation's economy is restored to high employment. An Administration policy aimed at quelling inflation by keeping the economy indefinitely underemployed is a prescription for continuous stagflation, not a return to economic health.

title: Blind Learn Daily Living
description: BAY SHOREThere is threeroom apartment here in a local shopping center where about 80 Suffolk County residents meet at various times to overcome a mutual handicapblindness.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Muhammad Ali
description: I have often wished I had time to cultivate modesty, but I am too busy thinking about myself, said Edith Sitwell. In this unusual hook Wilfrid Sheed takes on the difficult job of explaining fame, which he curiously defines, in terms of his subject, as a singular lack of modesty, and the even more difficult job of rationalizing Muhammad Ali's compulsive promotion of his fame.

title: Best Seller List
description: Based on reports from more than 250 bookstores in 110 ?? throuehout the Limited States. Weeks are not necessarily consercutive.

title: Bricklin: Survival, but No Profit Yet
description: A little over a year ago, a college dropout with a history of meteoric business successes began to produce a new car, the Bricklin, in the teeth of the auto industry's worst sales slump ever.

title: Dog Show Calendar This Week
description: TodayNorthwestern Connecticut K.C. allbreed and obedience, Fair Grounds, Route 63, Goshen, Conn.; 1,583 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: CHESS
description: Alexandre Louis Deschapelles (17801847), one of the great classical French masters, held a singularly uncomplicated view of strategy, which he was not timid about expressing.

title: Birds of a feather
description: Mother Goose is an elusive old bird. Her age and her national origin remain a mystery, as do the breadth, depth and scope of works attributable to the lady. Although the first formally published hook bearing her name, Mother Goose's Melody: or, Sonnets for the Cradle by John Newbery, was published circa 1765, she's probably closer to tour hundred years old, for it is rumored that she was making her debut when Shakespeare was a lad. Certainly, she had achieved a degree of fame in the first part of the 17th century, when a quarter of the presently recorded Mother Goose rhymes were in daily use.

title: U.S.Golf Lead Is Widened
description: LIGONIER, Pa., Sept. 20Coming out in waves of strength and reserves, the United States smothered the BritishIrish golf team today in the second day of the 21st biennial Ryder Cup matches.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: New York is a happier place now that the New York City Opera has added the sunginEnglish version of Donizetti's The Daughter of the Regiment to its repertory. It is a frothy little work that, heard in English, strongly suggests Gilbert and Sullivan. But of course, since Donizetti came first, it really is Gilbert and Sullivan who suggest Donizetti.

title: Why the Huge Deficits?
description: The nation's urban problems have been neglected, and the cities' financial irresponsibility decried by an Administration that knows how to simulate fiscal responsibility but that will have run up collective budget deficits of over $200 billion in eight years. This fiscal record is mainly the result of economic mismanagement. Economic slumps have caused most of the huge deficits; these were worsened by a conservative push to reduce the tax base, on grounds that it would restrain Federal expendituresexcept, of course, military expenditures or subsidies to specially favored industries.

title: An Ailing Member Of OPEC
description: ALGIERS  The Algerian representatives at the OPEC price meeting that begins on Wednesday find themselves in a particularly difficult negotiating position.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1975

title: 4 Killed in Alabama Crash
description: GORDO, Ala., Sept. 20 (UPI) A car traveling on the wrong side of a road early today collided head on with a tractortrailer truck, killing four persons and seriously injuring another, the police said. One of the victims was an infant. The infant's mother, whose name was not known, was hospital??zed in serious condition in Birmingham. The truck driver was treated and released, the police ??.

title: A Variety of Hook Rugs to Be Displayed
description: MANHASSETSome 300 hooked rugs, wall hangings, and other objects will be exhibited for two days here this week, and demonstrations of hooking, a craft developed by American settlers in Colonial times, will be given throughout the show.

title: L. I. Hunting Starts Oct. 1
description: ALBANY  The hunting season on Long Island will open on Oct. 1, with one major changean increase in license feesand a new revised format for free hunting and fishing guides issued by the state.

title: Festival of Succoth Observed by Jews In WeekLong Rites
description: The weeklong Jewish Festival of Succoth, or Feast of the Tabernacles, began at sundown on Friday as leaders of major Jewish groups emphasized the festival's theme of thanksgiving and happiness, and the need for peace.

title: The Democratic Outlook

The professional politicians are already assessing the candidates and the issues in terms of their appeal to these two critical groups.

title: With Costs Rising, Homeowners Seek Extra Living Space Down Under
description: In easier times, they might be in the market for new homes, but with housing prices and mortgage interest rates going through the roof, more and more suburbanites are looking to the basement for extra living space.

title: GROH RESIGNS JOB, CITING PRESSURES, ON CITY CLEANUP
description: Citing intolerable pressures, Robert T. Groh tendered his resignation as the city's $39,000ayear Sanitation Commissioner yesterday, the north day of a 10day ultimatum by Mayor Beame to get the city cleaned up or resign.

title: Plan to Remove the Drift From Port Here Backed
description: A Federal plan to collect and remove drift from the water of the Port of New York received solid endorsement last week.

title: Mets Win in 11th; Yanks Victors, 41
description: With no worlds left to conquer in 1975, the New York Mets turned yesterday to the task of conquering the Philadelphia Phillies and injecting some mischief into what was left of the Eastern title race in the National League. And they did both by beating the Phillies, 97, on a twoout home run in the 11th inning by Ron Hodges, who had not hit a major league homer in a year.

title: Hysterectomy is the second most frequently performed major operation. Should it be so frequent?
description: The National Center for Health Statistics estimates that more than 690,000 women will have hysterectomies in the United States in 1975. This procedure for removal of the uterus will be the nation's second most frequently performed major operation. Only tonsils will be taken out more often. At a time when lowered birth rates and control of fertility and childbirth have vastly reduced uterine disease, almost half of all American women over 40 will be advised to have their wombs removed; 378,000 will have their ovaries and Fallopian tubes taken out. These women will pay a total of $400million in gynecologists' fees alone, and the operation will end in death for about 12,000 of them.

title: ARMY TOXIN VICTIM TOLD HE HAD COLD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The daughter of a microbiologist who died in 1951 of a rare disease he had been studying for the Army at its biological warfare laboratory at Fort Detrick, Md., recalled today that his illness was initially dismissed by Army doctors as a common cold and that, when his condition worsened, he was at first denied admission to a military hospital.

title: Screening of Psychiatric Hospital Aides Is Urged
description: TRENTONState Senator Alexander J. Menza, a legislative champion of the rights of psychiatric patients, has proposed changes in the procedures for selecting and training personnel for county and state psychiatric hospitals.

description: TodayBoulder Brook, Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, N.Y. Local, novice and children's working hunters; pleasure, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Catamarans Offer Design Challenge
description: Patrick Beatty is a mildmannered South African. But mild is not the word for the response his new sailing machine has received from his colleagues in the vanguard of catamaran design. What Beatty has done is build himself a cockpit in the sail wing, no easy trick. But in weaving together aeronautical and marine design concepts, the man in the goldrimmed glasses has created a hybrid within the innovative C Class catamarans.

title: A DesignItYourself Shop
description: BRIDGEHAIVIPTON  The name of the shop is obviously Spanish: Las Mariposas, The Butterflies. Yet, there is something vaguely Chinese restaurant about the boutique housed in a converted home in the center of this hamlet's Main Street business section. By taking a neckline from seven offered on Column A, sleeves from seven on Column B and pants or a skirt from seven on Column C a shopper, in effect, can design her own dress.

title: POLL SHOWS G.O.P. AT 35YEAR LOW
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The strength of the Republican party has reached its lowest ebb since before World War II, the Gallup Poll reported today.

title: What's Doing in ACCRA, GHANA
description: OVERVIEW  Accra, capital of the West African republic of Ghana (formerly a British colony called the Gold Coast), has the reputation of being the friendliest city in the continent's most hospitable country. Accra is unmistakably African. Africans run it, and the visitor sees Africans spending their money freely alongside foreigners in the few expensive hotels, restaurants and department stores. The city has a population of about a million and is a very lively place where everything from politics to sports is discussed loudly and with great bursts of laughter. Women wear the panye, a colorful twopiece wraparound dress with matching headtie, and they adorn themselves with gold earrings and necklaces. Men wear 12footlong cloths, which are wrapped around the body, draped over one shoulder and heldwith varying degrees of majesty with one hand. Ghana is the world's largest producer of cocoa and it mines gold and bauxite. A military government rules the country's 11 million people, but there are practically no restrictions on personal freedom, and foreign tourists, about 80 per cent of whom are black Americans, can travel about at will. There are accommodations at prices to fit every wallet. The currency is the cedi, which is stretch of beachfront.

title: BOULEZ CONQUERS EUROPE IN 23 DAYS
description: PARIS, Sept. 20Pierre Boulez and the 108 members of the New York Philharmonic brought the house down Thursday night at the Salle Pleyel here after the last notes of Stravinsky's Petrushka gave way to a full 10 minutes of wild applause and cheering.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 20 (AP)Matt Allison, a former professional baseball player, tossed four touchdown passes today as Rutgers routed Bucknell, 473, in the season opener for both teams.

description: Basketmaking, perhaps the most ancient of all handcrafts, is more than merely a means of fabricating containers by hand. Over the centuries, people have used basketry techniques to make hats, snowshoes, hunting traps, chair seats and even native huts.

Wrightman of Alvinston, Ontario. The ceremony was performed in the Ridgeview Congregational Church in White Plains by the Rev. James Christopher.

title: Case Not Quite Closed

But nobody yet knows why and how the granddaughter of William Randolph Hearst, a symbol of aggressive conservatism, turned to violent radicalism.

title: Economic Indicators
description: WEEKLY COMPARISONS

title: A poet on a painter
description: Unlike most collections of poems, this one has a named hero and an overt subject. The hero is an aging liberal, a painter called Hazard; the subject is Hazard's attempt somehow to maintain himself as one who participates in the divinity of the world. But we meet him at a bad time, When his hopes are dashed, his guard down. While the newly victorious Nixon gang is putting it together and the kid next door with her Rolling Stones on stereo is getting it together, Hazard is trying simply to keep it together. Work at his easel should help, but even that has hit a bad patchfor two years now he has been painting, in a child's palette/not the plotted landscape that holds dim/below him, but the human figure dangling safe,/ guyed to something silky, hanging there,/full of halfremembered instruction/but falling, and safe. This surrogate man in midair neither splashes down into legend like Icarus nor lands on his feet behind enemy lines. His mortal trouble is that he's safein twocar creature comforts, an enduring marriage and the restraints of his own good nature.

title: Letting the Moisture Escape
description: One of the most frequent causes of paint peeling around the outside of a house that is covered with painted wood clapboard or other wood siding is moisture vapor which gets trapped inside the hollow wall spaces behind the siding. Although this moisture sometimes gets in from the outside due to leaks or defects on the outside, it is most often the result of high indoor humidity which develops when windows are closed during cold weather while the normal routines of cooking, cleaning, washing and bathing continually add gallons of moisture to the indoor air.

title: SOVIET REPORTS A NEW VOLCANO
description: The Soviet Union has reported the birth of a new land volcano, reputedly the first such event since the birth of Paricutin in a Mexican cornfield in 1943.

title: The Scott Joplin Rag
description: On Thursday night, one of the most fascinating sagas in American musical history comes to an endor perhaps a new beginningwith the opening on Broadway of a curious and possibly highly significant work called Treemonisha. The piece can best be described as a folk opera. It was written by the ragtime master Scott Joplin, who worked on it obsessively during the years prior to World Wax I. It was sung only once during the author's lifetime at an audition walkthrough for potential backers, with Joplin himself at the piano. For more than half a century it lay dormant, unknown to all but a tiny handful of ragtime enthusiasts, and unheard even by most of them.

title: Conley Joins a Pupil in Debut Recital
description: Eugene Conley, a tenor who has not sung here since he left the Metropolitan Opera in 1956, returned to New York on Friday night to give a joint program in Alice Tully Hall with one of his pupils, Maria Powell, who was making her local debut. The reappearance of the American artist was obviously a cause for nostalgia and it brought out a large, warmly welcoming audience.

title: Some Japanese Poems About Roy Rogers
description: That classic American experience, the cowboy movie, is nothing foreign to Japanese viewers. Saturday night in Tokyo finds Hoss bellowing like a sumo wrestler who has stepped on a stray rowel. Via the unwritten but pervasive laws of cultural return (some would say comeuppance), we get judo, karate, and samurai epics. Junior bashes bricks in the playroom; Gabby Hayes cusses in Japanese as he takes some varmint's slug in the left arm for the 8,054th time.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Under a state law that went into effect March 1, 1967, injured victims of crimes or the survivors of slain victims are entitled to compensation. The maximum art injured victim may claim is $15,000 for loss of earnings. If he dies his survivors may claim up to $15,000 if there is loss of support. There is no limit on claims for medical expenses incurred as a result of a crime.

description: SCARBOROUGH, England, Sept. 20Delegates to the Liberal party conference in this pleasant seaside resort ended their annual metting today agreed on two points: They do not like the way the country is being run, and they would have a better chance of running it themselves if someone changed the election laws.

title: A doityourself economy
description: Despite the dominance of the modern industrial economy, much production as well as consumption occurs outside the cash marketplace in the home, a fact wellknown to housewives whose 16hour day would cost ten to fifteen thousand dollars yearly if purchased on the open market. But the housewife is only the most visible and animated piece of household capital, according to Scott Burns. Everytime you rent a Uhaul, brick in a patio, grow a vegetable, fix your own car, photocopy an article, join a food coop, develop film, sew a dress, avoid purchasing a convenience food, stew fruit, or raise a child, you are committing a productive act, even though these labors are not reflected in the Gross National Product.

title: PANAMA SAYS TALKS ON CANAL BOG DOWN
description: PANAMA CITY, Sept. 20 (AP)Panamanian negotiators said today that talks on turning the Panama Canal over to Panama had bogged down over United States insistence on the right to guard the waterway indefinitely. There was no immediate comment from the United States.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Every large city has a number of flourishing choral societiesNew York alone boasts over two dozen professional and amateur groups but by and large they draw on a limited repertory of standard favorites by Bach, Beethoven, Handel, Haydn and Mozart. This is a shame because there is a wealth of music for soloists and chorus from the 18th and 19th centuriesBrahms, Schumann, Schubert and Mendelssohn all wrote great quantities of itthat one rarely hears, even on records. The following recent disks do include a few offbeat items mixed in with new versions of the perennials, which only emphasizes how much unfamiliar territory is left to be discovered.

title: Endpaper
description: They are the heroes of the suburban age, those fearless men and women who ply the great railroads twice each day to wrest their sustenance from a heartless city. On the Long Island, the Penn Central, the Jersey Central, they ride through hardship and adversity, and their shared experience is the stuff of legend. Here are a few of their stories and anecdotes, every one of which has been attested to by a commuting observer I believe to be completely credible, and mightily courageous as well.

title: Rare September Days
description: Lowell wrote about the rarity of June days, and Holmes the elder wrote of chill September. Neither of them seems to have noticed that some of the rarest days of the year come in September, days when it is comfortably cool but pulsing with life.

title: ISRAEL CONFIDENT ON FUEL SUPPLIES
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 18With the impending return of the captured Abu Rudeis petroleum fields to Egypt, Israel is reverting to her pre1967 energy situation, that is, total dependence on foreign supplies. Israel possesses no sources of energy.

title: Following a dream
description: Since the great navigators of the middle and later 18th century returned from their %oyages of discovery in the Pacific with alluring accounts of paradise, the fabled islands of the South Seas have beck oned dreamers from half a world away. Their advent in the South Pacific created a new school of romantic literature that continues to grow with books like Thor Heyerdahl's latest memoir, FatuHiva.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 33yearold Manhattan physician was shot by a gunman when he answered a knock on the door of his former wife's home in New Hyde Park, L. I., the Nassau County police reported. They said the physician, Dr. Charles Malone of 250 East 39th Street, was visiting his 31yearold exwife, Susan, when he went to the rear door to answer a knock at about 11:40 P.M. As he started to open the door, the gunman fired a shot through the door, striking him in the left shoulder. The physician tried to close the door but the assailant forced it open and shot him again in the right leg. The gunman fled on foot.

title: Making Oil Billions Now Takes a Little More Ingenuity
description: WASHINGTONBy the end of this month, the seven sisters will have been stripped of their seventh veil. It was Enrico Mattel, the maverick Italian oilman, who first called the big international oil companies sisters, out of envy at their discretely coordinated control of the world's supplies. And today, their names are still household words in almost every country: Exxon, Mobil, Shell, Texaco, BP, Socal and Gulf.

description: The Ford Administration and the Federal Reserve Board at one in their commitment to hyperconservative economic policiesblame the rise in interest rates on inflation and the fear of inflation. They have vainly sought to cure inflation and inflationary expectations by cutting social outlays in the Federal budget, keeping the money supply growing slowly, and trusting in free markets to cure all other problems.

title: TV VIEW
description: It is not as if ABC has a stranglehold on worstofseason citations for new series. A year ago, NBC came out on top with Sierra, featuring a pretty collection of pouting young women and men who wanted to be park rangers when they grew up. Earlier this year, CBS ventured forth with Khan!, about an AsianAmerican private investigator whose immovable ways make Charlie Chan seem recklessly vivacious. No, ABC is not alone, but this season the network appears determined to look that way.

title: DEPTH OF TENSION OVER SINAI ACCORD TROUBLING EGYPT
description: CAIRO, Sept. 20 7 Tension between Egypt and her Arab critics over the new disengagement agreement with Israel has lasted longer and continues to run deeper than Egyptian officials had expected.

title: Red Smith
description: There were several major differences between the 1974 and 1975 strikes by players in the National Football League, and one aspect that was unchanged. In neither case was money a prime factor.

title: Nation's Founding Topic of Exhibits
description: NEWARKExhibitions relating to the founding of the United States are planned for the next eight years by the New Jersey Historical Society.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: NOW! Read 1,000 Pages of Institutional Research in 30 Minutes!

title: Chilean Junta Resisting Critics
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 16Two years after the bloody coup. that toppled the Marxist coalition Government of President Salvador Allende Gessens, the military junta that governs Chile has developed a siege mentality against critics of its harsh programs for economic recovery and of its continuing violations of human rights.

title: The Nation
description: New Hampshire, Taking Its Time, Elects Democrat

title: American Artists Group Salutes the Bicentennial in Concert
description: American music will be with us with a vengeance for a while, as this country celebrates its Bicentennial. The vengeance is deserved, however, because our native compositions have so often taken second place in our cultural life. A new organization out to make audible the riches of our musical heritage is American Performing Artists, Inc., which sponsored its first concert on Thursday night in Alice Tully Hall.

title: Despite Some Doubts, Congressional Approval Seems Assured
description: WASHINGTONSecretary of State Kissinger's carefully nurtured Sinai disengagement pact between Egypt and Israel will gain Congressional approval in the coming weeks, but only after some secondguessing and a lot of hard questions. The nation had a chance to sense the flavor of the debate going on between Congress and State Department officials: Former Under Secretary of State George Ball voiced the concerns of Congressional critics in a Newsweek article, and Mr. Kissinger responded pointbypoint with a speech in Cincinnati.

title: Residential Areas Fight Institutional Incursions
description: The movement of drug rehabilitation centers, sexcounseling centers, halfway houses and other such miniinstitutions into some of the city's prime residential areas is producing increasingly bitter resistance among their new neighbors.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Desert gold. It began, as many publisher's success stories do, with a quandary. The manuscript, by a Ph.D. candidate, was brought to the University of California Press by the author's mentor. Its significance as a scholarly contribution was attested to by a half dozen leading anthropologists. Yet the style in which it was written was so much like fiction, its lack of conventional scholarly apparatus so conspicuous, the university pressmen wondered whether it belonged on their list. After much soulsearching, they ventured a 2,000copy first printing in June, 1968.

title: The Nation
description: ATLANTA  One of the key elements in Richard Nixon's capture of the Presidency in 1968 was his Southern strategy.

title: NonInsulator
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the federally supported independent agency that sets highlevel policy and funnels funds to the nation's public radio and TV stations, is confronted by another crisis not of its own making. The nomination of Joseph Coors to the Corporation's board has detonated new charges of political and programing intrusion by officials In Washington.

title: 77Yard Dash Sparks Kansas to 1410 Victory
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 20 (AP)Eric Franklin's 77yard, run helped Kansas defeat Kentucky, 1410, today.

title: Campaigning for 80 Assembly Seats Is Beginning in Earnest
description: TRENTONWith legislative approval of Governor Byrne's $923million bond issue now complete, Democrats and Republicans began campaigning in earnest this weekend for the 80 Assembly seats to be contested in the November election.

title: China Watch: Clear as a Cloud
description: HONG KONGThe Chinese press recently denounced a popular 14th century novel on peasant heroes, and all signs indicated that Peking was once again gearing up for that quintessentially Chinese phenomenon, a new ideological campaign.

title: Packaged Greece: The Acrimonious Odyssey of Bus Five
description: EPICTETUS would have known how to weather the vicissitudes of my Golden Greece package tour. How do we act in a voyage? the Stoic philosopher asks. We choose the pilot, the sailors, the hour. Afterwards comes a storm. What have I to care for? [Only to] submit to being drowned without fear, without clamor or accusing of God....

title: Unveilings
description: CHASEAdrienne. Unveiling In the loving memory of Adrienne Chase on Sunday, Sept. 21 at 1 P.M. at Mt. Hope Cemetery, HastingsontheHudson, Westchester. Please enter at Jackson Ave. entrance at Administration Bidg. (There will be no postponement.)

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the The New York Times last Sunday said a Gallup Poll indicated President Ford would lead Senator Hubert H. Humphrey by 50 to 42 per cent if the two faced each other now in a Presidential election. The figures should have been 52 to 40 per cent.

title: Weddings
description: BakwinWinchester

title: Schoolmaster and patriot
description: Of all the major figures of the early Republic, Noah Webster has perhaps retained the weakest hold on the modern imagination. We think of him todayif we think of him at allas the author of the remarkable dictionary of 1828 which defined almost 70,000 words and promoted spellings that to this day distinguish an American from a Briton (honor not honour, theater not theatre, traveling not travelling).

title: Art Councils in Uphill Fight
description: NORTH BERGEN  Although the State Council on the Arts is flourishing because of the star attractions that it helps to sponsor, the same thing cannot be said for the local councils.

title: New African Art Shown in Newark
description: NEWARK The Newark Museum has revamped its Gallery of African Art to include many pieces formerly not on view and others recently acquired. As now constituted, the gallery is designed to present a clearer picture of the role that African art plays in the life of communities there.

title: Mine Blast in Australia
description: MOURA, Australia, Sept. 20 (AP) Thirteen miners were missing and feared dead today after an explosion and a fire in a coal mine here We know 13 are dead but little more than ?? at this stage a spokesman for the Queensland Department of Mines said.

title: The World
description: It appears that the Sinai agreement between Israel and Egypt will take effect soon, but somewhat later than had been hoped. Israeli troops are clearing minefields and the Congress seems ready to approve the presence of 200 American technicians in the desert to monitor the ceasefire. But there were several events last week that showed how difficult it will be to achieve a fullfledged peace in the Middle East.

title: Mrs. Smith Says G.O.P. Will Ignore Nixon in '76
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich. Sept. 20 (AP)The chairman of the Republican National Committee said today she expected the party to ignore former President Richard M. Nixon during election campaigns next year.

title: Casual suits him
description: Bill Stratford never wears dungarees. But then he never wears ties, either.

title: FolkArt Exhibition Planned in Lincroft
description: LINCROFTWhat is described as a major exhibition of American folk art will open at the Monmouth Museum on Sept. 30. The show, a joint production of the Monmouth County Historical Association and the Monmouth Museum, has been underwritten by a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: A Secret History
description: WASHINGTONIn the very first series of experiments with hallucinogenic drugs that the United States army sponsored in the early nineteen fifties a man died. Not much later a Central Intelligence Agency experiment with LSD led to another death.

title: When Steelers and Whizzer Were Young
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers. Super Bowl winners! Marvelous! After 41 years of frustration and futility, unencumbered by a league championship, the Steelers won the big one and go into the new season as kings of the hill. The mind boggles, particularly the mind of a man in middle age who grew up in western Pennsylvania.

title: Arts Council Head Learning Caution
description: If there is one thing that Joan K. Davidson has learned after three months on the job as chairman of the State Council on the Arts, it is to appreciate the pressures that go with having $34.1million to distribute among 1,700 needy organizations who asked for $90million this year.

title: Greetings
description: Falk

title: The Trouble With Papp
description: With the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center approaching its third season under the direction of Joseph Papp, and with Mr. Papp ready to embark on a new theatrical course at the Beaumont, it seems a good time to reassess his accomplishments and aspirations, and the thinking behind them. Earlier this year, in response to evident and growing audience dissatisfaction with the kind of plays he had been presenting at Lincoln Center  mainly contemporary works by playwrights nurtured at his Off Broadway Public Theater and often ??otably raw in language and subject matterMr. Papp announced a radical change of policy. Henceforth, he said, the emphasis at the Beaumont would be on classical plays featuring guest stars of international stature; new plays would continue to be staged at his Public Theater and elsewhere. The elsewhere, it later developed, was the Booth Theater on Broadway, where Mr. Papp is about to launch a season of plays by five of his favorite young playwrights.

title: The Chief Awards at Darien Dog Show
description: VARIETY GROUPS

title: American League
description: New York 4, Cleveland 1.

title: STEUBEN PARADE DRAWS THOUSANDS
description: Scores of marching bands playing Bavarian music, twirlers wearing smocked dresses and flowered wreaths and colorful floats from various parts of West Germany inched slowly up Fifth Avenue yesterday for the 18th annual Steuben Day parade.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Financing School Sports
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DANCE VIEW
description: LONDON Twentyfive years is no great length of time in the affairs of men, but it happens to be quite a period in the history of indigenous ballet in the Englishspeaking world. London Festival Ballet, which this year is celebrating its silver jubilee is oddly enough, one of the oldest established companies in the AngloAmerican dance world, and, with its 75 or so dancers, it is also one of the largest. It was also, until 10 years ago, probably the last major ballet company anywhere to be operated with the idea of making a profit rather than a loss. Nowadays, like every other major theatrical institution in Britain and probably the rest of the world, it is a deficit operation kept alive by public fundingchiefly, in Festival Ballet's case, from the Greater London Council, the city's governing body, and the Arts Council of Great Britain.

title: Klein Budget for '76 Keeps 1975 in Mind
description: HAPPAUGE  The $532million standstill budget that John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, presented here last week was both his blueprint for governmental operations in 1976 and his platform for reelection this year.

title: Problems May Bring Them Together
description: The struggle in the New York State Legislature over emergency aid to New York City highlighted not only a deepseated hostility toward the city but also the historic division of the state into three, often competing parts: New York City, upstate and the suburbs.

title: Article 15  No Title
REPORT ON MEN'S WEAR
description: For the first time in several seasons, the word fashion  this fall a synonym for dressy elegance  is being heard in the men'swear industry. Manufacturers have rid themselves of their dismay over the decline in sales of tailored clothing brought on by men's acceptance of relaxed dress rules. The clothing makers are fighting back, and what they're armed with can be summed up in that one word, fashion.

title: Radio
description: The Week's Concerts

title: Shop Talk
description: FAR HILLSThe rusticated, shingled buildings of the Country Mall, formerly used by a school, were attractively and well designed. Now 14 offices and shops around a courtyard, the atmosphere is that of a small English hamlet coupled with the colonial ambiance that everyone seems to be striving for this year.

title: The look of your labor
description: In the third act of Die Meistersinger, when the Nuremberg cobblers, tailors and bakers hold their annual picnic on that big meadow, they not only sing about the virtues of their callings but parade the uniforms that make them easily readable as cobblers, tailors and bakers. The scene from Wagner is a stylized representation of 16thcentury life in Germany, a time and place when a worker's guild affiliation could be spotted the moment he set foot out of his lateGothic front door.

title: OnceReadable Cellulose, Such as Newspapers, Is Being Turned Into Sugar
description: America is in no way so bountiful, and in no way prodigal, as in her wastes. Products are manufactured toward a single end, residues often ignored or sewered. Says E. R. Pariser, Senior Research Scientist in the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Department of Nutrition and Food Science, materials are considered waste simply because they are not being utilized. He describes waste matter as an anthropocentric concept; waste is matter out of place. . . . One of the important general attributes of life is that it is wasteproducingparticularly American industrial life.

title: Scores of Detectives Seek Clues In Forest Hills Double Murder
description: Scores of detectives roamed Forest Hills, Queens, yesterdayinterviewing shopkeepers and their employes in a search for clues in Thursday's double murder in Forest Hills Gardens.

title: Elisabeth LaMotte and Jon Roy to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis Howell LaMotte 3d of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Elisabeth Marsden LaMotte, to Jon Joseph Roy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur James Roy of Millbrook. N.Y.

Article 8  No Title
description: U.S. OPTION INTERNATIONAL

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the The New York Times last Sunday said a Gallup Poll indicated President Ford would lead Senator Hubert H. Humphrey by 50 to 42 per cent if the two faced cacti other now in a Presidential election. The figures should have been 52 to 40 per cent.

title: New & Novel
description: The Enchanters

title: Auction Will Aid Homemaker Unit
description: OLDWICK  The Visiting Homemaker Service of Hunterdon County will hold a benefit auction next Saturday at the Oldwick Community Center. The sale will begin at 10:30 A.M.

title: Binny, a Sealyham, Is Judged Best of 1,932 at Ox Ridge
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 20 Chalk up No. 30 for the Sealyham terrier, Ch. Dersade Bobby's Girl.

title: Starr's Kick Gives Darien a 97 Victory
Book Ends
description: Comics. Charlie Brown and the rest of the Peanuts gang have without a doubt sold more paperback collections of their adventures than any other comicstrip charactersover 100million copies is the current claim. Hardcover collections are another matter. There was a collection of Peanuts strips published four or five years ago by Holt, Rinehart & Winston, and come October 2which by no chance whatsoever is 25 years to the day from the first appearance of Peanuts in the papers Holt will bring out the most ambitious hardcover Peanuts yet. This is a coffee table book called Peanuts Jubilee, and will consist of the best Peanuts strips over the years as selected by their progenitor, Charles Schultz. As it turned out, though, the book is more than a collection, for it also contains Mr. Schultz's autobiography. Originally he was supposed to write only some caption material but, according to Holt publicity director John Taylor, once he got started, he couldn't stop. Known as an intensely private man, Mr. Schultz nonetheless wrote a 20,000word account of his life and career and he would have written 100,000 words, if they had let him, Mr. Taylor said. Also included in the book are various SchultzPeanuts memorabilia; such as his early commercial, art, pages from a World War II sketchbook and other drawings. Holt obviously expects Peanuts fans to sit up and take notice; the first printing is 100.000 copieshigh for a $35 book ($29.95 until Dec. 31).

title: Hobart 55. Roch. Tech 37
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 20 (AP) Jeff Thon, the quarterback, was one of three Hobart runners to gain more than 100 yards today in a 55.37 college football victory over Rochester Tech.

title: Literal approach
description: ACROSS

title: U.N. Trade Group Gets a Larger Role
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20The favorite economic forum of the world's poorer countries, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, has been accorded a significant share in efforts to improve the economic lot of third world countries.

title: Power Out in Nashville Storm
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 20 (UPI)  Strong winds and slashing rains knocked out power in about 10,000 homes last night, blew out a large window in a 24thfloor hotel rooftop restaurant and caused about 40 traffic accidents.

title: President to Visit Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20An early visit by the Portugese President, Gen. Francisco da Costa Gomes, to the Soviet Union has been quietly arranged, according to informed Western European diplomatic sources.

title: Beirut Strife Eases Under New Truce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20Another ceasefire was proclaimed tonight in Beirut after the Foreign Minister of Syria, Abdel Halim Khaddam, had met with a broad spectrum of political and religious leaders.

title: Alabama Romps, 560, On 35Point First Half
description: TUSCALOOSA, Sept. 20 (AP)Gus White and Woodrow Lowe led a reckless Alabama defense that thwarted Clemson tonight as the Crimson Tide rolled to a 560 football victory.

title: L. I. Cyclists Commandeer A Vacant 20 Acre Tract
description: COMMACKFor at least three years  although nobody seemed to know for exactly how longdozens of motorcyclists have been converging on a 20acre vacant tract here to test their skills against its treacherously hilled and rutted terrain.

title: Factory Jobs for the Disabled
description: WAYNEIt is lunchtime on a sloping green lawn off Woodbridge Terrace here, and the 32 workers laugh and joke with each other before returning to their jobs.

title: Plea for Needy Set In East Brunswick
description: EAST BRUNSWICKThe township's annual Crop Walk, an appeal to fight world hunger, will take place on Oct. 26. Last year, 400 members of the community walked 10 miles, raising more than $12.000.

title: State Asked to Make Part of St. Albans Naval Site a Park
description: A relatively local Issuewhether part of the site of a sprawling Veterans Administration hospital in Queens should be obtained from the Federal Government and transformed into a parkappears to have set the stage for a controversy of far broader scope affecting hundreds of communities throughout the state.

title: Reevaluation of City Projects Requested
description: John E. Zuccotti, chairman of the City Planning Commission, directed the heads of all city agencies yesterday to rejustify all capital projects that have not yet moved to the construction stage.

title: Israel in Warning to Syria
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 20 (AP)Israel today issued a veiled warning to Syria not to intervene in Lebanon's bloody civil war.

title: Mary Weller Has Nuptials
description: Mary Calvert Weller and Didier Marcel Brodbeck were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. William Sydnor in Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va. The bride is a secretarial assistant to the president of Ted Bates International in Paris, where her husband is an account supervisor with Ted Bates. S.A.

title: Miss Sundman Wed to R. E. Angevine
description: Maureen Anne Sundman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Sundman of North Caldwell, N.J., was married there yesterday afternoon to Robert Edmund Angevine, son of Harry W. Angevine of Glen Ridge, N.J., and the late Margaret B. Angevine. The ?? Thomas E. Davis performed the ceremony in Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church.

title: Becoming clothesconscious
description: I have a oneseasonold sheepskin coat from Abercombie's that is the love of my limited sartorial life. If I gained five pounds, it would fit me perfectly. I also have seven pairs of sneakers and one pair of terrific blue kangarooskin Onitsuka track shoes, which helped their original owner (not me, alas) finish sixth in the 1968 Olympic decathlon. I would wear nothing but those track shoes and my sheepskin coat, if I didn't think that such an ensemble would cause too much comment at work.

title: Budget Reform: The Quiet Revolution on Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  Sometimes it is the quiet things, slipping by almost unnoticed at the start, that change the power structure of this noisy city more than anything else. The new Senate and House Budget Committees are the latest evidence of the point.

title: Invading Canada Again: A Motorized March and a Mock Battle
description: CANADA is about to be invaded. American forces are marshaling in New York and Maine for a twopronged attack that will be launched before the month is out. Sweeping through New England, they will join forces for a frontal assault on the city of Quebec.

title: Winnies: Year of the woman
description: It's prizegiving time on Seventh Avenue. On Wednesday night, the Coty American Fashion Critics Awards will be presented. A slew of special awards have been announced  to Calvin Klein, to Geoffrey Beene, to a group fur designers, to men'swear designers  but the excitement centers on Winnie, fashion's equivalent of the Oscar. Secret ballots have gone out reporters and editors across the country, and the results will be announced during a show at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: Congress Shows Its Colors
description: WASHINGTON  The Democratic Congress has been frustrated this year by its inability to override most of President Ford's vetoes and by its failure to put together a workable energy program. But in its effort to reestablish itself as an equal branch of government in the fields of foreign and national security affairs, Congress has done better than might have been expected.

title: The Election Watchdogs Are Being Watched
description: Just after he had been named to the new Federal Election Commission in March, Neil Staebler, a former Michigan Democratic Congressman, explained how he planned to approach his task as one of the six overseers of the campaign finance law.

title: E. G. Bewkes 3d, Belinda Bowling Marry in Darien
description: Belinda Ann Bowling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Chandler Bowling of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Eugene Garrett Bewkes 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bewkes Jr., also of Darien.

title: TV VIEW
description: At a screening the other afternoon at NBC, the TV critic for a local newspaper fell asleep in the middle of The Invisible Man. It was the seventh program he had seen that day, the seventh time he had hunched over a notepad in a dark room watching little people run around inside a box. He was a grownup of intelligence and wit, neither which was needed to appreciate The Invisible Man.

title: Banks Driven to Less Advantageous Financing
description: Faced with a thoroughly negative investor view of their common stocks, the nation's big banks have begun to show a willingness to be both innovative and openhanded in their efforts to round up new capital.

title: POLICE IN NASSAU STAGE JOB ACTION
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 20Nassau County police officers, who have been working without a contract since January, began a job action today as some 120 dayshift men out of a total force of 3,500 called in sick.

title: Something New in Life For BangkokStrikes
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 20Strikes are becoming part of the fraying fabric of life in Bangkok.

title: Ford Says He Would Welcome Primary Competition by Reagan
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Sept. 20President Ford said today that he welcomed competition from former Gov. Ronald Reagan for the Republican Presidential nomination. He said competition was healthy for the party and expressed confidence he would win.

title: Diana Pettus Has Nuptials
description: Diana Brewster Pettus of New York was married yesterday morning to James Mott Clark Jr. of New York and Water Mill, L.I., a partner in the New York architectural firm of Rosenfeld/ Harvey/Morse. The Rev. John L. Felmuth, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony on the beach in Water Mill.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: The following article is excerpted from a commentary by Professor Herbert Stein of the University of Virginiaa former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Adviserson the proposal for national economic planning introduced this spring in Congress (S1795). Mr. Stein's paper is being published by the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research in Washington.

title: Schoolgirl Program Hit by Cuts
description: Last hired, first fired, a popular slogan among minorities in describing the employment situation, can also be applied indirectly to girls' athletics in the New York City public school system. After a long fight to obtain intramural sports for girls, the program was among the first to be abolished in the city's 40 per cent budget cuts of schools' athletic programs.

title: WhiteCollar Jobs Seen in L.I. Future
description: Right now job openings are overshadowed by job losses in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. But when the econmoy of the area begins expanding at a normal rate its job openings are expected to average 64,000 a year, predominantly of white collar jobs.

title: Job Plan Reduces City Welfare Roles
description: Last October, a group of people receiving public welfare assistance were enrolled in a program at the South Shore Division of Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center, Far Rockaway, that was aimed at training them for hospital jobs.

title: NATO IS PRESSING JOINT OPERATIONS
description: RAMSTEIN, West Germany,  Despite major political problems and continuing squeezes in military budgets, the North Atlantic alliance has begun to improve its ability to fight a conventional war in central Europe.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: You'll find top jobs offered in the CAREER MARKETPLACE columns in the Business/Finance Pages of The New York Times every Tuesday.

title: Elmhurst Dairy Seeking to Have Surrounding Land Condemned for Expansion
description: Efforts by the Elmhurst Dairy, the largest milk processor in the city, to acquire additional space for its plant in the South Jamaica section of Queens has led to a bitter confrontation with owners of small businesses who say they are being squeezed out by their large corporate neighbor.

title: Opposition Mounts Over Watchung Preserve Road
description: SUMMIT  Opposition is continuing to mount against plans for closing a fivemile gap in Interstate 78 that would breach or trespass on the 1,811 green and wooded acres of the Watchung Reservation.

title: Theater: Revelations From London
description: LONDON  The theater should be a place of revelations; those revelations may be surprising, for such is usually their nature, but the surprise achieved, they must also be satisfying. Two plays in London demonstrate how such revelations may and may not be encompassed. The first is a very somber narrative about a Victorian family, A Family and a Fortune, taken from an Ivy ComptonBurnett novel and starring Alec Guinness and Margaret Leighton. This offering at the Apollo Theater is very hard going indeed.

title: U.C.L.A. Defeats Tennessee. 3428
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (AP)  Wendell Tyler and Wally Henry broke loose for long touchdown runs and John Sciarra directed three scoring drives today as the University of California, Los Angeles, beat 10thranked Tennessee, 3428.

title: Susan's Girl Wins Beldame
description: Susan's Girl, the millionaire 6yearold daughter of Quadrangle, won the 37th edition of the Beldame Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. Fred W. Hooper's mare outlasted Victor Zamboria's Tizna to win the $113,300 contest at 1 miles by a neck.

title: CABINET IN LISBON FACES PROBLEMS
description: LISBON, Sept. 20  A new Portuguese cabinet, sworn in last night, began today to dig its way into a mountain of political, economic and social problems that had become aggravated by more than two months of nearparalysis in running the country.

title: Possible Link to Blacks Killing Investigated in Dayton Slaying
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 20 The authorities here are looking into whether a suspect in the killing yesterday of Dr. Charles A. Glatt, a desegregation planner, may have been the same man sought in the slaying of at least six blacks There in the last four years.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Edited by ANN BARRY

title: Montauk Lab to the Rescue
description: MONTAUKStrangelooking flotational devices marked with the letters NYOSL are a familiar sight to local boatmen here. The devices usually indicate that a scientific study is in progress by the New York Ocean Science Laboratory.

title: Fall Foliage Time: Inns of Vermont...
description: THE weak trees, as the natives call them, are already ablaze, and soon all the hills and valleys of Vermont will offer visitors their annual tableau: Tiny white villages adrift in a sea of crimson, orange, yellow leaves. To my mind, nowhere else in autumn do the works of man and nature exist in more perfect harmony.

title: Anne Mountcastle Is Bride in Baltimore
description: Anne Clayton Mountcastle, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Vernon Benjamin Mountcastle Jr. of Sparks, Md., was married yesterday afternoon to John Seaman Bainbridge Jr., son of Mrs. Garrett Bainbridge of Baltimore and Mr. Bainbridge of Bedford Hills, N.Y.

title: Michigan Tied by Stanford
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 20 (AP)  Mike Langford kicked a 33yard field goal with 9 seconds remaining today to give underdog Stanford to a 1919 college football tie with secondranked Michigan.

title: Dance: Hauser Troupe
description: Everything that the Nancy Hauser Dance Company does reflects professional polish, and yet the company's first concert in New York turned out to he warm rather than piping hot. The company was generally good, the technical support superb and Miss Flauser's choreography intelligently shaped. But there was a feeling of models too faithfully followed rather than creative freshness. The group made its appearance at Hunter College Playhouse on Friday evening to open Hunter's fall dance season.

title: Orioles Win in 9th and Close Within 3 Games of Red Sox
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 (AP) Paul Blair rapped a threerun homer in the seventh inning and hit a gamewinning double in the ninth tonight to lift Baltimore to a 54 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers and move the Orioles 3 games behind Boston in the American League Eastern Division.

title: Events Today
description: Flea Market: Proceeds to benefit the Staten Island Historical Society, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Richmondtown restoration parking lot, to the rear of the Court House, Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown, S.I.

title: Toe ShoesThe Satin Thorns Under Every Ballerina's Feet
description: Backstage, in the eerie preperformance halflight, fragilelooking ballerinas are committing acts of violence. Grasping a new toe slipper by its soft heel, one repeatedly wallops the hard boxthe front part of the shoe that will support her as she whirls or balances on points  one, two, three times, with all her considerable strength, against the brick wall. Another moves to a nearby door, opens it, inserts the front of the shoe in the door jamb and viciously slams the door shut. These dancers are simply using time  honored methods to break in the shoeswhat many call these bloody... shoesthat will carry them through the evening's performance of Swan Lake or Serenade.

title: Major Museum Shows Dominate The New Season
description: As is usual these past few years, a season of trendless diversity awaits us. The most exotic event will undoubtedly be the opening of the new Islamic galleries at the Metropolitan Museum on Oct. 4an opulent, Arabian Nights installation of sumptuous carpets, jewelry, metalwork, pottery and glass from the farflung world of Islam. The Met's increasing recognition of this material, hitherto peripheral to its fix on the art of the Western world, has been abetted by several factors: increasing public and scholarly interest in Islamic culture, the museum's thrust toward the decorative arts under the direction of medicvalist Thomas Hoving, andnot leasta $500,000 installation gift from the museum's president emeritus, Arthur A. Houghton Jr.

title: Transit Car Testing Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 20 (AP) The National Transportation Safety Board urged yesterday that steps he taken to make certain that all rapid transit cars have adequate emergency braking systems. The recommendation is a result of testing, done by the hoard after three Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority trains ?? ?? on Aug. ??

title: Tennis Revisited: Second Looks at Women's Tour, Forest Hills and Nail Polish
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tanner And Ashe In Final
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20Arthur Ashe and Roscoe Tanner disposed of their semifinal opponents today and will meet tomorrow in the final of the $100,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis competition.

title: Kissinger Rebuts Pentagon Over Missiles for Israelis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Secretary of State Kissinger, apparently annoyed by Pentagon criticism, said today that he wanted to put in perspective the American military relationship with Israel.

title: 161 Shot Wins At Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., Sept. 20 (AP)Jane Levien's Michael's Bullet, a 161 outsider, rallied from fourth place coming out of the turn and won the $25,000 King Neptune Stakes today at Monmouth Park by threequarters of a length over Whatsyourpleasure.

title: Georgia Tech 38, Miami (Fla.) 23
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 20 (AP)  Danny Myers, a quarterback, scored three touchdowns and passed for another today as Georgia Tech triumphed, 3823, over Miami of Florida.

title: The Region
description: New York City last week experienced the luxury of dealing with its financial crisis without an immediate deadline requiring a great deal of money in a hurry. It is not yet clear whether that was a rewarding experience.

title: DEMOCRATS CLEAR 31 FOR JUDGES' RACES
description: A Democratic judicial screening committee yesterday recommended 31 candidates as qualified for party nominations for nine vacancies in State Supreme Court in the First Judicial District (Manhattan and the Bronx).

title: Attica Prosecution Seems to Be Slowly Running Out of Steam
description: Last fall, some prosecution and defense lawyers were grimly predicting that it might take until the end of the decade to unsnarl the legal complexities growing out of the 1971 prison uprising at Attica.

title: Business Index Falls
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity fell to 371.3 from 390.3 a week earlier. A year ago it was 405.1.

title: Pop Notes: Get Set for the Superstars of Tomorrow
description: At the beginning of each new fall season, the pop recording industry not only releases a batch of disks by bestselling artists but also deluges the market with recordings made by newcomers, many of whom are automatically labeled superstars of tomorrow. With luck, a few of these manufactured superstars of tomorrow may compensate for those established artists who each year either fail to produce new albums or who release disks that result in disappointing sales.

title: Greeley Beats Gorton, 190, For Ninth Straight Triumph
Hope S. Lloyd Becomes Bride
description: Hope Starr Lloyd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Lloyd of Chestnut Hill, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to L. Randall Yates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Thomas Yates of New York and Islip, L. I.

title: Bogota, to Combat Guerrillas, Promotes Rural Reform Through Cooperatives
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 17 To combat the spread of Communist guerrilla movements, President Alfonso Lopez Michelsen says his Government will continue to promote agrarian reform through land distribution and the formation of peasant cooperatives. He also says that land distribution by itself is no panacea for the needy peasants.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: OPTIONS

title: Rate Rise For Water Sought By Jamaica
description: ALBANYThe Public Service Commission will open a series of public hearings Tuesday to determine whether or not to grant a 23 per cent rate increase to the Jamaica Water Supply Company.

title: The Morality Of Consent
description: This short but provocative volume, completed just one week before Alexander Bickel's death, is a fitting testimony to the author's extraordinary, though tragically brief, career as a constitutional scholar, lawyer and teacher. In just a hundred and a half literate pages, we are treated to vintage Bickel insight into every major political issue of the decade, from the civil rights movement, to the Warren Court, through the frenetic university upheavals, andinevitablyto Watergate.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: TODAY'S GAMES

title: Rosalind Franklin and DNA
description: By Anne Sayre. 224 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $8.95;

title: Special to Ply Lehigh Route
description: SOUTH PLAINFIELDThe huffing and puffing of two steam locomotives will echo throughout Central Jersey on Oct. 25, when a special 15coach train carrying some 800 passengers will make a round trip here from Bethlehem, Pa.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I cleaned every object made of bronze or brass in my home (antique candelabra, lamps, etc.) with a solution of lemon juice and salt, rubbing with steel wool. When finished everything looked shiny and clean, but after several weeks everything is now a dull and moldy green color. Can you please help?Mrs. G. W., Putnam Valley, N. Y.

title: Letters
description: Switching seats

title: States Slash Inspections On Job Safety
description: On the night of Aug. 29, water cascaded into a 600footlong sewer tunnel being completed at Niagara Falls, N.Y., filling it and drowning five construction workers. The next morning three compliance officers of the FederaI Occupational Safety and Health Agency arrived at the scene to conduct an investigation. It is still going on.

title: A speculative fiction
description: Everyone predicts the future, but no one lives in itwith the possible exception of those highly imaginative and, at times, alarmingly perceptive writers who write what is called science fiction. So categorized, they may appeal to a presumably limited audience but, at the same time, they possess an enviable freedom: where mainstream writers are committed to the real world or the historical past, and can selfconsciously bend this reality into fanciful contortions (i.e., surrealism, of either the hard or softheaded variety), the writer of science fiction freely and without coyness creates a world of his own, populates it as he likes, and even gives himself the freedom to write in a matteroffact style. The result, as in Barry Malzberg's Guernica Night, can be quite powerful indeed.

title: Concert Tour Set for Naldi
