description: NORTH PLAINFIELDBack in 1956, when Ronald Naldi was a student at Bound Brook High School and sang the tenor lead in H.M.S. Pinafore, he came to two conclusions: He would probably marry his leading lady, Carlene Cristman, and that the life of an opera singer was undoubtedly for him.

title: Miss Edens Is Bride of Jay Wilson
description: Stephanie Talbert Edens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Luther Edens Jr. of Winnetka, Ill., and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Jay MacLean Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Page Wilson of Brooklandville, Md.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I am the shamed owner of a gas guzzler. It amuses some people, angers others, makes most of my acquaintances feel superior and embarrasses my friends, who feel socially diminished by being seen in company with a person who still drives a gas guzzler.

title: 2,500 Want Pacific Isle Given Back
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 A judge of Britain's High Court mill set out soon on a 10,000mile journey to settle a complaint by 2,500 people that the remote Pacific island where they once lived has been ravaged by the governments of Britain, Australia and New Zealand.

title: Cooley's Anemia Aid
description: Twentymile walkathons in Brooklyn and Nassau and Suffolk Counties will he held on Oct. 5 to raise funds for the Colley's Anemia Blood and Research Foundation for Children. For more information, contact Al Addessi at (212) 9468233 in Brooklyn, Susan Paradiso at (516) CH 86770 in Nassau and Peter Mulieri at (516) 7517773 in Suffolk.

title: DEMOCRATS SPLIT ON DELEGATE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The Democratic National Committee's Compliance Review Commission today rejected a challenge brought by New York's New Democratic Coalition against the state party leaders' plan to select delegates to the National Convention.

title: Posen's Two Paintings a Year Are Well Worth Waiting For
description: For anyone interested in the current realistic redirection of American Art, the prospect of seeing two new paintings by Stephen Posen in a forthcoming group show at the O.K. Harris Gallery in SoHo should be assurance that the movement is still valid in spite of the abuses to which it has been subjected.

title: Shows Open
description: Shows that are not affected by the strike:

title: Wood, Field & Stream: On Bass
description: CROTON RESERVOIR, N. Y. For decades the big black bass of the Croton Reservoir, both largemouth and smalimouth, provided sport for only a knowledgeable few, and even today the fishing pressure on this long, narrow, manmade lake is extremely light.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ELEVEN years ago in the deep burgundy velvet of the Theatre des ChampsElysees in Paris the stockholders of a struggling French computer manufacturer  Compagnie des Machines Bull  met for a dramatic moment to decide whether to accept the takeover bid of a giant foreign corporation, the General Electric Company.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Postscriptsfor those who complain that I never give the endings to my cliffhangers. One reason, of course, is that there are no endings; urban criseshave a way of going on forever. In preservation, however, the wrecker's ball can write finis, and in planning, the opportunity can be Irrevocably missed. But except for the finality of demolition or completed construction, there is almost always a next chapter or verse.

title: Dowling Planning Hunger Workshop
description: A conference and concert sponsored by Dowling College and World Hunger Year will be held at the college on Friday from 9 A. M. to 2:30 P. M.

title: Is groovy groovy or ghastly over 40?
description: My husband owns more necklaces than I do, a woman of indeterminate age was overheard to say proudly to her companion one recent Saturday afternoon in Bloomingdale's. The reasons may be psychological, sociological or sartorial, but more and more middleaged men are dressing in the socalled groovy manner initially favored by men in their early 20's.

title: Long Theater Strike Seen As Musicians' Talks Stall
description: The musicians who shut down much of Broadway last week are pretty much sets for a long strike, I. Philip Sipser, lawyer for Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, said yesterday.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A: MORE ON INSECTS IN POT PLANTS (Sept. 7) Helen S. Berg, a Westchester County reader, has another suggestion for getting rid of millipedes and sow bugs in pots of house plants. Here is her idea. The cheapest and safest way is to fill a bucket with soapy water, about one tablespoon of liquid soap to a gallon of water. Add a good dash of household bleach. Put each pot into the bucket and let it remain until the soil level shows dampness. Try to keep the foliage clear. Most of the unwelcome pests will get the message quickly.

title: Job Outlook for Aged Is Bleak
description: TRENTONThe job outlook for New Jersey's elderly is far from rosy, experts in the field reported last week.

title: Card of Thanks
description: Kimmel

title: Adoptions Are Brisk For Pets
description: The problem of dogs being abandoned, particularly by vacationers, was discussed in this column last week. However, there is hope for some of these animals. Several organizations are doing good work in adoptions. Perhaps the best known in New York City are the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to animals and the BideAWee Home Association. A relative newcomer is STRAYS (Society to Rescue Animals You've Surrendered). A leader on Long Island is the North Shore Animal League. Across the river in West New York, N. J., is the Animals Need Your Kindness Corporation.

title: Syracuse Kick Beats Iowa, 107
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 20 (AP)  Dave Jacobs, a freshman, kicked a 41yard field goal into the wind today and gave Syracuse a 107 victory over Iowa. It was the best start for Syracuse in eight years.

title: Dial M for Muddle
description: Following are excerpts from September 1, 1975, telephonic communications between President Gerald R. Ford of the United States of America and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, also of the United States, and between Mr. Ford and President Anwar elSadat of Egypt. They are based on Presidential documents, from Washington.

title: A Perennial Border In Three Easy Stages
description: The challenge of a perennial garden is irresistible for most gardeners. For those who are ready to pick up the glove, I submit a beginner's perennial border, in three easy stages.

title: TUNA FLEET CALLS U.S. POLICY TIMID
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 20The Government's new plan to place a limited embargo on imports of tuna from nations fishing out of season in a conservatiori zone of the eastern Pacific was denounced this week by officials of the American Tuna Boat Association as a timid and meaningless gesture.

title: If not a revival, at least a boomlet
description: When Rudyard Kipling died nearly 40 years ago, his critical reputation, if not his popularity, had been fading for a generation. The title Edmund Wilson gave his essay on the author and his work in the early forties was The Kipling That Nobody Read; and though Wilson allowed some rather grudging merit to a few of the late stories (specifically Mary Postgate and The Gardener, his verdict was generally accepted. Except for the children's booksKim includedfew read Kipling then and even fewer do now.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Dig and store gladiolus corms and dahlia tubers that have flowered.. . . Last call to take cuttings of geraniums, begonias, lantanas, petunias, etc. to root for house plants. . . . Water newly seeded lawns daily. . . . Finish dividing established perennials. . . . Plant peonies... . Continue planting evergreens, lawns and bulbs.

title: The deadly move to sea
description: What everyone remembers long afterward is the silence, deeper than the voices or the occasional sounds of machinery. That, and the lack of a sense of motion. If you didn't know better you might imagine that you were sitting in a room somewhere with the shades drawn. Or, perhaps, in a slightly crowded suite of offices. There are overhead fluorescent lights in all the rooms and passageways, and carpets on the floors.

title: Kansas Governor Sees Both Wheat and Chaff
description: George Meany and his longshoremen's union are using the American farmer as a scapegoat in their attempts to block the sale of a portion of this year's bumper wheat crop to the Soviet Union. By using the farmer as a whipping boy to force the use of more United States ships in the grain trade they have posed a threat not only to the agricultural economy of the Midwest but to the economy of the nation as a whole.

title: East German Pilot Flees
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Sept. 20 (Reuters)  An East German pilot flew a singleengine plane across the border into West Germany today and asked for political asylum, the Police said. A spokesman said it had apparently not come under fire while crossing the clsely guarded frontier.

title: History of Men's Clothing
description: Le style, c'est I'homme is a dictum that ascribes a considerable importance to man's appearance and his mode of dress. Many of us discount the significance of dress, asserting that it is only a superficial manifestation of character. But a man's dress tells much about the individual, for what he wears is the result of his taste and his esthetic decisions, which are linked up with a broad spectrum of social considerations. Oscar Wilde said only a fool doesn't judge by appearances.

title: Suspect Named in Slaying Of Officers
description: The police took into custody yesterday a man who allegedly said he had been with the gunman who killed two police officers last Tuesday night and they also identified the alleged fugitive killer.

title: Future Social Events
description: Sept. 23The Davis & Long Company, a gallery at 746 Madison Avenue (at 65th Street) will donate its premises for an exhibition of art objects on loan from some of our most famous interior designers and from private collectors, which will benefit the Drawings and Prints Conservation Fund of the Cooper  Hewitt Museum. It's open to the public from Sept. 24 through Oct. 9 and contributions are voluntary. So loosen the purse strings and have a look at items from the collections of William Pahlmann, Mrs. William P. Rayner, Melanie Kahane, Oscar de la Renta and others. There'll be a subscription previewchampagne, hors d'oeuvres, distinguished companyfrom. 7 to P.M. Tickets, $35 a couple. The CooperHewitt Museum will move to its new home, the old Carnegie mansion on Fifth Avenue after completion of renovations.

title: Probing the Kafkaesque World of Welfare
description: That's me! That's me! That's me! cries Valerie Johnson, a welfare client in Frederick Wiseman's new TV documentary, Welfare, which will be shown Wednesday evening on WNET in New York and nationally on the public broadcasting network. A case worker seems to have found Valerie's lost file, and with it her official identity, the only one that counts for her now. The name is right, and the address is almost right. Valerie's taut Modigliani face is transformed. But the social security number is wrong. It may not be her after all. She'll have to come back again in the morning, go to Reception and get an appointment for Group Four.

title: Lobbying Curbs Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) Gov. Philip M. Noel of Rhode island, representing the National Governors Conference, told a House subcommittee that the conference opposed provision restricting contact by state and local officials with members of Congress and the executive branch.

title: Food News
description: NEWARKOne bite into a chunk of Giordano's crisp, heavycrusted Italian bread, and you will be inclined to believe whatever this thirdgeneration family of bakers tells you, even that it is still a favorite of Frank Sinatra.

title: Terrorists in Iran Said to Be Tracking U.S. Aides
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 20Some United States officials have been under surveillance in recent months by persons believed to be Iranian terrorists who have vowed to attack Americans, wellplaced Western European and American informants report.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Beware the man who is most securely bound. In the Cambridge Ensemble's production of Jean Genet's Deathwatch, which has been imported from its home base in Boston to East Fourth Street for the next few weekends (Wednesdays through Sundays), the man most securely bound is known to his fellow cellmates as Green Eyes. As he sits transfixed, eyeballs rolled upward beneath quivering halfclosed lids, on the steel doubledecker that passes for a prison bed, one foot gives off a snakelike rattle each time it moves. A chain, brightly silvered so that we shall never quite forget its presence, locks him permanently to the leg of the bunk. A long chain, a loose chain, one that can be gripped in the fist and used as lariat, whip or strangler's noosebut a chain. The two men who share his quarters, his ideals and eventually his hysteria are perfectly free to move about, away from him if need be.

title: JAMES HARTLEY, 68, BALLISTICS EXPERT
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 20James C. Hartley, firearms and metallurgy expert, died last night at the Lawrence Memorial Hospital here. He was 68 years old.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Senate

title: In This Issue
description: TO THE QUEEN OF THE COWBOY KING

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  New Jersey voters have never turned out in large numbers for offyear legislative elections. Only 64.4 per cent of the registered electorate cast ballots in 1967, and 61.8 per cent in 1971.

title: Conserving elegance
description: When I was growing up, a Southerner took his wardrobe seriously. I was reared, in part, in Virginia, where clothing often had a historya first formal suit, for example. might have been inherited in excellent condition from a cousin or elder brother. We Southerners were spiritually akin in this conservatism to those Boston ladies who, according to legend, said to the clerk in the department store: We have our hats.

title: RADICAL JOCKS
description: Jack Scott is standing on the steps of the State Capitol, his slim body very still. His head, goldenfringed in the noon August sun, is slightly cocked, like a runner's waiting for his name and event to be called. He is smiling with closed lips, giving his bearded, bespectacled face a gentle, almost beatific cast. He nods to the cadence of his introduction.

title: Vincent Lopez, Bandleader, Dies at 80
description: Vincent Lopez, the orchestra leader whose popularity in person, on the radio and on television lasted more than half a century, died yesterday in the Villa Maria, a nursing home in North Miami, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Call him Ishmael, call him the last of the pro footballniks. After nearly 10 years in a coma, he awoke in 1984. He had gone into shock in 1975 when it appeared that the National Football League would not open its season because of a labor dispute. Throughout his coma, his body rejected nourishment except for a mysterious serum melted down from N.F.L. highlight films and fed to him intravenously. Offense for breakfast, defense for lunch, special teams for dinner. When he awoke with his doctor at his bedside, he didn't realize that he had been in a coma.

title: Four novels
description: Home From the wars. By Jorge Amado. Translated from the Portuguese by Barbara Shelby. 551 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.

title: Miss Hohl Is Bride of Thomas Hubbard
description: Christina Leddy Hohl, daughter of Mrs. Clarence L. Hohl Jr. and the late Professor Hohl of the Manhattanville College history faculty, was married yesterday to Thomas Ralph Hubbard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hustace Hubbard Jr. Both families are of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Sammy's Ye Old Cider Mill, Route 24, Mendham. (201) 5437932.

title: The Beech Trees of North America Are Threatened by a WestwardSpreading Fungal Disease From Europe
description: An epidemic of fungal disease that has been slowly spreading from Nova Scotia westward has reached proportions that pose a threat to the beech tree population of North America, according to recent pathology surveys.

title: The World
description: TOKYOJapan is beset on all sides. China wants a peace treaty with a clause opposing Soviet hegemony in Asia. The Soviet Union, warning against a revival of Japanese Militarism, wants a peace treaty of its own, plus economic cooperation to develop Siberia. The United States wants Japan to be less passive in providing for its own defense, thus easing the American burden. France wants the yen and other major currencies on fixed, rather than the current floating exchange rates. Oil producers want higher prices, threatening to disrupt the Japanese economy again. South Korea wants the Japanese to contribute to Korean security, economic development, and trade balances. North Korea Wants Japan to give it political and economic treatment equal to that given South Korea.

title: Upbeat classic
description: Earl Carlyss is 36 and has never owned a pair of blue jeans. He thinks they're hot and uncomfortable. He does, however, have a brown tuxedo with brown velvet lapels, which he wears with an ocher shirt, brown velvet bow tie and brown patentleather Gucci shoes. Carlyss is second violinist for the Juilliard String Quartet, and these are his working clothes.

title: N.Y.M.A. Returns With 146 Success
description: CORNWALLONHUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 20New York Military Academy's return to varsity football was a big success today with a 146 defeat of McBurney. N.Y.M.A. had deemphasized its program last season when it was forced to field a junior varsity team because its squad was small.

title: Sachem Harriers Triumph
description: KINGS PARK, L. I., Sept. 20Port Jefferson, Holy Trinity and Sachem won varsity team titles today in the Nassau County Coaches scholastic crosscountry meet.

title: Assembly to Vote Tomorrow on Rise in School Aid
description: TRENTONUnder the threat of Supreme Court intervention on Oct. 1, the State Assembly will convene here tomorrow to consider final legislative approval of a bill mandating a $320million increase in state aid to public schools.

title: May, Two Homers Down Indians
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 20The Yankees heat back Cleveland pretensions today with a 41 victory over the Indians at Municipal Stadium.

title: Being Small Is a Problem for Caldwell
description: CALDWELL  Many communities are content to be small and suburban, but being small is a problem for this Essex County borough of 1.3 square miles. Caldwell has no industry and no room for growth, and so there are no new ratables to be added; thus, as municipal costs go up, the entire bill must be paid by the 8,700 residents. Sometimes, the borough has to do without services it needs because it lacks the funds.

title: Water Safeguard Urged
description: TRENTONUsing the recent crisis here as an object lesson, the Byrne administration and Democratic leaders in the Senate have begun a campaign to finance a series of regional interconnections for New Jersey's crazyquilt collection of independent watersupply systems.

title: 19Game Drought Ended by Upsala
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., Sept. 20 (AP)Ron Forino gained 124 yards rushing and Robert Ryoul accounted for two scores as Upsala posted a 2014 college football victory over Swarthmore today. The game, the opener for both teams, broke a 19game Upsala losing streak and ran Swarthmore's loss string to 32.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900 WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (515) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800 CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Lawyers Study New RealEstate Law
description: NEWARK  Hundreds of New Jersey lawyers are going back to the classroom this week, not for annual reunions but in an effort to learn the fine points of a revolutionary new realestate law.

title: Taste Grape Varieties Now And Order for Spring Planting
description: Gardeners may be overwhelmed by the goodtasting grapes available for home planting, each differing in flavor and color. Those who plan to grow grapes might like to sample local varieties before deciding what grapes they will plant next spring.

title: Events Today
description: Flea Market: Proceeds to benefit the Staten Island Historical Society. 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Richmondtown restoration parking lot, to the rear of the Court House, Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown, S.I.

title: LETTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Caren Suzanne Friedberg Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Alan Friedberg of Wayland. Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Caren Suzanne Friedberg, to Hillel Sander Hammerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Hammerman of Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Design
description: At Alderbrook, the handsome Hudson River Valley home of Jan and Joyce Nadelman, the phrase living with art takes on a new dimension. The house, beautifully sited on wooded land with a view of the river, contains hundreds of works by Jan's father, the sculptor Elie Nadelman, whose retrospective show opens this week at the Whitney Museum. Heads, figures awl animals in a variety of Nadelman styles and scales line the halls, disport in bay windows, sit on table tops, occupy odd corners. Yet the gallery feeling has been avoided. These lively, robust presences, endowed with a spirit of their own, are so well deployed in the the ample rooms that the life of the household flows smoothly around them.

title: Democrats Facing a Battle for Party Leadership in Nassau
description: MINEOLAThe selection of Nassau County Republican and Democratic party chairmen last week and this week presages an election that will pit Democratic candidates, flush with victories at the polls last year, against Republicans who virtually control county and town government.

title: Facts in Musicians' Strike
description: Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. I. Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.

title: FILM VIEW
description: All choices are political, Lina Wertmuller, the gifted Italian director, suggested here in an interview last February, and in none of her earlier films seen in this country has this thought been more wittily and exuberantly demonstrated than in her newest film, Swept Away (By an Unusual Destiny in The Blue Sea of August). You may notice that I didn't identify Miss Wertmuller as the gifted Italian woman director, though women directors in motion pictures are still so rare that the fact remains newsworthy. She is, before everything else, a firstrate director and screenwriter (she does her own screenplays), a talent of such independence and range that some details in her films give pause to her sisters in the feminist movement.

title: Meals for Aged Set In Highland Park
description: HIGHLAND PARK  Dr. David Schwartz, chairman of the Highland Park Commission on the Aging, has announced that, beginning Oct. 1, a luncheon for the borough's elderly will be served daily at the Middle School, on South Fifth Avenue.

title: Japanese Educators Visit Catholic Schools
description: Why do you have the national flag in the classroom? Hitoshi Kuramoto asked a student at Our Lady of the Snows School in North Floral Park, Queens.

title: Arabs Study Use of Oil Money To Develop Sudan as Granary
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 20 (Reuters)  Sudan may become the granary for the Arab world with the help of Middle Eastern oil money.

title: Visual Arts Display Planned in Jamaica
description: Printmakers Media Day will be held on Oct. 18 at the Jamaica Arts Center, to promote awareness in the visual arts.

title: Diagramless, 17 by 17
description: ACROSS

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Yankees will be at Shea Stadium for the final week of the regular season with games at 8 P.M. tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday against Boston. Then comes a threegame series against Baltimore at 8 P.M. Friday and 2 P.M. Saturday and Sunday (Fan Appreciation Day).

title: Swedes Win Doubles as 6,500 Protest
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, Sept. 20 (AP)With about 6,500 shouting leftwing demonstrators only a few blocks away, Sweden defeated Chile in the doubles today and gained a 21 lead in the Davis Cup tennis semifinals.

title: Composting, The Key to Better Soil
description: If you make a big pile of fallen leaves on a warm autumn day, add enough highnitrogen (or green) plant materials and a sprinkling of soil, dampen it and leave it for a few days, the pile will heat up and shrink down to half its size.

title: Fading Recovery?
description: Is the economic recovery, barely four months old, already in troubleand, if so, why?

title: The relentless arithmetic of the future: Already four blacks for every white. By the year 2000, five. By 2020, seven.
description: JOHANNESBURG. Friends met me at Jan Smuts Airport. We walked through the domestic side of the terminal, past the signs for the nonEuropean toilets and lunch counter, across the road to the parking lot.

title: STAMPS
description: Charles Thomson, who for more than a decade set down the birth records of a new nation as secretary of the Continental Congress; that guided the Colonies along the road to independence, has been remembered by the United States through a new postal card.

title: $1 Price on Columbus Block
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 20 (UPI)The Columbus Development Department disposed of a block of inner city homes at $1 each by lottery Thursday. There were 32 winners, who must show proof within 120 days that they can pay for repairs and maintenance, make the houses habitable within six months, move in within 18 months and live in them for four years before they get title.

title: 2 Jumpers Tie For Show Title
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 20Jack Benson, who quit his job with a trucking company to turn professional only three weeks ago, rode Toy Commander to a tie for the open jumper championship today at the Suburban Essex Horse Show.

title: Litter Called Growing Problem in U.S. Cities
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20Despite the expenditure of billions of dollars and millions of manhours, the problem of litter in the nation's cities continues to grow.

title: HARD TIMES HURT GHANA'S RULERS
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 20 (AP) An austerity budget with big tax increases coupled with an already soaring cost of living has left Ghana's military Government at its lowest ebb in popularity since coming to power in a coup nearly four years ago.

title: Article 13  No Title
Revamped Giants to Face Eagles in Bid for Equality
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20Before the whistle blows, reads a sign on a classroom wall back at the Giants practice center, all are equal.

title: Philadelphia Refuse Men Clean Up in Contest Here
description: The embattled City Sanitation Department suffered another defeat yesterdaylosing a truckdriving competition in an intercity roadeo against the Philadelphia Streets Department.

title: No Fare Details Here
description: A spokesman for Pan American here said yesterday that he did not have details of the new fare arrangements but that they had been applied for in accordance with the regulations of the Japanese Government and went into effect on Sept. 1.

title: Street Race Puts Hill in Driver Seat
description: Phil Hill, who still is the only American to win the world driving championship, has a special interest in next Sunday's Formula 5000 race through the streets of Long Beach, Calif.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, September 21, 1975

title: Jet Forced to Land in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 19 (UPI)A Delta Air Lines L1011 bound for Los Angeles, carrying a full load of 250 passengers, made an emergency return landing at Hartsfield International Airport Friday after one of its jet engines shut down in flight.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: In many elementary schools across the country, the teaching of science has shifted away from the traditional textbookanddiscussion approach to the inquiry or discovery method.

title: Article 17  No Title
description: decided to pull up stakes and move to the country. They never regretted it.

title: Helen C. Williams Is Married At Home to David Maclay Jr.
description: Helen Croxton Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Croxton Williams of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, was married yesterday afternoon to David Sears Maclay Jr., son of Mrs. Adele S. Maclay of Darien, Conn., and David S. Maclay of Westport, Conn.

title: Oswald Calls to Embassies Reported Taped by C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The Central Intelligence Agency secretly taperecorded two telephone conversations between Lee Harvey Oswald and the Cuban and Soviet Embassies in Mexico City some eight weeks before President Kennedy was shot to death on Nov. 22, 1963, in Dallas, Government sources familiar with the events said today.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Today, you can get high interest rates a lot of places. It's Tomorrow you have to worry about! Read: The Arithmetic of Disadvantage a free booklet.

title: Letters: Franklin's Stove
description: To the Editor:

title: Leonia Offers Films of Old
description: LEONIAWhat would you expect to get out of a course that begins with The Last of the Mohicans, and ends with The Best Years of Our Lives, with stops along the way for The Birth of a Nation and Citizen Kane?

title: The American System And Its Creative Tension
description: When Congress undertook to investigate American intelligence activity, it was probably inevitable that there would be conflict with the executive branch over access to the facts. Secret intelligence information and operations have been an important element in the growth of Presidential power since World War II, and no President could be expected to have much enthusiasm for sharing the secrets.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1975

title: D. H. Lawrence in parts and pieces
description: Both these authors chose interesting subjects; Emily Hahn, the accounts of Lawrence written by those emotionally involved with him, accoums which do indeed deserve more respect and attention than they have received; Philip Callow, the experience which lay behind Lawrence's imaginative fictionthe facts of his life, up to 1919. Unfortunately, the book Miss Hahn set out to write remains to be written, while Mr. Callow's already has been written, for he has nothing substantial to add to earlier accounts.

title: CROCKETT'S DEATH AT ALAMO DOUBTED
description: DALLAS, Sept. 20 (AP)It history occurred the way John Wayne played it in The Alamo. David Crockett was bayoneted by fiery Mexican challengers and then blew himself up in an ammunition dump at the Alamo. But a Mexican officer who was present left a diary saying that Crockett was captured, tortured and then killed.

title: Council in Yonkers Bows to Let College Build Dormitories
description: YONKERS, Sept. 20The Yonkers City Council voted reluctantly last week to permit Sarah Lawrence College to build new dormitories, thus apparently purging itself of possible citation for contempt of court.

title: Blair L. Sadler, Georgia Robins Have Nuptials
description: Georgia Lynne Robins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Robins of Kingston, Pa., and Blair Learner Sadler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Sadler of Allentown, Pa., were married yesterday morning in the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Ernest Gordon, dean of the chapel, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: All in the (Lennon) Family for Immaculate
description: Joe Lennon made his debut as head coach for Montclair Immaculate yesterday, and his younger brother made that debut a success.

title: Tip on Hideout Guided F.B.I. to Hearst Trail
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20The arrest of Patricia Hearst and three radical companions resulted from information Walter Scott gave the Federal Bureau of Investigation about a hideout in Pennsylvania, an official source close to the investigation said today.

title: Walter H. Weed Jr. Dies; Estate Manager Was 75
description: Walter H. Weed Jr., chairman of Weed & Frost. estate management, and former president of Bartram Brothers, Inc., investment brokers, died Friday in Greenwich, Conn. where he lived. He was 75 years old.

title: Division Is Victor; Carle Place Wins
description: Carle Place and Levittown Division, two of the perennial powers in the Nassau County football, opened their seasons yesterday, and it looks as though it will be business at the same old stand for both.

title: 4,000 Turn Out to Mourn Slain Officer
description: Under skies as sombre as the mood of those who attended, more than 4,000 mourners, including Mayor Beame, jammed the streets of Harlem yesterday morning to pay their respects to Police Officer Andrew Glover, who was slain along with his partner Tuesday night.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to the Pioneer Valley in western Massachusetts, the fastest route from New York City may be by way of 195 (the Connecticut Turnpike) and 191. But traveling north on the Hutchinson River Parkway and 1684, east on 184 and then north from Hartford on 191 is tollfree and prettier by far, The trip from midtown New York to the Massachusetts border takes about two and onehalf hours.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Silver today.

title: City Council Schedule Of the Week's Hearings
description: City Council committees will hold the following public hearings this week:

title: Cadets Roll Up 644 Yards, Their Biggest Total Since '44
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 20With its best offensive display in 31 years, Army punched over eight touchdowns and gained 644 yards today in crushing Lehigh, 5432, before a crowd of 27,872 at Michie Stadium.

title: SPAIN REPORTS 57 HELD AS GUERRILLAS
description: MADRID, Sept. 20 (Reuters) The Spanish police anounced the arrest today of 57 urban guerrillas in three cities in a continuing drive against extreme leftist and separatist groups.

title: American and Japanese Air Carriers Are Engaged in a War Over Rates for Traffic Across the Pacific Ocean
description: TOKYO, Sept. 20  Pan American World Airways and Northwest Orient airlines are engaged in a rate war with Japan Air Lines and other Asian carriers that fly the Pacific Ocean.

title: New Start for Portugal
description: With patience, firmness and tact, Vice Admiral Jos Pinheiro de Azevedo has apparently constructed a Government of civilians and military officers that should be able to lead Portugal away from Communism and toward democracy. By selecting four Socialists and two Popular Democrats for his Cabinet, along with a single Communist, the Premierdesignate has kept a promise to form a Government that reflected the overwhelming victory for democratic forces in the elections last April.

title: PIERSON IS JOKANAAN IN SALOME OPERA
description: In the performance of Richard Strauss's Salom given by the New York City Opera l at the New York State Theater on Friday night, Edward Pierson took the role of Jokanaan for the first time with the company.

title: Anniversaries
description: Lubin

title: News of The Realty Trade
description: The New York Attorney General's office has approved the filing of a prospectus for a 20 story condominium apartment building to be constructed at 315 East 48th Street, the first project here in which the purchasers will be restricted to foreigners.

title: Margaret Chase Smith: Still Involved
description: SKOWHEGAN, Maine (AP) Her desk is less cluttered now, though mail still piles up like the logs jamming the Kennebec River, which flows in back of her house.

title: Fall Planting
description: Gardeners in the country often take the bright flowers of spring for granted. Not their city counterparts, however. Every sprig of color, scent of greenery and touch of bloom is appreciated. And terrace planters can change their neverchanging buildings by planting flowering bulbs everywhere there is space.

title: Aviation Museum Planned at Teterboro
description: TETERBOROAn agreement between the Teterboro Aviation Hall of Fame and Pan American World Airways will provide space for the state's first aviation museum.

title: U.S. Astronauts Are Greeted in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20The three American astronauts who piloted their Apollo spacecraft to the rendezvous with a Soviet Soyuz capsule last July arrived today in Moscow to begin a twoweek tour of the Soviet Union.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Recent signs that the decline in the national birth rate may be halting are of twofold, if contradictory, significance to George Joseph Hecht, the almost octogenarian chairman of Parents' Magazine Enterprises, Inc., and foxy grandfather of family oriented publishing.

title: Minimall Is Rising in Queens
description: WOODMERE  Shoppers accustomed to visiting the myriad stores spread out over the expanse of the Five Towns Shopping Center here will soon be given a new challenge when the morn and pop concept receives mass production treatment.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Women Seeking Top Posts In Schools
description: PLAINVIEWNone of the 107 Long Island high schools has a woman principal. Only two of the 102 junior high schools have women principals. Just 17 per cent of the 455 elementary schools in both counties are headed by women.

title: Robin A. Arbon Wed to B. P. Miller
description: Robin Alexes Arbon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Arbon of Glen Head, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Bradford Putnam Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew O. Miller of Laurel Hollow, L.I.

title: BRIDGE
description: A famous bridge writer is on record as saying that the most intractable problem in bridge is the kibitzer evil. There are rules for kibitzers, just as there are for players, but they are frequently disregarded. The ideal kibitzer watches one hand only, never opens his mouth during the bidding and play, and says very little in between deals: He makes a postmortem comment only if asked to do so.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: For the man who has everything but could use a bigger tax writeoff, MercedesBenz is designing a $35,000 car, the MB 690 SEL.

title: Carlie Butcher Plans Nuptials
description: Willard Carlisle Butcher of Wilton, Conn., president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and Mrs. Butcher have announced the engagement of their daughter. Sarah Carlisle Butcher, to Neal Stuart Garonzik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Henry Garonzik of Gloversville. N. Y.

title: Abortion Rally in Bonn
description: BONN, West Germany, Sept. 21 (AP)Traffic mae to a halt in downtown Bonn today as 20,000 demonstrators marched to demand abolition of the law against abortion. The rally, which drew young women and men from several cities in seven special trains and 80 buses, marked the opening of a campaign to revoke a restrictive abortion ruling of Feb. 25 by West Germany's highest court.

title: 4 Field Goals Help Cowboys Win, 187
description: Winning the opening game of the National Football League schedule is an old tradition in Dallaseven when the opposition is provided by the Los Angeles Rams.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A highranking Syrian mediation mission appeared determined yesterday to establish a durable truce among Lebanon's warring factions on the left and right as an uncertain calm settled over Beirut. Syria's Foreign Minister, Adbul Halim Khaddam, said we will not leave Lebanon until the crisis is solved, even if we have to stay a month. On Saturday night he had cajoled the leftist and rightist leaders into a ceasefire that has only been occasionally violated. Ultimately, the leftists hope to alter the National Covenant of 1943, which gives a leading political role to Lebanon's Maronite Christians and divides electoral offices on the basis of religious affilation. Altering the National Covenant is anathema to the Phalangist leader, Pierre Gemayel, who has threatened to internationalize the crisis' if it is not resolved soon. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Tropical Storm Rebuilds Strength and Moves to Gulf
description: MIAMI, Sept. 21 (UP)Tropical Storm Eloise moved into the Gulf of Mexico south of New Orleans tonight and began rebuilding strength to threaten the Gulf coastal area of the United States.

title: CURBS ARE TIGHTER ON SOUTH KOREANS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 19After two stormy years of political conflict, President Park Chung Hee appears to have suppressed almost all dissidence against his rule.

title: JORDAN ASSAILS STUDY'S FINDINGS
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 21 Mayor Paul T. Jordan said yesterday that he was pretty damn mad about the conclusion of a federally financed study that said Jersey City was the worst large American city in which to live. He noted that the study was based on data more than five years old that predated his administration, which began in 1971.

title: SYRIANS PERSIST IN EFFORT TO END LEBANON'S CRISIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 21A highranking Syrian mediation mission appeared determined today to patch together a durable truce among Lebanon's warring factions as an edgy calm settled over Beirut.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1975

title: KISSINGER MEETS GROMYKO ON ARMS
description: Secretary of State Kissinger flew to New York yesterday to continue discussions with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, on ways to end the impasse that has so far held up completion of a new agreement to limit strategic arms.

title: 25TH AMENDMENT SAID TO WORK WELL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) The 25th Amendment to the Constitution worked exceedingly well in the elevation of Gerald R. Ford to President and Nelson A. Rockefeller to Vice President and should not be revised, a Senate report concluded today.

title: Free Tuition Under Fire
description: The recommendation by State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist that the City University abandon its traditional tuitionfree policy deserves something more by way of response than a rejection based merely on sentiment and tradition. In this critical period when the university is laboring under draconian budget cuts and the city's capacity to support any of its past commitments is in question, no proposals that might ease the fiscal pinch can be ignored.

title: TIMOR REBEL TELLS OF A BORDER CLASH
description: DILI, Portuguese Timor, Sept. 21 (Reuters)Unidentified troops, some wearing Indonesian uniforms, attacked forces of the Revolutionary Front for Independent East Timor yesterday on the territory's south coast, Rogerio Lohato, the front's military commander, said here today.

title: Meat Cleaver Fails To Work  Safe Stolen
description: Flailing on a safe with a meat cleaver is not the most facile way to break into it. And trying to make off with the safe in a cab, unnoticed, is fraught with risks, especially if the thief orders a leisurely getaway.

title: Dr. J. R. Rohrbaugh Weds Jane Ehrensall
description: Jane Ellen Ehrensall, a pediatric nurse practitioner and nursing coordinator of the Mission Hill Health Center in Boston, was married yesterday noon to Dr. James Richard Rohrbaugh, a resident in pediatrics at Boston City Hospital.

title: Article 1  No Title
Honeywell Officer To Testify as Trial Of I.B.M. Resumes
description: Juries H. Binger, chairman of the executive committee of Honeywell, Inc., is scheduled to be the first witness when the Government's civil antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation resumes today.

title: FORD SEES PERIL OF 'BIG BROTHER
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 21 President Ford said today that the Government was accumutating vast amounts of information on American citizens, and declared, We must protect every individual from excessive and unnecessary intrusions by a Big Brother bureaucracy.

title: ISRAEL DELAYING NEXT SINAI STEP
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 21The Israeli Cabinet voted today to instruct the nation's representatives at Geneva to initial but not to sign the final document that will put the interim disengagement agreement with Egypt into effect.

title: Chile Ousted By Sweden; Ashe Victor
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, Sept. 21 (AP)Sweden gained the Davis Cup final for the first time in history today when Birger Andersson, who becathe a fulltime tennis pro only six months ago, clinched the threeoffive series with Chile with a 63, 1412, 61 triumph over Patricio Cornejo.

title: Baseball Box Scores and Standings
Oil Diplomats Soften Strategy
description: PARIS, Sept. 21Exporting and consuming countries appear to be subtly changing strategy in the diplomacy of oilmoving back from confrontation toward a more moderate position where the politics of cooperation may finally break through.

title: Both Sides Harden Stands In Hoboken Teacher Strike
description: HOBOKEN, Sept. 21With the teacher strike here almost two weeks old, attitudes on both sides are hardening.

title: TWO ELECTRIC CARS FOUND TO BE UNSAFE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) The two most widely sold electric cars in the United States marketthe Elcar 2000 and the Citicar SV48are so unsafe that they should not be allowed on the highway, according to the Consumers Union.

title: Elephants Are Declining Rapidly in Africa
description: The African elephant, the largest land animal alive, is declining in numbers so rapidly that some wildlife experts fear that within a decade it may be on the verge of extermination in much, if not all, of Africa.

title: JetsBills Scoring
U. N. Ready to Greet and Guard An Emperor, a King and Others
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 Security precautions were reinforced at United Nations headquarters today in preparation for the expected appearance tomorrow or Secretary of State Kissinger and of other visitors in coming weeks.

title: A Most Important Accessory for Fall
description: Fling it, sling it, wrap it, drape itdo with it what you will. That's the whole point of fashion's most important accessory this fallthe shawl.

title: World Football League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: JAVITS CHIDES FORD FOR STAND ON CITY
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits charged yesterday that President Ford had been captured by Treasury Secretary William E. Simon's wrong attitude toward New York City's fiscal crisis, an attitude the Senator characterized as sit tight and keep a stony face.

title: Improvement of the Greed
description: The last time Mayor Beame mentioned higher stocktransfer taxes as a means of reducing New York City's $3.3billion deficit, he was snowed under like a rookie quarterback getting blitzed by the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: LEE Y. SCHNEIDER
description: Lee Youdin Schneider, treasurer of the Order of Pythian Sisters, who operated the Schneider Tax Service, accountants, died Friday in Forest Hills, Queens, where she lived. She was 67 years old.

title: Miss Balgooyen Bride of M. D. Drysdale
description: Marjorie Ellen Balgooyen, a soprano with a master's degree in music history from the University of Michigan, was married yesterday afternoon to M. Dickey Drysdale of Randolph, Vt. He is editor and publisher of The White River Valley Herald, a Randolph weekly.

title: Scoring and Statistics of N.F.L Games
description: AT BLOOMINGTON, MINN.

title: Soares, Tired but Triumphant, Looks Ahead to Election Victory
description: LISBON, Sept. 21It was past midnight when a tall man with wavy dark hair and a familiar face walked into the restaurant and slumped wearily into a chair. There were dark circles under his eyes and his face was nearly as gray as his banker's pinstripe.

title: Tanner Beaten in Final
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21Arthur Ashe won the Pacific Southwest open championship, and its $16,000 first prize, today  a dozen years after his first victory here as al 20yearold student. In a match of thundering aces and serving heroics, the Wimbledon champion and topseeded player defeated Roscoe Tanner, 36, 75, 63 in 95 minutes.

title: Boom in Art Photography Poses Problem in Expertise
description: Nothing is more remarkable on the art scene just now than the booming activity on the photography front. Museums formerly indifferent to collecting or even exhibiting photographs are suddenly desperate to acquire classic examples of vintage prints before they disappear from the market. Curators who once specialized in the niceties of mannerist paintings or the pediments of the Parthenon are obliged to become overnight experts in a field where the canons of scholarship and connoisseurship are still being formed.

title: BEATRICE LANDMAN
description: Beatrice Eschner Landman, widow of Rabbi Isaac Landman of Congregation Beth Elohim in Brooklyn who edited the Universal Jewish Encyclopedia, dled Saturday in Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. She was 88 years old.

title: 7 Farm Union Aides Arrested For Trespassing on Coast Farm
description: EARLIMART, Calif., Sept. 21. Seven organizers for the United Farm Workers were ar rested yesterday for trespassing at the Marco Zaninovich ranch here.

title: Carl Green Weds Miss Wattenberg
description: Pamela Wattenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Wattenberg of New York, was married here yesterday to Carl J. Green, the Ford Foundation's representative in Tokyo and program officer for Japan and East Asia.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Inquiry on Theft of $50Million From Hunt Foods Reported Rejected
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 21A member of the Hunt oil family says that its widely advertised H. L. H. food company lost $50million to $60million between 1940 and 1970 because of stealing by key company employes and that the Justice Department has refused for five years to investigate.

title: Buffalo Rushes for 309 YardsNamath Intercepted 4 Times
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 21Stunned almost immediately by their own mistakes, the Jets floundered through one of their poorest performances in years today and dropped their National Football League opener to the Bills by 4214.

title: Consumer Confidence Is Up, Survey Shows
description: The Conference Board reported over the weekend that its index of consumer confidence advanced to 77.3 per cent of the 1967 average during August, up 9 points from the June level. The rise marked the fourth consecutive increase in the index, which is compiled every two months for the board by National Family Opinion, Inc.

title: A Musician on Strike
description: I enjoy working in the theater, Stanley Koor says, and it's one of the few sources of steady employment for musicians that is left in the city. A percussionist in Pip pin since the show opened in 1972, Mr. Koor has been playing in New York theaters for 20 years and, despite the element of insecurity in all branches of theater employment, gives no indication that he would like to leave it.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
TV: Cosell, the Unpredictable, Opens New Series
description: The Horrible Howard monster is now being marketed as the cozy Cosell doll. The new packaging, unveiled on ABC at 8 P.M. last Saturday, is a series called Saturday Night Live with Howard Cosell. The live part has less to do with Mr. Cosell than with the transmission of the broadcast. Standing on Broadway, outside the Ed Sullivan Theater, the host explained: Tonight on our stage, you'll be seeing other [sic] great faces, plus the unexpected, because this is live.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Abie Nathan Arrested
description: PORT SAID, Egypt, Sept. 21 (AP)The Israeli Peace crusader, Abie Nathan, who wanted to sail his private boat and a cargo of flowers through the Suez Canal, was arrested today trying to row ashore, a Foreign Ministry official rePorted. An Egyptian naval aunch intercepted Mr. Nathan. He was accused of trying to enter this canal port illegally on a British passport.

title: CELIA CRUZ MARKS 25 YEARS OF SONG
description: Celia Cruz may not be a name on everybody's lips, but to Spanishspeaking people and Latinmusic buffs, she is a top singer. On Saturday, a program called The Three Eras of Celia Cruz was celebrated in the Grand Ballroom of the Americana Hotel by an overflow audience.

title: Article 3  No Title
Shriver Expresses Doubts About School Busing Orders
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) Sargent Shriver, the newest candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said today that court ordered school busing, in some instances, was counterproductive.

title: Heath, After Meeting, Says Mao Seems in Good Health
description: PEKING, Sept. 21 (Reuters)Former Prime Minister Edward Heath met today with Chairman Mao Tsetung and reported later that Mr. Mao was wellinformed and in comparatively good health.

title: Saturday's Football
Saigon Economy Strained, Refugees Say
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 21Refugees coming out of South Vietnam say that economic conditions in Saigon are becoming increasingly difficult and that there is some continuing armed resistance to the Communists and a resistance radio that broadcasts daily.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Roasted sweet peppers, known as pepperoni, are one of the joys of an Italian antipasto. Both red and green sweet peppers  sometimes known as bell peppers, particularly in the Southseem available in particular abundance this season, and Samuel Hirsh of Jackson Heights, Queens, writes that he would like information on roasting the peppers.

title: AmericanBred Filly Wins in Paris
description: PARIS, Sept. 21 (AP)Ivanjica won a duel with another Americanbred horse, Nobiliary, and captured the $250,000 Prix Vermeille, the most important race for 3yearold fillies in Europe, at Longchamp today. Ivanjica earned more than $125,000 by finishing 1 lengths ahead of her yearlong rival. May Hill, a Britishbred, was third and Sea Sands fourth in the 1mile classic. It was the fourth victory in seven starts for the Kentuckybred daughter of Sir Ivor and made her one of the favorites for the world's richest thoroughbred race, the Prix de l'Arc Triomphe, in two weeks.

title: 700 at Rally in Carolina Urge Swamp as a National Preserve
description: COLUMBIA, St C., Sept. 21A 12yearold campaign to make the Congaree Swamp, a 70,000acre bottomland forest in central South Carolina, into a national preserve was revived with gusto over the weekend.

title: JAMES F. CASKEY
description: James F. Caskey, who retired 12 years ago as advertising publication manager of The New York Times after 40 years with the newspaper, died yesterday at his home, 2101 Cedar Avenue, the Bronx. He was 77 years old.

title: Voting Law Gives Leverage to Labor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The first statewide test of the new Federal campaign law in New Hampshire last week demonstrated dramatically the powerful political leverage that the reform statute has given to organized labor.

title: Red Sox Win, 65; Rice Out for Year
description: A basesloaded double in the ninth inning by Denny Doyle drove in two runs yesterday and lifted Boston to a 65 comeback victory over the Tigers in Detroit, but the Red Sox suffered a crippling blow as they stayed 3 games ahead of the hardcharging Baltimore Orioles, who also won, in the American League East race. They lost Jim Rice for the season.

title: 2Day Election in Finland To Choose a Parliament
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 21 (Reuters)Finns began voting today for a new parliament against a background of rapidly rising unemployment and other economic problems.

title: Patrolman Takes Truth Drug To Aid Recall in Theft of Lamp
description: LAKEWOOD, Sept. 21An Ocean County Park patrolman was injected with sodium pentathol, the socalled truth drug, to help the police find clues; to the theft last month of a $25,000 Tiffany lamp from the Georgian Court College here.

title: Nancy Tatum Sings Lead in City Opera Turandot
description: Nancy Tatum, a Memphisborn soprano who made her Metropolitan Opera debut last fall in Turandot, appeared for the first time yesterday afternoon at the New York City Opera, once more in the title role of Puccini's last, unfinished opera. She served as the focal point of a firstrate performance, the season's fourth of this dramatically ludicrous but often stirring opera.

title: Slip, Slide and Slosh For Firemen at Fair
description: Among the contests at the Oradell Bicentennial Country Fair was an oldfashioned tugofwar. More than 5,000 people attended the full day of activities at the Benbyre Farm, despite rain.

title: Concert
description: It's not surprising the Gregg Smith Singer's 197576 Bicentennial tour program of which the group offered a preview yesterday afternoon to a spottily attended Alice Tully Hallshould be devoted to American music. That the program didn't make a fully satisfying effect had nothing to do with the performances but rather with Mr. Smith's programing and just maybe  with American music itself.

title: WEISL TO RESIGN; MAYOR MAY ASK OTHERS TO LEAVE
description: Edwin L. Weisl Jr., Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, said yesterday that he would resign his post today, becoming the second highlevel Beame administration appointee to depart in the recent drive for efficiency and productivity in city agencies.

title: Botanists Study a Plant in Death Valley
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 21  Three botanists went into Death Valley this weekend to study an extraordinary form of life, a scrubby plant called tidestromia oblongifolia: The hotter and dryer and more inhospitable conditions are the bigger and faster tidestromia grows.

title: San Diego, in Reelecting Mayor, Backs Rigid Controls on Growth
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 21The voters of this second largest California city, who are not only content but also determined to remain No. 2, gave a vote of confidence last week to San Diego's growth controls that are among the most rigid in the nation.

title: Suzanne J. Tillman Married To Richard William Darrow
description: The marriage of Suzanne Jane Tillman to Richard William Darrow, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Hill & Knowlton, Inc., international public relations and public affairs counseling concern, took place here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale performed the ceremony at the Marble Collegiate Church.

title: Bridge:
description: The most obvious difference between tournaments here and tournaments in Europe is that most parts of Europe offer cash priz?? The American Contract Bridge League, throughout its history, has barred money rewards, and independent attempts to establish money tournaments have repeatedly failed.

title: Deaths
description: BERMANMarie K., beloved wife of the late Louis, devoted mother of James, Virginia Staughter and Richard; cherished grandmother, loving sister of Leon Kellner and Ida Youman. Reposing at Frank ??. Campbell, Madison Ave. t 81st St., with services Monday 10 A.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Heart Fund would be appreciated.

title: Facts in Musicians' Strike
description: Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. I. Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.

title: Oklahoma Shackles Dorsett and Presents Joe Washington
description: Tony Dorsett, Pittsburgh's excellent running back, learned Saturday that even though individuals win allAmerica honors each year, they can't do it without help. Virtually helpless in efforts to shake free against the Oklahoma defense, the allAmerica tailback picked up only 17 yards, by far the lowest onegame figure in his three varsity seasons.

title: Mets Drop Home Finale, 42
description: The Mets said goodby to 52,144 of their customers in Shea Stadium yesterday in their final home game of the season, and left them with two mementoes of the summer of 1975: a monogrammed totehag and a 42 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Wildcat Oilmen a Dying Breed
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 21  Wildcatter! The word itself helps perpetuate the image of the independent oilman: a twofisted, hard  drinking leather  faced Texas Yahoo with a nose for crude oil, an eye for wild women and a wallet stuffed with hundred dollar bills.

title: CATHOLIC TEACHERS DROP STRIKE THREAT
description: A threat by members of the Federation of Catholic Teachers to strike against 325 schools In the Archdiocese of New York was called off yesterday when 350 members of the union, Local 2092 of the American Federation of Teachers, voted against a work stoppage according to Jack O'Neill, president of the union.

title: Hog Prices Reach Record; Retail Costs Not Dropping
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 21. As hard as it was for Middle Western farmers to believe, the stockyard price of hogs has soared to $63.25 a hundred pounds, a record that is nearly double the price, a year ago.

title: Donna Mitchell Bride Of A. C. Westermann
description: Donna E. Mitchell, news manager for Patrick Carr Associates, a New York advertising agency, was married yesterday to Alfred C. Westermann of New York and Westhampton Beach, L. I. He is vice president and director of sales training for Petry Television, Inc., television representatives.

title: Missiles to Israel Unlikely Till '78, Schlesinger Hints
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21, (Reuters)  Defense Secretary James R. Schesinger hinted today that even if Israel's request for mediumrange Pershing missiles was approved, the weappns might not be delivered un?? 1978.

title: Use of Student Addresses In Durkin Drive Regretted
description: PLYMOUTH, N. H., Sept. 21 (AP)Bruce Poulton, chancellor of the University of New Hampshire system, has issued an apology for the improper use of student address labels by the Senate campaign of John A. Durkin, which Mr. Durkin won last Tuesday.

title: Bomb Rocks Residence of Lisbon Chief
description: LISBON, Sept. 21 (Reuters)A bomb exploded today outside a seaside palace where Portugal's new Premier, Vice Adm. Jos Pinheiro de Azevedo, was relaxing after three weeks of negotiations to form a fragile multiparty government.

title: PRICE RISE CALLED SETBACK FOR F14
description: The recent disclosure by the Defense Department of a million price increase for the F14 Tomcat fighter has put, new, unexpected pressures on the controversial plane's supporters in Congress and the Navy and has also seriously weakened prospects for future orders by the Pentagon.

title: U.S. Golfers Keep Ryder Cup, 21 to 11
description: LIGONIER, Pa., Sept. 21The 12man team representsing the Professional Golfers' Association of America completed this afternoon a threeday rout of the BritishIrish P.G.A. team and won the 21st biennial Ryder Cup Matches. The final score was 2111.

title: Michael Berger Weds Linda G. Rosenzweig
description: Linda Gail Rosenzweig, a lawyer with the Camden (N. J.) Legal Services, was married yesterday to Michael Scott Berger, a lawyer with the American Civil Liberties Union in New Jersey.

title: WEISL RESIGNING; MAYOR MAY ASK OTHERS TO LEMIE
description: Edwin L. Weisl Jr., Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, said yesterday that he would resign his post effective today, becoming the secondhighlevel Beame administration appointee to depart in the recent drive for efficiency and productivity in city agencies.

title: Treemonisha Ends in Capital; Cast's Pay Cut
description: The cast had just finished the final number of Scott Joplin's mythic opera Treemonisha before a capacity audience of 3,500 in Washington's Kennedy Center yesterday when its star, Betty Allen, stepped out and warded off the spectators' ovation.

title: Belmont History Lesson
description: Harry T. Mangurian Jr.'s American History, who scored his first victory, as a 3yearold only last month at Saratoga in sloppy going, demonstrated again yesterday that an offtrack is his best path to the winner's circle.

title: TEXAS DEPOSITORY OFFERED FOR SALE
description: DALLAS, Sept. 21  The Texas School Book Depository, where Lee Harvey Oswald fired the shots that killed President Kennedy, is up for sale for $1million.

title: Algeria Blacks Out News Of 4 Who Held Egyptians
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 21 (Agence FrancePresse)  Algeria has blacked out all news of the four Palestinian gunmen who arrived here Tuesday morning holding three Egyptian diplomats as hostages.

title: OneShot Victory For Miss Washam
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 21 (AP)JoAnn Washam, a longdriving, thirdyear pro from Fort Worth, won the $40,000 Portland golf tournament today at the Portland Golf Club. She finished one stroke ahead of Sandra Haynie and won the top prize of $5.700.

title: 18 Drown in Mexico
description: CIUDAD OBREGON, Mexico, Sept. 21 (UPI)Eighteen peopleseven of them childrendrowned when a crowded passenger bus ran off the road and plunged into a canal near this city in northwest Mexico Saturday, the police reported today. Five other persons were missing.

title: Personal Finance: The New Tax Form
description: Although few have hegun preparing for their 1975 Federal income tax returns, the Internal Revenue Service has made advance proofs of the new forms available. A look at the form used for most personal returnsForm 1040 and its accompanying schedulespoints up the impact of the Tax Reduction Act of 1975.

title: Blue CrossBlue Shield Getting Joint Agency
description: For the first time, the alue Cross Association and the National Association of Blue Shield Plans are goingto promote  themselves in a joint advertising effort. That, of course, calls for a single advertising agency.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GRAPE DEAL The Brasserie, that subterranean 24hour French restaurant that hosts among others a variety of wearyeyed predawn allnight onthetowners, is launching a threeweek champagne harvest festival tonight.This means champagne for breakfast, champagne for lunch and champagne for dinner. Fifty labels of champagne will be available as well as breakfast chats about the wine with a French count on how to buy, store and serve champagne; daily 5 P. M. classes in restaurant French; and Mondays through Thursdays, at 11 P.M., French cooking classes. And frequent appearances of singers, cancan dancers and strolling musicians.

title: Lisbon and Chile: Diverse Paths
description: LISBON, Sept. 19Portugal is not Chile! they cry at every political demonstration and in private conversations. But the Portuguese nevertheless identify their revolution with Chile's lost cause. The late Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens has become a Portuguese national hero. and his portrait is seen everywhere.

title: ExMagistrate Ploscowe Dies; CriminalLaw Expert Was 71
description: Former Magistrate Morris Ploscowe, who had served on several important law commissions, died yesterday at New York University Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 125 Riverside Drive.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 (UPI)David Kotey of Ghana won the World Boxing Council's featherweight title from Ruben Olivares of Mexico last night, but the split decision had to be announced after the fighters had taken cover from the nearriot in the Forum ring. After the rugged 15rounder ended, the proOlivares crowd of 5,000 took over the ring. Kotey's trainer, Francis Clottey, was hit by a chair and had to be hospitalized. Ushers and security guards were showered with beer and debris. The State Athletic Commission Chairman Robert Turley, said: People talk about many of the African countries being the underdeveloped nations. Now I'm not so sure.

title: SYRIANS PERSIST IN EFFORT TO END LEBANON'S CRISIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 21A highranking Syrian mediation mission appeared determined today to patch together a durable truce among Lebanon's warring factions as an edgy calm settled over Bejrut.

title: DALEY SEEKS SWAY OVER CHICAGO JOBS
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 21 Mayor Richard J. Daley is seeking to scrap Chicago's Civil Service Commission to provide himself and his department heads with what he recently described as more flexible control over snore than 40,000 city jobs.

title: South African Rand Is Devalued 17.9%
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 21 (AP)A 17.9 per cent devaluation of the rand, effeclive tomorrow was announced by South Africa today to strengthen its balance of payments position. The nation, the world's largest gold producer has been hit by the dropping price of gold on world markets.

description: In his heyday as Soviet dictator, Nikita Khrushchev used to like to quote Lenin's prediction that sonic day gold would be used to make toilet seats. That day is hardly around the corner, but it is striking that gold this year has been providing vivid proofeven disastrous proof for some speculatorsthat in the midnineteenseventies prices can still go down, and even sharply.

Groh under strong pressure from Mayor Beanie is an encouraging attest to the Mayor's newfound determination to provide the kind of executive leadership needed if New York City is to rescue itself from fiscal and administrative disaster.

He was there to take advantage of a special offer of halffare tickets for those who could prove they were unemployed.workers rose from about 600,000 in the early sixties to a peak of 800,000 in the record year of 1973, when the Industry sold 11.4 million cars.

title: Learning to Live Together:
description: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. In the furor over the mythical evils of school busing and the purported inviolability of neighborhood schools, the nation has overlooked four essential points. School desegregation is a necessary, viable and important national goal. The Constitution requires it. Minority children will never achieve equal educational opportunity without it. And our children will never learn to live together if they do not begin to learn together now.

title: Hunt Said to Link Nixon Aide in Plot To Kill Anderson
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21E. Howard Hunt Jr., who is serving a jail term in Florida for his, role in the Watergate burglary, has told associates that he was asked about five years ago by a senior official in the Nixon White House to assassinate the syndicated columnist Jack Anderson, according to a report today in The Washington Post.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The 10 power companies serving the Delaware River Basin region said yesterday that they needed to build four fewer nucleargenerating stations in the next 14 years than they had estimated last year. In a revised report to the Delaware River Basin Commission, the electric companies said that power conservation efforts, the general economic downturn and revised estimates of future power demands indicated a reduced need for new facilities between now and 1989. The report dropped four nuclear stations that were proposed in 1974. They are the Delaware Bay plant near Bridgeton, N.J.; the Upper Delaware station near Point Pleasant, Pa.; the Portland, Pa., plant conversion from fossile fuel to a nuclear facility, and the Cliff nuclear station that would have been built near Cumberland, N.J.

title: Two Years of Pinochet
description: On the second anniversary of the putsch that brought him to power, President Augusto Pinochet announced a partial easing of Chile's state of siege. The tragedy is that the mental state of siege that afflicts the junta and dictates perpetuation of repression remains in full force. General Pinochet and his colleagues still see Chile as the toppriority target of a worldwide Communist conspiracy and are prone to regard all critics of their harsh rule as either agents or dupes of the Kremlin.

title: Books of The Times
description: As someone who believes in Freud, the unconscious mind and the decisive role of childhood experience in adult behavior, I felt basically sympathetic to what the psychoanalyst Herbert Hendin is trying to do in The Age of Sensation: A Psychoanalytic Exploration, which is an attempt to find out what's behind the rising incidence of suicide, sexual impotence and drug use among young people today. As the reaction to the youth upheavals of the nineteensixties continues to coalesce, some of the diagnoses of what really hap pened are beginning to sound as superficial and tendentious as the slogans broadcast by young people to explain what was wrong with the world in 25 words or less. So it a relief to see Dr. Hendin digging into the subsoil of rebellious behavior, and demonstrating that there was considerably more going on than parental permissiveness, instant gratification, worship of youth or even a rejection on the part of youth of the competitive technological society they were presumably being asked to embrace without questioning.

title: SteinSteingut Feud Turns a New Page
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein's simmering feud with Speaker Stanley Steingut has begun a new chapter that Steingut partisans contend should be entitled the Case of the Purloined Portfolio.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The Government announced today that it was removing the 60centabarrel fee on imported petroleum products, largely to end uncertainties about the future of the fee that were threatening to create shortages of imported home heating oil and heavy industrial fuel this winter.

title: 3 Die in Louisiana Mishap
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 21 (UPI)  An automobile driven by a hitandrun driver plowed into a group of men crabbing from a bridge on the OrleansSt. Benard Parish line today, killing three men and injuring three others. The police identified the dead as Joseph Martin, 30 years old; William Harrell Jr., 42, and his brother, Gerald Harrell, 33.

title: Screen: Lumet's 'Dog Day Afternoon'
description: "Dog Day Afternoon," which opened yesterday at the Cinema 1, is Sidney Lumet's most accurate, most flamboyant New York moviethat consistently vital and energetic Lumet genre that includes "The Pawnbroker" and "Serpico" and exists entirely surrounded by (but always separate from) the rest of his work. Mr. Lumet's New York movies are as much aspects of the city's life as they are stories of the city's life."Dog Day Afternoon" is a melodrama, based on fact, about a disastrously ill-planned Brooklyn bank robbery, and it's beautifully acted by performers who appear to have grown up on the city's sidewalks in the heat and hopelessness of an endless midsummer.If you can let yourself laugh at desperation that has turned seriously lunatic, the film is funny, but mostly it's reportorially efficient and vivid, in the understated way of news writing that avoids easy speculation.Each of the several principal lives it touches has been grotesquely bent out of shape. The director and Frank Pierson, who wrote the fine screenplay, don't attempt to supply reasons. The movie says only that this is what happened. No more. This severely limits the film's emotional impact, though not its seriousness or its fascination. "Dog Day Afternoon" is a gaudy street-carnival of a movie that rudely invites laughs at inappropriate moments, which is in keeping with the city's concrete sensibility.The incident on which the film is based was the attempt to rob a branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank on Aug. 22, 1972. The two bandits, one of whom was seeking money for a sex-change operation for a boyfriend, failed miserably, after they held the bank's employes hostage for 14 hours, appeared live on television, became the center of an impromptu neighborhood Mardi Gras, and negotiated for a jet plane to fly them out of the country.Mr. Lumet's film is exclusively concerned with the robbery attempt and the time it occupied. Only briefly does the film move out of the bank and away from the lower-middle-class neighborhood of apartments over pizza parlors, barber shops and barrooms. We occasionally see the neighborhood in a high, smoggy long-shot, the tar-paper shingles shimmering in the reflected heat.Most of the time the film stays contained within the bank. This concentration in space and time is responsible for much of the film's dramatic intensity.So too are the brilliant characterizations by the members of the large cast, including Al Pacino, as the (probably) more than a bit mad mini-mind of the holdup, a man with bravura style when he plays to the crowds outside the bank but apparently quite demented in his personal relationships.He vows his love for his wife and children and especially for his boyfriend, whom he had "married" in a drag wedding some months earlier with his mother as a witness. On the other hand, the boyfriend, played with just the right mixture of fear, dignity and silliness by Chris Sarandon, testifies that his would-be patron has tried to kill him on several occasions.The other characterizations that one remembers are those of Penny Allen as the bank's efficient head teller, Estelle Omens as a woman teller of a certain age who objects to profanity even under stress ("My ears aren't garbage cans"), John Cazale as Mr. Pacino's sidekick in crime, a man who doesn't smoke because "the body is the temple of the Lord," and James Broderick and Charles Durning as the chief representatives of the law. Of particular interest is Susan Peretz as Mr. Pacino's wife, in whom one sees the tangle of city distress, anger, sweetness and violence, which is one of the main things that "Dog Day Afternoon" is all about.

title: Accidental Death Toll in '74 Called Lowest on Record
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (UPI)The National Safety Council says the nation's death toll from all accidents decreased by nearly 11,000 last year compared with the 1973 toll and was the lowest death rate on record.
