title: MADRID'S MOVES HEIGHTEN TENSION
description: MADRID, Sept. 21Eleven death sentences against political terrorists in three weeks, the arrest of close to 200 persons, a crackdown on the press and sharpened hostility abroad to the Spanish Government have increased tension in Spain to the highest point since the assassination of Premier Luis Carrero Blanco in December, 1973.

title: Ukrainians Celebrate Centennial Here With Parade
description: Led by a group of redhatted Cossacks on horseback, a parada of more than a thousand UkrainianAmericans, including folk dancers and bands in native costume, marched down Fifth Avenue yesterday in the pouring rain to celebrate the American Bicentennial as well as the, 100th anniversary of Ukrainian settlement in the United States.

title: 5 Die in Iran Train Crash
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 21 (AP)A freight train and an oiltanker train collided in a tunnel in. southern Iran today, killing five crewmen and igniting several hundred barrels of crude oil, authorities said.

title: Lindsay Nauen Married
description: Lindsay Berta Nauen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Nauen of Sioux Falls. S. D., was married there yesterday afternoon, to Richard Harry Weil, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Weil of New York. Rabbi Eugene Hibshman performed the ceremony in Mount Zion Temple. The bride is an archivist with the Philadelphia Jewish Archives Center. Her husband is studying for a master's degree in environmental science at Drexel University.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The northbound lanes of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive between 23d and 28th Streets have been closed to traffic for two to five days while repairs are made and other structural problems are corrected, the Department of Highways has announced.

title: BRITISH EXAMINING DIEGO GARCIA ROLE
description: LONDON, Sept. 21British authorities are coming under increasing pressure to explain this country's role in the resettlement of more than 1,000 island residents to make way for an American naval base in the Indian Ocean.

title: Fire Reveals Reactors' Hazards
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21A major fire that six months ago knocked out the world's largest nuclear power plant may force utilities across the country to spend millions, possibly hundreds of millions, of dollars making safety improvements in their reactors.

description: Charles E. Crissey, who retired in 1963 as editor of The Guild Reporter, the publication of the Newspaper Guild, died yesterday in the Fairfax (Va.) Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: DAVID M. LEVY
description: David M. Levy, special events coordinator in the Green Haven Correctional Facility in Stormville, N. Y., died Saturday of a coronary attack in St. Francis Hospital, Poughkeepsie, N. Y. He was 49 years old and lived in Wappingers Falls. N. Y.

title: In Memoriam
description: SCHIFFMANBeatrice, departed Sept 22, 1968 In cherished memory of my beloved wife, darling mother, grandmother and sister. So deeply loved and sadly missed. Rest in peace Your loving family

Northwest Energy Planning ProRata Purchase of Apco
description: The Northwest Energy Company, whose revised cash tender offer for shares of the Apco Oil Corporation expired last Friday, announced that 2,695,185 shares had been tendered at $25 a share.

title: 800 L.I. Teachers Ratify Pact; Classes Are to Resume Today
description: FARMINGDALE, L. L, Sept. 21 Eight hundred striking teachers were scheduled to return to classes in the Half Hollow Hills school district tomorrow following ratification late tonight of a new threeyear contract.

title: SinatraFitzgeraldBasie Had Gross of $1.08Million
description: The Frank SinatraElla FitzgeraldCount Basie concert grossed a reported $1.08million for its twoweek, 16performance stand, which ended Saturday night at the 1,900seat Uris Theater on Broadway at 50th Street.

title: Elephants Are Declining. Rapidly in Africa
description: The African elephant, the largest land animal alive, is declining in numbers so rapidly that some wildlife experts fear that within a decade it may be on the verge of extermination in much, if not all, of Africa.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: 1975, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Court Action on Girl in Coma to Start Today
description: The New Jersey court system will begin today to undertake a review of the complex legal questions surrounding a proposed withdrawal of lifesustaining medical procedures from a terminally ill patient.

title: Wildcat Oilmen a Dying Breed
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 21  Wildcatter! The word itself helps perpetuate the image of the independent oilman: a twofisted, hard  drinking leather  faced Texas Yahoo with a nose for crude oil, an eye for wild women and a wallet stuffed with hundred dollar bills.

title: Saigon Economy Strained, Refugees Say
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 21Refugees coming out of South Vietnam say that economic conditions in Saigon are becoming increasingly difficult and that there is some continuing armed resistance to the Communists and a resistance radio that broadcasts daily.

title: Patriots Lose on Fumble, 70
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 21 The New England Patriots, who spent most of last week on strike, lost their opening game to the Houston Oilers, 70, today. But their walkout, which ended late Thursday afternoon, had less to do with the outcome of the game than rain, which first came down in volume at the start of the second quarter and continued to the end of the contest.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Prudence H. Bach Wed to A. N. Madia
description: Prudence Halle Bach, daughter of Julian Bach of New York and the late Mrs. Bach, was married yesterday to Anthony N. Madia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Madia of North Bergen, N. J. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father.

title: ROBERT L. BARBOUR
description: Robert L. Barbour, founder and president of the PR Publishing Company, which publishes directories and the weekly PR Reporter, a newsletter, all in the field of public relations, died Saturday in Alice Peck Day Day Memorial Hospital in Lebanon, N.H. He was 64 years old and lived in Meriden, N.H., where the company is situated.

title: Vulcans on Top With Late Rally
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 21 (AP)Matthew Reed, his receivers covered, ran 32 yards to cap a late comeback and give the Birmingham Vulcans a 2216 World Football League victory over Charlotte today.

title: Ronni Gordon Wed To Alan Eisenberg
description: Ronni Gail Gordon, a business reporter with Dun & Bradstreet, was married here yesterday morning to Alan Martin Eisenberg, an associate in the law firm of Hays, St. John, Abramson & Heilbron. The ceremony was performed in the GethEl Chapel of Temple EmanuEl by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel.

title: Petroleum Import Fee Off; Heating Oil Savings Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The Government announced today that it was removing the 60centabarrel fee on Imported petroleum products, largely to end uncertainties about the future of the feel that were threatening to create shortages of imported home heating oil and heavy industrial fuel this winter.

title: The Dance: Joyce Trisler's Company
description: Joyce Trisler's Danscompany, which gave a series of performances this weekend at the Theater of the Riverside Church, is a small, agreeably trained moderndance group that seems capable of giving modest but genuine pleasure, but lacks something in personal character.

title: Patricia Gilbert Is Bride
description: At Temple Sinai in Stamford. Conn., yesterday, Patricia Susan Gilbert, a graduate of Beaver College, was married to William Douglas Yaffa, an alumnus of Hobart College. Rabbi Samuel Silver performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Theodore D. Gilbert of Stamford and Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Yaffa of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Beame Urges Both Sides To End Musicians' Strike
description: Mayor Beame intervened in the musicians' strike yesterday, calling union and theater leaders to Grade Mansion last night to express his deep concern. The strike, started last Thursday, has shut nine Broadway musicals.

title: Boston Teachers Ready to Strike Today, Complicating Desegregation Campaign
description: BOSTON, Sept. 21Publicschool teachers here were preparing today to strike tomorrow in the face of a state court prohibition against work stoppage. The teachers' decision created another problem for Boston's school desegregation efforts.

title: Advertising
description: It looks is ff the Newspaper Advertising Bureau is the first group to come up with a method of testing advertising effectiveness through the farreaching new Universal Product Code.

title: New Malaysian King Sworn In at Rites In Kuala Lumpur
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 21 (UPI)Sultan Lahya Sept. 21 (UPI)Sultan Yahya Ibrihim was sworn in today for a fiveyear term as the sixth Paramount Ruler of Malaysia at a ceremony at the royal palace here.

title: Refiners Cut Fuel Useage
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) The American Petroleum Institute said over the weekend that the oilrefining industry had already achieved more than half the 15 per cent energy savings it promised within its otvn operations. In 1972, the A.P.I. reported, refineries burned about 11.5 barrels of oil for every 100 barrels refined into products.

title: Using Your Intelligence
description: Samuel A. Adams is an intelligence analyst, a specialist on Vietnam, who spent ten years in the Central Intelligence Agency. He liked the work, as he says. But he quit the C.I.A. in 1973 in frustration at the way lies and politics corrupted its function.

title: A Story, Fictional and True, of Homosexual Son
description: Dear Mama,

title: SHOP TALK
description: The problem at Putumayo is what to examine first. The selection of South American handcrafts in Dan Storper's small shop at 142 East 73d Street is almost overwhelming in its variety.

title: Shepp at Vanguard Gives a Jazz Show Blending New, Old
description: When Archie Shepp was in the forefront of those jazz avantgardists of the midnineteensixties whose music consisted largely of frantic shrieks and squeals, there were calmer moments when his performances on tenor saxophone suggested that, in other circumstances, he might have carried on the warm, bigtoned tradition of Ben Webster.

title: Bel Canto Opera Offers La Vida Breve
description: La Vida Breve, a zarzuelainfluenced opera composed by Manuel de Falla in the early years of this century, is too short and too flawed a work to have made much headway in the operatic repertory, but two popular dances and some vocally gratifying scenes for its soprano heroine have made it a matter of flickering interest over the years. It has been stage and recording vehicle for Victoria de los Angeles, and the Metropolitan Opera did it with Lucrezia Bori in 1926.

title: Radio

title: Image and Substance
description: The cheers with which the National Federation of Republican Women received President Ford's latest declaration of war on social spending undoubtedly were music to Candidate Ford's ears. The conservative audience in Dallas, deep in the heart of oilrich Texas, shouted a predictable No to the question whether the President should roll over and play dead as Congress passes more and more legislation to strangle free enterprise. And a resounding No again to the proposition that the Federal Government has an obligation to hardpressed cities such as New York.

title: GiantEagle Scoring
Jersey Consumer Notes
description: The state ombudsman for elderly nursing  home patients has been appointed and plans as one of his first policies to answer the special hot line phone himself every Wednesday. The line is used to receive complaints or information concerning the elderly.

title: Fernandez Beats Monaco at Forum
description: Taking charge of the fight from the opening bell, Jose Fernandez of the Dominican Republic won by a unanimous decision over Domenico Monaco of Brooklyn in a 10round lightweight bout Iast night before 2,023 at the Felt Forum.

description: The essence of experiment is failure, and there was plenty of failure to be seen at the opening of the 16th series of Dance Uptown at Columbia University last weekend. It was an evening of minor graces and horribly subdued virtues. To put no finer a point upon it, the performance was mildly awful.

description: Rutgers University opened a campaign yesterday to have Paul Robeson, one of the finest football players in the university's history, elected to the National Football Foundation Hall of Fame. title: Books of The Times
description: The flood of 1966 coated Venice with 40 inches of sludge: the popular imagination coats it with an equivalent layer of sentiment. Richard de Combray has somehow managed to write a splendid book about Venice by amalgamating these two layers. In Venice, Frail Barrier, he shows us the best and the worst of this fairytale city, explains why the world cares so much about it and Venetians care so little.

David Mathews, the new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, says he does not care so much about the nuts and bolts of health insurance, education programs or welfare reform as about government in generalits impact on peopleand about whether he will be able to put his mark on the monstersized agency he heads.

title: Business Briefs

Aggregate profits fell to $53.6million in July from $103.8million in June and are widely expected to show a Toss or a very small profit during August. Most of the poor showing was attributed to low trading volume.

Madison College of Harrisonburg, Va., was the host of the affair that was called the tournament of champions.

title: Notes on People
description: An official spokesman for the Shah of Iran, in an interview yesterday, denied persistent rumors in Teheran's diplomatic community that the reason the Shah sometimes appears drawn, worn and thin is that he is suffering from a lingering and increasingly grave malady. No man who is ailing could work under such pressure as he works under and could travel around the way he does, the spokesman said, adding that the Shah puts in a minimum of 12 hours of work a day. If he looks thinner now than he did five years ago, the spokesman said, it is, if anything, because of overwork and fatigue.

Thus, the predictable exchange of recriminations now raging between Mr. Weisl and the Beame administration may tell New Yorkers less than they need to know about why the parks are in such deplorable shape and what needs doing to improve matters.

Still, there was a lot of good music for a relatively low price.

description: TOKYO, Sept. 22Emperor Hirohito said today that he knew beforehand that Japan planned the attack on Pearl Harbor but that he was powerless to prevent it.

description: A sharp contraction in savings inflows in August was reported yesterday by the United States League of Savings Associations, supporting widespread indications that rising interest rates in the money markets have been attracting money away from savings accounts.

The work will be performed by the George A. Fuller Company, a division of Northrop.

title: Capital for Energy . . .
description: A vast commitment of capital will be required over the coming decade to allow this country to meet its energy needs, whether or not total energy independence is a practical national goal. Though the private sector is theoretically capable of generating the needed money, it is a proper role of the Federal Government to assure that investment is attracted where it will do the most public good.

title: STUDY BY REYNOLDS IS CITED BY BURMAH
description: LONDON, Sept. 22 (Reuters) R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., the giant American holding company with interests in tobacco, aluminum, petroleum and Foods, is conducting a study to determine whether Reynolds should buy the North American assets of the financially strapped Burmah Oil Company, Burmah said today.

title: 4 Thai Police Die in Ambush
description: BANGKOK Thailand, Sept. 22 (Reuters)About 150 Communist guerrillas ambushed a Government patrol in southern Thailand Saturday, killing four border policemen and wounding 16, the police said today. The clash took place about 150 miles north of the Malaysian border.

title: LANGUAGE IS TOPIC OF CONFERENCE HERE
description: About 500 specialists on the origins and evolution of language and speech met yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel to begin a fourday conference under the sponsorship of the New York Academy of Sciences.

title: Bennetts Australian Victor
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Sept. 22 (UPI)Vic Bennetts of Sydney shot 72 today for a fourround score of threeoverpar 287 and won the Australian professional golf championship. He finished three strokes ahead of Kel Nagle, Robert Taylor and Brian Moran, all of Australia.

title: Whitmore, in Film, Gives 'em Truman
description: It starts bumpily and against the grain. "Give 'Em Hell, Harry!" a filmed version of James Whitmore's monologue re-creation of Harry S. Truman, has a lot going against it.Almost any stage show put flatly and squarely on camera gives a weakened, strained effect, like coffee made with used grounds. Filming a monologue imitationa uniquely theatrical formis especially chancy.When a lone figure comes out on a stage to do something so seemingly impossible as juggle seven balls or imitate a courting elephant, the audience is at least briefly on his side. Its sympathy, its will to believe, can be quickly dissipated by a bad performance, but it is there for a while.Films are different. We are skeptical when they try to address us. Movies have to wait a little. We only assent slowly to a face talking to us from the screen; there has to be some preparation first. Perhaps that is why so many movies begin with long shots, aerial sequences, views of people going about their business and paying us no attention.And here is Mr. Whitmore straight off, sitting at a desk and trying to make us believe he is Harry Truman. We know he isn't Truman; he doesn't even look very much like him. And whom is he trying to fool, with his noisy snuffling after each especially trenchant remark? Stage devices come unbuttoned in front of the camera.And yet "Give 'Em Hell, Harry!," which is being shown for a limited run at the Ziegfeld Theater, works its way gradually past these problems. In the end, it captivates and even moves.For one thing, Mr. Whitmore may suffer the disadvantage of playing a stage part on the screen, but it is a first-rate stage performance. It is clear why his show has been such a success onstage in Washington. If at the start he is an actor straining away to imitate Truman, by the end he is the man.The script, put together by Samuel Gallu, is beautifully articulated and balanced. Mr. Gallu has taken a series of Truman confrontationswith General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, with the Ku Klux Klan, with the railroad unions, with a lawn mower back in Independenceand, using real quotations, friends' reminiscences and his own sensitive and restrained imagination, has made a portrait that is stirring as well as amusing.Perhaps the main force at work among all the craftsmanship is the way that Truman's authenticity  his sense of his limits and his additional sense that these limits were also possibilitieskeeps gnawing away at our awareness of what has happened since in American politics.In a way it took Richard M. Nixon to make Truman appreciated. How else could the sight of Mr. Whitmore fishing in his pocket for a stamp to mail a letter convey such a dramatic pang, a sense of the coarsened Presidential ethics of more recent times?

title: Cheers, Then a Shot, And Crowd Screams
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 The corner of Post and Powell is usually quiet and sedate. Here, just a few yards in on Post Street from Union Square, is the side entrance to the elegant St. Francis Hotel.

description: ALBANY, Sept. 22Governor Carey, outlining a plan today. to reorganize the State Mental Hygiene Department, urged politically oriented members of the Mental Hygiene Council, in cluding the State Republican chairman, to resign so that he could appoint replacement who have a professional or community interest in mental health problems.

description: MORRISTOWN, Sept. 22A Superior Court judge allowed constitutional issues to be raised today in the case of 21yearold Karen Ann Quinlan, whose parents are seeking to withdraw medical procedures that have kept her alive for five months.

title: NaturalGas Scarcity Said to Worsen
description: Consolidated Edison't chief forecast engineer said yesterday that shortages of natural gas for heating and cooking would be more severe this winter than had been predicted and that the fuel's cost to Con Edison already had risen 150 per cent in a year.

title: Market Members in Joint Float Decide to Allow Swiss to Join
description: BRUSSELS. Sept. 22  The Finance Ministers or the six European Common Market countries whose currencies float jointly agreed today to allow the Swiss franc to join the float.

title: Paper's Indictment Raises Question of Duty to Police
description: A Florida court case involving The Fort Myers NewsPress. one of the Gannett chain of daily newspapers, is raising once again the question of what obligation the press has to cooperate with law enforcement officials in criminal investiga, tions.

title: Jacksonville State Punished
description: HAMMOND, La., Sept. 22 (AP)The football program at Jacksonville State University in Jacksonville, Ala., has been placed on probation for one year and penalized by the Gulf South Conference commissioner, Stanley Galloway. Galloway said the university admitted violating conference and National Collegiate rules by staging an illegal scrimmage against an outside opponent.

title: White Plains Waits For H.U.D. Decision On Old Courthouse
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 22A twoyear struggle over the fate of a Westchester County courthouse is likely to be resolved early next year, with the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development deciding if the nowempty structure is to stand or fall.

title: British Soccer Standing
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Raiders Conquer Dolphins
description: MIAMI, Sept. 22 The Oakland Raiders beat the Miami Dolphins, 3121, tonight, a decision that marked the Dolphins' first defeat on their home field, the Orange Bowl, in 31 games covering almost four years.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: 1975. by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Monday, September 22. 26th day. Weather clear, track good.

title: Environmentalists and OilState, Conservatives Likely to Fight Plan for Energy Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22An unlikely coalition of environmentalists and oil state conservatives is expected to seek to scuttle President Ford's plan for a $100billion Government corporation to finance projects aimed at freeing the United States from dependence on foreign sources of energy.

title: Money
description: NEW YORI, VO JS Money rates for Prime rate 8.

title: Ishbel Ross, Biographer, Dies; Wrote About Prominent Women
description: Ishbel Ross, writer and novelist, was found dead early Sunday in the rear yard of an apartment house at 155 East 76th Street, where she lived. She was 79 years old.

title: Federal Workers' Union Warns of Walkouts on Pay
Elderly Merchant, Officer and 3d Man Shot in S.I. Fracas
description: An elderly candystore owner, a police officer and a podiatrist were all shot last night in a bizarre burst of gunfire that erupted as the merchant pursued two muggers with a .22calibre rifle in the Stapleton section of Staten Island, the police reported.

title: Pride and Pleasure Evident Beneath Usual Restraint
description: The Japanese residents of New York, ordinarily models of inconspicuousness in this teeming city, are preparing with customary restraint but with much pride and pleasure for the upcoming visit here next month of the Emperor and Empress of Japan.

title: Abraham Sachs, 93, Dies; Teacher and Businessman
description: Abraham Sachs, a retired publicschool teacher who later had a diversified business career, died Saturday in New York Hospital. He was 93 years old and lived at 300 East 71st Street.

title: DR.BERNHARD OLSON, INTERFAITH LEADER
description: Dr. Bernhard E. Olson, national director of the interreligious affairs department of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, died yesterday in Madison Avenue Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Baldwin, L.I.

title: J.W.O. VON HERBULIS
description: J. W. O. Von Herbulis, who retired in 1953 as vice president of the Waterman Steamship Company, died Sunday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L. I. He was 79 years old and lived at 153 Brompton Road, Garden City, L. I.

title: Exchange Seat Sold
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday a seat was sold on the exchange for $105,000, off $20,000 from the previous sale on Aug. 27. The exchange said the current market is $85,000 bid and $114,000 asked.

title: U.S. Aid to Israel and Egypt Is Expected to Cut Other Projects
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22To the extent that the new Middle Eastern aid package goes through Congress, it will inevitably lead the legislators to cut other foreign aid programs and perhaps the Pentagon budget, members of Congress and high Ford Administration officials predict.

title: Textile Man Is Shot to Death on East Side Streit
description: A 55yearold textile manu. facturer was shot to death yesterday morning near the East Side apartment building where he lived as he resisted what detectives said might have been a kidnapping attempt by, two men. His killers put his body into a car and left the car in front of a nearby hospital, where it remained unnoticed for two hours.

title: Namath's Knee, Jets Hurting
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 22 Blue Monday. The Jets were black and blue today. The films were blue. And their pride hurt more than the physical beating they suffered yesterday at the hands of the Buffalo Bills.

title: ExC.I.A. Analyst Denies Distortion Of Tet Troop Data
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Skepticism about their own conclusions and petty bureaucratic restrictionsnot deliberate distortion of the factsmuted the Central Intelligence Agency warning of the 1968 Communist Tet offensive in Vietnam, according to a former intelligence analyst.

title: People in Sports
description: Two weeks after having defected to the United States to escape the control of the Czechoslovak Tennis Federation, Martina Navratilova signed a threeyear contract yesterday with the Cleveland Nets of World Team Tennis.

title: Pact Ends 2Week Strike By Englewood's Teachers
description: ENGLEWOOD, Sept. 22Englewood's 300 public  school teachers and most of their 4,000 pupils were back in classrooms today after a strike by the Englewood Teachers Association. The city's seven schools had been closed for two weeks.

title: Fogle Opens Bid for Job With Knicks
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 22  The 197475 Canisius College basketball brochure began its tintype of Larry Fogle: What comes next is ultimately up to the boundless Fogle. As the New York Knicks opened their rookie training camp today at Monmouth College, the story remains unchanged for the offensively talented rookie.

title: COUNSEL CLEARS EXSCHOOLS AIDE
description: A special counsel retained by the Board of Education has cleared Dr. Edythe J. Gaines, a former top city school official, of any breach of law or ethics in connection with the 1970 award of a school contract to a computerservices company headed by her brother.

title: Memorial Service
F.B.I. Focus of Inquiry on Oswald Note
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The Justice Department has begun a criminal investigation of the circumstances surrounding the destruction of a letter threatening the Dallas police that was delivered by Lee Harvey Oswald to the Dallas office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation shortly before the, assassination of John F. Kennedy.

title: Hurricane Hits Gulf Coast With Heavy Rain and Wind
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 22 Hurricane Eloise, struck a fourstate area of the Gulf Coast with torrential rains and pounding seas tonight.

title: TestTube Nonsense
description: As a veteran rider of the New York subway, I was amazed at the innocence of the C.I.A. after learning that this supposedly cunning bunch of conspirators has been secretly using me to test underground killing devices.

title: GLOBAL RISE ASKED IN FOOD SUPPLIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The world has only a decade or less to start coping effectively with its population problem, according to a report issued today by the National Research Council.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Seoul in The New York Times yesterday recounted the death of a journalist who some opponents of the South Korean Government suggested had been murdered by Government agents. As the result of a typographical error the dispatch said that now proof of the charge has come to light, It should have said no proof has come to light.

title: Article 1  No Title
Chess
description: In sacrificing a rook for minor piece plus a pawn, very little material is lost; valuing a pawn as one, a minor piece as three and one half and a rook as five makes such an exchange sacrifice equal to giving up half a pawn. Consequently, in pulling off the exchange sacrifice, other factors, positional and tactical, determine success.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Theodore H. Black, Chancellor of the State Board of Regents, announced that he would urge his colleagues to eliminate a provision in the new teachers' contract that allows for cuts in instruction time for New York City public schools.

title: Market Place
description: Corporations that seek to go private and their dissenting shareholders would probably agree that present techniques for accomplishing that goal are unsatisfactory.

title: Today's Entries at Keystone
description: FIRST$3,500, cl., 3YO and up, 6f.

title: MGM Is Accused. By S.E.C. on Deals
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission accused MetroGoldwynMayer, the film maker, of engaging in transactions with its principal shareholder, Kirk Kerkorian, and failing to adequately include them in its public financial reports.

title: Kennedy Doubts Alleged Assassination Policy!
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)  Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that he was satisfied to a moral certainty that neither of his brothers, President John F. Kennedy and Senator Robert F. Kennedy. tolerated a policy of assassination.

title: N.F.L. Council Pension Proposal
Shows Open
description: Shows that are not affected by the strike:

title: Use of U.S. Foreign Units To Evade Taxes Scored
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (Reuters)  Major American corporations are using intricate new schemes to evade taxes through foreign operations, Internal Revenue Service commissioner Donald Alexander said today.

title: Aspin Says Few Navy Ships Are Prepared for Combat
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) Projections from official Navy inspection reports indicate that only about 6 per cent of the service's 500 ships may be fully combatprepared, a Congressman contends.

title: Hearst Inquiry Focuses on Possible Symbionese Role in April Bank Holdup
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22The Federal Bureau of Investil gation is focusing its attention. on an April 21 bank robbery to determine if Patricia Hearst's, associates in the radical group called the Symbionese Liberal tion Army had anything to do with it, an official source close to the investigation said today.

title: Freedoms Few in Cyprus Area
description: YIALOUSSA, Cyprus Panos Lazari's wife has not seen her parents for more than a year, even though they live only a few miles away. The children here cannot go swimming, the young men must report to the police twice a day and the fisherman are not allowed to use their boats.

title: Xerox to Cut Copier Price Soon And Rental Rate After Yearend
description: The Xerox Corporation announced yesterday that it would, reduce rental rates of copiers and duplicators for most commercial customers, starting Jan. 1. Purchase prices for most the equipment will be reduced immediately, the company added C. Peter McClough, chairman, acknowledged that this would have an adverse effect on nearterm copier and duplicator revenues. But he added:

title: People and Business
description: A huge number of trees could remain standing unless pulp and paper prices are allowed to rise, J. Stanford Smith, chairman of the International Paper Company, said here.

title: Bill Seeks to Broaden State's Control of Schools
description: TRENTON, Sept. 22The bill approved by the Legislature today calling for thorough and efficient education in the state's public schools would permit the Department of Education to implement a wide range of classroom reforms.

title: Syrians Pressing Mediation Effort as Beirut Truce Is Violated
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 22A Syrian mediation mission appeared to be running into difficulties in Lebanon today as a ceasefire arranged on Saturday night continued to be violated in several parts of Beirut.

title: OTB REVIEW URGED ON BUYING GARDEN
description: Three elected city and state officials called yesterday for public hearings on the proposed purchase of Madison Square Garden by the Offtrack Betting Corporation before any deal was completed.

title: HotAir Balloons Collide
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 (UPI)Two hotair balloons collided about 600 feet above ground yesterday, but the pilots were not injured. The balloons, taking part in a hotair balloon rally in Forest Park, landed safely in a clear area.

title: Rumania Adjusts Currency
description: VIENNA, Sept. 22 (Reuters) Rumania raised the value of the lei by about 2 per cent against several Western currencies, but left the rate for the dollar unchanged, the official Rumanian news agency said today.

title: Stock Prices Drop In Slower Trading
description: Stock prices turned lower yesterday as the market encountered profit taking after its twoday rally last Thursday and Friday.

title: U.S. PLANS TO TEST AUTOFREE ZONES
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 22 (UPI)  Experimental automobilefree zones will be established in several cities next, year with an eye toward keepling cars out of large downtown districts forever, the Federal Highway Administrator said today.

title: St.John Perse Dies
description: St.John Perse, the romantic poet who won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1960, died at the age of 88. Page 38.

title: Clemency Program On Draft Resisters Defended on Board
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 22 (UPI)The majority of the 18member Presidential Clemency Board today defended the board's yearlong effort to reconcile Vietnamera draft resisters and military deserters against criticism from a fourmember minority.

title: Honeywell History Given as U.S. Trial Of I.B.M. Resumes
description: The trial of the Government's antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation resumed yesterday after a 10week recess with James H. Binger, chairman of the executive committee of Honeywell, Inc., tracing his company's history in the computer industry.

title: Mediator, Gloomy on Musician Strike, Calls for Urgent Bargaining Session
description: The state's top mediator, warning of the possibility of long musicians strike, called an urgent bargaining session last night and said he was prepared to stay until dawn, if necessary, to achieve a settlement of the Broadway walkout that is cutting increasingly into midtown business.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1975

title: FORD ESCAPES HARM AS SHOT IS DEFLECTED; WOMAN SEIZED WITH GUN IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22A shot was fired at President Ford as he stepped out of a downtown hotel here today, but a civilian bystander deflected the gun just as it went off and the President was not hit.

title: U.S. Sues Over Fees for Anesthesia, Alleging Conspiracy by Doctors' Group
description: An antitrust suit was filed by the Justice Department yesterday charging the American Society of Anestheisiologists with conducting a conspiracy to raise, fix and maintain fees for anesthesia services.

title: COORS BREWERY SUED BY U.S. OVER HIRING
description: DENVER, Sept. 20 (UPI)The Government has filed a hiring discrimination suit against Adolph Coors Company, the brewing concern headed by President Ford's nominee to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A woman fired a gunshot at President Ford as he stepped out of the St. Francis Hotel in San Francisco yesterday afternoon, but a civilian bystander deflected the weapon just as it went off and the President was not hit. The bullet struck the pavement, ricocheted up and slightly wounded a man in the crowd of more than 3,000 people that had gathered outside the hotel to catch a glimpse of the President. Police officers and Oliver Sipple, a 30yearold former Marine who had deflected the weapon, pounced on the assailant who was later identified as Sara Jane Moore, a 46yearold activist who had been questioned by the Secret Service Sunday night but was not detained. The crowd broke into screams at the sound of gunfire. Mr. Ford, stunned momentarily, doubled over and was immediately shielded and rushed by Secret Service agents to his limousine. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Bag Limits
description: John M. Anderson, National Audubon Sanctuary director, has sharply criticized some of the 197576 waterfowl huntingbag limits.

title: An Exhibition Is Opened Here on the Imperial Family
description: Standing before two ornate goldembossed thrones used for many years by Emperor Hirohito and Empress Nagako, to a background of exotic court music, dignitaries of Japan and New York City cut a tape yesterday to open a 10day exhibition here on the imperial family of Japan.

title: Italian City in Uproar at Babies' Death
description: AVELLINO, Italy, Sept. 19This is one of those crowded, rather poor cities in the southern Apennines with a pleasant town square, two swans, a plaque to the 19thcentury patriot Giuseppe Garibaldi, boys who shoot at pigeons with sling shots and, now, a tragedy.

title: AntiDefamation Unit Urges Ford Not to Name Eckerd
description: MIAMI, Sept. 22 (AP)The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith said today that it had asked President Ford not to appoint a Clearwater businessman, Jack Eckerd, as administrator of the General Services Administration.

title: Buses Won't Make Room For the HalfDollar
description: When is a subway token worth more than a 50cent piece? When you step onto a city bus.

title: Main Strength Registered in Primary Metals
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22New orders flowing to manufacturers of durable goods rose again in August, but by the smallest amount since the pickup in orders began last spring, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Musicless Broadway
description: The musicians' strike that has cast a pall over Broadway is another in the long series of labormanagement tragedies that dim hopes for New York's economic survival. The featherbedding rules mandated by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians have over the years militated against putting musical productions on the stage at all. The result has been a steady reduction in job opportunities for musicians and, with magnificent illogic, an attendant intensification in membership pressure to keep the rules as job protection.

title: Hunt Brothers Trial Told About Wiretap Payments
description: LUBBOCK. Tex., Sept. 22Three convicted wiretappers testified today that two sons of H. L. Hunt, the late billionaire, agreed to pay them $15 an hour to eavesdrop on six employes of the Hunt Oil Company in 1969.

title: Dividends
JAPANESE SAYS RIFT WITH U.S. IS HEALED
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22  Japan's Foreign, Minister said today that trust between Tokyo and Washington had been restored after earlier misunderstandings, and declared that the economies of his own nation and of the United States had seen the worst and were on the way to recovery.

title: City Consumer Aide Says State Doesn't Cooperate
description: The chief law enforcement official for the City Department of Consumer Affairs says his agency and the office of the State Attorney General are wasting their resources by duplicating investigations and lawsuits against the same companies.

title: N.F.L. Offers New Contract; No Progress Is Made in Talks
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP)The National Football League owners made their promised contract proposal to the players' union today, but a full days of negotiations failed to break the logjam in the 19month labor struggle.

title: Pride and Pleasure Evident Beneath Usual Restraint
description: The Japanese residents of New York, ordinarily models of inconspicuousness in this teeming city, are preparing with customary restraint but with much pride and pleasure for the upcoming visit here next month of the Emperor and Empress of Japan.

title: U.S. Seeking AtomExport Pact in 1975
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22In a move to prevent the spread of the capacity to make atomic arms, the United States wants to complete an agreement with six other countries by the end of the year on safeguards and controls for the export of nuclear fuel and fuelreprocessing technology.

title: Fiat Opens U.S. Headquarters in Montvale
description: MONTVALE, Sept. 22Fiat, the Italian automobile producer, officially opened its new United States headquarters here today. It joined a half dozen or so major corporations that have moved into new office buildings in this fourmilesquare suburban town in the last few years.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Magellan to MacArthur to Muhammad
description: MANILA, Sept. 22Only the backdrops change. The voice remains the same. So do many of the words. In the Mod Folk Arts Theater that juts into Manila Bay, the voice of Muhammad Ali today droned into the microphone.

title: J. MALCOLM M'FARLAND
description: J. Malcolm McFarland, a lawyer with the New York admiralty firm of Haight, Gardner, Poor & Havens, died Sunday of a heart attack at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 51 years old and lived in Cranberry, N.J.

title: Bomb Injures Three at Hotel In the West End of London
description: LONDON, Sept. 22A bomb exploded near the entrance of the Portman Hotel in the West End of London tonight injuring three people slightly and shattering big plateglass windows.

title: Shows Closed
description: The shows closed by the strike of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians:

title: State Justice Post Filled
description: ALBANY, Sept. 22 (UPI)William T. Bonacum, 52 years old, a retired New York City police inspector, has been named deputy commissioner of the state's Division of Criminal Justice Services, to manage the division's $8.3million identification and information service, which provides computerized criminal history information to law enforcement agencies.

title: GEORGE KETCHUM, FOUNDED AD AGENCY
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22George Ketchum, founder and former president of Ketchum, MacLeod & Grove, Inc., a Pittsburghbased international advertising and public relations agency, died here today. He was 82 years old.

title: Assassination Fever
description: The gunshot at perilously close range from which President Ford escaped in San Francisco yesterdayjust a little more than a fortnight after the last assassination attemptmakes it clear that Presidential security requires something more than brave declarations that a Chief Executive has an obligation to stay close to his people, no matter what the risk.

title: Kissinger, at U.N., Asks Freer Forum on Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22Secretary of State Kissinger proposed today an informal meeting of key nations as a possible new approach for clearing the way to further diplomatic progress in the Middle East.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: ACCUSER CHARGED IN SUFFOLK INQUIRY
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 22Roger Barry Petersen, the 22yearold handyman who has accused Henry F. O'Brien, the Suffolk District Attorney, of sodomy, recently impersonated a police officer to interview witnesses in the case and used a detective's badge supplied by the Suffolk police, according to wellplaced officials in the Police Department here.

title: SUSPECT ASSERTED SHE HELPED F. B.I.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22Sara Jane Moore, the woman arrested here today after a gun was fired near President Ford, recently contended that she once was an informant for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a volunteer worker among several civil rights and leftist groups.

title: In Shadow of Brother
description: During most of his prolific writing career, Max Wylie was in the literary shadow of his brother Philip, two years older whose novel Generation of Vipers, published in 1942, added the word momism to the American lexicon to describe the emasculating matriarch.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)Warning of possible unauthorized walkouts, the American Federation of oGvernment employes called today on the House to approve a 8.66 per cent pay increase for Government workers and hold Congressmen to n 5 per cent raise.

title: St.John Perse Dies
description: St.John Perse, the romantic poet who won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1960, died at the age of 88. Page 38.

title: FUTURES IN GOLD DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Gold futures slid sharply again yesterday to new contract lows on the Commodity Exchange. The October delivery closed at $133 1/10 an ounce, after being as low as $132. The decline in the last week has taken the price down more than $15 an ounce.

title: A Torrent of Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22It was raining torrents in Washington tonight, and there were torrents of questions about the personal safety of the President of the United States and about people who want to he President. The central question was whether the President, chosen for his job or fallen heir to it, can move among the people, talk to them, shake their hands, commune with them and come out alive.

title: Court Backs Pension Fund Use For Purchasing M.A.C. Bonds
description: ALBANY, Sept. 22Investment of $1.25million in state pension funds in bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, authorized by the State Legislature to keep New York City financially stable, is not a violation of pension safeguards guards contained in the State Constitution, Justice A. Franklin Mahoney of Troy ruled today in State Supreme Court.

title: . . . Directing the Flow
description: The dollar amount of energy investment required in this country through 1985, vast though it is, is not as big a problem as managing the optimum distribution of that investment among the various energy sectors. Several recent studies by Government and private economists, based on historical trends, agree that the economy can comfortably generate upward of $400 billion for energy investment between now and 1985.

title: New Techniques in Europe Bring Excess Lake of Wine
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 22The southern coast of Sicily and the fertile Languedoc region of France's Mediterranean Coast have been producing simple wines since Roman times. In the last decade, a mixture of modern vineyard technology and European agricultural politics has brought a revolutionary increase in the output of these and other regions of southern Europe, creating an unsellable wine lake that has become a major point of division among the members of the European Common Market.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NEW VOGUE For the second time in its history the Sotheby Parke Bernet galleries will hold an auction devoted entirely to photographs. Last February, the gallery held its first, in a sale that saw a familiar photograph called Steerage, by Alfred Stieglitz, sold for $4,500.

title: Associated Names Chief; Saks President at Magnin
description: Two of the country's major retail companies announced yesterday top management changes, one involving a coasttocoast move.

title: $200,000 Jewelry Theft Reported in Midtown Home
description: Detectives of the Manhattan burglary squad yesterday investigated the reported theft of $200,000 in jewelry from the apartment of Joseph DiLiberto, a commodities broker, and his wife, Linda, at 860 United Nations Plaza.

title: Leviathan and LaissezFaire
description: There is another side to the current disaffection with political government, party and the whole political habit of mind that has been so widely noted.

title: Mets' Records
RALLY CONTINUES IN DEBT MARKET
description: The rally in most fixedincome securities continued into its fourth day yesterday, as prices in both the corporate and government sectors closed higher. The twoyear notes auctioned by the Treasury last Tuesday at an average yield of 8.44 per cent were trading yesterday at prices to return 8.07 per cent.

title: RELIEF TO RESUME IN ORANGE COUNTY
description: Orange County, which has not paid any Medicaid claims ??ince last Tuesday, agreed yes?? to obey a state court ??irective that it allocate $1.5million in county funds for ??elfare fare and social service needs.

title: An Attractive Rizzoli Joins Union Square Bookshops
description: A champagne party, attended by representatives of book publishing and other communications media, the diplomatic and literary world and members of the Rizzoli organizations, including Angelo Rizzoli, head of the Milanbased multinational company, marked the opening of Rizzoli's downtown branch at the northwest corner of Union Square last night.

title: INDIA COURT BACKS FREEDOM OF PRESS
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 22 high court in New Delhi today upheld the freedom of the press, in a case involving the controversial dismissal of B. G. Verghese, one of the capital's most influential newspaper editors.

title: Prince Lays Part of Candide Deficit To Cost of Musicians We Don't Need
description: Angry about the musicians strike that has shut down his show Candide and eight other Broadway musicals, Harold Prince, the producerdirector, reloased some figures yesterday to demonstrate why producers are reluctant to grant musicians salary increases.

title: Red Sox Beat Yankees, 64, And Raise Lead to 4 Games
description: Cast in the role of spoilers in a pennant race they had expected to win, the Yankees spoiled nothing last night but a rainy Monday evening as the Boston Red Sox beat them, 64, at Shea Stadium and extended their lead to four games over the idle Baltimore Orioles.

title: G.M. TO RAISE OUTPUT OF NEW CHEVETTE
description: DETROIT, Sept. 22  The president of the General Motors Corporation, E. M. Estes, said today the corporation was planning to speed up production of its new Chevette to 65 units an hour from the 60 units it is scheduled to be turning out by midOctover.

title: BREZHNEV MEETS 3 U.S. ASTRONAUTS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22Leonid I. Brezhnev welcomed the Apollo and Soyuz astronauts at the Kremlin today, greeting each of them as a hero and using the occasion to talk of peace and of his hope for a treaty to limit nuclear arms.

title: Max Wylie, Writer, Murder Victim's Father, Is
description: FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Sept. 22 (AP)  Max Wylie novelist, playwright and former radio advertising executive, shot himself to death in a motel room last night, the police said today. He was 71 years old.

title: An OwnerBreeder Gets Thrill Betting on His Horses
description: Alan Rosoff looked up from his Racing Form when Joe Shea, the jockey agent, joined him at a table in the Belmont Park Terrace.

title: ALICE J. FAIRBANKS
description: Alice J. Fairbanks, a highschool teacher who retired in 1962 from the Washington school system, died Friday in the Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington, N.J., where she lived. She was 79 years old.

title: U.S. Warns Panama Not to Air Details Of Talks on Canal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The United States warned Panama today that public airing of purported negotiating positions on a new Panama Canal treaty could hinder the balancing of mutual interest that makes any such treaty possible.

title: Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: National League

title: Clyde Tunnel Bombed
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, Sept. 22 (AP)The automobile tunnel under the Clde River was closed for several hours last night after an explosion, following a warning from an extremist group called the Tartan Army that a bomb had been planted in the tunnel. The police said the damage was minor. The extremist group, about which little is known, has claimed responsibility for two recent explosions on an oil pipeline and a Glasgow suburban railroad line.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Seoul in The New York Times yesterday recounted the death of journalist who some opponents of the South Korean Government suggested had been murdered by Government agents. As the result of a typographical error the dispatch said that now proof of the charge has come to light. It should have said no proof has come to light.

title: A Torrent of Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22It was raining torrents in Washington tonight, and there were torrents of questions about the personal safety of the President of the United States and about people who want to he President. The central question was whether the President. chosen for his job or fallen heir to it, can move among the people, talk to them, shake their hands, commune with them and come out alive.

title: FORD WON'T STOP SEEING THE PUBLIC
description: WASHINGTON, Tuesday Sept. 23President Ford pledged today that despite the second attempt on his life in 17 days he would not capitulate to wouldbe attackers by altering his personalized, handshaking style of meeting the public.

title: A Harsh Report On Rocky
description: It will be weeks before the Moreland Act Commission investigating New York's nursing home scandals makes its formal report, but a draft memorandum to be circulated among the members takes a harsh view of former Gov. Nelson Rockefeller. If the ultimate commission report echoes the memorandum, Mr. Rockefeller's campaign for renomination to the VicePresidency could be seriously damaged.

title: LongLost Brahms Sonata Is Played
description: In the last months before he died, Brahms is said to have assessed his unpubliRhed manuscripts sternly and burned piles of music. Anyone who has heard composers discuss their own work recognizes how dangerous it might be to let them be the sole judges of their children. Music, you might protest, is too important to be entrusted to composers, rather in the way that war is too important to be entrusted to generals.

title: SAIGON IS ISSUING A NEW CURRENCY
description: SINGAPORE, Sept. 22 (Reuters)South Vietnam's Provisional Revolutionary Government today announced the creation of a new currency to replace the devalued money of the former government.

title: Prices on Amex Rise Slightly, While NASDAQ Closes Lower
description: The American Stock Exchange index moved up 0.04 yesterday following a week of strong gains and closed at 86.80. But more issues declined than advanced289 to 261.

title: Useful U.N. Initiatives
description: Secretary of State Kissinger's tour of the diplomatic horizon at the United Nations General Assembly yesterday suggested useful initiatives on three major world problems: the Middle East, Korea and the control of nuclear energy for peaceful uses.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Exxon Giving $200,000 for South St. Seaport Park
description: The Exxon Corporation announced yesterday that it would donate $200,000 to the South Street Seaport in a Bicentennial grant to be used to construct a park at Fulton and Water Streets.

title: F.B.I. Focus of Inquiry on Oswald Note
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The Justice Department has begun a criminal investigation of the circumstances surrounding the destruction of a letter threatening the Dallas police that was delivered by Lee Harvey Oswald to the Dallas office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation shortly before the assassination of John F. Kennedy.

title: 2D COAST EPISODE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22A shot was fired at President Ford as he stepped out of a downtown hotel here today, but a civilian bystander deflected the gun just as it went off and the President was not hit. A woman suspect was arrested immediately.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Basic training will continue at Fort Dix, the Army's sprawling camp in Wrightstown, Representative Edwin Forsythe, Republican of Moorestown, has reported. According to Mr. Forsythe, Secretary of the Army Martin Hoffmann told the House appropriations subcommittee that troop strength at Fort Dix would remain at least at its present level so long as he was Secretary.

title: Bombing Attacks Hit 10 Towns in Ulster; 15 Reported Injured
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 22At least 10 towns were hit by bomb explosions today in the worst day of violence in northern Ireland since the I.R.A. Provisionals' ceasefire began in February.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMOWITZAnna P., devoted wife of the late Dr. E. William Abramowitz, loving mother of Florence Molse. Adored grandmother of Elaine and David Moise Dear sister of May Periman, Della Jones and William Periman. Services, Wednesday, 1 P.M., at the Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: ASSERTED SHE HELPED F. B. I.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 Sara Jane Moore, the woman arrested here today after a gun was fired near President Ford, recently contended that she once was an informant for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a volunteer worker among several civil rights and leftist groups.

title: Concorde Model Is Burned
description: PARIS, Sept. 22 (AP)A fire early today caused extensive damage to the interior of the fullsized model of the FrenchBritish Concorde airliner, on display at Orly Airport outside Paris. Firemen said they believed the cause was a shortcircuit.

title: FINLAND ELECTS NEW PARLIAMENT
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Tuesday, Sept. 23Finland has chosen a new Parliament in an election called six months early because of the nation's economic problems, but the changes that the balloting produced were relatively small.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday. Sept. 22. 1975

title: Constitutional Issue Raised by Lawyer in GirlinComa Case
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J. Sept. 22A Superior Court judge allowed constitutional issues to Ihe raised today in the case of 21yearold Karen Ann Quinlan, whose parents are seeking to withdraw medical procedures that have kept her alive for five months.

title: MCA Sets Accord In Move to Acquire Shares of Putnam's
description: MCA, Inc., has agreed to acquire all of the outstanding shares of G. P. Putnam's Sons, Sid Sheinberg, president and chief operating officer of MCA, and Walter J. Minton, presi dent of Putnam's, announced jointly yesterday. One MCA share is to be exchanged for each four shares of Putnam's.

title: Bridge:
description: The growing number of enthusiasts who regard headtohead team matches as the most satisfying form of the game have a wide choice of events during the coming season. The following eight knockout contests will be played in the metropolitan area, and will continue for eight months or more:

title: Rivers Evaluates Proposal
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.. Sept. 22lit looks to me like the only big change is the one on the pensions, said Jamie Rivers, a Jets' linebacker, today after reading the contract proposal submitted by the N.F.L. The pension change is a good one.

title: Rhodesia to Set Up Panel With Power Over Press
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 22 (AP)The Rhodesian Government has announced new emergency powers to control the press.

title: HIGHER SUM IS URGED IN U.S. RAILROAD AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)  Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman Jr. urged Congress today to increase the Federal commitment to reorganizing financially ailing Northeast and Midwest railroads from $1billion to as much as $2.1billion.

title: Pirates Beat Phils, Clinch N.L. East
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22 (AP)Richie Zisk and Dave Parker drove in four runs each tonight to help the Pittsburgh Pirates clinch their fifth National League East title in six seasons with an 113 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Cheers, Then a Shot, And Crowd Screams
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 The corner of Post and Powell is usually quiet and sedate. Here, just a few yards in on Post Street from Union Square, is the side entrance to the elegant St. Francis Hotel.

title: T. & T. REPORTS MISUSE OP FUNDS
description: In a partial disclosure announcement, the American. Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that an internal audit of its books and those of Bell Telephone System subsidiaries had found scattered instances of improper use of corporate funds, mostly for political contributions. Omitted from the disclosure were timings concerning the Southern and Southwestern Bell companies, currently under investigation by government authorities for alleged illegal activities.

title: The Strategy That Liberated Portugal
description: LISBONAs Mario Soares saw two visitors out of his Rua de Malpique apartment last March, one reminded him that they had first met at lunch in Paris during his long exile there.

title: Kibbee Rejects $64Million Cut In the City University's Budget
description: Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee has rejected what he called an unexpected request from the City Budget Bureau for a cut of $64million from the City of $64million from the City University system's current budget.

title: F.B.I. Agent on Coast Loses Audience to Ford
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept, 22 (AP)Charles W. Bates, special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in charge of the Patricia Hearst case, was conducting a news conference today when the Presidential assassination attempt was announced. The 15 reporters raced out of the news conference, leaving Mr. Bates without an audience.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif.  David Kotey, 126, Ghana, outpointed Ruben Olivares, 126, Mexico, 15, winning the World Coxing Council featherweight title.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: MEXICAN CHIEF'S SUCCESSOR NAMED
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 22Mexico's longruling government party today announced its choice of the Finance Minister, Jos Lpez Portillo, to succeed President Luis Echeverria Alvarez when his sixyear term expires in December of 1976.

title: A Willowbrook Aide Is Slain in Robbery By 2 in South Bronx
description: A mentalhygiene therapy aide at the Willowbrook Development Center on Staten Island was shot to death Sunday in her fourthfloor apartment in the South Bronx by robbers. The woman, 48yearold Gladys Rambert, was found on the kitchen floor of her apartment, at 941 Tiffany Street by her 13yearold grandson, whose name was withheld by the police.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Loophole in New U.S. Election Law Opposed by Democrats but Is Favored by G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 22The Federal Election Commission has discovered still another gaping loophole in the new law that sought to limit political spending in general and put a specific $10million ceiling on any candidate's overall expenditures to win his party's nomination. There is no limit, it turns out, on what an individual can raise and spend to get elected as a convention delegate. And even if he is running pledged to a particular Presidential candidate (President Ford, for example) his spending does not count against that candidate's $10million limit.

title: Solomon Upset In First Round
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 (AP)  Jeff Borowiak upset Harold Solomon, 63, 64, in the first round of the $100,000 Fireman's Fund tennis tournament today.

title: REPORT IS ISSUED ON 10DAY CLEANUP
description: The 10day crash cleanup of New York came to an unspectacular end Sunday with more than half of the city's streets still filthy, Anthony T. Vaccarello, the mayoral aide who directed the effort for Mr. Beame, reported yesterday.

title: FORD TO ASK DRIVE FOR U. S. ENERGY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22President Ford said today that next week he would ask Congress for authority to begin a $100billion program to give the United States energy independence in 10 years or less.

title: Suffolk Confrontation
description: Any political organization that loses a district attorney is in trouble, a Suffolk County conceded earlier this year after the first Democratic District Attorney in the history of Suffolk County was elected. And so it seemed until this month when the Suffolk County Police Commissioner, a Republican under investigation himself, made one of the most bizarre moves by a public official in the memory of even veteran politicians.

title: FORD WON'T STOP SEEING THE PUBLIC
description: After the latest apparent attempt on his life yesterday, President Ford told his youngest son, Steven, that he was still undeterred from making public appearances.

title: World Football League
Sony Net Tumbles 27.7% in Quarter
description: The Sony Corporation, the Japanbased electronics company widely known in the United States for its audiovisual products line, reported a 27.7 per cent drop in net income for its third fiscal quarter, ended July 31.

title: Four More Beame Aides May Lose Their Positions
description: Four more Beame administration officials, including the heads of two of the city's superagencies, face the possible loss of their jobs in the coming reorganization of the city's governmental structure, sources at City Hall said yesterday.

title: Antiblackout Sports Law Supported
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)Sports events sold out before game time should continue to be televised locally, Reprecentative Torbert H. Macdonald, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today. His statement was strongly endorsed by Richard E. Wiley, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, and John A. Schneider, president of the CBS Broadcast Group.

title: Kissinger, at U.N., Asks Freer Forum on Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22Secretary of State Kissinger proposed today an informal meeting of key nations as a possible new approach for clearing the way to further diplomatic progress in the Middle East.

title: Van Pelt Gives Performance Long Awaited by the Giants
description: It's the first quarter of the Giants' season opener, and as Mike Boryla of the Eagles tosses a screen pass to John Tarver, Bill Lueck, Philadelphia's right guard, turns to block a Giant defender directly in front of him.

title: C.B.O.E. to Add 4 Stocks
description: Four new stock options will be added to trading by the Chicago Board Options Exchange on Sept. 26, the exchange said yesterday. It listed them as AMP, International Flavors, National Semiconductor and Williams.

title: School Principal and 5 Girls Killed in CarTrain Crash
description: GARDNER, Ill., Sept. 23 (AP)The principal of Goodfarm Grade School and five young girls were killed on their way home from a softball game when their automobile collided with an Amtrak Turboliner, the police say.

title: Gov. Brown Signs Bills Tightening 2 Gun Laws
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. (AP)  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. signed bills today imposing mandatory sentences for persons convicted of using guns in commiting serious crimes and requiring purchasers of guns to wait 15 days for delivery.

title: 2d Threat Against Ford Spurs New Action by House Panel to Curb Handguns
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Today, one day after the second attempt in three weeks to shoot at President Ford, the chairman of a House subcommittee studying gun control introduced a bill that would ban the manufacture, sale importation and possession of handguns and handgun ammunition, except for police and military purposes.

title: Food Prices Here Show a Rise Again
description: Sales on bottomround roast brought its average retail cost down 13 cents a pound last week to $1.77, but increases in other food items offset this and other reductions and the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City rose 0.1 per cent, according to the city Department of Consumer Affairs

title: Britain Drops Two Missiles; Will Use Foreign Weapons
description: LONDON, Sept. 23 (Reuters) Britain today canceled work on two of its missiles and announced that it would replace them with weapons purchased abroadfrom America's McDonnell Douglas and from a FrenchGerman combine.

title: Weisl Charges Pressure To Hire on Political Basis
description: One of the most frustrating experiences Edwin Weisl Jr. said he had as Parks Commissioner was the handling of rsums with the name of a Democratic leader penciled in the margina signal that the person should be hired.

title: People and Business
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister, said yesterday that his country would call for an oilprice freeze at the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries opening today In Vienna.

title: GROMYKO URGES MIDEAST PARLEY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, in an address to the General Assembly, said today that the Geneva peace conference was the appropriate mechanism for dealing With Middle East problems.

title: NEW STRIKES SET AT PAPER MILLS
description: MONTREAL. Sept. 23 (UPI) The Canadian Paperworkers Union announced strikes today against three more Quebec pulp and paper mills, bringing to. 11 the number of plants closed in central Canada.

title: Notes on People
description: The threeyear effort by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to deport John Lennon was temporarily suspended yesterday on humanitarian groundsthe pregnancy of his wife, Yoko Ono.

title: Wallace Opposed in Poll
description: In a sampling of Democrats and independents, 39 per cent say they could not vote for Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama if he received the Democratic Presidential nomination, Louis Harris, the pollster, said yesterday, However, of 19 names listed as possibilities for the Democratic nomination, Mr. Wallace led as first choice of 14 per cent of the 973 Democrats and independents questioned.

title: REALTY SUIT WINS $1MILLION AWARD
description: A State Supreme Court jury has awarded $1million in damages to two brothers who charged that they had been cheated by the First National City Bank, its realestate subsidiary and a broker in the sale of their midtown property for less than its true value.

title: CAIRO '67 WAR CHIEF BELIEVED POISONED
description: CAIRO, Sept. 23 (AP)Egypt's former War Minister was apparently poisoned in September, 1967, three months after the Egyptian armed forces were vanquished by Istael, and did not commit suicide as the Government announced at the time, security officials said today.

title: About Real Estate
description: High above Lexington Avenue these days, a construction crane with a boom 105 feet long is lifting the structural steel for the new Citicorp Center into place. It is a critical time in the birth of a skyscraper. The ironworkers, at a level 10 stories over the street, are building the trusses that will take the load of the 46 floors above and distribute it through the stiltlike legs and the central core of the tower and on into the ground.

title: PANAMA ASSESSES CANALPACT TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The Panamanian Government says it and the United States are still far apart on essential aspects of a new Panama Canal treaty.

title: Western Governors See Flaw In New Ford Energy Program
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Sept. 23President Ford's proposal to create a $100billion Federal authority to help the nation gain energy independence with 10 years came under fire today at the Western Governors Conference for its apparent failure to include energy conservation measures as part of the program.

title: BABCOCK & WILCOX PLANS UNIT SALE
description: The Babcock & Wilcox Company announced yesterday that it would sell its 23 per cent interest in Babcock & Wilcox, Ltd., in Britain to British investors but would continue its relationships with the British concern. The American company will receive about $27million for its interest, or less than book value.

title: HUNT CASE WITNESS TELLS OF WIRET APS
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 23A convicted wiretapper testified today, as the Government rested its case, that he had warned William Herbert Hunt it was dangerous to tap the telephones of top Hunt Oil Company employes.

title: City Projects Face 30% Fuel Rise In Con Ed Shift From Gas to Oil
description: About 6.000 tenants in Mitchel  Lama cooperative apartments and 18,000 in city housing projects face a 30 per cent increase in their fuel costs Nov. 1, when Consolidated Edison automatically switches the heating systems in their buildings from natural gas to oil.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: ERogers, Foli DPMontreal 1. LOBSt. Louis 7, Montreal 8. 2BK.Hernandz. Bilttner Jorgensen, Sizemore, Parrish, Mumphrey. 3BMackanin HRJorgensen (15) SBDwyer Foli, Brock.

title: Ranger Previews Open with Cast of 25 Tonight
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Sept. 23The New York Rangers, who will open their 10game exhibition schedule tomorrow night against the Boston Bruins in Providence, R. I., will take 23 players with them, including four goaltenders.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an account of a new management organization by the RCA Corporation in The New York Times last Saturday, one of RCA's divisions was incorrectly identified as NBC Global Communications instead of RCA Global Communications.

title: WINE TALK
description: A sommelier is a man who has spent a lifetime learning wines. The vineyards of the world, the thousands of labels, the good vintage years, the proper wine for every occasion at the best price; these are stuff of which good sommeliers are made. Right?

title: Household Help Graduates Show Off at Gracie Mansion
description: Eleanore Schweppe, one of the handsomest guests at the Mayor's house, wondered aloud, Who are they? about the women smilingly proferring trays of hors d'oeuvres and ladling ruddy, fruitfilled sangria into her glass.

title: Echeverria's Successor Emphasizes Jobs
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 23Mexico's Finance Minister. Jos Lpez Portillo, chosen yesterday to succeed President Luis Echeverra Alverez, said today that his main concerns were job opportunities and the distribution of wealth.

title: GUN PANEL MEETS ON KENNEDY CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23The seven firearms experts who will re  examine ballistics evidence in the Robert F. Kennedy assassination met here today for the first time.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.) FIRST$8,500, trot, mile.

title: Hurricane Hits Gulf
description: One man was reported dead as Hurricane Eloise struck west Florida and Alabama. Thousands fled homes in coastal areas. Page 22.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1975

title: Texts of Affidavits Submitted by Patricia Hearst and Her Parents in Bid for Bail
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23Following are texts of affidavits submitted today in United States District Court here in support of a motion for bail by Patricia Hearst, the defendant, her father, Randolph A. Hearst, and her mother, Catherine Hearst:

title: Economic Strategy
description: Herbert Hoover, looking back over the Depression years that devastated his Administration, modestly observed: I may reiterate that it is not given even to Presidents to see the future. Economic storms do not develop all at once, and they change without notice. In my three years of the slump and Depression they changed repeatedly for the worse and with the speed of

title: Schools and Taxes an Old Issue
description: TRENTON, Sept. 23The seemingly endless legislative battle over a state income tax to finance public schools is about to be fought again in New Jersey. It is a protracted struggle that has resisted resolution since 1972. It seems no closer to resolution today than it was three years ago. The school financing issue has set the stage for a constitutional collision between the Legislature and the State Supreme Court, with the court still running the show.

title: Caso Under Inquiry For Costs Incurred For His Bodyguards
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 23The Nassau County District Attorney's office started an Investigation today into claims for expenses arising from the use of bodyguards by Ralph G. Caso, the County Executive, when he is on vacation or on noncounty business.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMSFlorence, on September 23rd, 1975, in London, England. Beloved wile of Robert D. Abrahams. Devoted mother of Rif hard and Roger Abrahams and Marjorie Slavin, and cherished grandmother. Private services will be held in London.

title: Shows Open
description: Shows that are not affected by the strike:

title: Shah Is Offering New Plan To Aid Developing Nations
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 23Asserting that the leastdeveloped nations were the only ones really hurt by the quintupling of oil prices in the last two years and by worldwide inflation, the Shah of Iran revealed a new plan today for a special aid fund by the oilproducing countries.

title: Son on Bail for Shooting Father, Held as Mother's Killer
description: A 19yearold college student was taken back to the Suffolk County jail yesterday afternoon, a day after his mother had paid $2,500 to bail him out on a charge of having shot his father on Aug. 22.

title: Money
description: Prime rate 8.

title: BUCKLEY OPPOSES U.S. INTERVENTION IN CITY'S CRISIS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Senator James L. Buckley of New York said today that he opposed direct Federal intervention in the New York City fiscal crisis, to the consternation of members of the New York Congressional delegation who seek a united front.

title: Both Sides Stand Firm in Wilmington, Del., After Arrest of 209 Teachers in Bitter ThreeWeek Strike
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 23Looking quite out of place, 209 welldressed college graduates, some with master's degrees, were arrested, booked, fingerprinted, processed and marched before two judges here yesterday on charges of disorderly conduct.

title: New Repertory Group To Do Shaw and Wilde
description: A new repertory company, the InterNational Theater Company, was announced yesterday by Miriam Dassin and Riggs O'Hara, coproducers. John Dexter will direct the first two productions, Shaw's Pygmalion and Oscar Wilde's The Importance of Being Earnest. The company will have 18 to 25 actors, with each playing two roles.

title: Witness Links Mrs. Swintonto Letters To Press About 1969 Bombings Here
description: A paid Federal informer who testified yesterday in Federal court here in the trial of Patricia Swinton on bombconspiracy charges said that Samuel E.
