Melville, a confessed bomb conspirator, had told him Mrs. Swinton helped write communiques to the press about a series of bombings here in 1969.

title: Senate Liberals Fail to Shut Off Debate On a Measure That Would Curb Busing
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 23The Senate, entangled over an antibusing amendment attached last week to a $36billion appropriations bill, failed by a wide margin today to limit debate on the measure.

title: KISSINGER ASSERTS U.S. HOPE FOR AFRICA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 23Secretary of State Kissinger declared tonight that America's three major concerns for Africa were that the continent attain prosperity and selfdetermination and that it be free o greatpower rivalry.

title: Affidavit Filed for Miss Hearst Depicts a Terrorized Prisoner
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23Patricia Hearst signed an affidavit today setting out a story of physical mistreatment, confinement, terror and possible use of LSD that the document said caused her to take part in the bank robbery for which she was arrested last week.

title: In Memoriam
description: CARTONHelen. Memorial services will be held at the Fifth Avenue Synagogue 5 E. 62d St., Sect. 24, at 3 P M

title: Ulster Security Steps
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 23 (Reuters)  Tougher Army and police action against the I.R.A. Provisionals was ordered today by Merlyn Rees, London's Seretary for Northern Ireland. The instructions for steppedup security measures came after a guerrilla offensive in and around nine towns in Ulster yesterday.

title: In Utah School District. Busing Mean a 2Hour Ride
description: MONUMENT VALLEY, Utah At 6:30 A.M. just as the sky is brightening over Totem Pole, Stage Coach, The Mittens and the other majestic red sandstone buttes in this legendary high desert country, Leonard Atene, a 10yearold Navajo boy, stands on a lonely stretch of road. He is waiting for the yellow bus that will take him to school.

title: TEACHERS ASKED TO TUTOR PUPILS
description: School Chancellor Irving An ker called on the city's teachers yesterday to volunteer their time and services to tutor pupils and, in vaious ways, help a school population that has been ruthlessly deprived of such services by budget cuts,

title: Advertising
description: If you have mixed feelings aboutor are confused bythe new price and pride campaign from the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, don't feel bad, top agency creative people are not in agreement about it either.

title: One Is Reported Dead as Hurricane Strikes Gulf Coast
description: FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla., Sept. 23 (AP)  Hurricane Eloise, spawning tornadoes to accompany its torrential rains, swept inland today after reaching the Florida Panhandle coast.

title: The Forgotten Poor of Bangkok
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 23Boomchuay Pomsakul is among 40,000 people who live in a forest of shanties, creaking catwalks across green, scumfilled water in a district called Klong Toey, named for the canal it borders.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: TEACHERS REJECT ARCHDIOCESE BID
description: Rejecting what the Archdiocese of New York yesterday called its final offer, lay teachers at nine Roman Catholic high schools in the city and Westchester County voted unanimously to continue their weeklong strike.

title: Sporadic Shooting Continues in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 23 The Lebanese capital was relatively quiet tonight, with only sporadic sniping, machinegun fire and mortar explosions reported from various neighborhoods.

title: 276 Counties Told U.S. Must Approve Electoral Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) Attorney General Edward H. Levi announced today a list of 276 counties that are required by the recently amended Voting Rights Act to submit recent and future changes in voting and election procedures to the Justice Department or a Federal court for prior approval.

title: DETECTIVES ACCUSED ON A $90,000 BRIBE
description: A special state grand jury has heard evidence that four detectives and a police lieutenant conspired to receive a $90,000 bribepresumably in exchange for lenient treatmentfrom one of two major narcotics dealers they arrested.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Public Service Company of New Mexico is expected to offer today 675,000 new common shares at $17.25 a share through underwriters headed by Kidder, Peabody & Co.

title: Affidavit Filed for Miss Hearst Depicts a Terrorized Prisoner
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23Patricia Hearst signed an affidavit today setting out a story of physical mistreatment, confinement, terror and possible use of LSD that the document said caused her to take part in the bank robbery for which she was arrested last week.

title: U.S. STRENGTHENS SUFFOLK FORCES
description: YAPHANK, L.I., Sept. 23Federal authorities are doubling the number of personnel investigating organized crime in Suffolk County in the light of what they see as an immobilization of law enforcement in the controversyridden county.

title: Hoboken Teachers Union Is Fined $5,000 for Strike
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 23A Superior Court judge fined the striking Hoboken Teachers Association $5,000 today for defying an earlier court order to end a walkout that began Sept. 4.

title: Mets' Box Score
GOING OUT Guide
description: POTS OF HISTORY More than 600 pieces of pottery are on view at the Center for InterAmerican Relations in an exhibition, Ancient Ecuador: Culture, Clay and Creativity 3000300 B.C.

title: Books of The Times
description: Straight off, I'll have to admit that I don't really understand Ward Just's Nicholson at Large, the third novel and fourth work of fiction by a former political reporter who has also written nonfiction books on Vietnam (To What End: Report From Vietnam) and the. American armed services (Military Men). Too often, reading this story about

title: ROUSE UNIT VOTES DEDUCTION CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The House Ways and Means Committee approved today the imposition of strict limitations on the circumstances in which taxpayers may take deductions for the expenses of maintaining offices in their homes.

title: Some Hunanese Favorites From Uncle Tai (Cont'd)
description: 10 giant shrimp, about one and onequarter pounds, available in Chinese fish markets

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Music for the Royal Fireworks, Handel; Fantasia on Greensleeves, Vaughan Williams: Concerto for Piano and Wind Orchestra, Stravinsky.

title: U.S. CITES READINESS TO TALK WITH CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI)The Administration reaffirmed today its readiness to end the 14year hostility between Cuba and the United States.

title: Emergency Board Confirms Estimate of City Revenue
description: The process of shaping a more austere and candid city budget by midOctober formally began yesterday with notice from the Emergency Financial Control Board that the city would have an estimated $11.6billion in local, state and Federal revenues for the current fiscal year.

title: Strike Closes Paris Bourse
description: PARIS, Sept. 23 (AP)The Paris Bourse was closed today by a strike of clerks protesting the dismissal of eight clerks by a broker. The gold and foreign exchange markets also were closed by the strike.

title: Accused Ford Assailant Has Led a Tangled Life
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 Sara Jane Moore, the matronly woman accused of attempting to assassinate President Ford here yesterday, has for years deliberately sought to obscure her background and identity.

title: Policemen and Garbagemen Out in Bayonne in Dispute Over Pay
description: BAYONNE, Sept. 23This city of 75,000 people was left virtually without police protec tion and garbage collectors today as a result of a labo dispute over wages.

title: U.S. AND SPAIN SAY TALKS PROGRESS
description: United States and Spanish officials reported yesterday that important progress had been made in the drawnout negotiations for a new agreement allowing American military forces to operate from Spanish bases.

title: President Nominates Luger
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI)  President Ford said today that he would nominate Milton L. Luger, 50yearsold, of Albany, as assistant administrator of law enforcement in the Justice Department to head the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention of the department's Law Enforcement Assistance Administration. Mr. Luger has served since 1966 as director of the state Division of Youth.

title: Views on Attempt Against Ford
description: Professor of criminology at Harvard

title: Miss Fromme Is Judged Competent to Stand Trial
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 23A Federal judge ruled today that Lynette Alice Fromme was mentally competent to stand trial on a charge of attempting to assassinate President Ford here on Sept. 5. The judge also granted Miss Fromme's request to represent herself.

title: Knight Papers Fill 2 Posts
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (UPI)F. Gilman Spencer, editor of the Trentonian newspaper in New Jersey and a Pulitzer Prize winner, was named today editor of the Philadelphia Daily News. Mr. Spencer. 49 years old succeeds Rolfe Neill, who has been appointed president and publisher of the Charlotte (N.C.) Observer and News. The appointment, effective Oct. 6, was announced by Lee Hills, chairman and chief executive of KnightRidder Newspapers, parent company of The Daily News and The Charlotte newspapers.

title: INQUIRY IS CALLED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23President Ford, telling aides he is determined not to be held hostage in the White House, rejected today suggestions that he curtail his public appearances after yesterday's second apparent attempt on his life in 17 days.

title: 123 Drums of Toxic Liquid Fall Into New York Bay
description: The Coast Guard announced last night that 123 sealed steel drums containing a herbicide had tumbled into the Upper Bay when a storage pier collapsed off the Clinton area of Staten Island. By nightfall, it said, 57 drums had been recovered.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: Catholic Teachers on L. I. Accept Pact Like Last One
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Sept. 23 (UPI)Teachers in four Roman Catholic schools operated by the Rockville Centre Diocese on Long Island voted Monday to accent a new oneyear contract.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: From February, 1974, to last February, the price of a front hood for a 1974 Vega went up 63 per cent. Over that same period of time, the hood on a 1974 Cadillac Calais went up in price by 10 per cent, while the hood on a Cadillac Eldorado went up only four per cent.

title: France Wins Delay in Killing Of Woman by Rebels in Chad
description: PARIS, Sept. 23The French Government said today that it had won a reprieve for a French woman scientist held captive in northern Chad by African rebels, who had threatIened to put her to death this morning.

title: EXWORKER INDICTED OVER DEFENSE PHOTO
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI)A Federal grand jury indicted a former worker on a secret defense project today on charges of wilfully failing to report the illegal photographing of a classified document under his control.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TORONTO, Sept. 22 (AP)Forego, the 1974 Horse of the Year, and Foolish Pleasure, the 1975 Kentucky Derby winner, head an impressive list of 49 thoroughbreds nominated for the $150,000 Canadian International Championship, officials announced today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: HOSPITAL DEATHS TERMED DELIBERATE
description: MARION, Ill., Sept. 23 (AP) Someone deliberately added a lethal dose of a respiratory control drug to an anesthetic at Marion Memorial Hospital, where the death of two patients may have been caused by poisoning, according to the authorities.

title: Talks Collapse
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (UPI) Negotiations for a new National Football League player contract broke down today and player representatives agreed to submit to a vote of the membership the last proposal received from management.

title: Bond Rally Ends
description: The fourday rally in the bond market ended abruptly yesterday as the credit markets braced for the sale of $2billion of Treasury notes today.

title: The Deeper Questions
description: After these two sudden threats on President Ford's life, two questions haunt the American mind: What explains this mindless violence and even vengeance against the authority of the Republic? And what, if anything, can be done about it?

title: Alan Carter, Conductor, Dead; Founder of Vermont Symphony
description: Alan Carter, founder and conductor of the Vermont State Symphony Orchestra and retired chairman of the music department at Bennington College, died Sunday in Middlebury, Vt. He was 71 years old. The State Attorney's office ruled death by suicide from carbon monoxide poisoning.

title: HEARST PROSECUTOR DROPS GUN CHARGE
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (AP)  Federal firearms charges against Patricia Hearst and William and Emily Harris were dismissed today in the interest of justice, United States Attorney William D. Keller said.

title: GROMYKO URGES MIDEAST PARLEY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, in an address to the General Assembly, said today that the Geneva peace conference was the appropriate mechanism for dealing With Middle East problems.

title: Bishops Rebuked for Roles In Ordination of 15 Women
description: PORTLAND. Me., Sept. 23The House of Bishops of the Episcopal Church decried today the action of a Bishop who ordained four women to the priesthood in Washington early this month and censured three other Bishops who ordained 11 women to the priesthood last year.

title: Byrne Bids Congress Let Gas Price Rise Somewhat
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Governor Byrne of New Jersey advised Congress today to allow reasonable and limited price increases that would be necessary to stimulate new natural gas production.

title: FORD RESISTS GROWING PRESSURE TO CURB HIS PUBLIC APPEARANCES; GUARD FOR '76 CANDIDATES URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23President Ford, telling aides he is determined not to be held hostage in the White House, rejected today suggestions that he curtail his public appearances after yesterday's second apparent attempt on his life in 17 days.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: HONEYBEES AIDING POLLUTION FIGHT
description: Honey, used by the ancient Egyptians as an embalming fluid, cited as a sweet delicacy by Homer and Euripides and mentioned prominently in the Bible, has entered the modern scientist's laboratory, where it is playing a new and potentially important role as a monitor of environmental pollution.

title: Ancient Military Cemetery Is Unearthed in Thessaly
description: ATHENS, Sept. 23 (UPI)A farmer ploughing a field at the village of Ayios Georgios, near Larissa in Thessaly, turned up several ancient graves dating from the 5th century B. C., the Greek Archeological Service has announced.

title: KLEPPE ASSURED ON CONFIRMATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Thomas S. Kleppe, the millionaire former North Daokta Representative who is President Ford's latest nominee to be Secretary of the Interior, was assured at a Senate hearing today on his confirmation to the Cabinet post that, unlike his predecessor, he would be promptly approved.

title: FUTURES IN GOLD DIP TO NEW LOWS
description: Worried traders continued to sell gold futures yesterday as price declined following the drop in the price of gold overseas.

title: Argentine Workers Seize 26 Aides, Then Free Them
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 23 (Renters)Construction workers in the industrial ctiy of Cordoba took 26 company executives hostage today to dramatize pay demands, then released them a short time later, the police said.

title: AMEX PRICES DROP AS VOLUME SLOWS
description: Stock prices on the American Stock Exchange drifted down in slow trading yesterday. With little news influencing the market, the index closed at 84.14, off 0.46, on volume of 1.3 million shares, down from Monday's 1.5 million.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the luckiest declarers of the year was Paul Chemia of France, on the diagramed deal from the recent European Championships. And when it was over he impudently claimed that he had been unlucky.

title: Market Place
description: The Securities and Exchange Commision has circulated a proposed set of rules that would require publicly owned companies to footnote balance sheets and profit and loss statements with data on replacement costs.

title: Court Orders State to Free Prisoner After 44 Years, 31 in Insane Asylum
description: A 70yearold prisoner incarcerated for 44 years, 31 of them in an insane asylum to which he was transferred in apparent retaliation for his efforts to expose prison corruption, was ordered released yesterday.

title: Sinai Details Are Completed in Geneva
description: GENEVA, Sept. 23 (AP)Egyptian and Israeli military negotiators completed an agree ment early today setting forth, the procedures to be followed in Israel's second troop withdrawal in Sinai.

title: Presidential Protection
description: Revulsion and anger united Americans of all political persuasions yesterday in the wake of this month's second murder attempt on the President. More insistently than ever before, the question now becomes one of how better to protect the President and more broadlyas the 1976 Presidential campaign approachesof how to protect all who will be contending for that high post these next fourteen months.

title: Monarch of Towering Strength
description: MANILA, Sept. 23Rock music ricocheted off walls and ceiling of the folk arts theater, frightening the gull off the shore of Manila Bay. It sounded like the folk art of the North American artists, Joe Frazier and the Knockouts, but it wasn't, for this was morning, Muhammad Ali's time of day in the hall both he and Frazier use to practice punching faces. On the stage beyond the empty boxing ring, a choir of young people lined up facing a man who wore an academic gown with a droopy gold lampshade on his head instead of a mortar board. A press release identified him as Dr. Dominador S. La Madrid, President of the Philippine Institute tute of Doctors in Law, Chancellor of the Institute of Muslim Culture of Ortanez University and Chairman of the Muhammad All University Program. Somebody turned off the canned rock, and the choir sang the Muhammad Ali Leadership Song, composed by Dr. La Madrid, while a lady in the audience described Ortanez University as a nursing school connected with a suburban hospital.

title: Dolphins Learn Defense Needs Patching
description: MIAMI, Sept. 23The defeat of the Miami Dolphins by the Oakland Raiders, 3121, here last night does not alter the power structure atop the National Football League where these two teams have lived for so long and will continue to do so.

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post posttiens Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Three Arrested in Bronx Are Linked to Robbery Ring
description: Three persons allegedly involved in a Bronx robbery ring were arrested yesterday after raid on an apartment where one of them lived, according to the police.

title: Caribous Win, 108, In Lacrosse Playoff
description: QUEBEC, Sept. 23Travis Cook scored four goals, three in the final period, tonight as the Quebec Caribous defeated the Montreal Quebecois, 108, in the National Lacrosse League playoffs. The victory gave the Carlbous a 30 lead in the final fouroutofsevenseries.

title: BERGMAN TARGET OF NEW INQUIRY
description: An investigation by Charles J. Hynes, a special state prosecutor, into Bernard Bergman's operations at the Park Crescent Nursing Home, at 87th Street and Riverside Drive, has been underway for the last month, it became known yesterday.

title: Surge of Ice Sheet's Water Into Mississippi Said to Support Deluge Legends
description: Evidence has been found that torrents of water flowing down the Mississippi River from a rapidly melting ice sheet some 11.600 years ago raised worldwide sea levels enough to explain for the many accounts of a great prehistoric flood.

title: Ali Tells Public of His Private Life N.F.L.
description: MANILA, Sept. 23Quietly defending his right to have a girl friend as well as a wife, Muhammad All clarified today the role of Veronica Porche in his entourage. The exbeauty queen from Los Angeles has been a member of the world heavyweight champion's retinue for about a year.

title: CAREY DOUBTS TOLLS CAN EASE POLLUTION
description: Governor Carey yesterday questioned whether putting tolls on the East River bridges, as advocated by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, would actually lead to reduced air pollution as the authority has contended.

title: Miss Heldman Collects
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 (AP) A jury of the Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court awarde Julie Heldman, a tennis, pro, $67,000 today for injuries she, sustained during a Wightnan Cup match in 1971. She tore cartilage in her left knee while playing on artificial turf that the jury deemed was defective.

title: Sad Days for Boston
description: The shutdown of Boston's public schools by a teachers' strike cannot be judged by the yardsticks ordinarily applied to such work stoppages. It Is bad enough under any circumstances to make pupils the victims of a contract dispute in outright violation of existing state laws, but the action by the Boston teachers' union threatens to revive fears and hostilities so painfully overcome in the last two weeks as the community moved to implement Federal court desegregation orders.

title: ExLaw Partner Denies He Worked On 1969 Nixon Tax
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23James P. Tannian, a former law partner of Richard M. Nixon, testified today that he did not work in 1969 or 1970 on a 1969 income tax deduction from a donation or Mr. Nixon's VicePresidential papers.

title: Carty Out of Hospital
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 (AP) Rico Carty, the designated hitter for the Cleveland Indians, was released today from Lutheran Medical Center, where he was taken for Xrays and observation after being hit by a pitch during last night's 76 victory over Milwaukee. The Indians said Carty was suffering from slight bleedings in his left ear, but his doctor says he will be able to play

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Psychiatrists Fear Gun Episodes Will Be Contagious
description: Psychiatrists expressed concern in interviews yesterday that violence might he becoming more legitimate in the eyes of some disturbed people alienated by government policies. and that the two gun episodes involving President Ford might prove contagious.

title: Black Trooper Wins Suit On Promotion and Back Pay
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (UPI)A Federal judge says the Pennsylvania State Police denied a promotion for a black trooper because of his race and ordered the state police to promote him and pay $10,000 in back pay.

title: Memorial Sevives
New Shows, Unsettled by Music Strike, Looking for House Away From Home
description: The musicians' strike has not only stopped the music on Broadway, but it has also unsettled the shows that were supposed to come to Broadway in the next few months.

title: People in Sports
description: Frank Robinson, major league baseball's first black manger, signed to manage the Cleveland Indians yesterday for another year, but left his status as an active player in doubt. I don't think I'll play again, he said.

title: Talks Resume in Musicians' Walkout; Met Warns It Won't Open Without Pact
description: Negotiations aimed at ending the strike of musicians at Broadway theaters resumed yesterday, but the Metropolitan Opera warned that it would not open its season next month without a contract or a nostrike pledge from the musicians union.

title: Twins Again Foil. A's Effort to Clinch
description: Minnesota's ace righthander, Bert Blyleven, delayed Oakland's division clinching last night by stopping the A's on nine hits as the Twins posted a 43 victory in Oakland. Calif.

title: 5 Months in Coma, Young Woman Is a Patient Apart
description: DENVILLE, N. J., Sept. 23With one exception. all the patients in the intensivecare unit at St. Clare's Hospital here are there for a comparatively short time, usually for postoperative care until they can be returned to their rooms.

title: Battery Park City Asks F. H. A. To Provide Mortgage Insurance
description: The Battery Park City Authority, unable to market new obligations in a wary securities market, is applying for Federal Housing Administration mortgage insurance so that it can begin construction on 1,642 apartments in its projected new town in the Hudson River.

title: Sculptures at the Whitney Restore Nadelman to Glory
description: The rise and fall of great reputations is one of the most vexing mysteries of the life of art. One day an unknown talent suddenly emerges from the shadows, captures the limelight, effects a farreaching change in the art he practices, earns large sums of money and excites the envy of his peers, and then, owing to vicissitudes having little or nothing to do with the art in question, virtually disappears from the agenda of serious discussion. A door seems to slam shut, almost as suddenly as it once opened, and all attention is turned elsewhere untilin cases of rare good fortunethe magic moment of revival occurs, and the fallen reputation is restored to glory.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an account of a new management organization by the RCA Corporation in The New York Times last Saturday, one of RCA's divisions was incorrectly identified as NBC Global Communications instead of RCA Global Communications.

title: In Utah School District, Busing Means a 2Hour Ride
description: MONUMENT VALLEY, Utah At 6:30 A.M. just as the sky is brightening over Totem Pole, Stage Coach, The Mittens and the other majestic red sandstone buttes in this legendary high desert country, Leonard Atene, a 10yearold Navajo boy, stands on a lonely stretch of road. He is waiting for the yellow bus that will take him to school.

title: CHARLOTTE P. M'DONALD
description: Charlotte Page McDonald, who was prominent socially here and in Miami, died Monday in Miami at the home of her oldest daughter, Mrs. Don Shoemaker. She was 58 years old.

title: Mood of San Francisco: Shocked but Still Confident
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23  warm September sun, filtered through a light haze. bathed the bustling streets of San Francisco today. All in all, it was just th sort of early autumn day this city always looks forward to throughout its long, cold summer.

title: Excerpts From Gromyko Speech at U.N. Assembly
description: All participants in this world forum of states would probably agree that one of the main tasks in the international arena remains the elimination of hotbeds of armed conflicts. One need not dwell on how grave is the threat when this or that hotbed flares up and again develops into a crisis. The world has repeatedly faced such a turn of events and knows perfectly well how difficult it is to put out the flames of war.

title: Global Impact of Capital Shortage in U.S. Explored
description: Worldwide implications of an impending capital shortage in the United States served yesterday as the focus of a conference sponsored by the New York Stock Exchange that attracted toplevel speakers and an international audience.

title: Policemen and Garbagemen Out In Bayonne in Dispute Over Pay
description: BAYONNE, Sept. 23This city of 75,000 people was left virtually without police protec tion and garbage collectors today as a result of a labo dispute over wages.

title: Gold and Pound Plunge in Value As Dollar Sets Highs for Year
description: LONDON, Sept. 23Gold and the beleaguered British pound plunged in value today, accelerating an erosion that has been going on most of this year.

title: Judge Rules Rights Agency Discriminated Against Black
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) A Federal judge has found the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission guilty of practicing the kind of discrimination it was created to prevent.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Henry J. Price Dies at 44; Journalist, ExWeicker Aide
description: Henry J. Price, public in formation officer in the Middle West for the Drug Enforcement Administration, died Monday in Chicago of an apparent pancreas ailment. He was 44 years old.

title: Stage: Smoking Pistols
description: A comparatively recent innovation for the London stage has been the introduction of lunchtime theater. Now lunchtime theater has come to New York, presented in a pleasant basement theater called Theater Off Park and sponsored by the Community Church of New York. Snacks are served, and if you buy a hot dog, a free beer or soda will be thrown in.

title: Mets Trail, 60, Top Cubs by 86
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23With third place beckoning, the Mets overcame a 60 deficit today and went on to defeat the Cubs, 86. New York's 14hit attack included three key hits by Rusty Staub and an important game  tying pinchdouble by a rookie, John Stearns.

title: Bronfman Case Figure Is Foiled in Escape Bid
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., Sept. 23Mel Patrick Lynch, one of the two accused kidnappers of Samuel Bronfman 2d, attempted unsuccessfully Monday night to escape from the Westchester County Jail, where he is being held without bail awaiting trial.

title: Suffolk Savings Unit Robbed
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L.I., Sept, 23 (UPI)  Two gunmen held up the Century Federal Savings and Loan Association in East Northport, L.I. today and escaped with $7,396, the Suffolk County Police reported.

title: A.M.C. LIFTS PRICE ON '76 ALTOS 4,4%
description: DETROIT, Sept. 23  The American Motors Corporation announced today that it was raising its average retail prices on its 1976 model cars by $154, or 4.4 per cent.

title: CON ED AND LILCO FAULTED IN STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners made public a study today that seemed to indicated that in 1973 the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and the Long Island Lighting Company were among the worst managed power companies in the United States.

title: Shows Closed
description: The shows closed by the strike of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians:

title: Tax Reform Here
description: WASHINGTONNow that the State Legislature has acted to avert the bankruptcy of the nation's largest city, we have to assemble a longterm program for reestablishing and maintaining the fiscal solvency of New York City. A primary element of such a program must be the reconstituting of our tax structure once again to make the city viable and competitive. And that means tax reduction.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Shah of Iran revealed a new plan for the oilproducing countries to establish a special fund for the leastdeveloped nations. In an interview in Teheran with a New York Times editor he said it would be presented today at the Vienna meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. A fiveyear assessment an each barrel of oil would go into a lowinterest loan fund for specific projects in developing countries. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: TV Braces for Logistics of the Democratic Convention
description: Since the television networks are based here, the Democratic party's choice of this city for its 1976 national convention would seem both convenient for coverage and economically advantageous.

title: TV Review
description: If it's a new Frederick Wiseman film, this must be the opening of a new publictelevision season. This year's documentary is Welfare, a 2hour, 50minute portrait of a welfare center in Manhattan. It will be offered on Channel 13 tonight at 9.

title: ...Not Immunization
description: The difficulty with the immunization approach is that an attempt, before the President's arrival in San Francisco, to have imprisoned or deported everyone in the Bay Area who, in the estimation of some lawenforcement or psychiatric agency, might want to harm Mr. Ford would require action against thousands, even tens of thousands of people. The way would be open for egregious abuses in the worst tradition of a police state. Beyond that, such a tactic might well be counterproductive, rousing tensions and resentments that would move some who escaped such preventive detention to an attempt on the President's life.

title: Suspect in Slaying of Educator Said to Admit Shooting Blacks
description: DAYTON. Ohio, Sept. 23 (UPI)The accused killer of a desegregation expert has admitted being responsible for the shooting of 25 to 30 black people in the Dayton area the last four years, a police affidavit stated today.

title: Facts in Musicians' Strike
description: THE PARTICIPANTS

title: World Reaction to the Shooting Varied
description: FranceSoir, France's most popular daily, displayed a photograph of Mondayapos;s assassination attempt on President Ford across half the front page and a Rome leftwing newspaper gave the news a sixcolumn headline but Communist countries seemed hardly to notice the news,

title: American Roulette
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Prudence suggests that President Ford should cancel his public appearances for the next several weeks and restrict them thereafter to indoor settings.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY ??F TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 5.3411 UNTIL 5:30 P.M IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY NEW JERSEY (201) MARK T 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES(914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) /4/??0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800 CONNECTICUT (203) 3487747.

title: Woman in Coma: a Patient Apart
description: DENVILLE, Sept. 23With one exception, all the patients in the intensivecare unit at St. Clare's Hospital here are there for a comparatively short time, usually for postoperative care until they can be returned to their rooms.

title: Those Spicy Hunanese Dishes Hold No Terrors for Uncle Tai
description: Keenly observant students of Chinese cookbooks printed in English may note that a dominant number of recipes calling for beef specify flank steak. Similarly, a vast majority of the recipes calling for stirfried dishes made with beef, pork, chicken, shrimp or whatever call for the addition of one or more egg whites.

title: Jets Look A head, Hope for Rebound
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I. Sept. 23The Jets' scars began to heal today.

title: Monday's Fights
description: NEW YORKJos Fernandez, 133 pounds, Dominican Republic, outpointed Domenico Monaco, 133, Brooklyn, 10 rounds: Julio Valdez, 132, Dominican Republic, outpointed Eduardo Santiago, 134, Puerto Rico, 10.

title: Case Opposes PATH Plan, Asks Upgrading of Central
description: Senator Clifford P. Case urged yesterday the rejection of a controversial plan to extend the PATH transit line from Newark to Plainfield and recommended upgrading the Jersey Central Railroad instead.

title: REPORT BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23A special committee recommended today that Secret Service protection be offered immediately to all Presidential candidates qualified to receive Federal campaign funds.

title: Rain Whets And Snags East Race
description: Baseball's chances for an orderly end of the season were diminished, and probably enlivened, last night when the Boston Red Sox and New York Yankees were rained out of their scheduled game at Shea Stadiumforcing the Red Sox to play a doubleheader there tonight in their run for the Eastern title in the American League.

title: FINNS EXPECTING DELAY ON REGIME
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 22 With the twoday parliamentary elections concluded yesterday. Finns are facing the likelihood that they may not have a new government until early next year.

title: About Education
description: One day last year. Ralph Cioppa, science chairman at DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, was summoned to the classroom of a teacher who could not restore order when two youngsters began fighting.

title: Judicial Screening Panel Rejects Many Aspirants
description: Half of the prospective candidates for State Supreme Court in Manhattan and the Bronx, including many lower  court judges, were found unqualified for nomination to State Supreme Court in the first test of a joint Democratic regular organization  New Democratic Coalition judicial screening panel.

title: LEROY S. CLARK
description: Leroy S. Clark, who retired in 1963 as a vice president of the Midland BankNew York, died Monday. He was 77 years old and lived in Dix Hills, L. I.

title: Big Toll Despite Law
description: New York City has the toughest gun laws in the country, but the proliferation of firearms has grown to such proportions that on an average day, guns will still he responsible for two murders. 60 robberies and 22 assaults.

title: MRS. ROBERT WISE
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (AP)  Patricia Doyle Wise, wife of Robert Wise, the producerdirector, died yesterday of cancer at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 60 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (Reuters)A dispute developed today between officials of the State and Agriculture Departments over sales of grain to Poland and other East European countries.

title: Foreign Aid Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (Reuters)The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today approved a twoyear, $2.9billion foreign aid bill after accepting an amendment that will bar aid to countries discriminating against Americans on the basis of race or creed.

title: Card of Thanks
FOUR PLEAD TO KEEP RURAL POST OFFICES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) Four members of Congress from primarily rural districts testified today against a proposal to allow the Postal Service to close more than 12,000 rural post offices.

title: A Briefing for a Film By Ingmar Bergman
description: FARO, SWEDEN Dear Fellow Workers: We're now going to make a film which, in a way, is about an attempted suicide. Actually it deals (as usual I was about to say!) with Life, Love and Death. The reason is that nothing in fact is more important. To occupy oneself with. To think of. To worry over. To be happy about. And so on.

title: Ralston Is 3Set Winner
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 (AP)Dennis Ralston fought back today to beat Sherwood Stewart, 46, 76, 62, in a firstround match of the $100,000 Fireman's Fund tennis tournament today.

title: MADELYN DIXON
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 23 (AP)Madelyn Dixon, a retired film actress and widow of Thomas Dixon, who wrote two books that became the film Birth of a Nation. died Saturday. She was 81 years old.

title: BUCKLEY OPPOSES U.S.INTERVENTION IN CITY'S CRISIS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Senator James L. Buckley of New York said today that he opposed direct Federal intervention in the New York City fiscal crisis, to the consternation of members of the New York Congressional delegation who seek a united front.

title: Japan's Police Seize 1,221 in Raids on Gangsters
description: TOKYO, Sept. 23 (AP)Police officials said that raids were carried out on 1,081 gangster hideouts throughout Japan today and that 1,221 persons, including 27 big bosses, were arrested. The operation was the biggest crackdown on criminal organizations since World War II, they added.

title: $25,000 Bail Holds Suspect In Written Threat to Ford
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 (Reuters)Benedict Silcio, who gave his name yesterday as Ronald Carlo when he was arrested on charges of threatening the life of President Ford, was, arraigned today and bail WAS set at $25,000.

title: HOUSE BACKS CURB ON PRICES OF OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The House of Representatives passed today a major longrange energy policy bill that is completely at odds with President Ford's proposed program.

title: SHELL OIL SUSPENDS STRIP MINE PROJECT
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 23The Shell Oil Company, a major holder of undeveloped coal leases in the West, said today that it has suspended a multimillion dollar contract with Brown & Root, Inc., construction engineers, for one of several large strip mines planned on coal reserves held by the Crow Indians on their eastern Montana reservation.

title: Remarks by Shah on Iran's Policies and Plans
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 23Following are some remarks made by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi during an interview with The New York Times:

title: Secret Service Heard of Threat 2 Days Before President's Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The Secret Service learned two days before President Ford's visit to San Francisco that Sara Jane Moore had suggested to the local police that she might try to test the Presidential security system, Federal sources confirmed today.

title: L. I. Man Dies in Collision
description: TWENTY NINE PALMS, Calif., Sept. 23 (UPI)A man from Port Washington, L.I., was killed and his 3yearold granddaughter seriously injured to day in a collision between their pickup truck and a car at an intersection here. The Highway Patrol Said Frank J. Caruso, 57 years old, and his granddaughter, Elizabeth Bell, were ejected from the truck when it collided with a car driven by Claire Drake, 49.

title: About New York
description: Opinions on New York are so vigorousit's a jungle, a challenge, a visitor's paradise, a sightseer's pitfallthat there is no such thing as a New York story without a moral, even if the raconteur has none in mind.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Sept. 23, 1975

title: REPORT BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23A special committee recommended today that Secret Service protection be offered immediately to all Presidential candidates qualified to receive Federal campaign funds.

title: Business Records
SOVIET PROPOSES PACT ON NEW ARMS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 23  The Soviet Union, warning that science can produce ominous new weapons of mass destruction, proposed today an international treaty to prohibit their development and manufacture.

title: Major League Leaders
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: `Partition Issue Raised by Lebanese Strife
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 23 Is Lebanon becoming another Cyprus?

title: The Gun Culture
description: A shot rings out in the crowd. A President, a Senator, a civil rights leader falls. Some hits, some nearmisses. An outcry for a few days about guncontrol laws. The rifle lobby fires up its old propaganda: Constitutional right to bear arms; disarm criminals not people; it's not guns that do the killing but untrained persons, etc. And terror stalks the streets again, as American as apple pie and assassination.

title: Dismissed Investigator Gets Corrections Post
description: ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP) R. Robert Byers, who was dismissed as an investigator for the old Stale Correction Commission after charging that it was covering up abuses in state prisons, has been named chief investigator for the new Correction Commission.

title: Zoning Bill Would Push Housing on Smaller Scale
description: The Beame administration proposed yesterday a major change in the zoning laws to stimulate apartment construction in scale with surrounding neighborhoods and to promote better security for tenants, more recreational facilities and higher quality in housing design.

title: Dividends
Ford Aide Finds $15Billion Spending Rise Since May, Most Linked to Recession
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23James T. Lynn, director of the Office of Management and Budget, gave Congress some new figures today that showed that already identifiable increases in Government spending this year amount to $15billion more than the Administration estimated in May, but that only $5billion of the total was a result of Congressional actions that ran counter to Administration policy.

title: Seagram Company's Profits in a Slump; Other Earnings Comparisons Are Issued
description: A sharp slump in profits for the final quarter and fiscal year was reported yesterday by the Seagram Company, Ltd., the world's largest wine and spirits company.

title: PCB Hearing Officer Named
description: ALBANY, Sept. 23The State Environmental Commissioner, Ogden R. Reid, today designated Abraham D. Sofaer, a Columbia University law professor, to preside at a hearing here Oct. 20 on a state complaint that the General Electric Company is discharging polychlorinated biphenyl, PCB., into the Hudson River at company plants in Fort Howard and Hudson Falls.

title: 2 Exchange Seat Prices Off
description: Reflecting slow trading and sluggish profits for August and September, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday the second drop in seat prices in as many days. A seat sold yesterday at $90,000 off $15,000 from a sale Monday. An Amex seat sold yesterday at $48,000, down $5,000 from Sept. 11.

title: City's Clubhouse Politics Now in Limbo
description: A Brooklyn district leader telephoned City Hall yesterday Morning and, after noting the weekend resignation of two Commissioners, the possible resignations or dismissals of others, and the likelihood that with the reorganization of the city's socalled superagencies that perhaps hundreds of supervisors could also go, mentioned the names of several people he thought would be deserving replacements. He was told, Forget it. It's a new ball game. The rules of the new, emerging ball game, according to the players at City Hall, are dictated by the city's fiscal crisis and they specify, among other things, that membership in a friendly Democratic district club is not the automatic qualification for a city job that it once was.

title: Secret Service Heard of Threat 2 Days Before President's Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The Secret Service learned two days before President Ford's visit to San Francisco that Sara Jane Moore had suggested to the local police that she might try, to test the Presidential sccurity system, Federal sources confirmed today.

title: Hurricane Hits Gulf
description: One man was reported dead as Hurricane Eloise struck west Florida and Alabama. Thousands fled homes in coastal areas. Page 22.

title: Senator Says Nixon's Ban OnIllegal Acts Was Defied
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23Senator Frank Church, chairman of the Senate Select Cornmittee on Intelligence, said today that Federal intelligence agencies had sought President Nixon's approval for a variety of illegal acts, and then, after Mr. Nixon revoked his permission, paid no heed to the revocation.

title: PIANO JAZZ BY HILL HAS STRONG CHORDS
description: For the better part of the last decade, Andrew Hill has been a provocative, exploratory jazz pianist with an individual approach. He still has all these qualities but, as seen in his performance Monday evening at the Other End, 149 Bleecker Street, the ability to develop his ideas effectively is still proving elusive.

title: United City Voice
description: The executive committee of the United States Conference of Mayors will try at a White House meeting today to convince President Ford that the country's interests are badly served by his hostility to new Federal aid for distressed cities.

title: For the City's Fiscal Crisis, Executive Troubleshooters
description: Albert V. Casey, the $200,000 ayear chairman of American Airlines, sat in his Manhattan office fingering a published study of New York City's financial problems entitled Taxes, Expenditures and the Economic Base. Leaning back in his upholstered chair, he ticked off the basic elements of the problem confronting him.

title: Ubiquitous Catholic Negotiator
description: When Edward J. Burke leaves his white stucco home in Mount Vernon in the morning, he takes with him one of three battered and overstuffed leather briefcases. One con tains legal papers regarding Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens, a second is filled with documents regarding Catholic high schools in the, city and Westchester, and a third is stuffed with information on Catholic elementary schools. Mr. Burke, a Jesuittrained labor lawyer, is a negotiator for the city's Catholic schools in three separate labor disputes, two of which involve teachers' strikes that have disrupted education for thousands of youngsters.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Federal housing officials announced that federally insured private financing has been found for a housing rehabilitation project in the South Bronx that had been threatened by the inability of the State Housing Finance Agency to sell bonds for the project. The $12.5million private mortgage, from the Thrift Associates Service Corporation of Westchester, will permit the renovation of 384 apartments in 11 buildings in the Aldus Green project, Aldus Street and Bryant Avenue. Kraus Enterprises is the developer. Tenants will receive Federal rent subsidies.

title: Accused Ford Assailant Has Led a Tangled Life
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 Sara Jane Moore, the matronly woman accused of attempting to assassinate President Ford here yesterday, has for years deliberately sought to obscure her background and identity.

title: Dow Off by 0.55 to 819.85; Trading Continues Light
description: The stock market closed lower again yesterday in continued light trading. Investors retreated to the sidelines in the absence of fresh or firm indications of the course of interest rates or inflation.

title: Man Who Deflected Gun Asserts, I'm Not a Hero
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 (AP)I'm not a hero, I'm a live coward, said Oliver Sipple, who the authorities say may have saved the life of President Ford.

title: Baseball Owners Lean Toward 3City Shuffle
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 23 Owners of all 24 major league clubs headed today for Kansas City, where they will take up the longrange question of where baseball is headed. One possible revision, involving Oakland, Chicago and Seattle, appears to be gaining favor rapidly.

title: Shah Is Offering New Plan To Aid Developing Nations
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 23Asserting that the leastdeveloped nations were the only ones really hurt by the quintupling of oil prices in the last two years and by worldwide inflation, the Shah of Iran revealed a new plan today for a special aid fund by the oilproducing countries.

title: HOUSE BACKS CURB ON PRICES OF OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The House of Representatives passed today a major longrange energy policy bill that is completely at odds with President Ford's proposed program.

title: Auto Club Officials Agree To a Supervised Election
description: PATERSON, Sept. 23Offlcers of the North .Jersey Automobile Club, accused of dominating the election process in seeking to be renamed to the club's board of directors, agreed in Superior Court here today to a supervision of election procedures that would open the ballot to a challenging independent slate.

title: Yesterday's Keystone Results
description: Time126 2.5. Double There, Noble Comb, Pineland, Sid's Heirloom, Gazebo, Jay Jays Ghana also ran.

title: CITY URGED TO KEEP DRUG PROGRAMS
description: Eager to avert a change of control from the city to the stale of some Federal aid for drug treatment programs here, two Manhattan Representatives proposed yesterday that the Health Services Administration take over the responsibility of the Addiction Services Agency for financing private drug programs.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The unemployment rate in the State, which dropped slightly in July, climbed back to 13 per cent for August, well above the national rate of 8.3 per cent. Figures released yesterday by the State Department of Labor and Industry, put the number of unemployed people in midAugust at 437,800. The unemployment level reached 13 per cent in May.

title: Contract Awards
description: A contract for a new offshore water system, valued at about $50million, has been signed by the Guy F. Atkinson Company, San Francisco, an international construction concern, with the Southern California Edison Company. The contract is part of a $2billion expansion of the existing nuclear power plant in Southern California.

title: Miss Fromme Is Judged Competent to Stand Trial
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 23A Federal judge ruled today that Lynette Alice Fromme was mentally competent to stand trial on a charge of attempting to assassinate President Ford here on Sept. 5. The judge also granted Miss Fromme's request to represent herself.

title: Text of Ford's Comments
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)Following is the text of President Ford's comments to reporters upon returning to the White House last night:

title: ERITREA CONFLICT DRAINS ETHIOPIA
description: ASMARA, Ethiopia, Sept. 23 (Reuters)  Ethiopia's new military rulers need every cent in the treasury for their task of raising the country after centuries of neglect and feudal oppression.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Plans to Seil Ingot To China This Year
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, one of the nation's leading aluminum producers, has completed terms of an agreement with China for the sale of 50,000 tons of aluminum ingot to the nation before the end of the year.

title: Pan Am Announces Record for Profits In Month of August
description: Pan American World Airways reported yesterday a net profit for August of $23.6million, which the company said was the largest net profit it had ever earned in a single month.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Horses listed in order of post positions

title: Met: $35 Tickets and a Lingering Deficit
description: This year operalovers will pay up to $35 for single orchestra seats to Metropolitan Opera productions. And when they go, chances are the house will look full. How then, some must wonder, can the Met still be in the desperate financial straits it portrays itself?

title: H.R.A. Is Told to Rework DataProcessing System
description: The Budget Bureau directed the Human Resources Administration yesterday not to expand or undertake any new welfare programs or purchase additional computers until apparent deficiencies in its dataprocessing systems were corrected.

title: Islanders Beaten by Penguins in Preseason Game, 51
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 23 There were reflexive smiles of recognition as the New York Islanders greeted the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight in Nassau Coliseum before the Islanders' first National Hockey League exhibition game of the season. The teams had last met on April 26, when the Islanders defeated the Penguins for the fourth consecutive time to win their Stanley Cup quarterfinal series.

title: VOTE BY CONGRESS ON ISRAEL URGED
description: c Two Senators will propose tomorrow that Congress vote on the secret United States undertakings to Israel and Egypt as well as on the 200 American, technicians who are to police the Sinai disengagement pact, according to Senate aides.

title: Bond Rally Ends
description: The fourday rally in the bond market ended yesterday as the credit markets braced for the sale of $2billion of Treasury notes today. Page 69.

title: Boston Mayor Wins Top Spot In City's Preliminary Election
description: BOSTON, Sept. 23Mayor Kevin H. White won the top spot tonight in a preliminary city election that drew a light turnout in rainy weather.

title: U. of Penn Settles Long Sex Bias Suit By Paying $70,000
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23After nearly seven years of controversy a $70.000 outofcourt settlement has been reached in a sex discrimination suit against the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Mack Trucks Layoffs Set
description: HAGERSTOWN, Md., Sept. 23 (UPI)Another 150 employes at the local Mack Trucks, Inc., plant will be laid off indefinitely over the next several weeks, the general manager said today.

title: Missile Test Succeeds
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 24 (UPI) A Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missile was successfully launched yesterday and plummeted into the sea on target several hundred miles down the Pacific Missile Range. The launching was conducted by a Strategic Air Command from the 44th Strategic Missile Wing at Ellsworth Air ?? Base, S. D.

description: Miscellaneous 3454

title: Awake and Sing! at 40 in New Production
description: HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 24The Hartford Stage Company has just opened its new season with a splendid and timely revival of Clifford Odets's finest play, Awake and Sing! The play stands up admirablyit is now exactly 40 years oldand the staging and the acting show the American resident theater at its very best. On Friday, Paul Weidner, the company's producing director, and his company are to receive the Margo Jones Award, given each year to the person or theater in America displaying the most initiative in uncovering and producing important new works of dramatic literature.

title: 2 Reject New Pact In N.F.L.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)  The Buffalo Bills and Houston Oilers, two teams that refused to join last week's National Football ague strike, voted overwhelmingly today to reject the league's latest contract offer.

title: Experts Labor to Communicate on Animal Talk
description: Honored members of the Academy Kafka's story begins. You have done me the honor of inviting me to give your Academy an account of the life I formerly led as an ape.

title: Sustaining Life of Terminally Ill Called Complex Issue
description: Should the machine keeping Karen Arm Quinlan alive be turned off?

title: Radical Fugitive Arrested
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 24 (UPI) Leonard Handelsman, 29 years old, a radical sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation since 1970, was arrested here, early this morning. A warrant had been issued for Mr. Handelsman charging him with illegal flight to avoid prosecution in Chicago. Arrested with Mr. Handelsman was Gary Jerome McDonnell, 34, who was to answer charges on harboring a Federal Fugitive.

title: Contempt Trial Date Set In Teachers' Strike Here
description: Justice Irving H. Saypol of State Supreme Court yesterday set a trial date of Oct. 6 for civil contempt proceedings against the United Federation of Teachers for conducting the recent fiveday school strike in violation of the state law prohibiting strikes by public employes.

title: Birth Notice 16  No Title
description: Contents 14 room house. October 4th. 9:00 A.M. Preview Sept. 28th. 1 to 5 P.M. 2 Whitehall Ave., Deal, N.J. Estate of M. L. Buckner. Adm. $2.00.

NBCTV May Move Quickly to Drop Unpopular Shows
description: New television programs that have failed to catch the interest of the mass audience are likely to be canceled and replaced earlier than in any other season, some perhaps in the next few weeks, Robert Howard, president of NBCTV, indicated this week.

title: Suspended Sentence Given ExEditor in Stock Touting
description: William Eric Aiken, a former editor of Value Line Selection and Opinion who pleaded guilty last summer to accepting a $15,000 bribe to tout a stock, was sentenced on Monday to a suspended 18month prison sentence.

title: Stage: Odets in Hartford
U.S. Opposes Price Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (Reuters)  A spokesman for President Ford said the United States believed no increase in oil prices by OPEC was justified.

title: Birth Notice 6  No Title
Article 1  No Title
New U.N. Chief Hailed For His Staying Power
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24 Foreign Minister Sinnathamby Rajaratnam of Singapore reminded fellow diplomats today that a political leader who stays away from his capital incurs a certain risk.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Howard W. Johnson, chairman of the corporation of the Masachusetts Institute of Technology, has, been appointed president of the board of trustees of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. He succeeds John Coolidge, during whose twoyear term as president the board ousted Merrill C. Rueppel as museum director two years before the expiration of his fouryear contract. A successor to Mr. Rueppel has not yet been named.

title: Ali Says He Plans Year Off
description: MANILA, Sept. 24Muhammad Ali, who is capable of announcing his retirement and comeback in the same sentence, came up today with a plan to leave boxing flat on its back for a year.

title: Oldsters Recall Mamaroneck of Yesterday
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Sept. 24It was a time in Mamaroneck when young boys trapped muskrats and sold the pelts for a dollar, when the police patrolled on bicycles that, Battista J. Santoro recalled, they pushed more than they rode.

title: COMPANY REPORTS
description: For period ended Aug. 31 unless otherwise Indicated.

title: A Mushroom Walk and Other Amusements for Children
description: Although it is the former country estate of Henri Bendel and striking to look at, the Stamford Museum & Nature Center manages to keep a low profile most of the time. And if you don't live near it, chances are you don't know it exists. Nevertheless, it is a lively and lovely place to take children.

title: The Symbiotic Connection
description: At about 9 P.M. on Sept. 1, 1911, in the great Opera House of Kiev in the presence of Czar Nicholas II a young man named Bogrov drew a revolver and, firing at pointblank range, fatally wounded Premier Pyotr Arkadevich Stolypin.

title: IRAQ, IN U.N., ASKS ISRAFL'S OUSTER
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24Iraq's Foreign Minister today termed the plight of the Palestinians perhaps one of the supreme cases of injustice in the history of mankind, and said the right approach toward a settlement to the Middle East problem would, be the expulsion of Israel from the United Nations.

title: Kidney Patients Program in Trouble
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) Problems are plaguing the Federal Government's ambitious program to provide expensive artificial kidney treatments for thousands of people who otherwise would probably die.

title: Bayonne Bids Court Halt City Employes' SickOut
Issue and Debate
description: Growing concern over the legality of sports violence was underscored last Monday when the National Hockey League fined 62 players a total of $9,050 for exhibitiongame brawling.

title: IVON C. NEWBERG
description: Ivon C. Newberg, a Middle??own, Conn., real estate and insurance broker, died Tuesday at Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing, Queens at the age of 67.He is survived by his widow, Marian; two daughters, Mrs. Lester Baum and Ether R. Newberg, executive director of the New York State Democratic Committee; three brothers: two sisters, and two grandchildren.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: U. S,, SOVIET, CHINA REPORTED AIDING PORTUGAL, ANGOLA
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 24 Millions of dollars are being poured covertly into Portugal and Angola by East and West. according to four official sources in Washington. The funneling of the funds is part of the continuing struggle for control of the Mediterranean and for influence and raw materials in Central Africa.

title: Bill on Handicapped Cleared
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)The Senate gave final approval yesterday to a bill authorizing expenditures of $287million through the fiscal year 1978 to aid severely handicapped individuals. The voice vote approved a conference report on the bill, which the House passed last week. The measure goes to President Ford to be signed into law.

title: Curran Resigns Job As U.S. Prosecutor
description: Paul J. Curran announced yesterday that he was resigning as the United States Attorney here because it was time to return to private employment.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 AM., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Les Nations. L Espagnole, Couperin; Concerto for Two Pianos, Poulenc.

title: Oil Imports to U.S. Up Sharply in Week
description: Imports of crude oil and petroleum products into the United States rose sharply last week, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Article 7  No Title
Conflict at OPEC
description: A conflict over the size of an oilprice rise has developed at the Vienna meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Page 65.

title: AN INDONESIAN JET CRASHES, KILLING 23
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 24 (AP)An Indonesian jetliner overshot the runway today at Palembang in southern Sumatra, hit some coconut trees and burst into flames, killing at least 23 persons, officials said. Two others were reported missing, and 37 persons survived.

title: Stage: Odets in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 24The Hartford Stage Company has just opened its new season with a splendid and timely revival of Clifford Odets's finest play, Awake and Sing! The play stands up admirablyit is now exactly 40 years oldand the staging and the acting show the American resident theater at its very best. On Friday, Paul Weidner, the company's producing director, and his company are to receive the Margo Jones Award, given each year to the person or theater in America displaying the most initiative in uncovering and producing important. new works of dramatic literature.

title: Buckley Is Criticized
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Beame criticized Senator James L. Buckley yesterday for opposing direct Federal intervention in the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Up in Smoke
description: The peculiar priorities that operate in Congress when specialinterest legislation is on the floor have rarely been more evident than in the sneak maneuvers through which a $70million Federal handout is in process being given to tobacco growers.

title: Single Standard
description: Federal Judge Oliver J. Carter set exactly the right tone for the impending trial of Patricia Hearst on felony charges in ruling out requests for special treatment. What you are telling me is that I should make special rules for Miss Hearst and I am not going to do that, the judge told the heiress's attorney.

title: Westport Defeats a Change in Zoning Laws That Would Allow Apartment Buildings for the First Time
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 24 A plan to allow the construction of apartment buildings for the first time in this affluent residential suburb of singlefamily homes was resoundingly defeated here today.

title: Blinded Boy, the Man Who Attacked Him And Their Families Meet in a Courtroom
BOSTON TEACHERS GIVEN NEW OFFER
description: BOSTON, Sept. 24 (AP)Negotiators for striking Boston teachers considered a new School Committee offer tonight as enrollment in the newly integrated schools plummeted.

title: DEMAND IS HEAVY IN U.S. NOTE SALE
description: The Treasury auctioned $2billion of new 29month notes yesterday at an average yield of 8.10 per cent in a sale that attracted heavy public participation.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Stewart G. Pollock, a member of the Board of Public Utilities Commissioners, said that he was opposed to a proposal that would grant a 25 per cent discount on utility bills for the elderly. Mr. Pollock said that while he supported the purpose of the State Senate proposal, he could not endorse it because it would require one group of customers of a utility to underwrite the bills of another group of customers.

title: Indictment Charges A Transit Examiner Filed False Claims
description: A Kings County grand jury yesterday indicted a Transit Authority claims examiner on charges of creating fictitious claims for personal and property damage, recommending payment and then cashing the settlement checks for at least $16,250 under various names.

title: Contract Awards
description: Rohr Industries said it was the low bidder on a $49.1 million order to build 779 city transit buses for the New Jersey Department of Transportation. Delivery is ached uled to begin early next year.

title: PAYMENTS CITED BY CITIES SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24In the first voluntary submission by a company to the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Cities Service Company has acknowledged that one of its employes was given money to pay $30,000 for political purposes in a foreign country.

title: Death of Lake Studied To Pinpoint Man's Role
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24A century ago, silverladen steamboats chuffed across Owens Lake in Central California. Today it is 200 square miles of bonedry dust whose recurrent dispersion unhinges people physically and emotionally as much as 100 miles away.

title: SEATO to Be Ended
description: Foreign ministers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization agreed the 21yearold military alliance should be phased out. Page 22.

title: Newcombe Facing Tough Comeback
description: The money player is coming back, but how good will he be? John Newcombe, who missed Wimbledon and Forest Hills because of knee surgery, is working into shape in Hawaii and plans to enter his first tournament in his home town of Sydney, Australia, in three weeks.

title: No Help
description: In his meeting with the executive committee of the United States Conference of Mayors yesterday, President Ford matched his lack of concern over the problems of urban America with incredible unawareness of how much New York City has already done to end the chaos in its fiscal affairs. The nation's mayors found the White House well stocked with admonitions about prudent management, but Mayor Beame and his colleagues from other hardpressed cities came away with no change in the callous policies articulated earlier by Secretary of the Treasury Simonpolicies that can prove as damaging to the national economy as they are insensitive to urban needs.

CONVICTIONS UPHELD IN '68 FIREBOMBING
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 24State Superior Court Judge Sam J. Ervin 3d upheld today the 1972 convictions of three black activists accused of firebombing a riding stable here in 1968.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Hunting Debate
description: The world would be a far better place if someday we are rid of people like you who feel that the animal world is here for honorable men to dispose of as they wish, writes a correspondent to this column in response to comments therein on the subject of hunting.

title: JACOB A. PROBST
description: Jacob Anthony Probst, a lawyer who specialized in general corporate practice, died of pneumonia yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 40 East 66th Street and Westport, Conn.

title: A CRITIC IN SEOUL WARNS ON CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The South Korean opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung, believes his country will suffer the fate of another Vietnam unless the present Seoul Government is changed, he wrote in a document released here today.

title: Chess:

title: Katz, Former City Clerk, Indicted on Funds Charge
description: A yearlong investigation into payroll padding in the office of the City Clerk culminated yesterday in the indictments of Herman Katz, City Clerk for 16 years until he resigned last November, and Thomas A Lenane, the former deputy clerk.

description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 24 (AP) Baltimore's Jim Palmer notched his 22d victory, beating the Detroit Tigers, 81, tonight as the Orioles moved within 3 games of firstplace Boston in American eague East.

title: BIDS FROM DEBTORS ACCEPTED BY C.M.I.
description: Continental Mortgage Investors, one of the nation's big real estate investment trusts, said yesterday that it had accepted bids from a group of its senior debtors to purchase selected pieces of property from the trust's portfolio. The trust refused to name the banks involved.

title: Redford a C.I.A. Eccentric in Three Days of Condor
description: Turner (Robert Redford) is not your stereotypical Central Intelligence Agency operative, the shorthaired, buttoneddown kind we've seen testifying live on television from time to time. Turner's hair is fashionably long. He wears blue jeans and shirts without ties and he rides to work on a motorcycle. He's an eccentric link in the C.I.A. chain of command.

description: Paul J. Curran announced yesterday that he was resigning, as the United States Attorney here because it was time to return to private employment.

description: The New York Nets and Denver Nuggets of the American Basketball Association have applied for admission to the rival National Basketball Association. They are expected to announce their applications today, The Associated Press reported.

title: Portuguese Asks Military To Get Out of Government
description: LISBON, Sept. 24A leader of the second largest political party in the Portuguese coalition cabinet demanded today that the armed forces get out of government soon and open the way for the free play of electoral forces.

title: House Urged to Delay Hearings On I. R. S. Intelligence Programs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Department of Justice has urged a House investigating subcommittee to hold off public hearings on two top secret tax intelligence programs because disclosure might disrupt several potential prosecutions, House and departmental sources said today.

title: G.O.P. GROUP WARNS OF LOSSES IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)  Republicans, already outnumbered 2 to 1 in the House, could lose 25 more seats in next year's elections, a party panel has warned Republican. members.

description: LONDON, Sept. 24, (AP) A three  month advance that raised the United States dollar's overseas value by more than 10 per cent leveled off today, offering at least temporary relief to European currencies and gold.

description: I was attracted by the high yield and also by the fact that you don't pay any state or local taxes on the interest.

title: Rangers Defeat Bruins, 43, in First Exhibition Game
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 24With their power play in midseason form, the New York Rangers opened their preseason schedule tonight by beating the Boston Bruins, 43, at Providence Civic Center.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS TURKISH ARMS VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (Reuters)The Rules Committee of the House of Representa??ives today cleared the way for a new vote on lifting the arms ??mbargo against Turkey, de??ating an effort to postpone ??t for a month.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24Foreign ministers of the Southeast Asian Treaty Organization agreed today that the alliance should now be phased out.

title: Soviet Colt in Laurel Classic
description: The $150,000 Washington, D.C. International took on a decided foreign note yesterday with the announcement that the Soviet Union would be represented for the first time in nine years in the 1mile turf classic at Laurel on Nov. 8. John D. Schapiro, president of the Maryland thoroughbred racing plant, said at a luncheon at 21 Club in midtown Manhattan that the entry brought the number of definite foreign nations involved so far to six.

title: Coventry, England
description: COVENTRY, EnglandBy middleclass standards David Kershaw is doing well. He makes $13,500 a year, enough to put him among the top 10 per cent of Britain's wageearners. He has a good home, a challenging job and money in the bank.

title: VON SALLMANN DEAD, EYE RESEARCHER, 83
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24Dr. Ludwig Von Sallmann, former chief of ophthalmology at the National Institutes of Health, died here today at I he Washington Hospital Center. He was 83 years old.

title: Miss Moore in Upset
description: DENVER, Sept. 24 (UPI)Topseeded Martina Navratilova swept through her secondround match in the $50,000 Majestic women's tennis tournament last night. Wendy Overton bowed to 35yearold Sally Moore in three sets.
