title: Gromyko and Israeli Meet For Rare Talk on Mideast
description: Foreign Minister Yigal Alton of Israel and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, met for three hours last night at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations. It was the highestlevel SovietIsrael contact in nearly two years.

title: U.S. Assists Mauritania
description: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania, Sept. 24 (Agence FrancePresse) The United States signed an agreement here last night to add $335,000 for drought relief to a total development subsidy of $3million granted to Mauritania.

title: Hunts' Friend Says That He Suggested Wiretaps
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 24Kenneth Stanley Adams, owner of the Houston Oilers, a professional football team, testified today that he did not know it was illegal when he suggested to Nelson Bunker Hunt that he tap the telephones of Hunt Oil Company employes in an attempt to learn who had embezzled up to $50million.

title: College, School Results SOCCER
Whittling the E.P.A.
description: Three years ago Congress passed the Pesticide Control Act precisely because the old law of 1947 was weak, ineffective and limited to items in interstate commerce. Now the farm lobby and its champions in Congress are trying to undo the 1972 statute and undermine the power of the Environmental Protection Agency to control the use of a few potentially dangerous chemicals.

title: W. T. GRANT WINS SOME RENT CUTS
description: Some 10 to 15 per cent of the landlords of the 1,000 stores operated by the W. T. Grant Company have agreed to the retail chain's recent request for a 25 per cent reduction in rentals over the next two years.

title: WILLIAM T. HIGGS
description: William T. Higgs, president of Higgs Marine Service in the Bronx, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 72 years old and lived adjacent to his company's marina and in Jupiter, Fla.

title: Air Force Discharges Homosexual Sergeant
description: DOVER, Del., Sept. 24 (UPI) Sgt. Rudolph Keith has been given an honorable discharge from the Air Force because he is an admitted homosexual, a spokesman at Dover Air Force base said today.

title: C.I.A. MEN OPENED 3 SENATORS' MAIL AND NOTE TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence disclosed today that over a 20year period ending in 1973, the Central Intelligence Agency opened foreign correspondence to and from prominent Americans, including Richard M. Nixon and Senators Hubert H. Humphrey, Edward M. Kennedy and Frank Church.

title: Birth Notice 1  No Title
POSTAL SERVICE CUT IN RURAL AREAS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) Postal service to rural America would deteriorate if Congress agrees to the closing of 12,000 small post offices, the president of the National Association of Postmasters said today.

title: City's DrugAgency Head Denies He Plans to Quit
description: The Commissioner of the city's Addiction Services Agency, Jerome Hornblass, yesterday assailed as politically motivated a Federal study of the agency's administration of nine local drug programs that led to the transfer of a $4.4million grant from the city to the state.

title: TV: A W alters Visit to Royal Lovers
description: NBC's daytime programing department has spent about $250,000 to bring forth a 90minute television program that may well be the most ridiculous curiosity of the season. Barbara Walters Visits the Royal Lovers can be seen this afternoon at 1:30.

title: Gromyko and Israeli Meet For Rare Talk on Mideast
description: Foreign Minister Yigal AlIon of Israel and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, met for three hours last night. at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations. It was the highestlevel SovietIsrael contact in nearly two years.

title: NEW JERSEY
STEINGUT CONCERN IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: The special state prosecutor for nursing homes, Charles J. Hynes, has been investigating an insurance concern in which Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut was a principal until late last year, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Egypt Obtains 3 Arab Loans
description: CAIRO, Sept. 24 (Reuters) Egypt obtained $1.2billion in longterm loans from three Arab countries, Finance Minister Ahmed Abu Ismail said today. He said these included $600million from Saudi Arabia, $500million from Kuwait and $100million from Qatar. They were at low interest rates over 15 years with a fiveyear grace period.

title: Defender Beaten In Senior Golf
description: CARMEL, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP)  Henry Edwards, an Oklahoma City golfer playing in his first United States Seniors championship, knocked the defending champion out of the tournament today.

title: Birth Notice 20  No Title
2 Italian Doctors Arrested In the Deaths of 17 Infants
description: ROME, Sept. 24Two physicians in Avellino, near Naples, have been arrested in connection with the deaths of at least 17 newborn babies from salmonella poisoning in the last two weeks.

title: Byrne to Consider Asking $20Million for Medicaid
description: TRENTON, Sept. 24Facec with increasing threats by phy sicans and dentists of with. drawal from New Jersey's Medicaid program, Commissioner Ann Klein of the State Depart. ment of Institutions and Agen ties will meet with Governor Byrne this week to consider a request to the Legislature to appropriate $20million for Medicaid.

title: Music: Career Change
description: Dennis Koster, who abandoned a career as a flamenco guitarist seven years ago to study the classic guitar, gave the first recital of his new career on Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Still in his mid20's, Mr. Koster needs further maturing, both musically and technically, but he played a difficult program with considerable success.

title: Birth Notice 15  No Title
description: AUTION SALES

title: Search for Drums Goes On
description: The Coast Guard continued its search yesterday in the Upper Bay off Staten Island for 69 steel drums containing the slightly toxic weedkiller Cobex. Teams of divers and a flotilla of 14 boats recovered 54 of the 123 drums that fell into the water when a pier at Clifton, S. I., collapsed Tuesday.

title: Pro Transactions
Woman Trapped 22 Hours in Hospital Elevator on L.I.
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 24A 57yearold nurse's aide was trapped in an elevator at Hempstead General Hospital for 22 hours before being discovered this morning.

title: MRS. BERNHARDT COHEN
description: Leah Cohen, widow of Bernhardt Cohen, an inventor and manufacturer of textile products, died Tuesday at her home on East 77th Street. She was 73 years old.

title: Neat, Calm Air Belies City Labor Troubles
description: BAYONNE, Sept. 24This city appeared calm and reason. ably neat today as most of its policemen, firemen and sanitationmen refused to go to work for the fifth day in a row.

title: U.S INTERVENTION ON IMETAL DENIED
description: A toplevel Treasury official told Congress yesterday that the Government had no basis to interfere in the proposed acquisition of the Copperweld Corporation by the French Rothschild interests.

title: Unions Challenge Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 24 (Agence FrancePresse) Ethiopia's Federation of Trade Unions has delivered an ultimatum to the provisional military government to establish democratic freedoms within a month or face appropriate measures, according to a resolution adopted last night at a congress here.

title: GOLD FUTURES UP AFTER LONG DROP
description: Higher prices for gold yesterday in Europe gave a lift to gold futures contracts here of ter a long decline, resulting in a drop of about $20 an counce in the last eight trading sessions.

title: Yanks Put Off Again
description: The American League's Eastern Division pennant race was disrupted by rain for the second straight time last night when the Yankees and Boston Red Sox were forced to postpone their doubleheader at Shea Stadium.

title: Career Civil Servant Named Acting Head Of Park Department
description: Alexander Wirin, a career civil servant with 44 years' service in the city's Parks Department, was appointed Acting Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administrator last evening by Mayor Beame.

title: Panel Blocks Fed Audit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (Reuters)  The House Rules Committee today blocked a bill to require a Government audit of the Federal Reserve System. The bill would have required a full audit of the General Accounting Ofice, the accounting arm of Congress.

title: U.S. Witness Refuses to Link Mrs. Swinton With Bomb Plot
description: A government witness in the trial of Patrician E. Swinton on bomb conspiracy charges yesIterday denied telling Federal authorities a week ago that Mrs. Swinton had once told him she had written propaganda for an antiwar group that planted homemade time bombs at several locations in New York City in 1969.

title: CEMETERY PLOTS
description: GRAVE PLOTS for sale, Lexington, ?? ?? Memorial Cemetery. Earl Hanover, ?? Make offer. 20167??4338.

title: SIMON IS SCORED ON FISCAL POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The chairman and key members of a joint Congressional committee berated Treasury Secretary William E. Simon today as callous, and indifferent and called him the author of bankrupt policy that offered no relief for New York City's fiscal crisis.

title: Marine Is Among Three Held In $200,000 Theft From Navy
description: GAETA, Italy, Sept. 24 (AP) An American marine, an American civilian and an Italian were arrested today in the theft of $200,000 from the payroll for the U.S. Sixth Fleet's flagship.

title: GAINS HELD MINOR IN F.B.I. BREAKINS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) Domestic intelligence operations of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, including breakins in New York City and Chicago in the nineteensixties, produced few warnings of extremist and subversive activities and few convictions, Congress was told today.

title: Life Support for the Ill
description: Should the machine keeping Karen Ann Quinlan alive be turned off? That question, which demands a yes or no answer, has raised important and perplexing theological, medical, legal, social and ethical issues. But, as so often happens when difficult and unusual questions are raised, the courts have been called upon to provide an answer.

title: West Mifflin, Pa.
description: WEST MIFFLIN. Pa. When Gregory Wawro asked for some new toy cars not long ago, his mother told him they cost too much.

title: Market Place
description: The consensus these days is that the economy is getting ready to move upward after a year of widespread inventory liquidation by manufacturers.

title: Suspected Killer of 2 Policemen Seized As Officers, Acting on Tip, Spring Trap
description: Luis Serrano Velez, who had been sought as the gunman in the killing of two police officers on the Lower East Side last week, was arrested here last night when he succumbed to a police ruse and ran out of a West 19th Street apartment into the arms of four waiting detectives.

title: U. S., SOVIET, CHINA REPORTED AIDING PORTUGAL, ANGOLA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Millions of dollars are being poured covertly into Portugal and Angola by East and West. according to four official sources in Washington. The funneling of the funds is part of the continuing struggle for control of the Mediterranean and for influence and raw materials in Central Africa.

title: ISIDORE NEEDLEMAN OF AMTORG TRADING
description: Isidore G. Needleman, general counselor for the Amtorg Trading Corporation, the official Soviet Government commercial agency in this country, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, in St. Michael's, Barbados, where he had been on legal business. He was 72 years old and lived at 444 Central Park West.

title: M. A. C., City and State Aides Save Agency About to Default
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday came to the rescue of the New York City Educational Construction Fund, the independent agency that had faced default on $81 million in notes maturing today.

title: A's Win To Clinch West Title
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 24 The Oakland A's clinched the Western Division title in the American League for the fifth straight year tonight. They defeated the Chicago White Sox, 132, as Reggie Jackson hit two homers, his 33d and 34th of the season, and Vida Blue won his 21st game.

title: C.I.A. MEN OPENED 3 SENATORS MAIL AND NOTE TO NIXON

Nixon and Senators Hubert H. Humphrey, Edward M. Kennedy and Frank Church.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
GRACE DISCUSSES A SALE OF STOCK
description: W. R. Grace & Co., the inernational industrial conglomerate, is discussing an agreement to sell four million shares of newly issued common stock for $104million, or $26 a share, to the Friedrich Flick Group of Dusseldorf, West Germany. Grace currently has 31,301,471 common shares outstanding. Thus, if the sale is completed, the German organization would hold 11.3 per cent of Grace's outstanding common shares and would be the American company's largest single stockholder. The Flick Group would also he represented on the Grace board.

title: Modern Museum Plagued by Leaks
description: The Museum of Modern Art Is plagued by leaks in the roof and walls of the East and Garden Wings, additions completed 11 years ago at a cost of $5.5million. Since last spring, workmen have repaired the garden wall, facing on East 54th Street, removing its capstones to fill hollows where water had entered and affected the glazed surface of the brick, at a reported cost of $70.000.

title: Ford in Grain Assurance
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)  President Ford today assured a group of lawmakers and farmers the moratorium on grain sales to the Soviet Union and Poland is very temporary and will be resolved in the near furture.

title: Belmont Jockeys
Japanese Socialists, Ending First Visit to U.S. Since 1957, Foresee Better Ties
description: A leader of the Japan Socialist party, which after three decades in the Opposition now sees hope of gaining a role in the Government, declared here yesterday that the party was not willing to play a subordinate role as an American mascot.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1975

title: TIMES AND NEWS GET PHOTOGRAPH PRIZES
description: Photographers of both The New York Times and The Daily News won three awards in the 1975 New York State Associated Press Association photography contest.

title: Britain Announces Measures To Reduce 5.4% Jobless Rate
description: LONDON, Sept. 24The British Government announced measures today to alleviate the country's unemployment problem.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Horses Listed in Order of Post Positions Letter Designates OTB Listing

title: ExLegislator Wins No Show Case
description: ALBANY, Sept. 24An Albany County judge today dismissed criminal charges against Martin Ginsberg, a former Assemblyman from Nassau County who had been accused of putting two no show employes on his official payroll.

title: 3 ExJersey City Aides Indicted In Award of I.B.M. Contract
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 24A Hudson County grand jury indicted today three former Jersey City officials, an employe of the International Business Machines corporation, and an employe of the First Jersey National Bank on charges of conspiring to rig the specifications on a computer contract in favor of I.B.M. The company was also named as a conspirator.

title: Despite Its Workers' Walkout, Bayonne Appears Calm
description: BAYONNE, Sept. 24This city appeared cal mand reasonably neat today as most of its policemen, firemen and sanitationmen refused to go to work for the fifth day in a row.

description: Honored members of the Academy! Kafka's story begins. You have done me the honor of inviting me to give your Academy an account of the life I formerly led as an ape

title: Earle Cabell Dallas Mayor During 1963 Assassination
description: DALLAS, Sept. 24 (UPI)Earle Cabell, who was Mayor of Dallas at the time of the assassination of President Kennedy in 1963, died today of emphysema. He was 69 years old.

title: SovietCape Verde Ties Set
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24 (Reuters) The Soviet Union announced today it had agreed to establish diplomatic relations with the Cape Verde Islands Republic and would set up an embassy in the former Portuguese territory. The announcement, by the Tass press agency, said the island republic off the coast of northwest Africa would open an embassy in Moscow.

title: Panama Apologizes For Youths' Attack On U. S. Embassy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The Panamanian Government has apologized to the United States for an incident yesterday in which demonstrators broke about 100 windows in the American Embassy in Panama City, the State Department reported today.

title: Birth Notice 11  No Title
Archives Employe Testifies on Timing Of Nixon Donation
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24Mary W. Walton Livingston, a bespectacled, elderly archivist, testified today that it was not until March, 1970, that selection was made of Richard M. Nixon's Vice Presidential papers o be donated to the National Archives.

title: Saudis and OPEC Arguing on Size of OilPrice Rise
description: VIENNA, Sept. 24A ministerial conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries moved today toward what was expected to be a modest price increase for oil, but conflicts developed, chiefly between Saudi Arabia and militant members, over the size of the increase.

description: Chicago at Oakland  Wood (1520) vs. Holtzman (1714),

title: Events Today
CURRAN QUITS JOB AS U.S. ATTORNEY
description: Paul J. Curran announced yesterday that he was resigning as the United States Attorney here because it was time to return to private employment.

title: City Seeks to Speed Foreclosures Over Back Taxes
description: Legislation to cut the time in which the city can foreclose on taxdelinquent properties from three years to one year, and to enable the appointment of a receiver to collect rents to meet overdue taxes, will be introduced in the City Council shortly, Councilman Edward L. Sadowsky, chairman of the Charter and Governmental Operations Committee, said yesterday.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: LOS ANGELESFrankie Duane, 117 pounds, Venice, Calif., knocked out Jose Rosa, 115, Pasadena; Calif., 6 rounds. MIAMI BEACHOteniel Martinez, 133, Colombia, knocked out Frankie Otero, 133, Hialeah, Fla., 6; Vinnie Curto, 161, Miami Beach, drew with John Pinney, 162, Tampa, Fla., 10.

title: McCarthy Seeks Protection
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)  Eugene J. McCarthy's campaign chairman formally requested Secret Service protection today for the former Democratic Senator from Minnesota who is an announced independent candidate for President.

title: Music of Germans at America First
description: The series Hear America First faithfully obeyed the injunction in its title during the first three seasons of its existence. On Tuesday night, beginning its fourth season, it perversely, or as a kind of backlash, put on a program that might have been called Hear Germany Second. It included music by Peter Cornelius, Felix Draeseke and Julius Reubke, once important followers of Liszt in the mid19th century, who belonged to what was then called the New German School.

title: Suburban Police Chief on Coast Links Miss Hearst and the Harrises to Bombings
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24Patricia. Hearst and William and Emily Harris were linked today by a suburban police chief to, terrorist bombings that occurred in this area within the last six weeks.

title: COURT SAYS NIXON CAN BE QUESTIONED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24Former President Richard M. Nixon was ordered by a Federal judge today to submit to questioning under oath in a deposition in a civil lawsuit involving the wiretapping of Morton H. Halperin, a former National Security Council official.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FESTA ITALIANA The third annual Italian festival sponsored by the Shrine Church of Our Lady of Pompei begins tonight on Carmine Street in Greenwich Village. The opening marks the start of the parish's 50th year. It was in this parish that Mother Cabrini, the first American to be canonized, taught Sunday school.

title: FLORENCE PERLMAN, LEADER IN HADASSAH
description: Florence Bierman Perlman, a leader in many areas of the Hadassah organization, died of a brain tumor yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at 25 East 9th Street.

title: Miss Moore Says She Acted Alone in Protest
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept 24 (AP) Sara Jane Moore says she acted alone and was driven by personal rage and frustration when she fired a shot at President Ford in San Francisco on Monday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Agriculture Investigation on Possible Grain Fraud Said to Find Bureaucrats Inept
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The Department of Agriculture, in an investigation of its own failure to act on repeated warnings of possible corruption in the grain export trade, has uncovered a pattern of bureaucratic ineptitude and timidity, according to Government officials.

title: Dave Anderson
description: MANILA, Sept. 24He continues to be introduced as Smokin' Joe Frazier, but the smoke flutters in wisps now, as if the flames inside him had burned out. Once he was a gladiator consumed by fury. In those years he attacked his sparring partners, snorting and grunting and ripping them with his left hook, punishing them. When he finally had his headgear yanked off, he was smiling from the sheer joy of brutality. His sparring partners puffed their cheeks in relief. But today that fury and that left hook seldom were evident as Joe Frazier prepared to challenge Muhammad Ali in their world heavyweight championship fight, which will be available at United States closedcircuit television locations Tuesday night. Wearing an orange version of a small boy's playsuit, the 31yearold former champion worked methodically, almost mechanically, at the Folk Arts Theater where both boxers train. It's not easy for Joe Frazier to follow Muhammad Ali's act, which may be one reason the champion toils first. Ali upstaged Frazier again, peeking at him and provoking laughter from the audience as Flip Wilson would if he clowned behind Marlon Brando during a Shakespeare recital. In the ring, Joe Frazier pretended not to notice Ali's presence. By the time his workout ended, Ali had departed in a howl of sirens. But even as Joe Frazier, wrapped in an orange robe, leaned on the ropes above a multitude of newsmen, Ali intruded again.

title: BACHE GROUP LISTS PROFIT FOR QUARTER
description: The Bache Group, Inc., one of the nation's leading investment securities companies, reported yesterday a profit of $4.7million or 67 cents share, on revenues of $64.7million in the quarter ended July 31. In the yearearlier period, the company lost $1million on revenues of $40.4million.

title: People and Business
description: Lack of equity capital Is threatening the survival of America's minority businesses, the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson asserted yesterday at the start of the PUSH Expo in Chicago.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 1,250,000 common shares of Christensen, Inc., at $16.50 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. The offering includes 600,000 shares being sold by the company and 650,000 being sold by certain selling shareholders.

title: MAYOR'S LEAD CUT IN BOSTON VOTING
description: BOSTON, Sept. 24Mayor Kevin H. White held the top position in yesterday's nonpartisan preliminary election here, but by a much smaller margin than had been expected.

title: judge in Hearst Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24 Federal District Judge Oliver J. Carter did not meet Patricia Campbell Hearst for the first time last Friday when she entered Courtroom Eleven and case No. 74364 got under way. He met her 15 years ago when she was a little girl romping in the 22room family house in Hillsborough and he, already a Federal judge and a former highranking Democratic party official, was there as her father's guest.

title: Fleming Ousts Ramirez In West Coast Tennis
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24 (AP)Peter Fleming of Chatham, N.J., upset fourthseeded Raul Ramirez of Mexico, 63, 64, today in a secondround match of the $.100,000 tennis tournament at the Cow Palace.

title: Brazil Churchmen Fighting to Avert Bishop's Expulsion
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 23 (Reuters)  Brazilian church leaders have asked Pope Paul VI to intervene over the threatened expulsion of an outspoken bishop who has defended poor farmers against large landowning companies in the Amazon region.

description: PANAMA CITY BEACH, Fla. Sept. 24Bill Woodyard nevez feared the sea.

description: Oddly enough, Jam, subtitled a workinprogress, had a more finished look than any of the other officially completed, danced presented by Diane Elliot and Diane Boardman on Tuesday evening at the Cubiculo.

description: Kathleen Tatiana McKenna, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Steele Nichols of New York and Owings Mills, Md., and the late Norbert Augustin McKenna, was married yesterday afternoon to Sadat Pakay, son of Mrs. Ibrahim Pakay of Istanbul, Turkey, and the late Mr. Pakay.

description: HOBOKEN, Sept. 24The Hoboken Teachers Association continued to strike today, defying a second court order, issued yesterday, to return to work and a contempt citation that had cost it a $5,000 fine.

title: Seaver Foiled In NoBitter Bid
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 24Torn Seaver, for the fifth time in his career, was thwarted in his efforts to pitch a nohit, norun game today when the Cubs' rookie outfielder, Joe Wallis, singled to right field with two out in the ninth inning. It was the closest Seaver had ever come to pitching a nohit game and despite his superlative effort, he was not around for the finish when the Mets lost in the 11th inning, 10.

description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP)  Patricia Hearst is no longer listed as an urban guerrilla on a jail booking slip.

description: DETROIT, Sept. 24The four United States auto makers today reported midSeptember sales that were only sixtenths of 1 per cent behind the same period a year ago. Analysts said that sales were the fifth highest for the period and that strong early demand for the 1976 models were a factor in the improvement.

description: VICTORIA, British Columbia, Sept. 24 (AP)Negotiations in the strike by 13,000 British Columbia pulp workers broke down today but officials representing the forest industry and another union will continue their talks.

title: CORRECTION

He is a professor of psychiatry there and president of the American Psychiatric Association.

Mr. Kissinger may not have been aware then that his prediction would be put to a crucial test in the House of Representatives within 48 hours.

title: Clive Morton, Actor, Dies at 71; Butler in Upstairs, Downstairs
description: LONDON, Sept. 24 (AP)Clive Morton, a wellknown character actor who had ap peared in some 60 films, more than 100 television productions and many stage plays in a career that began in 1926, died today. He was 71 years old.

She was the wife of Walter .1. Holmes, public relations officer for State Controller Arthur Levitt, and made her home in Rockaway Point.

Nev., Sept. 24 (AP)Tom Watson and Al Geiberger topped the field for the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament starting tomorrow on the 6,800yard, par71 Sahara Nevada Country Club course. Geiberger and Watson, the two leading moneywinners in the 144man field, will chase the $27.000 first prize.

Tax on Pornography Rises In Balanced French Budget

description: There's a lot of things to be said about the game that haven't been said before, declared Marvin [Mandy] Rudolph yesterday as he lef his post as chief referee in the National Basketball Association to become a CBS television commentator for N.B.A. games, replacing Oscar Robertson. There's a lot of fun to be had there, a lot of intricacies to explain. And in the past the referees have been unduly criticized at times.

title: What Not to Do
description: BOSTON, Sept. 24When President Ford came out of the St. Francis Hotel in San Francisco, he did not plunge into the crowd to shake hand's; he just waved and headed for his car a few feet away. Large numbers of uniformed policemen kept people back with the help of barriers. There were plainclothesmen in and watching the crowd, and Secret Service agents surrounded the President.

description: The recent contraction in savings inflows at savings and loan associations and savings banks has again rised fears of a shortage of funds for home mortgages. It has also spurred interest in a type of mortgage that many thrift institutions have long been promoting as a means of providing an increased and more stable flow of housing creditthe variablerate mortgage.

description: Emerson Boozer returned to the Jets' backfield yesterday after having given his slightly separated left shoulder a few weeks to heal.

description: LISBON, Sept. 24  Vera Lagoa was not arrested today, as she had expected. But she is ready anyway, as is her friend. Fernanda Leitao.

description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (UPI)Vermont Royster, who was editor of the Wall Street Journal for 13 years, and six other journalists have received Gerald Loeb awards for distinguished business and financial writing.

title: Woman Fails in Attempt to Swim Around Manhattan
description: Diana Nyad, who swims long distances better than any other woman in the world, tried to swim around Manhattan yesterday. At P.M. she slid into the water off East 89th Street and headed north, but 6 hours 25 minutes later, feeling cold, frozen and tired, she was hauled aboard a police launch and taken to a hospital. She had got as far as Wall Street.

title: Article 2  No Title

description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (UPI)Seven firearms experts began private tests today on exhibits that were presented in the murder trial of Sirhan B. Sirhan to try to answer the question of whether more an one gun was used in the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

description: A conflict over the size of an oilprice rise has developed at the Vienna meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Page 35.

title: ROUSE PANEL ACTS ON CHILD CARE AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives approved today a basic change in the way that expenses for the care of children or other dependents can be used to reduce Federal income taxes.

title: Secret Service Intuition' Kept Ford Out of Crowd
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The White House said today that the Secret Service, acting on intuition, had cautioned President Ford against mingling with the particular crowd from which a woman fired a revolver at him Monday in San Francisco.

title: NYQUIST TO SEEK NEW RULE VOIDING CLASSTIME CUTS
description: The State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, said yesterday that he would seek new state regulations setting minimum schoolday lengths, effective next fall.

title: A Swimmer Fails to Circle Manhattan
description: Diana Nyad, who swims long distances better than any other woman in the world, tried to swim around Manhattan yesterday. At I P.M. she slid into the water off East 59th Street and headed north, but 6 hours 25 minutes later, feeling cold, frozen and tired. she was hauled aboard a police launch and taken to a hospital. She had got as far as Wall Street.

title: BEIRUT ACTS ANEW TO HALT FIGHTING
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon, Sept. 24Premier Rashid Karami announced this afternoon that at 20member committee had been formed to try to bring peace to Lebanon, which has been torn by outbreaks of political and communal violence since February.

title: New Suit Presses Right to Treatment for Mentally Ill
description: The legal concept of a right to treatment for mentally ill persons confined against their will, which various lawyers and psychiatrists have been battling to establish for 15 years, is being raised anew in a lawsuit filed recently in Federal District Court here.

title: Instant Magic Rinse Takes Years From Your Life!
description: I thought that young people had more problems than old people, and I hoped I could last until I was older so I wouldn't have all those problems. Then I looked around and saw that everybody who looked young had young problems and that everybody who looked old had old problems. The old problems to me looked easier to take than the young problems.

title: Earthquake in California
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 6.0 on the Richter scale struck the lower Gulf of California today, the United States Geological Survey reported.

title: Citibank's Analysis Of Conrail's Cost Put at $15Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The First National City Bank delivered to a House transportation subcommitte today a grim assessment of the future of the nation's railroads, forecasting. a $21.1billion cash gap over the next 10 years.

title: A CURB ON BUSING VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24In the second victory in a week for antibusing forces, the Senate voted today to bar the Department of Health, Education and Welfare from ordering the busing of students beyond the school nearest their homes.

title: Total Disclosure Is Urged on Any Pact to Sell the Garden to OTB
description: Alan N. Cohen, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, called yesterday for total public exposure of any arrangement that might be reached for the purchase of the Garden by the Offtrack Betting Corporation.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24New foreign direct investment in the United States declined slightly in 1974 from the record peak reached in 1973. the Commerce Department reported today. The inflow of foreign capital for direct investmentas distinguished from investment stocks and bondswas $2.22billion last year, compared with $2.66billion in 1973. Reinvestment of earnings United States affiliates of foreign companies was $1.55billion last year, making the total increase in the foreign direct investment position $3.5billion.

description: David D. Meador, who was manager of the Columbia University Club here from 1968 to 1973, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, in Boston. He was 44 years old.

title: MOST IN POLL SCORE POLICEFIRE STRIKES
description: A Gallup Poll released yesterday found that a majority of Americans believe policemen and firemen should not be permited to strike, but opinion was divided almost equally on whether sanitation workers should have the right to strike.

title: ASSASSINATION PLOT LAID TO FLORIDA MAN
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 24A 32yearold unemployed, forrner service station attendant was arrested in Ocala tonight on a Federal charge of conspiracy to assassinate the President.

description: Isabella Miele and her husband, Jean, stood in the corridor on the ninth floor of the State Supreme Court building in Brooklyn. They spoke in low voices with Charles Barra, an assistant district attorney.

title: Wall Street Firms Defend Rules Favoring Members of Exchange

description: Negotiators for both sides in the musicians' strike reassessed their respective positions yesterday as financial losses from the sevenday walkout mounted for producer's, nonsriking performers, theater district restaurants and other related businesses.

description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 25Governor Carey shifted his attention back upstate today but found the fiscal crisis of New York City dogging his trail In questions and concern.

title: 2 NEW IN DAUGHTER AT THE CITY OPERA
description: The New York City Opera's new production of The Daughter of the Regiment saw two new cast members Tuesday night. Neither stole the show, but then the show is so determinedly Sillscentered that nobody really could.

description: The New York Public Interest Research Group, a nonprofit citizens' organization, charged yesterday that Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was delaying a court determination of its challenge to the Legislature's voting many of its members $875,800 in lulus.

title: Imminent U. S.Spanish Treaty Raising Issue of Timing
description: MADRID, Sept. 24Spain and the United States are reported here to be close to agreement on five more years of friendship and cooperation just at the time of one of the strongest campaigns to be mounted in the West against the Franco Government.

title: Medical Dilemma
description: The dilemmas created by medical progress are rarely presented more poignantly than in the case of 21yearold Karen Ann Quinlan. She has now been in a coma for more than 160 days and her parents have asked a New Jersey court for permission to stop the machine that has kept her breathing these past five months.

title: Books of The Times
description: These stories are the sort that are generally praised as being marvelously understated. It would usually follow that the author's style, in his understatement, is delightfully lucid. Now, it seems to me that the majority of writers are understaters: there is almost always more to their characters and situations than they manage to convey. And often as not, writers do have a lucid style, which merely means that they are easily understood, rational, or clear.

title: Baseball Meetings End With Woes Unresolved
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 24 (AP)Major league baseball owners ended their meetings today without any definitive action on the problems facing the game on several fronts.

title: AMEX ISSUES RISE IN A BUSY SESSION
description: In brisker trading, prices moved ahead on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The index closed at 84.74, up 0.59. Volume rose to 1.61 million shares from Tuesday's 1.37 million.

description: The American Broadcasting Company said yesterday that Monday night's football game between Oakland and Miami drew a 36 per cent share of the national television audience About 40 million people watched at least part of the game, it reported.

Dozens of laws are being broken every day and night by the sex merchants and sex profiteers. The cuttingedge of this counterattack must be City Hall, with effective support from the courts.

description: Eugene J. O'Neill, Director of Public Safety for Bayonne, N.J., testified in Superior Court M Jersey City yesterday that a full complement of firemen was on duty Wednesday night and yesterday. It was the first time Bayonne had had normal fire coverage since Saturday, when most of its employes, including firemen, policemen and garbagemen, began calling in sick in a protest over wages.

title: Homosexual Controversy Erupts About Man Who Deflected Pistol
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25The husky former marine who emerged as a hero at the alleged attempt to assassinate resident Ford here Monday has since becqme the focus of a tontroversy over whether he is homosexual.

title: BRITAIN DISAVOWS DIEGO GARCIA ISSUE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25Foreign Secretary James Callaghan of Britain said today that his Government has no further liability for the 1,400 former inhabitants of the island of Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: After each assassination or assassination attempt, gun control prompts a brief flurry of outrage at the promiscuous use of guns in our society. People express serious interest in controlling gun abuse. Then, as the gun lobbyists go to work and apathy and resignation set in, the problem disappears from public view. We renew our interest only when a gun barrel is pointed at a President.

title: Sidney L. Solomon Dead at 73; Abraham & Straus Chairman
description: Sidney L. Solomon, chairman of Abraham & Straus until his retirement in January, 1970, and one of the country's most respected departmentstore merchants, died late Wednesday. He was 73 years old.

title: New Pact In N.F.L. Is Failing
description: National Football League players overwhelmingly rejected the owners latest contract offer yesterday, although the Cincinnati Bengals bucked the trend and voted to approve it.

title: Miss Moore Aided U.S. Firearms Unit Day Before Attack
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Sara Jane Moore, who is accused of attempting to assassinate President Ford, took part in an undercover Treasury Department operation against a suspected illicit firearms dealer a day after the department's San Francisco bureau was notified by the police that the woman had made what appeared to be a threat against the President's life.

title: Reserve Report
Krosnick, Quartet Cellist, Is Impressive on His Own
description: As cellist of the Juilliard String Quartet, Joel Krosnick must blend into the ensemble and to a great extent subordinate his artistic personality to the common good. Such selfabnegation probably breeds in any good ensemble musician the urge to break out now and then and do assertive, flamboyant things. Giddy things, even.

title: PLEAS ON 11 REBELS REJECTED IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, Sept. 25 (Reuters) A Spanish official today rejected protests abroad against death sentences passed on 11 urban guerillas.

title: PIKE TO REQUEST CONTEMPT ACTION IN C.I.A. INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Representative Otis G. Pike said today that in his opinion the executive branch was in contempt of Congress, and that he would ask the House of Representatives to take action next week.

title: The Pop Life
description: Reggaethat catchily syncopated form of Jamaican music that blends American soul and Kingston political resentment  may never sweep aside other forms of popular music, as its champions have been eagerly predicting for some time.

title: Priest in Coma Case Sees Problems in Legal Aspect
description: MOUNT ARLINGTON, Sept. 25The Rev. Thomas Trapasso, the priest who first advised Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Quinlan that a decision to seek permission for a natural death for their terminally ill daughter would not violate church teaching, has mixed feelings about moral theology being raised as a possible issue in court.

title: General Tire's Earnings Drop; Other Companies Also Report
description: AKROW, Ohio, Sept. 25 (Reuters)The General Tire and Rubber Company reported today a drop in earnings for the third fiscal quarter, ended Aug. 31, after setting aside $7.5million to cover the anticipated loss in the sale of its Spanish tire subsidiaries.

title: Shapp Enters Presidential Race As  Managerial Skill Candidate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania, who made a fortune as a businessman before entering politics, announced today that he was a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination on a platform of common sense governmental management.

title: DR. CARL FENICHEL OF LEAGUE SCHOOL
description: Dr. Carl Fenichel, founder and director of the League School for Seriously Disturbed Chlidren in Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home, 244 Henry Street, Brooklyn. He was 69 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The House Ways and Means Committee, responding to complaints of taxpayers and civil liberties groups, took some steps today to limit the authority that the Internal Revenue Service has in dealing with taxpayers.

PRUDENTIAL BUYS HAMBROS STOCK
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America has purchased about 2 per cent of the voting stock of Hambros, Ltd., and has made a $25million loan to Hambros, Reuters reported yesterday. The stock was, said to amount to about 2 lion shares worth:

title: Job Aid Intended for Poor Is Often Spent on Others
description: There is growing evidence that the Cdmprehensive Employment and Training Act of 1973 is often being used for purposes other than its intended one of providing job training and employment opportunities for the nation's disadvantaged.

description: A public offering of 125,000 common shares of Bangor Hydro  Electric Company, at $11.75 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Smith, Barney & Co., Inc.

description: The prospectus released yesterday by the Exxon Corporation for $400million in debentures and notes for the Exxon Pipeline Company disclosed new unauthorized payments by the corporation to officials of foreign governments.

description: Mankey

title: Major League Leaders
I Lost My Mind  In San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCOWho wants to be Chief Kook of Kookville anyway? I asked irreverently a few years ago when it looked as if Nobody would become Mayor of San Francisco. Therefore, I was less exercised than most of the locals when a Presidential aide, one lames Falk, described northern California as the kook capital of the world in the wake of attempts to assassinate President Ford in Sacramento and San Francisco.

title: Mandel Is Notified He's Among Targets In Maryland Inquiry
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 25Gov. Marvin Mandel revealed today that he had been notified by the Federal grand jury investigating political corruption in Maryland that he was a target of that investigation.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Monte Carmela is a very Italian restaurant at 1643 First Avenue near 85th Street, and Greek Village is a very Greek restaurant at 1016 Lexington Avenue near 72d Street. Monte Carmela won't bankrupt you if you use any common sense in ordering, and I have just figured that our meals at Greek Village, with appetizer, entree, dessert and coffee, have averaged $6.56 a person including tax, but no wine. You have to bring that yourself or go across the street to a Honor st ore.
