description: Federal Reserve

title: School Decentralization Facing Regents' Reform
description: ALBANY, Sept. 25Prompted by growing doubts about the effectiveness of New York City's school decontralization policy as it is currently structured, the State Board of Regents is expected to undertake an extensive examination of the fiveyearold policy.

title: EqualTime Rule On Political News Reversed by F.C.0
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The Federal Communication Commission, reversing long, held policy, ruled today that radio and television broadcast: of candidates news confer. ences and political debates wa no longer trigger equaltime access for all their opponents The 5to2 ruling, over tht Democratic National Commit tee's objections, could have in portant and immediate effect. on the Presidential campaigi of 1976.

title: BROTHER FIDELIS
description: Brother Fidelis Deichelbohrer, the first Maryknoll brother to be assigned to the missions in Africa, died of an electric shock Tuesday while doing repair work at the Maryknoll resience in Cincinnati. He was 65 years old.

title: Rain Cuts Crowd, Fields at Belmont
description: A sloppy track at Belmont Park for the sixth straight day found Joe King, the superintendent of the thoroughbred plant, taking the weather in stride. The same, however, was not true of horsemen and fans. Trainers of nine horses scratched entries from the program. Three of the withdrawals, made in the featurethe inappropriately named Sunsnme Nellcut the number of starters in that $20,000 sevenfurlong event to four.

title: COURT CURBS VESCO ON CONTROLS STOCK
description: Robert L. Vesco, the financier, and a personal holding company, Vesco & Co., Inc., have been ordered by a Federal judge to turn over to a courtappointed custodian all shares of the International Controls Corporation in their possession.

title: Secretary Schlesinger III
description: LONDON, Sept. 25 (Reuters) Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger became slightly ill today while flying by helicopter to a military establishment in western England. Mr. Schlesinger. 46 years old, is on an eightday European visit. He decided on medical advice to cancel the rest of his engagements and return to London.

title: Advertising
description: Reliable an ubiquitous sources in Detroit indicate that the beginnings of smiles are starting to appear on the peaked faces that run the auto industry.

title: EVEREST CLIMBED OVER NEW ROUTE
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Sept. 25 (AP)Two British climbers have made the first ascent of Mount Everest by the southwest face, the Nepalese Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: School Strikes Go On in Hoboken and Parsippany
description: Teachers strikes in Hoboken and ParsippanyTroy Hills continued yesterday despite court injunctions against the walkouts. There were some signs that progress toward settlements might he in prospect.

title: The Burnsian Cure
description: Chairman Arthur Burns of the Federal Reserve Board, in his major talk at the University of Georgia, has again addressed himself to the chronic problem of the postwar years: The inability of the United States economyand that of other countriesto achieve price stability and low unemployment at the same time.

title: A Dispute On Referee In Manila
description: MANILA. Sept. 25Debate over the selection of the referee for the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier world heavyweight championship fight developed today after Eddie Flitch, the challenger's manager, objected to Zack Clayton of Philadelphia as a candidate.

title: They Own the Streets
description: It used to be known as the Great White Way, Times Square, Broadway, the theater district; now it has become pimp, prostitute, porno and peepshow country. It is home for the big hustle, the mugger, con artists and criminals. This is the new worm in the Big Apple that has changed the character of the streets, the facades and even the buildings on some blocks in midtown Manhattan's West Side.

title: Facts in Musicians' Strike
description: Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. I. Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.

title: NB.A. Vows a Serious Look At Net, Nugget Applications
description: The New York Nets and Denver Nuggets applied formally yesterday for admission to the National Basketball Association for the 197677 season, but they faced legal challenges from within the league they are seeking to leave and from the N.B.A. Players Association.

title: Nothing Went Wrong
description: WASHINGTONNothing could reflect the chronic frustration of the Secret Service better than two related but contradictory political short reels acted out on Capitol Hill the morning following the arrest of Sara Jane Moore in the streets of San Francisco.

title: Books of The Times
description: The premise underlying this book is that its subject transcends its esthetics. We care so much abobt the composer Richard Rodgers, we think his life so significant, that anything he sets down in his autobiography, Musical Stages, is bound to be worth reading. Which is a fair enough assumption, up to a point. The music Mr. Rodgers has composed over the decades inhabits our consciousness like the furniture we grew up with. You didn't think anyone had actually created it; you assumed it had always been there. What's more, he has not only been connected with many of the most popular American, musical comedies of the past halfcentury  from The Garrick Gaieties of 1925 up through The Sound of Music of the early nineteensixties but he also helped to evolve the form of musical drama, from comedy illustrated with (and interrupted oy) song and dance, to plays in which story, dance, and song were integrated into a seamless whole.

title: INTEREST RATES TERMED STEADY
description: The upward pressure on interest rates appears to have abated, if only temporarily, and a period of shortterm stability in bank lending rates seemed possible following yesterday's report by the Federal Reserve B.ank of New York on the latest week's developments.

title: DEMOCRATS APPOINT SENATE PRISON AIDE
description: Emanuel R. Gold, the ranking Democratic member of the Republicancontrolled State Senate Committee on Crime and Corrections, yesterday appointed Burton Schoenbach, a prisonreform advocate and longtime gadfly of state corrections officials, as staff director and special consultant to the Democratic committee members.

title: Clyde Beals, 79, ExReporter And Newspaper Guild Aide
description: Clyde Beals, who had been an executive of the American Newspaper Guild and editor of The Guild Reporter from 1935 to 1940, died Sept. 12, apparently of a heart attack, at nursing home in O'Fallon, Ill. He was 79 years old.

title: Reporter in India For L.A. Times Ordered To Leave
description: NEW DELHI, Friday, Sept. 26 (AP)The Indian government today ordered the correspondent here of The Los Angeles Times. Jacques Leslie, to leave the country within 24 hours after his paper had refused to withdraw him.

title: Gardener Allergic to Grass
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP)Bill McDonnell who has worked as a gardener at Golden Gate Park for the last eight years, visited his doctor recently for a physical checkup. He was found to be in good condition except that he is allergic to grass.

title: Once More With Feeling
description: MANILA. Sept. 25To preserve a sense of proportion it is helpful to remember that people named Gus Dorazio, Johnny Paycheck and Ron Stander have fought for the heavyweight championship of the world and people named Marvin Hart. Primo Camera and Jersey Joe Walcott have held the title. A heavyweight championship fight is a major sporting event with a builtin quotient of excitement wherever it takes place. But when excitement crowds the borderline of hysteria the way it is doing here, it helps to remember that the principals in next week's entertainment are neither gods nor creatures from another planet, but two pugs their thirties with their best days behind them.

title: Congress, Despite Ford's Plea, Delays Action on Sinai Technicians
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Despite urgent pleas by President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger, the Administration has failed to win speedy Congressional approval for the stationing of 200 American technicians in the Sinai passes to monitor the new EgyptianIsraeli accord.

title: FarLeft Soldiers Stage Protest in Lisbon
description: LISBON, Sept. 25A large antiGovernment demonstration was held in Lisbon tonight under the sponsorship of an extreme leftist group of soldiers.

title: Rangers Fall, 83, To Bruins
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25Deep down in their hearts, the New York Rangers probably didn't expect to beat the Boston Bruins back to back. But when they took a 20 lead within the first 9 minutes tonight at Boston Garden, you could almost hear them humming to themselves: Two in a row, two in a row

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: OTB Payoffs subject to

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: Sept. 25. 28th day.

title: Harrises in Los Angeles Court For Arraignment on 18 Counts
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25Emily and William Harris were arraigned here today on 18 felony charges stemming from an episode last year that led to the death of fellow members of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army in a gun battle with the police.

title: 2 Storms Gain Intensity Over the Atlantic Ocean
description: MIAMI, Sept. 25 (UP)Tropcal storm Gladys grew to hurricane force today in the Atlantic Ocean while Faye approached hurricane intensity and churned toward Bermuda with 70mileanhour winds.

title: Parents Group Files Suit To Bar School Time Cut
description: A court suit aimed at preventing the Board of Education from reducing school time for pnpils as part of its settlement of th teacher strike was brought yesterday by the United Parents Associations. Acting on the parent group's motion, Justice Louis R. Heller of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn ordered the board to show next Friday why it should not be stopped from reducing the school time of elementary and juniorhigh school pupils by two 45minute class periods each week. Under the Sept. 16 agreement with the United Federatio of Teachers, which ended the recent five  day teachers strike, the two periods without pupils will be nsed for preparation or f ree time for teachers.

title: Shapp Enters Presidential Race As Managerial Skill Candidate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania, who made a fortune as a businessman before entering politics, announced today that he was a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination on a platform of common sense governmental management.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Mayor Burt Ross, of Fort Lee, whose testimony helped convict six men in an alleged bribe scheme, will be the new head of the New Jersey Energy Office. Mr. Ross, 32 years old, received nationwide attention last year when reported a $500,000 bribe attempt. He has been Mayor Fort Lee for four years. Governor Byrne said Mr. Ross's appointment did not require Senate confirmation.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: THE ORIENT EXPRESSION The Theater for Asian American Performing Artists is about six months old. It is the first group of its kind in the city producing theatrical works an its own, and it aims to provide AsianAmerican performers a place to work and to develop talents. It also seeks to train beginners. The group has performed at Lincoln Center and the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.

title: Miss Moore Aided U.S. Firearms Unit Day Before Attach
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25An undercover Federal firearms agent working with Sara Jane Moore accompanied her on a visit to a suspected illicit gun dealer the day before she allegedly attempted to kill President Ford in San Francisco, according to Government sources familiar with the case. The visit came one day after the police told Federal officials that Miss Moore had apparently threatened Mr. Ford's life.

title: Paula Shleffar Wed To Luis A. Garnica
description: Paula Lynn Shleaffar of New York was married last evening to Luis Armando Garnica, a Mexico City pianist and musical arranger who records for RCA with Los Internacionales, a rock group. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony in Temple EmanuEl.

title: Jury Pondering Swinton Verdict In Bombing of Federal Buildings
description: A jury began deliberating the fate of Patricia E. Swinton late yesterday in Federal District Court, where she is on trial on charges of conspiring to bomb Federal buildings in Manhattan in September and November, 1969. At 10:15 P.M. the jury ceased deliberations for the night.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 54311 UNTIL S:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:40 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (701) MARKET 3.39001 WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9.5300; NASSAU CO. (516) 74/.0500; SUFFOLK CO. ISM 6491800: CONNECTICUT 1203) 348.7767.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 6%
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 25The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated 51.12billion, up 8 per cent from the yearearlier $1.04billion. Total retail store sales were about $11.36billion, up 6 per cent from last year's $10.72billion.

title: OPEC DEADLOCKED ON OIL PRICE RISE
description: VIENNA, Sept. 25Oilexporting nations ere expected to go into a third, unscheduled day of talks tomorrow with differences over the size of a price increase described as tremendously wide.

title: Saudi Says Next Mideast Step Must Involve the Palestinians
description: The next step toward peace between the Arabs and the Israelis will have to involve the Palestinians, according to Prince Saud ibn Faisal, Saudi Arabia's Minister of State for Foreien Affairs.

title: $65,000 Big Board Seat Is Lowest in 20 Years
description: The New York Stock Exchange, plagued by continued low trading volume, reported a seat sale yesterday at a 20year low of $65,000down $60,000 from only a month ago.

title: LISBON AIDE DENIES REPORT OF C.I.A. HELP
description: PARIS, Sept. 25 (Reuters)Mario Soares, the Portuguese Socialist leader, today denied a press report that his party had received millions of dollars in aid channeled from the United States by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Stock Prices Drop On Amex and OTC; Trading Volume Off
description: In slow trading of only 1.2 million shares, prices on the American Stock Exchange moved down. The Amex index dropped to 84.56, off 0.17. Volume the previous day was 1.6 million.

title: ASSASSINATION PLOT ALLEGED IN FLORIDA
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. Sept. (AP)An unemployed service station attendant has told agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that he had been recruited to assassinate President Ford and Senator Edward M. Kennedy by a guerrilla group armed with rifles, grenades and rocket launchers, an F.B.I. agent said today.

title: Nainath to Play Against Chiefs
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 25 As he dressed for his first workout of the week, Joe Namath said today he had no doubts that he would play Sunday at Kansas City against the Chiefs.

title: 2 CHARTER ISSUES REVISED BY PANEL
description: The State Charter Revision Commission decided yesterday to withdraw tis recommendation that the City Controller be removed from the Board of Estimate and that the Mayor and Council President be coupled on a single ticket in quadrennial elections.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Oilexporting nations are expected to go into a third, unscheduled day of talks today in Vienna with differences over the size of a price increase described as tremendously wide. The leader of the Saudi Arabian delegation, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, left Vienna suddenly after what appeared to he almost a breakdown of the conference of ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. But he said he would return for today's meeting. [Page 1, Col. 7.]

title: Economists Are Waiting for September Fog to Clear
description: The numbers we're beginning to see do suggest that we're finally beginning to get some reasonably solid evidence that the recovery is making some considerable progress. That is the ultracautious way that Monthly Alan Greenspan, Perspective chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, ttad the tea leaves to an audience in New York earlier this month. September, which ends the third quarter of thk troubled year, seems to have left great uncertainty among; the economics profession's leading forecasters.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, twilightnight doubleheader, at Shea Stadium. Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow. Queens, 5:30 P.M. (RadioWMCA, 5:25 P.M.)

title: School Sports Drive Is Gaining
description: Efforts to restore funds to the Public Schools Athletic League program have resulted in little money so far, but the ??? for $1million seems to he gaining strength. The drive is being high guided by a group known as the School Save Our Sports Sports Committee. an amalgamation of prominent citizens, athletes and several P.S.A.L. coaches. The committee has made a significant move in the last few days, hiring a public relations consultant who is an experienced fundraiser.

title: ABC NEWS IN PACT WITH BRITISH GROUP
description: ABC News and Independent Television News, Ltd., of London announced yesterday the signing of a cooperative agreement under which each company will in effect purchase the rights to the other's news film and tapes daily. Desired news clips from either organization will be sent across the Atlanic by satellite.

title: House Panel Cuts Defense Requests Nearly $9Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 25 (UPI) The House Appropriations Committee voted today to cut defense spending requests by nearly $9billion, including $344.2  million reduction in funds for intelligence activities.

title: Two Men Call Musicians' Union Tunel
description: The men who hold sway over how much music will be heard in the coming weeks on Broadway and at the Metropolitan Opera are a labor leader who once played the drums and a labor lawyer who wishes he could play the piano.

title: Suspect in the Killings of 2 Policemen May Be Linked to a 3d Muirder Here
description: Luis Serrano Velez, the 26yearold former convict who, was arraigned yesterday for the murder of two police officers last week may also have been the gunman in a third homicide case here, the police said yesterday.

title: What Price Franco?
description: The United States may be on the verge of compounding its previous blunders on the Iberian peninsula with a fiveyear renewalat a cost to this country of $750millionof an agreement on friendship and cooperation with Spain. Here is another example of Secretary of State Kissinger's penchant for insensitive policies, supposedly rooted in realpolitih, that are offensive to the NATO allies and damaging to longrun American interests.

title: Mr. Ford's Bad Politics
description: The President and the press are giving each other a lot of free advice these days, not for the first time. The press is advising the skipper to be a little more careful, lest he gain a few votes and lose his life, and the President is advising the press to be a little less sensational lest it make heroes of assassins and encourage the violence it deplores.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Oilexporting nations are expected to go Into a third, unscheduled day of talks today in Vienna with differences over the size of a price increase described as tremendously wide. The leader of the Saudi Arabian delegation, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, left Vienna suddenly after what appeared to he almost a breakdown of the conference of ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. But he said he would return for today's meeting. [Page 1, Col. 7.1

title: Premier Bratteli of Norway Will Resign in January
description: HAMAR, Norway, Sept. 25 (Renter)Premier Trygve Brattell told a meeting of his party's national council today that he would resign early in January.

title: New Bond Issues
I.R.A. Warns British That Military Acts Will Go On in Ulster
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 25The I.R.A. Provisionals declared today that they would continue to take military action in Northern Ireland but indicated that their truce remained in force. The action, they said, would be in response to violations of their truce agreement with the British Army.

title: Business Records
description: Business

title: Job Aid Intended for Poor Is Often Spent on Others
description: There is growing evidence that the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act of 1973 is often being used for purposes other than its intended one of providing job training and employment opportunities for the nation's disadvantaged.

title: Westchester Study Sees An End to Era of Growth
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 25The days of population and economic growth in Westchester County, long a magnet for city dwellers and businesses on the move, may be over.

title: THEFF IS CHARGED IN MEDICAID BILLS
description: MINEOLA, L.I, Sept. 25A 49yearold Malverne woman was indicted today by a Nassau County grand jury on 23 counts of allegedly stealing abdut $50,000 in Medicaid funds while operating a nursing home in East Rockaway.

title: U.S. to Ask Nations For Grain Reserve
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 25 (AP) The United States will propose next week that a world grain reserve of 30 million metric tons be set up and held by individual countries as a hedge against future shortages and famine. Government documents showed today.

title: Westchester Study Sees An End to Era of Growth
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 25The days of population and economic growth in Westchester County, long a magnet for city dwelers and businesses on the move, may be over.

title: $3Million in Air Tickets Recovered in Bay State
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 25 (AP)Authorities confiscated more than $3million in stolen airline tickets in an apartment here in what was described as the biggest haul of stolen airplane tickets in the history of United States aviation.

title: REPORTS AT ODDS OVER JERSEY CITY
description: Last week, a federally financed study depicted Jersey City as the worst large American city to live in. This week, a separate and independent report by a former New York City official evaluated Jersey City as a potentially good place to live.

title: SOVIET IS CRITICIZED BY LEADER OF NATO
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 25 (Reuters)  Dr. Aseph M. A. H. Luns, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, accused the Soviet Union today of failing to live up to the obligations of the document signed at the European security conference in Helsinki.

title: Firemen Back in Bayonne; Other Protesters Stay Out
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 25Eugene J. O'Neill, Director of Public Safety for Bayonne, testified in court here today that his city had a full complement of firemen on duty last night and today.

title: Ice Halts Alaska Oil Field Convoy
description: POINT BARROW, Alaska, Sept. 25  A fivemilelong, halfbilliondollar convoy of barges carrying essential cargo to develop Alaska's oilrich North Slope, racing against time and the weather, turned back last night after a sudden change in the winds halted a dramatic dash around icelocked Point Barrow.

title: Barber's 63 Leads Golf By Stroke
description: LAS VEGAS, Sept. 25 (AP) Miller Barber, 44 years old, exploited nearperfect playing conditions today for a careerbest round of 63 and a onestroke lead in the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament. His total was eight shots under par.

title: White House Undecided
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25A spokesman for the White House press office said today that just what form President Ford would use to thank those who helped him in the San Francisco shooting episode had not yet been decided.

title: DOLLAR DECLINES IN FOREIGN DEALS
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 25, (UPI)The dollar fell on European money markets today, pulled down by the combined effects of profit taking, jitters over an anticipated increase in the price of oil and intervention by European central banks. Gold and the British pound both closed higher for the second consecutive day.

title: 200Mile Fishing Zone Backed by Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)The Senate Commerce Committee unanimously approved a bill today that would establish a 200mile fishing zone around the shores of the United States and forbid foreigners to take anything except surplus fish from those waters.

title: Iran Planning to Transfer Jet Fighters to Jordan
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 25 (AP)Iran has told the United States she is considering sending about a dozen Americanbuilt supersonic jet fighters to Jordan, the State Department said today.

title: DOCUMENTS GIVEN IN COMPUTER CASE
description: The Computer Industry Association released yesterday an internal document of the International Business Machines Corporation which Jack Biddle, the association's president contended directly contradicts the arguments of I.B.M.'s lawyers in the antitrust case brought against I.B.M. by the Telex Corporation.

title: Prime Minister Criteized
description: UMTALI, Rhodesia, Sept. 25 (Reuters)The chairman of Rhodesia's governing party charged today that Prime Minister Ian D. Smith had damaged Rhodesia's image by predicting an eventual sharing of power with blacks.

title: ExGiant Is Seeking Revenge
description: Larry Jones is a kick return Pr for the Washington Redskins. For about eight weeks last year Jones was a kick returner for the Giants. When he moved from New York to Washington, Jones packed his belongings in suitcase. He did not, however, take with him an 8 10 color photograph of Bill Arnsparger.

title: Ashok B. Bhadkamkar Dies; Indian Envoy to U.N., Ottawa
description: CAIRO, Sept. 25 (UPI) Ashok B. Bhadkamkar, Indian Ambassador to Egypt since 1972, died Wednesday night of a heart attack. He was 53 years old.

title: EqualTime Rule On Political News Reversed by F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The Federal Communications Commission, reversing longheld policy, ruled today that radio and television broadcasts of candidates news conferences and political debates will no longer trigger equaltime access for all their opponents.

title: Carey Will Name Two Judges To Supreme Court Vacancies
description: Governor Carey announced yesterday that he would appoint Civil Court Judges Hortense W. Gabel and Leonird H. Sandler, both Democrats, as State Supreme Court justices in the First Judicial District (Manhattan and the Bronx). They will serve until the end of this year to fill vacancies created by resignations.

title: Hollywood Scenario: Boom ancl Bust
description: HOLLYWOODThere is a curious scenario of boom and bust unfolding at the same time in Hollywood these days: Boxoffice receipts at the country's movie theaters are zooming toward a record for paradoxically, Hollywood's the second year in a row, but. producers are turning out fewer and fewer films.

title: WEAKNESS MARKS CREDIT MARKETS
description: Fears of a possible resumption of a rising trend in interest rates weakened the credit markets yesterday. Prices in both the Government and corporate market began to decline at the opening after Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board warned that increases in Federal spending might cause further rises in interest rates. He made the statement while testifying before the Senate Budget Committee. The weakness in both markets continued throughout the day. In the Government intermediate sector, prices fell oneeighth to threequarters of a point while declines in prices of longterm bonds ranged up to a half point. Yields in the Treasury bill area rose modestly.

title: U. S. Drugs Study Gives Low Priority To Marijuana Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)President Ford's Domestic Council drug review study group has recommended that a low priority be given to enforcement of marijuana laws.

title: BOB CONSIDINE, 68, DIES AFTER STROKE
description: Bob Considine, a gregarious, prolific and adventurous journalist who stood in the forefront of his profession for almost 40 years, died last night. He was 68 years old.

title: Anderson Says Fiscal Control Board Has Been Lax
description: The State Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson accused the Emergency Finan cial Control Board yesterday of failing to act swiftly or strongly enough to force greater austerity and fiscal reform on the city.

title: Bunker Hunt Says He Was Unaware Taps Were Illegal
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 25Nelson Bunker Hunt, a son of the late billionaire H. L. Hunt, testified today that he I would never have authorized; wiretaps on his father's top; aides if he had known it was illegal.

title: Women's Suit Fails to Halt Equal Rights Referendum
description: TRENTON, Sept. 25An attempt by a women's group to prevent a proposed Equal Rights Amendment to the State Constitution from appearing on the November ballot failed today.

title: Hearst Tape Suggests Conflicts With Affidavit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25Two days before Patricia Hearst signed an affidavit in which she said she wanted to be admitted to bail because she was eager to go home to her parents, she told a high school chum that she feared becoming a prisoner in my parents home, court documents here disclosed today.

title: Shows Open
description: Shows that are not affected by the strike:

title: U. S. Drugs Study Gives Low Priority To Marijuana Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)President Ford's Domestic Council drug review study group has recommended that a low priority be given to enforcement of marijuana laws.

title: Angola Faction Sees Abundant and Multiracial Future
description: LUANDA, Angola, Sept. 25A week ago Jornal de Angola, the semiofficial newspaper of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, the nationalist force that controls this capital, published an article that began, Thanks be to Comrade God, our people are now more politically conscious than the people of Portugal.

title: STUDY STIRS FEAR ON BANK HOLDINGS OF CITY'S BONDS
description: A confidential Federal survey has led some officials in Washington to conclude that 100 of the 14,000 banks in the United States are holding such large quantities of New York City bonds and notes that they would be in serious difficulty in the event of municipal default.

title: 238 BreakIns Committed By F.B.I. Over 26 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The Federal Bureau of Investigation committed at least 238 illegal burglaries against dissident American groups and individuals from 1942 to April, 1968, according to figures made public today by a Senate committee.

title: OPEC DEADLOCKED ON OIL PRICE RISE
description: VIENNA, Sept. 25 oilexporting nations are expected to go into a third, unscheduled day of talks tomorrow with differences over the size of a price increase described as tremendously wide.

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Roosevelt Entries

title: CRITICISM OF LILCO TERMED INACCURATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25A study that questioned the management ability of the Long Island Lighting Company is not accurate because it is based on a faulty assumption and wrong measure of performance, the company has charged.

title: NATO Forces Are Seeking to Standardize Equipment
description: BERGENHOHNE, West GermanyIn early September a battalion of American paratroopers jumped into an area just south of the Moselle River near Trier to set up a bridgehead in a training exercise. A Belgium army officer jumped with them, and they carried Belgian radio equipment besides their own.

title: NEW COSTS TO U.N. IN SINAI ARE SEEN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25Secretary General Waldheim told the General Assembly's budgetary committee today that the interim accord on EgyptianIsraeli military disengagement would entail additional financial obligations for the United Naions.

title: JORDANIANS STUNG BY MISSILE AFFAIR
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 25The compromise worked out last week to break the crisis over Jordan's desire to purchase 14 batteries of Hawk antiaircraft missiles illustrates the problems that arise from the United States policy of trying to influence both sides in the ArabIsraeli dispute and the delicacy of Jordan's position in trying to appear to her Arab neighbors as more than a client of the United States.

title: ROT WEATHER CUTS STATE'S GRAPE CROP
description: ALBANY (AP)  New York State vineyards are expected to yield 155,000 toms of grapes this year, down 12 per cent from last year's crop. However, that is still good enough to maintain the states ranking as the nation's No. 2 grape producer, second only to California.

title: Cocktail Danse Macabre Marks the Demise of Cultural Center
description: Nearly 500 mourners attended a wake for the New York Cultural Center last evening, marking the end of its 11year life. The occasion was billed as a museum cooling, though the freeflowing liquor and loud rock provided by a live combo gave it a desperately festive air.

title: Linden Chemical Company Is Guilty Of Polluting Arthur Kill in' 72 and '74
description: NEWARK, Sept. 25A Linden chemical company pleaded guilty in Federal District Court here today to violating the 1972 Federal water pollution control act by having dumped mercury and alkaline wastes into the Arthur Kill on two occasions in 1972 and 1974. The United States Attorney, Jonathan L. Goldstein, said the guilty plea by the Linden Chlorine Products company represented the first successful criminal prosecution in the United States of violations of the stringent threeyearold Federal statutes. which are designed to eliminate pollution of all United States waters by 1985.

title: Free Rides in Vienna
description: The City of Vienna has begrin a free car service for the handicapped. Minibuses pick up the physically disabled at their homes and take them to and from rehabilitation centers, with trained pesronnel attending them en route.

title: PIKE TO REQUEST CONTEMPT ACTION IN CIA. INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Representative Otis G. Pike said today that in his opinion the executive branch was in contempt of Congress, and that he would ask the House of Representatives to take action next week.

title: About Real Estate
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J.Andrea Towers is a 12story apartment house on a pleasant residential thoroughfare called Munn Avenue in the heart of East Orange.

title: AL JARREAU SINGS AT THE BOTTOM LINE
description: Al Jarreau, who is opening for Grover Washington Jr. at the Bottom Line through Sunday, is well worth a visit. At times he sounds like both Al Green and. Harry Belafonte (and even looks rather like Mr. Belafonte). But when he opens up, his voice takes on a more soulish bite. And when he moves onto his special turf, he becomes a singer of quite extraordinary virtuosity.

title: Rain Clouds Title Race For Red Sox, Orioles
description: The Boston Red Sox and Baltimore Orioles, who have been battling for American League Eastern Division honors most of the season, both lost out to the rain again last night.

title: Ford Is Reconsidering His Plans for Extensive Travel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25President Ford is reconsidering tentative plans for extensive crosscountry travel next month after two apparent attempts on his life, White House officials said today.

title: Contract Awards
description: A $22million contract for engineering, procurement and construction management of the Eneabba Mineral Sands project in western Australia has been awarded to Fluor Australia, Pty., Ltd., a subsidiary of Fluor Utah, Inc.

title: TALKS OPEN IN CHAD ON WOMAN CAPTIVE
description: NDJAMENA, Chad., Sept. 25 (UPI)A special French envoy met with Chadian rebels deep in the Sahara today and offered a ransom of $2.2million in cash and supplies for a captive Frenchwoman.

title: DOWRIES IN INDIA TARGET OF REFORM
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 25Meena Swaminathan, an enthusiastic partisan of the growing women's rights movement, has made a resolution that may startle a number of her friends her three daughters will have no dowries when they marry.

title: CONGRESS IS ASKED FOR FUEL FUNDING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The Ford Administration, supporting a proposal by Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, asked Congress today for immediate authority to give financial assistance to private companies to construct and operate synthetic fuel plants.

title: Strike Bars Opening of Treemonisha
description: The eightday strike of musicians, which shut down nine Broadway musicals last week, prevented Scott Joplin's Treemonisha and the Paul Anka show from opening last night.

title: U.S. AIDE DETAILS MORE GRAIN THEFT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Systematic thefts at another of the grain elevators operated by large corporations in the New Orleans area continued until this spring, according to information given a Senate hearing today by the chief Federal prosecutor in a broad investigation into corruption in the grain industry.

title: In Memoriam
description: CARTONHelen. Memorial services will be held at the Fifth Avenue Synagogue, $ E. 62d St., Scot. 29, at 3 P.M.

title: STUDY STIRS FEAR ON BANK HOLDINGS OF CITY'S BONDS
description: A confidential Federal survey has led some officials in Washington to conclude that 100 of the 14,000 banks in the United States are holding such large quantities of New York City bonds and notes that they would be in serious difficulty the event of municipal default.1

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: So far one campaign to convince parents to place their children in adequate automobile safety devices has been a failure.

title: LEBANESE LEADERS MEET IN PEACE BID
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon Sept. 25 (UPI)Isolated shooting incidents and two bombings hardly; dented the latest ceasefire hetween rival militias today as the nation's leaders met to chart a permanent peace between leftist and rightist factions.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TOMORROW, SEPT. 27 AMERIKANIS, Costa. Left Bermuda Sept. 25; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: Television
4 Italian Airmen Killed As Their Jets Strike Hill
description: BONN. Sept. 25 (UPI)Four Italian pilots were killed today in West Germany when their supersonic F104G Starfighters flew into the ground in perfect formation near the Luxemhnurg border.

title: SENATE SOFTENS ANTIBUSING PUSH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The Senate voted tonight to soften an antibusing provision approved last week, but liberals were thwarted in their efforts to nullify restrictions preventing the Department of Health, Education and Welfare from ordering busing to achieve desegregation.

title: SENTENCED IN 1931, INMATE, 70, IS FREE
description: STORMVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 25  Seventy  year  old Roy, Schuster walked out of Green Haven prison at 4 o'clock this afternoon, a free man for the first time in 44 years.

title: Senators Accuse Burns Of Undermining Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Members of the Senate Budget, Committee and Federal Reserve) Board Chairman Arthur F. Burns got into a heated argument today over whether the Federal Reserve had tried to offset the effects of last spring's antirecession tax cutand if so whether it had a right to do so.

title: People and Business
description: Garth Marston, acting chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, has told savings and loan association officers in California that he opposes efforts by state and local governments aimed at curbing the practice called redlinine.

title: KLEPPE ASSAILED ON HURRICANE AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Thomas S. Kleppe, President Ford's nominee to be Secretary of the Interior, was criticized today for his fourandahalf year record as head of the Federal Small Business Administration, but the criticism seemed unlikely to affect his nomination.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.7 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 206.8 from 206.1 last week.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Inmate at Attica Is Indicted After Attacks on 5 Guards
description: WARSAW, N.Y., Sept. 25 (AP)An Attica prison inmate, accused of stabbing four guards and clubbing another last week, was indicted by a Wyoming County grand jury today.

title: GOLDIN ACCUSES SCHOOLS ON AID
description: Harrison J. Goldin, the City Controller, charged yesterday that the Board of Education had failed to apply for $2.5million in state aid for education of the handicapped from 1972 through 1974, but the boartl sharply challenged the allegations, noting it had already collected more than $1.9million for the city.

title: Suspect in Police Killings May Be Tied to 3d Death
description: Luls Serrano Velez, the 26yearold former convict who was arraigned yesterday for the murder of two police officers 4 last week may also have been the gunman in a third homicide case here, the police said yesterday.

title: Immigrants Church Flights to Survive
description: In 1892, on the first floor of a storefront at 113 Waverly Place in Greenwich Village, the newly founded Missionaries of St. Charles opened a church and called it Our Lady of Pompei. Its mission was to help the hundreds of thousands of Italian immigrants who poured out of Ellis Island on their long journey to a better life.

title: Israelis Cautious
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 25Responsible Israelis tonight discounted speculation that the meeting between the Israeli and Soviet Foreign Ministers in New York would lead to a resumption of diplomatic ties.

title: Notes on People
description: Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, filed a consumer protection suit in Boston yesterday on behalf of a consumer named Ralph Nader. The action accused a booking agency and its successor of failing to pay Mr. Nader lecture fees collected in his behalf.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: AFTER FOUR DAYS OF RAIN:

title: WHEAT, SOYBEANS AND CORN CLIMB
description: In what commodity analysts called a dull trading day, wheat soybeans and corn moved up a little on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: A List of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: 1975 Rainfall Here Exceeds Average for Full Year
description: Rainsteady, heavy and unrelentingdrenched the metropolitan region for the fourth straight day yesterday, turning lowlying roadways into ponds, flooding some highways and making life generally unpleasant for hundreds of thousands of residents.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Coty Night: It Was Like A Family Night Out
description: It was, as such things go, a quiet family party. For the fashion family, that is. Calvin Klein brought his daughter, Geoffrey Beene brought his mother.

title: CONGRESS CHIEFS AND FORD CONCUR ON NEW OIL CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25President Ford and Congressional leaders of both parties agreed today to restore the system of price controls on oil that expired Sept. 1 and to extend that system through the middle of November.

title: Peking Is Pressing Rural Resettling of City Youth
description: KONG KONG, Sept. 25Early one morning this month, 15,000 new junior and senior high school graduates gathered in a square in the industrial city of Wuhan for a ritual that has been a central fact of life, for young people in Chinathey were being sent off to be resettled in the countryside.

title: Hearst Tape Suggests Conflicts With Affidavit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25Two days before Patricia Hearst signed an affidavit in which she said she wanted to be admitted to bail because she was eager to go home to her parents, she told a high school chum that she feared becoming a prisoner in my parents home, court documents here disclosed today, Last Saturday Miss Hearst was visited in San Mateo County Jail by Patricia Tobin, a girl friend from her private school days in Hillsborough, the posh suburb where Miss Hearst grew up.

title: Soviet Sees End of Seato As Sign of Asian Changes
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 25 (AP)A commentary by Tass, the official press agency, said today that the collapse of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization i)vas a result of disputes between the members, new foreign pc.,litical orientation of number of member countries and positive changes in the world arena.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Without losing their handpainted quality, needlepoint designs can now be turned out by the lithography press and the heattransfer machine, thus cutting the cost to the needlepoint worker by anywhere from a third to more than a half.

title: Plastic Container Boom Seen In Personal Care Products
description: There is a boom ahead for plastic containers for personal care products, according to the Plastic Bottle Institute of The Society of the Plastics Industry.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: WALKING TALL. PART 2, alrected by Earl Bellamy, starring Bo Svenson, at neighborhood theaters.

title: North Korea Bars Parley
description: UNITED NATIONS. N. Y. Sept. 25 (AP)North Korea today rejected a United States call for a conference of the United States, China and North and South Korea to discuss ways of keeping the Korean armistice. At a news conference, Kwon Min Jun, the North Korean observer at the U.N., said the American proposal cannot become a subject of any discussion.

title: In Eritrea, Dozens of Street Killings by Guerrillas Heighten a Mood of Terror
description: ASMARA. Ethiopia. Sept. 24 (Reuters)A burly exsailor drained his morning cup of coffee in the Royal Bar here and shouldered his way through a string curtain screening the doorway into the bright sunshine of the street.

title: Redskins 8Point Choice Over Giants
description: Because it had not been known until yesterday if Joe Naraath would play, no bet??? line had been established as of last night for the Jets game against the Chiefs at Kansas City on Sunday. Yes, Joe makes that much difference. The Redskins are favored, by 8 points, over the Giants in Washington. That one will be on television, Channel 2, starting at 1 P.M. The Jets game on Channel 4 begins at 2 P.M. and when over the station will pick up the BillsSteelers game, which begins at 4 P.M. in Pittsburgh. The Monday night match is nothing special, Green Bay at Denver, Channel 7, 9 P.M.

title: Israeli Leftists Visiting Soviet To Explore a Renewal of Ties
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 25An un official Israeli delegation of leftists is visiting the Soviet Union for 10 days to explore prospects for restoring diplomatic relations between Israel and the Soviet Union.

title: Earlier Evolution Suggested for Human Language and Intellectual Ability
description: Human language and intellectual ability, once thought to have been recent developments in man's evolution, arising perhaps only 20,000 to 50,000 years ago, are coming to be seen as having first appeared much further in the past.

title: House Unit Backs Ford on U.S. PayRise Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)  The House Civil Service Committee today defeated a resolution proposing an 8.66 Federal pay raise to replace President Ford's recommended 5 per cent pay increase ceiling.

title: Ice Halts Alaska Oil Field Convoy
description: POINT BARROW, Alaska, Sept. 25  A fivemilelong, halfbilliondollar convoy of barges carrying essential cargo to develop Alaska's oilrich North Slope, racing against time and the weather, turned back last night after a sudden change in the winds halted a dramatic dash around icelocked point Barrow.

title: Bridge:
description: The Von Zedtwitz double knockout team championship, one of the prestige events in the New York tournament program, ended Wednesday night in a victory for the favorites: Michael Becker, Matt Granovetter, Ron Rubin, Alan Sontag and Peter Weichsel, all of New York City and Jeff Rubens of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Vilas, Ashe Advance at Coast Net
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 (UPI)Guillermo Vilas, the Argentine star who is seeded No. 1. and secondseeded Arthur Ashe of Miami saved the $100,000 Firemen's Fund tennis tournament from becoming a disater area for topranked players last night. Three other seeded players were eliminated in secondround play at the Cow Palace.

title: OPEC Retains Decorum as Tensions Rise
description: VIENNA, Sept. 25Under orders to get news of any action on oil prices to Secretary of State Kissinger as soon as possible, the United States Ambassador to Austria, Wiley T. Buchanan, sent four of his officers to the entrance of the building housing the headquarters of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries on Vienna's famous Ringstrasse, opposkte the university. They merged with reporters, chauffeurs, policemen and even some curious students.

title: Immigrants Church Fightsto Survive
description: In 1892, on the first floor of a storefront at 113 Waverly Place in Greenwich Village, the newly founded Missionaries of St. Charles opened a church and called it Our Lady of Pompei. Its mission was to help the hundreds of thousands ofItalian immigrants who poured out of Ellis Island on their long journey to a better life.

title: TOP ITALIAN PARTY SEEKS A NEW LOOK
description: ROME, Sept. 25For more than three months since the governing Christian Democrats were set back by the Communists in elections, they have been struggling to discover something new to say to the Italian voters.

title: 2 Senators Hail Buckley For Opposing City Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Senator James B. Allen of Alabama, a Conservative Democrat, took the floor of the Senate this morning to praise Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, for opposing direct Federal intervention in the New York fiscal crisis.

title: Stock Index Off 5.95 as Trading Slows
description: The stock market declined inquiet trading yesterday after oil ministers of the Organizalion of Petroleum Exporting Countries reached an impasse on the oil Price question.

title: Only Supreme Judges
description: Governor Carey has made an important move toward improving the quality of judgesand justicein New York State. In appointing Civil Court Judges Hortense W. Gabel and Leonard H. Sandler to fill interim vacancies on the State Supreme Court, he has followed the recommendations of his impartial screening panel. This is a key step in putting men and women on the bench not because of faithful party service but because they are wellqualified for judicial service.

title: Red Cross Here Names Executive Board Head
description: Fred D. Thompson, vice president of the New York Times Company, has been appointed chairman of the executive board of the American Red Cross in Greater New York.

title: About New York
description: The oldest fastfood operation in New York is so swift that it moves on wheels and caters to a standup trade. The business is sheltered by a twocolor umbrella that is the sign of the hotdog wagon as surely as the three golden halls mark a pawn shop.

title: WORK IS STOPPED. ON SUBWAY LINE
description: Mayor Beame added a new stop yesterday to the Second Avenue subway linean embattled construction project that has been progressing steadily toward limbo.

title: Cyanamid Expansion Set
description: BOUND BROOK, N.J., Sept. 25 (UPI)The American Cyanamid Company said today it would build a $10million plant to make nigrosine dyes for use in printing and writing inks, paints, lacquers and plastics at its cdmplex here. The plant, which will double Cyanamid's output of these dyes, will be in operation in 1977.

title: LAYOFFS DECLINE AT AUTO MAKERS
description: DETROIT, Sept. 25Domestic auto plants this week are scheduled to build 155,532 cars, off 4 per cent from 162,118 last week and 10 per cent below the 172,753 units built in the corresponding week a year ago.

title: 12 Big Concerns Will Buy $20Million M.A.C. Bonds
description: As part of the effort to save New York City from default, 12 leading corporations have agreed to buy more than $20million of bonds in a new offering of securities by the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: House Votes Down Move to Reimpose Rhodesia Embargo
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)The House refused today to renew the ban on United States imports of Rhodesian chrome ore, ignoring warnings that continuing the trade would hurt United States relations with other southern African nations.

title: CONGRESS CHIEFS AND FORD CONCUR ON NEW 016 CM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25President Ford and Congres. sional leaders of both parties agreed today to restore the sys. tern of price controls on oil that expired Sept. 1 and to extend that system through the middle of November.

title: McDaniel Calls End To 21Year Career
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 25 (UPI)  Lindy McDaniel retired from baseball today after 21 years in the major leagues.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Listed to speak: Rumania, China, Bulgaria, France, Norway, Tanzania, Turkey, India, Ireland, Mongolia, Lesotho.

title: People in Sports
description: Daryle Lamonica, putting rumors and suspicions to rest, officially retired yesterday from the Southern California Sun of the World Football League. I've officially retired from pro football, said the quarterback, who played pro football for 14 years.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, Sept. 25, 1975

title: Ford Advises City Weigh 2Cent Rise in Sales Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25President Ford told Mayor Beame yesterday that New York State might want to consider a twocentsonthedollar increase in the sales taxto 10 per cent for New York City residents  to help ease New York's fiscal crisis.

title: Radio
Divesting Proposal For Cities Service Is Revised by U. S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)The Justice Department filed today a revised proposal for settling an antitrust suit against the Cities Service Company by requiring it to sell its service stations in Massachusetts and New Hampshire.

title: Adoption Papers Show Difference in Names
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 25Papers were filed today in the case of Karen Anne Quinlan that show she was adopted as an infant in June, 1955, by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Quinlan of Landing in Morris County, under the terms of a Pennsylvania court decree.

title: U.S. Election Panel Alters Rule On Congressmen's Office Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The Federal Election Commission approved today a scaleddown version of its regulation making members of Congress politically accountable for their privately financed office funds.

title: Suspect in Police Killings May Be Tied to 3d Death
description: Luls Serrano Velez, the 26yearold former convict who was arraigned yesterday for the murder of two police officers 4 last week may also have been the gunman in a third homicide case here, the police said yesterday.

title: and a New Twist
description: The one basically new Burns proposal (although he has broached it informally before) is to eliminate all involuntary unemployment by making the Federal Government an employer of last resort. This, he declares, is no radical or impractical goalat least not in the form in which he proposes it. He would offer public employment in such places as hospitals, schools or public parks to anyone willing to work at a rate of pay somewhat below the Federal minimum wage of $2.10 an hour. At the same time he would cut the duration of unemployment benefits to perhaps thirteen weeks or soas against the present emergency maximum of sixtyfive weeksin order to permit what he calls active searching for a regular job.

title: Priest in Coma Case Calls Legal Issue More Difficult Than the Moral
description: MOUNT ARLINGTON, Sept. 25The Rev. Thomas Trapasso, the priest who first advised Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Quinlan that a decision to seek permission for a natural death for their terminally ill daughter would not violate church teaching, has mixed feelings about moral theology being raised as a nossible issue in court.

title: JOYCE ACQUITTED IN BRIBERY CASE
description: WOODBURY, Sept. 25 (UPI) The Democratic chairman of Camden County, James Joyce, was acquitted tonight of charges of seeking $175,000 bribes in an influencepeddling scheme.

title: Box Scores and Standings
description: American League

title: Dollar Declines Abroad
description: The dollar fell on European money markets yesterday, pulled down by the combined effects of profit taking, jitters over an anticipated increase in the price of oil and intervention by European central hankers. The price of gold rose in London and Zurich. Page 55.

title: CHESTER DAVIS, 87, FARM EXPERT, DIES
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C., Sept. 25 (AP)  Chester Charles Davis, the nation's food administrator during the early years of World War II, died today at a convalescent center. His age was 87. He underwent brain surgery last April.

title: VOLUME WAIVER ON GAS APPROVED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Representative John E. Moss asserted today that the Federal Power Commission has appi owed longterm contracts for aatural gas sales to interstate pipelines without requiring producers to specify delivery volumes.

title: NBC DROPPING FAY AND MONTEFUSCOS
description: The first program casualties of the new television season are Fay and The Montefuscos on NBCTV. The network said yesterday they will be dropped from the schedule after Oct. 23 because of poor ratings.

title: Referee Concludes Justice Waltemade Showed Habitual Misconduct in Court
description: A special court referee has found that Supreme Court Justice Wilfred A. Waltemade's behavior on the bench was so rude and abusive that it constituted judicial misconduct violative of the standards applicable to all judges.

title: Memorial for Kriza Monday
description: A memorial service for John Kriza, who had been a principal dancer of the American Ballet Theater, will be held Monday at 1 P.M. at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street. Mr. Kriza, who was 56 years old, died Aug. 18, apparently by drowning near Naples, off the west coast of Florida.

title: Market Place
description: A local property owner called his lawyer a few weeks ago to voice concern about the possibility that New York City might default on its obligations to bondholders, something that is still regarded as a possibility despite massive efforts by state and local officials to ease the city's financial crisis.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Among the Charter reform proposals that will face the city's voters on Nov. 4 is one that would mandate changes in the way in which land use planning and development in the city takes place.

title: Business Briefs
description: The nation's three largest flour producers have raised the price 80.cents to $1 per hundredweight for allpurpose flour sold by supermarket chains. The producers, the International Multifoods Corporation, General Mills, Inc., and the Pillsbury Company, said that the increases, instituted last Friday, were due to higher wheat prices.

title: Immigration Chief Supports A Curb on Illegal Aliens
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25 (UPI) The Commissioner of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service says he supports legislation that would make it against the law for an employer knowingly to hire an illegal alien.

title: JACK ELLIOTT SINGS WINNINGLY AT CLUB
description: Ramblin Jack Elliott, the folksinging cowboy from Brooklyn, may not be a hot new artist, and he certainly doesn't have flashy recordcompany promotion to support his club dates. But Mr. Elliott who is currently at the Other End, 147 Bleecker Street, through Sundayis such a winning artist that he manages [to fill UD clubs anyhow.

title: 12 Big Concerns Will Buy $20Million M.A.C. Bonds
description: As part of the effort to save New York City from default, 12 leading corporations have agreed to buy more than $20million of bonds in a new offering of securities, by the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: LAUNCHING BEGINS INTELSAT SERIES
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 25 (UPI)The first of a new series of six Intelsat 4A advanced communications satellites, destined for synchronous orbit over the Atlantic Ocean, was launched tonight throueh an overcast sky.

title: Fla. State Lineman Permitted to Play
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 25 (UPI)United States District Judge William Stafford gave Waldo Williams, a Florida State University linebacker, permission to play in the remainder of the teams games this season. The judge deferred a decision on the athlete's lawsuit against the National Collegiate Athleteic Association until last November.

title: Speaking Lamely To the Question
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 25 Can you explain, the Swedish, television interviewer asks a visiting American, the new wave of violence in the United States?

title: Congress Quickly Passes Oil Curb Backed by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26Congress quickly approved today and sent to the White House legislation that would temporarily reinstate price controls on oil.

title: Television; Morning 5:30 (4)Modern Farmer
description: 6:00 (4)Agriculture, U.S.A. (5)Patterns for Living.

title: WILBERT C. WACKER
description: Wilbert C. Wacker, vice pres. dent in charge of personal insurance and marketing for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company died yesterday at his home. 40 Nauset Lane Ridgewood, N.,J. He was 53 years old.

title: High Cost of Staging Olympics Played Down Here by Drapeau
description: With the patience of a youngster showing off a new gadget, Mayor Jean Drapeau of Montreal demonstrated here yesterday how the roof of the 75.000seat Olympic Stadium would be folded and unfolded next summer.

title: P.U.C. Bars Interim Rise To Jersey Central Power
description: NEWARK, Sept. 26  The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners rejected as unjustified today an application by the Jersey Central Power and Light Company for $45.4million interim rate increase effective Oct. 1.

title: New Effort to Make Public C.I.A. Budget Is Scheduled
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Representative Robert N. Giaimo, a member of both the House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee and the Select. Committe on Intelligence will attempt again next week to make the budget of the Central Intelligence Agency public for the first time since 1947.

title: Nassau Rebuilds Market
description: NASSAU. Bahamas (UPI)Reconstruction has begun of the straw vendors section of the Nassau Public Market.

title: Business Briefs
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (Reuters)The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today it would not be compensated for $30million of investment made in Venezuela. Occidental will charge the uncompensated balance, net of any UnitedStates taxes, against its oil and gas abandonment reserve.

title: A Rahway Official Says He Accepted Bribes for 11 Years
description: ELIZABETH, Sept. 26 (UPI)The foreman of the Rahway Public Works Department admitted today that he had taken kickbacks for 11 years from a contractor who delivered road oil to the city.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: OSLO, Norway  Svein Erik Paulsen. 128 pounds, Norway, outpointed Antonio Guinaldo, 129, Spain, 15 rounds, to retain his European junior lightweight title.

title: $400,000 Is Paid, But Businessman Is Slain in Dayton
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept 26 (AP) Lester C. Emoff, a furniture store executive whose family paid $400,000 ransom, was found slain in a wooded area on the city's outskirts today. three days after his alleged abduction.

title: 15,000 Library Books Are Found In Lawyer's Village Apartment
description: Joseph Feldman, a 58yearold lawyer, was arraigned here yesterday after firemen discovered more than 15,000 New York Public Libiary books in his Greenwich Village apartmentpiled to the ceiling, covering the stove and filling the bathtub and sinks.

title: Power Drawn From Under Earth
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26As a possible solution of the worlds energy problem, a Connecticut research scientist has invented means, of drawing power from the white hot area 16 or more miles below the earth's surface. Alan L. Robertson of Newington, Yale graduate and former Marine officer, was granted Patent 3,907,044 this week for his geopenetrator system. It is assigned to the United Research and Development. Company, Inc., a Newington company that he heads.

title: August Shipments Of Newsprint Fell, Canadians Report
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 26 (AP)Canadian newsprint shipments to all markets in August totaled 622,775 tons, down 4.3 per cent from July and down 23.4 per cent from August, 1974, the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association reported today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Seven new cases of St. Louis encephalitis have been identified in New Jersey, according to the state's Health Commissioner, Joanne B. Finley. This brings to 18 the total number of cases of the sometimes fatal disease in the state this year. According to Dr. Martin Goldfield, assist. ant commissioner for laboratories and epidemiology, the recent torrential rains throughout New Jersey should help to control any further spread of the disease.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS U.S. WEIGHS SALES OF ARMS TO EGYPT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26The White House said today that the United States would consider Egypt's request for American military equipment to help President Anwar elSadat end his reliance on Soviet arms.

title: Smith of Rhodesia Says Truce Efforts Are at Lowest Point
description: UMTALI, Rhodesia, Sept. 26 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that Rhodesia was in a worse situation than when, his Government began efforts to settle with black nationalists. He told the Congress of his governing party, the Rhodesian Front, that the most serious damage was caused by; the fact that the black nationalists believed that South African pressure was causing Rhodesia to back down.

title: Eugene Feldman a Printer. Graphic Artist and Teacher
description: Eugene Feldman, a printmaker and founder of the Falcon Press of Philadelphia, printers of fine books and art catalogue s, died yesterday of heart attack at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 53 years old and lived in BelaCynwyd, Pa.

title: Books of The Times
description: Gifted with genius, Mary Ann Evans not only created some of the finest and perdurable fiction in the English language, but she also fashioned a most complex and great person, George Eliot. Her literary stature stands on such novels as Middlemarch, Felix Holt, the Radical and Adam Bede, but her personal attainments have only lately begun to be revealed. Gordon Haight started the process with his seven vokumes of The George Eliot Letters and a biographical study, and now Prof. Ruby V. Redinger of BaldwinWallace College in Berea, Ohio, gives us what is surely the most insightful account yet of the evolution of the boundlessly fascinating George Eliot.

title: EDWARD T. BOYLE
description: EDWARD T. BOYLE

title: Petroleum Diplomat
description: VIENNA, Sept. 26Venezuela's Oil Minister, Valentin HernandezAcosta, has a set of amber worry beads that he acquired some years ago in an effort to stop smoking.

title: Congress Quickly Passes Oil Curb Backed by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26Congress quickly approved today and sent to the White House legislation that would temporarily reinstate price controls on oil.

title: Number of Jobless in City Fell By 2,100 in August to 385,000
description: The number of people counted as unemployed in the city fell.2,100 in August, to 385,800, the State Labor Department reported yesterday, hut department economists called the change piddling, and far less than our seasonal expectations.

title: RULING IS AWAITED ON PENSION APPEAL
description: The Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on a lower court's ruling upholding the legality of a law mandating the use of public pension funds to purchase Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds.

title: Canadian Export Group Sign Loan Agreement With Cuba
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 26, (Reuters) The Canadian Export Devel. opment Corporation has signed loan agreements totaling $20. million to support sales of capital equipment and related services to Cuba, the Canadian Department of Trade, Cornimerce and industry said today.

title: Russians Assert They Predicted Volcano That Erupted on July 6
description: Soviet scientists predicted for the first time when and where a new volcano would be born, according to the Soviet press agency Novosti.

title: Facts in Musicians Strike
description: Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. I. Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.

title: 6 Golfers Tie for Lead at 134
description: LAS VEGAS, Sept. 26 (AP)Wally Armstrong, who was just trying to make the cut, birdied five of his last six holes and scored a 65 today that lifted him lino a sixway tie for the lead after two rounds of the $135.000 Sahara invitation golf tournament.

title: CBS Loses Bid to Analyze Ballistics Data in Ray Case
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 26 (UPI)A Criminal Court judge, William Williams, denied today a petition by CBS news to scientifiically analyze ballistics evidence used to convict James Earl Ray for the 1968 murder of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: OPEC May Settle On 10% Price Rise
description: VIENNA, Sept. 26The oil exporters cartel failed again to reach agreement tonight but appeared to be nearing a compromise on what qualified', sources said would probably; be a 10 per cent price increase followed by a price freeze.

title: Earthquakes Hit California
description: OROVILLE, Calif., Sept. 26 (UPI)Two small earthquakes rumbled through the Oroville area last night and early today, frightening residents, but causling no apparent damage.

title: Emergency Board Delays Decision on Teacher Pact
description: The Emergency Financial Control Board deferred decision yesterday on the labor agreement between the Board of Education and its teachers until the budget, implications of the agreement could be reviewed by an independent labor consultant.

title: WALTER H. HERMAN
description: Walter H. Herman, vice president for research and engineer, ling of the Franklin Mint, died of leukemia Tuesday at the CrozerChester Medical Center in Upland, Pa. He was 45 years old and lived in Wallingford, Pa.

title: Deluge Here Laid To Odd Confluence Of Weather Factors
description: The rains that flooded the New York area for the last five days resulted from an unusual combination of three factorsa large mass of warm, moist air from Hurricane Eloise; a lowpressure area that carried it northward, and a stationary front that condensed the moisture, turning it into the 7.89 inches of precipitation that the city has endured this week until last night.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Over Half of Israelis Favor. Sinai Accord With Egypt
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 26 (Reuters) A majority of Israelis are satisfied with the new interim peace agreement with Egypt, according to a public opinnlon poll.

title: Problems of Draft Evaders
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)  The Federal privacy laws will make it tougher for state and local tax collectors to catch draft evaders from the ranks of the 4.8 million military and Federal employes.

title: National League
description: Philadelphia 4, New York 3 (12 inn. 1st, twi).

title: Nessen Floats a Rumor Of a Maritime Project
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26Silence descended on the White House press briefing room today when Ron Nessen, President Ford's spokesman, stated: President Ford has signed an emergency order directing the Pentagon to begin immediate construction of an ark 350 cubits long.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERIKANIS, Costa. Left Bermcia Sent. 25: Oue 8 A.M. at W. S515 St.

title: CONSTANTINE COCOROS
description: Constantine Cocoros, vice president of Gino's, Inc., the national fastfood chain, and general manager for its operations in North Carolina, died Monday, apparently Of a heart attack at Ocean City. Md. He was 47 years old and lived in Berwyn, Pa.

title: Florida Ryled Disaster Area
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 26 (AP) President Ford today declared the State of Florida a major disaster area, eliele for Federal relief and recovery funds, as a result of Hurricane Eloise.

title: By DONAL HENAHAN
description: The New York Philharmonic and Pierre Boulez, back home at Avery Fisher Hall after their fourweek European tour, opened the Irchestra's 134th season on Thursday night with a program of classics old and not so old. Perhaps the musicians were feeling a posttour letdown, or maybe one went expecting too much of this opening program; in any event, the night threw off only intermittent sparks.

title: 5 of 11 Spanish Terrorists Must Die, Franco Decrees
description: MADRID, Saturday, Sept. 27 Generalissimo Francisco Franco refused yesterday to commute the death sentences of five terrorists who had been convicted of killing policemen, but he spared the lives of six others.

title: British Football
description: British Football

title: Giants No. 1 Selection Lost Chance to Start
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 26 Lou Gehrig was ready in 1925 when Wally Pipp got a headache and couldn't play. Gehrig stepped into the Yankee lineup and proceeded to play 2,130 consecutive games.

title: ThankYou Note Sent To Sipple by President
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 UPIPresident Ford has sent a letter to Oliver W. Sipple expressing his heartfelt appreciation for the former marine's help during an attack on the President in San Francisco Monday, the White House said today.

title: Big Board Correcfs Errors In Short Interest Figures
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that the total short interest figures it reported for July, August, and September and for, the WeilMcLane Company were overI stated because of incorrect information submitted to ft by one of its member organizations.

title: Means Test for Aged Is Held Up by H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has delayed for six months the enforcement of a requirement that elderly recipients of Federal social services document their income.

title: Failure to Restrict Miss Moore Linked To Role as Informer
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26The Secret Service decided that Sara Jane Moore did not represent a serious threat to President Ford's life largely because the San Francisco Police Department had told it that she had served the department and two Federal agencies as an informer over the last 18 months, law enforcement sources said today.

title: Red Soxwin 2 by 40; Orioles Fall 4 Back
description: BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP)Reggie Cleveland followed Luis Tiant's fourhit shutout with a fivehitter tonight as the Boston Red Sox Avept a double  header from the Cleveland Indians by 40 scores and moved within two games of the American League East Division championship.

title: Oklahoma Turns Back Miami, 2017
description: MIAMI, Sept. 26 (AP)Oklahoma's defense set up touchdown runs by Joe Washington and Elvis Peacock, then held off the University of Miami in the fourth quarter tonight to salvage a 2017 football victory.

title: Elizabeth Stoppage Ends
description: ELIZABETH, Sept. 26 (UPI)  The city's firemen, under a Superior Court directive. agreed today to end their sickout and return to work tomorrow while contract negotiations are held, with the Mayor acting as head of the bargaining panel.

title: Passaic River Overflows, Inundating Part of Wayne
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26Four continuous days of heavy rainfall caused flooding today along the banks of the Passaic River in Wayne, where the swollen river spilled over its banks in the Hoffmann Grove section of the township.

title: Like Harriman, College Named for Him to Be Devoted to Public Life
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 26Governor Carey, citing a critical need to train professionals for local and state government positions, tonight announced the establishment of the W. Averell Harriman College for Urban and Policy Sciences at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

title: Telling the United States About Chile
description: Someone once said that the world has been miniaturized by the incredible progress achieved in communications and transportation. And we must agree that the means of communication have so shrunk our planet that nothing can go unnoticed for more than five minutes. We are, of course, referring to important events and not to the minor happenings in which gossip columnists and rumormongers take delight.
