description: Juliette Maria Chiodo of New York, an assistant secretary in the national division of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, was married yesterday to Dr. Achim J. Heintze, a New York obstetrician and gynecologist. The Rev. J. M. Ryan performed the ceremony in the Transfiguration Roman Catholic Church in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Kazuko Hirabayashi And Dance Theater Are Seen at N.Y.U.
description: Three choreographers and a diverse range of interests were represented in Friday night's program by the Kazulm Iliraibayashi Dance Theater at the New York University Education auditorium, 35 West: Fourth Street.

title: Scarsdale Bows To White Plains
description: White Plains, Croton and Rye Neck won yesterday in a schedule abbreviated because of heavy rains.

title: Show Biz in the Afternoon
description: MANILA, Sept. 27At the corner of General MacArthur Boulevard and General Araneta Avenue in Quezon City, press buses led by a police car pulled into a parking area, and constabulary forced a path through the crowd to a doorway in the Philippine Coliseum. American fight fans who watch Joe Frazier and Muhammad Ali on closedcircuit television Tues day night will see a picture broadcast from this building, an airconditioned hall that has more seats than Madison Square Garden and looks like a pup out of Houston's Astrodome.

title: Criminals At Large
description: G. K. Chesterton, the famous and formidable British litterateur, started writing his Father Brown short stories around 1910 and continued them through the 1930's. Perhaps Chesterton intended his little priest to be an antidote to Sherlock Holmes. Where Holmes was all deductive logic, Father Brown worked by quantum jumps of intuition; where Holmes was magnetic and forceful, Father Brown was quiet and outwardly negative. Anyway, whatever the motivation, Chesterton had a lot of fun with his priestdetective, and the stories have deservedly become classics.

title: Interstate Roads Lacking Services
description: ALLAMUCHY  Motorists using the Interstate highways in New Jersey have been complaining about a lack of services on these roads.

title: Monkeys for Laboratories Are in Short Supply Here and the Price Is Going Up
description: TRENTON (UPI)Laboratory monkeys are becoming as expensive as Arab oil, and the shortage, if left unchecked, could hinder the progress of science, accordto New Jersey scientists Who use them in experirnents.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: DR. RALPH M. CHAMBERS
description: FAYETTEVILLE, N. C., Sept. 27 (AP)Dr. Ralph M. Chambers, a retired psychiatrist grid a former superintendent of state hospitals in Massachusetts, died yesterday. He was 85 years old.

title: Cardinal Feltin of France Dead; Archbishop Led WorkerPriests
description: PARIS, Sept. 27  Maurice Cardinal Feltin, former Archbishop of Paris and president of the French Roman Catholic Bishops Conference, died today of a lung infection at a monastery in Thiais, a Paris suburb. He was 92 years old and hade been living in the monastery. for the last 21/2 years.

title: Monmouth Offers Folk Art
description: LINCROFTAn arrestingly handsome exhibition of 200 examples of American folk art, chosen less for their historic associations than for their innate artistic beauty, will open Tuesday at the Monmouth Museum.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today Gold Coast, Melody Farms. Huntington, L.I. regular, green junior, amateurowner and nonthoroughbred working hunters; preliminary and junior jumpers, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Sunday Observer
description: So. Something must be written about the Bicentennial, eh? Why? Why? Why?

title: The old double standard made new
description: I have not read James Kirkwood's previous three novels (There Must be a Pony!, Good Times/Bad Times, P.S. Your Cat Is Dead!) or his account of the Jim GarrisonClay Shaw trial, American Grotesque. Nor have I seen the successful Broadway musical, A Chorus Line, on whose book Kirkwood collaborated. But I must say, after forcing my way through this shapeless, artless saga of a Vietnam war P.O.W., I am quite happy to have missed out on all those earlier opportunities.

title: SchlesingerWilson Talk
description: LONDON, Sept. 27, (Reuters) Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger met Prime Minister Harold Wilson today for talks on questions involving thy North Atlantic Treaty Organization and vastwest relations. Mr. Schlesinger is on tour which will include visits to Denmark, West Germany and France.

title: Indoor Vines That Climb Or Hang
description: Those fast growing vines that climb indiscriminately around the window ledge or hang from a basket keep me busy potting, pruning, shaping and propagating.

title: GARDEN REVAMPS OTB SALE STAND
description: Madison Square Garden has told Mayor Beame it would manage only the Rangers and Knicks if the Garden were bought by the Offtrack Betting Corporation.

title: Colleges Offering Televised Courses
description: EAST ORANGEThe New Jersey Association of Colleges and Universities, with offices here, is offering five courses that will be televised on public and commercial television stations.

title: For young readers
description: Ronald K. Messer has written an actionpacked first novel set in the late 1940's about poor Southerners, black and white. Shumway, who is 13 and white, narrates the adventures, showing over and over again the painful choices he's forced to make between loyalty to his black friend Lyle and fear of torment or ostracism by the prejudiced white community.

title: Books:Who and Where Is the Real Pete Rose?
description: Shame, shame on you, Pete Rose. It's not every day that we get the chance to trap a friend between the covers of book, especially a book described as the uninhibited diary of Pete Rose, man who averages 200 hits every summer for the Cincinnati Reds, who has played three positions, who has won three batting titles. Any fan might read it and learn what manner of baseball player this is, on the road or wherever. But I read it, and I'm still trying to learn what manner of man this is. Still looking for clues to the real Pete Rose. By Pete Rose With Bob Hertzel 227 Pages. PrenticeHall. $7.95

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The entry of psychiatrists into the cases of Patricia Hearst, Lynette Fromme and Sara Jane Moore may help to expose the widespread misuse of psychiatry by the courts in the determination of the mental competency of criminal defendants to stand trial. The triability standard as laid down by the Supreme Court is whether the defendant has sufficient present ability to consult with his lawyer with a reasonable degree of rational understandingand whether he has a rational as well as factual understanding of the proceedings against him.

title: Sharing a Cambridge grande dame
description: The Revolutionary War may have provided this Cambridge, Mass., house with its finest hour from a national point of view (it served as the first medical headquarters for the Continental Army), but architecturally its own age of glory derived from the personal extravagances of one Henry Vassall, a highliving colonial who took a modest structure of early17thcentury origins and in the seventeenforties, expanded into a Georgian mansion, a showplace even on showy Tory Row.

title: 2 Voices of Patricia Hearst Posing Problems for Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept, 27Two voices of Patricia Hearst echo through the court proceedings in the bank robbery charge against her, and the effect is to confuse her defense, her prosecutors and the public.

title: Preserving the visible past
description: (Continued from Page 21)who have gained respect and affection for the past and who find that they draw a steadily increasing nourishment from it has increased at an extraordinary rate. That the movement is authentically of the grass roots and not the product of an elite of scholarly urbanologists and wealthy crackpots is proved by the number of organizations that have sprung up in recent years for the purpose of locating, classifying, preserving and finding sympathetic new uses for old buildings and even for whole communities that have reached a respected but, in economic terms, a perilous old age.historic landmark district; this enclave of 25 square blocks contains the biggest assemblage of castiron loft buildings of any place on earth, many of which with their 20foothigh ceilings and broad bays, have proved ideal studios for artists and sculptors. On conducted tours of the district, Friends of CastIron ???tecture can be observed darting up to the pillared fronts of buildings and in order to test whether the pillars are of stone or cast iron, applying tiny magnets to their surfaces. Passersby shake their heads, plainly saying to themselves, New York is full of crazies. Not so; it is full of people who love it and who fight to keep its fragile fabric intact.

title: FORD CRITICIZES OPEC PRICE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27The Ford Administration publicly criticized the decision of the oilexporting cartel to raise prices by 10 per cent and said this meant that gasoline would increase by one to one and a half cents a gallon in the United States.

title: Karen Liebowitz to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ted Liebowitz. of Sands Point, L. I., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Sue Liebowitz, to Shahram Rabbani of New York, son of Mrs. Hazkel Rabbani of Teheran, Iran, and the late Mr. Rabbani.

title: Bars to Recovery Listed
description: BRIDGETON  Spokesmen for agricultural and industrial interests told a subcommittee of Governor Byrne's Economic Recovery Commission last week that recovery in South Jersey was being blocked by skyrocketing utility and tax rates and Department of Environmental Protection regulations.

title: NATO LEGISLATORS MEET AMERICANS
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 27When Erik Blumenfeld, a tall grayhaired foreignpolicy specialist from the West German Parliament, came to Copenhagen early this week for a meeting of legislators of NATO nations, the first person he looked for was Representative Wayne L. Hays, the Ohio Democrat who led the American delegation.

title: The Nation Is Tense, Caught Between Terrorists and the Government Response
description: MADRIDA few relatively small extremist groups are tying Spain into knots, paralyzing Government action, depressing the economy, polarizing political sentiment and spreading general fear.

title: American League
description: New York 3, Baltimore 2 (1st, 10 inn.).

title: By Robert Coles, the man who loves children
description: Robert Coles, psychiatrist ana psychoanalyst, is probably best known for his massive, threevolume study of children in various stressful situations, Children of Crisis. He has also written a lengthy exposition of the work of Erik Erikson. As he belongs to that select band of psychiatrists who write in clear and forceful English prose rather than GermanicAmerican Jargon, one approaches a new book by him with the expectation of pleasure and interest. This hope is somewhat diluted by the discovery that The Mind's Fate is a collection of occasional pieces, book reviews, articies for The New York Review of Books, The New Yorker, New Republic and so on. Many of these are of high quality, and worth reprinting; but the book must be regarded as an interim production, whetting the appetite for something more substantial in the future.

title: WHOOPING CRANES AWAITED IN TEXAS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 27As the whooping cranes return to Texas from Canada this winter, they will be holding their own in a fight against extinction. Eight young cranes are in the flock.

title: Cranberries Ready But Hard to Find
description: NAPEAGUE  Amity, the town besieged by the great white shark in Jaws may be fictional, but Cranberry Hole Road, given passing mention in the book, is on the map. It cuts from the Montauk Highway east toward Gardiners Bay, where Amagansett becomes Napeague. Like many of the roads in the area, its name is descriptive. It borders the bogs where the berries are ready for picking in October.

title: Increase in State's Population Projected
description: TRENTON  The state's population could increase to 8,280,000 by 1990 if the growth patterns of the early nineteenseventies continue, or to 8,660,000 if the longterm growth trend from 1900 to 1970 prevails.

title: Tigers, Underdogs, Rally in 3d Period
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 27Princeton was in the unusual role of underdog today in its football game against Rutgers, yet the Tigers came through with an 107 upset victory by scoring a touchdown in the third period before about 30,000 fans in Palmer Stadium. It was the 66th game in the oldest college football series, which started in 1869.

title: Brida Planned By Miss Wright
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stewart Wright of Ruxton, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Stanchfield Wright to Donald Joseph Ketter Jr. of Cheektowaga, N. Y., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ketter of East Aurora. N. Y.

title: New Zealand Bars Press From Using Names of Accused
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand Sept. 27The publication of the names of people accused of crimes but not convicted has been banned here under new.

title: The nourishment of things old, comely, familiar.
description: I am writing these words in the house of a friend. It is a big, ??? house in the style of the Second Empire, with high windows and a mansard roof that displays a merriment of painted iron fretwork against the sky. Well over a century old, the house looks out upon and agreeably dominates a small fenced park of even greater age, in which, among its clipped lawns and graveled paths, a bronze statue of some merit proves less interesting to the pedestrian than a large greenandwhite wooden birdhouse on a pole. From the window of the snug fourthfloor study in which I sit, I glance across the leafy benignity of the park to a number of other 19thcentury buildings, all of them gently resounding with what Henry James, in boyhood often a visitor to the neighborhood, liked to call the incomparable tone of time.

title: Hnueilings
description: COHNEstella G. The family of Este le G. Cohn will be gathering M unveil memorial in her loving memory Sunday October 5, 1975. Service% will be held 12 NOON at Mt. Pleasant Memorial Park, Hawthorne N.Y.

title: Purdue Defeated By U.S.C., 196
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 (AP)  Southern California's quarterback, Vince Evans, ran for two touchdowns and Danny Reece returned punts 47 and 68 yards today as the thirdranked Trojans overcame Purdue. 196.

title: Vice President With Clout
description: WASHINGTONNelson Rockefeller likes to reminisce about the Vice Presidents he has knownha counts sixand how they all became frustrated because they expected too much of their jobs. The real shocker, he relates, was an encounter with an absolutely frustrated, absolutely furious Lyndon Johnson in a hotel room in Miami where nobody was paying an attention to him. The White House, Mr. Johnson lamented, was forcing him to read a speech with which he totally disagreed.

title: About the Sleeping Beauty
description: Like all the great fairy tales, Sleeping Beauty is one of the archetypal dreams of mankind. In myth, legend and fiction, this entranced sleeping figure, awaiting the ripeness of awakening time, appears in embryo in the characters of Psyche, Ishtar, Brynhild, and even, as Alison Lurie suggested, in F. Scott Fitzgerald's portrayal of Nicole Diver in Tender Is the Night.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: As the brokerage house with the biggest clout on Wall Street, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., it can be safely said, has stepped on a few toes in the industry here and there.

title: Nancy P. Lybrook Is Married To Mark Joseph Warburton
description: Nancy Piper Lybrook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Reynolds Lybrook of Clemmons, N. C., was married yesterday afternoon to Mark Joseph Warburton, son of Brig. Gen. Ernest Keeling Warburton, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Warburton of Hardwick, Mass.

title: Yankee Box Scores
description: Yankee Box Scores

title: Museum Is Booking Visits by Classes
description: NEWARKThe Education Department at the Newark Museum is now making appointments for visiting classus during the new school ear. Each year, the department schedules museum visits for more than 50,000 children from school districts throughout the state.

title: Orioles Ousted Here, 32, 73
description: The Yankees eliminated Baltimore from baseball's last division title race yesterday by sweeping a doubleheader from the Orioles at Shea Stadium. The Yankee victory in the second game gave the Boston Red Sox the title in the American League's Easttern Division.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Victoria Gene Hamburg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee R. Hamburg of Glenview, III., was married here yesterday afternoon to John R. Peaslee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Peaslee of New York and Stoninaton. Conn.

title: Manhattan Tops Queens
description: Yves Conte, a sophomore, scored three goals as Manhattan College defeated Queens, 41, in a Met Conference Division II college soccer game at the losers field in Flushing. It the first lime in the Jaspers 9year history that they won their first two games of the season.

title: Shepherd Named Dog of Year For Saving Child From Snake
description: A German shepherd that attacked a diamondback rattlesnake to save a Tiger is America's dog hero, or rather heroine of the year. The shepherd is Fawn, owned by Mr. and Mrs. William Schlesinger of St. Petersburg, Fla., and the Tiger is the Schlesingers 4yearold grandson, Russ (Tiger) Schoenberger.

title: His Principled Position Is Based on Traditional Politics
description: WASHINGTONTwice this month President Ford journeyed to California. Twice this month a woman in California aimed a handgun at the President. President Ford plans a third journey to California. next month. Why?

title: HAVANAS, SI!
description: Fidel Castro and I have at least two things in common. We both once Wanted to pitch for a majorleague baseball team. And we both hope passionately that the recent signs of thaw in United StatesCuban relations will lead to a speedy abolition of the U.S.imposed trade embargo. Fidel understandably wants to end the economic isolation of his country from its most powerful neighbor. I see his point and applaud the idea, but, speaking now as a bourgeois malcontent, I will confess that there is something in this deal for me, something other than political altruism. Something that makes me drool with anticipation.

title: Mira Paces Vulcans To a 2618 Triumph
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 27 (AP)  George Mira hit Steve Barrios with a 40yard pass tonight for a touchdown that led the Jacksonville Express its 2618 victory over the Birmingham Vulcans in a World Football League game.

title: Syracuse 3113 Victor Over Tulane
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 27 (AP)  Earl Vaughn ground out 95 yards and one touchdown tonight to lead Syracuse to a 3113 victory over Tulane.

title: Is Space 1999 More Fi Than Sci?
description: A sciencefiction television show ought to be reviewed, it seems to me, not only for its dramatic quality, the acting, the plot, but especially for scientific accuracy. Why? Well, simply because television is a powerful educational influence. Why should it contribute unnecessarily to the raising of a misinformed generation?

title: The Reserve Clause: Key in All Sports Is Control of Players Not Under Contract
description: Just what is this reserve clause and why is everyone suing, stewing and striking about it?

title: NORWAYWILLWRB PRODUCTION OF OIL
description: OSLO, Norway, Sept. 27Norway's Premier, Trygve Bratteli, said today that his nation was placing a firm lid on oil production and that the looming bonanza in revenue would be tightly controlled.

title: McBurney Sets Back Riverdale
description: The Riverdale School, which posted its first losing season (three victories, five losses) last year, has gotten off to a slow start again this season. The Indians dropped their second game yesterday, losing at home to McBurney, 3214.

title: 2 Camels Help Brooklyn Mark Atlantic Antic Day
description: Two camels made their way down Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday, but the competition for attention was stiff.

title: B. Hunt Whitbeck Jr., Bank Aide, Weds Susan Katherine Oechlei
description: Susan Katherine Oechler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Oechler of Cincinnati, was married there last evening to B. Hunt Whitbeck Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitbeck of New York.

title: Safety Brakes for TrucksHow Safe?
description: Last January, after eight years of controversy, the Federal Government issued a regulation re'suiring certain brake systems for tractortrailer trucks, the behemoths of the highway. Rather than ending the controversy, the new rule deepened it.

title: McMahon Wins, Led By Jordan
description: Brien McMahon, Trumbull and Danbury each scored its third victory and remained undefeated yesterday.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Sandra Turtzo Married
description: Sandra Marina Turtzo, daughter of Mrs. J. Zern Heberling of Bangor, Pa., and New York was married early yesterday evening to Fred Wragge Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Smith Jr. of Washington. The Rev. Robert Andrews performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul in Washington.

title: Spanish Embassy Raid Reflects on Lisbon Control
description: LISBON, Sept. 27The first test of Portugal's new military: security force meant to respond to civil disorder with firm authority, apparently failed before the force was 24 hours old.

title: MUSICIANS STRIKE STILL AT IMPASSE
description: A ninehour bargaining session aimed at settling the 10dayold musicians strike that has shut down 11 Broadway musical productions ended yesterday morning with no progress reported.

title: PLANT IS PRAISED AS RICH IN PROTEIN
description: The National Academy of Sciences has uncovered a remarkable but littleknown bean plant that, if developed as a major crop, the academy believes, would go a long way toward alleviating protein shortages in the humid tropics.

title: Knowledge dethroned
description: Through the application of science, human beings in America and other parts of the world have been liberated from plagues, pestilences, threats of famine, hardship and torment that once seemed an unalterable part of the human condition. One need only rummage through the letters of our grandparents to be reminded of the debilitating, commonly fatal illnesses, physical pains, cripplings and disfigurements of body that we are so largely spared. It is hard to think of an area of modern physical welfare that cannot be traced in some way to science and technology. Nor, would I argue, an deny that the social scientist and humanist have made their very genuine contributions, too, to improving the administration of government and business and to a general rise in standards citizenship, taking that term in its widest sense.

title: JAZZ VIEW
description: Since the death of John Coltrane in 1967 the jazz world has been bereft of a major figure, one visionary musician whose style of playing and compositions earn the awe of colleagues yet whose records can still sell enough to support the experimentation vital to the evolution of contemporary music. Perhaps that role should have fallen again on Miles Davis, Coltrane's onetime mentor, but of late Miles's rhythmcrazy young hands have been doing most of his talking for him. And Ornette Coleman, too often silent and filled with his dignity, has removed himself from contention.

title: FUND SHIFT BACKED BY COLLEGE'S CHIEF
description: The president of Brooklyn College has defended the school's use of some SEEK and openadmissions money in regular academic departments but added that budget controls were being revised to help insure their proper use.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Prices declined last week on the New York Stock Exchange in light trading. At the close on Friday the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials stood at 818.60, down 11.19 points on the week. Volume for the week came to 69.07 million shares compared with 69.33 million shares traded in the previous week.

title: Keeping Track of Phony Claims for Products
description: WASHINGTONThe ancient Romans had a phrase for it, caveat emptor, Let the buyer beware.

title: Woman Cleared in Death Of a Vietnamese Orphan
description: CONYERS, Ga., Sept. 27 (UPI)A jury cleared a young mother today of charges she murdered a Vietnamese orphan she and her husband planned to adopt, but found her guilty of child abuse in the case. The Rockdale County Superior Court jury deliberated more than eight hours yesterday and today.

title: The Nation
description: President Ford has made public a $100billion program to achieve for the United States energy independence in 10 years or less. The plan, which has been compared with the Manhattan atom bomb project and Franklin Roosevelt's depressionera Reconstruction Finance Corporation in scope, has already produced dissension inside the Administration and it could be a factor in next year's Presidential election.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow. Queens, 1 P.M. (RadioWMCA, 12:55 P.M.)

title: ADOLF NUCHTERN
description: Adolf Nuchtern, executive vice president of Joseph R. Loring & Associates, a mechanical engineering consulting firm, died Thursday evening of cancer at North Shore Hospital, Roslyn, Li. He was 47 years old and lived in Kings Point. L. 1.

title: Letters: Berlin Guide. Recalls Great Times
description: To the Editor: On Sept. 8 my wife and I, along with our 13yearold daughter, were in Berlin for the first time. We decided to take the city tour offered by the B.B.S. servicea threehour tour by bus with German/Englishspeaking guide, in company with perhaps two dozen other tourists from many lands.

title: Carey Puts 74 Touch On Opener
description: Carey, which began last year's undefeated season with seven straight shutouts, started this season in the same fashion by whipping West Hempstead, 60, yesterday in a nonconference battle.

title: Onolee Coffey Sets Nuptials
description: The engagement of Onolee Anne Coffey to Reynolds du Pont Jr. has been announced by the future bride's mother, Onolee McDonnell Coffey. of Fishers Island, N. Y., sti'cl Coral Gables, Fla. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. du Pont Of Greenville, Del., and Fishbitt Island and a grandson of the late Lammot du Pont, woo was the eighth member his family to head E. L $31) Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc.

title: Solar Institute Is Sought on Island
description: MINEOLA  Long Island besieged for several years by a high rate of unemployment despite its wealth of scientific, technological and business resources, has started a strong bid to have a federally funded Solar Energy Research Institute in the bicounty area.

title: Anne Whitehead Will Be a Bride
description: John C. Whitehead of Essex Fells, N.J., and Helene S. Whitehead of Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Elizabeth Whitehead, to Edward Thomas O'Neill of Montclair, N.J.

title: Parisians Wonder What Will Fill the Great Hole That Was Les Halles
description: PARIS, Sept. 27When Parisians discuss what is becoming of Paris these days, there is often a Great Hole in the conversation.

title: The Leggy Kid on the Far Right Is Priscilla
description: She's the leggy kid on the far right of A Chorus Line, the one in the maroon Tshirt and the kelly green tights and the white bobby sox sticking out of white sneakers, the one who looks ever so slightly like Liza Minnelli. They cal her Morales in the show, and she plays a Puerto Rican from the Bronx who started to dance at the age of six when a man came around her neighborhood selling lessons. And that's just the way it happened in real life to Priscilla Lopez, the bouncy, 27yearold singerdanceractress who plays Morales, and who is emerging as one of the standouts of Michael Bennett's musical. Barring a continuation of the musicians strike, A Chorus Line is due to open officially on Broadway tonight after one of the longest previews in history.

title: Payment by North Korea
description: TOKYO, Sept. 27 (AP)North Korea has paid $2,00 compensation each to the fan ilies of two Japanese fisherme killed when their boat was a tacked by North Korean patrc boats earlier this month.

title: Margaret F. Grogan Is Married At Harvard to C. G. Petersmeyer
description: The Memorial Church at Hirvard University was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Margaret Fitzgerald Grogan, a 1973 graduate of Radcliffe College, to C. Gregg Petersmeyer, who graduated cum laude with the class of 72 from Harvard College and is doing graduate work in political philosophy at Oxford Tinivercitv in Fnoland.

title: Chad Orders France To Withdraw Troops
description: N'JAMENA, Chad, Sept. 27 (Reuters) Chad demanded the immediate removal today of all French troops stationed in its territory.

title: Jill Gerson Betrothed To Michael Jacobson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin C. Gerson have announced the engagement of their daughter. Jill Beth Gerson, to Michael Lee Jacobson, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Jacobson. Both families live in Scarsdale. N.Y.

title: FEDERAL INQUIRY TURNS TO MANDEL
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 27The Fideral investigation of corruption in Maryland that led to the conviction of Vice President Agnew and a host of local political figures and contractors turned officially this week to Gov, Marvin Mandel.

title: Runback by Morris Hills Helps Subdue Montclair
description: Glen Cameron, a quick tailback, returned a kickoff 73 yards for a touchdown yesterday as Morris Hills opened with a 167 upset victory over Montclair in Rockaway.

title: Careers Shorter In Formula One
description: With the Grand Prix of the United States coming up next Sunday at Watkins Glen, it is an appropriate time to examine Formula One drivers and the length About Motor Sportsof their careers. Ten years ago, 16 men scored points counting toward the world driving championship. Five years later, nine of those men were still among the point scorers. Today, there are nonealthough Denny Hulme, who retired last year, and Graham Hill, who retired earlier this year, came close.

title: Berner Posts a 286 Upset, Snaps Syosset Streak at 13
description: Berner ended Syosset's 13game winning streak yesterday with a 286 triumph in a nonconference game it saddled Syosset, the topranked team in New York State last year, with, its first defeat since 1973.

title: Miss Moore Taken to San Diego To Undergo Psychiatric Tests
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 27Sara Jane Moore was brought to the Government's new San Diego Correction Center late today to undergo psychiatric tests to determine whether she is to stand trial. She is accused of firing a 3Rcaliber revolver at President Ford on a San Francisco street last Monday.

title: BOOKS
description: The faculty of the Penland School, in rural North Carolina, has produced a series of books that represent the range of work taught in the many courses the school offers. This book on pottery is instructional and is liberally illustrated with many unusual clay products  pots, jars, decorative objects  created by the artistsinresidence. Though these craftsmen make no attempt to teach how to Book of Pottery.

title: There Are Only 25 Active Specialists, In Search of How the Language of United States Got That Way
description: In Bernard Shaw's Pygmalion Professor Henry Higgins was able to pinpoint the district of origin of a Cockney flower girl by listening to her accent and vocabulary. Could that be done today by an American linguistics expert and a local Eliza Doolittle?

title: BOOKS
description: Early Russian here encompasses the years between 1000 and 1700. It was a period when the Orthodox church was the seedbed of all architecture and decoration. This book is divided into two sections. The first traces the evolution of Early Russian architecture; the second describes and analyzes the major monuments. Four hundred and twenty illustrations (86 in color) provide ample documentation.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Fred Lynn, standout Boston Red Sox rookie, admits: I did set some goals at the start of the season. I hoped to hit 280 with 20 homers and 80 r.b.i.s. (He is hitting 332, has 21 home runs and has driven in 105 runs.)

title: National Wealth and Its Effects
description: National Wealth and Its Effects

title: Chart of the Woodward
description: Chart of the Woodward

title: Sounds lurid, reads poignant
description: This collection should rightfully win for its author wide attention and many readers, but there's a danger it'll he for the wrong reasons, since even the most measured plot synopsis may make these stories sound sensational or slightly psychopathic. In Homemade an adolescent boy experiences a comic sexual initiation with his prepubescent sister. Cocker at the Theatre concerns a rehearsal for a simulated copulation scene during which one couple has the rudeness to disrupt the cast by copulating. In Butterflies

title: Bridal Held on L.I. For Celia Goldberg
description: In the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, L.I., early yesterday evening, Celia tuner Goldberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Goldberg of Sands Point, was married to Darryl A. Marks. son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Marks of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Martin S. Rozenberg performed the ceremony.

title: Cyprus Factory Makes Fast Comeback;
description: LIMASSOL, CyprusEureka, Ltd., a producer of cleansers and cosmetics, was one of the most successful companies on this island until the summer of 1974.

title: CHASE BANK URGES TEMPORARY HELP FOR CITY FROM U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Chase Manhattan Bank has, for the first time, urged) the Federal Government to in tervene in the New York fiscal crisis.

title: New & Noval
description: The Soul Murder Case is a fingerexercise by the author of The Book of Numbers that displays only a smidgen of his formidable talent. What is here is the deepieated pessimism that threaded through Robert Deane Pharr's earlier book.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: Belmont Race Charts

title: The Nobility Of Failure
description: A premodem deathhaunted obsession lurks underneath the lan of the postmodern Japanese economic miracle. One could say Yukio Mishima's public disembowelment, five years ago, was a contemporary reenactment of the obsession. The obsession of which I speak has to do not just with death, but with a perfect deatha transcendent form of dying.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Last call to plant little bulbs seines, crocus, anemones, muscari, etc.  Tulips can be planted later, even November. Cleanup vegetable garden and start composting. Mist house plants that summered outdoors to aid their transition indoors.

title: American revivals
description: The Bicentennial has sparked the imagination of the homefurnishings industry. Many of this season's new designs in furniture and fabrics have roots in the American past. They're not just Early American, either. Styles range from Federal to Victorian. Both exact reproductions and free adaptations are available.

title: JEWS CELEBRATE JOYOUS OCCASION
description: Simhat Torahthe most joyous event in the Hebrew religious yearbegan at sundown yesterday with a spirit of gaiety in houses of worship throughout the city.

title: WHOOPING CRANES AWAITED IN TEXAS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 27As the whooping cranes return to Texas from Canada this winter they will be holding their own in a fight against extinction. Eight young cranes are in the flock.

title: Preserving tradition
description: Anyone who has done it, and who is also honest, can tell you: Restoring an old house is part altruism, humanism, euphoria and sanity, but it can also be egotism, materialism, despair and folly. In my very Savannah neighborhood, restoring old houses has contributed to divorce, bankruptcy and public mockery, but also to the preservation of gentle human values and cultural history and to an appreciation of the domestic arts and family life.

title: 50Mile Bike Race Is Slated at Shore
description: ASBURY PARKThe New Orleans Bayou Band vill provide Dixelandstyle entertainment for specta??? at the second annual Jersey Shore Bicycle race today.

title: Marathon Women Ready
description: In addition to the bicycle riders, pet walkers, afternoon strollers, and homegrown joggers, Central Park will be invaded by still another group todaymore than 500 distance runners from around the country and abroad. The occasion is the sixth New York City marathon, which has attracted one of the strongest contingents of runners ever. Sixty runners are women who will be vying for the Amateur Athletic Union women's national championship, and striving to furnish proof that women can prove their endurance in marathons other than the dance kind.

title: A TROUBLED CALM RETURNS IN BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 27Beirut was calm today, with only scattered incidents of sniping reported from outlying neighborhoods, as officials worked behind the scenes to keep a Syriansponsored ceasefire from unraveling.

title: Admirer of Norman Rockwell Following in His Footsteps
description: SOUTH RIVER  Joseph Csatari has achieved two ambitions he has become an artist, and now is following in the footsteps of an artist he has long admiredNorman Rockwell.

title: To conquer the world with a yawn
description: We all talk to you, and you just listen, a garrulous character says of Toby Roberts, the good listener of the title. And as Toby, a poor boy with his eye on the main chance, graduates Cambridge with a windfall First in History, flirts listlessly with a donship, beds a couple of upperclass ladies, and finally berths in a cushy investment bank, we follow the progress Jess of an acting, feeling being than a sort of ambulatory vacuum.

title: DANES RESENTFUL OF WELFARE COST
description: Public opinion polls show that twothirds of those suestioned find that taxes, which rose to the equivalent of 44 per cent of the gross national product in 1971, are unfair. Sixtythree per cent of those polled are said to feel that the socialwelfare state, which provides some money for 85 per cent ofl the population, has gone too, far.

title: Operetta
description: The New York City Opera's H. M. S. Pinafore put in at the New York State Theater for the first time this season Saturday afternoon, bringing with it a jolly assortment of seamen, officers and female companions that only W. S. Gilbert could have dreamed up, and everybody sang Arthur Sullivan's music as if they had grown up on it.

title: Nursing Surplus Is Found in State
description: TRENTONFor more than a decade, colleges and hospitals in New Jersey and elsewhere across the country have been straining their budgets to enlarge their nursetraining programs and alleviate what was considered a critical medical shortage.

title: Hospital Is Helping Adults To Learn
description: A widow, suddenly forced to he a breadwinner, grows perturbed because she must leave the high school diploma box blank on employment Questionnaires.

title: Almost the Best of Everything
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 27  Modern Sweden seems to have almost the best of everything, including a criminal justice system generally considered fair, humane and effective. Policemen are polite here, and as Kurt Lindruth, their chief constable, puts it, We do not like to shoot.

title: At home in church
description: When I came back from Hong Kong with two very small children, a friend asked me, What are you doing this summer? and invited me up to Stonington, Conn. It never ??? to me that New Yorkers went away for the summer, says Mrs. Inger McCabe Elliott, a photojournalistturnedbusinesswoman who spent six years living in the Far East. That is how she came to buy the cfmturyoid Baptist church that occupies the narrow end of a treelined block in the tiny port town of Stonington.

title: Free Lessons Set In Tennis and Golf
description: A free fourweek program of lessons in tennis and golf sponsored by the Town of Hempstead Department of Parks and Recreation will be available to residents age 18 and over.

title: Courses Scheduled For ForeignBorn
description: HACKENSACKRegistration for the Evening School for ForeignBorn Adults, a project of the Hackensack Board of Education, will take place tomorrow and Tuesday at the Middle School, 360 Union Street. Classes start Oct. 6.

title: Herman G. Fisher Is Dead at 76 Was President of Toy Company
description: Herman G. Fisher, for nearly 40 years  head of FisherPrice Toys, Inc., one of the largest toy manufacturers in the world, died Friday in Millard Fillmore Hospital, Buffalo. He was 76 years old.

title: POLLUTION LAW HELD DEFICIENT
description: WASHINGTONA Federal commission staff report has tentatively concluded that the Water Pollution Control Act of 1972 and its administration by the Environmental Protection Agency have been deficient in moving the nation toward the goal of clean waterways and water sources by the midnineteeneighties.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Just in case anyone got the idea from my last two columns that absolutely everything is coming up roses, for every rose there is a thorn, and here are a few more news items, good and bad. Still on the good side, one very late bloomer is the New London Railroad Station, the H. H. Richardson building of 188687 for which local and national preservationists have engaged in a 10year battle, reported here off and on, that seemed loaded against them in every way. It wasn't an uphill fight; it was perpendicular.

title: jemy City Acts to Save Old Cemetery
description: JERSEY CITYThe future of historic; but abandoned, Speer Cemetery, which is said to be the oldest burial ground in New Jersey, rests with a Green Acres application that the local Division of Planning is preparing to submit to the state.

title: Problems of the Unemployed Executive
description: Almost, nine years ago Richard H. Eggers Jr. resigned his management position in a small Long Island company and accepted an offer to join an international realestate marketing company. Within eight years at the new company Mr. Eggers had become executive vice president, his annual salary jumping from $21,000 to $37,000.

title: Abrams Says Utilities Charged $100Million for Taxes Never Paid to U.S.
description: Consolidated Edison and the other electric utilities in the state have charged their customers for almost $100million in federal taxes since 1974 that they actually never paid to the Government but were legally able to pocket themselves, according to Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx.

title: Smithtown Church Marks 300 Years
description: SMITHTOWN The First Presbyterian Church of Smithtown, which predates the founding of this country by 100 years, is celebrating its tercentenary this weekend.

title: Mets Lose To Carlton; Tied for 3d
description: PHILADELPHIA. Sept. 27Steve Carlton pitched a twohitter and the Philadelphia Phillies took advantage of three mental mistakes by the New York Vets tonight for an 81 victory.

title: Black Philly
description: South Street is an ambitious, scraggly novel with deep pockets and vast, bumping corners that reach into the limbo between the Schuylkill and the Delaware, for a long, bitter look at the corrugated country of black Philadelphia. Its gifted young author, David Bradley.

title: Revitalized Victorian
description: San Francisco is a city full of charming Victorian houses seemingly in constant process of being renewed, restored, revalued, resold and even, when need be, trundled to new sites. Recycling is integral to the realestate game there. But even for San Francisco the rambling, countrified Victorian house that C. David and Mary Robinson acquired is quite special, and the changes they have made in it and all they have revived have not only saved a marvelous old house but recycled an ambience as well.

title: 3 in Dayton Are Charged In Kidnapping and Slaying
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 27 (AP) Three men have been arrested and charged with aggravated murder, kidnapping and extortion in the kidnapping and murder of Lester C. Emoff, a 67yearold furniture executive.

title: Soviet Official Affirms Ideological Curbs on Import of Western Publications
description: MOSCOW, Sept 22A Soviet Foreign Ministry official has informed Soviet journalists that Moscow will not permit an influx of Western ideas and publications contradictory to Soviet legislation and to the morality of socialist society.

title: The State Education Commissioner, an Unabashed Liberal
description: It is a reflection of Ewald B. Nyquist's influence that New York State is still trying to compel its cities to bus schoolchildren for racial desegregation in a period when policy makers in many other states and even in Congress are rejecting busing.

title: Roxana Johnson Plans to Marry
description: Nunnally Johnson, the screenwriter, producer and director, and Mrs. Johnson of Beverly Hills, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Roxana Johnson, to Michael Guthrie Lonergan of New York, who is on the staff of Alexander H. Cohen, the Broadway producer.

title: Molecular Astronomy: The Great Void Is Alive
description: It may come as a surprise to the distilling industry, but there is a greater reservoir of grain neutral spirits adrift in the constellation Sagittarius than has been produced on earth since alcoholic beverages were discovered.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: THE hoary subject of opera in English is never far from us, and this column has dwelt upon it from time to time. It is a subject that goes back to Addison and Steele in 1711, something that had slipped my mind until the announcement of the Houston Grand Opera's staging of Handel's Rinaldo. On Oct. 16, Marilyn Home will be starring in Rinaldo, which will of course be sung in the original Italian. But it was that opera which brought forth the polemics of Addison and Steele's Spectator papers. Both of those writers were very much praoperainEnglish, and they may have been the very first to raise the issue.

title: Public Job Unions Mount Counterattack for Raises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The nation's public employe unions, confronted with a sharply stiffening resistance to their demands by elected officials, are beginning to fight back with increasing resentment.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The eyecatching drop in the open market price of gold appears to have little or no international monetary consequence, at least for now. Currency values are no longer pegged to gold, and even national gold reserves have been all but frozen and unused for more than four years. The member nations of the International Monetary Fund have agreed unanimously that gold will no longer carry an official price. West Germany, the second largest trading country in the world, is finding Eastern European business more meaningful these days as trade with its traditional Western partners has slipped. An allnight supermarket in New Jersey has added a new and different item to its stock allnight banking.

title: Students Campaign To Keep Athletics
description: EAST MEADOW  Last weekend, in what was an opening volley, some 300 student athletes from the East Meedow High School fannedout in the streets in an unusual fundraising campaigntheir ultimate goal, $20,000 for the school's athletic program.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONWith the Assembly elections only little more than a month away, the Democratic majority has set aside tomorrow's session for a rash of bills, most of them calculated to help the reelection chances of their Democratic sponsors.

title: Frenchmen Accept National Show Bid
description: For almost three decades the French equestrian team, always one of the best in Europe, was absent from the National Horse Show. Last year, the French made the Horse Show Newstrip to the National and the other two shows on the North American indoor fall circuit Washington and Toronto and made an excellent impression. So, said Ted Cushny, president of the National, we decided to invite them back this year and they accepted. We are very pleased.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: ORGANIZATION OF PETROLEUM EXPORTING COUNTRIES met in Vienna to set price level for oil. United States Government announced that it would lift 60centabarrel fee on imported petroleum products, retroactive to Sept. I. President Ford announced that he would ask Congress to authorize $100billion for development of energy resources.

title: Reports from Senator Jim and Brother Bill
description: It must tax the patience, if not the conscience, of these conservatives to spend so much time trying to shed what Senator James L. Buckley laments is their Wall Street, knownothing, treadingonthepoor image. The problem is particularly acute, of course, for a Senator who was elected in New York in 1970 with a scant 39 per cent of the vote and now faces a potentially tough reelection campaign before an electorate that may not qualify as one of the true rightwing bastions in America.

title: Jets Young Turk Faces Old Chief
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 27When I was a little boy, said the Jets Godwin Turk, I used to watch Len Dawson on television. And that's the only time I ever saw him.

title: BEAME IS FACING NEW BUDGET CUT
description: An $81million emergency budget expense that Mayor Beame rushed last week to rescue the City Educational Construction Fund from defaulthas become the subject of the first confrontation between Mr. Beame and others on the new Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: If the scope of his achievement is the only criterion, Sander is even morethe greatest portraitist, painter or photographer, of all time. Most portraitists, whether painters or photographers, confine themielves to a certain segment of societyto the poor and dispossessed if they are socially conscious documentary photographers, to peers and princes if they are Van Dyck or Velasquez, to celebrities if they are magazine photographers. Sander, however, took as his subject matter all of humanity as it presented itself to him in his time and place. He lived in Germany during the Weimar Republic, and from shortly after the First World War until the Nazis put an end to his enterprise in the 1930's, Sander strove to record and document all the social and professional types of his country, from bricklayers and peasant girls to generals and corporation presidents.

title: Natural Gas: Short, and Getting Shorter
description: The United States faces what may turn out to be the most severe shortage of energy in its history this winter as supplies of natural gas are expected to fall far below anticipated demand in many sections of the country.

title: Minor Pleasures Exist in PaperThin Play
description: Randy Goldsborough's setting and Louise Krozek's costumes are both tastefully sufficient, and the acting had a certain style. Kathy O'Callaghan did not have suite enough eccentric charm for the matriarch, but the younger people were decently portrayed. I particularly liked Sharo Laughlin as the spirited Isabelle, and Dan Diggles pulled off the Hugo/Frederic tour de force with all the requisite gusto. In all, an evening of minor but real pleasures.

title: Horse Show Results
description: Horse Show Results

title: Freeport Is 15th Victim For Holy Family, 2414
description: Holy Family scored on the first play from scrimmage yesterday and never trailed in a 2414 victory over Freeport that extended its winning streak to 15 games, the longest in Suffolk.

title: M'GOVERN SEEKING C.I.A. LISBON CURF
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27Senator George S. McGovern announced today that he would introduce legislation to ban further United States covert intelligence activity in Portugal and to give the Government of Portugal $55million in regular economic aid.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABCAM: Message of Israel. Address by Raboi Samuel M. Silver, of Temple Sinai, Stamford, Conn.Janacek.

title: DownatHeels Hotel Gets a Natty New Identity
description: The Hot 1 Baltimore is not Greenwich Village's longest running melodrama about a rundown hotel; the Hotel Greenwich is.

title: Needed more L.S.J.
description: During the heyday of Great Society hubris, Joseph Califano received telephone call from an angry Secretary of Agriculture, Orville Freeman. Califano, then the President's chief domestic political aide, had just briefed the press with Interior Secretary Stewart Udall about a new wilderness.

title: Major League Baseball
description: American League

title: TAX AIDE SAYS NIXON GOT BREAK ON AUDIT
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27(AP) An Internal Revenue Service agent has testified that he was dissuaded from investigating a controversial gift by former (President Richard M. Nixon beI cause of fear that an audit of Nixon's 197172 tax return might be publicized.

title: THE HOME
description: A New Yorker cartoon of some years back captured the public's growing infatuation with old houses. It depicted a construction site, little more than a gaping hole in a city block. A large sign read: To be built on this siteA new brownstone, spacious rooms, high ceilings, soundproof walls, gracious fireplaces, airy kitchens. Those features are attracting today's families who are disenchanted with anonymous high rises and lookalike suburban houses who find older houses roomy and comfortable, their spaces familiar and inviting.

title: The Ford Administration Would Like to Put Off a Decision
description: WASHINGTON  Probably the most delicate issue, both economically and politically, confronting President Ford is whether to urge Congress to extend into next year the temporary antirecession tax reduction enacted last March. There is no obvious right answer, though there are strongly held views on each side.

title: Vital Dialogue Is Beginning Between the Rich and Poor
description: The world has always been divided between have and havenot nations but the gap has recently been widening. For the last four years the percapita Income of the one billion people in the 30 poorest countriesalready at subsistence levelshas declined still further, while the industrial nations have been holding their own. This means that the richest billion people have been claiming more of the earth's scarce resources each year, and a majority of the poorest have been receiving less.

title: People/Business
description: Back in the spring of 1968, when student unrest was at its peak, a group of Princeton University freshmen decided to do something constructive about the situation.

title: OPTIONS TO AVERT LAYOFFS UTILIZED
description: The fourday work week for five days pay, which had seemed in store for many American workers, has since the recession taken on a new relevance with a major modificationfour days work for four days pay.

title: 7 Lion Turnovers Lead to 107 Loss
description: EASTON, Pa., Sept. 27Columbia opened its 85th season of intercollegiate football today amid a tragedy of errors that allowed Lafayette to defeat the Lions, 107, before a crowd of 5,000 at the Leopards Fisher Field.

title: A CBS Documentary About A CBS Blacklist
description: Eighteen years ago the Columbia Broadcasting Systern found John Henry Faulk, a 43yearold radio and TV personality with a Texas drawl, a country wit, an urban appeal and possibly slipping ratings, enough of a political embarrassment to fire.

title: Trainer Awaiting Pan American Games
description: SAYREVILLE  Vito Recine, the athletic trainer at Sayreville High School, is Mexico Citybound, having been selected by his peers and Olympic officials as one of the 12 trainers to accompany the United States team that will vie in the Pan American Games next month.

title: Field Searched for Hoffa's Body on Underworld Tip
description: DETROIT, Sept. 27Acting today on information provided by an informant who described himself as representing top organized crime figures, Senate investigators, state policemen and members of the State Attorney's General office here began a search for James R. Hoffa's body in a swampy field.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Dog Day Afternoon is not only the most accurate, most flamboyant of Sidney Lumet's New York movies, which include Serpico and The Pawnbroker, it is the best film he's ever made, with the exception of A Long Day's Journey Into Night, and that one had the advantage of the Eugene O'Neill play and three great roles superlatively acted by Ralph Richardson, Katharine Hepburn and Jason Robards.

title: Apolitical American Consultants
description: In April, 1974, Algerian President Houari Boumediene launched the rhetorical cold war between the developing nations and the industrial powers with a fiery speech before a special session of the United Nations. To the cheers of delegates from the Third World, he denounced the profligate ways of the West and attributed all the poor's troubles to the higher cost of goods purchased from the developed countries.

title: Morristown Chalks Up Its 21st Straight Success
description: Morristown broke away in the second half yesterday for a 270 victory over Columbia, the 21st straight victory for the Morris County power. Last season Morristown won the North Jersey Section 2 Group 4 title in the New Jersey's first postseason playoffs.

title: A Tibetan Art Stronghold
description: NEWARKThe reputation of the Newark Museum as stronghold of Tibetan art is pointed up in an exhibition, now on view, of photographs of ceremonies held in that Asian country.

title: The liberation of Total Woman
description: There is a revolution going on. Women who have been married 30 years are getting into their station wagons and just driving away. Younger wives go out on Tuesday nights not to play bridge but to consciousnessraising groups and karate classes. Teenaged girls are telling their mothers that they do not plan to marry. The Equal Rights Amendment will probably be ratified in 1976 or 1977.

title: Gas: New York Area
description: Utilities in the New York area are expected to get through the winter without any major curtailments of service, but only through considerable cooperation among the various distributors in the areaand the use of fuels other than natural gas.

title: Mobil Aide Asserts OPEC Step Shows Congress Must Act
description: A spokesman for the Mobil Oil Corporation said that the increase in crude oil prices announced yesterday by OPEC merely dramatizes the urgent need for Congress to reach an accord with the Administration on energy policy.

title: Ten things never to say to a younger woman
description: Kenneth Koch's poetry has up to now been regarded primarily for its humor. I remember reading in an anthology that he was a comic master, a lefthanded compliment if there ever was one when applied to a poetand although Koch's sense of humor is certainly one of the irrefutable delights of this collection, it is one among many. Other qualities these poems embody areat randomthe ability to move the reader, plain but beautiful language that should appeal to a wide audience, a general graciousness of spirit that has long been an unremarkedon hallmark of Koch's writing, and last but not least, outright wisdom.

title: Fight of a Lifetime Draws Glamour Set
description: MANILA, Sept. 27Manila's sunrise is starstudded these days as celebrities in sports and show business jet in on the 5:55 A.M. from Honolulu to attend the Muhammad Ali  Joe Frazier championship fight on Wednesday, (Tuesday night. New York time) at the Philippine Coliseum. Norman Mailer, the author, Ryan O'Neal, Warren Beatty, Gail Fisher, Hugh O'Brian and Connie Stevens, screen stars are among 40 names in the entertainment field who were invited to attend what is billed as The Fight of a Lifetime.

title: Malpractice Insurance: A Crisis for Architects
description: Architects are suggesting fundamental changes in their relationships with clients to check skyrocketing costs of malpractice insurance.

title: Ashe Sets Back Mayer And Reaches Semifinals

description: CAPE MAYThe New Jersey Audubon Society, the oldest and largest conservation organization in the state, will hold its 30th Autumn Nature Weekend here from Friday through next Sunday.

title: TV VIEW
description: There is nothing quite like television for bringing out the worst in inverse snobbery, Americanstyle. Unsparing efforts are made to keep TV at the bottom of the cultural totem pole, even though the medium has often proved its ability to compete vigorously in the populararts marketplace. Vested interests, of an incredible variety, appear determined to keep TV's image on the lowest of sociocultural levels.

description: LUANDA. Angola, Sept. 24International relief efforts to aid 250,000 Kongo tribesmen in peril of starvation have been thwarted as rescue agencies, including the United Nations, have failed to obtain necessary agreements from the three nationalist armies that have cut this Portuguese territory in three.

title: Father and son became friends
description: It is no easy task to write with candor of one's father. Hugo Black Jr.the son of a man who rose from Alabama country lawyer to United States Senator to the Supreme Courthas managed the trick. His book is not so much an evaluation of a famous man's career as it is the story of a father and son moving toward each other. The journey was difficult.

title: Lab Monkeys in Short Supply
description: The scientists are feeling the effects of a nationwide shortage of monkeys for laboratory experiments, and are smarting ??? the spiraling cost of the animals.

title: SEATO's Tearless End
description: The decision of the member nations of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization to phase out the alliance the logical consequence of American withdrawal from South Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos. Although the alliance itself remained virtually dormant throughout the American war in Indochina, the treaty originated in Washington's decision, after the 1954 French collapse and the Geneva settlement, to accept the chief responsibility for aiding the former French territories against possible threats from their Communist neighbors in North Vietnam and China.

It plans to erect a 365room motel on the site at a cost of more than $12The site is located on Red Oak Lane at the intersection of the Hutchinson River Parkway and the Cross Westchester Expressway. It is directly opposite the site on which Texaco plans to build a 740,000 squarefoot office facility.

title: 5 Are Executed in Spain Despite Pleas in Europe
description: MADRID, Sept. 27Five convicted political terrorists were executed by firing s'suads today after the Spanish Government swept aside lastminute appeals for clemency and disregarded violent protests in other parts of Europe.

title: Hunters and Antihunters: A Controversy Continues
description: The Guns of Autumn does an injustice to many hunters. Many people in Vermont, and I believe a sizable proportion of the hunting population in this country, hunt not primarily for recreational purposes but rather for food. (I lived with a lowincome family for three months whose only source of meat was wild game. When this kind of meat was unavailable, potatoes were served as the main course for dinner.)

title: Colgate Defeats Cornell
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 27 (AP)Bruce Basile directed Colgate's powerful wishbone offense to three scores in the first three quarters and the Red Raiders held on to defeat Cornell, 2422, and spoil George Seifert's coaching debut today.

description: Mrs. Peter Funk (Mailbox, Sept. 14) cries foul play at Arthur Ashe and asks, If Ilia Nastase is fined $8,000 for profanity, how much to redress the horror of Arthur Ashe's statement on TV that in mixed doubles he would aim at the woman's breast to frighten her?

title: What's Doing in GENEVA
description: GETTING ACQUAINTEDA visitor landing at Geneva's Cointrin Airport has immediately available to him one of the few real bargains in Switzerland in these days of the anemic dollar. Near the passenger exit he can board a big trolley bus, No. 33, for 90 centimes (about 35 cents) and ride anywhere in the city. The fare is good for one hour of travel with unlimited transfer facilities, which puts any spot in Geneva within reach. The trip from the airport to where the Rhone River slices through the center of the city takes 20 minutes on No. 33 bus. It can also be made at a reasonable price, 3 Swiss francs (about $1.10), on the airline coach that shuttles between the airport and the downtown Swissair offices at Cornavin Station. Taxis cost $1.10 just to board, while each kilometer (62 miles) adds approximately 38 cents to the fare, with higher rates at night and on Sunday and an extra charge for each piece of luggage that goes into the trunk or on the roof rack.

title: Connecticut Routed by Elis, 3514
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27Fielding a team with new players at key positions, Yale opened its 103d football season today by defeating the University of Connecticut, 3514. The teams played before a crowd of 18,900 in the Yale Bowl, refurbished with new turf and new paint.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ABOUT three months ago, when this year's difficult first half was drawing to a close, the economic community was unusually humble and wary about its forecasts. One private economist in Massachusetts even refused to join in the periodic forecasting derby because of dissatisfaction with the profession's ability to estimate various aspects of economic activity with a useful degree of accuracy. Others prepared multiple sets of forecasts based on various assumed scenarios for key issues.

title: Luxury Audio Is It Worth The Price Tag?
description: It is now possible to spend as much for a stereo system as for an expensive automobile. A case in point was an excellent Yamaha sound system, shown at a recent audio exhibit, with a price tag of a cool $6,000. Indeed, the comparison between the auto and audio industries may be carried further. Both industries have seen the recession cut sharply into sales of their low and moderate priced offerings while their luxury items still sell briskly. General Motors, for example, reported that while Chevrolet and Vega were laying off and shutting down, the Cadillac Division was doing excellent business. Similarly, at the last Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago, the most notable activity was in the topoftheline models.

title: Hofstra Forms Unit For Ethnic Studies
description: HEMPSTEADA center for cultural and intercultural studies has been formed at Hofstra University here in an effort to provide students, faculty members and alumni with information about their own cultures and about those of others on Long Island and in the metropolitan areas.

title: Doctors Will Confer On Legal Problems
description: BELLE MEADPhysicians from three states will convene at the Carrier Clinic here Wednesday to see if anyone has a cure for the growing number of legal headaches affecting members of the medical profession.

title: U.S. AGENT'S ROLE HINTED IN GUN SALE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27Mark Fernwood, the suburban gun collector who sold Sara Jane Moore the pistol she allegedly fired at President Ford here last Monday, says he believes that he obtained the weapon from a Federal agent who was possibly trying to involve him in an illegal arms transaction.

title: Herzog's 'Every Man for Himself' Is Stunning Fable Full of Universals'
description: The early tenor aria from "The Magic Flute" arches in a high arrow's trajectory over the opening shots: a boat moves on a blue river, a washerwoman on the bank looks up and regards us solemnly, and wind pushes the marsh grass in heavy waves.It is impossible to know why these things move us, or why they prepare us for an experience out of the ordinary. Throughout "Every Man for Himself and God Against All" there are moments when we drift a bit outside of ourselves, in a kind of detached gratefulness that the person occupying our seat is being given so much.Werner Herzog is a young German director with a rapidly growing reputation in Europe and, as yet, not much of a name here. "Every Man for Himself," which won this year's Grand Jury Prize at the Cannes Film Festival, should change that.Mr. Herzog does not deal with small corners of reality; he riddles with universals. Like Ingmar Bergman, his concerns are more mtaphysical than social, and again like Mr. Bergman, he explores them in ways that keep engaging our imagination, our intellect and our emotions.His pictures are populated with freaks and deformities or people in freakish or deformed circumstances. Not, at least in his latest films, in order to dwell on these extremeshe is in no way exoticbut to focus on the main human condition, as a man might climb to the foothills at the edge of a city to see the city better."Every Man" is set on a real historical incident. In the early 19th-century a man appeared in a square in Nuremberg. He could not speak, he could barely stand, he had apparently been kept in some kind of dungeon. His identity was a mysterythe only clue was a paper he carried that gave his name as Kasper Hauser and asked that he be taken into service as a soldier.He was taken in, taught to speak, to read and write, and then, in a fashion as mysterious as his first appearance, he was murdered.This is Mr. Herzog's fable, allowing both a concrete and a philosophical exercise of the questions: Where do we come from? Why are we here? Where do we go?A sound fable is not enough for a sound movie: "Every Man" is a superb movie because Mr. Herzog has managed to treat the fable in stunning human and dramatic terms. He has done so, in large part, through his use of a man identified only as Bruno S.he is not a professional actor, and he has spent some time in mental institutionsas Kasper.There is more than acting; there is a total, magical immersion of Bruno in the man who arrives in the world as a stranger, takes it in, tries to grasp it, judges it and is removed from it.Kasper is seen first in his dungeon, grunting and playing with his only possession, a wooden horse. His keeper, a man in blackMr. Herzog conceives God as a secret policeman  appears, jams boots on his legs, which are as soft and white as maggots, and carries him to the town square at dawn.The world discovers Kasper and Kasper discovers the world. Nothing very dramatic happens until the end: The film is mostly a gentle, meditative and poignant discourse. The authorities send a tiny owl of a notary around after Kasper to record his actions and pronouncements, beautifully played by Walter Ladengast.Kasper's extraordinary face, his eyes strained wide to see better, his whole posture suggesting a man trying to swallow, trying to grasp a world of strangeness, is the film's central image.As he learns to speak, he learns to think. He wants to accept society but he cannot. "Every man is a wolf to me," he tells the professor, haltingly. His only struggle is to search for his own meaning: He has no ego. "Nothing lives less in me than my life," he says.Scholars come to question him: he baffles and holds them off. He is trying to understand life, not the rules of life. He strains and strains; he dreams the beginning of a dream that may have the meaning he is looking for, but he can't manage to dream an ending.The man in black reappears"Wait here for me," he had instructed Kasper when he left him on the squareand strikes him down. Kasper dies, recounting the first half of his dream, an autopsy finds that his brain is deformed.The notary society's representative, emerges, writing in his book. "We have found an explanation for this strange man; we cannot find a better one," he says with deep satisfaction. As he walks up the street and this beautiful cryptic and satisfying movie ends, we see that he is limping: He too is deformed.

title: Why Ali Whipped Patterson
description: I had not seen [Floyd] Patterson since our fight In Las Vegas, but when I came across an article he'd written for a national magazine, saying some honest things about the loser, the admiration I'd had for him during my amateur days returned and I accepted an invitation to go out to his farm.

title: Assassination Attempts Spark Controversy Over News Media
description: Media coverage of the two recent alleged assassination attempts against President Ford has once again touched off a controversy over whether the press, in giving prominence to such sensational events, does I not inspire a contagion of the (violence.

description: SAG HARBORIf the Village Board has its way, this onetime whaling center on the East End's South Fork will be linked to New London, Conn. by a carandpassenger ferry.

title: Amanda Davis Bride Of David S. Anderson
description: Amanda Hale Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hanford G. Davis of Brandon, Vt., was married yesterday afternoon to David Stuart Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Anderson of Pittsford, Vt. The Rev. James Kvetko performed the ceremony in the Brandon Congregational Church.

title: ARABS WARN U.S. ON AID TO ISRAEL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 27The Arab League warned the United States today that moves to supply Israel with large quantities of advanced weapons, including missiles, were endangering peace in the Middle Fast.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on motion to close debate on appropriations bill for the Departments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare. which re'suired a threefifths vote of the Senate for passage. Motion rejected. 46 yeas to 48 nays, Sept. 23.

title: The Four Days of Mayaguez
description: President Ford and his spokesmen tried to make a silk purse out of a sow's ear when they described the Mayagilez affair as a regenerative turning point in this country's postVietnam recovery of national confidence and international prestige. Roy Rowan's hastily puttogether history of that sorry event, The Four Days of Mayagiiez may have been designed to do the same thingat least the book jacket blurb calls it a compelling story of bold confrontation and heightening drama, of the courage and heroism of the captured crew and the Marines during those tensionfilled days.

title: Nancy Blanchard Wed in Southport
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Nancy Franklin Blanchard, daughter of William Stokes Blanchard and Mary Fairbank Blanchard, both of Westport, Conn., to John Glennon Revenauali, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lynn Revenaugh of Greenfield Hill, Fairfield, Conn.

title: Anthony Drexel Duke Marries Luly de Lourdes in Coral Gables
description: Anthony Drexel Duke, an heir to the Duke and Biddle fortunes, yesterday took as his fourth bride the Havanaborn Maria (Luly) de Lourdes of Miami. The couple met last November, when Mr. Duke's son, John Ordway Duke, was married In Coconut Grove, Fla., to the bride's younger sister, Beatriz Alcebo.

title: WhigClio Society at Princeton Observes Its 200th Anniversary
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 27 Princeton University's American WhigCliosophic Society, the oldest college literary and debating club in the nation, celebrated its bicentennial today by unveiling a bust of Woodrow Wilson, presented by the Woodrow Wilson Foundation, and dedicating a display of memorabilia to George W. Oakes, Jr., a past WhigClio president.

title: Old House Offers Lesson in People
description: MILLWOOD, N. Y.We haven't made much money as landlords, but we've learned a lot about lifestyles.

title: Cadets Upset, 100, by Villanova
description: WEST POINT I, N. Y., Sepu. 27After four days of rain, the sun came out at Michie Stadium today. But that was about the only bright thing tha happened to Army's football team as the Cadets suffered a convincing 100 defeat by Villanova University.

title: The Maggie B. Written and Illustrated By Irene Haas. Unpaged. New York: Atheneum/Margaret K. McElderry. $7.95. (Ages 3 to 6)
description: A cozy, peachcolored bedroom, strewn with toys, lies neglected while Margaret Barnstable peers wistfully out her window at the North Star. The setting glows with a magical prescience; an appropriate moment for Margaret to wish for a ship Named after me/to sail for a day/Alone and free,/With someone nice/For company.

title: Major Role Against Hunger Urged for U.N. Universitil
description: TOKYO, Sep. 27An International committee of experts on food has recommended that the new United Nations University undertake a major project to alleviate world hunger by teaching people to make better use of food.

title: Respiratory Project Gets $20,920 Grant
description: SCOTCH PLAINSThe Allied Health Division of the Union County Technical Institute has received a grant of $20,920 to improve and update its twoyear associatedegree program in respiratory therapy.

title: COUNTRIES OF OPEC AGREE ON IN RISE IN THE PRICE OF OIL
description: VIENNA, Sept. 27  The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed today to a 10 per cent increase in the price of oil effective Oct. 1.

title: Wheatley Blanks Horace Mann
description: EAST WILLISTON. L. I., Sept. 27 Pete Mazzeo, Wheatley's junior quarterback, injured and unable to practice last week, threw touchdown passes of 24 and 22 yards to his tight end, Charlie Cassely, in pacing Wheatley to a 190 rout of visiting Horace Mann today.

title: Psychiatric Services in Coney Island Hospital to Be Sharply Cut
description: Sixty per cent of Coney island Hospital's psychiatric staff is scheduled to be transferred to other institutions soon in what the State Department of Mental Hygiene calls a realignment of services. An official of the hospital termed the move nothing short of tragic.

title: Forego Scores, Wajima Second
description: The winner and still the king? A crowd of 26,186 at Belmont Park yesterday received just cause to establish Forego as likely to retain his Horse of the Year crown when he sped to a 1length victory in the 22d running of the Woodward Stakes.

title: THREE JUDGESHIPS TO BE CHALLENGED
description: Queens Democrats and Republicans, who in recent years have run joint slates for State Supreme Court posts, will contest three seats at stake in the November election.

title: 8,000 in Louisville March to Protest School Bus Order
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 27 (UPI)About 8,000 antibusing demonstrators, led by an elderly woman in a wheel chair, staged a mass march in downtown Louisville today.

title: Ali and the Moral of the Story
description: TV Show, Sept. 13, 1975 About 500 miles to the south of Manila, site of the Thriller against the Gorilla, Moslem rebels are fighting threeyearold war against an Americansupported regime they consider a dictatorship. In two days, Muhammad Ali, a Moslem and a critic of American foreign policy, having plugged the Philippines into the Happy News Network, will switch all the world's rosecolored lights upon President Marcos's islands.
