title: Commuter Fights L.I.R.R. Arrest
description: WOODMERE  Jules Fox and the Long Island Rail Road have always gotten along like pizza pie and ice cream sodaswonderful by themselves, but a bit upsetting when put together. Recently the two met up once again, and it appears that only a legal bicarbonate can relieve the distress.

title: Exhibition Traces Ecology Problems
description: POMONA  Population: The Problem Is Us, the first in a series of environmental exhibitions developed by a grant from the National Science Foundation, is now on view in the library at Stockton State College.

title: A Cult Follows the Anti'sues Shows
description: ???  Anti'sue. shows and flea markets have become an almost everyday occurrence in suburbia, and from them have emerged cults of collectors, the curious, bargain hunters and sometimes, the lonely. All follow these events from site to site, week in and week out.

title: Boston Takes East Title
description: BOSTON, Sept. 27The Boston Red Sox lost 52, to the Cleveland Indians today but won the American League East Division title when the Baltimore Orioles dropped a doubleheader in New York. Boog Powell and Charlie Spikes hit consecutive home runs in the eighth inning to assure the Cleveland victory as Rick Waits set down the Red Sox on five hits.

title: The Nation
description: In an affidavit intended to secure her release on bail, Patricia Hearst has portrayed herself as an unwilling member of the Symbionese Liberation Army who now desired to return to her family. But Miss Hearst cast doubt upon that account by revealing, in a taperecorded jail conversation, that she considered herself a revolutionary feminist and feared being restcieted to her parents home.

title: LIBERALS ASSESS FIVE DEMOCRATS
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 27Five candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination pleaded their cases here today before more than 1,000 party activists from New York and New England.

title: The Trickiest Hobby
description: At a time when science has made almost anything seem possible and explainable, more people than ever are enjoying magic as a hobby. Stores that sell magic tricks and books report that sales have doubled in recent years, and schools have sprung up to teach aspiring magicians how to perform tricks.

title: SAIGON UNIT SEEKS DIVERTED U.S. AID
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 27.A South Vietnamese Government delegation has been touring Southeast Asia in a vain attempt to reclaim as much as $25million worth of food and supplies of the United States Agency for International Development that was diverted from Saigon just before the fall of the old Vietnamese Government.

title: TAX CUT REVERSES BURDEN FOR POOR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27A new study of the Federal taxes paid by different income groups concludes that the relative weight of the Federal tax burden borne by lowincome individuals had increased the most over the last 20 years until enactment of this year's tax cuts.

title: Redskins Favored to Work Jinx
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27George Allen, who runs Washington operation more covert than the Central Intelligence Agency, has blown his cover. Or, more precisely, Bill Arnsparger has blown Allen's cover.

title: Venezuela's Oil Output Off
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sepl 27 (UPI)Venezuela's averag daily oil production dropped b, 19.1 per cent, or 583,900 bat rels, during the first eigb months of the year, the Mine Ministry said today. Venezuel has been cutting back product ion to husband reserves.

title: Epilogue
description: A border dispute that has lingered since World War II is finally being settled. Italy and Yugoslavia are close signing an agreement that would formally cede to Yugoslavia an area south of Trieste, which she has administered since the war. Despite Yugoslav control of the area, Italian governments have insisted until now that the territory's status was open, with minor questions to be settled. An adjacent zone to the north, which includes the city of Trieste, was also disputed after the war. It became a part of Italy under a 1954 agreement.

title: National League
description: Philadelphia 8, New York 1 (n.). Cincinnati 7, Atlanta 6.

title: Rape Case and Petty Thievery Force Yale Into Strict Security
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 27The rape of a freshmen woman ntl a rash of petty thefts in the first three weeks of the new term at Yale University have prompted the most stringent security measures in recent years on the downtown campus here.

title: ART VIEW
description: For anyone with a sense of history, the new agreements between the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the French Government's Ministry of Cultural Affairsannounced in Paris on Sept. 16constitute an event rich in the ironies of national destiny. Between the art worlds of Paris and New York, there has long existed a complex network of very close relationships, at once esthetic, intellectual, economic and institutional. But the nature of these relationships has changed over the years, altered by the shifting strengths of cultural vitality, the vagaries of political fortune and the gyrations of the international art market.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: A team of French experimenters has turned, in effect, full circle. In an attempt to determine the true nature of globular, or ball, lightning, the French group has recreated, with 20century tools, Benjamin Franklin's fabled experiment with kite and key. They launched small rockets with long wires attached into stormy skies above the Massif Central, the great plateau region of central France. Like Franklin, the French attracted lightning.

title: It's Available, but the Price Has Declined
description: LONDONIn the view of European speculators, American consumers were so famished for gold last year, after a 40year ban on their owning it, that they would rush to buy it the moment they could.

title: Joint Bids Barred In Offshore Leases For Big Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI)  The Interior Department, in an effort to increase oil industry competition, has decided to stop letting major oil and gas producers make joint bids for Federal offshore drilling leases.

title: Living in a landmark
description: A rchitect John Stonehill and his wife, Judith, are the kind of concerned individuals who are preserving the texture of early Manhattan willingly, if unwittingly. Seven years ago, whentheir daughter was a toddler and their apartment on the upper East Side was beginning to feel cramped, they bought a small, red brick Federal row house in Greenwich Village a scant 12 hours after first setting eyes on it. It wasn't the house's landmark status that impressed them, nor was it the building's ambience, its associations with a gentler time and place. Rather, the row house reminded the Stonehills of their childhood, a remembrance that they wanted their own children, Alexandra, 9, and David, 5, to share. Reared in houses themselves, neither adult had ever felt comfortable living in an apartment where, in John's words, The problems go beyond the spaces to the question of arriving. You go through the lobby, then into the elevator and down the hall, and when you finally arrive at the door it's sort of a dead end.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 27 (UPI)Israeli soldiers today killed three Arab guerrillas who had infiltrated across the northern frontier from Lebanon, the military command said.

title: BESSIE BREUER, 81, NOVELIST, IS DEAD
description: Bessie Breuer, novelist and shortstory writer, died Friday at her home in New City, N. Y. she was 81 years old and was the widow of the artist Henry Varnum Poor.

title: College Drops Honor Code
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 (UPI) Undergraduates at Johns Hopkins University have aholished the school's 1913 honor code because they say it no longer inhibits cheating.

title: New Products
description: Securityminded homeowners and apartment dwellers who are looking for maximum security in their entrance door locks will he interested in an unusually strong lock called SUPERguard LOCK. Made by Ideal Security Hardware Corporation, 215 East Ninth Street, St. Paul, Minn. 55101, the lock is designed so that the inside and outside parts bolt to themselves, rather than being fastened to the door, so that the strength or construction of the door does not affect the security provided. No screws are exposed on the outside, and the cylinder is designed so it cannot be removed when the door is locked. Also the escutcheon plate cannot be ripped off. The lock is available in both single (key on the outside only) and double (key inside and outside) cylinder models. Prices range from $23 to $25.

title: Congress Expected to Hold Gun Curb to Saturday Night Specials
description: Any new gun control legislation that emerges from Congress this year will be limited to Saturday night specials, in the opinion of many gun control advocates.

title: Simpson, Steelers Clash Again Today
description: It is not every day that one can have a great football player in one's home for a couple of hours. Today is one of those days. On national television, O. J. Simpson About Pro Footballof the Buffalo Bills will run against Mean Joe Greene and those other notable Steelers in Pittsburgh. The game, with a 4 P.M. starting time, will be televised here over Channel 4 once the JetsChiefs contest is finished in Kansas City. If The Juice breaks one for a 65yard touchdown on his first carry from scrimmage and you miss it because the Chiefs and Jets are still flogging one another, write a letter to Carl Lindemann of NBC Sports.

title: loodplain Hearings to Start
description: TRENTONThe state's Department of Environmental Protection will begin a series of public hearings this week on regulations designed to control future development along the Delaware River between this city and Tocks Island.

title: Follow Up on The News
description: High school authorities in Drake, N. D., raided student lockers in November. 1973, and confiscated as profane all copies of Slaughterhouse Five, by Kurt Vonnegut Jr., and Deliverance, by James Dickey. Copies of the Vonnegut novel were burned. Deliverance was banned.

title: American Orchestras Are Back in the Recording Studios
description: One of the most notable recent developments in the recording industry is the growing presence on disk of many excellent American orchestrasnot superstar ensembles like Boston, Chicago, Clevieland, New York and Philadelphia, perhaps, but orchestras that are certainly equal in quality to many often  recorded European groups. Washington's National Symphony under Antal Dorarti and Mstislav Rostropovich and the Los Angeles Symphony with Zubin Mehta under contract to London.

title: The Charming Despot Behind the San Francisco Opera
description: SAN FRANCISCO The new season of the San Francisco Opera opened earlier this month with two of the biggest names in the world of operaJoan Sutherland and Luciano Pavarottisinging Il Trovatore. It was the first time the two had ever sung the opera together. Next month will find the renowned Soviet cellist Mstislay Rostropovich in the Bay City conducting his first opera in America (his second anywhere)  Tchaikowsky's Queen of Spades in RusSian, with his wife Galina Vishnevskaya in the lead. There will also be a new Gunther RennertRaymond Lepperd L'Incoronazione di Poppea and two ingenious new productions by JeanPierre Ponnelle. It is owing to such coups that the San Francisco Opera has won a reputation as second only to the Met in this country. And everyone agrees that the credit for that accomplishment goes to the rotund, energetic, irascible 70yearold Viennese dictator, named Kurt Herbert Adler, who has been the company's General Director for 22 years.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: BrooklynPhotographs by Abe Lerner, through October, weekdays, 9 A.M. to 9 P.M., Namm Hall Library, New York City Community College, 300 Jay Street.

title: Planners Push Jamaica El Razing
description: The City Planning Commission has approved an amendment to the capital budget that would facilitate demolition of the Jamaica Avenue elevate line east of Queens Boulevard.

title: O. G. Sexton Weds Barbara Haack
description: Barbara Ellen Haack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Haack of Potomac, Md., was married there yesterday afternoon to 0. Griffith Sexton, son of Mrs. John J. English of Bethesda, Md., and the late Comdr. 0. Griffith Sexton 3d, U.S.N., of Tampa. Fla.

title: For Shark Anglers, It Was a Whale of a Summer
description: BRIELLEIt never got to be as traumatic as Jaws, and the biggest thing around might have been only a threefootlong pup, but sharkfishing was a popular pastime off the Jersey coast this summer.

title: Barbara Rettig, J. V. McKee 3d Wed in Suburb
description: Barbara Allcne Rettig, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Rettig of Brookfield, Conn., and Naples. Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to Joseph Vincent McKee 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McKee Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

title: A Malpractice Issue Sparked Coma Case
description: MOPRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 27 A growing concern over medical malpractice litigation played a role in forcing into the courts and the public conscience the question of terminating extraordinary medical care for Karerf Anne Quinlan, the 21yearold woman who has been in a coma for five months.

title: INQUIRY EXPECTED TO CLEAR REBOZO
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27The Watergate special prosecutor's office will announce, probably next month, that it found insufficient evidence to warrant filing formal charges against Charles G. Rebozo, confidant and financial associate of former President Richard M. Nixon, sources familiar with the investigation said today.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: This Wednesday is the opening day of the ordering period for the fourth medal in the fivepiece series of official Mintstruck, Congressionally authorized commemorative medals from the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration. The A.R.B.A. is offering the 11/2inch medal (illustrated here) in bronze at $3.50 and in silver at $15. The maximum number of medals per order is three silver and four bronze and the ordering periods ends Oct. 31. Checks or money orders should be made payable to the A.R.B.A. and sent to P.O. Box 1976, San Francisco 94101. Orders will be processed on the customary first come, first served basis.

title: Louise Conklin Married on L.I.
description: Louise Cox Conklin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore B. Conklin Jr. of Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married there yesterday afternoon to Robert H. Stevens Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stevens, also of Westhampton Beach. The Rev. George W. Busier performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: Brown Is Headed. For Ivy Title Again
description: It appears that it will take another year before Brown's soccer domination in the Ivy League can be seriously threatened. Even with the eligibility of freshmen in soccer, News of Soccerwhich should help their opponents, the Bruins are strong and should take the title for the third year in a row.

title: Suspect and Three Customers Injured in Bank Robbery Here
description: A gunman attempting to escape after holding up a midtown branch of the Bowery Savings Bank yesterday was shot down by two Transit Authority policemen alerted to the scene by a customer.

title: KING or THE RING; Don King, a former numbers runner and convict (Murder 2) who quotes from Socrates and Galbraith, controls the heavyweight champand thus the game.
description: Don King is a large man whose Afro hairdo looks as though he's got his finger stuck in a light socket. Sartorially, he favors ruffles, spangles, sequins and velvettrimmed dinner jackets at midday. He has no especial gift for silence.

title: Breast Cancer
description: When the formerly unmentionable subject of mammary carcinoma finally got its day in the court of the media. shortly after the mastectomies of Betty Ford and Happy Rockefellerfar more was said about mutilation than about the fact that what is so terrifying about breast cancer, and ultimately more mutilating to the self than mastectomy, is not that a woman might have to face life without a breast (or even without two) but that she may not get a chance to face much life at all. Breast cancer develops in one out of every 15 American women. Of these, only 62 percent will survive the first five years even after surgical intervention. Another 12 per cent will fail to survive the next five years. Startlingly, these end results have not changed despite 45 years of surgical and medical advances.

title: TrafficControl System Set for Ports
description: The marine insurance industry expects considerable help in reducing vessel accidents and claims as, a result of new trafficcontrol systems being put into operation in major American ports.

title: Migrating Monarchs
description: Frost has come to rural fields and gardens and the fires of life burn low in the insect world. The bugs and beetles are nearing the end of their time. Crickets and katydids seem to sense it; when you hear them on a warm evening now there is a new sense of urgency in their calls. Bumblebees sleep late, sometimes in the shelter of tousled zinnia blossom, and wail for the sun to warm their blood enough so they can fly. Most butterflies have had their day and slumber as hostages to tomorrow in the egg, the cocoon or as caterpillars.

title: Both Class and Sass Prove EyeCatching
description: Maximilian furs have class, in much the same way as good royalty. Fendi furs have sass, in much the same way as show business. The one concentrates on suality and worlananhip, and leaves innovative styling to the nouveaux; the other is a collection where almost nothing is what it appears to be but is, nevertheless, effective, eyecatching and fun.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Although the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and the countries that import oil are locked in controversy, they agree in calling petroleum a natural resource. But both sides are wrong and.the oil importers make a capital error in accepting the term. Oil is not a gift of nature. In an economic sense, it is manmade.

title: Dayton Man. Indicted Earlier, Is Charged in 7 Slayings
description: DAYTON. Ohio, Sept. 27 (UPI)A Montgomery County grand jury indicted Neal Bradley Long yesterday for seven slavines dating to }972.

title: New Way of Breathing Taught
description: PARAMUSTake a deep breath, The chances are that your stomach muscles contracted as your chest cavity filled with air, which is the way you have been taught since your earliest exercise classes in kindergarten.

title: Headliners
description: The growing list of aspirants for the Democratic presidential nomination had still another name added to it last week: Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania. Governor Shapp, who was a businessman before entering politics, said he plans to base his campaign on the need for executive leadership and managerial skill in government. He said he plans to enter as many state Presidential primaries as possible. Most observers believe that the Shapp candidacy will be little more than a favoriteson campaign to enhance the importance of the Pennsylvania delegation at the 1976 convention. Governor Shapp is the eighth candidate to announce for the nomination he was preceded only eight days ago by Sargent Shriver, the Democratic VicePresidential candidate in 1972.

title: Ford Meets Chinese Group Of Scientists at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (Reuters)President Ford today met the highestranking scientific delegation from China ever to visit the United States.

title: A primer for renovators
description: But recession and rentiva, lion go together. For suburban families these days, it seems safer to hang on to that house whose mortgage is substantially paid off  and whose market value has increasedthan to make the emotional and monetary commitments demanded by building a new home. For urban families, the idea of a renovated brownstone with incomeproducing apartments takes on a special attractiveness.

title: New Providence Romps Over Berkeley Heights
description: Ted Blackwell, a junior yards and four touchdowns in 15 carries yesterday as New Providence, defending Group 2 champion, routed Berkeley Heights, 520, at New Providence.

title: Seminars Set for Nursing Home Officials
description: WEST ORANGETwo of Essex County's oldest institutions, Montclair State College and the Daughters of Israel Pleasant Valley Home, are offering a series of seminars for nursing home administrators and others involved in health care.

title: Louis Johnson: I Love DanceAny Kind of Dance
description: Very few blacks have had all the experiences I've had. There haven't been that many opportunities. I've performed and choreographed all kinds of dance, so that that's how I can go from Treemonisha to the Metropolitan Opera, says choreographer Louis Johnson, who created the much acclaimed dances for Scott Joplin's opera, Treemonisha and is about to become only the third black choreographer at the Met. Treemonisha came to New York this month after enthusiastic receptions in Houston and Washington, D.C.

title: CHESS
description: The most unexpected theoretical development of the year, the demolition of a main line of the Schliemann gambit defense to the Ruy Lopez, originated in an equally unexpected quarterJapan.

title: W. L. Van Alen Jr. to Wed Miss Guest
description: Virginia Guest, a descendant of the first Duke of Marlborough, and William L. Van Alen Jr., a descendant of John Jacob Astor, plan to be married in Washington on Oct. 18.

title: The Reserve Clause: Key in All Sports Is Control of Players Not Under Contract
description: Just what is this reserve clause and why is everyone suing, stewing and striking about it?

title: Brick 2 714 Victor For 12th in a Row
description: Mike Orenchuck, a senior fullback, plunged for touchdowns of 7 and 6 yards as Brick Township defeated Central Regional, 2714, in Bayville. It was the 12th consecutive victory for Brick.

title: City University Librarians Warn That Budget Cuts Will Sharply Curtail Their Services
description: Chief librarians throughout the City University system have warned that irreparable harm may be done to their libraries as a consequence of sharp reductions in staff, operating hours and acquisitioo of new materials, all resulting from budget cuts demanded by the Board of Higher Education.

title: Arapahoe Woman, 104, Dies
description: ETHETE, Wyo., Sept. 26 (UPI)Maggie Iron, who could recall being told of Custer's Last Stand, died Thursday. She was 104 years old, the oldest member of the Arapahoe tribe on the Wind River Reservation. I remember the news of the Custer battle on the Little Big Horn in 1876, she said in an interview last March. Mrs. Iron is survived by a daughter, 5 grandchildren, 11 greatgrandchildren and a greatgreatgrandchild.

title: Mich. State Routs N.C. State, 3715
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 27 (AP) Levi Jackson ran for three firstquarter touchdowns and Hans Nielsen kicked three field goals today as Michigan State capitalized on numerous North Carolina State mistakes and swamped the Wolfpack, 3715, in an interconference college football game.

title: TRISTATE AGENCY GIVES ROAD COST
description: The TriState Regional Planning Commission, in a new plan approved yesterday, estimated that $10.3billion would be needed for a modest expansion of this region's highway and public transport networks during the next five Years.

title: OPERA VIEW
description: The biggest surprise of the Bolshoi Opera's visit to New York last summer was the high quality of the company's singers. The largescale productions, the exceptional choral and orchestral work, the extraordinary sense of ensemble stylethese were all more or less anticipated, but not those voices. Russian singers, after all, have always had a bad press in the West, and most of them, particularly the sopranos, are generally brushed aside with cliches about the Slavic wobble. Of course the Bolshoi has its fair share of utilitarian or downright inferior artists, but on the whole the standards have improved astonishingly since the company last visited North America in 1967 at Montreal's Expo, and audiences were quick to single out their favorites tenor Vladimir Atlantov, baritone Yuri Mazurok, soprano Tamara Milashkina, mezzo Elena Obraztsova and bass Evgeni Nesterenko.

title: Victoria G. Hamburg Bride of John Peaslee
description: Victoria G. Hamburg Bride of John Peaslee

title: RUTH HUBBARD KNIGHT
description: Ruth Hubbard Knight, dean and counselor of women at San Francisco Theological Seminary from 1959 to 1969, died Friday at her home in Washington. She would have been 84 years old yesterday.

title: Holy Trinity Struggles To Down Mercy, 127
description: HICKSVILLE, L.I., Sept. 27 Holy Trinity, one of the top teams in the Catholic High Schools League last season. had to rally today to defeat a stubborn Mercy eleven from Riverhead. 127. It was a league opener for both teams.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
North Atlantic Show Opening
description: With flags and banners and a record fleet of more than 500, the fourth annual North Atlantic boat show opens Thursday for a fourday run at Yacht Haven West in Stamford, Conn. Billed as the world's largest inthewater show, it features 16foot daysailers to Chris Craft's luxurious 73foot motor yacht.

title: 6 Nations Recall Envoys From Spain Over Killings
description: LONDON. Sept. 27 (Reuters) The executions of five Spanish terrorists today provoked et bitter reaction in European governments, on European Streets and in the Vatican.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Boy fancy himself Eilert Lovborg, his mother fuss mightily over the suspicious books he's been reading, his editorfather find himself actually admiring Bernard Shaw his uncles and aunts and outraged neighbors parade their pompadours and their prejudices on a picnicking Fourth of July. The query in what does, or did, the play's strengths lie?

title: Cities: A Nitional Issue
description: President Ford a few days ago gave the mayors of some of the country's chief cities a political lecture lieu of economic aid. Their real difficulty, he advised them, was not so much with the Administration as was with Congress, which he knew from experience must be hostile to the idea of helping New York City In its present financial agony.

title: Confusion Of Loyalties
description: In recent days, we have had strikes of teachers in New York and many other places, of policemen in San Francisco, and of professional football players in Boston. Also, spectacular kidnappings, murders, demonstrations against busing and abortion, and two threats on the life of the President of the United States.

title: Endpaper
description: atale DeCarolis. 46, died on Monday, Aug. 25, in the cancer and tumor unit of Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: The Madness
description: For the second time within weeks, a gun has been pointed at President Ford while he was campaigning, and this time the weapon was fired. The President was not hit, but the extraordinary sequence of threats to Mr. Ford's life, and the circumstances of the latest incident, have raised anew some painful questions.

title: Culture Shock: Williamsburg & Disney World, Back to Back
description: THEY blur in my memory, history and fantasy, now that the trip done. Let me try to sort it out: The Governors Palace, with its magnificent maze, is in Williamsburg, Va., but Cinderella's Castle, with its mosaic mural, is in Walt Disney World, Fla. The King's Arms Tavern is in the Colonial capital, but the Liberty Tree Tavern is in the Magic Kingdom. The Blue Bell is in Virginia, along with the Sign of the Rhinoceros, and Tinkerbell's in Florida, along with Dumbo, the Flying Elephant. The cradle of democracy blends with the height of imagination, and every day through September, 1976, America on Parade, a spectacular Bicentennial salute, marches straight down not Duke of Gloucester Street in Williamsburg but Main Street, U.S.A., in the heart of Disney World. And there, at the head of the parade, bearing drum and fife and Betsy Ross's original pennant, dressed in tricorner hat and patched with bandages, stand the three symbols of the American Revolution: Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck and Goofy.

title: Hunt Says Oil Fortune Was the Key To Acquittal on Wiretapping Charges
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 27Nelson Bunker Hunt, the Dallas oilman, said last night that a huge fortune was the key to the acquittal of him and his brother, W. Herbert Hunt. in Federal Court yesterday of wiretapping charges.

title: Lehigh's Late Rally Subdues Penn, 3423
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 27 Lehigh scored three touchtowns the fourth quarter today and defeated Pennsylvania in football, 3423.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: MAXIM GORKI, Black Sea. Lett St. Thomas Sept. 26; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: Fry's Version Reopens at Gramercy Arts
description: Jean Anoilh's world is one of prettiness and parables, all delicacy and inconsequence. In 1950, when the French playwright's ('Ring Round the Moon was adapted by Christopher Fry, it brought a naughty touch of Parisian opulence to the somewhat drabber theatrical scenes of London and New York.

title: Katharine Tarbox, Bank Aide, Wed
description: Katharine Riggs Tarbox, an account officer with the First National City Bank, was married yesterday to Jeremy Miles Ferguson Warner, an assistant vice president. The Rev. Laurance McColl Horton performed the ceremony in the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien. Conn.

title: Ohio State Wins 500th, 327
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 27 (AP)  Pete Johnson scored a school record five touchdowns, and Archie Griffin became Ohio State's career rushing leader today, leading the secondranked Buckeyes to their 500th college football victory, a 327 rout of North Carolina.

title: Speaking Is Taught To Deaf Children
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The affliction is silence. It creates a world where birds do not sing, laughter is not heard and music does not play.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: The weekend golfer often fails to finish what he starts with his swing, which costs him distance and possibly accuracy. The ??? player doesn't accelerate the club in the hitting area; he hits to the ball instead of through it.

title: Soviet Leads U.S. in Will to Pursue Strategy, ExIntelligence Aide Contends
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27The Soviet Union has twice the strategic purpose and will to pursue national strategy of the United States, according to Ray S. Cline, a retired American intelligence official who has devised a mathematical formula to support his thesis.

title: A Grenadian Lament: Where Have All Those Tourists Gone?
description: GRENADA is the most southerly of the Windward Islands, washed by the Atlantic and the Caribbean, ventilated by the trade winds and situated safely beyond the hurricane belt. It boasts a friendly, generally integrated population, a wide range of accommodations, spectacular gopography and reliable sunshine. Then why last December were there fewer than a dozen white Americans on our flight? And during Christmas week, how come the Grenadian beaches were as deserted as Fire Island in November?

title: Humor Workshop Planned by College
description: TOMS RIVERHave sense of humor? Want to develop it more? Hope to make it pay off in a career in comedy?

title: Symposium Is Set on Weight Control
description: SOMERVILLE  A statewide symposium on Weight Control for Children and Adolescents will be held Oct. 15 at the Redwood Inn. Physicians, dieticians, nurses and other health professionals concerned with childhood obesity are invited to attend. The symposium will include a perspective of the complexity of the problem, a look at behavior modification and a report on a successful school program in weight control.

title: New Oil Opportunity
description: With restoration of price controls on almost twothirds of domestic oil output now assured until Nov. 15 by concurrence of President Ford and Congress, another opportunity has been gained to negotiate an agreed energy policy that can meet the nation's immediate needs. It a brief opportunity and it must not be missed.

title: Sun Comes Out, but Rain Did Millions in Damage
description: Sushine graced the sodden metropolitan area for the first time in five days yesterday as homeowners and publicworks crews struggled with flooded basements, clogged sewers, disrupted utilities and other remnants of the worst rainstorm here in years.

title: Lawyers Ethics in An Adversary System
description: Last August, the Committee on Professional Ethics of the New York State Bar Association addressed the following question: Does a lawyer who regularly fails to respond to telephone calls from his clients as course of conduct act improperly? The Committee provided an official answer yes and thereby provided further evidence to support the proposition that the subject of legal ethics is only slightly less boring than, say, Bulgarian linguistics.

title: Seychelles Islands Move Easily To Independence From Britain
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar, Sept. 27 (Agence FrancePresse) The Seychelles Islands, destined to become an independent member of the Commonwealth within a year, are heading for independence from Britain without any of the rancor and bitterness other countries have experienced.

title: McMenemy's Kick Beats Wagner for Post, 17 to 14
description: Tom McMenemy's 22yard field goal with 47 seconds remaining in the third quarter proved to be the difference as C. W. Post College defeated Wagner, 1714, in football yesterday.

title: American
description: Country huntboard reproduction has a scrolled apron, beaded edges on drawers and yew veneers. Drawers are fitted with silver liners and lochs. WA inches long, 36 inches high. By Wright. $1.035. Lord & Taylor.

title: 2 Firsts for a Prosecutor
description: TRENTON  She is said to be not only the first woman in the country to serve as a county prosecutor, but also the first black woman to fill such a post.

title: The Economy Is Spawning CollegeEducated Servants
description: When a West Side couple advertised recently for a warm, intelligent person to look after their two small children because the wife, a graduate of Sarah Lawrence, was going back to work, the very first applicant was a graduate of Sarah Lawrence. Within a few hours another Sarah Lawrence graduate applied.

title: Greek Fete in Clifton
description: CLIFTON  The annual Greek Festival at St. George's Greek Orthodox Church, 811 Valley Road, will be held Thursday through Sunday. There will be Greek food and wine, a boutique, entertainment and Greek dancing: Hours are 7 P.M. to midnight on Friday, 11 A.M. to midnight on Saturday and 12:30 to 8 P.M. next Sunday. The price of admission is 50 cents.

title: Letters
description: In his fine article, Conspiracy to the left of us! Paranoia to the right of us! (Aug. 24), Mark Harris points out that the rights of labor, the rights of women, the rights of the aged, the rights of children, the rights of the insane and the rights of all living creatures were always first the lamentations of nuts and outcasts before they became the judicious opinions of responsible people.

title: Box Scores of Major League Games
description: Box Scores of Major League Games

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The article by Reginald H. Jones, Chairman of the General Electric Company ('Why Congress Should Not Kill the DISC, Aug. 31) is a good rebuttal el the attacks recently waged against the DISC.

title: Exeter Routs Choate, 266, as Buckley Stars
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., Sept. 27Exeter crushed Choate, 266, today as Brian Buckley had a hand (and an arm) in all the scoring for Exeter.

title: U.N. Refugee Official Signs Aid Agreement With Hanoi
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 27 (UPI) Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, left Hanoi today after concluding an aid agreement with the North Vietnamese Government, the Vietnam press agency said.

title: How Much Security for How Much Surveillance and Detention?
description: WASHINGTONIn the summer of 1969 the Secret Service issued liaison guidelines to major police departments and some Federal agencies, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency, on the kind of intelligence data it needed for the protection of the President and other high officials.

title: The World
description: Just when it seemed that Portugal might emerge from political chaos, following formation of a new Government that took heed of the electoral strengths of civilian political parties, a new area of tension has developed. The broad agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union to limit strategic offensive weaponsan accord announced nearly a year ago with considerable fanfarehas not yet been reduced to a working document. Although to many Americans the state of the United States economy is not good, the view from overseas of the dollar is much different. Last week the dollar rose to its highest level this year in relation to other currencies. The result (also influenced by a fall in the price of gold) was that the British pound tumbled and South Africa devalued Rd nonetary unit, the rand. Five young Spanish terrorists have been executed by firing s'suad; as a result the Franco regime is faced with protest disturbances, and expressions of outrage from around the world.

title: All Weighs 224  To Frazier's 215
description: MANILA, Sept. 27The physical weight of Muhammad All and Joe Frazier, and the emotional weight of the champion's marital dispute dominated the countdown today for their world heavyweight title fight, which will be shown in the United States at closedcircut television locations Tuesday night. (The battle is scheduled to start at 10:35 P.M., New York time.)

title: When the Sheiks Sang the Depression Blues
description: The Sheik, that mysterious, burnooseclad prince of the desert, has long been a fascinating figure in American mythology. Nowadays Sheiks are owners of vast petroleum reserves and have become somewhat demystified in the process of losing fortunes at the gaming tables of Monte Carlo, but 50 years ago Sheikdom was a fashionable nevernever land, peopled with Valentinos who rode like the wind and always on the lookout for swooning damsels.

title: City Council Hearings Scheduled This Week
description: The following public hearings will be held by City Council committees this week.

title: The family of a man and the family of man
description: It's not exactly common, in recent years, to run across a clearly firstrate novel that traces the generations of a family. The last really good ones, if memory serves, were Wallace Stegner's Big Rock Candy Mountain and John Cheever's two Wapshot books. There are all sorts of reasons such novels don't get written, and one way of dramatizing Larry Woiwode's achievement in his huge new novel, Beyond the Bedroom Wall, is to spell out some of those reasons.

title: For young readers
description: So in this volume Will Stanton continues on his quest for the Signs that will complete the downfall of the Dark. This is the fourth in a projected series of five that tell of the struggle for power between the Light, a force for good embodied in a group of immortals called The Old Ones, and the Dark, which has a number of faces. This time he goes to Wales  from his home in Buckinghamshire to stay with a cousin, and meets there an albino boy named Bran and his white dog Cafall. Together they find the golden harp which will wake the Six Sleepers; and thus the Grey King, one of the faces of the Dark, is vanquished.

title: E. W. Scripps Company Elects a New President
description: Edward W. Estlow, general business manager of the ScrippsHoward Newspapers, has been elected president of the parent E. W. Scripps Company, effective Jan. 1, by the company's directors.

title: Nebraska Victor in 5614 Rout
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 27 (AP)  Terry Luck tossed three touchdown passes to lead fourthranked Nebraska to a 5614 victory over Texas Christian University today.

title: FloodDamaged Autos Need Prompt Attention
description: The American Insurance Association advised owners of flooddamaged cars yesterday that their vehicles could he restored In operating order if they acted suickly.

title: STATE EASES RULES ON AID FOR ELDERLY
description: New York State has liberalized income eligibility in programs for the elderly in its final plan for use of Federal aid for social services in the year starting Wednesday. At the same time it delayed the start of means tests until April 1.

title: Wilda Justice Is Bride of W. D. Haden 3d
description: Wilda Susan Justice, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Theodore Justice of Paramus, N. J., was married yesterday noon to William Dandridge Haden 3d, an architect, whose parents are Dr. and Mrs. Haden Jr. of Charlottesville. Va.

title: Russians to Assist Thailand In Development of Shale Oil
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 27 (AP)The Government has accepted a Soviet offer of technical help in the extensive development of shale oil it is planntng, a Foreign Ministry spokes. man has reported.

title: Bartering Is Back, Spurred by Oil Trauma
description: VIENNA  Following the 400 per cent increase in oil prices and the oil embargo ordered at the end of 1973, many oilconsumer countries rushed into bilateral contracts with oil  exporting countries to assure ade'suate and reasonable supplies.

title: Food News
description: COLTS NECKHe may be the only migrating beekeeper in New Jersey, but Arthur H. Barth, proprietor of the Colts Neck Honey Shop on Route 537. contends there is no better way to take advantage of the Garden State's flowering honey sources.

title: Slain Over No Money
description: A 54yearold Orthodox Jew whose religion forbade him to carry money on the Sabbath was shot to death in Brooklyn after he explained to a holdup man that he was carrying no cash. Page 43.

title: ARCHIE ROBBINS
description: Archie Robbins, a standup comedian, died Friday in Beth Israel Hospital. He Was 62 years old and lived at 330 East 58th Street.

title: In This Issue
description: PICTURE CREDITS

title: California Pianist Captures L. I. Contest
description: GREAT NECKFor once, the judges had no difficulty reaching a verdict.

title: Francesca Paolozzi Is Fiancee of Carlos Padilla
description: Hrancesca Pa??? a New York jewelry designer and daughter of Count and Countess Lorenzo Paolozzi of Rome and New York, plans to be married next May to Carlos Padilla, a furniture designer here.

title: Child to Mrs. Dickinson
description: A daughter was born Aug. 29 to Dr. and Mrs. Richard A. Dickinson of St. Albans, Vt., in the Kerbs Memorial Hospital there. The child has been named Grace George. Mrs. Dickinson is the former Lynn Sullivan of Cross River, N. Y.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Citing the need to cut uneconomic fuel consumption, the Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it would move to eliminate electric rate discounts for quantity users. The P.S.C. said the rule of use more but pay less will be discontinued for residential and small commercial customers unless reduced rates were justified by lower costs. Expert testimony will be demanded, the commission said, to prove cost justification for any discount rates.

title: Doria Martinelli Is Married Here
description: The marriage of Doris Martinelli, advertising manager of Henri Bendel, to Philippe de La Chapelle, a lawyer with W. R. Grace & Co., took place here yesterday afternoon.

title: Russian's Hopes Raised
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (AP)Aleksandr Sokolov, whose Austrian fiance, has been barred from returning to this country for their marriage, said today that he expects to be allowed to go to Austria and he married there. The writer said that passport officials had invited him to their offices Monday. Chancellor Bruno Kreisky appealed in a letter Thursday to the Communist party leader, Leonid D. Brezhnev, to make the marriage possible fer humanitarian considerations.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE FIRST CASUALTY, by Phillip Knightley. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $12.95.) A narrative account, by a London Sunday Times reporter, of the correspondent's role as hero, propagandist and myth maker, in wars from the Crimea to Vietnam; it Is truth, he conchub.% that always bites the dust first.

title: SAIGON'S CURRENCY ON PAR WITH HANOI
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 27 (Agence FrancePresse) In introducing a new currency this week, South Vietnam's revolutionary rulers made it equivalent in value to that of North Vietnam.

title: Winning Verse Selected For Rhodesian Anthem
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 27 (Reuters)Ten years after declaring independence, Rhodesia at last has a national anthem.

title: Sophomore Leads Irish To Victory
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 27 (AP)With Joe Montana, a sophomore, giving seventhranked Notre Dame the spark it needed at quarterhack, the Irish broke loose for a 317 victory over Northwestern today in Coach Dan Devine's debut in Notre Dame Stadium.

title: City Specifies Quality Goals in Housing
description: In the face of a bleak outlook for new construction and considerable opposition on the part of many developers and architects, the city's planners have decided to make their new residential zoning proposils elective rather than mandatory, as originally conceived.

title: Peru's New President Faces Diverse Economic Pressures
description: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 27A month after taking power in a bloodless coup, Gen. Francisco Morales Bermudez, the new President of Peru, is facing economic pressures that have led both leftists and conservatives to believe that there will be either an increase in state control over the coonomy or an attempt to stimulate private enterprise and investment.

title: TENANTS PRAISE HARLEM HOUSES
description: Thirtyeight years ago, Nixcola Ramsay moved from her congested apartment on Manhattan Avenue, which she shared with several people to help pay the rent, into the Harlem River Houses as one of its first carefully screened tenants.

title: Profit from pleasure
description: O riental rugs and carpets offer a unique form of investment. What else can he used to complement nearly all decorating schemes and give constant enjoyment to their owners while more likely than not increasing in value? Two years ago, at a Sotheby ParkeBernet auction of rugs and carpets, a Heriz silk rug, 5 feet 2 inches by 3 feet 10 inches, fetched $7,500. If it had been offered this year, it would surely have brought between $12,000 and $15,000. Last year, at the same gallery, a fine but small Hereke silk and metalthread prayer rug, 3 feet by 4 feet 1 inch, sold for a staggering $16,0130more than $1,300 a square foot.

title: Washington Tightens Its WagePrice Focus
description: WASHINGTON.The Government has a new chief monitor of prices and wages and a new, tougher line on price rises. The new chief is Michael H. Moskow, a 37yearold economist who has on the job two weeks as director of the President's Council on Wage and Price Stability. In his initial appearance as a Congressional witness last week, he unveiled the new view, one that has been developing within the council's staff over a period of months, particularly in its handling of steel and aluminum.

title: Jew Carrying No Funds on Sabbath Slain in Holdup
description: A 54yearold Orthodox Jew whose religion forbids him to carry money on the Sabbath was shot to death Friday night in Brooklyn after he explained to a holdup man he was carrying no funds.

title: Women Find SelfService Bouti'sue Can Mean a Little Dab Will Do Them
description: PARAMUS  Selfservice cosmetic boutiques are emerging in the state, tempting their potential customers with gleaming displays of glossy lipstick; pastel eye shadows and creamy rouges.

title: Rain Is the Top Performer in Rockland
description: A 50yard passplay from Paul Tortora to George SI. Lawrence accounted for the only touchdown scored in the county yesterday as weeklong rains forced post ponement of two games and reduced a fourth to a scoreless tie in the mud.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: When two anglers go forth there is always at least a slight sense of competition, although as one grows older this tends to fade.

title: Miss McPartland, Bobby Short Are Both Stompin' at the Carlyle
description: The Madison Avenue entrance to the Carlyle Hotel, jttst above 76th Street, is awash with music these evenings. OM the foyer on one side, Bobby Short has started his ninth year of singing and playing piano in the Cafe Carlyle. And across the way, in the Bemelmans Bar, Marian McPartland. who opened that room to jazz ,last winter, when she ohiected to sharing the Cafe Carlyle with the group called Manhattan Transfer, has returned for a second season.

title: Do I Hear Two Million On the Left?
description: Three minutes before he opened the fall season earlier this month at Parke Bernet, the nation's most prestigious auction gallery, John Marion, the firm's 41yearold president, strode into the sales room. Tall and slender, with looks only slightly less chiseled than John Lindsay's, Marion got smiles from the ladies who hoped to pick up a bargain and even from the dealers, He stopped to chat with old Willis, an usher who had been the sharpest of all bid spotters, able to interpret the flicker of an eyelid, back when Louis Marion, John's father, was in his own prime as an auctioneer here.

title: School Bells Ring for Gardeners,
description: Plant care, flower arranging, propagation, flower painting, nature study and landscape design are a few of the courses on gardening open to the public and offered by botanic gardens, arboretums and garden centers.

title: Borden town Lists House Tour Oct. 5
description: BORDENTOWNThe long history of Bordentown, from the 17th century to the present will be capsuled into a single afternoon next Sunday, when the Bordentown Historical Society will sponsor an openhouse tour of 13 homes and places of interest. The admission price of $3 includes tea at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. John Prynoski.

title: Late Tennessee Score Conquers Auburn, 2117
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 27 (AP)  Randy Wallace threw two touchdown passes to Larry Seivers as 16th ranked to Larry Seivers as 16th ranked Tennessee beat Auburn, 2117, today in a Southeastern Conference football game.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor.

title: Title Fight At 55 Sites On TV Here
description: A total of 55 locations in the Metropolitan area will carry the closedcircuit color telecast of the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier world heavyweight title from Manila, the Philippines, on Tuesday night, under the promotion of Don King Productions, Inc.

title: Class Scheduled For Babysitters
description: SUMMIT  Be a Better Babysitter, a course for youngsters of junior high school age, will be offered at the Y.W.C.A., starting Thursday. The course will deal with many aspects of babysitting, such as child behavior, how to handle minor injuries, what to do in case of a fire, caring for newborns and the expectations of both parents and the sitter.

title: Ban of Church Groups From Public Schools Will Be Appealed
description: EAST BRUNSWICKThe Board of Education here has been given a year in which to phase out a regulation permitting church groups to use publicschool facilities for educational and religious purposes.

title: Nuptials Held For P. L. Wilkie And Miss Smith
description: Elizabeth McKean Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Somers Smith of Villanova, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Lex Wilkie in Old St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa. The Rev. Richard Hess performed the ceremony.

title: BRIDGE
description: Psychic opening bids are out of fashion nowadays. Two decades ago they were common enough and were even integral parts of some systems such as RothStone They achieved a few striking successes, but their practitioners eventually decided that they lost more on the swings  big swings  than they gained on the roundabouts.

title: Home traditions
description: Left Cotton fabric has on overall squiggle print in beige and white. CalledGibbweed. it's 48 inches wide. $9.50 per yard. & Vice Versa.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: I t is just about 10 years ago that I arrived in New York to become dance critic of The New York Times. Our ship docked on Sept. 14, I went into the office for the first time as a staff member on Sept. 15, and the paper went on strike on Sept. 16.

title: Library in Paterson Sets Sunday Series
description: PATERSON  Something for Everyone is the theme of a series of programs to be offered by the Paterson Public Library, 250 Broadway.

title: Facts in Musicians Strike
description: Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. I. Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.

title: The Challenge Beyond Nihilism
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27There are fleeting moments when the public scene recalls the Weimar Republic of 932.33.

title: Athens Will Tear Down Junta Investigation Site
description: ATHENS, Sept. 27 (Reuters)The Greek Government has decided to demolish the Athens military police building, which became notorious during seven years of military dictatorship.

title: Memorial Services
description: MILNERLucille B. Memorial, services In honor of Lucille 8. Milner, a founder of lite American Civil Liberties Union, affil be held on Sept. 28, 1975, a P.M., at Umversalist Church, Central Park West at 76th St., New York City. In lieu of flowers, please sent contributions to the A.C.L.U. or an organization of your choice.

title: The Case of Redford vs. the C.I.A.
description: Three Days of the Condor has everything, and one thing too many, wherein alas lies its chic. But for the terminal protuberance, we would have an expertly directed, trimly jigsawed, adequately acted spysuspense story which catches the viewer with the opening scene: What can that mysterious man in The parked car be about, checking off the names, one by one, of the halfdozen people as they saunter into the American Literary Historical Society on Manhattan's East Side to begin a day's work? Why, what he is doing is making sure there's a full house, because at lunchtime, he and his accomplices are goinginto that staid old building to shoot them all down in cold blood, made colder by the special ice pellets used at least, that is one inference by specially designed carnagemachines.

title: From The Dead Father
description: The Dead Father plodding along, at the end of his cable. His long golden robes. His long gray hair to the shoulder. His broad and noble brow.

title: Behind Bayonne Strike: Fiscal Problems
description: BAYONNE  Six months ago, when Chuck Wepner, the local boxing hero, furiously and vainly fought to wrest the heavyweight title from Muhammad Ali, the residents here smiled sadly but proudly. Now there's a different kind of struggle going on and nobody is smiling.

title: Oilfield Barges Slip Through Ice Off Alaska After 2Month Delay
description: PRUDHOE BAY, Alaska, Sept. 27  After being blocked for two months by the worst Arctic icing conditions since, 1898, a massive convoy of barges carrying vital cargo for development of Alaska's North Slope oil fields began to pass around Point Barrow today and headed for the oil fields at Dnirihne Bay.

title: runny money is serious
description: A few years ago, to deal with the nation's socalled welfare mess, President Nixon proposed a Family Assistance Plan that provided a guaranteed income for the nation's poor. It offered cash grants to establish an income floor for the jobless and for the first time, cash supplements for millions of working families whose incomes fall below or just above the poverty line. Many welfare reformers considered this income supplement provision crucial, for it seemed the only hope for families caught in the familiar welfare trapsince welfare benefits decline as a family begins to earn its own income, the head of a family receiving substantial welfare benefits can see no advantage in getting off welfare by taking a lowpaying job.

title: In Memoriam
description: SUCKBernard L. Lovingly remembered today, on your birthday, and always.

title: STUDY CRITICIZES SCHOOL UNIT HERE
description: A state audit releaded yesterday charged that a Bronx school district had, with Board of Education approval, committed itself to longterm leasing of additional school space involving a future expenditure of more than $2.2million despite a declining pupil enrollment.

title: Linda Ronstadt Reprieve for Prisoner in Disguise
description: Linda Ronstadt, at age 29 and the owner of one of the major pop voices, has spent the greater part of her decade long career singing beautifullydespite poor album production, recurring crises of confidence, and the alltoofamiliar problems of being a woman in an industry controlled by the decisions of men.

title: PLAN COMPLETED FOR CENTRAL PARK
description: Rianning work has been cornpleted on an elaborate and con. trover s al $2.5million plan foi the rehabilitation of the southeast corner of Central Park, the park's most heavily usec section. But the plan may not go ahead because of the city': financial crisis and the resignation Monday of Edwin L. Weis Jr. as Administrator of Parks. Recreation and Cultural Afairs.

title: Culture Haven: Boston's Venetian Art Palace, Inside Out
description: IF you're short on travel money, you might consider taking in Venice vicariously this year by visiting the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston. It is the nearest thing in America to a Venetian palazzoexcept for the fact that it is turned inside out. Coming upon it in the Fenway, Boston's reclaimed marshes (or fens), you might not look twice at the Gardner. When it was being built in great secrecy in 1901, some onlookers thought it was intended as a brewery or warehouse. But inside it is a Venetian palace such as doges dreams were probably made of, clustered in a pillared, archwayed quadrangle around an inner courtyard.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: 9 ARE HELD HOSTAGE BY LONDON GUNMEN
description: LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 28 (Reuters)At least two youths brandishing sawedoff shotguns stormed into a restaurant in London's Knightsbridge district early today and grabbed about nine hostages.

title: POWERLINE LINK TO RADIATION SEEN
description: A Stantord University scientist believes he and his colleagues have found evidence that radiofre'suency oscillations from power lines on earth are exerting significant control over the radiation belts that envelop the planet.

title: Wendy Sletteland Wed to Norman Macbeth 3d
description: Wendy Anne Sletteland daughter of Kathleen Troast Pitney of Mendham, N. J., and the late Trygve B. Sletteland, was married early last evening to Norman Macbeth 3d, an assistant vice president of the First National City Bank, where the bride is with the international services division.

title: College Scores
description: College Scores

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Letters to The Editor
description: To the Editor: Because they were usually in groups, the billboards of yesteryear tended to provide a scattershot impression. Half a dozen or more cheekbyjowl are necessarily less memorable, as are the commercials that follow one another at the halfway point in hourlong television programs.

title: Swollen Sus'suehanna Surges Past Frightened WilkesBarre
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Sept. 27The swollen Sus'suehanna] River surged menancingly but safely past this frightened. sandbagged city today and headed relentlessly south. Downstream, Harrisburg braced for heavy flooding.

title: City Hall Reported Ready To Fight Charter Revision
description: The Beame administration is preparing to oppose publicly revision of the City Charter, a high administration official said yesterday as he added his gloomy note to a growing pessimism over the fate of the proposed Charter changes at the polls on Nov. 4.

title: REP. PIKE ACCUSES INTELLIGENCE ARM OF FAILING IN DUTY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The chairman of the House Select Committee on Intelligence said today that the United States security agencies had become such unwieldy bureaucracies that the country might not be warned in advance of an unexpected attack.

title: Clarinetist Weds Jane Bassewitz
description: Jane Bassewitz, a specialeducation teacher with the Board of Education, was married here yesterday afternoon to Jerome Samuel Bunke, a clarinetist and recording artist.

title: An Astronaut Complains Of Mobs on Soviet Trip
description: VOLGOGRAD, U.S.S.R., Sept. 28 (UPI)  Five American and Soviet spacemen who linked up in Earth orbit in July are getting so mobbed wherever they stop on a goodwill tour of the Soviet Union that one of the Aniericans complained about it today.

title: Federal Aid for Westchester Is Sought After Flood Damage Tops $20Million
description: Preliminary estimates of flood damage in Westchester County in the wake of last week's rains were put at $20million to $30million yesterday by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, who said he had asked for state and Federal declarations of disasterarea status to make aid available to affected homes and businesses.

title: Algren Decides to Live in Paterson
description: PATERSON, N. J., Sept. 28Nelson Algren, the novelist, moved here last December for what was supposed to be a brief visit to research and write a magazine story on the CarterArtis murder case.

title: The American Crocodile Is on Endangered List
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (Reuters)  The American crocodile, the rarest reptile in the United States, and five other North American species have been declared endangered, the Fish and Wildlife Service announced yesterday. It said only 10 to 20 breedfemale crocodiles were known to exist.

title: Despite Setbacks, Carter Hopes for Freedom
description: One year ago even, the most skeptical of convicts at the Trenton State Prison predicted that Rubin (Hurricane) Carter soon would be a free man.

title: F15 Test Pilot Honored
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 28 (UPI)The pilot of the McDonnell Aircraft Company who performed the crucial spin tests on the Air Force's new F15 fighter has been named test pilot of the year by the Society of Experimental Test Pilots. John E. Krings was given the 1975 Iven C. Kincheloe award in ceremonies at the Beverly Hilton Hotel last night.

title: Personal Finance
description: A woman purchased a hairdryer at a department store and within six months the casing split under heat. When she returned the dryer, she was told that its warranty covered only internal parts.

title: Seldom Active Senate Unit Drew $2Million in Decade
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Among the 299 subcommittees of Congress is an obscure Sen ate group named the Subcommittee on Immigration and Naturalization, which apparently has not held a formal meeting in a decade although over $2million has been authorized for its operations. The word apparently is obligatory since the records of Congress are sometimes written small and there is no complete score of meeting dates of committees and subcommittees.

title: Spanish Police Shoot Six In Basque Demonstration
description: MADRID, Sept. 28Civil guards opened fire today on a crowd of Basque demonstrators in Algorta, an industrial suburb of Bilbao, wounding at least six persons.

title: ATLANTIC FISHING WILL BE REDUCED
description: MONTREAL. Sept. 28 (AP)An international commission on Atlantic fishing agreed today to a Canadian proposal that would cut foreign fishing off the Canadian coast by 40 per cent.

title: For Which We Stand
description: BOSTON, Sept. 28The House of Representatives has been reformed: So we read earlier this year. New members have driven the dinosaurs from power and brought a spirit of reason into that once cynical place. The House can at last play its rightful part in making national policy.

title: Policemen, Firemen Back After 6Day Tucson Strike
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 28 (AP) A sixday strike by 90 per cent of the city's policemen and firemen ended today as a bitter and divided City Council approved, 43, a pay raise agreement. The agreement will give policemen sergeant rank and above, firemen from captain upwards, and other city employes in administrative jobs an immediate 7.5 per cent raise.

title: Egyptian Tells of Flights
description: CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 28 (AP)  Egyptian pilots have testflown the Americanmade Phantom jet fighter, backbone of Israel's air force, Vice President Hosni Mobarak said in an interview with the Cairo daily At Okhbar yesterday. Mr. Mobarak, a former air force commander, said Egyptian pilots had familiarized themselves with the aircraft in a friendly country, presumably Iran.

title: Big Week for Gays
description: WASHINGTONHow do you thank an alleged homosexual for saving the life of a President just after a military panel decides that homosexuals are unfit to protect the nation by serving in the armed forces?

title: Black Caucus Fund Dinner Becomes 2Day Affair
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Five years ago, the Congressional Black Caucus held its first fundraising event herea wellattended dinner, the proceeds of which were used to establish and operate a caucus office.

title: Coaches Say East's Elevens Show Most Improvement
description: Syracu'e, West Virginia, Pittsburg, Navy and some other Eastern college football teams are enjoying such unexpected earlyseason success that there is a promise of something other than the annual oneteam runaway by Penn State.

title: STEPHEN J. WEXLER
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 28 (AP)Stephen J. Wexler, chief counsel for the Senate education subcommittee since 1969, was killed here yesterday in a motorcycle accident. He was 40 years old.

title: National Football League Roundup
description: second straight triumph as Ken Anderson passed for three touchdowns, two to Isaac Curtis. Anderson, the N. F. L.'s leading passer last season, connected on 17 of. 21 aerials for 203 yards in three quarters of play. The Saints never penetrated beyond Cincinnati's 20yard line and were booed by a crowd of 52,531 most of the second half.

title: The Rev. Adrian Hebert, 59. Of St. Jean Baptiste's, Dies
description: The Rev. Adrian Hebert, former pastor of St. Jean Baptiste's Roman Catholic Church, Lexington Avenue and 76th Street, and former Episcopal vicar of the upper East Side, died of cancer Thursday in Lewiston, Me. He was 59 years old.

title: DAIRY UNIT AIDED BY RULING ON FUND FOR VOTER DRIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28The Federal Election Commission has issued a ruling that strengthens the political arm of Associated Milk Producers, Inc., which has been involved in numerous violations of campaign spending laws.

title: Airing the Candidates
description: By modifying the equal time rule for political candidates, the Federal Commmunications Commission has placed great trust in the courage and professionalism of the networks. It remains to be seen how effectively the broadcasterswho are licensed by the Federal Governmentcan stand up to the pressure and challenge. They do not have a notable record for resisting pressure for favored treatment from the White House or from Congressmen in strategic positions. Even at best it is extremely difficult to maintain an equitable balance as between incumbents and their challengers, especially those from minor parties.

title: Stunts and Space Liven 12th AvantGarde Fete
description: Charlotte Moorman has been putting on her AvantGarde Festivals of New York for 12 years, nowthe latest took place Saturday from 1 P.M. to midnightbut she didn't really call attention to lerself until the midnineteensixties, as the topless lady cellist beloved of the tabloids.

title: U.S. Begins Drive for Radio Personnel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The White House Office of Telecommunications Policy declared yesterday that a potential emergency existed in managing radio frequencies and instituted a governmentwide campaign to recruit and train personnel.

title: Doctor Who Runs Chain of Dialysis Centers Trying, With a State Senator's Aid, to Get a City Contract
description: A doctor who operates a series of more than 40 highly profitable kidney dialysis centers across the country has been trying with the help of an influential State Senator to take over from the city's municipal hospital system the more lucrative care of kidney patients, leaving the city with only the more complicated, costly cases.

title: France Opens First Drive on Smoking
description: PARIS, Sept. 28In the lobby of the Ministry of Health, a dummy dressed in blue denim, his plastic chest bared to expose brownstained paper lungs, puffs a Gauloise cigarette and emits a mechanical but horrific rasping cough.

title: Rise in EastBloc Troops Is Noted
description: VIENNA, Sept. 26  Despite a steady modernization and strengthening of the 925,000man Warsaw Pact ground force in Central Europe, Western experts here believe the situation is not a cause for alarm.

title: Bus Lines Escalate Fight Over Who Gets Subsidies
description: Amtrak. It's a vicious circle. Every time it comes around it costs us another $1billion, and still it's going nowhere.

title: Catholics at U. N. Will Commemorate Pope's 1965 Visit
description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., Sept. 28Roman Catholics in the United Nations will commemorate this week the visit here by Pope Paul VI 10 years ago, stressing their church's support for the organization and the third world countries that now make up its majority.

title: CableTV Piracy Is Target of New Law
description: A new state law will make it a criminal offense to pirate cableTV service beginning next month, and the cable companies operating in Manhattan say they will press the District Attorney to prosecute violators.There are a number of people who just don't know they are committing a crime when they take the cable signal without paying.

title: Conference Behind Schedule
description: BERLIN, Sept. 28Yugoslav diplomats here say that as a result of deepseated differendes among several Communist parties, no agreement has yet been reached on either an agenda or a date for the conference originally scheduled for East Berlin during the summer.

title: Facts in Musicians' Strike
description: Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. I. Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.

title: Import Cut Planned
description: TOKYO, Sept. 28 (Reuters) Japan will have to pay an extra $2billion a year now that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has imposed a 10 per cent increase in crude oil prices. International Trade Minister Toshio Komoto said today.

title: Gunmen Hold 7 in a London Restaurant
description: LONDON, Monday, Sept. 29 (AP)Three armed men held seven hostages in a tiny restaurant in London's fashionable Knightsbridge district last night as hundreds of policemen watched the entrances from the street and from roofs.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Monday, September 29, 1975

title: Hoffa Search Suspended
description: DETROIT, Sept. 28  It seemed like the perfect break in the case of James R. Hoffa's disappearance on July 30:

title: Women Marathon Runners Are Racing to Equality With Men
description: With 12 miles of Central Park roadway to go in yesterday's New York City Marathon, at least 100 male runners were ahead of Kim Merritt.

title: Vilas, Ashe Score And Reach Final
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Sept. 28  After Arthur Ache brushed aside Geoff Masters, 62, 62, in the first semifinal match of the Fireman's Fund International tennis tournament at the Cow Palace today, Guillermo Vilas was pushed hard by Jeff Borowiak before he could join Ashe in tomorrow night's final.

title: Beame at Cathedral Services Honoring St. Elizabeth Seton
description: More than 2,000 worshipers attended services at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon as the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York officially celebrated the canonization of St. Elizabeth Ann Seton.

title: Film Projectionist Injuried In Times Square Attack
description: A 71yearold Times Square film projectionist remained in poor condition at Polyclinic Hospital this morning from injuries suffered early yesterday when two youths assaulted him in the IND subway station at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue, the police reported.

title: RATE RISE IS SEEN IN COMING WEEKS
description: A rising pattern in interest rates  generally regarded as anathema for the fixedincome market  now appears to be in prospect over the next sevral weeks, according to Wall Street analysts. There are several powerful forces, they note, that should propel rates higher. The most obvious influence, with each passing day, is the huge amount of Treasury financing that faces the market during October.

title: Bridge:
description: There was a time when New York provided the majority of American international representatives. It was a slight surprise when players from the Midwest, California or Texas earned a chance for world championship honors. But those days are long past. In the last five years only four New Yorkers have been among 42 American representatives.

title: Milwaukee Problems Still Seem Solvable
description: MILWAUKEE  Since 1960, Henry W. Maier has occupied the Mayors office in Milwaukees elegant old Flemishstyle City Hall. He presides over a livable city that is noted for its breweries and possesses the highest possible bond rating AAA.

title: JOHN L BUCK DIES; FARM EXPERT, 84
description: Dr. John Lossing Buck, an agricultural economist and authority on fanning in China, where he lived for 29 years, died Saturday night at the Eden Park Nursing Home in Poughkeepsie. N.Y. He was 84 years Mold and lived in Poughkeepsie and formerly in Pleasant Valley, N.Y.

title: Sihanouk Back in Peking For Chinese Celebrations
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 28Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's titular head of state, who returned to Phnom Penh 19 days ago after five years of exile in China, returned to Peking today to take part in celebrations Tuesday to mark the 26th anniversary of the establishment of the People's Republic of China.

title: Hospital Holds a Party In Street to Alter Image
description: Welltodo matrons joined governesses and hospital staff members in front of the Le Roy Hospital on East 61st street yesterday for a Street Scene to raise funds for the hospital and to help change its image, long that of a preserve for the affluent.

title: MIDDLEMEN FUNDS IN MIDEAST LISTED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (Reuters)American companies have paid $18.7million to middlemen in four Middle Eastern countries in connection with weapons deals in the last two years, Representative Les Aspin said today.

title: Plan to Build Ritual Bath in Teaneck Spurs Debate in Jewish Community
description: TEANECK, Sept. 28The determination of an Orthodox Jewish synagogue to install a ritual bath so that its married women can perform an ancient ceremony of purification threatens to divide Jews in this suburban community.

title: Celeste Thomaris Wed to D. M. Moschos
description: Celeste U. Thomaris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Thomaris of Potsdam, N. Y., was married yesterday to Demitrios M. Moschos, assistant to the City Manager of Worcester, Mass. Archbishop Iakovos performed the Greek Orthodox ceremony in the Chapel of the Holy Cross at the Hellenic College in Brookline, Mass.

title: U.S. URGED TO BUY ARMS IN EUROPE
description: BONN, Sept. 28As the North Atlantic treaty allies move toward a new generation of weapons, a policy dispute is developing over whether the United States, which has dominated the arms business, will now start buying more European equipment for its forces.

title: Israel Arrests 55 Arabs On West Bank as Guerrillas
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 28 (AP)Fiftyfive Arabs living in the Israelioccupied West Bank, ineluding a leading lawyer, have been detained on suspicion of guerrilla activities, the Israeli military command said today.

title: Flood Damage in Region Is Assessed As Rivers Drop and Residents Clean Up
description: Preliminary estimates of flood damage in Westchester County in the wake of last week's rains were put at 20million to $30million yesterday by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, who said he had asked for state and Federal declarations of disasterare status to make aid available to affected homes and businesses.

title: City College Biomedical Center Is Operating Without Approval
description: City College's controversial Center for Biomedical Education, which has been buffeted for months by charges of discriminatory admissions policies, has been operating without state authorization since its inception in February, 1973, the State Education Department confirmed last night.

title: Jets Rush to a 3024 Triumph; Redskins Trounce Giants, 4913
description: Jets Win; Giants Lose

title: Sacramento College Says Miss Hearst and Harrises Obtained Fake Identity Cards
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28Investigators have discovered that Patricia Hearst and her companions in the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army, William and Emily Harris, obtained spurious college iderrtity cards and may have been living in the Sacramento area while Russell Little and Joseph Remiro were on trial for a murder allegedly committed to further the aims of the terrorist organization, a college official says.

title: U.S. URGED TO BUY ARMS IN EUROPE
description: BONN, Sept. 28As the North Atlantic treaty allies move toward a new generation of weapons, a policy dispute is developing over whether the United States, which has dominated the arms business, will now start buying more European equipment for its forces.

title: Youths Fight at Beach
description: SAVANNAH BEACH, Ga., Sept. 28 (UPI)A fight between high school students on a weekend beach outing sparked a freeforall and more than five hours of rock and bottle throwing at the police late yesterday and early today. Thirty youths were arrested, the police said.

title: Bus Lines Escalate Fight Over Who Gets Subsidies
description: Amtrak. It's a vicious circle. Every time it comes around it costs us another $1billion, and still it's going nowhere.

title: Chiefs Stopped On 5 at End
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 28On the secondgreatest rushing day in the team's checkered history, the New York Jets were forced to go to the final seconds before they were assured of a 3024 victory over the Kansas City Chiefs today.

title: Yanks Squeeze In One Last Victory
description: The Yankees ended their disappointing season on an inspirational note at Shea Stadium yesterday with a threerun, ninthinning rally to salvage a split of a doubleheader with the Baltimore Orioles.

title: SpanishBorn Friar Is Canonized by Pope
description: ROME, Sept. 28 (AP)Pope Paul VI today elevated a Spanishborn friar, Juan Macias, to sainthood in the Roman Catholic Church.

title: NOW Accounts Backed
description: DIXVILLE NOTCH, N.H., Sept 28 (AP)Senator Thomas J.
