McIntyre, Democrat of New Hampshire has urged Congress to approve nationwide use of socalled NOW (negotiated order of withdrawal) bank accounts to permit banks and savings institutions to allow checklike withdrawals from interestearning deposits.

title: Savarin's El Exigente Tells Ad Agency Adios
description: There were no fireworks and the natives didn't dance in the street at Foote, Cone & Belding last week. El Exigente, the demanding one, didn't smile.

title: Concorde's Makers Are Intensifying Search for Buyers
description: LONDON, Sept. 28When Donald Coggan, the Archbishop of Canterbury, took a test flight on the Concorde recently, there was some light jesting that the British and French, having tried everything else, had resorted to prayer to save their controversial supersonic aircraft from the auditors.

title: Books of The Times
description: The big question eating at consumers these days is just why eating suddenly costs so much. Who's making all the profits? Common sense tells us that someone in that not me chorus line of supermarkets, meat packers, food processors and farmers is not being entirely truthful. This gut feeling is reinforced by the periodic reports from the Department of Agriculture indicating that the farmtoretail price spreadthat is, the difference between the price paid by the consumer and what was paid to the farmercontinues to grow.

title: Bills Top Steelers As Simpson Stars
About New York
description: The new world faced by people who had sight and lost it can be frightening and frustrating. Their education in finding their way about this world that they once knew so surely becomes almost a crash course in learning how to use senses of hearing, feeling and instinct instead of the eyes.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THEM The phrase third world came into general usage about 12 years ago. Thirdworld people are the world's black, brown, red and yellow populations. This group constitutes a majority of the world's people.

title: Cowboys Defeat Cards in Overtime
description: Roger Staubach of the Dallas Cowboys and Jim Hart of the St. Louis Cardinals put on such a superb passing duel yesterday and it took almost eight minutes of overtime play to decide their game at Irving. Tex. The Cowboys won, 3731.

title: Lebanese Forces Comb Beirut for 71 Missing in Clashes
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. Sept. 28 (AP)Lebanene security forces combed suburban areas of Beirut today in search of 71 people missing and believed abducted during the last two weeks of fighting between Christian and Moslem elements here.

title: Houseball and Mikolajczyks
description: ARLINGTON, Va.For years I have had a fantasy. I sit at the head of a long conference table. Around the table are the publishers and editors of the top newspapers and magazines, the heads of the television networks, all of the prestigious liberal columnists and the leading liberal politicians. I rise and say:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mel Patrick Lynch, accused of being one of the kidnappers of Samuel Bronfman 2d, was transferred early yesterday morning from the Westchester County Jail in Valhalla to the Ulster County Jail in Newburgh. The move by state corrections officials, at the request of Mr. Lynch's lawyer, came a week after Mr. Lynch and another prisoner overpowered a guard and tried to escape.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Dr. C. H. Waddington, 69, Dies; Cast Lighton Life's Development
description: C. H. Waddingtor, the British geneticist who earned a worldwide reputation as scientist and philosopher, died Friday in Edinburgh, Scotland. He was 69 years old.

title: Louise Carol Schneider Is Married
description: Louise Carol Schneider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Conrad Schneider of Tenafly, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Steven Ira Shapiro, son of Mrs. Julius Shapiro of New York and the late Dr. Shapiro.

title: Moon's Followers Accused of Beating Adherent's Father
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 28 (AP)The New Jersey Insurance Commissioner, James Sheeran, said yesterday that he was beaten unconscious when he tried to retrieve his daughters last month from the International Training Center maintained by the followers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon in Barrytown, N.Y.

title: BENJAMIN NATCHEZ
description: Benjamin Natchez, a former vice president and treasurer of Finlay Straus, Inc., jewelers, and later controller of Bulova and Benrus watch companies, died Friday in Miami, where be lived. He was 71 years old and formerly jived in. Mamaroneck, N. Y..

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Terrier Gets Westbury's Top Award
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 28 The Sealyham terrier. according to the standard, should be the embodiment of power and determination, ever keen and alert. That could have been written for Ch. Dersade Bobby's Girl, a little whitecoat owned by Mrs. Dorothy Wimer of Churchtown, Pa., who led a field of 2,110 at the Westbury Kennel Club's 53d show today.

title: Dance: Lotte Goslar Mimes at Hunter
description: Lotte Goslar's programs are an acquired taste and because her gentle humane outlook on life is immensely. appealing, acquiring a taste for her comic pantomine sketches comes without effort.

title: William Gallagher Dies at 52; Won Pulitzer for Photography
description: FLINT, Mich., Sept. 28 (AP)William M. Gallagher. the photographer who won a Pulitzer Prize for his picture of Adlai E. Stevenson with a hole in his shoe, died today of meningitis. He was 52 years old.

title: Effects of 10% Oil Price Rise Are Assayed
description: VIENNA, Sept. 28  With their proceedings being followed more closely than ever before, the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have sought to characterize their 10 per cent oilprice increase as reasonable and consistent with their expressed desire to cooperate with Western and third world consumer countries. They point out that they will freeze the new price, which follows a fourfold increase over the last two years, until June 30.

title: COUPLE TERRORIZED; SUSPECT IS SEIZED
description: A man climbed through the window of a West Side apartment yesterday, tied up the couple who lived there and forced the woman at knifepoint to the street before he was apprehended by a police officer, the police said.

title: Horszowski Marks 75th Anniversary of Piano Debut
description: Mieczyslaw Horszowski was 8 years when he made his debut as a pianist in Vienna in 1900. Saturday night, he played a recital at Hunter College Assembly Hall as part of his 75th anniversary observance of that occasion. (Next year he will mark the 70th anniversary of his Carnegie Hall debut in 1906.)

title: TOP SCHOOL POST REMAINS AN ISSUE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 28 While controversy continues here over the resignation on Sept. 17 of the black superintendent of schools, Charles H. Durant 3d, this city's troubled publicschool system will begin this week to seek a replacement for him.

title: Transit Authority Gets Hgh Mark From Levitt
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt, who has criticized the Transit Authority in a series of 12 audit reports over the last three years, had good words for management in a final summary report issued yesterday.

title: Taft to Discuss Investments
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) Senator Robert Taft Jr., Republican of Ohio, and a group of business, labor and municipal officials will meet with Secretary of Commerce Rogers C. B. Morton tomorrow to discuss the economic impact of foreign investments on American cororations.

title: Kissinger and Argentine Official Meet Here on Closer Relations
description: Secretary of State Kissinger told Foreign Minister Angel F. Robledo of Argentina yesterday that the United States was watching his country's efforts to strengthen parliamentary government with understanding and sympathy.

title: LIBERALS IN KINGS NAME 8 FOR BENCH
description: The Kings County Liberal party, in its weekend nominating convention, designated eight candidates for 14year terms as State Supreme Court justices in the borough's Second Judicial District.

title: SWEDISH SCIENTISTS WIN $25,000 PRIZE
description: Two Swedish scientists were named yesterday to share the $25,000 Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize for their work with prostaglandins, body chemicals that affect high blood pressure, pregnancy, fevers and ulcers.

title: Article 1  No Title
Hawaiians Lose, 3225, To Steamer
Soccer Results
description: GERMANAMERICAN LEAGUE Major Division

title: COMMUTERS FIGHT TO SAVE BUS LINES
description: Commuters from two suburban communities who favor leave the driving to us over being a Dashing Dan are fighting a decision by the city's Board of Estimate not to renew franchises for two bus lines that have carried them to and from work for more than a I year.

title: Dr. Avrahm Yarmolinsky Dead; Public Library Russian Expert
description: Dr. Avrahm Yarmolinsky, a leading scholar, critic and anthologist in the field of Russian literature, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 300 West 108th Street.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: That recent recipe for stuffed chicken, the bird's cavity filled with scrambled eggs, struck a responsive note in the minds of numerous readers, particularly those of European background.

title: Twins Aim Higher Than Third
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 28 (AP)Frank Quilici was dismissed today as manager of the Minnesota Twins. A successor was not immediately named.

title: Women Marathon Runners Are Racing to Equality With Men
description: With 12 miles of Central Park roadway to go in yesterday's New York City Marathon, at least 100 male runners were ahead of Kim Merritt.

title: Janet Volker Has Nuptials
description: Janet Florence Volker, a customer account representative with the Bankers Trust Company, and William J. Sweeney, a lawyer with Haight, Gardner, Poor & Havens, were married yesterday afternoon in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn, L. I., by the Rev. Michael Reid, the assistant pastor.

title: 3 PITTSBURGH BOMBS LINKED TO EXTORTION
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28The authorities found bombs today at three area gasoline stations and said that they had been placed in gasoline tanks as part of a plot to obtain $45.5million from seven major oil companies.

title: Brewers Pave Way for Aaron?
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 28 (UPI)  Del Crandall, who spent 3 years trying to build the Milwaukee Brewers into a winner, was discharged today before the team's last game of the season.

title: U.S. Won't Try I.R.S. Chief in a Customs Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) Federal prosecutors have decided against prosecuting Donald C. Alexander, the Internal Revenue Service Commissioner. in an investigation linking him to a Seattle customs case, a Justice Department spokesman said today.

title: U.S. SENT MEN TO AID ISRAEL, SADAT SAYS
description: CAIRO. Sept. 28 (UPI)President Anwar elSadat said today that American technicians had helped Israel in the 1973 war.

title: GiantsRedskins Scoring
...No Detour Wanted
description: The original decision was entirely sound. If these are public expenses inextricably connected with the performance of a Congressman's public duties, then they should be paid for openly out of public funds.

title: Kodes Puts Czechs in Cup Final
description: PRAGUE, Sept, 28 (AP)Jan Kodes propelled Czechoslovakia into the final round of the 1975 Davis Cup against Sweden when he beat Tony Roche of Australia, 6.3, 61, 64, today.

title: Intensive Talks Held in Musicians' Strike
description: With increased pressure from business and artistic groups for an end to the strike that has shut down 12 Broadway musical productions, the state mediator in the dispute brought Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and the League of New York Theaters together again yesterday for intensive negotiations.

title: Panel of Judges Gives In to Pressure And Names a Man at the Last Minute
description: The new judicialscreening committee for Manhattan and the Bronx bowed to the pressure of black Democratic leaders in Manhattan last week and qualified at the last minute a judicial candidate who had earlier been rejected by the committee when it drew up a list of 31 judicial prospects qualified for the State Supreme Court bench. Judge Arthur E. Bell of Civil Court was rated qualified in a telephone poll of the 13member screening panel mere hours before the Democratic judicial district convention met to nominate Supreme Court candidates.

title: Abuses Found in Teamsters' Insurance
description: A State Insurance Department investigation has found that a teamsters' local here paid $1.6million in 1971 and 1972 for union members' life insurance that should have cost only $525,000 and that $1 million in commissions from the transactions has vanished.

title: Army Says It Has Not Yet Reached LSD Subjects for FollowUp Testing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Ten weeks ago, the Army promised to conduct followup examinations of about 550 soldiers to whom it had given LSD, but a spokesman disclosed today that the service has not yet tried to reach any of the men.

title: Global War on Smallpox Expected to Be Won in '76
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Sept. 23 Smallpox is about to be eradicated from the earth.

title: The New Plot for Ali, the Playboy
description: MANILA, Sept. 28After his workout at the Folk Arts Theater today, Joe Frazier introduced two of his dughters, 12yearold Weatta and 7yearold Natasha, to the Filipino audience and said, So you see, I have a lot of beautiful girls around me all the time. No translation into Tagalog was necessary. Joe Frazier is usually about as subtle as his left hook but, obviously inspired by Muhammad Ali's misbehavior as a husband, Joe Frazier has emerged as a dry humorist. When a group of visitors no ticed a lady sitting on his bed the other day, Joe Frazier explained, I'd like you to meet my girlfriend. After a pause, he added, and my wife, Florenceshe's both. More than ever, Joe Frazier has emerged the good guy against Muhammad Ali, the bad guy, in their scheduled 15round plot that will thicken in United States closedcircuit TV locations Tuesday night. Other heavyweight champions have fights.

title: The Theater: Night Must Fall Why?
description: The English have a way with murderand, for that matter, so do the Scots and the Welsh. There is something about the British Isles, often thought of as so tranquil, that seems to inspire murders both bloodthirsty and bizarre. Murders on foggy moors, corpses in trunks, torsos in acidthe whole rigmarole of homicide. It is not for nothing that the English detective story became a national cult, or that crime reporting, even in respectable newspapers, is carried out with a kind of relish that would be immediately suspect in a nominally less peaceful society.

title: The Theater: Victoria
description: In Victoria, a new musical about Queen Victoria and Prince Albert at Theater at Mama Gail's, coronation follows so quickly after christening that this is practically a baby  bunting queen. However, the instant the royal spotlight strikes, young Victoria smiles confidently: She is immediately aware of all the privileges and prerogatives of her office.

title: Convoy, Freed From Ice Floe, Thrusts Toward Alaska Oilfield
description: ANCHORAGE, Sept. 28In a dramatic, suspenseful thrust through Arctic ice fields, a large convoy of barges carrying cargo vital for development of Alaska's North Slope oilfields raced today toward its destination at Prudhoe Bay.

title: Fighting Addiction
description: The future of the city's Addiction Services Agency is cloudy. The National Institute on Drug Abuse has concluded that its overhead costs are too high and has asked the State Drug Abuse Commission to disburse the more than $2 million committed to support New York City drug programs. Mayor Beame is reported contemplating tucking the A.S.A. hack into the Department of Health and changing commissioners.

title: PUBLISHER CURBED ON AN ETHICS CODE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) For the second time, a National Labor Relations Board judge has ruled that an ethics code for newspaper employes affects working conditions and is subject to collective bargaining.

title: Despite Setbacks, Carter Hopes for Freedom
description: One year ago even the most skeptical of convicts at the Trenton State Prison predicted that Rubin (Hurricane) Carter soon would be a free man.

title: August Tool Orders Top July, but Rate Is Still Behind '74
description: Machine tool orders in August rose slightly from the July level but remained well below that of August, 1974, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported over the weekend. Shipments in August trailed the July total but were well ahead of the yearearlier pace.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: The minimum retail price for a quart of milk in New Jersey is to increase by 1 cent Wednesday. The lowest price at which milk can then be sold is 37 cents a quart, 69 cents a half gallon and $1.32 a gallon, according to the State Department of Agriculture.

title: Several of New Hampshire's Key Moderate Republicans Are Shifting Toward Reagan in February Primary
description: BOSTON, Sept. 28Afterthoughts on John A. Durkin's Democratic victory over Republican Louis C. Wyman in New Hampshire's rerun Senate election this month dwell on a variety of implications for the Presidential race in 1976, and particularly on the hazards for President Ford. The for mer New Hampshire House. Speaker, Stuart Lamprey, former Governor Hugh Gregg and a former state party chairman, David Gosselin, are among the moderate Republicans in the state now on the verge of joining Ronald Reagan's organization for the February primary.

title: Seldom Active Senate Unit Drew $2Million in Decade
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Among the 299 subcommittees of Congress is an obscure Senate group named the Subcommittee on Immigration and Naturalization, which apparently has not held a formal meeting in a decade although over $2million has been authorized for its operations. The word apparently is obligatory since the records of Congress are sometimes written small and there is no complete score of meeting dates of committees and

title: International Airlines Urged to Adopt Joint Tactics to Avoid Empty Seats
description: The international scheduled airlines, straining to reverse recent financial misfortunes, are being urged by two leading officials to take prompt joint measures to eliminate the problem of too many planes flying with too many empty seats.

title: For One of Last Victims, Pain and Disfigurement
description: BORAMPUR, Bangladesh, Sept. 23Aftabaldi has not looked at himself in, a mirror since he developed smallpox early last month.

title: Schmidt's Party Suffers a Setback In Bremen Election
description: BREMEN, West Germany, Sept. 28West Germany's top political party suffered a major setback today in an election in this northern citystate as vot ers apparently expressed their uneasiness over the country's economic problems.

title: Plan to Build Ritual Bath in Teaneck Spurs Debate in Jewish Community
description: TEANECK, N. J., Sept. 28The determination of an Orthodox Jewish synagogue to install a ritual bath so that its married women can perform an ancient ceremony of purification threatens to divide Jews in this suburban community.

title: St.Dominic's Trounces Chaminade
description: Tony Capozzoli began his senior season as a high school quarterback yesterday and it seems the ace from St. Dominic's of Oyster Bay, L.I., will again he as successful as he was in his preceding three campaigns. Capozzoli, rated among the top schoolboy quarterbacks in the country, threw three passes for touchdowns and ran 40 yards for one as St. Dom's whipped Chaminade, 4514, in a Catholic Schools Football League Long Island Division game at Hofstra Field.

title: Abuses Found in Teamsters' Insurance
description: A State Insurance Department investigation has found that a teamsters' local here paid $1.6million in 1971 and 1972 for union members' life insurance that should have cost only $525,000 and that $1 million in commissions from the transactions has vanished.

description: Jets Win; Giants Lose

title: Turks Report 6 Soldiers Slain in Clash With Kurds
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 28 (Reuters)Six Turkish soldiers and the head of a small Kurdish clan were killed in an exchange of gunfire in remote eastern Turkey yesterday, Turkish news agencies reported today.

title: Hill Captures Playoff In $135,000 Sahara
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 23 (AP)  Dave Hill, who had to shake off the potential disaster of a double bogey to gain a tie, won a suddendeath playoff in the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament today when Rik Massengale hit his second shot into the water.

title: Baseball Playoffs
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1975

title: A Silent Night? Where There's an Ear Plug There's a Way
description: Wouldn't It be nice some night if suddenly all the clanking garbage cans in the city were covered in velvet? If all the dogs agreed to lower their barks between 10 P.M. and 6 A.M.? If stereos played lullabies and traffic sounded far, far away?

title: DAIRY UNIT AIDED BY RULING ON FUND FOR VOTER DRIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28The Federal Election Commission has issued a ruling that strengthens the political arm of Associated Milk Producers, Inc., which has been involved in numerous violations of campaign spending laws.

description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53111 UNTIL 3:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNIIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) /4/0500; SUFFOLK CO. (316) 6691??00; CONNECTICUT (203) 34??7767.

title: BREZHNEV SEEMS TO BACK EDITOR
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28A recent meeting between Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party chief, and a Soviet editor who criticized some practices of Communist parties in Western Europe has stirred speculation among diplomatic analysts here.

title: Advertising
description: Humble pie will continue to be an A.&P. special this week. The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company today goes into the second phase of its Price & Pride campaign.

title: Mexican Leader Asks U.N. to Suspend Spain
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 28 (UPI)Mexico called on the United Nations today to suspend Spain because of serious and repeated violations of human rights.

title: Street Race, Auto Title To Redman
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 28 (AP)Brian Redman of England clinched his second consecutive Formula 5000 championship today when he won the Long Beach Grand Prix, the first major auto race on city streets in the United States in more than two decades.

title: LISBON LEFTISTS IN STREETS AGAIN
description: LISBON, Sept. 28Tension between Portugal's new Government and organized leftist challengers who have taken to the streets increased tonight, with the added dimension of harshly strained relations with Spain.

title: Hunt Is Said to Deny Report Of Order to Kill Columnist
description: Time magazine quotes a Watergate plotter, E. Howard Hunt, as saying that he was never ordered to assassinate Jack Anderson, the columnistonly to drug him, The Associated Press reported.

title: Spanish Police Shoot Six In Basque Demonstration
description: MADRID, Sept. 28Civil guards opened fire today on crowd of Basque demonstrators in Algorta, an industrial suburb of Bilbao, wounding at least six persons.

title: By the Children, for the Children
description: Some parents might discourage their offspring from a career in the theater, but not Jeanne and Don Niederlitz.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on Sept. 19 should have named Barry Bass as the source of a statement declaring that Eugene R. Kelley, the Suffolk County Police Commissioner, was present at a lie detector interrogation of Mr. Bass. The Commissioner has denied that he participated in that interrogation.

title: Schmidt's Party Suffers a Setback In Bremen Election
description: BREMEN, West Germany, Sept. 28West Germany's top political party suffered a major setback today in an election in this northern citystate as voters apparently expressed their uneasiness over the country's economic problems.

title: U.S.Turkish Relations
description: WASHINGTONThe sweeping arms ban imposed by Congress effectively extends to Turkey the treatment normally accorded an enemy state, wiping out, without a backward look, a relationship of trust and confidence nurtured over thirty years, and leaving in question an alliance that has been a cornerstone of United States security policy since 1950.

title: Relent, $32.80, Is Victor
description: With the trainers of Forego and Wajima reiterating yesterday that their top thoroughbreds would be pointed for the Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park Oct. 25, Tommy Trotter quietly prepared to return as the racing secretary and handicapper of the New York Racing Association.

title: REP. PIKE ACCUSES INTELLIGENCE ARM OF FAILING IN DUTY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The chairman of the House Select Committee on Intelligence said today that the United States security agencies had become such unwieldy bureaucracies that the country might not be warned in advance of an unexpected attack.

title: Editorial and Craft Employes At Newsday Authorize a Strike
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 28Editorial and craft employes, at Newsday voted 314 to 48, today to authorize their union's executive committee to call a strike at its discretion.

title: Flyers Defeat Rangers in Exhibition
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 The New York Rangers, playing without Brad Park and Derek Sanderson, lost to the Stanley Cup champion Philadelphia Flyers, 21, tonight. What they missed more than those two stars, however, was a power play.

title: Philadelphians Debate 2d Place in Vote
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27This city's threeman mayor's race has spawned one of the fiercest debates in its long and colorful political history.

title: Tenor Promising in City Opera Bow
description: Henry Price, who made a most promising debut with the New York City Opera yesterday afternoon as Alfredo in La Traviata, is a young, goodlooking lyric tenor from Dallas.

title: CHARLIE MONROE, BLUEGRASS SINGER
description: REIDSVILLE, N.C., Sept. 28 (UPI)Charlie Monroe, bluegrass guitarist and singer, died cancer yesterday. He was 72 years old.

title: 4 A's Pitchers Combine for NoHitter
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 28 (UPI)Four Oakland pitchers Vida Blue, Glen Abbott, Paul Lindblad and Rollie Fingerscombined to pitch the first nohit game in baseball history by more than two pitchers in a 50 victory today for the A's over the California Angels.

title: Turks Fully Colonize Citrus Region of Northern Cyprus
description: MORPHOU, Cyprus  This provincial capital, the center of a rich citrusgrowing area in northwestern Cyprus, has been thoroughly colonized by Turkish Cypriotes from the south.

title: New Map for Politics ...
description: American politics has long been an unmapped jungle. Candidates set their own boundaries and followed the high road, the low road or somewhere between as preference and necessity impelled them. Legal guidelines on campaign expenditures were more loophole than law and could be safely ignored.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on Sept. 19 should have named Barry Bass as the source of a statement declaring that Eugene R. Kelley, the Suffolk County Police Commissioner, was present at a lie detector interrogation of Mr. Bass. The Commissioner has denied that he participated in that interrogation.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which secucities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: The Literary Scene: Macdonaldizing
description: At a watering hole where scribblers go to trade lies and steal one another's ideas, concern was expressed the other night for James Joyce. Word had reached the watering hole that Tom Wolfe, who has already exposed The New Yorker, Felicia Bernstein and modem art, was writing an article for Esquire that would blow the whistle on Ulysses.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OPEC, Despite Pressure, Sticks Together
description: VIENNA, Sept. 28It was the longest, tensest, most grueling conference in the 15year history of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Britons Praise Zaki
description: LONDON, Sept. 28Western Europe, which depends on imported oil to a much greater degree than does the United States, accepted without much complaint the 10 per cent price increase imposed by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: AGED LIVING ALONE ARE ON RISE HERE
description: The number of older people living alone in New York City has been accelerating, rising by 26.3 per cent since 1970 to 373,000 in 1973, according to a study by the city's new Department for the Aging.

title: Turkey Eases Poppy Curb
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept, 28 (AP)  Turkey will permit her poppy farmers to more than double their acreage for poppy, cultivation a Government decree said today. The announcement came shortly before a midterm Senate election scheduled for Oct. 12. Turkish poppies are considered the source of heroin that winds up in the United States and elsewhere.

title: First Mortgage REIT Fights to Survive
description: First Mortgage Investors, the nation's oldest and third largest real estate investment trust, is fighting for survival, and the outcome will have a profound impact on the prospects of many other REIT's and thousands of REIT shareholders and bondholders.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1975

title: Seaver Wins 22d
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 Tom Seaver made his last hid to capture a third Cy Young award when he gained his 22d victory today in the Mets' final game of the season. However, the New York ace was unable to finish the game, which the Mets won from the Phillies, 54.

title: Article 2  No Title
Events Today
description: Theater

title: Melita Riley Bride of Geoffrey H. Moore
description: Melita Holly Riley of New Canaan, Conn., a consultant in the United Nations Statistical Office, was married yesterday afternoon to Geoffrey Hoyt Moore of Ridgewood, N. J., vice president for research at the National Bureau of Economic Research here and a former United States Commissioner of Labor Statistics.

title: Screen: Rural Sheriff
Blacks in Rhodesia Choose New Leader
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 28Joshua Nkomo today accepted the presidency of the African National Council, the umbrella organization of Rhodesia's often squabbling nationalist groups. He gave pledge to continue negotiating for majority rule, warning that should this course fail, armed struggle will be inevitable.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Hot Dogs to Contain Less Pork Until July
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)Farmers are sending so few pigs to market these days that the Government is letting processors put more beef and less pork in hot dogs.

title: Church Unit Tracing Draft Offenders
description: The National Council of Churches is endeavoring to inform 192,000 young men who registered for the draft in the Vietnam war but who failed to report for induction that only 4,400 of them still face charges.

title: JetsChiefs Scoring
New Jersey Briefs
description: Teacher strikes in two municipalities in the state continued yesterday as negotiations apparently remained deadlocked over money issues. In Hoboken, talks broke off Saturday with the school board reporting that both sides were as far apart now as the first day we were on strike. Some 400 teachers struck Sept. 4, preventing instruction of 9.000 pupils.

title: Moon's Followers Accused of Beating Adherent's Father
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept 28 (AP)The New Jersey In?? surance Commissioner, Jame?? Sheeran, said yesterday tha?? the was beaten unconsciou, when he tried to retrieve hi?? daughters last month from th?? International Training Cente?? maintained by the followers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moo?? in Barrytown. N.Y.

title: ARCHDIOCESE HITS STRIKE TALK SNAG
description: Negotiations to settle the strike of lay teachers at nine high schools in the Archdiocese of New York were broken off yesterday, hours after they had resumed.

title: Saudi Foreign Minister Calls Rise Moderate
description: The Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia said yesterday that although his country failed to maintain a freeze on oil prices, it succeeded in moderating the increase approved Saturday by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: ULMONT O. CUMMING
description: Ulmont O. Cumming, an expert on industrial patents who headed the International Service Corporation, died yesterday at his home, 400 East 56th Street. He was 78 years old.

title: Unanswered Questions
description: Senate hearings on President Ford's nomination of Thomas S. Kleppe for Secretary of the Interior have been a feeble probing into a weak appointment. Members the Interior and Insular Affairs Committee have seemed more intent on assuring Mr. Kleppe that he needn't worry than with eliciting hard information about his record, his ideas and his qualifications for a position vital importance at this point in the country's history.

title: Global War on Smallpox Expected to Be Won in '76
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Sept. 23 Smallpox is about to be eradicated from the earth.

title: Spain Charges Interference
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept 29Spain today denounced as intolerable interference the demand by President Echeverria that th eFranco Government be suspended from the United Nations for violations of human rights.

title: Untermeyer at 90: An Anthology of Living
description: NEWTOWN, Conn., Sept. 29Louis Untermeyer, whose faith has launched a thousand poets and whose taste has shaped a thousand textbooks, has just thought of another anthology that needed his talents.

title: Court Blocks H.E.W. Guidelines For Funded Day Care Centers
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 29 (AP)New guidelines by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare for federally funded day care centers across the nation were blocked by a Federal court in an order made public today.

title: BLACK TV STATION OPENS IN DETROIT
description: DETROIT, Sept. 29  It's really exciting, said Sharon Crews, the new station's weather reporter. It's history.

title: Dismantling of City Transport Agency Is Urged by Its ExPlanning Director
description: A recent planning director for the city's Transportation Administration yesterday called Tor the dismantling of he superagency, describing it as a self  serving, disconnected wheel with no practical purpose or mission.

title: Export Licenses Required
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29To the extent that the General Motors project in Poland requires shipment of equipment or technology from the United States, export licenses from the Commerce Department will be required. These licenses are now granted fairly routinely for all but the most sophisticated equipment that is deemed to have a potential military usefulness.

title: Wilt out to Confront Lakers
description: Wilt Chamberlain is apparently ready to challenge Jack Kent Cooke's assertion that the Los Angeles Lakers still own the 7feet2inch center. Chamberlain said yesterday he would report to the Lakers' training camp either toBasketball or tomorrow and that could force the Lakers to pay him a $450.000 annual salary or trade him. It is doubtful the Laker owner would want to pay the 39yearold Chamberlain since he is already paying Kareem AbdulJabbar a reported $500,000 annually to play center.

title: THOUSANDS STRIKE IN BASQUE REGION
description: ZARAUZ, Spain, Sept. 29 Tens of thousands of Basques went on strike in northern Spain today in protest against the execution Saturday of Basque separatists convicted of killing policemen.

title: Aides Say Ford Has Foiled Challenge by G.O.P. Right
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 White House aides are saying privately that President Ford has successfully blunted a challenge by the right wing of the Republican party to his nomination in 1976 and predict that he will soon adopt a slightly more moderate stance to broaden his electoral appeal.

title: Roy Stryker, 82, Who Directed Photo Study of Depression, Dies
description: Roy E. Stryker, who as chief of the historical section of the Farm Security Administration from 1935 to 1943 directed the photographers who documented America during the Depression, died Saturday in Grand Junction, Colo., where he had been living. His age was 82.

title: Denunciations Intensify
description: ROME, Sept. 29 (Reuters)Denunciations of Spain intensified today as governments, political leaders and labor organizations expressed anger at the execution of five convicted Spanish terrorists.

title: PIKE PANEL SEEKS HOUSE VOTE IN BID FOR SECRET FILES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The House Select Committee on Intelligence agreed today to seek a resolution from the full House of Representatives supporting its demand for unimpeded access to classified documents and other materials that the committee has subpoenaed from William E. Colby, the Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Ali Is 21 to Win Showdown III
F.B.I. Agent Says Participant Admits Extortion Scheme
description: NORFOLK. Va., Sept. 29 (AP) An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that Paul D. Mcthven had ??igned a statement in which he admitted having taken part in a plot to extort $45.5million from seven major oil companies.

title: COURT VOIDS LAIN ORDERING 2 FUNDS TO BUY CITY BONDS
description: A key part of the emergency state law for holding off default by the city was struck down yesterday by the state's highs court, compounding the crisis and depriving the city of some of the funds it needs to survive until December.

title: U.S. Experts Believe Soviet Is Stressing Blitzkrieg Training Against NATO
description: The Army will begin the movement of 10,000 troops to Europe this week with equipment for an exercise intended to demonstrate Western strength against a Soviet army prepared, if war comes, for a blitzkrieg.

title: No New Ideas Needed
description: AI Ullman, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, can't be accused of trying to kid anyone about tax reform.

title: World Violence and the Verbal Arts
description: In the nineteenfifties a truism gravely offered younger writers as law was that the novel was dead, poetry dying, and all verbal art shortly to follow, since imagination, against the violence of the present world, had no force worth considering. The world's disorders were now of such magnitude that there was no point in replicating them on the page in any way except one. All the power was now in the miserable fact. From now on, this would be all that serious people wanted to hear.

title: Air Force Grounds Copters
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (Reuters)The Air Force temporarily grounded 51 helicopters today while it investigated a crash last Friday that killed 16 servicemen in West Germany. The Air Force said, 40 HH5 air rescue helicopters and 11 CH53 cargo versions were restricted from flying routine operations but will be available for urgent needs.

title: H. Bacon Collamore Dead; Insurance, Steel Official, 81
description: H. Bacon Collamore, who retired as chairman of the National Fire Insurance Company and then was chairman of the Pittsburgh Steel Company, died Sunday in Hartford. He was 81 years old and lived in West Hartford.

title: 3 Countries Receive Loans From the I.M.F. in S.D.R.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (Reuters)  The International Monetary Fund said today its executive board has approved loans totalling 108.47 million Special Drawing Rights to three countries.

title: Canadian Bill Bids U.S. Magazines Alter Content
description: The Canadian Government, in another effort to improve the competitive position of Canadian magazines, plans new regulations that Secretary of State Hugh Faulkner said yesterday would compel Canadian editions of Reader's Digest and Time to differ in content by 60 to 80 per cent from United States editions.

title: Operating Capacity Gains
description: American industrial concerns operated at 70.5 per cent of their capacity in August, up from the 69.5 per cent operating rate in July, according to preliminary estimates made yesterday by the McGrawHill Publications Department of Economics. It said industrial production rose for four consecutive months from May through August and that if the trend continues, the industrial operating rate would he close to 75 per cent by year end.

title: Helsinki Aftermath
description: Dr. Joseph Luns, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, has become the first major Western official to offer an evaluation of the consequences to date of the signing of the Helsinki Declaration last summer. His criticism that Moscow is not living up to the agreement tends far more to support last July's skeptics than it does to back President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger, who defended the utility and importance of the Helsinki Declaration and its uretentious signing ceremony.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1975

title: Naming of ExPolice Chief To Drug Agency Dropped
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) Jerry Wilson, former Washington, D. C., police chief, has been dropped as the Ford Administration's choice to head the troubled Drug Enforcement Administration, according to a Justice Department spokesman.

title: Harris Inventory Hints They Got Tax Refund
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 The inventory of materials found in the apartments of William and Emily Harris and Patricia Hearst suggests that the Harrises may have received an income tax refund from the Internal Revenue Service while they were hiding From the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Language and Man
description: What shall we think of Lana, the verbal chimpanzee? Lana communicates regularly with her trainers at the Yerkes Primate Research Center in Atlanta using a computer. By now she has a vocabulary of 120 words with which she composes novel ideasboth questions and statementsnever taught to her. Is she or is she not talking, that is, using language similar In some degree to human use of language? Are her typed conversations essentially different from signlanguage conversations between deaf persons?

title: Text of Colby Statement
description: The action of the House Select Committee on Intelligence to recommend that the House of Representatives adopt the proposed resolution is indeed, in the words of the resolution, a grave matter. It goes to the heart of the question of whether the United States can conduct intelligence operations essential to the safety and welfare of our country.

title: Inquiry Begun on Incidents At Moon's Church Center
description: The Dutchess County District Attorny is conducting a preliminary inquiry into whether a number of incidents involving the training center of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church at Barrytown, N.Y., should be investigated by a grand jury.

title: Rapes at Hunter Spark Student Protest
description: More than 100 student demonstrators, angered over the rape of three students at Hunter College in the last two months, invaded the office of the school president yesterday to demand more guards and tighter security, which was cut over the summer as a result of the city's fiscal crisis.

title: New York's Jobless
description: The unemployment rate in this city continues to hover close to 12 per cent, half again as high as the national rate. The inability of one worker out of eight to find a New York job gives particular urgency to official efforts to avert new layoffs as well as to attract new industries.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Hearst Evidence Search Yields Lists of Banks and Executives
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29Lists of business executives in this area, and lists of banks, sonic illustrated with floor plans, were found in the apartments of Patricia Hearst and her companions when they were taken by surprise and arrested Sept. 18. official court records showed today.

title: Aides Say Ford Has Foiled Challenge by G.O.P. Right
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 White House aides are saying privately that President Ford has successfully blunted a challenge by the right wing of the Republican party to his nomination in 1976 and predict that he will soon adopt a slightly more moderate stance to broaden his electoral appeal.

title: Family Ponders Its Rare, Fatal Hereditary Disease
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 29Nearly 100 descendants of a Portuguese sailor named Antone Joseph held a family reunion here this weekend to discuss the disease that has been kill ing them, their parents, brothers, sisters, aunts, uncles and cousins continuously since the eighteenfifties.

title: P. & O. IS ACQUIRING GAS AND OIL LANDS
description: The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company announced in London yesterday that it was acquiring oil and gas production interests valued at $55million from the Kirby Petroleum Company, a unit of Kirby Industries, inc., of Houston.

title: Film Festival: Malle's 'Black Moon'
description: The time is early morning, midsummer. A fat badger noses its way across the macadam surface of an otherwise deserted two-lane highway. What would so fascinate a badger on the surface of a highway? The trail of a lost friend? The scent of an old hot dog? In the distance we hear a chorus of crickets and, close up, the sniffing of the badger.All is serene until a car appears in the distance. The self-absorbed animal pays no attention. It continues to sniff, to consider and to move a few more inches on. You know what's going to happen. It does, swiftly, with a small thud. The animal is squashed. The car swerves to a halt and a pretty young woman with blond, Alice-in-Wonderland hair alights. She looks at the body, but there isn't much one can do. She gets back into the car and races off.At this point, the beginning of Louis Malle's vivid fable of a film, "Black Moon," the girl suggests Lewis Carroll's Alice going down the rabbit hole in a sports car, falling into another dimension of experience. It's a world where, like Alice and sometimes like Goldilocks, she is successively ignored, threatened, bullied and laughed at, while she tries stoically to make order of things and only occasionally loses her temper."Black Moon" will be shown at the New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 9:30 o'clock and again on Thursday at 6:15 P.M.It's an uncharacteristically eccentric film to come from Mr. Malle. His best movies"Le Feu Follet," "Murmur of the Heart." "Lacombe, Lucien" and the documentary "Humain, Trop Humain"have, by the simplicity and precision of the film-maker's style, transformed the banalities of the real world into poetic visions. "Black Moon" is a poetic vision made to look so absolutely literal one doesn't question the validity of the images.Alice/Goldilocks (the character's name is actually Lily) is running away from a ferocious, all-out war between men and women. We first hear the sounds of battle on the highway. Further on, the girl witnesses the execution of a dozen women soldiers by a male patrol. As she continues to flee, she comes across the body of an old shepherd hanging from a tree above his flock.Finally she finds uncertain sanctuary in a handsome old farmhouse occupied by a batty, bedridden old woman who converses on a two-way radio across time ("What's that you say? Priam's dead? What about Helen?"), her mute son and her nonmute but equally enigmatic daughter.The movie evokes the dream state without once resorting to the use of fuzzy filters, slow-motion photography or even lap dissolves. We see everything with the clarity with which Lily observes it, though, unlike Lily, our tendency is to interpret what we see rather than simply to accept it. If one can accept the images in this way, the movie has a liberating effect. If not, it's a diagramless crossword puzzle.I'm not sure it's ever possible to respond to anything as literal as a movie composed of recognizable people, animals and objects, and not to wish to interpret the images in some fashion, at least part of the time. Thus, Lily's flight to me, seems to be out of a world of accepted, natural disorder (war) into a state where no laws yet apply, at least none that she understands. At the end it's as if she were at the beginning of comprehension and a new order."Black Moon" is baffling and beautiful and occasionally very funny. The cast includes a rather testy unicorn who can quote Lady Maceth and a large rat named Humphrey who talks in an unknown language to the old lady. There are flowers that moan when Lily lies on them and the recurring image of small naked children herding pigs. When Lily listens to a slug as it crawls over a log, it sounds as if a defeated army were making its way over a mountain."Black Moon" is dazzling to look at, for which Sven Nykvist, the cinematographer, is partly responsible. The cast includes Cathryn Harrison, who is Rex Harrison's granddaughter, as Lily, Joe Dallesandro (the mute son), Alexandra Stewart, (the daughter) and the late Theresa Giehse, to whom Mr. Malle dedicates the film, as the old lady. There is an order to this film, but we must supply it, each according to his needs.

title: Nov. 1 Is Pulitzer Deadline
description: Columbia University yesterday announced that Nov. 1 was the deadline for the submission of nominations for the 1976 Pulitzer Prizes in letters. The prizes cover fiction, historyautobiography, history, poetry and general nonfiction covering the calendar year 1975. Inquiries may he addressed to Prof. John Hohenherg at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

title: 2 PARTIES ENDORSE BENCH CANDIDATES
description: Manhattan and Bronx Republicans and Conservatives endorsed a slate of nine candidates for the State Supreme Court at First Judicial District conventions of each party at the Roosevelt Hotel last night.

title: Kissinger Tells Arabs U.S. Role in the Mideast Is Irreversible
description: Secretary of State Kissinger told representatives of 19 Arab countries last night that the United States involvement in the efforts to achieve a peace settlement and economic progress in the Middle East was irrevocable and irreversible.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Outgoing

title: OPEC to Weigh Cutting Poor Lands' Oil Prices
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 29 (AP)The Organization of Petroleurn Exporting Countries will discuss lowering crude oil prices for developing countries, Kuwait's Oil Minister, Abdul Muttaleb Kazemi, said today.

title: Murderer Who Got His B.A. in Prison Wins Early Parole
description: A 29yearold convicted murderer who became the first prison inmate to get an Associate in Arts degree from the State University of New York and then went on to win a Bachelor of Arts, has been pa roled as an example of rehabili tation through education.

title: COMMISSION SCORES CAPITAL PUNISHMENT
description: NEWARK, Sept. 29The 11member Newark Human Rights Commission today condemned the concept of capital punishment as immoral and called on the Sate Legislature to defeat a proposed bill that would reinstate the death penalty for persons convicted of killing law enforcement officers.

title: U.S. to Pay $7.1 Million For Indian Tribal Land
description: WENDOVER, Utah, Sept. 29 (UPI)  The Goshute Indians, one of the poorest tribes in the United States, have voted to accept a $7.1million offer to settle a 100yearold land dispute with the Federal Government involving about five million acres in Utah and Nevada.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: From Smorgasbord To a Burgare Boom
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 28No American in Stockholm could ever be confused enough by jet lag to think he was in New York. The streets are too clean here, autos stop to let pedestrians cross and taxi drivers never complain about the size of the tip, since they seldom get a tip.

title: Teachers Vote to End Strike
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 29 (UPI)  Striking teachers here voted overwhelmingly today to approve a twoyear contract, clearing the way for 14,600 publicschool students to return to class tomorrow. The district's 900 teachers had been on strike for one week. Most classes had been curtailed.

title: Eric is 15 and is the family cook and Tom, 17, does the dishes every night, and Terry, who's 12, well, she's still learning about housework . . .
description: STAMFORD, Conn.Eleanor Berman has found the answer to the livein help problemher children.

title: Market Place
description: Copper, which has been priced at less than the cost of production since the first of the year, may well rise in the months ahead and may help bring about a recovery in the depressed shares of leading producers of the metal, according to Herbert Barchoff, president of Eastern Rolling Mills, Inc., a leading producer of copper alloys.

title: Times Names Vice President For Ads, Family Circle Chief
description: Fred D. Thompson, a wellknown figure in the magazine industry, has been named vice president for advertising of The New York Times, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The Times and chairman and president of The New York Times Company, announced yesterday.

title: Hurricane Winds Stronger
description: MIAMI, Sept. 29 (UPI)The hurricane called Gladys, churning to the northwest in the open Atlantic, had winds of 75 to 90 miles an hour today.

title: Visit of U.S. Astronauts to Soviet Pervaded by Memory of Last War
description: VOLGOGRAD, U. S. S. R., Sept. 29  An old man had pinned his medals and faded ribbons to the lapel of his jacket and was squinting against the morning sunlight for a glimpse of the Apollo and Soyuz astronauts as they walked by.

title: MilkPrice Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill designed to assure dairy farmers that the milk pricesupport level would reflect costs on a more current basis. The measure would require the Secretary of Agriculture to set the support level at the beginning of each quartet instead of just at the start of a marketing year.

title: HanoiPeking Links Show Slight Strain After Talks on Aid
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 29China has announced the departure of a topranking North Vietnamese delegation in tones indicating that problems remain in relations between Peking and Hanoi.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dropped line in the review of the film Every Man for Himself and God Against All in The New York Times on Sunday resulted in one actor's receiving praise meant for another. The praise was intended for Walter Ladengast, who played the role of a professor.

title: Illinois Death Penalty Law Is Ruled Unconstitutional
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 29 (AP)The state's death penalty law was ruled unconstitutional today by the Illinois Supreme Court.

title: Kennecott Seeks Stay of F.T.C. Order For Peabody Sale
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation has asked a Federal Appeals Court in Denver to stay an order of the Federal Trade Commission requiring the big copper producer to file by tomorrow a plan for divesting itself of the Peabody Coal Company, the nation's largest coal producer. The company said it needed more time to provide its divestiture plan.

title: U.S. AND POLAND SET GRAIN PACT
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 29 (UPI)The United States and Poland agreed in principle today on a longterm grain trade pact.

title: Beame Fighting 2 Council Bills That Would Curb Police Spying
description: Two City Council hills requiring a court order to place undercover police agents in groups or organizations or to employ electronic and photographic surveillance is noncriminal investigations were strongly attacked yesterday by the Police Department, the Beame administration and District Attorneys.

title: Heil Hitler Disrupts Rites for Jew Slain in Holdup
description: A funeral procession for an Orthodox Jew slain during a holdup on the Sabbath apparently because he was carrying no money was disrupted yesterday morning by schoolchildren and bystanders who shouted Heil Hitler and Hitler was right.

title: BYRNE ASKS STUDY OF CARTER CASE
description: Governor Byrne yesterday asked the chairman of the New Jersey Assembly Judiciary Committee to review the triplemurder convictions of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis and to recommend whether pardons should be granted.

title: Hudson Review Sets Up $12,500 Literary Award
description: A new literary prize, the Bennett Award, worth $12,500 and to he given biennially, has been established by The Hudson Review, a literary quarterly. The award is named after Joseph D. Bennett, a founding member of the publication and a longtime editor, who died in Australia in 1972 at the age of 50.

title: DOLLAR AND GOLD GAIN; POUND FALLS
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 29 (UPI)The dollar closed higher on European money markets today, strengthened by the general view among hankers that the United States economy can easily absorb the 10 per cent. increase in the price of nil decreed by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Paean to Simpson: Everything Back
description: Let us appreciate him while he is here. He is so special, this O. J. Simpson, and his occupation, running back in the National Football League, so precarious. As to style, Simpson is, on the one hand, a cutter. That is a trade label for a running back who pushes off hard on one leg or the other to change direction, minimize the, and gain yards. Simson also is, in pro football language, a strider, a junker, a stutterstepper. O. J. is everything, including, pleasant and intelligent.

title: Emil Gorovets Projects Warmth And Flair in Official Song Debut
description: Never underestimate the power of the ethnic press. On the basis of reports in the Russian and Yiddish newspapers, Emil Gorovets sold out Town Hall well in advance of his concert on Sunday. The Ukrainianborn singer apparently was one of the Soviet Union's most famous pop entertainers until his decision to emigrate to Israel several years ago. Mr. Gorovets moved to the United States this year and, although he has sung at various functions here, this program was announced as his official American debut.

title: Kansas City. Kan., Police Begin FullScale Strike
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., Sept. 29 (UPI)The Fraternal Order of Police reversed a decision to call off a sickin action and began late today the first fullscale policemen's strike in the city's history.

title: Happy Jets Doff Helmet To Blockers
description: Happy Jets Doff Helmet To Blockers

title: School Aid Signed, Despite Fund Lack
description: TRENTON, Sept. 29 (AP)Governor Byrne today signed legislation mandating a $334million increase in state aid to public education and asked the State Supreme Court to accept the new law without the guarantee of financing to pay for it.

title: cord & Taylor Seen Switching Officers
description: A week after the Associated Dry Goods Corporation announced a succession in its top management, the departmentstore chain has moved to shake up Lord & Taylor, its largest and formerly its most profitable division, according to reliable sources.

title: Fiber Meadows
description: Winter fields and autumn wheat, the first snow, streams, mountains, the wind, the nightthese are the auras that Lewis Knauss creates.

title: Coors TVN to End News Film Service To Stations Oct. 31
description: TVN, Inc., which has billed itself as an independent television news network since it began operating in May, 1973, said yesterday it would all but go out of business Oct. 31.

title: COLLEAGUES ATTEND RITES FOR CONSIDINE
description: St. Patrick's Cathedral was filled to near capacity yesterday for a funeral mass for Bob Considine, journalist for more than 40 years, who died Thursday at the age of 68 after a stroke.

title: Anker Plans to Fight U.S. Cut In Fund for School Lunches Here
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker plans to challenge an effort by the United States Department of Agriculture to disallow $7.3million in Federal funds for the school lunch program here.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 250,000 common shares of the Southern Connecticut Gas Company, at $18.50 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation.

title: General Motors Is Said to Plan Truck Manufacture in Poland
description: WARSAW, Sept. 29The General Motors Corporation intends to manufacture trucks in Poland for sale throughout the world, including the United States, according to commercial informants.

title: MARSHALL AND I.B.M. SETTLE TRUST SUIT
description: Marshall Industries, a distributor of electronic components, and the International Business Machines Corporation, announced yesterday a settlement of an antitrust lawsuit brought by Marshall against I.B.M.

title: Facts in Musicians' Strike
description: Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. I. Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.

title: BYRNE ASKS STUDY OF CARTER CASE
description: Governor Byrne yesterday asked the chairman of the New Jersey Assembly Judiciary Committee to review the triplemurder convictions of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis and to recommend whether pardons should be granted.

title: OilPrice Rise Dismays Japan; Miki Calls Cabinet Into Session
description: TOKYO, Sept. 29The Japanese Government was visibly dismayed today by the 10 per cent oil price increase announced over the weekend by the Organization of Oil Producing Countries.

title: At 75, Settlement House Group Still Offers a Firm Hand to Poor
description: It was at the University Settlement House on the Lower East Side that Abe Beame met his Mary, the young Jacob Javits learned to take a bath, Walter Matthau got a start in acting and George Gershwin played the piano.

title: Safety Council Reelects 2
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (UPI)The National Safety Council reelected today Vincent Tofany as its president and Dr. Dewey F. Barich as its chairman of the board at the council's 63d annual National Safety Congress and Exposition.

title: JOHN M. OLIVER
description: John M. Oliver, a teacher of French at the Horace Mann School from 1929 to 1968, died Sunday at his home, 600 West 239th Street, the Bronx. He was 77 years old.

title: Safeway Stores Raises Net 43%; Other Companies Issue Reports
Political Balance Tilts in Lisbon
description: LISBON, Sept. 29The balance has tilted again in the struggle for the eventual control and mold of Portugal. NonCommunist forces dominate the government and military leadership. It is the far left that is taking to the streets in an effort to stem and possibly reverse the tide again. The far left is receding and, in the process, regrouping after a certain amount of fragmentation when victory seems within reach. But no one in Portugal, far left, centrist or right, thinks stability has been achieved.

title: Giants Heavily Criticized
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 29The Giant coaches, wondering where they had gone wrong, remained behind closed doors for hours today watching films of the Washington debacle that was supposed to be a football game.

title: 5 to 6% Rise Slated In Price of Steel
description: Steel prices are scheduled to rise tomorrow by roughly 5 to 6 per cent, with industry officials expressing confidence that the higher prices will hold.

title: LISBON OCCUPIES RADIOTV STUDIOS HELD BY LEFTISTS
description: LISBON, Tuesday, Sept. 30 Portugal's Premier ordered troops yesterday to occupy leftistcontrolled radio and television stations to halt a provocative campaign of seditious attitudes against the Government. But some soldiers sided with the broadcasters.

title: 19 TransAtlantic Airlines Are Fined in FareCutting
description: Nineteen of the world's largest airlinesall but four the major transAtlantic carriers serving New Yorkpleaded no contest here yesterday to criminal charges of illegal farecutting and were fined a total of $655,000 in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Essex Jail Warden Indicted on Charges Of Selling Narcotics
description: Albert T. Collier, the warden of the Essex County Jail in Newark, was one of 24 defendants charged yesterday with participation in a conspiracy to distribute substantial amounts of heroin and cocaine.

title: 2Hour Search Futile
description: DETROIT, Sept. 29 (UPI)The Michigan State Police, acting on an anonymous tip, spent two hours today digging in a site about one mile from the area where searchers spent most of the weekend seeking the reported burial site of James R. Hoffa.

title: With OilWell Drilling Increasing, the Mud Business Is Booming
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 29Mud is big business. Some people put walnut shells in it. Others mix it with ground corn cobs and old bread wrappers. Italians mellow their mud with grape seeds. Algerians spike theirs with crushed olive pits.

title: Kansas Doctor Will Aid In Tests on Sara Moore
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 29 (AP) Dr. Walter Menninger, clinical director of the Topeka State Hospital, will take part in the psychiatric examination of Sara Jane Moore, who has been accused of attempting to shoot President Ford, a medical spokesman said today.

title: Thru Is Through As Chicago Tribune Ends Spelling Fight/subhead>
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (UPI)The Chicago Tribune said today that it had lost much of its campaign to simplify spelling of the American language and that thru was through.

title: WARREN R. STARR
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 29 (UPI)Warren R. Starr, president of the Hawaii Medical Service Association and an influential business and community leader, died Friday on a safari in Kenya. He was 63 years old.

title: Hoffman Bids Cities Cut Industry RealEstate Tax
description: NEWARK, Sept. 29Joseph, A. Hoffman, the State Commissioner of Labor and Industry, urged city governments today to give realestate tax abate ments to industry to regenerate ailing urban centers and attract new investment to New Jersey.

title: MANY FEARS SEEDS OF WORSE RECESSION
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 (UPI)  George Meany, A.F.L.C.I.O. president, warned today that the Administration's economic policies have sown the seeds for deeper, more serious recession in the future.

title: People and Business
description: Senator John Tunney, Democrat of California, urged yesterday that the United States require the Soviet Union to sell this country oil at less than world prices in exchange for the opportunity to buy American grain.

title: People in Sports
description: Harmon Killebrew, whose 573 home runs over 21 seasons are the most hit by a righthanded batter in the American League, has been notified that he will not be retained by the Kansas City Royals. After 20 years with the Washington senators and the Minnesota Iwins, the 39yearold Killebrew spent the last season as the designated hitter for the Royals. He hit 14 homers with a .199 batting average and knocked in 44 runs. Killebrew is not being considered to replace Frank Quilici as manager of the Minnesota Twins. I won't ever hire a manager again who doesn't have experience at managing and Harmon hasn't managed, said Calvin Griffith, Twins' president.

title: SOVIET TO EXTEND NEWSMEN'S VISAS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29The Soviet Government has agreed to ease exit and entry rules for American correspondents residing in Moscow, the United States Embassy announced today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1975

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Erratic 'Elektreia' Retells Legend
description: Miklos Jancso's version of the legend of Electra opens in the fog, sets out in all directions at once and never does find itself again."Elektreia"the Hungarian title is "Szerelmem, Electra," which means "Electra, My Love," and better reflects its pastry-tray characteropens at Lincoln Center this evening, the seventh offering of the New York Film Festival."Elektreia" is played in a mixture of ballet, song and dialogue. Visually, it is erratic, with moments of great force and others of considerable silliness. Dramatically, it is weightless. Politically, it is schizophrenic. The libertarian points made in the first hour, when the Electra legend is retold, are lopped off in a mushy 15-minute coda that has the effect of an ideological sales tax.With a muddy plain, and horsemen wheeling and maneuvering in the background, Mr. Jancso produces a stripped-down "Electra," in the sense that there is virtually no scenery besides the plain itself and a brick barn, and virtually no props. Also in the sense that many of the figures who mime the chorus wear no clothes.Electra, played with windblown fierceness but not much effect by Mari Torocsik, is held in unwilling subjection by Aegisthus, who has killed her father, Agamemnon. She strides about reproaching Aegisthus for his bloody rule and warning him that her brother, Orestes, will come and kill him.Aegisthus, whose portrayal by Jozsef Madaras is the one dramatic strength of the film, speaks of the need of rulers to be harsh, asserts that people live better under fear and blames Agamemnon for confusing his subjects by giving them freedom.Perhaps the boldest bit of political satire, in a film made under Hungarian state auspices, comes in the scene of a feast day when Aegisthus's subjects, normally herded about by black-garbed men with whips, are entitled to speak freely."My wife bore me three sons this year," one man says."Money was worth twice as much "this year," says another."This year I had good dream," says a third.Mr. Jancso brings tragic tension to several confrontation scenes: the first between the prisoner Electra and the tyrant Aegisthus; the second between Orestes and the tyrant he has overthrown. In each case the dialogue proceeds while the weaker person advances instead of retreating, and the stronger one retreats instead of advancing. It is a bold reversal, and works brilliantly.Orestes shoots Aegisthus with a pistol, and he and Electra walk off. It would be kind to suppose that Mr. Jansco has walked off too. In any event, somebody left the camera running for another quarter of an hour.Orestes and Electra shoot each other, fall dead, get up again, climb into a red helicopter. This hovers overhead while a voice tells about a firebird that gives the working classes strength and hope. The movie peters on out with masses of people dancing and the voice droning such phrases as: "Tomorrow is a new day," "A new world starts at last" and "Perhaps this, our great creed, shall someday be realized."It is as if somebody had poured a great deal of water into a small and never very robust soup.

title: Socialist Asks Protection
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)Peter Camejo, the Socialist Worker party's Presidential candidate, asked today that Secret Service protection he provided for all Presidential candidates.

title: 200 Cartoons at Animation Fete
description: The Third Animation Film Festival begins today, providing New Yorkers with a rare chance to see what used to he common movie fare: some 200 cartoons.

title: House Supports Extension
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)The House passed today legislation allowing day care centers another six months to meet staffing requirements without loss of Federal aid.

title: CONVOY IS EXPECTED IN PRUDHOE BAY SOON
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29The AtlanticRichfield Company said today that a longdelayed convoy of barges bound for Alaska's Arctic oil fields was continuing to make progress through icecovered seas and said it was expected to reach its destination at Prudhoe Bay tomorrow.

title: Islanders Set Back Flames
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 29 Bad words and good goaltending enlivened an exhibition tonight in which the Islanders defeated the Atlanta Flames, the team that New York nosed out of a berth in last season's Stanley Cup playoffs, by a 51 score before a crowd of 10,747 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Water Fund
description: LANDER, Wyo.Antelope and other wild creatures, as well as domestic livestockand birdswill benefit from the Water for Wildlife project recently begun by the Lander OneShot Antelope Club.

title: Failure in Harlem
description: In the wake of collapse of the MillbankFrawley lowincome housing project in Harlem, there are a lot of tired fingers all over town. People uptown, in City Hall and in the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development are all energetically pointing at one another in an effort to assess and avoid the blame for failure. And quite a failure it was.

title: Cordero Victor In Westbury Sulky
description: WESTBURY, L. L. Sept. 29 Confessing he wasn't sure where the finish line was, Angelo Cordero Jr.. one of America's premier thoroughbred riders rallied threewide in the stretch in the Jockey Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: Ecology Bill for Building Is Approved by Assembly
description: TRENTON, Sept. 29The Assembly gave final approval today to a measure that requires the Sate Department of Environmental Protection to approve construction permits within 90 days of their submission.

title: Bridge
description: The customary advice given to a player who thinks his contract is safe is to take a second look and try to discover what might go wrong. Sometimes one has to look very hard indeed.

title: Ford, Sigining Oil Control Bill, Asserts People May Spur Congress on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29President Ford declared today that it may take an aroused citizenry to persuade Congress to adopt a comprehensive national energy policy.

title: Layoff Set by Paper Strike
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 29 (AP)A strike by 376 paperworkers at a newsprint mill in Kenogami, Quebec, has resulted in the layoff of more than 1,700 other employes of the Price Company, Ltd., a company spokesman said. More than 20,000 members of the Canadian Paperworkers' Union have gone on strike idling about half of Canada's newsprint production.

title: Books of The Times
description: What is a classic? This was a question T. S. Eliot posed in the title of a paper he presented to England's Virgil Society in 1944. And it is the question dilated upon by Frank Kermode, critic, editor and King Edward VII Professor of Literature at Cambridge University, when in 1973 he delivered the T. S. Eliot Memorial Lectures at the University of Kent. But what can all the talk have been about, one wonders upon picking up the published version of Professor Kermode's lectures, The Classic: Literary Images of Permanence and Change? After all, a classic is simply a work of literature that keeps getting read generation after generation, isn't it? Or rather, to put a slightly finer point on it: A classic is a book that authorities make young people read because it thought to be good for them. Or it is a book that young people keep rediscovering because it actually appeals to them. Generation after generation. I mean, Caesar's Gallic Wars is a classic. So, in a limited sense, is The Catcher in the Rye.

title: Chains' August Sales Up 8.1%; Gain Is Second Highest of Year
description: Chain store sales in August rose by 5.1 per cent over the level of August 1974, according to a compilation of Chain Store Age magazine. The August gain was the highest since last May and the second highest of the year. It compared with a gain of 7.7 per cent in July and 7.9 per cent in June.

title: Contract Awards
description: The FMC Corporation received a $104million Navy contract for Mark 25 guidedmissile launching systems.

title: Buffalo Aide Gets State Post
description: ALBANY, Sept. 29 (UPI)John F, Downing, Deputy May or of Buffalo. was named today assistant commissioner for operations in the State Department of Transportation.

title: Thinking Things Over
description: The Sticking Point

title: Greystone's Appeal Over Accreditation Denied by Council
description: TRENTON, Sept. 29 (AP)The state disclosed today that it had lost a bid for restoration of the accreditation of Greystone Park Hospital, the largest state psychiatric care facility.

title: $14MILLION TO AID RURAL PHYSICIANS
description: The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation announced yesterday the establishment of a $14million national project designed to help overcome a severe shortage of physicians in many rural areas.

title: U.S. Aids Angola Airlift
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (Reuters)  American commercial jets have airlifted more than 9,000 refugees from strifetorn Angola to Portugal since Sept. 7, the Air Force's Military Airlift Command announced today.

title: $200,000 in Rare Coins Stolen at Drake Hotel
description: Rare coins valued at $200,000 and jewelry worth an estimated $6,000, were reported stolen last night from the apartment of a resident of the Drake Hotel, at 440 Park Avenue near East 58th Street, according to the police.

title: Carey Puts Teachers' Pact In Doubt Because of Cost
description: A preliminary analysis of the twoweekold teacher contract here indicates that it could cost the city $140million this school yearas much as $80million more than had been budgeted, for a teachers' settlement, Governor Carey said yesterday.

title: A SENATOR WARNS OF SINAI IMPASSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The Ford Administration's efforts to speed Congressional approval for the stationing of 200 Americans in the Sinai passes ran into a new roadblock today that threatened to cause further delays.

title: Oklahoma City Revives Downtown Section With Underground Plaza After Years of Growing Outward
description: OKLAHOMA CITY,  Residents of this conservative, rather prim old boom town are only joking these days when they say Oklahoma is a great place for going underground.

title: 30 Killed and 100 Are Hurt In Train Crash in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 (AP)At least 30 persons were killed and 100 injured tonight in the collision of two passenger trains 30 miles north of Buenos Aires, according to police reports. Many of the injured were reported to be in critical condition.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Members of Local 371 of the Social Services Employes Union staged a sitin at the offices of the city's Addiction Services Agency Commissioner, Jerome Hornblass, charging that political considerations were behind the dismissal of 35 employes last week. They also protested alleged attempts to force workers to write letters in support of the Commissioner and the agency. Agency officials denied the charges and said that the dismissals, resulting from the withdrawal of a Fedora grant, had been made according to Civil Service guide. lines.

title: Moose Solters Dies at 69; American League Outfielder
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 Julius (Moose) Solters an American League outfielder from 1934 to 1943, died yesterday in Mercy Hospital. He was 69 years old.
