title: E.E.C. Unemployment Rise Slows in Several Countries
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 29 (Reuters) Unemployment in the European Economic Community is rising but the rate of increase is slowing in some countries, E.E.C. Commission statistics showed today.

title: AntiForeign Protest Called
description: MADRID, Tuesday, Sept. 30 (Agence FrancePresse)Spanish authorities last night asked the people of Madrid to turn out en masse tomorrow to demonstrate indignation at foreign protests over the execution of five revolutionaries last Saturday.

title: DOUGLAS PRESENT AS COURT RETURNS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas joined the Court's eight other Justices today for the first working conference of the 19751976 Court term, apparently determined to continue on the bench despite possible health problems caused by his stroke last winter.

title: F.T.C. Pact Set on Selling Pasco Oil Units to Amoco
description: An agreement with the staff of the Federal Trade Commission has been signed settling cerain antitrust issues that the staff had raised about the proposed sale by Pasco, Inc., of crude oil producing properties to Amoco, it was announced yesterday by Pasco.

title: Hirohito Leaves on U.S. Trip Amid Tight Security
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 30Amid heavy security measures, Emperor Hirohito left today on a jet airliner for his first state visit to the United States.

title: Shell Oil Freezes Rents It Charges Independents
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 29The Shell Oil Company will maintain for one year, starting Wednesday, rentals charged to its independent dealers throughout the country, a company official said today.

title: U.S. Sees Internal Matter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The White House today described the executions in Spain as an internal matter for the Madrid Government and said they would have no effect on the negotiations for a new agreement on United States military bases in Spain, which were reported to be close to conclusion.

title: Teachers Union Is Cited For Parsippany Strike
description: MORRISTOWN, Sept. 29The ParsippanyTroy Hills Education Association and its executives wert charged with criminal contempt of court by a Superior Court judge here today after all but 40 of Parsippany's 650 teachers defied a permanent injunction and struck for a ninth day in a salary dispute.

title: The Persian Mind
description: TEHERANIn no major country of the contemporary world can Louis XIV's famous aphorismL'tat, c'est moibe applied with more accuracy than in Iran. As he gravely acknowledge, His Imperial Majesty the Shahanshah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi is indeed the personification of the state. Short in stature, conservative in dress, reserved in demeanor, the Shah of Iran, receiving a foreign guest in the Frenchstyle drawing room of his relatively modest palace on the edge of Teheran, insists that his style of autocratic kingship authentically reflects the Persian mind as it has existed for 2,500 yearsand that it perfectly suits today his 35 million subjects as they hurtle forward on a flood of oil into the economic, social and political maelstrom of the modern age.

title: Congress Asked to Allow Up to 10Year Terms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The Treasury asked Congress today for unlimited authority to sell securities with maturities of up to 10 years as part of its emerging strategy of managing the massive borrowing required by this year's and next year's budget deficits.

title: LISBON OCCUPIES RADIOTV STUDIOS HELD BY LEFTISTS
description: LISBON, Tuesday, Sept. 30 Portugal's Premier ordered troops yesterday to occupy leftistcontrolled radio and television stations to halt a provocative campaign of seditious attitudes against the Government. But some soldiers sided with the broadcasters.

title: At 75, Settlement House Group Still Offers a Firm Hand to Poor
description: It was at the University Settlement House on the Lower East Side that Abe Beame met his Mary, the young Jacob Javits learned to take a bath, Walter Matthau got a start in acting and George Gershwin played the piano.

title: ROBY HARRINGTON JR.
description: Roby Harrington Jr., who retired in 1970 as vice president, and director of Johnson & Higgins, international insurance brokers, died Sunday at his home in Tryon, N.C. Be was 69 years old.

title: Prices Pull Back a Bit on Deficit Forecast
Doctors Ponder Way to Shatter Fatal Illusions of Immortality
description: Since hopes of eternity spring eternal, the American Health Foundation held a symposium here yesterday on The Illusion of ImmortalityA Dilemma of Disease Prevention.

title: Secret Service Guards Offered To Six Democratic Candidates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Democratic Presidential candidates who collected more than $100,000 in campaign contributions during the first half of 1975 are going to be offered Secret Service protection this week.

title: 65 FREED BY PEKING TO ASK TAIWAN VISA
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 29Sixtyfive of the 144 Chinese Nationalist agents released by Peking week ago have received permission to leave China in an attempt to return to Taiwan. Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency, announced today.

title: 2 Inspections Find Health Violations In N.Y. Yacht Club
description: The New York Yacht Club. the home of the America's Cup and the scene of elegant dinners, was among II food establishments cited by the city's Health Department yesterday for failing to correct health violations.

title: President Will Avoid Big Planned Gatherings
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 29 (UPI)President Ford will avoid planned large gatherings where crowds cannot be screened and will go more for impromptu meetings in which audiences can be watched more closely, his campaign manager said today.

title: Accord Endangered
description: A dangerous delay has crept into the process of Congressional endorsement of the IsraeliEgyptian agreement. The suspicion has been growing on Capitol Hill that Secretary of State Kissinger may be less than candid in revealing the extent of future commitments which the United States would be undertaking. But such suspicions, whether or not justified, should not be allowed to inhibit the carefully circumscribed Congressional approval of an American civilian crew of technicians to man the early warning systems of the Sinai.

title: Ashe Defeats Vilas in Final
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 Starting with a blitz but finally winning a tense struggle, Arthur Ashe defeated Guillermo Vilas tonight, 60, 76, and won the $100,000 Fireman's Fund International, the last major American tennis tournament of the year.

title: SOYBEANS, CORN AND WHEAT DROP
description: The selling of grains, especially corn, to local grain elevators by farmers acted as a price depressant to futures trading yesterday on tht Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Japan's Unpretentious Emperor
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 30 Thirty years ago this month, Emperor Hirohito called on General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, the Supreme Commander of the Allied occupation forces, to tell him: I come to you, General MacArthur, to offer myself to the judgment of the powers you represent as the one to bear sole responsibility for every political and military decision made and action taken by my people in the conduct of the war.

title: Plane With 60 Plunges Into Sea Near Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, Sept. 30 (Reuters)A Hungarian airliner carrying more than 60 people plunged into the sea as it approached Beirut early today, and there were believed to be no survivors, sources at the airport here said.

title: EDMUND WHITING
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Sept. 29 (AP)  Edmund Whiting, a sculptor who was head of the art department at Franklin and Marshall College, died yesterday at Lancaster General Hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: PRICES ARE DOWN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market dropped yesterday in light volume. Traders found little news that could be construed as bullish.

title: Stage: Finn MacKool Opens at de Lys
description: Some plays are curious, some plays are add and some plays are just downright strange. Frank Hogan's play Finn MacKool The Grand Distraction, which opened last night at the Theater de Lys, seemed to be a mixture of all three. It was also one of those plays where you might casually wonder what the playwright was trying to do to your mind, and why? Why indeed?

title: BRICKLIN CANADA TO FILE CHAPTER XI
description: DETROIT, Sept. 29 (AP)The founder of Bricklin Canada, Ltd., makers of the $10,000 sports car hearing the Bricklin name, said the concern would file this week for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PERCUSSION WITH STRINGS Two musicians who are unquestioned masters of jazz improvisation, playing their instruments with case and grace, are the pianist Oscar Peterson and the guitarist Joe Pass.

title: CONGRESS'S BLACKS SILENT ON CITY AID
description: The Congressional Black Caucus, which normally might be expected to be aggressive in its support of New York City's quest for Federal help during its fiscal crisis, has remained silent on the issueto the dismay of black officials and others in New York.

title: Advertising
description: Perhaps the most frequent complaint against advertising is that it is manipulativethat it makes people buy what they don't need or want. How many books or articles with that sort of twist have there been since The Hidden Persuaders was written by Vance Packard?

title: Jefferson Beats Lincoln by 246
description: Jefferson began its defense of the Public Schools Athletic League football title yesterday with a surprisingly easy 246 victory over Lincoln at Jefferson's field. Gary Johnson and Fernando Perez paced the Jeffs' ground attack, which scored 18 points in the fourth quarter. In another Division I game Canarsie tied New Utrecht, 1414, when Dave Wiltshire ran 27 yards for a touchdown with 2 minutes to play. Canarsie missed two chances to win. In Queens, Bayside ruined Adams's first game at its new field when it scored a touchdown early in the third period for 83 victory.

title: New Jersey Brief
description: Despite an earlier directive from Attorney General William F. Hyland designed to do away with it, the New Jersey state police are still following a quota system in issuing traffic summonses, according to Thomas lskrzycki, president of the State Troopers Fraternal Association. With the number of summonses issued reported at a new high, two state troopers, Kenneth Parker and James Boylan, have filed a grievance over the procedure, Mr. Iskrzycki said, adding that both men have outstanding records.

title: MUSICIANS' TALKS DEADLOCKED HERE
description: An 18hour bargaining session aimed at ending the musicians' strike that has shut down 12 Broadway musical productions ended yesterday morning at Gracie Mansion with a union statement that we are even further apart than ever.

title: THOUSANDS STRIKE IN BASQUE REGION
description: ZARAUZ, Spain, Sept. 29Tens of thousands of Basques went on strike in northern Spain today in protest against the execution Saturday of Basque separatists convicted of killing policemen.

title: Walter Dunbar, Probation Chief Who Gave Data on Attica, Dead
description: Walter Dunbar, State Probation Director and former executive deputy commissioner of the state Department of Correctional Services, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in the Albany suburb of Guilderland. He was 60 years old.

title: U.N. Panel Accredits Israel, With Libya Protesting
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29The Credentials Committee today accredited the delegation of Israel, together with representatives of most other members of the 141country General Assembly. Libya registered strongest reservations on the acceptance of Israel and hinted at possible further steps.

title: UDALL WILL ENTER STATE'S PRIMARY
description: Representative Morris K. Udall announced yesterday that he would enter the New York Democratic Presidential primary, which he said would make or break Presidential candidates because it was one of the first major primaries next year.

title: U.S. Formally Orders Tolls On Bridges to Manhattan
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency issued formal orders yesterday to require the city and state to establish tolls by mid1977 on all bridges across the East and Harlem Rivers. Mayor Beame responded by initiating court action to invalidate the longexpected directives.

title: A FACTION IN TIMOR ASKS JAKARTA'S AID
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 29 (Reuters)The Democratic Union of Timor, which has been fighting leftists for control of Portuguese Timor, has called on Indonesia to intervene militarily to end the crisis, official sources said here today.

title: Strictly Chicken, Island Variety
description: MANILA, Sept. 29Paranaque is a teeming neighborhood on the southern edge of Manila, a cluttered, untidy area which, by Philippine standards, stops short of squalor. Picture the South Bronx melted down in equatorial heat to onestory shops with jerrybuilt shacks of driftwood and scrap lumber on the roofs and in the back yards. Up an alley from one of the busiest streets, cars were parked every which way alongside a low, unpainted building with a rusted iron roof. It was early afternoon, but roosters were crowing in a raucous chorus that suggested sunrise on, a poultry farm, or maybe a press conference in Muhammad Ali's dressing room. This was an ordinary Sunday the Paranaque cockpit. On an ordinary Sunday, gamecocks start slashing each other with murderous steel spurs at 7 A.M. and keep it up until 8 P.M.

title: Plane Tickets for Hawaii's 10,000Mile Football Trip to Rutgers: $32,500
description: The University of Hawaii will make a 10,000mile round trip this week to play Rutgers in football at New Brunswick, N. J., Saturday afternoon. This is the second half of a hometohome arrangement with the Scarlet Knights. who went to Honolulu in December of 1974 and lost. 2816. D. Edward Chid, Hawaii's acting director of athletics, said yesterday that transportation costs would be about $500 per person. With about 65 players, coaches and other university personnel making the trip, it will cost Hawaii approximately

title: I.R.S. Commissioner Says Employes Who Object to Policy Try to Ruin Him
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Donald C. Alexander, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said today that he was the victim of a concerted effort by some former and a few present I.R.S. employes to discredit him because they did not agree with his policies.

title: General Motors Is Said to Plan Truck Manufacture in Poland
description: WARSAW, Sept. 29The General Motors Corporation intends to manufacture trucks in Communist Poland for sale throughout the world, including the United States, according to commercial informants.

title: Notes on People
description: The controversial, researchoriented Federal prison to open in January at Butner. N. ?? will be headed by Donald A. Deppe, a former University of Maryland professor who has been educational director of the Bureau of Prisons since 1973.

title: Chess
Copies of Paris Fashions Walk Out at Brisk Pace at Fall Show
description: On the surface, it was the same show of European couture copies that's been opening, spring and fall, at Ohrbach's for 25 years. Lookalike mannequins strolled down the runway two by two, one in a Paris fashion, the other in a New York copy.

title: Church May Be Named A National Historic Site
description: In 1733, a 26yearold immigrant German printer named John Peter Zenger became the focus of a freepress trial when he published an account of how the Royal Governor of New York had tried to rig an election held at the St. Paul's Church village green, then in the Town of Eastchester.

title: Caribous Win Crown
Briton Is Killed on Everest But Teammate Reaches Top
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Sept. 29 (AP)A British expedition conquered Mount Everest for the second time in three days last Friday, but one of the members of the assault team was killed before reaching the 29,028footsummit, the Nepalese Foreign Ministry said today.

title: New Rangers Top Flyers, 53, Here
description: Like a shy young dance partner, the Rangers are learning how to take a lead and hold it. After letting the Philadelphia Flyers catch up last night at Madison Square Garden, New York scored two goals in the final period and waltzed off with a 53 triumph.

title: Nielsen Finds Nonwhite Homes Spending 16% More Time at TV
description: In a special analysis of its national ratings, the A.C. Nielsen Company has found that nonwhite households spend 16 per cent more time watching television than households in general and that they average more viewers per home than white households.

title: Chile Peso Replaces Escudo
description: SANTIAGO, Chile. Sept. 29A new currency, the peso, went into circulation here today, the Chilean Central Bank said today. It replaces the escudo. whose value had been eroded by inflation. The peso is worth 1,000 escudos, or about 15 United States cents, the, bank added.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dropped line in the review of the film Every Man for Himself and God Against All in The New York Times on Sunday resulted in one actor's receiving praise meant for another. The praise was intended for Walter Ladengast, who played the role of a professor.

title: Girl, 11, Allowed On Football Team
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 29 (UPI) An 11yearold girl's sex discrimination suit against the Chester Rebels football team was dropped today after the team and its hackers said she could once again take the place she earned in the backfield.

title: New York and Oil Are It
description: It looks as if the Republicans are going to run against New York next year and the Democrats are going to run against oil.

title: BOYCOTT OF SPAIN URGED BY MEXICO
description: MEXICO CITY, (AP)President Luis Echeverria Alvarez has urged that the United Nations impose a political, diplomatic, economic and communications boycott on Spain in retaliation for the execution of five antiGovernment guerrillas.

title: Shows Closed
description: The shows closed by the strike of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians:

title: Ferdinand Jicinsky, 80, Dead; Banker Aided '48 Czech Exiles
description: Ferdinand Jicinsky, a retired banker and former European director of the American Fund for Czechoslovak Refugees, died Sunday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived at 200 Garth Road, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Carey Puts Teachers' Pact In Doubt Because of Cost
description: A preliminary analysis of the twoweekold teacher contract here indicates that it could cost the city $140million this school yearas much as $80million more than had been budgeted, for a teachers' settlement, Governor Carey said yesterday.

title: Hearst Evidence Search Yields Lists of Banks and Executives
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29Lists of business executives in this area, and lists of banks, sonic illustrated with floor plans, were found in the apartments of Patricia Hearst and her companions when they were taken by surprise and arrested Sept. 18. official court records showed today.

title: Treasury Bills Rise At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: FORD'S SELECTION ON S.E.C IS TOLD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29President Ford intends to name Roderick M. Hills now a counsel to the President, as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, White House officials said today. The announcement will be made soon, perhaps tomorrow.

title: Philippine Navy Forces Rebels To Yield Ship and 29 Hostages
description: ZAMBOANGA, the Philippines, Sept. 29 (UPI)A Philippine admiral forced some 40 Moslem pirates today to surrender unconditionally and release a Japanese freighter and 29 hostages they seized Friday.

title: Harrises See Brainwash In Miss Hearst's Affidavit
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 (UPI)Emily and William Harris acknowledged today that Patricia Hearst seemed to be. abandoning them in the affidavit that she signed last Tuesday, but they contended that she was being manipulated and brainwashed by her family's lawyers.

title: Transit Unit Reelects Ronan
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, was reelected chairman of the American Public Transit Assoelation at the association's annual meeting in New Orleans yesterday. Members or the transit association represent more than 300 rapidrail and motorbus transit systems in North America.

title: JOSEPH LIFF DIES; STATE JUSTICE, 68
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 29 State Supreme Court Justice Joseph Liff died here last night, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 14 Deer Park Lane. He was 68 years old.

title: In Line for S.E.C.
description: President Ford intends to name Roderick M. Hills chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, White House officials disclosed. Mr. Hills, now a counsel to the President, is the husband of Carla A. Hills, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Page 51.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (Reuters)Manufacturers expect their inventories to decline about $1.9billion, in both the third and fourth quarters of the current year, the Commerce Department said in its latest survey issued today. It said in July, when it conducted a survey, durable goods producers expected their inventories to decline $1billion in the third quarter and $1.8billion in the fourth. Nondurablegoods producers expected their inventories to fall $800million in the third quarter and $100million in the fourth, according to the survey.

title: U.S. BEGINS DEBATE ON FUEL SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The Administration and Congress began debating today the extent to which the Government should risk the taxpayers' money in encouraging private companies to build and operate synthetic fuels plants.

title: Five ExSchenley Employes File Suit to Regain Pensions
description: Five former employes of Schenley Industries, Inc., filed a lawsuit yesterday to regain pensions denied them because they went to work for a rival liquor company, the American Distilling Company, United Press Internation reports.

title: The Epidemic of Assassins
description: So far President Ford has been a lucky man. We can only hope this will hold, for despite the best efforts of his protectors luck will inevitably play a major part when some warped mind turns to assassination.

title: EFFECT UNCERTAIN IN OILPRICE RISE
description: The exact effect on consummers in the Unites States of the 10 per cent price increase by the Organization of Petroeum Exporting Countries remained unknown yesterday, awaiting additional details from OPEC as well as possible actions by the Ford Administralien

title: Article 2  No Title
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 29Ice packs were taped to some very big Jets' feet this morning. But the New Yorkers' most famous knee, the right one belonging to Joe Namath, was not being treated.

title: N.F.L. Players Appeal To Congress for Action
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)The National Football League Players Association brought their labor dispute with the owners to Capitol Hill today and received a somewhat sympathetic through noncommittal reception from the House LaborManagement Relations subcommittee.

title: YONKERS TEACHERS WIN TWO RULINGS
description: YONKERS, Sept. 29  Two separate decisions have ruled it favor of the Yonkers Federation of Teachers in its attempt to force the Board of Educa tion to meet contractual obligations.

title: Shows Open
description: Shows that are not affected by the strike:

title: Rejection in New Bedford
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 29 (AP)Striking New Bedford teachers rejected a newcontract offer tonight, a spokesman for the Massachusetts Teachers Association said.

title: GISCARD CONFERS WITH SCHLESINGER
description: PARIS, Sept. 29Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger met today with President Valry Giscard d'Estaing and French defense officials in a visit American officials hope will remove some of the abrasiveness in military relations between the United States and France.

title: Sadat Visit to Begin Oct. 27
description: CAIRO, Tuesday, Sept. 30 (AP)President Anwar elSadat will pay a state visit to the United States Oct. 27Nov. 6, the semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram reported today.

title: In Line for S.E.C.
description: President Ford intends to name Roderick M. Hills chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, White House officials disclosed. Mr. Hills, now a counsel to the President, is the husband of Carla A. Hills, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Page 51.

title: Gunmen in London Free 2d Hostage From Restaurant
description: LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP) Three gunmen, holed up for more than 40 hours in a 10by12foot basement storeroom of a restaurant, freed a second of their eight hostages tonight for health reasons, the police said.

title: A Ship Sails Directly From Egypt to Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 29 (Reuters)The first ship to sail directly from Egypt to Israel since the founding of Israel in 1948 arrived today in the southern port of Ashdod.

title: White Plains Troupe Gets 4 Festival Prizes
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 29The Fort Hill Players of White Plains, an amateur theatrical group, won four major awards and nearly took the top prize yesterday at the Light Opera Festival in Waterford, Ireland.

title: Theater: Shingyo Follows Death of Soul in Space
Rep. Harrington a Frustrated Bystander in House C.I.A. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29A frustrated bystander in the struggle between the White House and the House Select Committee on Intelligence over Congressional access to intelligence information is Representative Michael J. Harrington.

title: House Votes Fiscal Curb on Mail Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)The House voted tentatively today to return to Congress miscal control over the United States Postal Service. The sponsor of the amendment said that the chance of final enactment was only 4060.

title: 18 Arrested in Vientiane Protest Against Pathet Lao
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Tuesday, Sept. 30Eighteen opponents of the Communist led Pathet Lao were arrested last night after conducting the first protest demonstration since the Pathet Lao seized power from the old coalition Government last spring.

title: Casey Stengel, Yankee and Met Manager, Dies at 85
description: GLENDALE, Calif., Sept. 29Casey Stengel, who won a niche in baseball's Hall of Fame by managing the New York Yankees to unsurpassed triumphs and the New York Mets to amazingly popular losses, died late tonight

title: In Memoriam
description: FEIGINDanny. Departed Sept. 30, 1968 We miss you more and more each passing year. You are always in our hearts. Mom and Dad

title: ROCKEFELLER TO RUN FORUMS IN SIX CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)  President Ford announced today that he was sending Vice President Rockefeller and other top officials to six cities from coast to coast to hold public forums on domestic policy.

title: People of Beirut Venture Out And Take a Look at the Ruins
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. Sept. 29After two weeks of factional fighting that left 300 people dead and caused widespread destruction, city dwellers ventured into the streets of Beirut today.

title: GORDON HARROWER
description: Gordon Harrower, a retired textile executive, died of a heart attack on Sunday on a visit to London. He was 84 years old and lived at 770 Park Avenue.

title: CloseUp on Welfare
description: This is the night of all nights to stay home and watch TV. For two hours and 47 minutes the Public Broadcasting Service will televise nationally a documentary by the immensely gifted Frederick Wiseman based on real life scenes at a Manhattan welfare center, apparently in the winter of 1974. The program Welfare is the most powerful and discomfiting took at the welfare mess I have ever seen.

title: CentralLocal Board Rift Widens Over School Day
description: Opposition to a scheduled shortening of the school day as part of the recent teachers' strike settlement has created the most serious rift between central education authorities and the city's locally elected school boards since the start of decentralized school operations in 1970.

title: The Significance of Squeaky Fromme
description: Is Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme, the 27yearold girl who tried to assassinate President Ford, just one more youthful psychotic, whose case should be disposed of by the state's criminal psychologists, and forgotten? Or does the girl in the long, bloodred nun's robe and hood, who proudly wears the Manson mark of Cain on her brow, have some social and political significance for our culture and our system of government?

title: A Big Family Gathers to Ponder Its Fatal Hereditary Disease
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 29Nearly 100 descendants of a Portuguese sailor named Antone Joseph held a family reunion here this weekend to discuss the disease that has been killing them, their parents, brothers, sisters, aunts, uncles and cousins contimuously since the eighteenfifties.

title: PIKE PANEL SEEKS HOUSE VOTE IN BID FOR SECRET FILES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The House Select Committee on Intelligence agreed today to seek a resolution from the full House of Representatives supporting its demand for unimpeded access to classified documents and other materials that the committee has subpoenaed from William E. Colby, the Director of Central Intelligence.

title: IMMUNITY STUDIED FOR HOFFA TIPSTER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that an underworld informant who has attempted to provide clues to where they former teamsters president, James R. Hoffa, may be buried may have to be granted some immunity to be sure the body is found, if it is there.

title: COFFEE PRICES UP AT GENERAL FOODS
description: The General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising wholesale prices of its retail brands of coffee, effective immediately. The company said that wholesale prices of its ground Maxwell House brand would go up 5 cents a pound, while increases for all of its ground coffees would average 7 cents a pound.

title: CatholicSchool Teachers Here End Strike for Now
description: Lay teachers at nine Roman Catholic high schools in the city and Westchester County went back to their classrooms without a contract yesterday after a twoweek strike, but threatened to walk out again if an agreement with the New York Archdiocese was not reached soon.

title: Broncos Defeat Packers, 2313
description: DENVER, Sept. 29 (AP)Denver's opportunistic defense bottled up Green Bay's ground game and the Broncos' substitute quarterback, Steve Ramsey, directed a makeshift offense to a 23 13 victory over the Packers tonight in a National Football League came.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 29 (AP)K. S. (Bud) Adams, owner of the Houston Oilers, said today owning a National Football League team wasn't as much fun as it used to be and he was negotiating to sell all or part of the team. Adams, who has owned the Oilers since their beginning in 1960, declined to name the group seeking to buy the Oilers but added that the team would remain in Houston if sold. The franchise is estimated to be worth $18million.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Snider Bids for Job
description: Duke Snider, the former Brooklyn Dodger center fielder, yesterday was reported to have applied for the manager's job with the New York Mets. Snider is currently serving as batting coach and broadcaster for the Montreal Expos.

title: COURT VOIDS LAW ORDERING 2 FUNDS TO BUY CITY BONDS
description: A key part of the emergency state law for holding off default by the city was struck down yesterday by the state's high court, compounding the crisis and depriving the city of some of the funds it needs to survive until December.

title: Grant Loss Expands; Stock Suspended
description: The W. T. Grant Company, one of the nation's largest retail chains, said yesterday that its losses have been larger than expected in its current third quarter and that it was now operating with a negative net worth.

title: The Jealous Rival
description: One of the interesting and rather depressing aspects of transportation regulation has to do with what happens when one carrier or another comes up with something innovative. As often as not, its competitors run to the regulators like jealous rivals to complain.

title: Boston's Teachers Reach Tentative Strike Accord
description: BOSTON, Sept. 29A tentative agreement in the teachers strike here that has interfered with courtordered busing to desegregate the city's public schools was reached early this morning.

title: Engineers Will Honor Croton Water System
description: The American Society of Civil Engineers will honor the Croton water supply system as part of its program to seek out and identify historic civilengineering landmarks which represent significant contributions to the development of America.

title: 19 TransAtlantic Airlines Are Fined in FareCutting
description: Nineteen of the world's largest airlinesall but four of the major transAtlantic carriers serving New Yorkpleaded no contest here yesterday to criminal charges of illegal farecutting and were fined a total of $655,000 in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: Shanker Opposed Teachers' Strike
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29Albert Shanker, who led the teachers' strike that virtually closed New York City's schools for a week early this month, said yesterday that he had opposed the walkout but had not been in sufficient control of his union to prevent it.
